review_text: We visited this small garden in Marrakech after having visited several others in the area. It was expensive and we had a timed ticket which we bought on line the previous week and the site wouldn't let us buy tickets to the 2 museums as it said there were none left. On arrival we asked about museum tickets and they were available -lots of people buying them. The gardens them selves are in majorelle blue which is the garden's distinctive feature, however the gazebos were full of people queuing to have their photographs taken with views of the various water features. There is little underplanting of the various palms and little originality in any feature. The bamboo were fine. The over crowding is due to bus tours coming in from all of Morocco.

This is quite a nice garden on a property once owned by Yves St Laurent. Long queues to get in, but if you go down to the YSL museum and buy a combo ticket the queue is much shorter and you then get to walk straight into the gardens and Berber Museum without the wait. The Berber Museum is well worth it. There are some wonderful artifacts there and a lot of interesting historical information.  The lighting is very poor, so if you want to read the info sheets take your best reading glasses. The YSL Museum is a waste of money unless you like modern art. There are a range of YSL dresses and accessories to look at.  I’m not into that sort of thing so didn’t spend more than 10 mins there. The gardens are peaceful and a nice chance to sit away from the crowds of the Medina.   You don’t need more than an hour to do all three. Total cost on the combo ticket is 180 dirhams. I don’t think the whole gardens/museum complex is worth queueing an hour for though.  If you are short of time you won’t really be missing anything spectacular. It’s a pity it’s not just possible to see the Berber Museum by itself, as that was the best bit.

Avoid the queue by buying the combined ticket from the YSL museum (it's not a big museum you're basically paying extra to avoid the queue). The gardens were bigger than I was expecting and they're well cared for with that beautiful blue building which now houses the Berber museum (again not big but with an interesting design especially the jewellery room). Interesting place with a visit.

The garden itself is lovely and very beautiful. However be warned that the gardens are very busy and the atmosphere is ruined by a mob of tourists taking selfies and queuing for an opportunity for photos at the best spots. I would suggest arriving early and buying the combo ticket with YSL museum to save money and avoid queuing for tickets.

One definitely feels transported out of Marrakech into glorious green gardins when walking through the Jardin Majorelle, which hosts some unique looking trees, and plants. This is a nice way to spend a morning or afternoon though I do not know how much entrance cost because it was included in our tour. If the entrance fee is hefty... one might wish to reconsider unless they truly have an interest in this type of attraction. There are parks and gardens in every city and I would think a traveler might be more interested in the more unique aspects of this city especially if the price tag is heavy.  With that said... it was a lovely way to spend an hour or two.

Get here around 8:30 and it is nearly deserted otherwise it gets extremely busy. Queues to get entrance tickets get very long from about 10;00 onward and seemed slow ro clear so we gave up on our first attempt to visit. If you like gardens this is a peach.

We escaped to this oasis on a hot afternoon in June. Really liked the fact that you could get a combination ticket for the Yves Saint-Laurent museum, gardens and Berber Museum, and we spent a couple of hours exploring it all (and you could easily spend more time in the garden). Loved the water features and the walking paths. Read a bit about the history of Majorelle (and YSL and Bergé for a full appreciation). Would definitely return on future visits to Marrakech. BONTAKS TRAVELS

Not realising that we should have booked in advance before we left the UK, we followed advice to arrive at the garden early - 8.30 a.m. and found only half a dozen people in the queue ahead of us. We were able to wander in peace for an hour before the coaches arrived!  We skipped the crowded cafe (good decision) and headed to the adjacent YSL Museum at around 10.30 and with our combined tickets were able to dodge the already lengthy queue. I can honestly say the Museum blew us away! The design of the building and the way in which  the exhibition of designs, films and biography has been curated was enthralling.  We found the cafe here excellent - smart, quiet, and not as pricey as it looks. Overall, come early; Le Jardin in late February was pleasant but not outstanding (but thank goodness it was saved from the developers) -  Do not miss the YSL museum.
review_title: Lovely garden but don't miss the YSL Museum.

review_text: Beautiful gardens with stunning colours and a most eclectic mix of plants and trees. Resist the temptation to take photos every 5m and just enjoy the beauty of this garden. Best to arrive early, as once it gets busy, the garden does feel a little crowded. Also, if you weren't able to buy online, the earlier you arrive, the shorter the queue for tickets!! Buy a combined ticket if you can and see the YSL Museum and Berber Museum at the same time - both definitely worth visiting.

Loved it here. The gardens are well maintained and beautiful. Lots of different plants. There’s a Berber museum inside which was really interesting and you only pay an extra 10 DHM to visit. We didn’t have to queue to get in and this was around 12.30 in the afternoon. Children under 12 are free. Definitely recommend!

If you have a headache after exploring the Medina Markets and Jemaa El Fna then is the place to come. For 155 Dhirams you can have a soothing walk all around the beautiful garden surrounded by exotic plant life from South America, China and of course North Africa. They also have a gift shop that sells plenty of tea and a cafe to sit down and relax. A must for anyone wanting peace of mind.
review_title: Therapy from the Hustle and Bustle of the Medina

review_text: I love the tranquillity of Jardin Majorelle and have visited many times over the years. However, although the garden itself has never disappointed, I’ve always felt troubled by the amount of graffiti, often declarations of love, that vandals had carved on to the bamboo trees and wondered why staff had not been sufficiently vigilant to prevent this from happening. Anyway, visiting recently, I found that various changes had been implemented, including staff being far more visible than in the past and an obligatory online booking system being in place (you can no longer pay on arrival). However, the one change that gave me the most joy was finding that all the graffiti had been removed from the bamboo trees. I guess that the presence of more staff, who were strategically placed along a prescribed route that visitors were encouraged to follow, would prevent future vandalism. These gardens are so serene and spending an hour here, especially when there’s few people around, feels like being in paradise.
the place were amazing and very refreshing but i think the price of the combined ticket is too much since the big museum was not as we expected...

These are lovely gardens, very photogenic but so over crowded. We visited 19 years ago and it was so peaceful and wonderful. Last week we were herded around like sheep and you had to constantly queue at many of the best photo opportunities. Understandably these are very popular but it has lost the wow factor from years ago. Also, a bit overpriced but worthy of a visit if you've not been before...suggest you go first of last thing.
review_title: Lovely garden but so crowded nowadays

review_text: Buy the comprehensive ticket online to gain entry to the beautiful garden,  the interesting exhibit about the Amazigh people of Morocco and the YSL Museum down the street. Buy your ticket online to avoid the long ticket line. Go early in the morning to avoid crowds. No photos in the museums and exhibits.  Watch the short film about YSL ay the YSL Museum.

Look, I think it’s worth the visit because it’s a bit of tranquility outside the bustling city, although it is definitely overpriced.  You can walk there from the Medina. There are not many species of plants and almost no identification labels so I wouldn’t really call this a botanical garden. There are security guards everywhere making you stick to a path like cattle, even though there are paths going left and right.  Nope, you must follow everyone else.  And it’s quite small. But here’s the main problem.  It’s a nightmare of people trying to get instagram photos next to something half decent to make it look like they are the only one there.  So there are queues and queues of people who want to all get the same photo at every possible nice looking thing.   So if you just want to take a normal photo of a pretty building, you can’t because there is someone pretending to be a model in front of it.  It’d absolutely relentless. If you find a nice place to sit and try to admire the scenery for a few minutes, people will literally notice you and then stand around waiting for you to get up so they can sit there and get a photo. 3 out of 5 and that’s being generous.   Go there to laugh at the people pretending to be models.  It’s probably more entertaining than the plants.

Gorgeous gardens full of lots of native plants, beautifully maintained. It was a great way to spend an hour or so, though beware of the ridiculous number of Instagrammers trying to get the next great photo.  Also, don't touch the plants! LOL It's frowned upon. It also has a really nice cafe.
review_title: Lovely experience in the heart of the city

review_text: It was a fantastic garden. Many different kinds of plants are located around. You can buy online ticket and try to be there on time. You can take many nice photographs. Yves Saint Laurent lived there for a while if you want you can visit the museum

Embarrassed for the way we were spoken to. Arrived at 17:01 as per the sign said last entry at 17:30 for a 18:00 close. Turns out the last ticket could be bought at 17:00? When we explained and pointed to the sign, the staff just said well noones in the ticket office, couldnt be bothered to look us in the eye when speaking. One man in particular, when I explained this was bucketlist for me and it was our last day, kept hinting they could let us in and then just went “what a shame”. Kept telling us it was sold out when it was quiet, on the rate occassion they decided to answer our questions. Truly odd to advertise incorrectly and then make excuses - gutted.
review_title: Incorrect times advertised and rude staff

review_text: No recommendations ….. for experienc is ok.. nice but not with this price…. I think more bigger and we see more things. Short visit. 40 min…
Extremely stunning.We really enjoyed our visit in this beautiful gardens.very well arranged and maintained.number one for instagram lovers.

A lovely colorful and peaceful garden. However, the highlight for us was the excellent Berber Museum that displayed costumes and incredible Berber jewelry. I only wish that there had been English descriptions of the history. The Saint Ives Museum was also interesting, especially the video. The black dresses on the black models were difficult to see with the dim lighting.
review_title: Wort the combo ticket, book online for the time you wish to visit.

review_text: A must-do experience. Have lunch at the cafe inside the gardens and experience mint tea being poured from arm's length.

We attempted to visit Majorelle on our last stay in Marrakech but the wait was going to be hours to queue for entry and we therefore gave up! This time was more successful as the online booking system has improved the situation. We did still wait around 30 minutes but it was worth it! The gardens are breathtaking with beautiful plants and unusual cacti Colours throughout the gardens are wonderful Plenty of photo opportunities A lovely little restaurant situated near the Garden’s exit We visited in the middle of the day and were waiting to do photos etc as it was very busy. Try to visit as early as possible I would say is the preferred option.

We bought the basic tickets (no museum) which cost 155dh each. At a very gentle stroll, it took us about 30 mins to see the gardens. Although it was pleasant and well-kept, it was nothing spectacular and definitely not worth the money. I can't for the life of me understand why this attraction is rated so highly. Save your cash and stroll around the gardens of the Mamounia Hotel for free. Much more impressive.

The gardens are stunning and very well kept. The cobalt blue used on the house and other fixtures is so vibrant. We were the second through the door when it opened at 8.30am. we got a lot of great photos without anyone around. By 9.30 it was packed. Get there early we got taxi from Jemaa El Fanaa square for 30 dirham.
review_title: I love the vibrant blue but get there early

review_text: Very nice gardens with more Cacti than I knew existed. Well organised and maintained. Make sure you get there early as even in the off season it was very busy. Note that tickets have to be purchased online before
best place to get your holiday pics . lovely mix of colours, plants and art. do take time to go through the  different varieties of plants .

This is Marrakech's No 1 tourist attraction. Book online a few days in advance and avoid disappointment. The garden was first formulated in 1923 by Jacques Majorelle (hence the name). After many decades it was purchased by the fashion designer Yves Saint Laurent and there is a memorial in the garden dedicated to him. You walk through a series of walkways around the garden which is well stocked with numerous types of cactus and bamboo's as well as indiginous plants.  There are beautiful ponds throughout the gardens and some wonderful houses all painted in electric blue. The downside is that it is very crowded, even with pre-booked tickets we had to queue 45 minutes to get in and you cannot walk freely around the gardens, there is a particular route  you walk which I presume is due the crowds. There is a  wonderful bookshop and upmarket shop at the end of the tour that caters for designer gifts and coffee books. If you visit  in low season it might be less crowded.
Botany has been my main hobby recently, just can't get enough of nature, I saw an Argen tree here. Check it out !

The most expensive ticket you will buy in Marrakech for the LEAST exciting experience. Nothing special at all, small garden with different trees that are imported from somewhere else. The security is everywhere around you which did not make me feel comfortable. There were 4 weird fish from Asia in a dirty pond I don’t know what is the context for their existence, and YSL memorial is so lame. So packed and so overrated. Hotel Mamounia has the same trees with even more variety, much much bigger space, with different cafes and restaurants,  and free entrance!
review_title: I don’t understand what is this cost for..

review_text: We went here as part of a guided tour. Go early as it gets very busy. It was ok, if you like looking at plants that were taken from other parts of the world. It’s a private garden so I doubt it supports the local economy in any way. Nice cafe at the end to grab a coffee or food before moving on.

Make sure you purchase your tickets online before your arrival. You won't be able to buy tickets on the spot. They put you by your time slot in front of the gate and without a reserved ticket you won't be able to go in. Garden itself was beautiful with exotic plants and blue houses everywhere. makes for perfect photo shots.
Well-Maintained: The garden's pristine condition and well-kept paths contribute to a pleasant and enjoyable visit for all visitors.
WHAT A beautiful GARDEN MAJORELLE WAS REALLY ONE OF THE BEST THINGS WE DID IN MARRAKECH AND BERBER MEUSEM OH MY GOD THIS COLLECTION BY ysl WAS ABSOLUELY AMZING
There is something special and magic in the garden - online booking only which is actually smart so there is solid management of the many visitors.

We had a good experience here. Great photo opportunities. The museum inside costs extra. If you are a botanical garden lover, this may be a bit basic compared to other ones you have seen. But a nice way to spend a couple of hours in greenery.

Decided to start my new year by visiting the famous Majorelle garden, Nah this was of course ruined by the shouting of the security guard to me in front of everyone. I may have made a mistake while buying the ticket online but they could just tell me privately and without shouting in front of everyone that was so embarrassing. So after sorting this out at 9 am, we started our tour that lasted not even 10 min, what a waste of energy and money, I really don’t know what is the big deal about it but everything was like everyone garden in Marrakech, secret garden is waaay better although is smaller ! I don’t recommend at all! Sorry

It deserves 0/5 stars, actually. Terrible experience. It's a small place with some unusually sized cacti. 450 dirhams for a family of four is as bad as throwing it down the drain. Generally, there is not much to do or see in Marrakesh, so we went there. But it was so evident this place was someone’s glorified back garden. Every 10 feet was manned by a rude employee who would tell you how to walk in that little dump. The only thought I had during my visit was that I could have donated that 450 dirhams to many beggars we saw all over the town.

Absolute must-do, the Gardens are stunning! We visited on a combined ticket with the Musee Yves Saint Laurent and advance booking is highly recommended. Despite advance booking we queue outside (in the shade mostly) for about 20 minutes. We walked around the stunning gardens first, then stopped for a light lunch in the cafe and then the YSL museum. Hope this review was helpful and you enjoy your visit.
review_title: Absolute must-do combined ticket with the YSL museum

review_text: I was pleasantly surprised by Jardin Majorelle. The price vs. what I had read in reviews made me questions if this was worth a visit. I would say yes but go early before the crowds arrive. A "must see" for lovers of cacti and the colour blue.
review_title: An OK Place to Visit for Cactus Fans

review_text: The garden boasts a beautiful landscape with easy walking paths, picturesque views, vibrant colors, and lush greenery. It's advisable to purchase your ticket in advance to secure your preferred time slot, but on-the-day purchases are also available—just be prepared for potential wait times. Conveniently, there are numerous cafes nearby, offering a pleasant option to pass the time while anticipating your visit.

This is a really lovely, quiet, shady spot albeit a small garden that could be completed in 30 mins.  We stretched it out to a couple of hours by doing 7 loops, lots of photos and a coffee. We got there early but in December it was quiet and was better around 10.30 when it started to warm up and still quiet.  Down side is quite expensive for a family, there is a discount if you have a student card but not many kids in secondary school have one.
review_title: Small but beautifully maintained, exotic garden - expensive for what you see.

review_text: One of the best place in this city, the garden is stunning! Very colourful and beautiful! You can per-book the ticket online, it’s very easy with the process.

The fresh air is a perfect reason to visit this lovely place! Make sure to book your tickets before visiting and follow the scheduled time. Don't be late. On the ticket, at the bottom left corner, there is information about where to start your tour. Initially, I was annoyed by their directive regarding where to commence my own tour, but it's simply their policy.

We tried to visit in November, but were thwarted by the need to book on line.  We were prepared on our return to Marrakech, and easily got tickets the day before our visit, for the time we wanted. Not a cheap venue, especially if you go for the combined museums’ ticket, but we came away with the view that it was worth it.  We spent a good few hours in the garden, as the Berber/Amazigh museum is within the area…..sometimes just sitting on the numerous benches, and just revelling in the views.  We sort of went round twice, as we realised we had missed areas, and this did not present a problem to the security staff.  The gardens are really beautiful, and there are a myriad of photo opportunities…. Even if you have to avoid the Instagram/Facebook selfie aficionados…. particularly impressive is the use of colour.  Sadly the plant identifications weren’t as helpful as they might have been.  Some had no labels at all, which is a pity, but others might have been included in a group identification board…. Great idea, but this needs serious revisiting, as many have grown out of all recognition, or are simply no longer there or replaced by something else.
review_title: Wish there were a way to avoid the crowds!

review_text: Unfortunately this is NOT the experience it once was. The staff has managed to ruin a lovely spot with their harsh treatment of visitors. It was not like this in the past. There are and were years ago the very obvious signals of disrespect for anyone other than the French such as the complete dismissal of anyone who speaks any other language (all museum exhibitions are written only in French). Ironically in a museum that displays Berber culture they manage to negate all Berber identity. I truly cannot believe they are still able to get away with French colonialism and charge for the “privilege”.

Based on the pictures and reviews, we started our visit with enthusiasm. Once inside, we found the layout and plant selection to be quite mediocre. Some elements appear to be randomly arranged - a large Koi pond on one side, a small Koi pond at the very end. Some plants looked untended and dry. Despite the moderate crowd, we were ushered for no clear reason at various spots. We also had to wait for a long time after we were done to collect a backpack we had to leave at the entrance. Save your time and money and see the other great places in Marrakech.
Beautiful, huge gardens with all types of plants and cacti. It was a lovely place to stroll for an hour or so.
Overrated tourist attraction. The gardens are nice but it is quite small and takes about 1 to 2 hours. Lots of people. Nicely painted blue and yellow. Lots of cactus plants.
that was one of the highlights of the trip we visited the gardens the berber museum and YSL all was a very nice experience highly recommended

I didn’t know what to expect, except that I have been told it was very very beautiful. It opens at 8:30 in the morning and I would recommend going at 8:30 in the morning as it was very busy at 10:30 am. The only annoying thing where people who were the staff at the gardens who wouldn’t let you go back five paces because you’d missed looking at something and insisted you had to go round the entire garden until you got back to the beginning again, I’m afraid I just completely ignored them. It was especially annoying when I just wanted to use the bathroom.🤦‍♀️😂 However, the buildings are an incredible blue with yellow and Oka colours and fantastic for taking photos and the assortment of cacti and palm trees and water features are delightful. We actually spent a lot of time looking around and then we had a break and had some tea in the café, and then we discovered we missed a whole section , so we did that as well. Fortunately, we had bought a combine ticket which gave us entry to the bERBER museum,  the YSK  museum as well as the gardens

Experiencing the enchanting majorelle garden is undoubtedly a delight,but the prepayment requirement through the internet can be a source of inconvenience for some visitors. I think to go back to on site option could enhance the overall visitor experience,ensuring that the magic of majorelle is accessible to all at any time.

Beautiful vibrant colours throughout the garden. Very relaxing feeling inside.  Small shops within. A long queue to get inside, they were allowing a set number of people at a time. A nice stroll through the whole garden took us just over an hour as we stopped for photos many times! 🙃  worth the money and time
The definition of an oasis in the middle of a busy city. Very extensive, beautiful gardens. Interesting, albeit expensive, gift shop. Definitely worth a visit.

We got the combi ticket and visited the Jardin Majorelle, Berber Museum, and Yves Saint Laurent museum. The garden itself was nice, I was slightly underwhelmed as was expecting a little more from the top rated thing to do in Marrakesh. It was so busy it took some of the charm away unfortunately. It's also really unhelpful that you can't buy tickets in person at all anymore, only in advance through the website. Both of the museums were pretty average. The Berber museum didn't have any other language apart from French so we walked around viewing cool looking objects with no idea what they were. The ysl museum was odd, there was a random snake exhibition in the building and only one room dedicated to ysl. Disappointing.
review_title: Glad I visited the gardens but wouldn't go again

review_text: We paid for the combined ticket to the Jardin Majorelle/Berber Museum/Yves Saint Lauren exhibition. Definitely book in advance as entry numbers are limited and the attraction is very popular. I enjoyed walking around the gardens but I wouldn’t say they were anything special. Although to someone interested in horticulture I am sure they would find it more interesting. I found the Berber museum most interesting - it gives a great illustration of how Berber culture is quite different to Arabic culture, something I was unaware of before I visited Morocco. I also had no idea that Yves Saint Lauren is considered such an important figure in Marrakech. There is a whole museum devoted to his work next to the Jardin Majorelle - again not particularly to my taste but I am sure that anyone interested in fashion would very much enjoy the exhibition.

Impossible to get in to the gardens or Museum. You MUST buy tickets online ahead of your visit when you have good wifi Outside the museum and garden the website falls over repeatedly at payment stage There were hundreds of frustrated tourists and Moroccans standing outside when we tried to visit who also couldnt make the online ticket system work ! Good luck!!!
review_title: Abortive trip to YSL museum and majorelle jardins

review_text: First of all, we were impressed by the perfect organisation at the entrance. Tourists queue up in groups divided per reservation time (16/16,30/17...). The personnel uses laser scanners to check the online-bought tickets. At reservation time, hundreds of tourists were checked in and entered the gardens in seconds. The place itself is very beautiful, 'instagrammable' (=aesthetic) and vibrant with colors. What amazed us most was the Pierre Bergé Berber Museum (ticket not included, must be added to the garden's ticket). NOT TO BE MISSED AT ANY COST! The hall with the starry desert night and the Berber women jewels is hypnotic, amazing, jaw-dropping and leaves you speechless. A must-see when in Marrakech.
review_title: Amazing experience. Berber Museum additional ticket HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

review_text: A really nice, picturesque place to visit. You’ll need to buy tickets online and book a time slot, it gets really busy, I’d advise arriving around 20-30 mins before your allocated time slot. There are a few different ticket types available, we went for the garden only but you can buy additional tickets for the ysl museum and the Berber museum too. Once you’re in you’re free to spend as much time in there as you’d like, it’s not massive and you can do it all in the space of an hour or so but still worth checking out.
review_title: Very picturesque, if you’re into gardening you’ll love this place even more

review_text: Digital discrimitation. You are only allowed to buy the tickets through the wesite and you must pay with a credit card. So if you only have cash you are denied entrance because they do not sell tickets.
Absolutely loved even if i am not a botanist or gardener.  Recommend to buy tickets before and avoid que, as well visit at early morning when there no that much visitors.

This is surprisingly more interesting than your typical botanical garden. Besides the bamboos and other plantations, there is a small patch of desert cactus. The arrangement is very nicely done. The most interesting part is the YSL blue building. Every angle could be a picture frame. The striking color contrast can only be made with experienced artistic eyes. We thoroughly enjoyed the visit. Reviewing the photos after the trip gives us even more pleasure.
review_title: The amazing YSL garden is a must-see

review_text: Nicely designed and well maintained garden. It has numerous attractive varieties of cacti.  The Berber cultural museum is located within the garden and is worth a visit. The garden also has a nice cafe.
review_title: Worth a visit while in Marrakesh

review_text: If one like plants and colors then Jardin Majorelle is a must. Booking beforehand is a must because the place is crowded. Too crowed !

A beautiful garden to visit unless you are really enthusiastic a little bit expensive , should really include the museum but that's an extra so when buying your ticket make sure you buy the museum as well or you will not be allowed in. Where had a 1330 slot had to queue until 1350. Your ticket is only valued for 29 minutes after your designated slots so make sure you're on time.

Beautiful gardens, immaculately kept and easy to get around. The gardens themselves are quite small so you could rattle around them quite fast but take your time and enjoy the scenery. Tickets have to be bought online but there is free WiFi outside the gardens so this is easy to do. Get there early (9:00) or so to avoid the crowds. We did this and were allowed in at 8:45 so it was empty. The cafe does some great tea and the shop has lots of good books to buy. If you are very lucky you might even get to see an Influencer in the wild, angrily trying to get a photo/video with no else in the way.
2013.03 Colorfull, inspirational , cultural, original - great place to visit and capture unique pictures. Must see

We bought tickets online, around £26 with the conversion rate. (Make sure you download the correct tickets before going as you might not have data!) We were booked in at 12 noon, but arrived early and they are very organised, you queue in your due viewing time, so no point being early, except Rue Yves Saint Laurent is very nice! It has a few shops and cafes along it, so we popped in for coffee at one. They are not overpriced considering where they are, about £3 for coffee which is the normal price. We joined our queue and after ticket check, we went in. The gardens are lovely, they are small, but definitely worth a visit. There is a small pond, some koi carp, huge cacti if you're a cacti fan! Very peaceful and although you can spend as much time in there as you want, such as sitting in the shade and just taking in the tranquility of the place, you do have to go in one direction! There is no going back at any point. There are also two pretty spots where you have to wait for people to take pictures. (Some of the young insta girls were taking a while!) There is a book shop, a gift shop and a really nice cafe. After wandering around the gardens and taking lots of photographs, we sat in the cafe in the courtyard with coffee and cake which was around £8. We enjoyed the peace after the souks and the square, it was well organised and not overcrowded as they control entry. We walked from the medina which took around ten minutes which is safe and there are lots of security around the gardens.
review_title: Lovely tranquil gardens to wander around after the hectic souks and square.

review_text: This garden is small, tidy and easy to access.  However the entry fee is too expensive.  Apart from some cactuses I couldn’t notice anything unusual.  There are guards at every few meters but I couldn’t understand their purpose.  Perhaps, my benchmark are set too high being a resident of England.  Very poor value for money.

One of the most beautiful places in Marrakech. You have to see it, it's breathtaking. I would recommend to book your tickets in advance and the cafe located inside it's a very nice option to visit before leaving the gardens.
review_title: One of the most beautiful places in Marrakech

review_text: Amazing place ! Highly recommended. note : make sure you be there early morning if you want to take some beautiful shots because it gets busier after 9am

Extremely rude staff. We bought student tickets and when we showed them our IDs, they said it was not enough. They said they needed to see our classes. I could not log on to my canvas school account, but when my sister showed hers, the lady started scrolling and clicking on her lessons and homework. It was an unbelievable invasion of privacy. I tried to show her her screenshots of my enrollment receipts and she grabbed my phone and started scrolling through my photos too. I had to take my phone from her since she was ignoring our protests about her scrolling through private information. In the end they forced us to buy new tickets since they didn't believe we were students, and we couldn't refund. As foreigners it was very stressful and it felt like they were doing it on purpose since we looked very young and Asian; I noticed they treated other nationalities differently. The garden is mediocre; the museum architecture is beautiful but the exhibitions were lacking in every sense. A waste of money.
review_title: RUDE STAFF, BEWARE IF YOU'RE STUDENTS

review_text: Overpriced! Hardly anything to see just a few trees and a pond. By accident ordered ticket for a day before and we could not exchange for correct day, made us pay again. Do not recommend. Front desk lady was not helpful
Unmissable for both gardeners and artists. Berber museum. A foundation to help artists and young people. A very worthy cause as well as being exquisite.
review_title: Classiest garden, perhaps in the world?

review_text: The most beautiful place we visited whilst in Marrakesh. It was £25 each to visit both Jardin Majorelle and the YSL museum and they’re about 100m away from each other. The garden breathtaking and all the staff were very lovely and spoke English ( which was helpful for my friend and I as we speak limited French). There’s also a beautiful coy fish pond and vibrantly coloured plant pots throughout the whole garden. Would highly recommend visiting if you’re in Marrakesh.
Awesome gardens with great architecture and sceneries to admire. You can go quickly, but i recommend to spend enough time to enjoy it fully :)
review_title: Great oasis that you should visit!

review_text: Jardin Majorelle is a tranquil haven amidst the vibrancy of Marrakesh, with stunning cacti and a lush landscape. The garden's compact size makes for a perfect short visit, and pre-purchasing tickets online streamlines entry. The ambiance alone is a delight, making it an essential stop for those who appreciate serene beauty and the art of gardening.

First get there early. We entered just after 9am and it was peaceful with few other people - when we left (about 10.30am) there were long queues outside. This is a small tranquil garden in the modern part of Marrakech. Take your time as you saunter around. There are some amazing plants especially cacti. The gardeners are terrific in keeping the surrounding gravel spotless. The Museum of the Berber is worth a short visit (inc with your ticket). There is a cafe if you need a break - alternatively there is a large one opposite the entrance.

Pretty gardens but you really couldn’t spend more than 30 minutes here. Very overpriced. Crowded with so many self absorbed narcissistic people taking selfies everywhere. Couldn’t get many decent photos due to all the girls wanting a 20 minute photo shoot on every corner, next to every plant pot, at every door and next to every building. Buying the tickets online before was unnecessary and downright expensive when there’s no WI-FI 🙄

Stunning Tranquil gardens perfect for some time out from the bustle of Marrakech! Shady and green with lots to see! Gorgeous bold blue, yellow and orange colours - obviously favourites of Yves Saint Laurent!

Jardin Majorelle is a "must see" for anyone visiting Marrakech. The gardens are spectacularly maintained and even when it's crowded, there is a sense of tranquility that is a welcome respite from the bustling city just outside the walls. Buy your timed-entry tickets in advance on-line, and get to the garden EARLY. It is extremely popular and even by 10AM there can be long line-ups. The joint ticket that includes the Berber Museum and the YSL Museum is worth the extra few dollars. Note that the best experience will include access to the Villa Oasis garden (a separate garden on the same property), which is only open Friday to Monday. While many reviews will tell you that you only need an hour to see all of this, I suggest that is way too little time to appreciate it. If your objective is to rush about taking selfies with large cacti, by all means - give yourself an hour or so. But to actually enjoy the place, I suggest at least a couple of hours. Jardin Majorelle has a cafe (we didn't try it) and there are several just outside the Jardin on Rue Yves St. Laurent.
review_title: Jardin Majorelle is lovely - so take the time to enjoy it

review_text: Absolute rip off and it was crowded. Its about £12 to basically see a garden which turned out to be Instagram central! There is nothing there other than plants. No description, one memorial to YSL. You have to book a Separate ticket to the museum to enter the blue house. 30minutes of my life waste for a garden. Avoid and do something else with your time! There is no way you can spend more than 30mins here- we walked around it twice and was still done in 30mins. Best part …. Leaving!

Having read  plenty of reviews here, I followed the advice to book either early or late. We chose early, arrived about 10 minutes before our 9am slot, and walked straight in with no queuing or faff. It was still quiet enough that we could wander at will in any direction we chose, with plenty of space and peace to take photographs if we felt like it, and just chill if we didn’t. Absolutely gorgeous. Cool and beautiful - a fresh garden-y delight around every corner. Having dashed out our riad without eating (see earlier comment re ticket time lol) we had the Moroccan breakfast for 115dh each in the lovely cafe - one of the best breakfasts of our entire trip. Fantastically fresh and tasty and very huge! Top quality mint tea too.

This was our second visit to this lovely tranquil desert garden. A shady oasis away from the heat. Well kept. However, I agree with a previous comment about too many posing influencers but that is not the gardens fault and is definitely worth a visit.

A place located in a very nice area of Marrakech created by a painter and refined later by a fashion icon - YS. The attention to the detail and the chromatic is scintillating. The gardens are so nice and so colorful. The Berber Museum is so chic and informative and pleasant to visit. The café and that boys serving there are so cool and fun. I would say afternoon is better due to the light. Buy the package because everything worth visiting. Including the YSL House which shows an amazing collection of photos... A bit an obsession in the indoor spaces to forbid photographing is a bit annoying.
YSL garden in his house … stunning blue. Desert garden how it should be done! Greens, citrus yellow, stunning blue, pools, cacti
review_title: Desert garden as it should be done

review_text: Save your money and your time. I’ve been to people’s backyards that has more plants than here. The size of the jardin is just about half of a New York City block. There is a small koi fish pond that’s about 5x5 meters and there’s 4 fish in it. Hope you find this useful, I don’t know what the hype is all about 🤷🏽‍♂️
review_title: Don’t get what the hype is about

review_text: Visited as part of a tour group . Wanted to visit for years & finally managed to ……so glad as it is breathtaking. As part of a group we had a limited time but arrived just after the gardens opened . Leaving just over an hour later it was starting to get busy. They have a “ one way “ walk in operation, which is quite a good idea . If you want to see something agin then you go round agin . The colours are amazing , cobalt blue is a favourite of mine . This teams up so well with the orange & yellow . The plants look beautiful too. There is a Berber Museum to visit , sadly we didn’t have time for this but I’m sure it would have great presentation & items to see . There is also a memorial to Yves St Laurent . Would recommend this 100%

The combined ticket to Jardin Marjorelle, YSL exhibition and the Berber exhibition are worth the visit. I did not expect the exhibitions to deliver such a high standard of curation. The gardens are a peaceful oasis one inside the walls. The cafe inside the garden is a pleasant break while visiting the gardens.
Not that special, after 20 min you are done. It is a pretty location for pictures and a good escape out of the city. We just expected more from it.

Lovely gardens although it was quite busy with lots of people and it felt a bit like a conveyor belt. Various places to sit, which was a good rest from the heat.  Many people taking their Insta photos which can be a bit annoying. The traditional Berber museum at the end was interesting too.
The gardens were ok. There was way too many people to enjoy them properly. I preferred seeing YSLs sketches and clothes in the adjoining museum

The gardens themselves are lovely and you can spend a good 45 minutes to an hour wandering the site. If your into ysl there is also the museum next door which you need to pay an additional fee for. I'd your in the area then this is a good additional place to add on but it's not really an attraction in itself. Given its recent boost in popularity due to going viral on several social media platforms you can play a good game of spot the influencer in the wild- you can't take a foot anywhere without some pretentious influencer basically hissing at you for getting in their shot. Hate to see what it's like during peak season.
review_title: Lovely garden, shame about the influencer's

review_text: Overpriced and over-rated. It was Ok. Not a bad place to visit but it’s nothing special. Had to wait in line to get in and it’s not a must see. A lot of people taking pictures of cactus.
We thought the entry fee was very overpriced for what was on offer.  Why the entry fee has to be exclusively pre-booked on the internet is unnecessary.
Lovely garden! Recommend visiting! The garden is well maintained and a sensory experience, beautiful colours and plants
It good but no toilet  tycygjguttvgufrrcutgudryfyticrvrdyx(hmbt4yrrcrtycydrbjhnuouSfvnuidcha bdudahk. FS uhobsdohu Srugi churisa cuig Dashcode aseiguf fsdguidiugdsbcuho$xguco dsgou csduibs cdaohb

Our Guide Mohamed, is friendly and speaks well, chatting with us about the gardens that we visited. Driver, Khalid, brought us safely to our destinations amidst the busy morning traffic. I'm a solo traveller but shared a car with another lovely couple. The Marjorelle is beautiful but too many people to enjoy it in peace. Regardless, It was nice to be able to see it. Menara towers didn't have much to see compared to Marjorelle.  But I was also glad the guides brought us to a shop with beautiful home stuff, that we didn't need to haggle for price.
Over priced, too many people packed in to enjoy the garden. Berber exhibition only in French. Forced to move in one direction instead of wandering freely.

The gardens were quite beautiful and offer a relaxing contrast to the chaos often associated with Marrakech. The vibrant colors and vegetation make you feel like you're in a movie. The downsides were that It was quite busy when we went, so I recommend going as early as possible. If you're planning on buying something at the café expect prices made for tourists. Finally, since this is far from the city center I recommend going by taxi, and always be wary of the taxi prices.

A delightful escape from the city. Due to the trees and vegetation, it is cooler inside than outside the garden, which is a real pleasure on a hot Marrakech day. Slow down, relax, unplug and enjoy, we did.
review_title: A delightful escape from the city

review_text: The overall impression I am left with is of security guards telling you to go a different way and crowds making it difficult to see anything. Good for those who like to shuffle - even then it only takes 30 minutes to get round. I have seen much better cactus gardens for free. Overhyped. Terrible value for money

Beautiful day out. Following the reviews someone suggested to go early and it paid off.  We got there around 10ish. And we saw the queues as we were leaving. It is exciting and very unique and had a few spots to take some lovely pics.  We didn’t do the museum but the garden was great and we spent around an hour there. Before visiting the next site. We made a day off visiting all the sites in one day. We booked a taxi for the day. Which helped with a little one. But we also got to see a lot.

Following a visit in 2016, I took my family who visited Marrakech for the first time. Whilst I preferred to book online as last time the queues outside were a nightmare, I was surprised to see so many ‘security’ staff throughout the gardens. Not only do they look miserable they make you feel on edge! We had to ask several times if we could walk in an area. We visited at 4.30pm on a Friday afternoon and it wasn’t to busy, but we got to see the Instagram crowds lining up in certain areas for photo opportunities Yes it is a beautiful place away from the hustle and bustle of the medina but 15 euros? We were only there 40 mins max. Note - I wouldn’t recommend walking from the medina, take a taxi. There is also a taxi rank by the entrance for after.
review_title: A quiet haven at a price

review_text: A wonderful break from the bustle of Marrakech. The gardens are lovely and you need to take your time exploring them The museum was also interesting We finished off in the cafe - which was welcome though pricey
review_title: Lovely spot for some relaxtion and recovery

review_text: Must see! Vibrant colours set off the garden! Shady so nice in hot weather! Lots of photo opportunities! Didn’t visit museum so can’t comment but garden is value for money and a must see when in Marrakesh
review_title: A must see when in Marrakesh

review_text: We spent an enjoyable couple of hours in the gardens. The cacti are huge. Gorgeous colours and easy to walk around. Nice gift shop and cafe. Worth a visit. I’d suggest going early to beat the crowds. We went in at 9.30 and there was no queue, coming out at 11.30 there were large queues
Nicely laid out gardens Disappointing because there was very little plant information and variety of plants Extremely busy even though it is timed ticket entry

A smaller garden full of cactus and other drought resistant plants with plenty of shade complete with bright blue and yellow pots. I am sure if you are a fan of YSL it means much more, we are not. Nice cafe to retreat to and guests are lightly sprayed with water which is a nice touch and not as bad as it seams!
This oasis of calm is situated 20 min walk from the old town and is one of the "must see" attractions of Marrakech

Save your money and go to the Secret Garden instead! I'd heard such great things about this garden and was excited to see it but was really disappointed. As other reviews have said, it's mainly good Instagram content. While there are some nice features, the layout of the garden was pretty poor with no real discernable sections or flow.  The cacti were cool but otherwise plants were just bamboo and ferns which are common in other Moroccan gardens that are much cheaper. We went at 11am and it was packed with people, so you can only sort of shuffle along- not particularly relaxing. Architecture was also disappointing- it's just that the buildings are painted a vibrant blue more than any interesting structureor design. Buying tickets online was also a nightmare for international travellers as when purchasing the site/bank sends a code to your home registered number which you can't do if you aren't using international roaming. We had to get our hotel manager to book for us. PLUS the site makes you sign up before trying to purchase and therefore gets your email address and details which is outrageous data collection!
review_title: Give it a miss- overpriced and disappointing

review_text: The Jardin Majorelle were beautiful and contrary to a lot of other reviews, I really appreciate the fact that it’s a break away from the hustle. I found them to be really beautiful and a big juxtaposition of its surroundings.

I must say, I am neither a great garden expert nor I do have an Instagram account. With this being said, I really cannot understand the hype behind. I do not have any problem with the queuing and the timeslots, if you do your homework before going you just know how it works. The price is on the very high scale for the tickets in Morocco, hence I have been expecting something mindblowing - which is the case if you have an Instagram account and you really need to brag about your Morocco vacation. Walking in the garden is just waiting for dozen of people looking for the perfect shot - not caring one bit about whatever the garden is. Not that it is easy to understand what the garden is, as there is basically no explanation anywhere. The cherry on the cake was requiring to get an additional ticket for getting into the house/museum, I might sound cheap but after spending maybe 15€ entrance (by far the most we paid in Morocco) - this was just a joke. On top of that, the garden is not that close to the Medina, hence you will also need to get a cab to go there. In a nutshell, I cannot really blame "the garden" for being an Instagram Hotspot and I do not expect them to push out people monopolizing spots for 15 minutes looking for the perfect spot. But the price is way too high for what you get. There are beautiful gardens you can visit for free in Fes and Rabat, and better ones in Marrakesh like the Secret Garden. P.s. Just removed two stars - when checking the price I realized that they send you an account confirmation with your password in clear text. In 2023. I mean, seriously? This speaks words about how your data is stored and about the security procedures. If you consider that you have to buy tickets online...
review_title: If you do not have Instagram, use your time differently - insufficient Website security standard.

review_text: Miraculously quiet oasis in the heart of the city. Immaculately kept garden of bamboo, palms and cacti and Arab architecture. Price was a bit high, 150MAD, as it's not a large place and you had to pay with an app not cash nor card.
review_title: Lovely quiet oasis in the heart of the city.

review_text: Overrated for the price.. a simple garden which can be walked around in 20-30 minutes.. the Berber museum is a big let down considering the history of the Berbers… a definite waste of money….

If you want to see some large cacti this may work for you. Otherwise you will find the place overpriced, overpopulated and overrated. Hugely expensive for Dhs 200 for a visit only worth half an hour of your time, even including the miniscule  Berber museum. The staff are numerous and dictatorial.

How bold to paint plant pots in vibrant & dramatic cobalt blue, the brightest of yellows, orange, pale blues, benches painted in light green, cemented pathways painted red, the colours will just blow you away. In loving memory of it’s creators Yves Saint Laurent & life partner Pierre Bergé, it truly is their “Garden of Eden”……
review_title: IF YOU DO NOTHING ELSE WHILST IN MARRAKESH YOU MUST SEE THIS GARDEN…..

review_text: Very expensive Staff rude. Not worth it. Not much else to say that would help. Very missable experience

Lots of good photo opportunities and well maintained grounds, berbur museum was slightly disappointing due to size although the whole space has a very aesthetic layout, not overly busy and was easy to book online
review_title: Aesthetic experience wish it was bigger

review_text: Beautiful garden in marrakech.beautful collection of different plants.The gardens are well kept.book online

Basicaly just a park with some cacti and palms and a gazebo in the middle with some frogs. There are parks like this all over the world for free but this one is somehow worth 15 euros?! Basicly just for taking instagram photos. Security all over the place like there is something very valuable in the middle of the place, but they are just standing there doing nothing. To top it all off we were both students and they didn't believe us since our student cards were issued in 2020./2021. (date of issue), so wr had to pay 75 morwle MAD (7.5 EUROS) for entry. The key of this trap is that you must buy the tickets online before you come so it would be stupid to just turn back.
The key characteristic of the gardens is the temperature: 5 or 10 degrees lower than outside. 15 euros adults is a lot of money for what you see. There are lots of policemen controlling where you go.
Visiting Majorelle Garden was a serene escape! Vibrant flora, artistic allure, and a tranquil oasis in bustling Marrakech. A must-see botanical haven.

I wasn't sure about this from the website - it looked small - but friends had recommended it, and I'm glad I listened to them. This garden is unlike anything I've visited before (and we're RHS and National Trust members!). The design and planting is exquisite. While the plants are mostly shades of green, the structures are vivid colours, especially blue and yellow, and the combined effects of foliage, cacti, palms, bamboo, water lilies, climbing bougainvillea are breathtaking. It's essential to book online in advance, and I'd recommend getting in as ealy as possible. We booked for 10am, and it was already quite busy at certain photo-points around the garden.
This is a place not to be missed; tickets have to be booked on line now, but the gardens have been "updated" since covid and are even more wonderful - the colours and plants are just amazing!

Hard to navigate around all the tourists dressed to the nines so they can pose for photos. Then a bird splats on your head, and you spend most of your visit trying to get poop out of your hair. At least that makes for some interesting pics! The garden is pretty, but small for the price (€15 not including the Berber museum). We were done in less than half an hour.

This is a very popular attraction due to social media. You are required to queue no matter what time you get there. This is essentially a photo opportunity attraction, as people scramble to get the best shot everywhere you look. Whilst we did enjoy our visit, if you have limited time in Marrakesh we would recommend spending your time visiting authentic Riad sites in the Medina.

Considered to be one of the city highlights, not only because of having been built by Majorelle but because of having been inhabitted by the well known fashion stylist Yves Saint- Laurent, these astoundingly beautiful gardens and the house that proudly stands in it are definitely worth the visit, even if visitors have to be "patient", as the photo points are always overcrowded despite the visiting hour schedules. The blue house, now turned into a Berber Museum is equally worth the visit ( notwithstanding the fact that photos cannot be taken). I suggest you book your visit for the first available visiting hour (09h30) because that way you might stroll around a bit more at ease.
If this is a number 1 tourist attraction... Marrakech is not about visiting these kind of spots. If you need something disappointing: go here.
Relaxed, quietly respectful. Very well maintained. you must take your ticket on ligne. Would recommend spending 1 hour here.
These gardens are not your normal run of the mill gardens. The variety of cacti  and unusual plants is amazing.  You enter into an atmosphere of cool air due to the shade from the beautiful trees
review_title: Yves Saint Laurent at his best

review_text: Definitely bring your card so you can make purchases in the gift shop. They have souvenir shops and the garden is photo ready!!!
review_title: Go for a visit; you won't regret!

review_text: Apparently a must do when visiting Marrakesh but I’m afraid to say we were pretty underwhelmed by Jardin Majorelle! ! It’s pretty and immaculate and well kept but small and we walked around it in under 10 minutes.  So not great value for the price either!  €15  (150dhs).  The cafe looked ok but we went to Macha at the Dar El Boucha instead for a very unique coffee experience! Would I recommend? Possibly but just don’t expect a massive Botanical Garden - perhaps my expectations were too high!
review_title: Pretty small garden and well kept!

review_text: Relaxed, quietly respectful. Very well maintained. Lovely cafe and facilities. Would recommend spending 1 hour here.
I enjoyed my tour of this place , especially for stunning Pictures , My Partner was more interested in the history.

Very beautiful garden, with old plants, including some gigantic cactus and palm tree. A visit that give you a sense of serenity. The only down side is that it is a bit pricey. We recommend combing with Yves Saint Laurent museum located next door. Booking is mandatory so do it online before going to have your time slot.

What a waste of time and money! Full of instagram photo chasers posing all over the place. It’s a gravel pit of cactus plants with pots painted in various colours! The staff are rude and the amount of security is a joke. We got told off for walking the wrong way, got told off for holding on to a hand rail and got told of for stepping on a low wall. I saw a man get told off for resting his tripod on a seat? Seriously, not worth the effort.
review_title: What a waste of time and money

review_text: Nice garden, but that's it. Such a pricey ticket to just see plants. The place is full with wannabe influencers that make the experience less relaxing. There are lines just to take a picture. The worst thing is the bunch of security guards that make you take the fastest route so you leave the garden fast. Do you really need 10-20 security guards on a garden?
Amazing plants in a fabulous garden with numerous water features and pools with water lilies. Beautifully laid out and maintained.
It was a very nice garden a little small and a lot of people crowding popular picture spots. The museum is worthwhile

We booked our tickets online and turned up, joining the queue to enter. Although the gardens were pretty enough, it was full of teens taking ages to get the perfect selfie (rather annoying when you wanted to get a photo yourself) and ‘security’ who were quite obnoxious. It was around £12 to enter the garden which felt a bit expensive in comparison to the Jardin Secret which was cheaper, nicer and more relaxing. Overall, glad we came to see it, but it wasn’t brilliant.

The Jardin Majorelle is a must see in Marrakech. We were very grateful that we booked our tickets a few days in advance and got the exact entrance time we were looking for. We visited in the morning which was perfect as it would definitely be really hot in the summer during the afternoon. We put our selfie stick to good use as they are so many stunning views in the gardens.
review_title: A must visit if you are in Marrakech

review_text: The YSL Gardens in Marrakech captivated me with their serene beauty and meticulous design. Each step revealed vibrant flora and artistic landscapes, creating a truly enchanting experience.

Beautiful garden with some superb plants and trees. The colours of the pots and tiles with the backdrop are fabulous. If I was to say anything negative it would be that it's not overly cheap for the size of it.

The gardens themselves are definitely worth a visit. They are beautiful and it’s really something to be seen. I’d recommend visiting as early as possible in the day as we did to avoid the crowds. We visited at 8:30 and the gardens were very quiet when we arrived, but became very busy quite quickly. The thing that lets this place down are unfortunately some very unfriendly staff that leave you terrified of putting a foot out of place. I was wearing a shawl over my dress as it was the cool early morning when we arrived, and upon removing this when the day became very hot I was told off by an abrupt guard (still not sure what the issue was here.) We also saw many guests scolded for not following the correct ‘route’ around the gardens, despite there being no signs directing you where to go. We did eat in the cafe and this was a pleasant experience with FAR friendlier staff than those dotted around the gardens. All in all this was quite an uncomfortable experience all round but the gardens are lovely.
review_title: Beautiful gardens, shame about the staff!

review_text: a litle bit expensive but worth it though... colorful and well managed and maintained . great place...
A real oasis in the town.   Worth spending an hour simply to smell the scents of the exotic plants and flowers,   You can sit on a bench and relax.
Small and expensive. The gardens are nice, but it is too expensive. Not recommended. And you have to buy tickets online.

Lovely to get away from the hustle and bustle and recommend booking ticket for 8.30 to avoid those tourists who insist on having photos taken standing in front of the many cactuses. The path is not that wide in places so you might have to stand while the whole crowd of tourists each have their photo taken. Cafe quite expensive but expected. Lovely selection of plants; other than that not much to rave about. Immaculately kept although would benefit from have the blue paintwork cleaned now and again so it doesn't start to look shabby.
review_title: Tranquil and lovely selection of cactuses although small gardens

review_text: Officious , unwelcoming You arrive outside to be poured back across the road for online booking Once in don’t turn right as you’ll be immediately pointed in other direction - but no signs or information to advise you Walk around , queue for insta location photos if that’s what floats your boat but lighting was inappropriate Cafe fine Ps don’t touch the little information signs on a display of cacti -that’s wrong too Most things you want to explore / learn/ enjoy - Forget it But whatever you do don’t take one step outside the gate and expect to be allowed to step back inside to your parents - our youngest son wasn’t allowed to step back in for a family photo Three staff then continued to argue with my husband All very unnecessary and unpleasant But unsurprising when you think it’s all about looks and not reality Despite being about gardens no encouragement nor ability to recur plastic use - eg no water filling , no recycling If you care about our planet, family Moments etc , sorry to say  don’t spend your money here
review_title: Prickly staff to match the plants

review_text: Absolutely beautiful! I really enjoyed walking around these amazing gardens. The bright colours, the beautiful plants. The koi pool, the fountains. Highly recommend 👌

This place is absolutely unique. Amazing play of colors and light. The large well-kept garden is impressive. Everywhere there are discreet employees directing the movement of tourists in an almost imperceptible way.

We hugely recommend going to the gardens early, when there are fewer people visiting to get a sense of the tranquility. The gardens aren't big, but they are very beautiful, and lots of unusual plants to enjoy.
review_title: Beautiful gardens, and very tranquil if you visit early

review_text: So this was supposed to be the highlight of our trip in Morocco however due to the inconsideration of Management at Jardin Marjorelles that experience has been nothing short of a horror. Booked my 09:30am ticket the evening before and was delayed in our arrival time by an hour due to a flight delay and a lack of transport. Explained this to the staff on our arrival at 10:30am however no one was willing to assist even when we escalated it to Management. To think that this was our first experience of Morocco and we would once more have to pay the full ticket price for an hour delay that wasn’t of our doing is highly unacceptable. When questioned on such inconsideration, we were told we should have called before to explain we were running late, which is a fair thing to do, however considering the circumstances (we were on a flight with no cellphone connectivity and we had not even gotten a chance yet to buy a sim as we rushed straight there after arriving), however when we explained our pleas fell on deaf ears. Please do better more so for your international clientele. You are ambassadors of Morocco and an experience like this no doubt leaves a bitter taste on anyone’s mouth.

A nice garden with lots of different species of plants and flowers. It can get crowded but there are a lot of staff to help and guide you. It has been well maintained. It is recommended to book your tickets before arriving and be on time as there are certain number of visitors at a time. There is a museum dedicated to YSL designer next door to garden at an extra fee.
It’s a desert in a city. Beautiful gardens amidst vibrant colors and a colorful backdrop. It gets quite crowded during tourist season.
Very pretty. I enjoyed the garden. Can get crowded. But definitely worth seeing. Lots of cacti and beautiful trees.

This is my third time visiting the garden since 2010 and the experience has changed in some important ways. We took about an hour just visiting the gardens (we skipped the museums). Most notably, as earlier reviews noted, you can ONLY buy tickets online in advance now, not in person, and you must pick a half-hour time slot to enter. This is new and it's presumably to avoid what had apparently become round-the-block lineups to enter, which would be dangerous in the summer heat (it was 40+ celsius this week). Make sure you have your actual tickets on your phone, not the email confirmation of your purchase. At the same time, the price has doubled to 150 Moroccan dirham per adult, easily way more than any other sight in Marrakesh. It's also on the verge of being overwhelmed by crowd control. Aside from the timed tickets, there are guards standing at certain paths telling you not to go this way or that way, which unfortunately undermines the experience of wandering and discovering the gardens on your own, as you once did. The other annoyance is of course the crowds themselves. We were there in June, which seems to be the beginning of low season, so there were still areas that were pretty quiet, but any of the obvious places to take photos have awkward clusters of people all waiting to take the same picture. If you just want to actually take in the view and examine the details of the garden, you're at risk of someone breathing down your neck, waiting for you to move so they can pose. Again, it sort of defeats the purpose of the gardens. It remains a beautiful place, fun to explore, and inspiring for anyone who likes design and landscaping. Among other highlights, you'll be surprised at the sheer variety of cacti in the section near the exit. If you're in Marrakesh, there's no reason to skip it, especially as it's different from the typical medina sights. But if you want your own pictures, give yourself plenty of time and plan on being patient with impatient people.
review_title: Beautiful place, but slightly overshadowed by crowd control

review_text: exquisitely organized, beautiful and elegant. learned a lot about YSL , the museum and gardens ara a must in Marrakesh!

We have seen the pictures of the garden online and we found it was cute and maybe worth spending an afternoon there. It started with the tickets. On the way out of the hotel we mentioned where we go. We were told we would not get in without tickets bought online. Then we tried to buy with the museum together, it was not available, then going back to the garden alone it was. What we did not realize was that the month jumped to July instead of June. Upon arrival we were told it is our fault and there is nothing they can do. An unfriendly cashier offered to change them for the next day. We explained that we are leaving Marrakech next morning so we can’t come back. She said if we had a flight ticket to show she would maybe reconsider. Since we traveled by car that was a lost case. I offered to show the next hotel reservation but she was stiff like a stick. Since we already wasted the afternoon to get there we bought another set of tickets. Then the true horror started. “Stand here”. “Move there”. “Left side of the sign”, “not so far left”. Real military regime or high security prison. Only guns and the barbed wire was missing. At 16:02 (two minutes after time despite the terror) we were admitted in. Not better there. A guard every few meters. “Move over”, “one person at the time”, “don’t stand here”, “keep moving”. The nazi guards with a dead serious faces were pushing the crowd towards the exit. Each group has 30 minutes (here 28) to stream through and depart before the next group. I was so angry with the entire experience that I barely took a picture there. Just rushed towards the exit to have this nasty event behind me. I don’t know how pretty a garden can be to be worth going through that nightmare. This one was not for sure.

I was a little apprehensive about going to the Jardin Majorelle and the YSL Museum as I felt that it was a likely tourist trap. I was mistaken. The garden is simply incredible. It is peaceful and just gorgeous. The plants are so healthy and beautiful, it is a feast for the eyes. The bar serves good food and drinks (it has AC if you need a break from the heat) and the numerous staff is very helpful. We arrived 55 minutes earlier than our reservations (which must be done online) and they let us in. I love cacti and I was in paradise. They have healthier Seguro cactuses than you find in Arizona. :) The YSL (Yves Saint Laurent) was surprisingly interesting. Going there was my wife's idea but I enjoyed much more than I expected. I did not know about the man behind the brand and learned quite a bit. I also got a sense of how the haute couture process works.
review_title: An oasis of peace in a crowded city!

review_text: The famous Le Jardin Majorelle is a place that is usually on everyone’s to do list when thinking of Marrakech. The majority of these types of typical tourist traps tend to be overcrowded & overrated however the Majorelle is the exception to this rule. It really is as beautiful as it seems in pictures & then some. The foundation has beautifully maintained the uniqueness of the gardens as well as laying out the history of Jacques Majorelle, the Berber people & of course Yves Saint Laurent. The cafe there sells exquisite tea & food, & the YSL museum next door houses the legends of YSL fashion with original sketches by Yves Saint Laurent. The entire experience can definitely be a day trip out & is 100% worth the hype.

There is a big difference between visit in 2019 and this year. You have to buy tickets online and make the reservation at exact time. They raised the price from 7 EUR to 15 EUR in May 2023. The enter is every half an hour. There is no possibility to buy tickets on the entrance. We came 25 minutes earlier 8:05 in the morning and there were no visitors waiting to enter, but nevertheless we had to wait in the line for 8,30 (as reserved) After 9:00 it was already very crowded. Very disappointing that you can't find out when it is open also the rest of the garden with the house. Employees said that it is open from time to time and without any schedule. Garden is really special and when visiting Marrakesh, you just have to visit it. But careful planning - hour, buying the tickets on line... don't be late.
Be aware you need to book tickets and a time online. It's difficult to appreciate with all the Instagram selfie takers.

Excellent all together ! Fantastic gardens with pools and running water, benches to sit, a nice cafe, amazing plant species in their full glory ! A true oasis . The Berber museum in the gardens also exquisite ! It is a pity photos are not allowed and no catalog exists in the shop. A very worthwhile visit!

We came here on a morning trip from La Palmeraie. It is absolutely beautiful both fir it’s planting and architectural touches. We had two small children with us (3 and 6) who found plenty to interest them.
review_title: A beautiful garden, shady and accessible, interesting for all ages

review_text: The garden was IMMACULATE. The blue walls and all the plants in the garden made it look like a little oasis. The fountains and blue walls are the perfect backdrop. I took a million pictures while I was there. It was almost too hard yo leave. The Pierre Berger museum was fantastic as well.

YSL is rolling in his grave, because this is not a tribute: the attitude of the guards is like a prison mentality. If you are a college student from the USA, be forewarned: they will not trust your ID. If you love YSL, please don't attend this tourist trip. Buy a nice piece of clothing, enjoy.
The most beautiful gardens, vibrant colours, peaceful and simply wonderful. We booked our tickets online. If you’re in Marrakech this is an absolute must……

It was a really pretty garden and I really enjoyed wandering round it but I would say it's perhaps over hyped because of the insta photo ops, the garden itself is actually quite busy and not that big. I would also say it seemed a bit too over policed in terms of being told off (very politely tbf) for walking the wrong way in an area that wasn't signposted - it just didn't create a relaxed atmosphere. It was pretty though.

Visited the Jardin on 8th of June 2023. When we're arrived whe heared we can online book tickets on line. After booking we had to wait for 2 hours. Very exotic plants for taking pictures in the background. Further nothing special at it, as we thought.
review_title: Exotic environment as background for pictures

review_text: A very pretty spot, just quite crowded with tourists taking photos.  Lots of nice places to take photos though and the shop was lovely.  We went at 3.00, so maybe if theres a quieter time be better to go then

The gardens are quite pretty but they were not the highlight of Marrakesh for us. There is so much more in the Medina to see and experience. But what really stuck out as this was at the end of our 10 day trip was how rude the security were from the second we got there. I understand it’s a tourist destination for sure but our driver tried to drop us off where he always drops off his people and the security outside was yelling at him and holding my door shut. It seemed overly aggressive as there wasn’t anyone waiting behind us. Outside they want your ticket but it was not clear where that ways. The first individual was super rude and just keep saying “that’s not your ticket, where’s the ticket.” Finally someone helpful did come over, for us connected to wifi and helped us get the tickets. Inside wasn’t much better. They were just very rude in how they told people things and it was a turn off. We wished we could have done the Berber museum but it wasn’t clear when buying tickets so we didn’t get to see that. We were done within an hour. The gardens themselves are not that large. I gave it a 3 because they are nice, cool, clean gardens but they could work ok some kindness in their manner of speaking with people. Everyone else we encountered in Morocco was incredibly kind.
Beautiful and the Berber Museum is fascinating.  Try to get there early, and buy tickets online before your visit

Over rated. Photos really make this look a million times better than it is. A very dry, arid garden without much to see. The buildings make a nice Instagram photo.. from a certain angle but other than that is just follow the crowds round a dry path..

On the first entry for the day.   No huge crowd….just 10 of us.   Security here was very professional , polite and thorough.  Sadly required as can be seen by the intentional damage that dumb visitors have caused to so,e of the succulents. Anyone who suggests this is a waste of time clearly has no appreciation of a beautiful garden in an agriculturally hostile county.  It has little to do with YSL “fandom” but the vision and fulfilment of a beautiful colourful and peaceful place which also offers a large local employment opportunity. Please! If you are a “tik tok” meme seeke  taking all the prime photo spots for several takes. If visiting be considerate! Take your photos and move on.

There is no doubt that these are beautiful and interesting gardens. They were very crowded,  but we were still able to enjoy the lavish planting and beautiful surroundings. The only problem was the behaviour of the security guards checking the tickets.  We were part of a mainly young photography group from many parts of Europe.  For some reason, the guard got it into his head that one of the young people had used her ticket before. This was impossible because we were part of an organised tour. Not only did he initially refuse entry, but he was threatening and extremely hostile during the encounter.  Luckily,  the tour leader remained calm and polite, and after a period of 30 minutes, she was finally let in. This spoilt the experience for us all.
review_title: Beautiful gardens spoilt by hostile and aggressive security staff

review_text: The colours made the whole garden. I would not have wanted to miss this experience. Definitely worth the two hrs, we were there.

You required to make an online booking for this popular attraction in Marrakech. The garden's atmosphere is a contrast to the bustling city, however was definitely filling up with tourists as the morning went by. You witness vibrant, well maintained and presented cactus, trees and succulents. There are many attendents which ensure you stay on the path and not get close to the plants. It is also a place to see people getting those Instagram shots and a challenge to not get anyone else in. It is worth checking out the museum and shop. Spent under 1.5hrs here.

Definitely a must go when in Marrakech. If you are staying in the centre then it’s about 35-40 minute walk or you can take a taxi for no more than 50dhs. You have to pre-book your slot online before you get there! We didn’t realise this but luckily got a 9am slot booked while stood outside at 8:45am! However all the later slots had been booked up! I would say book as early as possible, especially if you are going in summer. The temperature will be much cooler so you are able to wander around the gardens without being overheated and there will be less people. When we went there were a few tours groups already arriving but if you hang back and walk around at your own pace you can enjoy the gardens at your own leisure.

Beautiful experience.  The downside is the number of people, noisy and intrusive.
