You can hardly enjoy the beauty of the gardens with so many people milling about and cutting one another to go first.  Even shopping at th4 shops is a nightmare because of the number of people.  You cannot browse leisurely.

This is a definite must see when visiting Marrakech, but is also a definite must book as tickets are not available on the door. Even if you have a booking be prepared to wait in a queue well beyond your entry time as it is organised chaos. Once inside the garden it is quite small and there are a huge number of visitors at any one time, making photography very difficult. The planting scheme is very varied and the garden is well tended. The onsite Berber museum and shop are also worth a visit.

This place is an oasis of serenity in the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. Yves St Laurent did a great job with his creation - the layout of the plants, water features and meandering pathways is just gorgeous, and easy to spend an hour or so, just taking it all in. Heads up though - it's just been introduced that tickets have to be prepurchased online. Entry is allowed at half-hour intervals, to control the crowds

Great ambience in a beautiful setting with free wifi. From there it’s all downhill…. Breakfast option : Moroccan Breakfast Absolutely nothing else. Service: very traditionally French.  Re: 100% indifference. The staff have no warmth or hospitality at all. The food arrived relatively quickly. The omelette was well made. The bread (crepe)  was less appealing than burnt cardboard. Value for money? - No. 70 MAD for poor service with average food in a nice setting. I won’t come back and won’t recommend this place. It wasn’t a disaster but it wasn’t good or acceptable either.
review_title: Very average food with poor service.

review_text: Pretty place but max 30 mins and you're out. Amazing how something so pretty and very cool can be in a busy street so blooming hot
review_title: Visit to Yves Saint Laurent Museum and Gardens

review_text: Beautiful garden, and i would have given the museum and café 5 stars, but there is No good places to sit and relax In the garden, and you can only go one way around. For me that ruins the garden experience a little…
Awe-inspiring once in a lifetime trip, made amazing with a great group of people! it was a nice small group, excellent guide who provided us with lots.
perfectly kept gardens, very tranquil inside. numbers are kept to a sensible amount and have to book prior to visit, online only.
Don't know why everyone said to go there. If you're not a YSL fan, there seems little point. It was pretty, but very small and not worth the trouble.

a well-appointed all-inclusive hotel with good free transfer to Marrakesh although  you must take up your allocated return slot or catch a taxi £6-£10 Great food, good entertainment program throughout the day and evening. Recommended fro couples and families
Nice place but over tourism is back after Covid - what a pity. Too many people, even with the slot system they have.
review_title: Super nice garden but too crowded

review_text: The gardens weren't all that spectacular except for the collection of different cacti. You can roam the entire Gardens in about 20 minutes. It is not first in line, first entry as large tour groups will bump you. Guards weren't the friendliest, some even rude. It won't be the end of the world if you skip this during your Marrakech visit.
review_title: Just alright...skipable if you have other stuff to do.

review_text: So many photo opportunities in these beautiful gardens - go early to avoid the crowds. Make sure you book online before you go.

As soon as you pass the gates, you have the feeling that you have entered another world, so green and cool it is on a hot day... It's incredible, you can't believe that this lush vegetation is possible in Morocco. Huge Koi fish, water lilies, fountains, plants from all corners of the world, countless frames for wonderful photos. Yes, it is Heaven.

Make sure to come here during your stay in Marrakech as these gardens are absolutely stunning.  I was able to take pictures even with so many people walking around outside.  Go late in the afternoon for better lighting and fewer crowds.
review_title: Make sure to come to these gardens

review_text: The gardens are beautiful and the history of the gardens creation is just as lovely. Well worth a visit for a leisurely afternoon. Take a bottle of water as the walk around can take some time and there is nowhere to easily get refreshments until you are close to the exit.
Beautiful garden with many different type of plants.the gardens are awesome to visit.its a must to visit
Small garden but worth the visit.  My nephew took so many photographs, particularly of the frogs nestled around the ponds.  It was worth buying a timed ticket before visiting so avoiding the queues.
review_title: Prebook your timed ticket and avoid the queues

review_text: I very good time at the gardens in the city of Marrakech. This was a great experience for us as it was amazing

There's a lot to see packed in to this small garden. The plants though not native seem fitting for the Marrakech climate. The garden is beautifully maintained and easy to navigate. There are a few water features and structures providing visual interest. You must book in advance online. This is a very popular place with times entry! This is the only knock against the place, it's a bit pricy and you have to share with a lot of other tourists. If you're on a budget go next door to the cafe at the Maison de Marjorelle. This is a separate space and not as well curated as the gardens, but you can experience the structures and the flavor of the gardens for the price of a cup of mint tea.
review_title: A Lot In a Small Space

review_text: I love a garden and often make time to see them when I travel - that is not true of our larger group.  However, the lush gardens, the striking use of color and the architecture won over everyone.  This was a highlight for our entire group.
review_title: Stunning beauty.  An aesthetic highlight of our trip

review_text: Lovely garden with many types of plants, including cacti of all sorts. We enjoyed tea and delicious cookies in their garden cafe.
review_title: Pretty, peaceful spot to get away from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech.
writer_informations: Washington, District of Columbia, United States,73 contributions

review_text: A must-visit in Marrakesh if only for the photos you’ll take. We went at 8:30am and it was the perfect time, we got there a little late so we were let straight in rather than waiting outside for the timed entry. By far the best time to go in terms of both crowds and lighting, which was super pretty and great for photos! You might not spend long here, but you’ll get some great stuff for the team out of it. Definitely book in advance to avoid any issues! A taxi from the medina should cost more than 30dh but be prepared to haggle at peak times as they know it’s touristy.
Fantastic gardens in the city, great architecture and landscaping that from the hundreds of succulents, cacti and other exotic plants. Well worth a visit.

A lovely escape from the madness and heat of Marrakech. It’s relatively small and not on the scale or grandeur of other formal gardens you may have visited in the world but the Berber museum and gardens shop are good to see too. Queueing system is frustratingly over engineered and can leave you sweltering in the heat. Overall worth doing rather than not …. Just …

We were quite disappointed with the gardens. It turned out to be just not our thing. We were unsure whether to go but everyone we spoke to said we should go. It might have been because we walked around three miles each way in the blazing heat and then had to queue up for our time slot in the blazing sun but we thought it was a bit of a let down. It’s a nice little garden , it’s a green oasis with no flowering plants and it’s not very big. To have to share it with hundreds of other people with the same time ticket made it not enjoyable. It’s nicely looked after but it was the least enjoyable thing during our stay but then we are all different !

The gardens are wonderful to visit. Getting tickets is very easy on line and when at the gardens the lines are well organized and managed well. The garden is very well kept and even with lots of people , peaceful.

To be honest, it was quite underwhelming.. very instagrammable, so you’ll see a ton of ‘photoshoots’ going on, which can be annoying if you find yourself in a crowd. Apart from that, desert vegetation and serene environment.

The gardens are beautiful, very formal and not at all natural. Bright colours and amazing cacti. But it was  very busy and difficult to enjoy because of this.  It’s also fairly small which doesn’t help with the crowd. Not sure if there’s a quiet time to go but if possible go then. Also pre book as most slots were full

The gardens are nice but nothing exceptional.  Certainly not worth the price ($15 US) compared to other attractions in Marrakech.  You must buy tickets in advance and then wait in your que until your entry time.  Even with the controlled entry the gardens are extremely crowded and it is difficult to get any photos.  IMO there are much better ways to spend your time in Marrakesh.
review_title: Not worth the time or admission price.

review_text: We booked tickets online, you cannot just turn up and buy tickets you can only book online now. We booked for 9.30am. I would suggest getting the early tickets, whilst it is still busy it is easier to get around. The gardens are stunning, we thoroughly enjoyed our visit and enjoyed a drink in the cafe. There is a single ticket each which is 150 dirhams each just for the gardens (which we booked) there is a combined ticket you can choose to visit the YSL museum as well.
WOW - what a place. This garden is outside the median but not a bad walk. The gardens are just plain stunning. Very well worth visiting.

The small garden is not so small but also a very calm and interesting place.   Once you learn that the trees and plants are from all over the world it becomes more interesting.   You can just as easily enjoy the beauty, quiet within a big city or just find a quiet corner bench with sunt to relax.

The gardens are beautiful, but this place is a tourist trap. $15 entrance fee (must buy a timed ticket in advance online and then wait in a long line to enter). So crowded you can barely move. Just dodging people the whole time and can’t really enjoy the gardens. Don’t waste your time or money.

Corrupt guy managing the queue taking money for people to push in. Poor queue management at the best of times with people joining wherever. When challenged the guy doesn’t care. Management should Investigate
review_title: Corrupt queue management. Queue jumping.  Bad

review_text: The most amazing gardens we’ve seen considering it is in such an arid country. There were long queues to get in but the staff tried their best to help.  We saw plants, shrubs and trees we had never before encountered. The biggest bamboo ever and plenty of lovely succulents. The colours used enhanced the look of the gardens. A most wonderful experience.
The best time of day to view this popular garden is first thing in the morning or late afternoon. You need to book a time in advance.

It was a beautiful place to visit . After spending a few days visiting the craziness of the Médina area , this was a welcomed respite. The foliage & grounds were pretty & very well maintained. it was so cool & relaxing as the trees gave you lots of shade . Not very big . We were done seeing it all within an hour or so which is why I felt it  was a but expensive at 20€ & that’s not counting the YSL house & museum which would of been extra which we did not partake of .

I booked my ticket online a day before the  visit and chose the 820 am slot. The garden is about 15 min walk from my riad. When I arrived there was already quite a lot of people waiting but thankfully the waiting time wasn't too long got in about 10 mins later. Garden isn't very big but well maintained and had a small pond with koi and the centrepiece blue building which houses the berber museum. Definitely a must visit when in marrakech

Absolutely lovely!  Bright and colorful with many different areas to enjoy.  Go early!  We did but it quickly became crowded.  It really was hard to enjoy everything because everyone was posing and taking pictures.  Every way we turned we had to stop and wait to pass because of photo taking.  Many photo opps here and I understand but it was frustrating.  We stayed about an hour.
The garden is well kept and that's all.  Can´t by tickets on the spot, only online in advance.  Tourist trap in a certain way.  Didn't enter the Museum.  Nice cafe inside.

The jardin is beautiful but rather a victim of its own success and some of the staff have a bit of an attitude. Getting in can be a real ordeal, with officious police-like staff and a strictly timed and rather aggressive entry process which doesn't get things off to a good start… Book in advance, be prepared to queue even with pre-booked tickets and time your visit carefully so you're not shuffling slowly, looking at the back of fellow visitors' heads the whole time!

The gardens were gorgeous...many different types of plants, from cacti to succulents to palms and water lilies. An oasis of calm in Marrakech.  Beautifully cared for.  Gets very busy...you must buy tickets online.
review_title: A beautiful sanctuary in the middle of a busy city!

review_text: Very pretty relatively tranquil walk though it can get crowded fast. Difficult to take photos without someone in them, but a pleasant couple of hours spent. Berber museum was excellent! Cafe was slow to provide service. Food looked great but didn’t really measure up on taste. Be on time for your scheduled ticket! They are pretty much on time with entry!

This was our favourite visit of our 4 day trip to Marrakesh. However the guide books did not mention that you now need to book online in advance only. No tickets available at the site, so beware. 150d (about £12.50) per adult. Beautiful extensive gardens to wander with amazing variety of cacti and other plants. Shady and tranquil. Each entry group starts on the half hour, so wait a few moments on a bench once inside and relax and let them all pass you - then you get to stroll around and enjoy in relative peace! It is stunning with the huge plants contrasting against the painted buildings and manmade features. I would recommend at least 1 hour, but you could easily spend 2 hours or longer with a drink in the pretty cafe. We didn't visit either of the 2 museums which were charged extra.

This garden was a wonderful place to spend some time.  I throughly enjoyed the variety of cacti, snake plants, aloe vera plants, fruit trees and my favorite the Paperflower Tree.  Also note that the garden's security will be very alert in watching how you treat the place so don't touch anything.  I thought it was a bit much but when I saw the vandalism done to approx. 3-4 tall cactus trees I was heart broken and angry that someone would carve their names into the side of such a beautiful plant.  I didn't get to visit the Yves St. Laurent museum which is directly connected. Tickets do go quickly, maybe next time.
A marvellous collection of trees, palms, plants, cactuses and flowers. The finest Garden I have ever had the pleasure of visiting. A must for visitors to Marrakesh..

Yes, the garden itself is beautiful, but the crowds inside the garden meant that the atmosphere wasn't what a secluded garden should be. I suspect this was partly due to timing on our part. I would suggest booking for early morning, just after opening (or potentially late afternoon) when crowds should be lesser than those during the middle of the day.

We pre booked tickets for this venue as we were warned it would be very busy. Good job we did as there were people being turned away. Entry is in 30 minute time slots. So the queues built steadily, but we were admitted promptly into a cool garden of bamboo and palms, it was much bigger than we had thought and well worth the entry fee. We stopped for a mint tea and some water in the cafe, this was good but overpriced due to the location a d captive audience. The colours and tranquility of the gardens were amazing and I would definitely.put this at the top of a must see in Marrakesh list.

This is a lovely garden brimming with plants and colours and designs inspired by Yves San Laurent. We bought tickets in advance and we’re there for 9am but it was already busy. There is a lovely cafe within the gardens. Well worth a look and inexpensive to visit.
Excellent gardens clean environment and very organized. Buy the tickets online. Try to get there very early in the morning when they open.
review_title: Shooting experience in the middle of chaos of Marrakesh

review_text: This is a truly amazing garden! The perfect balance of the presentation is stunning at every turn. I believe that I have never seen better! Also loved the art deco studio.
fab wander round these stunning tropical gardens - bit of a one-way system and quite busy in places so queuing for photo opps, but lovely!
Underwhelming.. you have to queue for every photo opp. Whilst it's a pleasant garden it's not worth the wait. The best part was that there was plenty of shade.
Beutiful Gardens clean and tidy however overcrowded, long lines... even though you have to pre book a ticket with a time slot online and the staff by enlarge were unfriendly.

It was okay, but in reality there is not that much to see and there are always big crowds which makes it difficult to enjoy the scenery and take photos . The Berber women museum is very interesting . Beautiful colours and some very cool cacti plants .
beautiful garden, Berber museum is very interesting but the lines are long to get in so get there early if you can....
Pretty garden but relatively small and very little information about the plants. Felt more like a giant photo op than a learning experience.
review_title: Pretty garden that’s essentially a photo op

review_text: It is a nice garden with a lot of different cacti, but not really that special. To make it more interesting we did a photo challenge in our family.

A tranquil and beautiful oasis in the bustle of the city. Gardens are beautiful and very well kept. Not too busy to walk around as there is limited entry based on the time of your ticket (don’t be late!).  You really are there to see the gardens and main house (with small museum). Lots of history and a spectacle for the eyes.
Beautiful gardens - but the queues to get in (even when booked in advance) and the signposts giving the direction to walk in,  made the experience a trying one for this impatient rule breaker!
review_title: Like being in a long airport queue

review_text: Lovely garden but much better visitor control in terms of how many people can visit the site needs to be implemented.

Wasn’t good value for money, overpriced for what it is, we waited standing in the line for more than 1 hour to access, the garden it self is beautiful but very crowded and that was unpleasant, avoid the morning visit.

We thought that the Jordan measurer was quite overpriced for what you get, and certainly not the same amount of value. As for example the Secret Garden. Paying £35-£40 for less than one hour of crowds and admittedly nice gardens wasn’t brilliant value for money. There are other far better ways to spend your time and money in Marrakesh, and I’m amazed that this is number two of things to do in the city. There are additional charges to visit things like the YSL Museum, which may have added to more interest, but would have cost more, so I question the value of those too.
review_title: Nice enough, but not great value for money

review_text: A beautiful garden worth a visit.book the tickets in advance .we were here 9am to avoid the crowd.the park is very beautiful and well taken care.
Wonderful oasis and welcome escapism from the Medina and chaos of Marrakech. Truly magical gardens, huge cacti like I've never seen before amazing experience.
review_title: Magical escapism, truly jaw dropping and relaxing experience in this wonderful garden.

review_text: This garden dedicated by Yves St Laurent is a must see while in Marrakech There are beautiful walks and the colours are amazing, even the gift shop is beautiful.
The gardens are beautiful but crowded.  None of us felt this was worth the hype. Couldn't get a seat in the café or anywhere in the grounds for that matter.

Well worth a visit - the garden is relaxing even when busy! The Berber museum is small but very, very interesting with a great display of artefacts. We shared a delicious ice cream (Moroccan flavours) and Moroccan pastries at the café.

Such a lovely garden. It is a great shame that the many security guards around every corner of the garden spoilt the visit. They were far officious stopping people from touching the walls, putting a hand in the water. You have to go round the garden in a set route and could not retrace your steps even a few paces to take a photograph as the guards stopped you and ordered you to walk around the whole garden again! What should have been a lovely relaxing visit turned into a march!
review_title: Not as relaxing as you first think

review_text: Lovely garden, best visited in the early afternoon to escape the heat and wander through many shaded areas. Make sure to buy a combined ticket with the Berber Museum which is a definite highlight of the visit. Nice cafe for a rest.
review_title: Scenic garden with great Berber Museum

review_text: Absolutely worth your while to visit this gem in the center. Attached was the Berber Museum, shops and a restaurant. Just a fantastic afternoon spent in the gardens and loved it. A must see. Have to book on line for tickets. Separate tickets for the garden and museum. Lines were a little long  timed entrance. Weekends are even busier. Staff very nice.
review_title: Trip to the gardens in Marrakech

review_text: My wife and I booked our visit online which has to be done prior your visit. There are allocated time slots. Be prepared to queue when you arrive - you will be placed into a queue line relevant to your booking time. There is some shade from the trees  and cooling spray mist whilst queuing. When you enter the gardens you immediately notice how quiet it is. You are guided around a set route from beginning to the end, although there is no pressure for you to keep moving - you can sit and just take in the lovely gardens. There are many  varieties of flowers, plants and cactuses from all around the world. There are toilets available if needed. We paid to enter the Berber Museum which is within the grounds, and I'm so pleased that we did. The costumes and jewellery displays were amazing. We had a lovely lunch in the cafe and I would say the food was very good - be prepared to wait for a seat. In summary the gardens are beautiful with YSL tributes everywhere and well worth the visit.

The security guards were rude and obnoxious. Mr Youes Chaabet demanded a ticket for my child which we were happy to pay. We paid online and were able to show the transaction. The email with the ticket code did not come due to slow internet. He harassed us into paying again and again. Wasted our time. Cursed us in his language and ruined the whole evening of my birthday. My child is 10…. So much for the experience. Very unhelpful, rude and completely not needed the harassment. I hated the experience and the place!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!.
Wonderful gardens with a high sense of peace and calm. Lines can be long but well worth the visit.. it was much smaller than I thought.

Nice place but smaller than I expected. Not sure it's worth the queues - be warned this isn't somewhere you can just turn up you really need to pre-book an entry time. That said with a pre-booked time slot it's worth a visit, pretty gardens to wander around probably spend an hour here. If your a photographer lots of nice photo opportunities.

Wonderful gardens. So well set out and although busy we still found a sense of peace and calm .  We saw Koi Carp, terrapins and frogs amongst water lillie covered ponds. inspirational and great photo opportunities.    Please book online in advance as lines  can be long and you will be disappointed to miss this  A highlight of our trip
review_title: A beautiful retreat in hectic Marrakesh

review_text: Nice Gardens but over rated for what it is. There are many nicer gardens in Marrakech. The YSL museum is small and was not particularly interesting, with the exception of one room of the dress designs. The Berber museum was the best exhibit here.
review_title: Average Gardens, crowded and not worth the wait.

review_text: I really loved the cactuses, so many different and so enormous. The garden is not very big, it was much smaller than I thought. Needless to say, it is packed with people. The Berber museum was slightly disappointing. You have to buy tickets online to get in.

The gardens themselves are beautiful, and the contrasting blues and yellows of the architecture against the plants looks lovely. It’s just too busy. People everywhere queuing up to get their perfect Instagram shot. You are forever trying not to be in the way of someone’s photo. I’d read it was better to arrive early, we got 9:30am tickets and I dread to think what it’s like during their ‘busier’ times! Staff, particularly security staff outside, were amongst the least friendly people we’ve met in Marrakech, very much there for crowd control. It’s nice to see, but I think it’s too touristy to recommend and we left relatively quickly.
review_title: Too busy to be an oasis in the city…

review_text: What a wonderful and enchanting piece. The place is an a array of pure plants, trees and bamboo paradise which has an real essence of charm and satisfaction. Yves Saint Lauren private garden is tasteful yet beautiful layers of cactus to blooms of hedge row flowers. The bright blue and yellow house and bridges give a wounded compliment to its surroundings. This very well maintained garden is a joy but que early as it gets busy.
review_title: A beautify within the heart of old city

review_text: Must see attraction but ticket is a bit overpriced and so many security guards in the attention.  Suggested that everyone needs to queue up as some with tour guide just skipped the line.

While in Marrakech we visited the Jardin Majorelle and Berber Museum. The gardens were delightful and the museum was interesting. The biggest disappointment was the gift shop. There was nothing inexpensive to buy! Lovely leather purses, beautiful silks but not affordable. Not even a post card!
we came here twice on two separate tours and we were just as wowed by the beautiful scenery the second time as we were the first. the berber museum was interesting too.

The gardens were beautiful and well worth the visit. Visited the cafe and very disappointed that the waiter tried to knowingly short change us by 100 MAD, then only to get angry with us for not tipping us after he tried to short change us.

The garden is quite small and aside from the blue building and arches there really isn't much more to it aside from a few cactus and exotic plants. It gets very crowded so expect to wait in line for a while at your entry time before you actually get in. Perhaps social media may have boosted the popularity so it in turn there is a lot of footfall meaning essentially having to que to take pictures at each of the iconic spots. The berber museum is unbelievably tiny and you get ushered through at speed so probably spent no more than 5 minutes in there. Also there are barely descriptions and captions in English, so if you are not a fluent French speaker, good luck. If you run into any issues, the staff are generally rude and unhelpful. I purchased a ticket for both the gardens and berber museum for my party. Entry to the garden was fine however we were refused entry to the museum on the basis that out tickets had allegedly been used before. The guard at the door was rude and unsympathetic treated us like criminals and would not assist us in any way not even allowing us to take a picture of the error message to investigate further with the company we booked with. It definitely put a dampner on the day and eventually after 15mins of being held outside he let us in however we had to board our coach in 5 minutes so it was pointless. Advice: book everything directly and book transport seperately as there are many companies looking to scam and charge a premium for tourists desiring convenience through booking packages. Overall as I said the gardens are nice, but don't expect too much or more than you see in pictures as that is really all there is to it. I am sure there are more exciting gardens to explore in Marrakech such as Le Jardin Secret but unfortunately I found this out too late in my trip.

There is a lot of hype about Jardin Majorelle. If you are into these things, it is understandable that reviews are good (although I believe that this is 100% related to name association). The no bag rule was very, very inconsitently practiced and the no credit card rule has no place in Morocco. It is a hyped elitist place which could have been anywhere in France

No doubt of its type one of the finest desert gardens in the world. If that is your biscuit. Cacti and drought lovers. But there is a but. To this English reviewer used to verdant green and watery colours and shapes it looks a tad dull and sterile.Chacun a son gout. Nevertheless it is beautifully curated, and the very large number of visitors are shipped though efficiently if a little soullessly.Really a must for those who like this sort of garden.
Beautiful, relatively quiet garden although obviously very popular with visitors.  ASlthough it is not enormous, the planting is very clever and we loved it.

I have visited here several times before, this time it was very different. Firstly, had to book tickets in advance, which I’ve never had to do before. Then had to queue to be let in. Saw literally dozens of people being turned away. Time limit on length of stay. It was so busy. Would have liked to get chance to sit and chill out, but this wasn’t possible.

The garden is overpriced and underwhelming.  It's full of lots of non-native plants - like bamboo and cacti - that you could see anywhere.  The blue paint used on the building and pools is pretty and makes this place Instagrammable, which is probably why it's so popular.  Given the price, you'd be better off exploring some of the city parks and other gardens.  I also visited the Berber museum inside the garden, which was interesting, but very small and lacked English signage explaining the displays.
A cactus garden with a very blue house in it. Maybe we see a lot of the same plants as we live in California.

Book the gardens before you visit. Don't do as we did and expect to pay at the entrance. There is a QR scan on the outside of the Gardens, however it is extremely popular so a time slot is not immediately available. Giving cash to someone who claims they can get you in is not recommended. If you do have a time slot be prepared to queue in the heat of the sun. Sun hats and water in the queue highly recommended. The shops in the area are high end as you can imagine. Taxis are very plentiful. You will be asked outside the Gardens if you want a taxi, you will be asked every two seconds
beautiful garden.this is a must to visit when in marrakech.we booked this online to avoid the queue.well kept garden,

We visited at 11am. We did pre book tickets however you will still have to queue for entry at your allocated time slot.  I would recommend to definitely book in advance. Earlier the better! The gardens are beautiful and peaceful to sit in. It is a world away from the busy medina. However the gardens did started to get crowded as it hit lunch time. It is not huge so this is a nice morning activity, but not all day. There is a cafe onsite.

In my opinion, this is a complete rip-off. The gardens are indeed, very beautiful but very small. For a considerably less money you can see equally beautiful gardens of the Jardin Secret. Oh, you can go to one of the many beautiful parks and gardens that are carefully curated by the city and are completely free to get in. For example, crypto Park, which, despite its name is utterly delightful. The number of tourists allowed on each visit to Jardin Majorelle detract from the experience. On the day I visited I had paid both for a visit to the gardens and also to the museum. I was part of the last visit of the day, but no one told me on entrance that I needed to be at the Museum door before 4:30 pm. There was a huge group of Spanish tourists, who not only blocked pathways, slowing down the floor around the gardens, but also took up the museum. Ali visit allocation of 30 people. At 4:30 pm I was at the Museum door, but was told there were no more visits that day. I didn’t get a refund or even an apology! As advised by the workers, I contacted the Directa by telephone. Despite kindly impolitely explaining my disappointment and requesting a refund, they put the phone down on me. My recommendation is, save your money and go to one of the alternatives.

Lovely early morning spot to explore. Beautiful gardens and cafe worth a visit for the Moroccan tea. Definitely visit the YSL museums too. We took a taxi there and then had a still back to medina afterwards was about 15 mins
review_title: Ideal for an early morning visit

review_text: This place is absolutely gorgeous! I chose the first slot of the day and there was a very light rain that morning so it didn't get busy for quite a while. If you are interested in gardens in any capacity, this is a sight that you cannot miss. I didn't eat at the cafe, but I did shop and prices were reasonable. I also visited the Berber museum (which is extremely small but worth the price). The fashion museum was closed during my visit, but the garden contains a memorial to Yves Saint Laurent, and his ashes were scattered here.

Great my fav although preferred the secret garden not so busy and more chill for food etc however this was so pretty and lots of tourists instagrammers getting pics taken in pretty dresses etc but all in all lovely garden great weather but busy

Firstly you have to book online, including a time slot, it's easy enough.  On arriving you wait in an area allocated to your time slot.  Your ticket is checked and people enter a few at a time.  It's very well organized.  Large backpacks have to be handed in, it's secure.  There is a partial one way system, but no signs to tell you that.  The "guards" will turn you back at times.  They are friendly enough.  Once inside you can stay as long as you want, although it is difficult to spend more than 45 minutes in there. The gardens are very beautiful, but there are not many flowers, just lots of cactus, palm trees and bamboo.  At approx €15, I feel it is somewhat overpriced for what you get.

I’ve only visited the “ garden “ part not the ysl museum . There are lines to take pictures and the attendance rush you. It’s several people at a time trying to take a picture in a small area, then they rush you out. It’s barely a garden, it’s a walkthrough of bamboo. Save your money ! I wish I did .
Overrated especially when it can take days to get a time slot to visit. A large succulent garden with bamboo trees. We did not do the Yves SL museum as the garden was underwhelming.

Vising the jardin was a nice break from the busyness of our stay in Marrakech. It does get crowded and we did have to wait in line to purchase access so plan accordingly. The garden hosts a variety of plants and fruits, and is well-maintained. We enjoyed the exhibits on the Berber groups, which I found to be the most educational on the topic during my stay in Morocco. There's definitely photo ops if you're into that, but since it's pretty touristy make sure to allow time for that. After our visit we had some tea in the cafe within the place before continuing our itinerary, which I felt was a nice end to the viist.

Queued for 30 minutes, even with pre-booked tickets. One-way system in operation when inside. Very clean and well maintained. A couple of good photo opps. An oasis of calm. Not much to read. Over-priced.

Spent a beautiful morning wandering the gardens and it did not disappoint. We got purchased tickets in advance and chose an early time in the morning when it was less crowded and not as hot. The gardens and colors are everything you’ve read about. I also recommend the addition of the Berber Museum section lots to learn there. We also made a stop in the shop on the way out and bought a gorgeous leather tea box.
It was nice inside, but felt like they just took some palm trees from the local park and stuck them inside and had me pay for them.  A little underwhelming

Beautiful garden and setting. Make sure you book your timed entry in advance. They have just instituted this recently. Book for earlier in the day as the end of day time slots don’t allow enough time to see the museum too and you can’t buy the combo ticket . This happened to us. I was disappointed to not be able to tour the museum.
review_title: Make sure you book your timed entry in advance. Book earlier in day so you can see garden and museum.

review_text: The gorgeous and Instagramable Jardin Majorelle is a must-visit garden in Marrakech, especially for those with limited time. As a heads up, it's important to book in advance and arrive on time for your visit. Additionally, staff can be a tad extra for no particular reason. Exp. couldn't stand a small tripod on the floor to take pictures.
review_title: Instagramable But Staff Could Be Nicer

review_text: We visited here 2 times and we love this place, I booked it on Viator. was nice and cool my hotel was near by and it was jst 2 mnts walk
The gardens were nice and clean.The staff were not friendly at all and they were impolite.Very crowded place . We had to wait at the line for a long time.
Hardly a flower to be seen Lovely cactus and palm tree Does not take long and you need to book and queue Personally won’t have bothered but a contrast from the hustle and bustle

The visit is well organised in time slots, there’s a restaurant at the gardens and more near the entrance. Book online beforehand. There’s a lot of posing for photos going on so be patient. The plants are beautiful. Well worth a visit.
A pure aesthetic delight..a small but significant design masterpiece that makes it among the top sights of Marrakech.
beautiful well-kept garden with too much security, to be reserved online in advance. Not cheap for Morocco

As a lover of gardens, I went in with a lot of expectations, which were not met. While the gardens are well maintained, I don’t think there was anything special about them. It may be more pleasant in less crowded conditions, but I would not recommend visiting during high season. The Berber museum was small, but had an interesting collection.

We bought the combined ticket so we had entry to the garden, the shop and the Berbermuseum. It was rather disappointing for 30 Euros per person. We walked through a  tiny park with huge cactuses, bamboo and some trees. In 15  minutes you have seen it. We entered the tiny museum and saw the Berber craftwork- the text to it was in French. In 10 minutes we were out. So if you want to pay 30 Euros for seeiing some huge cactuses in a garden that has a historical connection to Yves Saint Laurent, then don"t be surprised you pay mostly for the name!
Beautiful gardens and a berber museum.  Very crowded when I was there, I think I would have enjoyed it more at a less crowded time.
Very busy, some interesting bits but not sure what all the fuss is about. A little disappointing to be honest. Too many security guards spoil the ambiance.

This is a beautiful garden in the heart of Ville Nouvelle. This was the first attraction we visited in Marrakech. You have to book tickets online. If possible get there early. We booked for 11am and it was fairly busy. Entry also includes the Berber Exhibition, long queue, but well worth it. Stunning display of Berber art and culture. The entry also includes the Yves St Laurent exhibition. Not really my thing, but never the less an impressive collection of his work, including drawings and outfits.
Amazing stop - loved the museum.  The ticketing process however left much to be desired.  The online booking was misleading.
Beautiful garden in a very human setting.  Not so large as to be intimidating but more thoughtful and feels private.
A Fabulous place full of amazing plants, colourful buildings and local history. Not to be missed.  Grab a mint tea in the tea rooms to soak up the atmosphere

Not worth the high price which they’ve increased 3x and horrible ticketing system that no one of the staff seem to understand, let alone the guests. Plus it’s just not worth it in general for your time or money. See the courtyard tea room which is free, get your photo and then leave. Avoid anything with a ticket.
review_title: Not worth it and horrible ticketing system

review_text: The colors of this garden are astonishing and it has a range of plants from all over the world.  It located a bit far away from the touristic area so you probably will need a taxi to get there. The reasonable price to get there from the Medina is maximum 5 euros, so ask the driver before you enter the taxi how much it is gonna cost in order to not get scammed.

We bought tickets online and the day before and could only get 8am slots. We took a taxi from the medina for 100 dh and paid the 150 each (foreigner price more than double the local price). We walked around it for maybe 1/2 & that was stretching it. Then we had to haggle for a 80 dh taxi ride back. Don’t waste your time. We felt bamboozled as it was regarded as a must see, we’re pretty sure it’s a tourist marketing ploy. Nothing else is open that early so nowhere else to go but the hotel.

Book one of the earlier slots if you can. the later in the day the busier it seems to get. The selection of flora and fauna in the garden is astounding and that blue color just pops - but there were people EVERYWHERE!!!
An extraordinary garden withwell tended plants and an artful ensemble witha very accurate organization.
review_title: the most beautiful place in town

review_text: Very nice place in Marrakesh. Exotic garden. Very beautiful, adorable garden with stylish design. Friendly staff. Nice museum.

I can't believe that such an ordinary place is rated so highly or dubbed "must-see" in Marrakesh. The city has so much more to offer than this overly hyped, overpriced, and overly crowded hangout places. It's a great experience (and perfectly fine) if you are into getting dressed for the summer catwalk and taking a ton of pictures but otherwise please save time for all the other fun things that the lovely city offers. You have to buy timestamped tickets and show up exactly at the time and then wait in line despite buying timestamped tickets!  I would rather not disrupt my itinerary to fit this in my short period but unfortunately, it was sold to us as a must-see. The gardens in Bahia palace should suffice if one is looking to incorporate nature into their itinerary.

It's wonderfully colorful - very full always with lots of people, that's my only downside.  You show up for your timed entrance and then there is a line to get in.  It takes a while to process the tickets and it's another line to wait in!
review_title: Adorable but small so it is crowded

review_text: We missed seeing the garden which was our first choice, but we could see glimpses from the street and it looked gorgeous.  We went in the Musee de Yves St Laurent and had a drink in the cafe instead.

A bit disappointed with this to be honest. It's a 30 minute walk from the center of Marrakech or a short taxi ride so easy to get to but is in a busy area so not a retreat from the full on intensity of the Medina. Booking on line is essential as you can't walk up and get in. When you are in its too small and overcrowded to enjoy. The flora is impressive and the Berber artifact is interesting up to a point. If you don't speak French or Arabic you won't know what most of it means though and there is just to little going on to justify the £30 combined ticket cost per head. The association with Yves St Laurent is interesting but not really explored. The cafe was the best thing thrre

I was there during off-season, you reserve and pay for tickets online, so be sure to have a cell with internet, there was a half hour wait, so a relatively easy entrance.   But the staff were not as friendly as in all the others places I visited, I think they are just exhausted from all the questions about how you get the tickets, where you stand in line, etc.   I imagine in high season it's a bit chaotic.   And yes, the gardens are beautiful, but so are all the other gardens, including some public ones that have no entry fees and lines.   The museum was closed on the day of our visit - I imagine its worth a visit, but really don't know.  If your visit is only to see the gardens and the lines are too long, skip it, you haven't really missed anything.
review_title: Beautiful, but was expecting more, so maybe a bit overrated

review_text: Tickets must now be bought in advance online for a specific time, which on the other hand prevents all the wait at the door. Garden is good but small, and certain spots can be crowded by photographers or selfie takers.

I would have rated higher but this was let down by the significant queues ( even though pre-booked  tickets) . We had booked the 3 centre ticket but could get into the Berber museum having given up waiting after 20 minutes with no shift in the queue.the gardens are beautiful but just too many people to fully enjoy the views

Most importantly - you have to book online before you go. We just turned up on the day and had to book for a different day as the bookings were full. It is peaceful, excepting the many tourists wandering round, and the plants are of interest if you look closely. Most visitors seem to have come because of Yves Saint Laurent and many dress up in the blues and yellows of the colour scheme - very amusing! It is quite expensive compared with other attractions in Marrakech and the garden area is not large. The café immediately next door to the gardens is a better place for a coffee than the café on site.
review_title: Quite a different vibe from the rest of Marrakech

review_text: Beauty and serenity combine in this lovely (previously) YSL-owned sanctuary. Unique look and feel, you will be treated to lush landscapes, calming water features, unique vignettes and outdoor spaces and a lovely boutique. Located in the middle of the city, this attraction is easily reachable by taxi, but buy tickets online and go early to avoid the crowds!

For a garden enthusiast, I was really looking forward to seeing this site, especially as it is #2 of things to do in Marrakesh on the Trip Advisor site. Having booked ahead for 2.30pm a Tuesday afternoon we had to queue for 25 minutes before being allowed in, then shuffled around the surprisingly small area along with 100’s of other visitors. It took us precisely 20 minutes, which didn’t represent any kind of value for money. Some of the cacti were interesting but I felt distinctly underwhelmed overall. Don’t expect anything much and you won’t be disappointed like we were.

We booked tickets online well in advance but we had to still line up in the hot sun for 20 minutes. The gardens are well maintained and the colour palette is lovely. The only downside was one security guard said backpacks were not permitted which is not noted anywhere on the website, not on the booking and certainly no guidelines written clearly at the entrance plus there were plenty other visitors with backpacks. When we pointed all this out, the guard backed off. A little ridiculous in my opinion.

The hype surrounding this garden must be due to YSL's name. The garden is actually small and without the Majorelle Blue paint, there would be nothing to recommend it. Instagrammers are all over this place and there was an actual fight between them when I visited. Personally I didn't feel it was worth the admission fee or the discomfort of so many people to wade through. The gift shop is nice though. If you want a real garden, go to Anima Garden.
Long orderly queues.  Short visit. Interesting garden mainly consisting of bamboo trees,. Very peaceful feeling.,

The garden is small and unusual, mostly cactuses from the Americas! It’s a lovely respite from the hubbub of the city. The museum with Berber artifacts is small but exquisitely curated. The objects are top quality and well displayed. The gift shops are fabulous! The merchandise is top quality and surprisingly reasonably priced, especially the leather goods and jewelry.

You have to pre book on line and around 400 people allowed in at any one time so huge queues outside for their alloted time slot.  Yes, they are quite unique, particularly for Marrakech with amazing colours but i dont like the regimentary style of guiding you round the pathways and if you dare to go a slightly different route the sullen security guards issue a sharp "non".  And queues of people waiting to get the "perfect" picture.  And very overpriced for what it was.  Worth going but not a "must see"
review_title: Underwhelming and expensive - a designer garden with designer prices

review_text: The gardens were absolutely stunning! The area outside was very crowded, however, the security spoke flawless English and were extremely helpful. Inside, the gardens were very well maintained and we had a wonderful time.

We loved this garden because although it was busy the design meant you could take pictures without anyone in them so it appears as if you are there on your own. The colours are joyous and we enjoyed learning about the history. The fact that proceeds from the gardens go to such worthy causes is the best reason to visit.

Overcrowded & a bit chaotic to enter. The garden is ok but not “must see.” It was a large home surrounded by a desert garden among normal apartment buildings in Marrakesh. It was a getaway home for a famous fashion designer. Tickets overpriced for what it is. I was there in February and it was overcrowded. During the high season it must be unbearable.
review_title: Underwhelming, crowded & not cheap. Nice pics.

review_text: The gardens are nice, but the area is too small, too expensive for what they offer. You can buy tickets only online, which is something we didn't know. When we got there, the staff informed us about it. When tried to buy tickets online, they had available after 4 hours, so we had to change our program, visit other places and come back again. So buy your tickets before you go there and be there earlier, since there is a long queue!! For the gardens you need max 30 minutes!

Definitely book in advance and yes it will be busy!  Worth it though - lovely tranquil walk amongst the fabulous 2 acre landscaped garden using bright yellow and cobalt features. You can even leave your bags/coats in a secure area whilst you visit. Definitely recommend.
review_title: Worth a visit- even when busy

review_text: My Mom and I visited here on the last day in Marrakech. I purchased our tickets ahead of time and it was definitely a time saver. We enjoyed the beautiful and breathing gardens. The Berber museum, while small, was educational. I loved the organized flow due to the high volume of visitors.

The gardens are absolutely stunning. It was smaller than I expected given the price. You could walk round it in as little as ten minutes or stretch it out for much longer. You must buy tickets online, and when you get there, you queue behind a sign saying what time you have booked for. All the people who have booked that time are let in together, so it is busy and quite crowded.

A real shame that you have to book online and there is NO opportunity to purchase a ticket with cash on the day. Annoying that WiFi is not great so you are told to cross the street to log in and book. BE WARNED that students MUST have identity card. It is beautiful but marred by ticketing system.
Beautiful and interesting garden. Peaceful haven away from the frantic atmosphere of Marrakesh. Easy walk from the centre of the city.

It's 10 years since I last visited the Majorelle, and the experience doesn't get any better - despite visiting on an overcast day, the blue of the walls still popped against the sky and the green plants, and the water pools were a calming influence compared with the chaos outside the gates. Make sure you go as early as possible, and book your entry before you arrive, as that helps you sidestep the queues, which can build up quickly
review_title: Tranquility in the chaos - but go early!

review_text: Do not take the taxis that are near by, they attempt to charge more than double.   We wanted to go to the square, we new it cost as much 20, they were asking for 50, so we took a taxi in the main avenue (just walk 1 corner). The Garden nice, also has nice are to take a tea and maybe some sweet. Go early, I was at 8:30, 1h after started to be crowded. When I left it was queue outside.  I would recommend even go at 8:00.
review_title: nice garden but avoid taxis near by

review_text: Some way out of centre, and online entry tickets now required for all visitors. But experience was rather soulless and disappointing.

Great experience walking around the gardens first thing in the morning. We were able to enjoy it without bumping into others with cameras and appreciated seeing the garden in the early morning light. It was a very peaceful experience. I recommend getting a ticket for when the gardens open in the morning - by the time we left around 10:30 there was a long line to get in. We also really enjoyed the small Berber museum on site as well. The jewellery collection was so lovely and the presentation is fabulous.

This was a total waste of time. The place was small and resembled the car park of an Ikea store. The security staff were dreadful, there were dozems of them doing nothing apart from posing in their ludicrous uniforms. On advice, we queued for an hour before our allotted time, then still had to wait another 45 minutes to get in. We had an 80 year old in a wheelchair and a 4 year old child...they did not give a monkeys. We presumed it was becuase it was busy....no, it was not, it was just French arrogance in the door staff, they 'believed' this was some exclusive Parisien night club and they wanted to make you wait. They wanted queues as it created mistique. The place overall was nothing. Don't waste your time...we were only there for a few days and we all regret going there.

We were booked for 12:30- 1:00pm. Marrakech traffic (as it was a holiday) was pretty awful. Arrived just before 1:00pm. By the time we found where to go it was 1:02pm. The people on the gate not only refused us entry ( I accept we were 2 minutes after allotted time), but were downright rude and nasty about it. Upset my young daughter how aggressive they spoke to me. In m own country, I’d have created a fuss.. but being a foreigner I accepted their horrible attitude and walked away quietly. My advice… It may be beautiful (I’ll never know), but don’t give this place your time or money.. there are so many beautiful friendly places and people In Marrakech.. this place is not one of them.
Very nice time spent at these well kept gardens. You need to book online at least 24 hours in advance

We booked before we arrived in Marrakesh and that was necessary.  The Gardens are outside the old city walls but easy to find.  They restrict numbers coming in into 30 minute blocks but once inside you are not under pressure to leave.  The Gardens have a Cafe & Toilets that were fine and the grounds were immaculately maintained.  Well worth a visit.
review_title: An unexpected gem of a location

review_text: A beautiful garden in the middle of Marrakech. Get there early and purchase your ticket early to ensure entry.
review_title: Beautiful garden in the middle of Marrakech.

review_text: We were here as the garden opened and enjoyed our time wandering thru admiring all to take in.   The memorial to YSL and Pierre very quiet area in the garden. Well worth coming here as many plants not seen before.

Tried to visit this supposedly ‘must see’ garden in Marrakesh. Terrible organisation. The queues were huge and when you arrive you’re told that you have to book tickets on-line. Directed to a crowded wifi- zone outside the entrance but the signal is very poor and the wi fi keeps dropping out. This was at 10:30am in low season and the earliest tickets available for the same day were 13:30pm. Kept losing WiFi signal, payment kept failing so we gave up trying. Visited the Jardin Majorelle cafe instead.  Drinks were nice but service was poor. Had to ask three times for the bill and still didn’t get it. Had to go and pay at the till (which they didn’t like). When we left the cafe the door was closed to visitors because the place was too full. Overpriced for what it is. Not a pleasant experience. Took a taxi to walk around the free and peaceful Menara Gardens instead. The Secret Garden (Jardin Secret) within the Medina is lovely and a much better experience. It’s also cheaper but go early to avoid the queues.
Good place to spend an hour or two and to take some pictures. Need to buy tickets and schedule time/date online ahead of time.

In our recent experience Marrakech is generally inot wheelchair friendly ,whatever you may read. The Majorelle gardens were an exception. Well laid out  and welcoming. Lovely wheelchair friendly visit

This was disappointing. We were hoping for beautiful gardens to spend some quiet time in, but. there are crowds of people and you are shuttled along a pathway with little time to stop and look, and very few photo opportunities because of all the instagrammers. It's a shame, because it could be a real oasis but feels more like a disney-esque tourist trap.

Great, great, great! Please purchase ticket before arrival online. This is the only way you get the ticket. We visited in february, low season I guess and at the arrival purchased tickets online. Had to wait only 1 hour, but I think people who arrived later, had to wait longer or had to postpone visit to other day. I guess 1 hour is enough to enjoy all the plants and views.
I didn’t arrive with high expectations and it is a small garden, but it really is a place of utter calm and tranquility. I could easily have spent the entire day sat there with a book - beautiful.
Worth going to but buy tickets online in advance and be prepared to queue to get in even with the pre-booked ticket.

I was very excited since everyone said, "you must see the gardens"... very touristy, plants were nice, wished there had been some flowers. Many "influencers?" blocking areas trying for the perfect shot became annoying. Didn't make it to the museum. The cafe was nice and the sandwich I had was good and not too pricey.
review_title: Def a tourist place I could have skipped.

review_text: It was one of the best places we visited in Marrakech, amazing garden, very clean. Had a great virgin cocktail and a great time. Quite crowded for extrasezon. You need to buy your ticket online and are very serious about you showing them the ticket on email not a photo.
review_title: A great place to visit in Marrakesh

review_text: Fantastic gorgeous oasis. Marvelous grounds, shop, museum, restaurant  highly recommended. A must visit.
Magnificent layout and selections of Flora and Fauna in this garden blended so well. The natural colour mix  and decor was  magical and so vibrant . Entrance fee expensive but worth a visit.

We visited here in January on a rainy day and it was still pretty busy so I'd imagine it would be crazy on a nice day on the summer so be prepared for a queue. The cost for two to enter the garden was around £30, so not cheap. The garden itself is beautiful with bamboo and palm trees among many others as well as the unique blue coloured buildings. There is also a cafe and toilets within. Personally overpriced for what it is and you'll need to dodge all the "insta" photography constantly but if you can ignore all that the gardens are stunning.
review_title: Beautiful garden at a premium price

review_text: We visited this garden, not able to get a peak as all the walls are quite high. On entering into the sprawling expanse of plants from all over the world and the Majorelle blue accent walls, this poses photo opportunities for the young ones. There was an additional charge for entry into the Berber Museum.  This should have been included in the total entry prices

Stunning garden and home lovingly restored by Yves and Pierre. Unfortunately the house -- now a museum of YSL was closed between exhibitions. But nonetheless a treat to walk around and also visit the Berber museum.

Lovely gardens in Marrakech. Cacti, palms and bamboo create lovely shaded oasis. Museum gives flavour of Berber people. Cafe in nice tranquil courtyard and neighbouring upscale shops make this a very desirable place to visit if you are staying in Marrakech. (Neighbouring YSL museum currently closed Feb 23 for renovation - reopens next month).

Very nice garden but very small, over priced and from all the hype I feel it is over rated... we got a taxi from the main Jemaa-el-fna Square to the gardens for 50Dm.  You must book tickets online, so best to do so in advance so get the time slot you want. Huge queues but reasonable well organised. The gardens although very nice are rather small and pristine.... it seems to be more about photo opportunities than the plants.....  I felt it was more like a theme park..... The restuarant was very pleasant with a nice menu all sensibly priced considering the venue. In summary, it's just an over priced tourist attraction that should be called "The Instagram Garden" !!!!

It's one of the must see destinations in Marrakech and rightly so. They operate an online booking only system. There is WiFi available by the entrance so that you can book online but I'd recommend pre booking. I found the WiFi hit and miss. Paid 50 Dirahms each way for taxi from Jemma el Fanaa square. May have been able to negotiate a slightly lower rate but I'm a tourist so small overpayment is acceptable. The cafe is well worth a visit too. It's a garden so how long you want to spend is up to you, but it's not a very large area, so an hour should suffice.
It was a nice garden but overrated for what it was. Mainly an opportunity to get Instagram pictures for most visitors I saw there.

I'm not mad on gardens but a pleasant place to spend an hour or so. Best to book on line and chose a time. Some people try to get in early but the security guards check your ticket and kick you out of the queue, which goes down quickly when the cheeky people are removed ! The cafe is excellent with good reasonable priced food.

Long lineup for nothing - Only two counters were opened but one of them was for garden entry only.  Lined up for 1/2 hour,  honestly nothing really special about the garden.  Long lines for all the IG photo spots.  We only spend 1/2 hour inside the garden.  Not really worth it.  Nothing really special

These gardens are lovely and the museum is very interesting. It’s a limited variety of plants and not very big - it was also extremely busy so not exactly the relaxing break from the busy city. There are plenty more garden spaces within the city that might offer the same/similar. The queuing wasn’t particularly well organised, and fairly manic. Slightly out of the way, so perhaps not worth making a special trip to see, unless you’re nearby,

What a disappointment! At 200 dh each (including the Berber Museum), this is an extremely expensive attraction. The high cost has apparently paid for an excessive number of officious staff policing the gardens. There is a strict one way system which takes away from what could be a relaxing experience in beautiful surroundings. It's a real shame that what could be a lovely place to visit has been ruined by the way that it is run.

15 euro per person in a very expensive price for Marrakesh, and even more that one has to wait sometime to first buy a ticket and then enter the gardens. Nice garden but small compared with other gardens in Marrakesh. One can see everything on you tube

Went there as part of Tour and thankfully got straight in.  Arrived around 930am so Garden quite busy even then.  Lots of people taking selfies all round the place which is generally is very off putting.  Difficult to take pictures without loads of bodies in them.  Pleasant stroll but really only an hour at most with lots of giant Cacti on display.  This place clearly lives on who owned the place in the past.  Did the Secret Garden later which thought was a more interesting place to visit.  As I left at around 1030 noticed the queue was massive - so get there early would be my advice
review_title: A Tick in the Box Place

review_text: Didn’t end up getting in. Queued for 20 mins, was then told we were in the wrong queue. Then got told to scan a qr code & join the other queue that was twice as long. Qr wouldn’t scan as we couldn’t get more data (sim not working in Morocco) so we waited thinking we would eventually get to a box office/human we could buy a physical ticket from. Nope. Staff told us to leave the second queue after being stood there over half an hour. Very unhelpful, I was beyond annoyed. Happy to take the money off people but provide no assistance whatsoever. Wasted over an hour of my last day queuing for nothing. By the sounds of the other reviews we dodged a bullet.
review_title: Disorganised Queue system, never made it in

review_text: This place was the one that made me want to visit Morocco. Make sure you don’t miss it while visiting Marrakech! I bet you will love it too!
review_title: This place was the one that made me want to visit Morocco 🤩

review_text: Well I came here after it was highly rated on tripadvisor and things to see It was around 13 pounds for entry and although I am not much a plant/flower person it was just ok and I was out on less than an hour and didn't get value for money. There were a few photo opportunities and the places if quite well under shade from any sun, there's a book and another shop
review_title: A brief look at something highly rated

review_text: A rich Frenchman has created a very nice garden and another rich Frenchman has purchased it from the first one. The second one is more famous.

This was recommended in the guide books but we wish we’d read personal views beforehand. The gardens are interesting but not vast - you could walk round in under an hour. But the organisation and attitude of the staff ruined the whole experience. The price has just been increased - now more than double what it was a week ago and you have to book online. Despite that we still had to queue for close to 45 minutes . The staff were officious and unhelpful and the ticket system has a number of flaws. Then when you get inside it felt as if there were almost as many security staff as customers, who seemed committed to ensuring you could not just relax and enjoy the environment. We are glad we’re have already experienced the warmth of the Moroccan people, as otherwise this would have wrongly coloured our view of the country. Overpriced for what it is in comparison to what else we have seen and visited.

Unless you're extremely interested in gardens and/or botanics, you're probably gonna be all the way through in less than 25 minutes. With that in mind, the entrance is pretty expensive. The garden is a nice little oasis, but The Secret Garden is supposedly at least as pretty and much easier to get into. The last point is worth elaboration: Entrance tickets bought online are booked for a certain time slot, but there's no system in place to control who gets in line when, so queueing outside Jardin Majorelle is pretty chaotic. Not only is the line gonna be long unless you book an early ticket, but an angry employee will be walking back and forth along the line, scolding you for standing in line and making you leave the line unless you've ordered for a certain time slot – as if you had any way of knowing what time slot everyone else's tickets are for. Most unprofessional ticketing system I've ever experienced, and that's saying a lot.
review_title: Pretty garden, but with a miserable queueing system

review_text: Very tranquil for a rest from the medina. The exotic garden is full of varied plants but although the Islam garden was tranquil and well maintained the planting was repetitive snd dull but maybe that was the point. There was too long a wait for us to ascend the tour so we didn’t see the view. I think having lunch there would be a good Nice to make the most of the tranquility.

Quite a walk from the main square up here, we bought a combination ticket for 600 dirham !  So expensive. Tip here is queue at the YSL museum much smaller queues. In hindsight a single ticket would have been better as we fix like the YSL museum. The gardens themselves are stunning, cafe very busy so we couldn't try but looked nice.

Although the original ticket office is staffed, the staff members insist that visitors purchase their admission tickets on their mobile phones. For visitors from Canada and the United States without cellular Internet in Morocco, the first ridiculous step in purchasing a simple ticket is to access wifi in the street. Then the "guest" is required to provide full name, email address, phone number, credit card number, and more. Unlike other places in Marrakesh, this place will not accept cash. What's worse, it's not clear when the ticket is purchased online is that it doesn't include the Berber museum inside the garden. The whole shabby looking garden can be seen in 15 minutes for an outrageous ticket price and ordeal.
review_title: Majorelle Ripoff with Outdated Covid-19 Protocol

review_text: The photos tell it all. Just be sure you reserve in advance and don't overlook the lovely Berber museum.

A great selection of ponds, fountains and plants just outside the city centre. The ticket price is cheaper for residents, tourists pay a lot more. I can understand it, but I didn't find it fair to be honest.

What a brilliant place. The colours are amazing it's a real treat. The planting is lush and the house an amazing blue. Apart from the queue to get in it was the perfect visit. Buy tickets online before you go.

This is a small, lovely garden filled with many succulents surrounded by structures painted vivid shades of blues and greens.  It is not a botanical garden so serious gardeners may be disappointed.  I think it’s overrated; tickets were $15 and the lines snake down the block for tickets and entrance.  Our guide told us the popularity is due to Instragrammers who were swarming all over the place without any real interest in the garden itself.  I was glad we saw it; I would have thought we were really missing something based on the lines and hype.
review_title: Small, lovely garden, mostly with succulents.

review_text: I thoroughly enjoyed visiting this garden, as this had been on my wish list for a while having already taken inspiration and having had some knowledge about it beforehand. The garden isn’t very large, and only took about an hour to wander, relax and take it all in, it has meandering paths and a number of water features, it consists of mostly desert plants, very large and multi varied cacti and succulents, as well as palm varieties and bamboo. The colours on the ‘house’ are stunning, and it is a peaceful oasis in the middle of the city. Gardeners and those with knowledge of its history will appreciate the garden very much, but it does get busy and a lot of visitors mainly appeared to be too interested in themselves and posing for Instagram pics, so you do have to be patient waiting for a clear space to take some pics of the plants and features!! It’s important to book online beforehand and advice recommends early or late bookable times, we visited at 4.30 (closes at 6.00pm in winter) and although still busy it wasn’t too crowded. It’s £150 Moroccan Dirhams (approx £12 per person) so double the cost of most other Marrakesh attractions.
review_title: Garden better appreciated by gardeners and those with background knowledge

review_text: My hotel recommended that I visit the gardens as the colours and light would be good for photography. I was expecting a large gardens, and I have walked around bigger Garden Centres at home. There were just palm trees and cacti, and very little flora, but it was the winter months. The colours of the structures gave the gardens character, and there was a memorial to Yves Saint Laurent and also a carp pond, and that's about it. I didn't visit the museum dedicated to YSL as fashion is not my bag, plus I could see that fro free in the V&A in London.

Book online before going and go first thing in the morning.  It gets very, very busy and is a pretty small space with narrow paths filled with tour groups with each person taking endless selfies.  Having said that, the cacti are wonderful and in perfect condition and the gardens are beautifully maintained.  The shop is by the main house, not the exit and has wonderful things in - but at a price.  It took us less than half an hour to walk around and there is not much else in the vicinity so do go early.  It will mean you have the rest of the day free for other things.
Overcrowded, over priced and rather officious staff spoiled our viwing of a lovely garden. if you go buy tickets online as queue to buy is chaotic and badly organised

A long distance if travelling from the south of the city only to find that the museum is not open although the website says it will be closed from the 30th! The gardens on their own do not take that long to walk round. Also It will save time if you pre-book as not really anything else nearby to do.

Just burned £12 on this... Nice selection of plants and garden and that's about it. Tiny, packed with people taking photos of themselves with I don't know what, and completely overpriced. I think it's all about because of that French designer guy and everyone wanted to come here and take photos to show that they've been here but that's about it. Been to some nice places in Marrakech so far, this has been the biggest letdown...

This is an OK place but in my view not worth the hype — well maintained grounds with some interesting gardens (mostly cactus), pretty blue house. The YSL-Bergé link is an interesting aspect of Marrakech and fashion history of course. However the site in my view pales in comparison to other gardens in Marrakech, and the proliferation of cheap instagrammers ruins the vibe. The Berber museum is a highlight and the on site cafe is pleasant with a nice selection of food.
The peace and tranquility of these gardens are an experience not to be missed. The on site museum was well worth the extra. But the use of the particular shade of blue is fantastic.
It was an incredible value for visiting this heaven. Do not forget to book the online ticket in adv. We were so lucky that we found a free slot a day before. We would wholeheartedly recommend.
mostly the advertising, there are many cactus sorts to see, very nice, but there is little marking as to which cactus what name. Quite small garden. Would not really recommend.

With hundreds of different cactus plants, water fountains and the Yves St. Lauren, this gardens attractions offers a quiet greeny area to rest. Few benches to sit around. Lots of photos of the different cactus plants. Don't miss the Berber Museum- worth the entrance fee.

I'm here to correct all the misinformation from the otherwise great show "Inventing Anna." My friends and I toured the Gardens as part of our March 2022 tour. Our guide dropped us off, and we had a little over an hour. The entry fee is a little steep for Morocco, but this is a gorgeous oasis in the city. Yves Saint Laurent knew beauty, and this garden reflects that. Even in the bustling new city, the traffic fades away inside the walls. We stopped for plenty of photos along the way, of course. But generally, we just walked the main loop. We skipped the small interior museum, loving plants more than fashion. There are so many different cacti and shrubs that I never knew existed. Well worth a visit, but it'll get crowded even in the off-season.
review_title: Stunning green oasis worth a calming walk

review_text: very nice Garden it worth to visit once in time   , you need to get your ticket online , if you could have a local guide that will be very helpful learning about the History of the garden

Oh my gurd, where to begin! We precooked a joint ticket for both the YSL museum and the garden/jard-in. When we arrived the queue for the garden was absolutely massive and so we instead headed to the YSL first, please see my review on that page if you're interested about the museum! After we had finished up in the museum we headed back to the garden and the queue was gone, we were impeccably confused! It was like someone had come along with a hoover and sucked everyone up, however when we left the queue had returned to it's previous humungous stature so I think it's very hit or miss when it comes to the queue! Once inside of the bodacious garden/jard-in Helen and I were suddenly overcome with emotions as we're immediately greeted by the most gorgeous and ravishing bamboo tree and oh it was just so winsome! If you know me, you know I love bamboo so this was a treat and a half! As we progressed through the botanically fetching jard-in we see the most darling water feature where you can stand in a little structure and admire the water. HOWEVER, this is where my biggest peeve found its way into the day, the crowds! Hecking hell, there were pesky people everywhere you go, like pigeons! And if that wasn't bad enough, they were all preposterous posers! Which meant that I couldn't even look at the features because everyone fancied themselves rather too much, well not everyone but a select few. I'd like to disclaim that I don't have an issue with people taking photos with the stupendously awesome backdrops however it was a little excessive and taking the George Michael a bit when they start trying 50 different poses, but each to their offensive own am I right?! We saw the botanically blue house thing which oh my Gordon Brown, it was to die for! Helen couldn't help but pose with the velvet blue house, however the squitters had struck me so I couldn't bring myself to smile. But there were the most gorgeous cacti and glazing green colours towering over me so I was in awe, I wish I was there with better bowels to be honest. Although bowels aside it was pretty damned beautiful. It is this point where myself and Helen were struck the most, after the house is another quaint little pond thing. There was a darling but somewhat rudimentary woman stood there posing which was fine, until she insisted upon about 20 different poses and 100 different photographs. Helen decided enough was enough and barged through and peeked at the flapping fish, unfortunately I missed out on seeing the fishies. All in all the jard-in was just spectacularly breathtakingly beautiful, but it was very much tainted by the displeasurable disturbances of business and not enough viewpoints.
