Another example is some posers on a path, meaning we couldn't go anywhere and they took about 5 minutes and didnt even apologise, how rude am I right?! Oh and by the way, they have coi karps! Thank you to Helen and the Jard-in majorette team for making this divine trip possible. I wish you all the best and I'm sure you'll take on my feedback. Love, hugs and other drugs, Charlie
review_title: Would you rather: Flocks of pigeons or myriads of posers

review_text: This is the most beutiful garden I have ever seen. the choice of colours of the pots, this beautiful blue walls and all the cacti are stunning. and next door YSL museum is an absolute must

Was going to skip because people said it was a waste of time- just cactus. It was amazing. Cacti I'd never seen before. Layout was just an easy stroll. Memorial to YSL and Pierre Bergé. Water features were beautifully placed. Lovely cafe in a courtyard. Colors of hard scape were lovely contrast to the cacti. Definitely a tourist site but I loved it.
Really nice place to visit. We had some coffee and food in the cafe, would recommend this to come and visit it specifically if you love plants

The garden is beautiful and it costs 120 Dirhams to see it, so that's around 14€/15$/12£. Lots ofbshade tonhidrn from the sun if it's too hot. Sometimes there will be small lines of people to take pictures at certain spots, and that's pretty much the only annoying thing we've witnessed.
review_title: Beautiful garden with lots of shade

review_text: It is like an oasis in the city center of Marrakech. A lot of plants inside, mostly cactus, very well preserved and clean. Many places inside for photo shooting if you find the appropriate time that it does not have too many people which is the major negative issue of the spot.
review_title: A nice spot in Marrakech but too crowded

review_text: It’s overrated. Small simple garden with few plants that you can see within 15 minutes. There are free public parks much better arranged all around the world . This garden is no worth $16 entrance
Quite honestly a disappointment. If you pay 30 euro pp to see these gardens i'd think of sth more special. I do not recommend this

A lot of money, to see a lot of cactus. Not many flowers.  Not really worth the money. Didn’t visit the museum, so can’t comment on this. But on a plus, it is a charitable organ addition which goes to the poor. Would visit again

This garden space is lovely - the color palate of the architecture surrounding the greenery is essential to what makes it special, so in that sense it has a unique character that makes it worth a visit. That said, if you're a fan of gardens as gardens, you may find it a bit underwhelming relative to the crowds roaming the space (even arriving before dawn, you'll find it packed with bus groups within an hour of opening) and there are other gardens that are likely to provide more relaxing and contemplative atmosphere. Even Cyber Park, which isn't aspiring to instagram design or exotic flora, is a pleasure to wander without people somewhat rudely jostling for selfie angles.

Jardin Majorelle are beautiful. Stunning and peaceful you could imagine Yves St Laurent strolling around in the evening! In the hurly burly of busy Marrakech, perfect place to unwind. NB - useful to book tickets in advance - the first day we attempted to visit the queues were huge so we left. We booked online for the next day but the queues were practically non-existent! Not a huge amount of information around the garden and the staff I asked about different plants basically shrugged their shoulders with disinterest. Would have been good to have more seating dotted about to be able to absorb the tranqulity. Extremely well kept loos!

Jardin Majorelle and Musee YSL are far more popular than I had expected. The garden is a gorgeous collection of palms and succulents set in a tranquil setting with a memorial to YSL. They are not extensive -- just a stroll rather than a hike. There's a very nice looking cafe that we didn't use but would be a nice lunch or coffee spot (and this was not crowded at 11 am). The garden is connected to the museum, which I wish we would have visited first as both were crowded but I think it would have been better at the museum had we gone there first. It is a very nice relief from the maelstrom of the city, and is very handicapped accessible (though the rest of Marrakech really is not).

Located to the north of the medina - we took a TukTuk from the main square. There is a small pretty street leading to the entrance with ticket holders on one side and a larger queue for those who had not booked (there were also QR codes in the street, so that you could book online). The tickets aren´t cheap at 300DH (about €30) to include the gardens, plus entry to the Berber musuems . Gardens: We loved our visit to the gardens where the vibrant colours, the fountains and exotic plants come together to make it a charming and relaxing hectare of parkland. Musée Berbère: the electric-blue art deco studio houses the musuem, which showcases 600 artifacts, including wood and metalwork, textiles and a room of regional traditional costumes displayed with the flair of a catwalk show. Best of all is the brilliant mirrored chamber displaying a collection of chiseled, filigreed and enameled jewels. There is also a busy boutique and a pretty cafe.
review_title: A haven of peace amidst the crazy city!

review_text: The garden is very picturesque.  We didnt care that it had a 'YSL' label attached - just went to see if it was pretty, and it was.  But in early Jan was quite crowded.

A pretty garden, yes. Some unusual plants and creative displays too, and like others I found it to be an overpriced tourist trap. We spent about an hour before getting bored but it was at least a change from the medinas.

If you remove “Yves Saint Laurent” from the name of this little garden, there won’t be queue, and you will spend 5 minutes to shoot a few pictures and you leave. I bought a ticket in advance not to be in a queue and went there very early in order not to be in a crowd. It is still not really impressing :)

Beautiful gardens, lovely place. You could see what Morocco did for the career of YSL in terms of motifs and direct “inspiration”. Still, price is a ripoff for foreign tourists. When you put in perspective that the combined tickets costs more than Musee d’Orsay or the Louvre, you feel sorry for perpetuating it. YSL collection, a rotating one, is small. Albeit interesting, again- it is nothing like the grand retrospectives. Local staff at entrance was rude, seemingly to all lining visitors.
review_title: Lovely concept, which is also an expensive ripoff of foreign tourists

review_text: In January 2023, the price was 15 euro pp. We queued for one hour and it was just not worth paying that price. Yes, it is a beautiful garden, but overcrowded and really not extraordinary. I would not recommend it at all. Too much to get a couple of fancy photos.

We arrived just before 5pm and there was a short queue.  The cacti were reasonably interesting but the garden layout wasn’t anything special.  It was mainly being used for people posing for Instagram accounts. The YSL museum is currently shut.
fantastic time in peaceful place, far from noisy life in Marrakesh , great to escape and to have calm moment.
amazing romantic day with my girl here. it is quiet, beautiful and lovely place to spend some hours with your partner.

The place was like a sanctuary. Lots of plants and it feels like you’re in a place where you can rest. Aside from tourist flocking the place, there are also bird around the area and you can hear them. The colours are vibrant. The only thing that made it 4 stars is that we were not able to enter the YSL MUSEUM tho we clearly paid for the combine ticket. The thing is that, no one guided us as to where we need to enter and the path took us to the exit and when we asked for their staff where we can enter for the ysl museum, he scanned our barcode and said that it cannot be done anymore since the ticket is already been used. Such a shame really. We definitely told him that we just exited the Jardin but that was the response we got. Anyways, everything was beautiful!

The gardens were nice to look at and walk around in, but really nothing special and not worth the price. Similar sorts of gardens in other destinations are free to visit. Was expecting more. The Berber museum was more interesting than the garden itself. If you have spare time and are looking for something to do this will suffice. But don't expect anything special. Would not call it a must-see. Thankfully there wasn't much of a queue as we entered, but as we were leaving a large queue had formed.
review_title: Decent garden, but not worth the price

review_text: It was my friend who suggested that we visit this place, she got to know about it after watching the netflix drama 'inventing anna', haha. The place is beautiful, lots of blue. Apparently it's trademark.  Bamboos and cactus. Great place for photos and videos. Spent a lot of time just doing that. Worth a visit.
Mostly desert plants. Go early to avoid crowds at the ticket office,you have to wait in the sun otherwise.
These gardens are absolutely stunning and well worth a visit. The delay and difficult entry did spoil the tranquility!
review_title: Beautiful gardens and Berber museum, but terrible entrance process - book online is your best bet

review_text: very nice gardens with museum entry. we get our ticket online so this is best option to avoid crowds waiting for tickets. the garden itselfs offers nice walks, flora and fauna with very intereseting views, worth to see & visit.
The gardens is really amazing, full of colors and beautiful plants and cactuses. and museum of Yves Saint Laurent is wonderful. Highly recommend to visit.

This is easily the best thing in Marrakech. And it is popular. Huge lines to buy ticket and to see the gardens. End of 2022 the amount of tourists just killed the mood. You line up for an hour to buy ticket then another hour to get in. It just killed the mood. Worse you go in and there are hundreds of tourists pointing their cameras in all directions. Some girls with heavy make up and flowing dresses taking instagram pics (yes this might mean you are one of them). It is all very fake and pretentious ladies, please don't do it.  All the amount of fake smiles inside just killed it. Should you go? 100%. It is the best thing. But buy your ticket in advance. Get in first thing in the morning then get out. What I find ironic is the top sight in Morocco is from a western culture, not local.
review_title: Too many instagram posers faking a pose

review_text: We were a bit disappointed with the gardens given all the hype. If you are determined to visit the gardens then its a must to buy your tickets online 24hrs before as you can skip both enormous queues and enter directly. The gardens are lovely with a good collection of cactus, and the buildings look lovely within them. Getting good photos is hard as the gardens are filled with tourists. The ushers are a bit of a pain as they don’t let you wander but direct you along a fixed route. We much preferred the secret garden within the medina. Probably in our top ten places to visit in Marrakech but not in the top 5 for sure. If you have not booked your tickets in advace then  we would recomend skipping the Majorelle Gardens.
review_title: We were a bit disappointed with the gardens given all the hype.

review_text: The place its was like heaven you must visit, you feel like you reach a some millionaire house 🏡 just vist in marrakesh Morocco 🇲🇦
review_title: Only in short it's amazing place to visit you will you are in heaven,

review_text: yes it is a beautiful garden but it is just a regular GARDEN. not worth a very long queue to go in and not worth the entrance fee.

Completely and utterly disorganized. Three lines merging for prior purchased paper tickets, online tickets and no tickets. Two hour wait in a seething mob of French expats. Awful and really expensive.

A 30 min walk from the centre, a 40 min queue (although you can book tickets online), over £20 per adult.........and you could walk round it in 10 mins....without rushing. It's clean, with a tranquil atmosphere, but really small and not (to my mind) worth visiting to see a few cacti and trees.

Prebook or go to the YSL museum first and buy a combination ticket (worth it) Gorgeous gardens of cactus and other plants and very instagrammable building. The cafe has a great range of food and Wi-Fi.
review_title: Gorgeous Gardens and Cafe but the queue for entry was hell

review_text: Lovely garden with a lot of different species. The gigantic cactii are spectacular. The place is very crowded so try to book tickets online 24 hours prior to your visit. The blue is everywhere and looks stunning in photos.
So many interesting and beautiful plants to appreciate! It's a bit crowded and expensive but otherwise a great experience.
It is very nice and green. You want to take picture at each corner. It has a moroccan style. International visitors need to pay 120 MAD for entrance. I think it is too expensive.

Majorly not worth it. We spent 25 minutes there. Don’t believe the hype. A few cacti and a museum of two rooms all with French description and no dates on artefacts so may as well be in the souks looking at Berber crafts. One to miss!

The garden itself was fantastic and worth a visit, however it can get pretty hectic there. At first we arrived on a Friday around 10:30 am and queued to get the tickets, after an hour the queue hasn't moved much and it became apparent that due to a high number of people in the garden, they are not selling more tickets. In addition to that, people who had bought their tickets online the day before were given priority to enter the gardens. We gave up and left, bought the tickets online for Saturday and came back at 8:30am the next day. For a while we were the only people in the garden and it was a perfect opportunity to take pictures and look around, after about an hour it became super crowded. So I would recommend visiting the garden, but do so early in the morning and with pre-purchased tickets!
review_title: Beautiful garden, but book your tickets beforehand!

review_text: The gardens are composed mostly of bamboo trees and cactuses. The house is nothing special yet colorful. I would rather spend my time and money visiting other enchanting places in Marrakech.

The entrance fee is 120 dirhams for international visitors which i feel is expensive and it is recommended to visit early in the morning when the opens for visitors to avoid a long que waiting to get in if you arrive around 11:00AM to visit,which may consume your time especially if you are on a one day visit to marrakech.The park is well maintained with variety of cacti  and is worth a visit if you are a garden lover.
To visit outside the crowds ! Do not forget to take the pictures in the early morning or evening light

Stunning garden - not to be missed on a Marrakech trip. We wished we'd booked in advance as the queue was huge when we got there. The ticket office staff were really grumpy and unhelpful and there were a huge amount of 'security' type staff around the garden, which seemed a bit odd. Otherwise, it is a stunning place easily walkable from the Medina. If you do get a taxi, don't use the ones outside the garden but walk to the road and haggle.
Very nice gardens - peaceful.  We got their early to beat the crowd (part of a group tour).  Make sure to see the YSL memorial.  There is also a small Berber museum on the grounds - worth a visit.

A beautiful garden no doubt, but being herded through it in a one way system like sheep in a pen (or people in an airport) really drained all the joy from what could have been lovely experience. Disappointing.
A great experience of the gardens and the memorial of YSL I would definitely recommend so peaceful and calm there.
In the heart of Marrakech these garden are well worth a visit. Best book in advance or expect a lengthy queue for tickets. Lovely little cafe in the garden too...try the hot chocolate!
review_title: Beautiful way to spend a relaxing morning

review_text: Ok, so as a garden and botanical enthusiast, I was greatly dissapointed. Entry 12 Euro is ok, but we had to move through the whole garden in a queue due to the fact that there were probably 1000 tourists too many in the garden.  There were no special plants, no really WOW features. Just a big garden with lots of pathways and small pools in typical Morrocan style and it's blue colour. Probably have 3 photos without a head or a hand from someone else in it( you will not be able to make same photos as presented above unless you want to prolong your visit to 4 -5 hours).

Beautiful but there needs to be some kind of quality control or controlled path.  Too many influencers/Instagramers taking over space. I know that sounds rude and petty.  Maybe a limited about of people in at a time. I’ve got lots of photos of other people.
review_title: Beautiful but too many people in space at the same time

review_text: overcrowded place, worth to visit but definitely not in peak time. best to get tickets in advance online or you will need wait to get them for about 2 hours. the garden itselfs is beautiful.
review_title: nice garden to visit with family

review_text: Surprising beautiful garden, considering the garden is located at desert era, you can see the European fashion style and taste in this garden, which located in a desert muslin country, it created strong cultural and bright color contrast, it's a interesting place to visit.

If you are in Marrakesh and even if you think I'm not a big fan of gardens then i suggest you visit this magical place.  Agreed if it is swarming with tourists then it will lose part of its charm but try to go early or off season if possible and make sure you book your tickets i advance to avoid the lengthy queues.  It's not so much about the garden as the boldness of the YSL / Majorelle blue painted onto the artists studio, the light as it creates added drama and intensity against the sky and the lush planting. The Berber museum within the grounds is also beautifully presented under a dark ceiling of twinkling lights and each object is illuminated with added impact. 100 yards down the road is the YSL museum which is a must see also and this garden is a testament to his creative genius.   There is a monument to him in the grounds of the Majorelle gardens.
review_title: Lose yourself in these wonderful gardens

review_text: It's beautiful but at the end of the day it's an overpriced tourist trap where locals pay 1/5 of your price to go to. It's mostly people taking instragram pictures. Bring your student ID to pay half.

The gardens are simply amazing! Tranquil and peaceful. These gardens are beautifully designed and have the most wonderful plants, trees and water features. I was so impressed by the various giant cactus. I would highly recommend a visit 💞
incredibly a beautifull garden and museum and has beautiful fauna. The fees are reasonable too. It's quite small but gets overwhelmingly crowded. I recommed to visit 

A nice large garden with a variety of plants and especially cacti that I have never seen before. There are a couple of shops onsite but I feel that they are unnecessarily overpriced (as you might expect). As I am not a local, the entrance fee was 120 Dirhams (approx £10) on the day I went.
…save your money. Just some palm trees, bamboo and cacti…..even long lines. No idea why so many people go here

Such a beautiful place!! So unique and colorful. It's really a gem within the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. The YSL Museum and Berber Museums are also fantastic parts of the visit, not to be missed.
This beautiful garden together with two museums is truly a delight to the senses.  So many exotic plants with wonderful architecture around.  This is truly an unmissable place to visit!!
review_title: Fantastic garden with so much to enjoy!

review_text: We really enjoyed our visit to the garden.the garden is well kept . you can also visit the YSL.you can buy your ticket online to avoid crowd
Beautiful  Gardens and beautiful house. Check out the history and interpretation in the shop in the bottom.
A beautiful and mesmerising place to spend a time, it is one of the best gardens in Marrakech. The colors in the garden is stunning. It worths a visit !

We enjoyed our visit to the garden, so many beautiful plants and vibrant colours. We came during July which was the warmest time of the year in Marrakech, the heat was unbearable but we went to the restaurant for some ice cream to cool us down.
Beautiful & tranquil. Colours are fantastic. Smaller than expected. Definitely book ahead. Great for photos!!

We visited with my daughter, wife, and in-laws. The gardens are nice and well-kept, and if it weren’t for the masses of people, could have a spot for relaxation and reflection. I don’t really know that to day - I’ve seen a lot of botanical gardens that have a wider variation of plants with a more natural feel. They also claim it accessible for handicapped, but not so much the Berber museum, where we couldn’t bring in our stroller. It’s a nice visit for sure, but I’m not really sure what the hype is all about.

As gardens go, these are well nice. Mr YSL did a good job conserving the. It was 120 p/p for a ticket (€12 or £12 | this is Nov 2022), this was a fair enough price when you realise the money is going to local projects of a similar ilk. You can walk the entire gardens in 30 minutes, a max of 1 hour would be enough that’s with taking loads of photos. If you like doing Insta-style photos, this is a great place for it. That colour blue is a very nice colour. We didn’t buy the extra ticket for the mini museum within the gardens (The Berber Museum)
review_title: We’ll worth an hour of your day

review_text: While Jardin Majorelle costs more than other sights in Marrakech, it is a decent getaway from the hustle of the Medina. The Pierre Bergé Berber Museum is worth the extra 30 Dirhams with their tasteful collection.
Not worth the long line.  Bamboo Eastern garden not cactus garden.  Small.  I would skip it.      My family didn’t like it either,
Don't simply see the gardens. Go to the YSL and Amizigh (Berber) museum. 2-3 hours total. Don't freak over the long line. It goes pretty fast.  Totally worth it!
Just a small crowded park with too high price. There are some free, much bigger and more beautiful parks in Marrakesh. Yo can go through the full park in 10 minutes. 1 Eur per minut..
Buy your ticket online - and go before 9:45 - otherwise too crowded. We didn't go to the museum. The blues in the walls are so beautiful. Walk if you can - the taxis traffic is crazy
A great way to learn about the native plants while enjoying the colorful pots and areas for pictures.
really nice relaxed atmosphere and a beautiful gardens to wander around - loads of good photo opportunities

Careful with your tickets - I asked for a combined ticket for the gardens, berber museum & Yves Saint Lauren museum - instead they charged me for two peoples entry to the gardens. I was then refused entry to both museums, waited 45 minutes for a manager to resolve the issue (who never showed up) and then eventually gave up, leaving without a refund. Hopefully I'm an anomaly, but ensure you check you're given what you've paid for!
As long as you make to some come when it's not too crowded, Jardin Majorelle offers a peaceful reprieve from visiting the various signtings in Marrakech, especially during the hot midday.
This is a unique garden to visit outside old Medina of Marrakech and it is located in new town. Highly recommended to see and visit!

Fantastically picturesque and well kept gardens. There is plenty to see and many photo opportunities around the gardens. Be prepared for crowds and long queues - but that is to be expected at such a deservedly popular attraction. It's highly advisable to book tickets in advance.

The gardens are beautiful but small, overcrowded and over priced. I went at 10am and had pre-booked my ticket the day before online. If you don’t you have to que for the tickets and then que to get in. I also booked the Berber museum. It’s also very small and the descriptions are in Arabic and French so unless you can understand either language you don’t get the full benefit of a visit here.

Fabulous gardens. Laid out in an easy and flat terrain. Ideal for wheelchairs. Long queues to get in so allow plenty of time OR go to the nearby Yves St Laurent museum and purchase garden tickets to avoid the queue.
review_title: Visit with friends to Majorelle Gardens

review_text: Total waste of money, have no idea where the reviews come from. Its a total tourist trap. It takes about 15 mins
review_title: Its just a garden full of cacti, notyhing more

review_text: Nice plants but so many people. Go to see Anima instead! The Berber Museum was small and I learnt so little from it. Better to speak to the nomads themselves
review_title: Jolly crowded with staff directing your route around to keep some flow going

review_text: What an incredible place. The gardens are beautiful, and the tranquillity is spoilt only by its popularity. Do yourselves a favour and walk past the ridiculous queue to the YSL museum, buy a combined ticket for YSL, the gardens, and the Berber museum, and save yourself a lot of queuing!

Had a very bad experience with the ticket seller for this garden.  Bought  combination ticket for 220 dihrams. I gave her 250 dihrams. She handed me a ticket and only 10 dihram coin. I was puzzled. I the ticket printed as 220 dihrams. There are no additional charges but i got back only 10 dihrams.  I returned to the ticket office within seconds.  I asked her about it. She said she gave. I told no. She insisted.  She said i put into my card holder.  I knew i had only one piece of 20 dihram note in my card holder. . And she saw it. And she insisted.  I didn't want to ugly with this kind of people in a foreign country. Shame on her. Scamming on just $2. Highly recommend to be take precautions in this place. Even people working on a well-known place.  It's a garden with the name related to Yves Saint Laurent. A garden with catuspictures. No character. It's not pleasant to visit after the encounter. Very disappointing.
Beautiful oasis in a busy city. If you like gardens, make time to visit this one. The history is also interesting

The gardens themselves are beautiful and well worth spending the time walking at a leisurely pace with some great photo opportunities. Would highly recommend buying your tickets online as the queue for tickets on the day was huge! (you can do this on their official website which you get a QR code for and can walk straight up to the entrance on the day to scan). I personally bought the all-in-one ticket which allowed you entrance to the gardens, Berber museum and Yves Saint Lauren Museum. Whilst it felt pricey at the time it actually turned in to good value as i spent the majority of the day there. Word of warning.. The cafe in the gardens is overpriced, lacking in menu choice and comes with a side of very poor customer service!

Arrived with 45 mins left before close at 6pm. It was ample time to get around as the gardens are very small. Luckily the hordes of tourists who come here had long gone so a gardening photographer's dream especially if Mexican cacti and palm trees float your boat...The cafe looked cool. Don't expect too much by way of flowers and colours. It's a little minimalistic. A cool tribute to a cool guy.

The garden was phenomenal. The cacti were varied and the plants very well developed, it was a joy to walk round. We stopped for a drink in the café which we were not so pleased with, it was very expensive and service was very slow. But still a nice location.

I visit botanic gardens everywhere I go. This was a waste of time and the worst botanic garden I've visited, especially after visiting the Kirstenbosch National Botanical Garden in Cape Town and the Botanic Garden in Palermo last month.             It was disappointing that only about 5% of the plants are identified. Save yourself time and money and don't visit this garden.
review_title: A waste of time for botanic garden aficionados

review_text: Although this is a top attraction in Marrakesh, it can be very crowded and doesn't feel very serene. But it's a lovely place with pretty buildings and lush foliage.
Walkable from the Medina.  Queued for about 30 mins to get a ticket but garden didn't feel at all crowded.  Simply glorious

Lovey visit, such beautiful gardens! Marrakech is so busy and visiting the gardens completely took you away from all the hustle and bustle. I advise people to book the day before they go, otherwise the Que is usually about 30 minutes!
The garden is incredibly instagrammable, well maintained and has beautiful fauna. The fees are reasonable too. It's quite small but gets overwhelmingly crowded.
Amazing nature viiews with a lot of different and unique plants, without forgetting the berber museum .
Beautiful gardens .. it gets crowded, but worth it the detail and the history of the palaces are great

Very pretty garden but much smaller than I expected. I spent two weeks in Morocco, and compared to other sites I had seen on the trip, this was somewhat underwhelming. But if you only have a few days in Morocco and want to escape the craziness of Marrakesh, it’s a nice spot to spend a half hour or an hour.

We went on a Sunday at 10am and had to wait 1 hour before entering. We did not book any tickets ahead of time, hence purchased them on-site. For those with rental cars, it can be problematic to find a close-by parking spot, until we found a private parking were the attendants were charging MAD20 to park and it worth the price as it was secured and tucked away from all the buses and drop-off. The gardens themselves were beautiful and worth 1-2 hours of your time.
review_title: The only place I would queue to see a garden

review_text: TOURIST BEWARE OF SCAMMERS AND THIEVES AND EXPECT TO BE DISAPPOINTED. How this is the number 1 tourist spot, I don't know. Granted there are some nice palms and cactus here but the overall experience is nothing special and really just a waste of money. As this city lack real authentic culture you are effectively forced into going to visit this site as a basic checklist list activity due to the limited things you can do in Marrakesh. You will pay £32 Entrance to basically walk through a garden centre of cactus plants!!! If you have time to kill then check it out but like much of Marrakesh this isn't much to see nor is there any real culture to experience. Some of you may think there will be some real photo opportunities but this is not true. The reason why this is the number 1 spot is simply due to the influence the YSL foundation has over the tourist board and government. Which inadvertently aim to drive tourist traffic to this site. Yes this may be the best botanical garden in Morocco but remember you are in a desert where green space is scarce. See it might be a refreshing change to see greenery when you are surrounded by grime, pollution and red bricked buildings. Expect long queues outside the venue. Approx 1 hour 30mins. Admission with get you into the ysl museum but again nothing special. Clean toilets though if you need it. If you walk from the town centre souks/ markets to Ysl garden it will take approx 30mins. You can take a cab but do not pay more than 30dhs. Taxi will say minimum fare is 50dhs. FYI is you take trips over 10km expect to pay no more than 100dhs or £10. On your way to the gardens  You will be hassled by scammers and in our case followed by thieves on mopeds who ended  up stealing our phone in broad daylight via a snatch and dash.
review_title: Jardin Majorelle YSL Garden - waste of time and money

review_text: You wouldn't expect a garden of mostly cactus to be so attractive and beautifully landscaped with other plants. Definitely, if you are in Marrakech, this is a must.

This is a such a beautiful attraction, it is easy to book a cab from the 'town centre/market' to the gardens for less than £5. A tip I'd note is that you want to plan on arriving here before 5pm in order to have enough time to see everything and take it all in.
I hadn't been planning on going here originally but I'm glad I chose to spontaneously! Value for money -  I took so many stunning photos here. So tranquil

This is rated as the number one experience in Marrakesh but it’s hard to understand why. The gardens are nice but not more than the botanical gardens in many big cities. The number of security guards around the gardens was absurd. combined with armed police and soldiers outside, you do wonder what they are worried about. The most surprising thing was that for such a crowded attraction, there are just 2 toilets for the whole garden. Portacabins with a woman who jumps in to clean them after every single person.  Strange. Although we did spend an hour wandering around, if it wasn’t for the extra “private garden” part that was open as well, it would be hard to justify the price or the queues to get in.
review_title: definitely overhyped and very busy for what it is

review_text: A calm and serene paradise amongst the hustle and bustle of the busy city. We booked in advance and saved ourselves a lot of queuing time
Very pretty and a nice break from the hot dusty city.  We were told to go around 4:30 for the best light. But it was also a good time because the crowds were already gone.

To get in when we visited you would have needed to queue for at least an hour in full sun. When we abandoned the queue after 30 minutes having not moved at all as my mother was suffering in the heat, there were people at the back who were probably looking at longer than an hour. There is no shade, no water, and no information. The entrance is chaotic with throngs of confused tourists being heckled by street hawkers. This was a very disappointing experience, amongst the worst tourist traps I have experienced globally. Mr. Majorelle I’m sure would be appalled at the guests having to suffer in the heat and sun. This was was a rare negative experience during our stay in Morocco and I recommend against visiting - there are plenty of other great gardens in the city.

One of the best gardens i have visited on my last trip to Marrakech absolutely its worth a visit everything about the plants and nature is fantastic. There are so much to learn more when it comes to gardens. Absolutely recommended best way to start your day

I was really fortunate the day I chose to visit the garden as I arrived soon after it opened and it wasn’t busy. I chose the combined ticket which meant I got to see Le Jardin Majorelle, The Berber museum and the YSL museum. I have to say that although the garden is nice and the colours, particularly the vivid blue, instagram worthy, I don’t really believe it is deserving of all the hype it receives. This is just my personal point of view. It’s a nice garden but it wasn’t my favourite garden in Marrakesh. I think there are nicer ones, including Le Jardin Secret, that seemed far less touristy but again it was quiet when I visited. I am still glad I visited Le Jardin Majorelle to make up my own mind. I found the Berber museum interesting and informative. I also saw the cafe in the garden but decided to walk down the street to the YSL museum and in doing so found a wonderful cafe just before the entrance to the museum that I had to myself. The outside seating area was pretty with flowers and a peaceful area to enjoy a drink. In my humble opinion if you get to see these gardens then great but don’t feel you’ve missed out on the best attraction in Marrakesh if the queues are too long. You may just have saved yourself a feeling of being slightly underwhelmed.
review_title: I couldn’t help feeling somewhat underwhelmed

review_text: This garden is a must-see. Very beautiful and worth the price of admission. It's extra to see the Berber museum but that's interesting.
review_title: Been twice in 10 years and will go again next time I'm in Marrakesh.

review_text: Take your time and amble around the magical gardens. So many cacti and the vibrant colours are phenomenal. I am honestly in awe of the place. Feels surreal now but what an experience of pure beauty
We spent a couple of hours here walking round the beautifully maintained garden. A nice tranquil place to visit in the heart of marrakech. The cafe is also worth a visit and reasonably priced.
The gardens are absolutely stunning, unfortunately when we visited it was extremely busy. The queuing system is very confusing. Make sure you ask which queu you have to follow.
Avoid long queues in the hot sun by booking online. We only checked after getting there but the gardens open really early which would be much less crowded.
Gorgeous YSL home and gardens takes you right out of the city and into paradise. Perfect for a stroll.
Part of our tour. It was nice. But have been to  many Botanical gardens including our own at home which are nicer.
Beautiful and well kept garden. There’s a variety if species selected by Majorelle. Definitely worth a visit. Be aware of queues.

Beware of credit card scam in ticket booth. The gardens are fantastic a 5 star attraction and well worth the visit. I would recommend getting tickets on the website 24hours before going to avoid the long queues and also to avoid any scams. When I purchased our tickets, the man in the booth had his phone propped up suspiciously against the wall and pressed his screen. He then took my card and started flipping it over and back multiple times before putting it in the machine. I think he was videoing my details. Luckily I was able to freeze my revolut card instantly on the WiFi so money could not be taken. I would pay cash and avoid using card. It definitely tainted our experience.
review_title: Beware of Scam paying with card at ticket counter

review_text: A beautiful, peaceful garden in the middle of the city. Don't miss the attached Berber museum and the Yves St. Laurent museum with a collection of his beautiful dresses. Do buy tickets in advance, but be sure to buy tickets for all 3 areas. We also enjoyed lunch there. Loved it!!
Although it is a beautiful garden we couldn't quite understand the hype surrounding it. Be sure to buy tickets in advance but there will still be a long queue for your alloted time.
To me it was crowded, and nothing special about it. It is basically a garden full of cactus and it is not spacious as expected. Don't expect much during your stay.. it's a garden after all.

Great for an amble for an hour or so, but rather over officious guards that keep you moving in one direction round the garden, did make it feel rather like a botanical IKEA.  Try and avoid busy periods, otherwise you'll be surrounded by people taking what I can only imagine must turn out to be very dull photo's of virtually anything.  Some of the queues to take pictures at particular spots left me scratching my head, but I'm a boring, non Instagram dinosaur - apparently.  All in all, a pleasant enough diversion, and I'm glad that it's there - but I'm also glad we pre-booked our tickets.  I would have resented queuing for longer than the fifteen minutes it took us to get in.

Felt like a crowded summer theme park like much like Disney Land.   Full of small children from large families, parents stopping to take pictures of their children, inability to pass the slow moving crowded walk space.    This is surprising to me as i am a true plant lover and i did not enjoy myself.    Do not go here if you are already not in the best of moods.  The long wait times, confusing lines, didn’t know where to go, lack of ability to sit and enjoy the area made this a very uncomfortable experience for me.   I bought a ticket ahead of time and still waited longer than anticipated. I did enjoy the YSL museum, much less crowded.
review_title: Feels like a very crowded theme park, I do not recommend.   Not relaxing.

review_text: We booked a ticket on a certain time. When we came to the Jardin la Majorelle there was a huge que that we skipped thinking we would can go in because we were nice on time. To our suprise (and many in that same que) we had to stand all the way in the back of the line. Fortunately after 15 minutes of waiting we could go in so it wasn't as bad as it looked. The garden is very beautiful and also very  crowded, what's fine because there is a lot to see around you. Different palmtrees and cactus plants. There is a Berber museum that is inside the garden. You have to buy a combination ticket but it is absolutely worth it. It's a beautiful museum with a lot of nice cultural  belonging like clothing to different parts of the Berber cultures. All included we were the for a small two hours and really enjoyed ourselves.

Beautiful garden which feels like an oasis in Marrakech.   We recommend the side entrance by the souk where the line is shorter. It combines and African atmosphere with some Japanese meditation section.

We spent a lovely hour or so wandering around the garden admiring the cactai and beautiful space. It wasn't too busy as we arrived in late afternoon but it's quite expensive for international visitors (110DH). We didn't have time to go into the Berber museum but this is only an extra 20DH so perhaps worth a look.

What a beautiful and serene place to find.  Hidden behind tall walls you’d miss it if it wasn’t for the queue of tourists.  There’s a massive selection of plants which next to the bright blue pottery has a wow factor.  Despite it being on the tourist route it wasn’t crazy busy.

A beautiful place but absolutely rammed full of tourists which rather detracts from the tranquility. Cacti and plants are lovely but it was not  as manicured a garden as I expected. I actually preferred the YSL museum up the street (bought the combo ticket)  and enjoyed the costume exhibition. Definitely recommend booking online - even that is a bit chaotic on arrival - as the queues were horrendous!
review_title: Good to see but overflowing with people

review_text: Jardin Majorelle is a big and very great garden, THere are sooo many plants! I have never seen so big cacti like I saw in Jardin Majorelle. There is also water and many fish, even golden fish! There are so many frogs in the water and the frogs are very tiny. There are also many  pomogranate plants! Great experience. I prefer that you have a tourguide who shows you around the garden so the tourguide can explain better to you. I had a tourguide. You have to visit Jardin Majorelle once in your life.
Absolutely amazing place, undoubtedly the most beautiful place we’ve visited while in Marrakesh. An absolute must see! Highly recommend!
Amazing place, offering amazing views with nice contrast. The legendary Bleu Majorelle give to the place a very photogenic touch. A place definitively worth visiting!
We wentand visited this garden as a part of our half day trip in marrakech. A bit crowded but a nice relaxing walk thru the gardens
Its pretty but nothing from other world, cactus everywhere a blue house, small pond .. I would skip it from my travel to be honest.

What a lovely escape from the noise of the souks. Gorgeous garden, I loved the cactus garden and the vibrant colors of the verdant vegetation and of the blue and yellow buildings.  There are birds singing and there is plenty of room to sit and admire the plants.  The gift shop has some great souvenirs.  There is also a cafe if you would like a refreshment and quick snack.
Lovely place to walk around and escape the hustle of the city. Gets packed quickly though, Pro Tip is to buy your ticket online a few days before you go to get in early
review_title: Beautiful Garden when it isnt swarmed

review_text: Beautiful gardens- well maintained and managed. Adjacent Berber museum worth a visit to see traditional garments and how they vary across the Berber regions
review_title: Exceptionally well kept gardens, great colours and photo opportunities

review_text: This is a must see attraction on any visit to Marrakesh. In particular we’d like to thank Abdulfatta and Soufaine who work at the entrance and helped my friends and I with our pre- booked tickets.   Unfortunately we were unable to retrieve our reservation via our phones and both employees went above and beyond to assist us, which we really appreciated. The gardens were beautiful and did not disappoint.   It was a hot day when we visited but there was plenty of shade to stay cool. Lots of other visitors were ensuring they had instagram worthy photos!  Which there are many opportunities to do.  It’s an amazing place!

The gardens are absolutely stunning. We bought our tickets in advance (definitely the right advice) and it seemed a bit crowded at first (we arrived at 10am), but within a very few minutes, the crowds dispersed as people realized that there was a new MUST-TAKE-A-PHOTO spot every few feet. We were confused about where to go and ended up missing the Berber museum (which I believe is accessible from the gardens), but honestly, we didn't even mind because the gardens themselves were so gorgeous. The other really nice thing was that the plants and trees provide so much cooling shade. The temperature was a good ten degrees cooler than outside. We stayed in the Medina, and the gardens were a wonderful respite.
review_title: Now I know why it's called the selfie capital of Morocco~

review_text: This garden was very serene and the color schemes are very cool. I was glad I visited it. Nice serene spot even though filled with tourists

Wow wow! So beautiful, the garden is so wonderful, despite being busy i  did not feel rushed or on top of others. There is a walk to take you through so you're sure not to miss any section. The plants are unreal, and there are so many varieties. There is more to this than just a garden. There was a bit of a queue for tickets but it moved quickly and as i said it really did not seem over packed. Put on your todo list for sure.
The gardens are a lovely destination to visit in Marrakesh but lots of other people think that too, making the space feel more crowded than one would make like. We preferred the Secret Garden.

Jardin Majorelle is a cute little oasis in Marrakech. Getting the tickets can be confusing but if you plan to go to the garden, berber museum and YSL museum get the combination ticket. The garden is filled of cacti and a cute pond. the berber museum is informative but mostly in french or arabic. YSL did have a great breakdown on the timeline of fashion pieces as well as a great line up of runway pieces.
This garden is so beautiful and so well designed. It is a wonderful break from the city even though it is only minutes away. Take your time here and enjoy.

Purchase tickets online and in advance to avoid lines. Go early-preferably when they open at 8 am to avoid the onslaught of tourists and instagramers who show up after 8.30 am. Student tickets are specifically for International University level students (this confirmation came directly via email from Jardin Majorelle info team) so purchase tix accordingly. Gardens are beautiful-more so when it is not very busy. The Berber museum was very well put together and thoughtful to the Berber culture and traditions. Very informative. Depending on how busy it is, how many pictures you take, min time spent here is probably 30 mins.
review_title: No to be skipped if planned properly

review_text: My second visit and i love the gardens .i enjoyed the berber museum and watched the videos .the coffee shop is excellent .on leaving the queues were enormous  arrive befor 9.30 in. My humble opinion. I adore their perfume only available there

Lovely collection of exotic plants from all over the world and an interesting little museum about Berber culture with over 600 pieces of jewellery and costumes. Restored by Yves St Laurent and his partner Paul Berge to the original garden design. ‘Majorelle’ blue is a wonderful backdrop to the cacti and bougainvillea. Very crowded (worth paying for a guide to skip the long queues) but still peaceful. Next to the YSL museum which is also well worth a visit.
review_title: Peaceful garden in the new quarter next to the YSL museum

review_text: A gorgeous garden with the famous blue backdrop. Expect it to be very busy. The cafe is good but pricey

We visited the gardens after the YSL Museum and purchased a combined ticket. Unfortunately, whilst the YSL Museum was one of the trip's highlights, we didn't feel the same about Jardin Majorelle. We ended up not getting there until later in the day when it was very busy in some places. The gardens were pretty quiet, but there were queues of people at all of the famous spots to take pictures and then walk on. The beauty of the garden felt quite tainted by this, and we were in and out in 15 minutes. It is a beautiful place and maybe if we had gone earlier in the day I would have felt differently about it. If you are looking to see the gardens, I would recommend Le Jardin Secret in the medina instead.
review_title: Beautiful place, a little spoiled by the queues for photos

review_text: i love how the place is so natural and so relaxing and beautiful im going to visit again soon best regards

Hands down the most stunning place in Marrakesh. The gardens are beautiful with a large range of cacti and other plants to admire. The grounds are all perfectly manicured and clean. The building is beautiful though a hotspot for people trying to be Morocco’s next top model which can be frustrating if all you want is a simple photo! Make sure you book as the queue for tickets is insane and arrive when your ticket allows to prevent a wait; I booked and arrived on time and skipped the whole queue! Don’t come to Marrakesh and not visit the Jardin Majorelle!
Book tickets in advance. Cheaper to book combination tickets. There are 2 queues, so make sure you are in correct queue.
A beautiful garden but the large crowd limits the peacefulness of the garden. Expensive for such a brief experience. By all means go… but only if you have surplus time in Marrakesh.
Ali made certain we visited this amazing site/home/garden Trip was winter 2020 just prior to Covid outbreak
review_title: Part of our 2020 trip to Morocco

review_text: A simply stunning immaculately maintained garden (with the bonus of seeing YSL's Villa Oasis garden next door too). Go early, pre book tickets to avoid the long queues. And also visit the YSL museum next door which is well worth it. Nice cafe too in a walled courtyard.
It's a great area, although it gets too busy sometimes, so try to go when it's not peak season. Never again during the busy tourist season; the line for tickets was over two hours long.
It is one of the must to see in Marakech! Just to have ideas how it is posssible to make miracles in dry  Morocco land. Very inspiring experience :)
This is a beautiful place to spend a few hours. I know very little about fashion but I really enjoyed the museum and the gardens. The gift shop was great and I enjoyed both restaurants.

I bought a combined ticket for the YSL museum and gardens online which needs to be done 24hrs in advance. If you turn up on the day to buy tickets you will likely have to queue whereas you stroll on in with your pre-bought ticket. Note -  the museum is closed on a Wednesday. The gardens are beautiful but very touristy and you have to fight for your chance for photographs due to the many photoshoots going on around you. Had a lovely lunch in the cafe and highly recommend the fresh lemonade which was refreshing on a super hot day. Well worth a visit.
Good, but was 2nd option over Yves Saint Laurent Museum; it was closed at our arrival, the cost is a little bit expensive
A long queue awaited us but it was worth the waiting, the garden is a real jewel in the desert and with many interesting plants and cactuses
review_title: remarkable vegetation and well kept garden

review_text: it was so beautiful and peaceful. there wasn't so much people so the visit was comfortable. the blue colors were so important
This gardenis  full of familiar & exotic plants & interesting architectural details.  It can be visited easily at one's own pace.
great way to spend a couple of hours looking at their gardens and see a very good collection of cactus and other plants
review_title: Nice place to spend some time

review_text: I love Jardin Majorelle, its distinct "Majorelle Blue" and the floras. To avoid the crowd, get your ticket online and come here early so you will have time to appreciate the place.
Great garden, very clean and organized! The cactus was amazing! You will not be disappointed! A++++++

waste of time ... not worth the effort at all ... it's too hyped for what it really is.  We paid the tickets, came in, toured it in 5 minutes and our reaction was: that's it???? NOT WORTH the queue to see it ... at all.
Much smaller than expected, its nice and a must have if you visit Marrakesh. Nice YSL Shop inside with good prices
Get up early and enjoy the peace of these gardens. Take a while to sit and enjoy, it’s hard to believe that the hussle and bustle of the city, it’s just outside the walls.

Quite pleasant gardens, but ticketing and entry arrangements ridiculous, certainly until lunchtime. Firstly, the gardens are actually not that big, and certainly unable to cope with the demand. It’s necessary to join a long queue to buy a ticket (for us, one hour), then join another queue to get in. For us, about 40 minutes. This queue competes for entry with those holding online tickets. And tour groups have priority over all! The gardens were completely overwhelmed by demand and had to work on a one in, one out arrangement. To cap it all 120MAD each without entry to the museum. In all honesty, the gardens are not that spectacular and certainly not worth the queuing and the cost. Once in it’s a bunched-up one way system. It has to be said though, that the gardens are beautifully tended. (In fact, we bought our tickets from two women who just gave up queuing and we came close to doing the same)
review_title: Pleasant, but really not worth the queuing and cost.

review_text: This location was a part of a guided tour of Marrakech and is well worth experiencing. It does not require a signifcant amount of time but the trees and foliage are stunning.
review_title: Beautiful garden in the middle of Marrakech

review_text: Pleasant, fairly small garden, of mostly cacti and succulents, with few flowering plants. Beware of long queues, as garden restricts numbers. There are 2 queues, one to buy a ticket (in our case over 1 hour in a queue that rarely moved because the garden was 'full') and then second queue to gain entry, about half hour, so buy tickets online and queue just once. We did not have time to go in the YSL museum.
review_title: Pleasant garden of cacti & succulents, but beware long queues

review_text: This once private garden was a phenomenal adventure with hundreds of unique plants. The garden covers a very large area and there is a cafe' to relax and enjoy the scenic view

First thing I must stress to everyone, go early as the line ups can be quite long, we were there at 830 am. The gardens are , a living work of art composed of exotic plants and rare species Jacques Morelle collected during his worldwide travels.  The gardens were opened to the public in 1947 but after his death in 1962, it fell in abandon ..but luckily Pierre Berger et Yves Saint- Laurent acquired it in 1980. The garden is a place where it is so peaceful and serene.

The garden is exquisite and the cafe offers a wide range of great Moroccan food, including a wonderful breakfast . The Berber Museum is fascinating though the lack of any english labelling was somewhat inconsiderate towards us anglophones whose french craft words are somewhat limited. However, the big but is that Majorelle doesn't appear to limit the numbers of tourists entering the garden and so within an hour of opening, it is like Time Square: noisy, crowded and full of narcissistic princesses in floaty dresses who are only interested in striking poses in the most iconic locations to feed their insatiable appetite for social media attention. This creates congestion and even queues at a number of hotspots which in times gone by one would have lingered at to soak up the beauty of an exceptional botanic garden. All pretence that this is a place of charm, sophistication and contemplation is soon lost and you may wonder why you bothered to make the effort. (NB: a taxi to/from Majorelle from/to the Medina should be no more than 30 DH. All taxi drivers will attempt to get at least twice out of you so agree the price up front. When they realise you're serious, they eventually given in)
review_title: All charm destroyed  by a tourist tsunami

review_text: The garden was carefully arranged, like an embroidery. You can feel the love of the various owners for the place.

The museum gardens and art are quite beautiful and a pleaser hour can be spent here. The birds we didn't see as the area was closed. The Berber museum costs extra, so if you've already had a Berber experience it can be skipped.

I guess this is one of the top gardens I don’t really get it seems like a lot of cactus bamboo and a few trees. There is huge lines to get in it’s supposed to be like the place to take Instagram photos because of the blues and yellows I just don’t get it
review_title: Not one of the most exciting Gardens

review_text: Excellently maintained gardens with unique flora and fauna. Welcome surprises on the turtles and frogs. Well laid out. Should have gone earlier and booked tickets beforehand to avoid the queues!
review_title: A welcome escape from the hullabaloo of Marrakech

review_text: We visited here on our first day in Marrakech, taking a taxi from the hotel. It was a private garden, that's now connected to the Berber Museum and the YSL Museum. You can buy a ticket for just the garden at 120D or pay a bit more to add one of both other museums at the same time. The garden is just a walk through bamboo and cactus, with the occasional fountain and pool. For the first day, it was interesting, but nothing special. BUT, we also visited the Berber Museum and that was small but fantastic, well worth the 30D extra. Artefacts, tools, weapons, clothes and one room full of jewellery with a star studded ceiling to represent the nights sky in the desert.

Thinking to avoid some of the heat of the day, we headed to Marjorelle gardens in the morning.  And so did a lot of other people.  We stood in line for about 45 minutes to get tickets.  It was hot.  But inside the gardens were shady and very well maintained.  We spent about 3 hours here including lunch in their restaurant,  Very pleasant.  Would recommend for anyone.

Since "everyone" told us that we have to visit this place, we did. It is easy to buy a ticket on the internet to avoid waiting in line for the ticket booth. The gardens are impressive and beautifully maintained. The fountains, waterways and the main house are in the beautiful special blue color of Yves Saint Laurent. It is certainly worth a visit although I wouldn't say that you haven't seen Marrakech without seeing these gardens...
review_title: Beautiful gardens, worth the visit though a bit oversold

review_text: Nice way to spend a few relaxing hours before heading to airport. Very distinct visually. Quite compact. There are some free gardens around locally just off the main road as an alternative

A must-do experience while in Marrakech, but quickly overwhelmed by visitors as the day goes on. A real oasis in the madness of Marrakech. Avoid the taxi drivers outside the main gates who will gouge you for a trip back into town - walk a little way away, and then prepare to haggle.
review_title: Avoid the tour groups - go early

review_text: If you are a gardener or just enjoy the tranquil setting of gardens - this is the place to go Unfortunately depending on the time you go there may be a lot of instagram influencers looking to take their photos everywhere so be ready to wait at points to take photos
Beautiful place to visit and can’t believe it’s so quiet in the gardens.  Recommend that if you want to visit to buy tickets online as there is a queue normally.
The entry fee is off putting but worth a look if you enjoy this type of activity. The garden is well kept and serene

The most romantic designer garden by a great fashion designer YVES SAINT LAURENT Loved the colour themes of blues turquoise yellow and the thriving plants made a great setting for photos A truly relaxing time and will visit again

Lower your expectations I can full of high expectations considering the big names involved However although the place is well kept, even d catus look clean the place is v small. When there is couple of big tour groups like ours it's hard to take photo without someone in your camera's view Photos are not allowed in the museum and there os v little to see just a few mannequins Given YSL and his partner's dark history with Moroccon young boys all in all I have not enjoyed the place
Beautiful place, relaxing and shaded. The blue paint is such a distinctive mark of this unique place. A must visit while you in Marrakesh.
A lovely gardens but I think it’s over rated In Marrakech it’s an oasis I agree The cactus garden is fantastic But be seen much better around the world.

The Garden Majorelle is not only a lovely garden but also has a small Berber Museum that has amazing artifacts.  We learned a tremendous amount about the Berber culture at this location.  Don't miss it.
Remarkable gardens with history, restorations by Yves Saint Laurent and partner, then foundation, with flora international and cobalt accents

YSL created a home and workplace in crazy Marrakesh and part of his legacy is this small garden in the modern city. It's a garden with exotic plants  with burgundy painted paths and blue and yellow urns. Take your time just as you would sip an expensive wine.
Fun place to see a variety of botanicals and taking fun, colourful pictures in Marrakech. You don't really need more than an hour here.
Overpriced entrance fee, but the garden is nice. Museum was small, and   displayed basic Berber items. Cafe was nice, with decent fare.
We visited this wonderful garden and recomend it highly. The entrence fee is high, but I think it is worth to go if you like plants and cactus.
A must go spot whilst in Marrakesh.  The colors, and unique history is just amazing. Entrance is fast and affordable.
Overpriced for what is just in esscense a private garden. There are a large number of better places to visit in Marrakech
We found the garden nice, but not worth the entrance fee. Once the museum opens again, it may be worth to travel to this destination.
review_title: Considering the entrance fee - this is not so special.

review_text: Decently pretty gardens but certainly not worth the 120 MAD entrance price. I was in and out within 5 minutes and there was a feeling among a lot of the people I saw leaving at the same time as me of "Oh, is that it?". I loved Marrakesh but it generally isn't somewhere I'd rate in terms of specific tourist attractions - better to go and get lost in the Medina and eat some nice food.
review_title: Among the most expensive 5 minutes of my life

review_text: If you only do one thing go here, it is the most beautiful garden and so serene and quiet out of the bustling city that is Marrakech. The gardens are immaculate and have so many wonderful plants and amazing cactus collection. You will get home and want to transform your garden!!! Lovely restaurant here too, had a super lunch, not to be missed

This is the one main attraction in the new city and is an oasis amongst the modern sprawl of Marrakech. The site is not huge - it doesn't take long to visit - but it is worth it.  It is very popular and busy though so be prepared to queue (if you don't book ahead) and to have to deal with crowds in quite a small area.
The lovely gardens and museum were one of the highlights of our visit.  They even sell "Marjorelle Blue" paint in the museum shop.
review_title: A must see during any visit to Marrakech

review_text: Gorgeous garden in central Marrakech. You will find quiet corners and delightful displays in vibrant colors. Definitely worth a visit. If you are a photographer you will find many opportunities for gorgeous photos
I went with younger sister and she got very bored ( definitely not a lot of things to se if you are a kid ) al though she did like swing the animals that include fish , frogs and turtles .
review_title: Don’t recommend for children under age of 10 . Although it is a very lovely garden

review_text: Wonderful gardens. Great way to spend some time away from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. Enjoy the vibrant colors.

I visited due to top opinions, but for me the place - as nice as it is - doesnt justify the entrance price in any way. I may be ignorant and if you like plants you may appreciate the visit more. Perhaps Ive set my expectations too high. I would say Maroccan price would be adequate (40MAD instead of 120MAD).
review_title: Decent spot, but expensive for what it is.

review_text: Cost MAD120 pp. USD 8 Small.  Poor.  Nothing special. Lot of bamboo.  No flowers. How can this be the no. 1 attraction?? Highly underwhelming. Market square and Medina were OK. Otherwise forget Marrakesh.  Same for Rabat, Fes and Casablanca. Tangier was great.  We should have stayed two weeks there instead.
review_title: What a joke !!  No. 1 thing to do in Marrakesh???  B.S.

review_text: This was on our itinerary and we were very unimpressed.  Tons of tourists taking selfies.  We asked to leave 5 minutes after we arrived.  Save your money.  Go to the souk and enjoy the market, food and local culture.
A great escape to nature. We have spent a wonderful morning walking around the gardens. It was very clean and very peaceful

If you’re going to Marrakesh, stop by for a cheeky visit. It’s not v big so you won’t need hours. Get there early to be the influencers. We paid the non student, non residential price of 120 dirham each, which I feel is worth it for the experience. There are several go-to places for photos so you might have to queue once inside. There does happen to be a cloakroom on entry so you can leave any large bags. The cute cafe is a win; the staff are great & honey pancakes (which were remarkably similar to crumpets) were beaut. Stay away from iced coffees. There’s a gift shop, too. If you’re a YSL fan, don’t forget your debit card! One visit is enough but deffo whack it on your to do list.

This was a beautiful place to wander around and then enjoy coffee and dessert at the café (which also has wi-fi).  The line to get in was really long but I already had a ticket and walked right in.  The YSL museum is also a short walk away.

My worst experience in Marrakech. Expensive, small, huge lines under the hot sun, too much people in…What to say about it? Except for the “Instagramable” photos that people can get inside because of the bright blue colour?
Marvellous gardens, extremely well-kept. Unfortunately both the museums were both closed for renovation

From a historical perspective, this location is interesting.  The grounds are quite sprawling and beautiful.  Sadly the experience was dampened by girls and their personal need for the perfect Instagram photo.
The gardens are really nice but quite expensive for a family to visit. It only took 30 minutes to walk around. Unfortunately the YSL museum was closed due to renovations
review_title: Gardens were beautiful but expensive for the size

review_text: Beautiful garden. Well worth a visit. Its bigger than I thought it was so can easily spend 1 and a half hours there. Its more than the blue building you see in pictures. I would recimmend going as soon as they open in the morning. We got there at 9:30 and there were only a few tourists and no queue outside to get in. By the time it was 11, it was jam packed and queues started building up for taking pictures at scenic areas. Only reason I've not given it 5 stars is because it's over priced for tourists. If you were to choose one garden this one would be the one to go for.
review_title: Beautiful garden but over priced if you are not Moroccan.

review_text: Well worth it, do not miss, costs 70 dirhams to enter. There is a coffee shop also if you want a drink
review_title: Beautiful Moroccan blue with stunning cacti plants

review_text: There are other, bigger, better gardens in Marrakech. This one is very nice, but if you only need to chose one, I preferred the Jardin Secret

A great mid-morning to early afternoon trip, the garden was serene and beautiful. I would estimate it's about 15 degrees (F) cooler once you enter the garden than outside it's gates. A lovely stroll and easy paced compared to the chaos of the Medina and Souks, this was truly a retreat!
review_title: Beat the Heat with a trip to the garden!

review_text: Its actually a nice garden with a lot of different plants. The blue house is very beautiful and good for a photoshoot. But as there are so many people inside, its actually not a nice experience anymore.
review_title: Too expensive for what it is

review_text: The gardens are absolutely gorgeous. Be sure to visit early or you can end up in the middle of a lot of photoshoots,

Only the Berber Museum inside is interesting (very) but you cannot go there without paying the very expensive entrance fees for Jardin Majorelle. Jardin Majorelle  is a small garden with cactus and desert plants, has no particular interest for us... unless you are a botanist
A visual feast of nature blended with ceramics and objets in dramatic hues of blue- and with a beautifully curated museum at its heart
review_title: Mesmerising combination of nature and art

review_text: This is a real jewel in the city.  get there early and its quiet to with a great Tea room.  The peace and tranquillity made it a highlight of the holiday.
Many plants from around the world (especially mexico).   VERY IMPORTANT to save time to see the Berber / Amazigh museum which was deeply informative.
review_title: Worth the visit (after the YSL museum)

review_text: i really liked this garden and the design of it , i want there zith my family and i was amawed by it .i totally recommend

Majorelle is nice but just not worth the 120dh and long queuing to enter. The cafe is probably the most expensive we've seen in Marrakech, the plants are average and honestly we just don't get the fuss. We skipped the YSL museum though and the Oasis was closed the day we visited so maybe we just missed out on much. Do yourself a favour and skip this overpriced garden and choose Anima instead (same price, free transport, amazing and surprising garden).

We visited on our last day in Marrakech - we went around midday - just before it starts getting hot! It was 40º, there was shady spots to get out of the sun - and thoroughly recommend going before lunch or early evening. Great to see how Moroccan fashion has evolved and how Yves Saint Laurent made this his home.

The garden is pretty with many different green plants and bright blue  buildings. Inside the garden there is a Berber Museum (costs extra), an Yves Saint-Laurent exhibition and a nice café. Most information about the plants and Berber items are in Arabic and French, so bring a dictionay if you don't speak either, or just look and enjoy. Is you choose to visit the Yves Saint-Laurent museum 100 meters down the street, you can buy a ticket for all three entrances and save some money.
review_title: A nice way to spend a day in Marrakech.

review_text: This was great curated informational tour of yves saint laurent the only thing that spoiled it we were not allowed to take photos which spoiled the visit

I love plants and was quite taken buy the gardens and the icing was definitely the Berber museum. I would rate the garden experience 3.5 and the museum a 4. It's quite a small garden for the amount charged and so is the medium. All doable in 30-40 mins. My beef was the prices advertised on the Baird are not what you get charged at the door. It cost 150 dirhams to access garden and Berber museum. Board had around 80 dirhams which was student only price. Anyway, a decent day out in boiling hot weather so plant shades were a safe haven
review_title: Do visit but get tickets online cheaper if you can

review_text: Very interesting place where to spend some hours in relax above all when the temperature of Marrakech is high 'cos thanks to all the plants, coming from all over the world, this place offers a natural shelter in a magical background
Definitely worth a visit to see this amazing garden with its hundreds of cacti and other plants, flowers and structures.  Fallen in love with Majorelle Blue. xxx
review_title: Stunning garden displays - eye popping colour and designs

review_text: it was great to know more about this lovely city, we really enjoy this trip, we were tired but it worth every minute. Good to see .

While the gardens were presented well, it was a very small place. It has some fun photo opportunities with bright blue walls and nice architecture, but the variety of plants is lacking. We spent maybe an hour in total including the gift shops and the small on site beree museum. It is nicely done, but most of the plant life is a variety of cactus species.
it was great to know more about a lovely city, we really enjoy this trip, we were tired but it worth every minute.
While it was interesting to see, Its a lot of money for the amount of time you will spend in it. Though I appreciated the care it takes and the colours where beautiful.

We meandered through this beautiful garden, admiring the plants as well as the garden design. Not sure if we could have had a guide but I think that would add to the experience to have a better understanding of the thinking behind the garden and learn more about the plants. We stopped in the restaurants and enjoyed light nibbles and drinks.

The Gardens are lovely and contain beautiful succulents as well as other trees and flowers.   I enjoyed walking the grounds, but I wish it was bigger.  The cafe has a clean bathroom which you may use.
Go early and take your time. It can get be crowded, but there seem to breaks between groups, so it pays to not be in a rush and also enjoy the people watching!
review_title: A Must Do when in Marrakech

review_text: very exceptionel place i highl y recommend it its eeally very amazing and its one of the most beautifull gardens

Got in around 10:15. Plenty of folk already there, lining up at multiple places to pose for pictures, and guess what, you get to pause your walking to accommodate them or get in line yourself. The garden itself is delightfully shady and cool. The plants are in obvious good health, and the landscaping design, that is the strategic placement of plants to one another, is pleasing. Flat, paved paths, good for mobility impaired. Not a particularly child friendly attraction, best for adults, good place to bring older relative because shady, pretty, and level path. Still, as a visitor I would think twice before visiting, as in my opinion, it does not illuminate Moroccan culture or history.

This beautifully shaded garden with a wide variety of exotic plants will help you escape the Moroccan summer heat for a while. It was our favorite attraction in all of Marrakech and offered a stress-free, leisurely walk along pathways in a large space so shaded and cool that you’d think you’re indoors in an air-conditioned building.
review_title: A wonderful escape from a chaotic city!

review_text: Stunning gardens such wonderful colours and so beautifully laid out. The museums are worth a visit especially the YSL

This beautiful garden was a great spot to relax and enjoy the previous estate of Yves Saint Lauren. The entrance fee should not prevent you from visiting this incredibly attractive garden set in the centre of Marrakech.
The entrance fee should not stop you from visiting this historic collection of the beautiful cactus garden, an oasis in the heart of Marrakesh.
review_title: Beautiful Garden and collection of Cactus and Succulents

review_text: Beautiful, peaceful garden in busy Marrakech.  This was a spot to relax and feel the difference while sightseeing busy Marrakech.
Loved it ! was beautiful ! Why blue ? Because when there is water there is life ! Long queues to be expected but if you have a guide you can easily avoid it !
review_title: Amazing ! To see once in your life !

review_text: Had such a nice visit to Jardin Majorelle that I actually went twice. Beautiful gardens. Nice staff.
An amazing cactus garden although too many visitors taking over for selfies. Can be calm and cool oasis.
Le Jardin Majorelle was everything I imagined and more!  I loved spending time in the garden.  The greenery and landscaping are immaculate and a must-see when visiting Morocco.
Nice place to spend the morning or LATE AFTERNOON. CAFE AVAILABLE historic interest book shop Fashion interest

One of the tourist attractions around marrakech so expect a crowd. Best to go first thing in the morning as less people and you can enjoy the grounds better plus shorter queue for admission tickets (advise from our private tour driver). If doing a quick stroll 1 hour is sort of sufficient...could easily spend longer if not in a rush! Beautiful grounds and lovely areas to sit and just relax.
Very nice place to visit with an amazing spot for Photo shooting me and my friends took 1000 photos there I recommend it

Majorelle Garden was like a oasis and was one of highlit tour in Marrakech including the Bahia Balace inside old Medina. We hgily recommend visiting the place to early morming because it is less crowded
review_title: Majorelle Garden was like a oasis and was one of highlit tour in Marrakech including the Bahia Balace inside old Medina.

review_text: This Jardin Majorelle is one of the perfect oasis in Marrakech even is litle bite priced compared other historical sites inside the city. Highly recommended for everyone who wants to take photos! Go eraly morning because it is less crowded

Beautiful garden but all those would-be instagrammers spoil part of the experience-i enjoyed walking around. It was smaller than expected and yes its pretty but i would not go back and there are many more beautiful gardens in other places of the world without the price tag. The Berbere museum was an unexpected delightful experience and i would have loved to spend more time inside! When i bought the tickets late afternoon i was not informed about the closing time and almost missed going inside because i did the garden first.
review_title: Pretty but too many posing instagrammers spoil part of the experience

review_text: Nice garden, but not worth the price. In a city like Marrakech where you can see history and beauty in every corner, there is no reason to see that garden among many. Also, the place is full of people taking picture to share on Instagram. There is no peace in that garden as far as I was able to see!

This is one of the most visited garden in Marrakech including saint laurent museum and berbere. This museum offers insight into the unique history and arts of the Berber peoples of Morocco. As well as, Musée Yves Saint Laurent Museum is super pretty!
review_title: Must this Garden inside Marrakech city

review_text: But not a real competition to normal botanical gardens, even though they charge as if they were. Some spots are vey picture worthy. Not too crowded - a big plus.
