Vibrant colors and satisfying symmerty - An Instagrammer's paradise! Definitively wear something bright and complimentary to the vibrant blue and yellows for nice IG photos. Get here early as it gets soooo busy, and waiting in the hot sun in that queue is no fun. Loved the Berber museum too, showing all the traditional clothes and artifacts of the Berbers. Don't get a taxi outside the gardens - they charge exorbitant prices. Nice cafes line the streets with that cool mist spray - much needed after wandering around the gardens.
review_title: Get here early to avoid the queues!

review_text: Wonderful oasis in the heat of the day. If you want to visit the Yves St Laurent Museum next dorr, check opening times as we had to make a return trip.

It was a beautiful garden, that's all. It was small, overcrowded, overrated. I think what makes it so special is its history. Because of its popularity, to take a nice picture was very hard. And i guess again due to its popularity ticket price is 140 dirhems, which is crazy.
By far the "must see" of Morocco! Plan to spend at least 3 to 4 hours here; you won't want to leave. Ever. It's that amazing.

Very peaceful and shady, a big contrasts to the busy streets of Marrakech. If you are facing a long queue, we went straight to Yves St Laurent museum and bought a ticket for both the museum and the gardens and skipped the entire queue.
Nice and quiet place. Unfortunately, the queue was too long and we had to wait a bit long. We will visite it again
must visit this beautiful garden if younger in Marrakech, you will find all kinds of plants there, coming from the four corners of the world, also the traces of the famous hyves Saint Laurent

A pretty garden but nothing spectacular. It's likely overhyped because of the name. I've seen much more impressive botanical gardens elsewhere (California, Nevada, etc.). But the shades of blue you can find here really is beautiful, and you can get some really nice photos here with the Majorelle Blue and green cacti. The small Berber museum inside doesn't have any English explanations, only Arabic, French and maybe Spanish? Be sure to come early to avoid the crowds. You can also buy tickets online to avoid the long lines that tend to form.
review_title: Beautiful, come early to avoid crowds

review_text: Lovely and immersive. You can really see the 60s vision of a garden come through. There was a queue despite coming early as advised by our riad, so bring hats to protect your head! But once you’re in it’s naturally shaded and beautiful.

Beautiful gardens and interesting history - though could be better represented. The Pierre Berges exhibit in the centre is excellent, but small, but worth the add on. If worries about visiting other places in Marrakech, this is a nice place to start. However, it was quite busy at 11am, so try and go even earlier or much later perhaps. Takes about 75 mins at a leisurely pace.

Simply beautiful...  so many wonderful plants in excellent condition.  Really spectacular. Next door to the Yves St Laurent museum.  Could have done without the museum, but the gardens were wonderful.

My wife and I recently visited Jardin Majorelle and although she thoroughly enjoyed the photo opportunities, I found the whole experience underwhelming and overpriced (although there is a considerable discount for students and locals so take your student IDs if you have them). The whole setup, including the museum is a tourist trap and if I could go backwards I'd use the almost half day on any of the many more culturally important and beautiful sights in and around Marrakech.
Beautiful garden. Perfect for a quiet start to your day. We went early, but it started to get busy fast.

Beautiful gardens and such a relaxing and calm spot in the craziness of the centre of Marrakech. Lovely gift shop. We liked the Berber exhibition but would have liked to see it more reflect culture and language of the Amazigh. Only negative we felt some of the staff were quite rude, but not all.

Despite pre booking a timed entry the gardens were overcrowded which made it difficult to enjoy what should have been a tranquil visit. The gardens are nice but I wouldn’t rave about them. Not sure why this is one of the top rated things to do in Marrakesh. The Bedouin museum was very interesting but again far too many people, not chance to social distance. What was the point of timed entry if they just let too many people in at once!

Beautiful gardens but I was disappointed how small this was with quite limited seating on such a busy day..  We hadn't prebooked  which was a mistake.   I had read about it being a tranquil oasis but actually it was chocker full of people looking for shade on a hot day.
In the middle of a residential area is the garden next to YSL Museum. A very nice and quiet place. Unfortunately, the queue was too long and we had to wait a bit long.
we loved this place such interesting plants and colurs. it was a shame we missed the pierre berger museum , it was supposed to be breathtaking

The best tip - go early - we were there as soon as it opened. We got in easily and it was SO quiet you could really absorb and appreciate the wonderful gardens and planting. We went into the Berber Museum too which is fantastic and I would love to go back there again to soak up the exhibitions and info further. We had tea in the little cafe - everyone was super friendly and great service. We noticed that on our way out suddenly there were people everywhere on the paths as its so popular - I think anytime after mid morning it could possibly too busy to appreciate the beauty of the place. We visited early on a Saturday morning.

A banal garden composed with plants from all-around the world: from Japan, to USA, to South America and other African states. Nothing special. Not for sure to pay 12 euros. But one of the only 3 or 4 places to check in morrocco
review_title: Nothing better to do, it's OK to see

review_text: Relaxing and pretty.  Go early (or late afternoon) to avoid the queues.  Buy the combination ticket and see the 2 museums. Don’t miss the Berber museum.  Wasn’t expecting it to be so interesting.  Also, the YSL museum up the road…fascinating.  Great morning spent here.

Walking through different parts of this large garden is a very relaxing experience. I never knew that cacti could come in so many different shapes and sizes ! I recommend booking online in advance. The online booking needs to be at least 24 hours in advance. Whether on-line or at the ticket office buy the Combined Ticket because the Berber museum is a MUST see !
review_title: A beautiful selection of cacti and a great well preserved Berber museum

review_text: A bit out of town (though walkable from the medina if the weather isn't too hot) the gardens are delightful, but it felt relatively expensive for a relatively small garden. But definitely glad we went
review_title: An enjoyable stroll, but quite small

review_text: This place is just magical! Do not miss out on this! I recommend going first thing in the morning so you can see the place with not many tourists around. I wouldn't recommend to buy the combined tickets tho, the museums weren't good at all. No English explanation either so unless you speak French, you won't know what are you looking at.
Sure it's a must to do when you are in Morocco ❤️ Very nice garden near the museum Yves Saint Laurent... It's instagrammable place
review_title: Must to do if you are in Marrakech

review_text: We paid for the museum and garden ticket, 440DM for two and to be honest it wasn't worth that at all in my opinion. My Mrs wanted to go and see it, and it was one to tick off the list but very limited in value and in my opinion, and we could be out of there in about 45 mins covering everything at a slow pace. Still, she was very pleased to see it so 3 stars, she has suggested possibly 4 so we are meeting in the middle. Down to me, i'd give less than that.

I would have given this 4* except for the price! 120 Dirham for international visitors but only 40 Dirham for locals? Perhaps we should have a similar charging structure in the UK for international visitors instead of "suggested donations" - it would raise revenue for sure! I reckon its worth 60 Dirham max as the gardens take around 15/20 minutes max to walk around - we have seen better and bigger

I don't like leaving negative reviews, but the garden and Yves Saint Laurent museum were way overpriced and I wish I had read the other reviews before wasting time here. First, the garden is nice and cool, and if it's a hot day and you have no other way of cooling down, by all means spend $22 each to walk around the small garden for 15 minutes. The berber museum was also small and not terribly interesting. The best part of the Yves Saint Laurent museum was the movie about the man (in French, with English subtitles). But I just don't understand the price. If it had been $5, or even $10, I might bother to spend an hour or so here (gardens and museum) if I had extra time.  It was our least favorite thing to do in our 7 days in Marrakech.
review_title: Really? How they get away with charging $44 for 2 is beyond me

review_text: Well worth a visit but buy tickets online before turning up, and get there before 9am to see the gardens before they get too busy. Nice little cafe in the grounds
one of the more memorable gardens I've seen in my life.  Very well maintained and enjoyable to visit.
Essential visit to this magical place in Marrakech. Impressive garden and beautiful colors in the city.
Its a nice oasis in the middle of the city but quite small!  A nice break from the busy Medina and souks

If you are tired of shopping and bargaining and the noisy Medina, take a break and visit this interesting and beautiful gardens as well as the adjacent  Yves Saint Laurent and Berber museums . Entry fees - 220.00 dirham (around 22 USD )  per person .
Its a heaven on earth, not a plant person me but truly amazing, its a wonderful afternoon walking around the gardens, great little coffee/tea shop at the end without crazy prices
This is such a colourful and artistic oasis, cannot miss while in Marrakech. I'm not a designer brand fan by any chance, but the way they present his life and his creations is very captivating.
Not a long visit but a must visit. Absolutely beautiful. We'll kept and clean. Most enjoyable, walk around.
The museum was of interest about the life and work of Yves Saint Laurent, also when you come to move on to the gardens you walk straight in ,the queue for just the gardens can be quite long.

Jardin Majorelle is a perfect oasis in Marrakech. Lovely manicured gardens and water features. The cafe staff were really nice and food/drink good. The little Berber museum inside is definitely worth a visit too. However, it was so busy...people queuing to take photos in certain areas and queuing for the museum as well... it wasn't ideal with a 4 year old and we felt a bit rushed in places and couldn't queue to see some things. It might be better for them to limit numbers onto the site more effectively? That said, I'm glad we went, it was a nice day out.

We visited the garden and the Berber museum in April 2022, it wasn't as busy as some people said. Probably because we visited there in the afternoon. The collection of the plants are extensive, and the colour design in the garden are very pretty, lots of places for photo opportunities. The Berber museum was a plus to the garden, its amazing to see the jewellery collection of the Nomads. We really enjoyed our visit there.

The cactus collection is worth the visit by itself.  The colourful building stands out like the ocean in the middle of the oasis.  The museum has a wonderful collection of artefacts and garments which illustrate the history of Morocco.
Be sure and hit the YSL museum while you are there. Great boutique as well! Recommend hiring a guide so you bypass the long  lines.

Beautiful and well-maintained garden with history. Crowded with lots of tourists. The line was very long so best to get a “skip the line” ticket. Good thing the weather was not hot and humid that day.
review_title: Worth visiting for a change of scenery

review_text: Such a beautiful place to visit. Really a must see in Marrakech. It is huge and makes for beaautiful pictures. We saw turtles, Koi fish, Frogs and tonnes of beautiful plants.
Very expensive for what it is, 12€ is not worth it, I think should prized something like 3€, the visit is short

Visited the gardens and had to pay an entrance fee but that was reasonable. Long queue though as you would expect on a  popular tourist attraction. The gardens are beautiful in the variety of plants on show but the bright vivid painted colours of the walls of the buildings is what really make the gardens pop and prove to be popular photo stop points.
nice, peaceful, cultural and fashionable garden in the busy new town. A moment of quite contemplation. don't forget to visit the museum of YSL next to it.

you can't spend your stay i Morocco and specifically in Marrakesh without having a half day visit of this Magnificent Garden  through Planet of Morocco we discovered Majorelle Garden and we had a lot of amazing pictures in this lovely place
review_title: Le meilleur Bleu et Jaune de Marrakech

review_text: The gardens are lovely, but it seemed a bit pricey for what is was. Also we went early (9.30 am) and it was already very crowded, which ruined the ambience somewhat.
review_title: Nice gardens but a bit overpriced and busy

review_text: Lovely and well maintained gardens. Lots of chances for photos and if you booked the combined ticket - the second museum for the Berber people is situated here. A nice place to visit but very busy as everyone comes from YSL too. Lots of interesting and well cultivated trees and some fish, frogs and tortoises too!

it is a beautiful garden. Best to do on a sunny afternoon so the color zing more. only downside, it is very popular!! so very difficult to take pictures without strangers on it. do not forget to visit the Berbere Museum inside.
Amazing visit to YSL gardens. Peaceful and colorful, it is an oasis on the edge of the Medina of Marrakech. We loved our visit.

Loved our visit here.  Great to look around and take in the relaxed atmosphere away from the chaos of the centre.  You really do feel you are away from it all in the beautiful secluded majorelle gardens.  Apparently his home in Marrakech was Yves place of inspiration and it certainly oozes this whilst walking around especially the museum.  The opening of both museums was organised in 2017.  Apparently all of his ashes are buried in the Majorelle gardens.  What a great place to kill some hours whilst mooching around in the museum.
This was a nice garden but I wasn't taken aback by it.  It was average, in my opinion.  Maybe had we gone during the Spring (which it was still cool in March), it may have been a lot better.
Beautiful place to visit but busy: loved it but preferred the secret garden in the city centre Medina
Pay the extra and visit the small museum inside the garden.  The garden is pretty but not entirely typical of the area feeling like part of the SW US more than Morocco.

It’s a pretty garden, but definitely not spectacular.  Maybe my hopes were too high from other reviews.  I found it quite crowded and very touristy.  Personally, I would skip this purported “must-see” attraction. The photos posted here are about it, other than the gift shop.
review_title: Nice, but too crowded and not in a good location

review_text: The Majorelle Gardens are a must-see in Marrakesh.  Beautifully designed and maintained, cool and shady on a hot day.  It's like walking through a work of art.
Too expensive. 120 dirham (12 euros) per person, for a 10 minute walk around the garden. Plus another 100 dirham (10 euros) for the Yves Saint Laurent museum!

Was recommended by several people and reviews here are so good. It is a garden with some pretty features but not worth the money, go and spend the money in the Souks!! I wish I had. We paid to visit the exhibition too, €22 all I think it was, overpriced!! There are other more interesting and authentic sites to visit in Marrakech. I won't be recommending this garden to others.

A nice way to spend an hour or so. Not earthy shattering but lovely. Make sure you get tickets in advance as the lines were ridiculous when we went. I heard the Berber museum inside is well worth it but the line was too long for us.

Worth a visit if only to find out a little more about YSL and the thinking behind some of his designs.  The gardens were tranquil (we visited in April) and perhaps had the benefit of tourism not really fully underway yet again in Morocco.  The Berber museum was quite small but interesting if you took the time to read the details of what was on display.  The outstanding winning item of the visit which we all loved were the Majorelle painted items, lovely to see and look fantastic in our photos.  The YSL museum, gardens, and Berber museum are worth visiting only if you are prepared to take the time to get something from it, otherwise you could walk round and wonder why you came. It was quiet when we visited so that may have helped us all to enjoy a tranquil, relaxed visit.
Magnificent gardens worth the visit, the color Majorelle Blue is throughout and break taking.  Go in the morning before the crowds.

Its alright, we read it was a must see of Marrakech in one of our tour books and the concierge at the hotel recommended it, we walked to it from the main square, took about half an hour, nice walk (prepared to be hasseled along the way of course)  Its not what I was expecting, the gardens were a lot smaller than I expected and busy! If you have a family with children (like I did) you stand in a different line that is much shorter than the other line.  We didnt spend long there, I think there are nicer gardens that are free!

Like so many 'must see' attractions across the world, this is in my view overrated. Along with the self-indulgent YSL museum next door, I left with the feeling that someone is making a lot of money from gullible tourists here. That said, I understand that the gardens are run as a not-for-profit organisation which gives proceeds to charity, so that softened the blow a bit. In April the place was crowded, and there was a kind of shuffling line for most of the visit. The gardens are nice but underwhelming, the little tortoises are cute, and you might see some cool frogs too. But it felt all a bit too 'tick the box' for me, and I would not particularly recommend it - I am sure there are much nicer, quieter gardens in Morocco without all the hype.
A beautiful,  botanical and relaxing garden to visit and take some memorable pictures. It's best to have a  guide with you

Lovely garden, but seriously overcrowded and overpriced for the experience. The place was filled with tourist snapping instagram oictures and paying a steep price to do it. I felt like this showed the dark side of how social media turns us into sheople. The blue color was nice.
review_title: Overprices with long lines for an instagram picture a million people have done.

review_text: You need to see this in Marrakesh! Beautiful afternoon outting! YSL has always been a love of mine and his gardens are a must see!!!

Feeling the Median is a bit too much for you? Finding this Garden helped me first time I came here, It gave me the peace and quiet from a full morning at the souk. I love all the colors and the way they've planted every single tree in this place. It's worth going with family too At times it can get super busy so try and get there early morning or in the middle of the day :)
review_title: Great to go for some hideaway

review_text: Avoid the big queues by either booking online or going to the YSL museum and getting the museum tour and gardens ticket. Have to say the YSL museum is much more interesting than I thought it would be. The gardens are stunning though.  take your time have a coffee in the cafe and enjoy
review_title: Great place to Visit, a bit pricy though

review_text: Excellent garden with different kinds of plants especially the cactus garden was special. There is also an excellent cafe serving delicious food.
Absolutely gorgeous. We were with a very informative guide and did not have to wait in line. I would advise buying tickets in advance and go early in the morning as it gets very very busy.
We arrived at 11.30 to find a huge queue An hour later it had gone. Unusual planting with huge bamboos and cacti. With wind and sun it was very crlming despite the crowd. Berber museum worth a visit

One of the best attraction and garden in Marrakesh.  Entrance is on the expensive side (compared to local).   Well worth a visit if this is the only place you have time in Marrakesh.  If you want to avoid the crowd, it's best to go early.
If the town gets too hot, then head for YSL's garden, it's an oasis. The café serves lovely food and drink
review_title: a lovely oasis of calm in a hectic town

review_text: This garden is overrated.  You are restricted to crowded walkways and watched over by plant minders.  Very few of the plants have labels and there is no WiFi to go online to identify unknown plants. The Jardin Secret is much better.  More to see.  Less crowded.

We managed a good 10 minutes to get around the gardens. Bamboo, koi carp and lots of cactii. Very disappointed after leaving this to the last day of the holiday. Our hotel recommended The Secret Garden and we ignored their advice. Foolish and nieve mistake!!
review_title: Boring and over-rated unless you're a fan of bamboo and cactii

review_text: Beautiful gardens which offer an escape from the busy streets of Marrakech. Would probably be prettier in late April or May when things are more in bloom as there was not much to see besides cactus and some water features. Overall not worth the money as we only spent 25 minutes there and some of the paths were closed off.  Don't recommend.

Absurd tourist trap. Single file, slow waslk around tourist track. ONLY worth for lovely bookshop. They let way too many people in, it's overpriced, and not near anything else. It's a trap. Short, and the gardens are dry, and uniteresting. It USED to amazing, 20 years ago... riding on coat tails...
review_title: No need to visit - just look at a photo without 800 tourists in it, Done.

review_text: Just returned and must admit slightly underwhelmed. We walked from the Tikida Gardens  which took about 30 minutes each way but it only took us 30 minutes to walk around the whole garden twice. The garden is a little oasis in a busy suburb but not that much to see and more cacti than flowers. If we had paid the excursion price of 900 DH instead of the online entry price of 240 DH I would have been even more underwhelmed
review_title: Nice Gardens but you won't be there that long

review_text: its nice but nothing amazing...lots and lots of people doing instagram pics. Too busy to be relaxing! Book your ticket online beforehand to avoid the queue
Definitely a must do trip. Has wonderful array of flowers, plants and trees and great place for pics.
Musst go during your visit of Marrakesh, but the museum from Yves Saint Laurent that is next to it is not so worth it.
We spent a great and timeless moment in the garden. We were not alone, of course, but it didn’t create bottlenecks. cost: $12 - expected duration: 2h Strongly recommend to make it once.
What a beautiful garden, so many cactus species and the colours wow wow wow You can't leave Marrakesh without visiting this garden

From the bamboo grove to the stunning array of desert plants to the tranquil reflecting pools, this garden never fails to impress. The berber museum inside the garden is also worth a visit. Eat first or after. The food there is good, but the same or better is available elsewhere for less.
review_title: One of a kind. A truly beautiful garden

review_text: An amazing garden and museum. It's really beautiful. You'll wait a long time to get the perfect shot in places or selfies, but it's certainly worth the wait. It's all very well taken care of.
I feel like I am missing something-  a nice garden which I'd expect to walk into at no cost in any other city. 12 euro- I feel half daft for paying it
Covid restrictions just lifted and a guide got us tickets without waiting in a long line - lead to a very pleasant experience
review_title: Great if there is a smaller crowd

review_text: Great architecture in a unique place to visit while in Marrakech. Easy to arrive with a quick taxi from the Medina.

My wife and I had been looking forward to our visit the gardens were lovely but it was mainly all the same, it was a very enjoyable day just expected to see a lot more different plants and flowers Nice cafe and the museum was fine, is it worth seeing yes but wouldn’t go again

A magnificent haven of peace, in the heart of the city, yet protected from the incessant tumult of beautiful Marrakech.  It is a pleasure to stroll through the peaceful alleys lined with giant cacti and other succulents.

Majorelle Garden, this exotic and quite oasis collects flora from different continents and gather them in this amazing colorful villa. The gaden is pleasantly cool and completely calm. It has a space looks like a forest full of palm trees, cacti, and other exotic plants that are closed to each other.
Beautiful cactus garden with lots of great places to take photographs.  Gets a little crowded so good to get there early in the day.

It’s a feast for the eyes for fans of cactuses and succulents! It’s a shame Trip Advisor doesn’t have a ‘good’ option as the Jardins Majorelle is just that. Small, peaceful and inspiring - “Could I grow that or do that in my garden back home?!”
Really nice experience! Lovely garden with lots of cool places to take nice photos. Also the blue house is nice and the so many types of cacti is the best part.
review_title: Very cool garden!  So many types of cacti!

review_text: The Jardin Majorelle deserves to be one of the must see sites in Marrakech. It is well maintained with an amazing variety of plants, fountains and gates. However it was crowded when we visited and we weren't even there in the high season. Interesting history and hard to believe that the gardens were almost lost because of neglect.

It's undeniably pretty with lots of places to take your best social media picture (full disclosure: I did myself), but it's very small, even if you visit the Berber museum (recommended), and will take an hour at most.  The Yves St. Laurent museum was closed on the Wednesday we visited.
We explored Marrakech with our tour guide and this garden was a highlight of our city tour. It is worth the trip to see it
Definitely worth a visit in Marrakech. The gardens are beautiful and it's so interesting to see how they influenced YSL's design esthetic.

Lovely gardens, but very small and with no remarkable plants. The variety is minimal and the price to get in not worth it, even more so if you have to budget in a cab to arrive there. I imagine it could be a great, cool and shady escape in summer. Will not go back, but I am pleased I ticked this off my list.
review_title: Not good value for money, but a lovely, cool and shady space

review_text: A nice escape from the commotion of the city! Beautiful for a stroll. If you're a college student you get 50% off with an ID card!
Plan to spend some relaxing time here at the gardens. They are just beautiful. The filled with so much color.photo opportunities are amazing,
review_title: What a beautiful place to visit

review_text: Stunning gardens, a must see when in Marrakech. Were not too busy which was nice. Good affordable entry price for students :)
This garden was a highlight of Marrakech and is worth the trip to see and the $12 entry fee. We almost didn't go but we're so glad we did.
well worth a trip      A calm oasis in the middle of the city.     Nice coffee shop,  gift shop.   Plenty of photo ops
review_title: calm amongst the business of the. Medina

review_text: Stunning location with gorgeous plants and attentive staff. Gift shop was fantastic and affordable. It also had a great price for students!
easy to discover and we got plenty of time to enjoy this garden with amazing scenery, colours and photos.
totally great decision to come here in nice sunny day in Marrakech with our kids. we like the whole gardens.
located in the centre of marrakech, we got here by horse carriage , amazing experience during day excursion in marrakech, gardens are beautiful, amazing decorated.
i recommend everyone to visit famous gardens, worth to visit for 30 to 60 minutes, enjoy the atmosphere and flowers. ideal romantic walking.
as a part of guided marakech gardens tour with Desert Sans Frontieres i found this place very attractive.
A property rescued and restored by YSL and his partner, the garden is a beautiful oasis in Marrakech with a lovely house displaying Berber crafts and design
we visited this garden 2 times while exploring marrakech, greta design, perfect for romantic walk in sunny day.
Beautiful oasis in hectic Marrakech, great Berber museum within the gardens and a fabulous gift shop
this is must visit place for everyone. easy to get tickets online by myself, the gardens are unique, lovely and great for photos, easy to catch a horse-carriage ride back to hotel.

We spent a lovely afternoon at the Jardin Majorelle in Marrakech. The gardens are beautiful and are worth spending time there wandering around. There are currently Covid-19 restrictions in place which forces you to walk around the gardens in one direction which is good because there were a lot of people visiting when we went. Definitely recommend visiting it if you are in town.
The most amazing place for photography. The colours and the gardens. The majorelle blue is just amazing
We had a great day at the Majorelle gardens in Marrakech. It was an amazing spot to relax and reconnect to nature

We visited this Beautiful garden during our tour. The main attraction - the villa - was closed because of the Covid but you can still walk around the garden. Face mask was required during our November 2021 visit. Garden was beautiful - if you have 1 hour, its worth a visit if you're in Marrakech.
Wear something pretty and take the most amazing photos here! A beautiful and tranquil space. The gallery has a lovely cafe for a bite to eat.
The gardens were beautiful and extremely well cared for. I did imagine the place to be larger than it was, but there were so many photo opportunities there as well as the museum I really enjoyed it..
I mean the house of YSL... fashionistas and connoisseurs of finer taste take note, this is something not to miss!
review_title: Amazing place, well worth the trip

review_text: There are so many wonderful sights in Marrakech but Jardin Majorelle is a must see!  I never knew so many cactii existed. Walk through the gardens,  visit the Berber Museum inside and enjoy the experieince!
writer_informations: Stone Mountain, Georgia, United States,10 contributions

review_text: really suprised by beauty of this garden, totally amazing to spent here 45 minutes , hundreds of fotos in phone wow wow wow

The colors, the collection of trees, the peaceful air, the history, all make this place unique and a point of contact between art and nature. The intense bleu it fit the temperature of this city. Don't miss to visit
review_title: A place to do in the city, we loved it

review_text: Lovely gardens.  Very peaceful.  Worth spending an hour or twoto escape the noise and crowds of Marrakesh.
really not to be missed. the collections of trees, next to houses of Yves St Laurent ( not possible to visit except some times for a very confidential fee)is just amazing.
review_title: a must to see and what a collection of palm trees and cactus

review_text: We felt the money we spent was not worth it. The place is full of tourists and the gardens are nothing special. The museum is the only real attraction.
review_title: expensive, not worth the price if you plan to visit the countryside

review_text: A must visit, early morning recommended before the heat rises and the tourists appear. The colour of Majorelle blue is stunning against the Moroccan sky and the cacti are amazing.

We loved the vivid colors and spectacular cactus collection at the Majorelle Gardens. The adjoining Berber Museum contains artifacts, costumes and jewelry that helped us understand and appreciate their culture and history. It’s small, very well curated.
and 4th time nice to visit this garden in city centre. easy to find and explore, ticket get online  for good price. love the colours of blue and yeallow
Beautiful exotic garden with a romantic history. Visit and make sure you have enough time to loop the garden a few times and order a mint tea from the cafe - it's delicious!
review_title: Love it, my favourite place in Marrakesh

review_text: So worth the entree fee- this garden is incredible and big!Great place for photos and the workers are super friendly. You can’t come to Marrakesh and not come here!!
Beautiful garden, with a lovely gift shop. Was bustling with tourists but no problem for me. Missed a chance to get one of the eponymous fragances. Other nice gifts in the store.
yes this was my greatest excursion while in morocco as i loved to take photographs with amazing cactus, flowers and exteriour of Jardins.
amazing place to relax , take photos and enjoy the calm moments. after exploring main square this is what we needed.
This place isn’t most visit in Marrakech. There is a lot of different places to visit in this awesome city. Ticket is also very expensive. 120 dirham per person is a lot for this garden
walking through the gardens is my strongest experience while spending 3 days in marrakech city with my friends.

This is the most amazing stunning garden I have ever visited.  There is a vast range of tropical plants, succulents, colours and the Berber Museum was packed with interesting items of jewellery and costumes.  The shop had a large selection of quality items that could not be found elsewhere in Marrakech.

The Jardin Majorelle is your typical tourist hype, charging a lot for very little. The gardens which are the main attraction are nothing special outside of the cactus area. You would do better to have a drink at the Hotel Mamounia and stroll around their beautiful landscape.
We have spent in Majorel's garden and the truth is we have had a very good time with our guide hassan
beautiful and very nice garden in Marrekech , we are really enjoyed our visit we recommended this place
Rather crowded and small garden. Unless you are a cacti addict you are better off spending the 120 dirhams entrance fee on something else and take botanical pictures in one of the nicer city parks.
An oasis of calm and serenity in the madness of Marrakech Fantastic plants, could have sat all day long soaking in the quietness.

Very nice and tidy. Unfortunately, not all parts are accessible but what is is a refreshment in the hustle and bustle of Marakesh. The bistro inside also brings the expected flavours. But the lemonade could be a bit bigger :)
A small but lovely gardens, quite dear and differs from the guide book. Currently  costs around £10 UK pound as of Oct 21. Definitely worth a visit if you like cactuses😁
been here before our toubkal trek, so great experience. Lovely photos for me and my wife. Must visit place.
Very beautiful gardens and very interesting museum.  Need at least an hour to visit garden  and museum
This is a really beautiful place to visit for a few hours to escape the hustle and bustle of the medina.

Jardin Majorelle. Glad we went, but somewhat underwhelmed and thought MAD120 each for the gardens plus MAD30 each for the Beber Museum was way overpriced. We would have given three stars, but the price pulls it down to two for us. There are some amazing plants in the garden, but to quote my husband it is "overworked" so more of a plant display than a garden. Lacking life and soul. Not sure when the bamboo fencing was installed, but it is not fitting. I wonder what the garden was like in Majorelle's lifetime. I hope a lot less "sterile". The Berber Museum had some interesting pieces, but was too dark. Maybe we had been spoiled by our recent visit to the Gulbenkian in Lisbon, which was a truly amazing place, needing far more than the one day we had to really appreciate it. My husband wished that he could have seen how Majorelle's studio had looked. As it houses the Berber Museum that is not possible. The villa that normally has paintings in was closed for renovations, so no chance of seeing any artwork. Pleased to have gone and think we were lucky that (due to the effects of the pandemic on tourism) it was very quiet, but in many ways the walk there and back (About 40 mins each way) from our hotel in the medina was more interesting. Won't be rushing back.
Very beautiful! Nice escape from the busy atmosphere of Marrakech. Lots of people stopping to take photos but that’s to be expected.
Well worth going for the colours alone, the gardens are very calming - the Majorelle Blue is stunning
Beautiful BUT definitely worth heading their in the early AM as It can get a little busy and you have to queue up for photos in the 'hotspots'

Beautiful and quiet gardens were a nice counterpoint to the chaos of a major city.  Learned a bit Yves Saint Laurent and Pierre Berger's life in Morocco.  The Berber Museum onsite is fantastic!  Amazing collection that highlights the attention to detail in everyday items, clothing, and jewelry of the Berber people.

Yes, it is a MUST to visit per Tripadvisor reviewers, but it is a very small garden (i.e. you done in 15-20 minutes) and it is not worth the money you pay to enter. Price should be must lower than what is right now.
review_title: It is just an average garden for an expensive price per person

review_text: We had a great afternoon walking around the gardens. It was very well organized. Staff were very helpful.
The Majorelle Garden was amazing, we love it so much. Highly recommended. The price was good and you can visited without local, just bring your camera to take beautiful photos.
Unique garden blue and yellow makes a great capture for pictures. You will find diversity cactus collection is worth the experience.
A glorious natural respite in the new City of Marrakech. Extremely well done presentation and included the Berber Museum.

The Marjorelle Gardens are a welcome oasis from the Marrakesh heat. It is a must-see attraction in Marrakesh which provides historical interest. A monument to YSL stands in the grounds, which are mostly a selction of different cacti. The cafe serves a large selection of food and drink at very reaosnable prices, with air- sprayers to cool customers down in pleasant surrounding.
review_title: A welcome Oasis from the August heat

review_text: The garden only takes an hour or so to walk through, but it is worth it, very pretty blues and yellows aginst the greenery. The trees are tall and sweeping and give a great break from the heat, the cafe is a delight and a good stop if you are hungry.

Well designed garden with fountains and carp ponds, very colourful! Early visit recommended to avoid crowds. Interesting selection of plants from all around the world. YSL museum was closed unfortunately. Garden quite small, so hour is enough.
What a beautiful place  ! No line, few people inside. It was the perfect moment to visit Majorelle. I was expected it bigger but it still very beautiful
This is a place of vibrant colours and plants, it also holds the YSL museum which was closed at the time but definitely still worth a visit
The gardens are worth a visit, beautifully kept and include a nice small museum on Berber relics. There is also a nice cafe.
This place was absolutely beautiful. I could not stop taking pictures. If you are looking for a good place to take wonderful pictures- look no more.
A don't miss in Marrakech- absolutely stunning gardens, instagram worthy. Be sure to include the Berber Museum ticket since it is worth seeing but no photos allowed.

Marrakech is without a doubt a very nice place to have a break yet it is a busy place. Les jardin Majorelle are an oasis of quieteness within this busy city and the way it is taken care of offers every visitors the opportunity to escape thanks to a dramatic change of environment.
review_title: Popular placer yet worth every visit

review_text: Wonderful serene experience! A must see! The museum was extremely informative with extraordinary visuals.
You must see the gardens at least once when in Marrakech. It was an amazing experience . The colors as well as the trees were perfect2
This place was a jewel in the hectic city of Marrakesh. The buildings, plants and ponds were so refined and tasteful. The dominant blue colour (bleu majorelle) is striking.

I enjoyed my visit to Jardin Majorelle. Got to see a large variety of well maintained trees and caxtus from different parts of the world. The on site guide is helpful and knowledgeable, he gave us a tour of the Jardin while explaining its history and its relation to the famous Yves Saint Laurent. In addition, we got the chance to tour a the nice berber museum where we learned about the history of a different culture . It's a must visit while in Marrakech. Entrance fees: 100 MAD for tourists / 20 MAD for locals
One of the best gardens in the city. Part of the Gardens were closed but what we saw was amazing. we will surely return

Our second time to this garden.  Basic garden tour lovely with very helpful staff.  The tour of the residence and private garden very special if available.  Amazing colors and cactus.  Very unique place.

A beautiful garden in the city. However we were quite dissappointed as some of the paths in the area were closed. There was not much people when we went there but still we couldnt get full access of some areas to take great photos. But still it was worth it to go atleast once.
Good things to discover on the museum (traditional clothes, old objects used by ancestors) some old stylish clothes of 50th to 90th On the garden some sahara flowers from africa and south of america

The Majorelle Gardens are quite large gardens with a multitude of different plants. The plants are divided into cacti, palms, bamboo, garden plants and aquatic plants. Although it is not necessary to follow a predefined route during the visit, to see the garden in all its beauty, you should usually follow the directions on the map provided at the ticket office. If you like Islamic art, you can also visit a small museum in the gardens.
Great place to go if you need a break from the crazy Medinas.  Its a small garden but the blue on the buildings.

A magical oasis of design and botanicals perfectly blended! Highly recommend this garden to anyone visiting Marrakech, the cafe is stunning too - great food and service! Thankyou to the not for profit org that keep this afloat and so well preserved for the general public to enjoy 💕🌵🌸❤️💫

A very nice well-maintained place with pretty colors, very nice museums, a small cafe/restaurant is hidden inside. Small flat on the info present in the museum of Berber arts in my opinion incomplete (suddenly an almost distorted rendering) ...
The Jardin Majorelle is a must-visit. One of the most amazing places I’ve ever seen. Breath-taking garden. Don’t leave Marrakech without visiting it!
review_title: One of the most amazing places I’ve ever seen. Don’t leave Marrakech without visiting it!

review_text: the Majorelle garden is very pretty ,and the Berber museum was very rich seeing all those jewelries and traditional clothes made living the old time  of Morocco . sad we cant use the cameras or phones inside the museum .
Went with family last year before covid hit. Loved it. The garden is so colourful and beautiful. Would recommend 100%

The garden is absolutely beautiful. Loved walking through what seemed to be an oasis of beauty engulfed by tall trees and shrubbery. Only to be outshined by the multitudes of colors exuding from its buildings and art. It’s a wonderful place to learn about the history of the French when they colonized Morocco. It’s a beautiful exhibit yet I found it ended to fast. I was there for a maximum of 25 minutes and I took lots of pictures. Strongly suggest you avoid the cafe as it is expensive for absolutely no reason. Highlight? Saint Laurent Store (magnificent). See my page for photos

This is the second time we have been to the majorette gardens and they are beautiful. The contrast of colours and plants make for great photos but the price has increased by 3 euros in 3 years and the garden is quite small.
Me and my friend, we have been there for couple of hours, we love the colors, decorations, plants, but it small and crowded with alot of tourist... Better to go in the morning
Exellente visit to Jardin majorelle in Marrakech, Nice time was there, Visit Morocco is good country!
Happy to includes this place for a different stories that we heared about Marrakech & Morocco... Worth a visit

Always the same pleasure to walk there ، especially with few visitors like now! A treat to take pictures and fully appreciate this haven of peace with magical colors and reflections. Not to mention the special characteristics of the scenery and the richness of the Barbier Museum!
Such a stunning garden, you can feel the inspiration just flowing when you step inside. Would recommend anyone staying in Marrakech to visit, for a break from the hectic city.
Open during COVID-19, and also you can eat in restaurant there ( not a take away). Ask for mint tea it’s really nice. Other food is good on museum restaurants level

It's a gorgeous but small space.  It costs quite a bit as a tourist. We also visited the berbere museum, which is interesting.  Open during Covid, which was a plus and very little traffic. Must wear mask while in the garden.
review_title: Pretty, but expensive if not Morrocan

review_text: I really enjoyed this location. Lovely area to take fun pictures. I would certainly recommend this place.
The majorelle gardens are a must see in the city of Marrakech. Try to spend at least 3 hours to cover the entire gardens.

The worst place I visited in Marrakech is this overrated small limited Garden, I went this Saturday, there is nothing wow about it, nothing, just a bunch of alleys, and few plants, and a building with colors and there is a small Museum with Berber stuff, one route once you enter leads to the shop which makes this place awfully commercial trap, and nothing more. There is more than twenty personnel watching every step you make, I got sick of them telling me: don't go there, come from here, stop here, take pictures here, wear mask properly, no pictures inside, don't sit here. I FEEL LIKE I AM IN A PRISON. If you offer it for free I will never go back as that costs me my precious time. I won't recommend wasting your money and time on this crap
review_title: THE WORST  - OVERRATED AND MORE CONTROL LIKE A PRISON

review_text: It seems to be in a fairy tale! ❤️ If you want to make wonderful pictures, this place is perfect for!!! If you want to relax in peaceful place, go there, simply perfect!
A beautiful garden even it was busy. We spent there an hour taking pictures o different flowers and plants
Very interesting gardens, you have to book because they are very popular. There are cafes to stop at and an indoor exhibition . When we went it was very busy
Very interesting gardens,  you have to book  because  they are very popular. There are cafes to stop at and an indoor exhibition . When we went it was very busy .
review_title: A very pleasant stroll  in very pleasant gardens.

review_text: We went here July 2019, absolutely beautiful,  radiant colours, small but absolutely worth visiting,  this is the New Medina, but only 10 min walk from Old medina.
Enjoyable stroll around the garden and the museum with Berber exhibits. We went in Jan 2020 so didn't have to queue too long for tickets (about 20 minutes)

Peaceful and beautiful! That's the first 2 words that come to my mind. I really enjoyed the garden itself. However I must admit that was too crowded for the price charged. Also, It's not possible to go inside the house, just the garden. There's a bar inside but the prices are absurd for what's supposed to be Marrakech prices.
This garden is a lovely oasis in the madness of marrakech. It was a relaxing and interesting walk. Many interesting plants and lovely shady areas to sit.
Stunningly designed garden. Huge trees, gorgeous plants, and use of colour to highlight the beauty. Take your time, and just let the atmosphere soak in through your senses.
highly recommended place for instagrammers and tiktokers you can take some cool photos and videos here love it
Jardin Majorelle is a beautiful and serene park with most beautiful landscaping I have seen with captivating colours. Lovely location.

Nicely designed and maintained gardens. This is a great place for a visit, especially after the hustle and bustle of the markets. The gardens are also perfect to enjoy on a scorchingly hot day since the heat does not seem as bad around the plants, ponds, and fountains. It is exciting and surprising to discover a garden like this in the middle of the desert. It's also a popular spot that can get overcrowded. (PaM)

What a beautiful place to visit.  Took my Mum to Marrakech for a few days and this was definitely the highlight of the trip.  Spent the morning wondering round the garden and finished with a really tasty lunch in the museum cafe next door.
We were impressed by the colors and the botanical variety: it's incredible how this many different types of flowers, trees, herbs can "sit" in harmony in this not that big space.
Strongly recommend a visit, even though it's very crowded and a long while to queue. We made the most of it by going to the YSL museum first and picked up tickets for both.

Jardin Majorelle is the perfect place to cool down after walking around in the sun. It contains a wonderful collection of cacti, numerous ponds, and distinctive use of bold cobalt blue. Be sure to visit the  Islamic Art Museum of Marrakech , too.
review_title: A garden of cacti, sculpture, and  remarkable blue

review_text: We were waiting in a queue more than an hour for the entrance ticket, but it worth it because it's one of the most picturable places in Marakkesh. We tried also the restaurant inside the gardens but food and service was under average.
Absolutely beautiful gardens and so cool inside, sheltered from the hot sun. Lots of beautiful things to see. Well worth a visit. Very reasonable price.
great to visit , no need to use expensive Tui trip arrange on your own or via Get your guide , Was quiet early morning
take the time to enjoy this peaceful garden. All the colors (blue, green) are gorgeous and let you forget all the hustle and bustle of downtown. This is my favorite venue of Marrakech
One of the most beautiful gardens I have visited and an amazing setting. The blue walls. Oh, the blue walls...
writer_informations: Sao Joao do Estoril, Portugal,31 contributions

review_text: An oasis of colour! This beautiful garden is absolutely stunning. There are all kinds of plants, trees, ponds, a museum and much more. We were in Marrakech for only a couple of days but made sure we allowed time to visit this Garden, created by Frenchman Jacques Majorelle. After falling into disrepair, the Garden was bought by designers Yves Saint-Laurent and Pierre Bergé who restored it to its former glory. It is a must see, despite the multitude of visitors.
review_title: Colour and more colour and flowers and more!

review_text: Very, very beautiful and unique garden ! The little haven of Marrakech full of diversity of trees and plants architecture and design combined.

As the guide books tell you, this garden was created by the French painter Jacques Majorelle and was saved from destruction ("redevelopment") by Yves Saint Laurent. The garden is an eclectic mix of plants and ponds providing a meditative atmosphere (give or take fellow tourists).  The garden also includes a Berber museum which is quite interesting, but unfortunately no pictures are allowed in it. The only reason I downgraded this to 4 stars was the crowds, and I visited in and off season :(
Well worth a visit.  We went with Click Excursions.  We combined this with a tour of the Souks on horse drawn carriage  so our tickets were included & didn't have to queue

A beautiful site to go definitely when in Marrakech. The walk through the garden is beautiful, serene with trees plants artificial ponds with koi fishes, birds chirping, breeze blowing. Amidst all the greenery is the beautiful indigo building which is a museum. Loved the room with the berber tribe exhibit. Exhibiting the culture, jewelry, clothes, things they used.

This garden was very beautiful. Feels like you’re not in the city. Even though there are many people you can just relax and enjoy the garden. There’s a lot to see and you can take beautiful pictures here. It’s something else. Very nice. A must visit when in Marrakech.

I went to the Majorelle House and Gardens the day after Christmas Day in 2019. The line to ticket office near the entrance was a bit long but I had seen worse at other places in general. I bought the adult combined ticket at the ticket office because I'd planned on going to the YSL Museum and Gallery afterward. The Majorelle House and all of its grounds with its gardens are very pretty indeed and I love blue anyway however it was packed in there on that particular day. The museum in the house itself is a museum that preserves the history of the Berber people and photography isn't allowed inside of the museum. I liked the arts and crafts including metalwork that were being preserved by the museum. I love the gallery, book shop and gift shop - the items they sell are amazing and I wanted to buy practically everything! If I had the time during that day I would have stopped in the pretty outdoor cafe in the Majorelle House and Gardens but I only took a couple of quick pictures of the cafe instead. The cafe's tables were packed on that day too. I had to go and walk quickly down the street to the YSL Museum and Gallery nearby and spend time walking through there plus I had an appointment that afternoon for a hammam service at a spa. I do recommend going to see the Majorelle House and Gardens a lot though.
review_title: Very pretty with an interesting museum, lovely galleries, book shop, gift shop and a very cute outdoor cafe

review_text: This is a must see in Marrakech.  Yes, it is crowded.  Go early.  Enjoy the cool garden in the morning with the early light and the striking blues and exotic plants and pools.
Nice to visit, full of visitors, the museum inside was closed. Check it before going. You can arrive there just walking from the center. It takes 15 minutes max.
a definate must !  A oasis of beauty , peaceful and tranquil in this bustling city, vey impresive a must do

Not realising that we should have booked in advance before we left the UK, we followed advice to arrive at the garden early - 8.30 a.m. and found only half a dozen people in the queue ahead of us. We were able to wander in peace for an hour before the coaches arrived!  We skipped the crowded cafe (good decision) and headed to the adjacent YSL Museum at around 10.30 and with our combined tickets were able to dodge the already lengthy queue. I can honestly say the Museum blew us away! The design of the building and the way in which  the exhibition of designs, films and biography has been curated was enthralling.  We found the cafe here excellent - smart, quiet, and not as pricey as it looks. Overall, come early; Le Jardin in late February was pleasant but not outstanding (but thank goodness it was saved from the developers) -  Do not miss the YSL museum.
review_title: Lovely garden but don't miss the YSL Museum.

review_text: The area around it was full of construction sites, roadworks, etc and we didn't thought it was going to be something WOW but it actually was. Inside the walls, it was like an oasis of quietness and just a great place to sit and relax. That blue color is stunning so it's definitely something that you need to add on your To See list if you visit Marrakech.
review_title: An oasis of blue within Marrakech

review_text: This was a must see on my list for Marrakech. We traveled in February and it was still very crowded so I am not sure what it is like in high season. It was a beautful place to explore and walk around with friends. Just watch out for the influencers!

Jardin Majorelle is an Instagram paradise! It was a beautiful escape from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. We bought the combined ticket with the YSL and Berber museums as well, which should not be missed! When leaving, grab a taxi in front of the gardens. We wasted a lot of time trying to catch one back on the main street.

Simply stunning, the YSL Museum, the gardens, the Cafe. All fantastic. We thought it would be a short visit but the grounds are huge with some stunning features and the museum has so much in it. Take time to relax I’m the lovely shaded courtyard cafe before you leave
writer_informations: La Cala de Mijas, Spain,29 contributions

review_text: This is one of three famous/must see gardens in Marrakech. We visited the day after Morocco closed its borders, and pubic galleries & museums were closing down. And being on edge about our immediate fate, we found this tranquil garden most soothing for jangled nerves. The garden is full striking colour counterpoints, both from the plantings and the colour decorations all around. This garden has been on our list for a long time & it didn’t disappoint. The other 2 must see gardens here are the Jardin Secret and the Palais Riad Lamrani. Both are amazing.
Tranquility in amongst the frenetic happenings in Marrakesh. Would recommend a visit. Purchase the multi ticket to see the Berber museum and the YSL museum.  Get there early to beat the queues.
I loved this place!!! It's filled with many nooks for great pictures. One tip is go early to avoid the crowds. Enjoy definitely worth the visit.

It was a great site! So happy I did the “touristy” thing and visits YSL’s home. The colors, the layout, and the fashion we’re all very inspiring and captivating. Apart from dealing with several tourists sightseeing as well; this was a great venture! It’s worth your whole yo experience that piece of the culture!
Beautiful and very well kept! Thank you YSL for recovering this beauty and preserving it to be a must-see in Marrakech!
I spent a very pleasant morning at the Jardin Majorelle while on a trip to Morocco. It is a beautiful and serene spot and well worth a stop while in Marrakesh.
I did expect the gardens to be larger, but they were very well tended.  The water features were lovely.  I also enjoyed the shop of YSL goods.
Beautiful gardens. Lovely to walk around. Very relaxing. The Berber muesem is very interesting nice too see different history.

We really enjoyed visiting Jardin Majorelle. It felt truely relaxing, and the colours were really vibrant. My only criticism is the amount of selfie takers there were. As you walk along paths in the garden, it did get frustrating at times having to stop and manoeuvre around people taking selfies constantly.
review_title: Worth a trip out of the medina for

review_text: Along with visiting the Yves Saint Laurent museum next door, we visited the Jardin Majorelle. Tip:  Buy the combined ticket if you plan to visit the museum, and BUY IN ADVANCE TO AVOID QUEUES. The gardens themselves are very beautiful, but we found it a bit busy and also there are not many places where you can just sit down, and enjoy the scenery and peace and quiet.  It's more of a place you walk the path, and leave. Within the gardens, is the Berber Museum which is worth a visit but its not a lengthy stay. If you're looking for things to do, its not a bad way to spend an hour but I personally wouldn't advise to go out of your way to see.

The key to visiting the Jardin Majorelle is to go as early as possible, when it's cooler and the place is not overrun with the self-obsessed.  There are plenty of nice photos to be had, but only before it gets too crowded. We didn't visit the YSL museum through choice, but the Berber museum was very interesting and for us worth the small extra fee; it was just a little sad that photographs in there were banned and there was no leaflet available with photos to help us recall the interesting exhibits that we saw. A key point: The gardens of the Villa Oasis are not well signposted, nor are they mentioned on the leaflet available at the ticket office.  Worse still, on the day we visited they only opened a little later, and folk were standing in line waiting for them to open.  One wonders how many visitors see the Majorelle and come out without seeing or knowing about the Villa Oasis gardens. This attraction is definitely worth a visit, but if you don't go early, be prepared to be sickened by the narcissism and selfishness of the other visitors.  The books say it gets quieter near closing time, so if you can't rise early, try that.
review_title: Go very early to beat the narcissists!

review_text: with the bright blue colors and garden, this is a photographers dream place. We were debating if we should visit this place or not in Marrakech, but decided to go. Buy it on your own instead of doing through the hotel as they will charge you a lot more. We spent about 1.5 hours and got some spectacular shots. We went on a Wednesday, and apparently the YSL museum next door is closed that day.
Beautiful cacti garden, but rather small and many tourists which made taking pictures or standing still quite difficult. But we enjoyed our time there.
A really nice place to coool down in a hot city. A nice garden with nice trees, flowers etc. I recomend to go when it open, as it get very crowded .

Bit of a trek finding the entrance but once there you’ll be greeted by friendly staff, who speak good English. There is an entrance fee to pay; discounts may be available. The gardens are almost fully accessible (may struggle with a wheelchair on the bridge, but everywhere else is accessible) Inside the gardens are beautifully kept, very serene and tranquil. There are lots of places to take photographs and sit and appreciate the gardens. Hard to believe your in the middle of Marrakesh as it’s so peaceful. The gardens can be busy with tourists of all nations. Although you do get a hand book when you pay the entrance fee; you’ll be as well just mooching about. Simply beautiful and expect to stay a good few hours.

We were really impressed. Beautiful grounds, buildings and incredible cacti. However, it was packed by about 10am and just one giant Instagram photoshoot - people dressed to the nines queueing to look pensively into the distance. Sign of the times! We enjoyed a nice coffee in the shaded cafe garden.
review_title: Beautiful place but got packed quickly

review_text: Probably the best thing we did in Marrakech, the gardens are not huge but they are fabulous. Great tea at the restaurant.

We arrived early and were glad we did as there were long lines when we left at 11. The gardens are gorgeous and there is a nice book store. They are fairly small but very colorful. The Berber Museum is very interesting but no pictures allowed. I loved the displays of clothing and jewelry. The YSL museum had beautiful pictures, posters and was very sleek. You could take pictures of everything but his dresses, which was my favorite part. You could breeze through all 3 in less than 2 hours or spend more time to read in detail. Definitely worth a visit. I loved it.
Beautiful garden to spend many hours wandering, peacefully sitting and gaining many many pictures. The best few hours of Marrakech were spent here.

Just loved this place and could not believe how beautiful, ordered and calming it was, despite the crowds.  Definitely get there as early as possible - we queued for around 40 minutes, arriving at 11am.  Check opening hours online as it is not open every day.  It is so worth having a refreshment in the cafe as it is a little oasis away from the crowds, has its now toilets and the traditional mint tea is lovely, coming with a little snack.  This allowed a lovely hour to just enjoy the ambiance.  It is only a 15-20 minute walk from the Medina and was very easy to find. Some nice, well-priced gift shops on the road odjacent if you don't want to brave the souks.
This was beautiful, we had a lovely wonder round. It was amazing being in the beautiful gardens and we had a lot of fun here. Would recommend on a sunny day and would definitely come here again
If you want gardens then don't bother. There are many better in Marrakech. If you want to see where Yves Saint laurent and Hubby hung out then maybe of interest. Long queues and lots of people.
review_title: Rather dull gardens and not worth the trip from town. Long queues.

review_text: better to book your ticket upfront ! the place is crowded ! I don't know what to tell more. arrive early !
Spectacular garden where YSL himself lived. There is also a little museum shop and on specific days you visit his residence.
writer_informations: Las Palmas de Gran Canaria, Spain,36 contributions

review_text: We had a lovely hour here. I recommend that you go early in the morning as it gets very crowded with the selfie brigade. Luckily we were part of a small group so we did not have to wait in the growing queue to get in - we were ushered to the front much to other people's annoyance. There are several picturesque spots and the little Berber museum was interesting too.

There were a Long que until we Got into the garden. We weren’t prepared for that, but it’s good to know that you should expect that. The museum was closed that Day (wedensday) which we couldn`t read in the guide books. It was a shame ‘cause we realt wanted to go there and we could easily had gone there another Day if we knew. But the place is stunning, the Colors are so beatiful. But you should expect a lot of other turists there as Well.
This was an amazing little trip in the heart of Marrakech, a beautiful botanic garden. I took amazing photos and got off the buzz of the square for a while.
Beautiful garden with a lovely restaurant. Different colours pots and plants from 5 different continents

I found the Berber and YSL museums much more interesting than the garden which is mostly cacti and succulents although there were some pretty awesome examples.  Too many people spending too much time taking selfies with their friends and cacti.
review_title: If you visit .do not miss the small Berber Museum

review_text: Gorgeous little trip to these beautiful gardens. Perfect to escape the midday Moroccan heat. We had a lovely few hours here.
Beautiful escape in Marrakesh with gorgeous colors and gardens! A must when visiting Marrakesh in Morocco.
Must see when in  Marrakesh. Although the villa of YSL can not be visited. The garden is a delight. And the museum top.

Nice small garden. Need 30 minutes here. Do really dislike all the instagrammers - everywhere are rows/lines for people because they all want to make pictures/selfies at some nice spots. Other visitors are blocked and can't pass true.
exquisite, beautiful. Loved this wonderful garden in Marrakech.  Great palce to take pictures. Takes about 45 mins to 1 hour.

In case that you have plenty of time to spend in Marrakesh, then go there - be ready to wait for 30 -45 min at the ticket office (unless if you book it through their official site). Its so famous because of YSL (who created it). The place is very nice with plenty of plants but crowed at the same time.
Jardin Majorelle was a beautiful relaxing few hours and the YSL museum was worth the visit even on it's own merit.The Restaurant served excellent food at Lunch time. ,
Friendly staff and beautifully maintained gardens. Especially loved the blue accents everywhere.  Highly recommend.
The gardens are a haven of peace compared with Marrakesh, very beautiful. I would advise going early or later in the day to avoid long queues

After the busy souks it was lovely to enter the calm of the Jardin Majorelle. The plants are amazing and the blue of the artist's house and other areas is stunning. The cost was reasonable (70 MAD) and I would definitely recommend a visit here.

Visited here 14 years ago, and it's still wonderful. The cacti and bamboo have grown bigger, the famous  colours pop, and the memorial stone to YSL and Berge is  moving. Make sure you go when it opens (8.00am) to avoid the queues and crowds, and ensure you buy the ticket for all 3 so that you can  visit the excellent berber museum in the grounds. A great little cafe for mint tea and almond pastry, + a couple of little shops added now.
What an amazing place, so calm. A smallish garden but beautifully kept. You must get there early to avoid the crowds. Liked the Museum as well.
Just a lovely and tranquil setting away from the city. The colors, plants, layout is so well done. A beautiful gift shop and cafe. A real highlight.

I have wanted to visit these gardens for a long time and I was not disappointed. The cacti are amazing and the blue building is stunning. I had the same feeling in this place as I did in Frida Kahlo’s house (The Blue House) in Mexico, very calming & peaceful. I advise you get there early before the crowds to experience the same, it opens at 0830. Well recommended.
A beautiful oasis well worth a visit. Get the ticket that does everything, cafe there lovely and not bad on price.
Busy. But worthy of a visit. There is a lot to see and I would suggest you take a camera or mobile phone to take pictures
It was quite crowded even right when it opened - and quite small. It was nice but I'd recommend the secret garden instead.
review_title: Nice but not a must see

review_text: Nice place to visit but I would not loose sleep if you miss it.  We found the Cyber gardens near the old city just as nice - more open and free ,!
review_title: Nice to visit but could have missed it off trip

review_text: ..but it´s not a "Must See". And it is crowded. But if you have enough time in Marrakech, you can have a look...

A lot is made of this being a ‘must-do’ in Marrakech. I disagree. I feel it is more a ‘can-do’ if you are bored walking the endless Medina. It costs MAD 70 (about US$9) just for the garden( extra 110 to also visit the museum which is about a block away. The 30-minute lines to buy a ticket seem to be always there, and you only get shade about half the time. The garden itself is honestly just meh. Very crowded, with at least 10-20 people in line to get a picture at specific spots. The plants are all desert varieties of palm trees and cacti from all over the world, but unless you are a serious succulent geek, they are just spiny plants. There is a Koi pond with about 10 fish. You walk this crowded cement walkway around the garden and then you’re out. There is a Berber museum inside the garden which costs an extra 10 and I skipped. Bottom line, some nice benches in the shade to sit at for a lot of money and after a long line.

Yes, the gardens are beautiful and, once you have completed your circuit, you may find it rewarding to take a more relaxed stroll in the opposite direction. However, our enjoyment was tempered by the large proportion of people who seemed uninterested in the garden and more interested in endless photos of themselves posing. For a more enjoyable (and free) garden experience, sit down and relax in the Cyber Park, just Northwest of the Koutoubia mosque.
This is small but lovely enough and worth a visit if convenient. It's loaded with photo opportunities - a bit more style than substance but such is fashion. Good people watching too.
Enjoyed the shade of the Jardin Majorelle, we went in 32 degrees and it was lovely as it was shaded. Small garden but worth 70 dirhams entry price, plants are gorgeous but can get crowded.

Beautiful gardens , very popular , long but quick queue to get in . Brilliant colours and lots of photo opportunities. Although very busy most tourists were friendly and took turns to photograph each other, so didn’t have to rely on selfies. Highly recommended.

I enjoyed the gardens, but thought the Berber museum was the most interesting piece of this place. It has lots of info on the Berber people, including maps, clothing, jewelry, and more. If you're of the Instagram type, the gardens provide a nice backdrop for that. Get there early - there was a line when we arrived at 10. If there is a long line, you can buy tickets 100m up the road at the Yves Saint Laurent museum as well.

We had to pay for the garden even though we only wanted to visit the Berber  museum( at another cost!) The museum was very well laid out and really interesting. Quite long queues to get in. Need more payment booths.

just avoid, it’s £7/8€ for something we have for free in so many european cities for free, they are bigger and beautiful. in my opinion just avoid marrakech and spend one or 2 nights in the desert or just go for all inclusive hotel. all of the gardens in marrakech are small, you can see them in 10 min. the cactus are full of graffiti names, it’s overcrowded with wannabe influencers, lost tourists and one expensive caffee
If you like architecture or gardens you’ll appreciate it. Also those that want colorful profile pics for social media. But overall a bit pricey and overrated.
Really well done garden - just take care to time it well to avoid a mob scene.   Very easy to get to from Marrakech.    Suggest Amal as a good restaurant nearby before/after.

Nice garden, full of beautiful trees, cacti, ponds and water features. We went down about mid-day to find a huge queue outside. So decided to come back early the next day when they opened 8am. Worked out perfectly, no queue and only a few people dotted about, ideal for getting the photos without people walking in front of you. We got the combo ticket so we could go into the Berber museum and the YSL museum just down the road. The YSL museum opens at 10am so we had plenty of time to walk around the garden before heading over for when it opened. Again walked right in because we already had the tickets. If you're into fashion and all that it's worth a look, my wife loved it.
I knew as I entered that the garden would be a wonderful place to spend the morning. Soothing shapes and colors and well maintained

A few hours spent away from the hustle and bustle of medina life is a welcome break. This tranquil garden made famous by Yves Saint-Laurent in the 1980's is still a beautiful retreat and well worth a visit.
Great secret place. It is an amazing place and a must see. The cafe had a great menu and the staff were great.
Stunning, bold, bright colours. Huge range of plants & flowers. Gorgeous surroundings, picturesque & so tranquil.
A quiet oasis of calm and beauty from the madness of the medina ... a truly stunning place to spend an afternoon
review_title: An oasis of calm and beauty

review_text: Lovely garden, good to have a walk around and a bit of peace from the bustling Medina. Lots of plant and wild life to see. A few nice spots for photos. The Berber museum is inside also. It's small but it's ok. There is a cafe, but I wasn't in so cannot give an opinion.
A nice oasis in the center of Marrakech! Don't miss the berber traditional art and jewellery museum - a must see!
Very beautiful garden and place. We were there at the beginning of March and it was still a bit crowded. They have great discounts for students.

As mentioned buy combo ticket  at YSL musee and visit here first . The lines for the garden were long. The gardens are a separate entrance about fifty yards from Musee. Before viewing the gardens take a break in one of the many nearby cafes.  There are also cafes inside both the garden venue and musee , all are busy. The Berber museum ,within the gardens , was very interesting and was included in our combo ticket.

This is a unique garden. It is also known as Yves Saint Laurengarden as he designed it with plants collected on his travels. Well worth going to for the Cacti there. It also has a small restaurant. A lovely day out, but can have long queues to enter.

Lovely garden in the middle of the city. Best to go there early morning or end of the day to avoid the crowd and make the most of this quiet and relaxing place. The blue color is nice but nothing special - they could have made it orange or pink, doesn't change much. But the beauty of the place and the nature is fantastic.

The quintessential tourist trap scam of a place that has very little to offer. Nothing worth visiting here as the property has no home to visit and a concrete marker of a memorial. Its is overcrowded and a giant disappointment. $18.00 per person we left feeling violated and shafted.
review_title: Giant Ripoff that should be avoided by all visitors to Marrakech

review_text: For my first three days in Marrakech in early february, it seemed like there were few tourists. But this place was very crowded with tourists. I'm sorry I didn't take the advice I read about going there first thing in the morning.

This is more advertised garden  with the connection Yves St Laurent. Lovely garden quite arty, understandably we had to queue to get in even on a Monday.  Nice  cafe in the garden recommend the marjorelle  club sandwich.

Lovely colourful gardens, very nice Yves Saint Laurent museum showing the mix of his haute couture and his daily fashion creations.  Also the Berber museum was interesting. The snack restaurant offers a nice variety of bits and pieces.
It is nice but I think seeing all the beautiful mosaics that are available in this country, they could have done something much nicer. The blue everywhere is nice but it all looks very average.

The Museum showed how diverse Yves Saint Laurent mind was and what an eclectic mix of haute couture and daily fashion he created. (And I'm a male philistine in this area) It held me captivated for 2.5 hours and taught me a great deal. The cafe was great and reasonably priced. The gardens were spectacular with a wide diversity of plants and trees from all over the world. Again, we spent over 2 hours and didn't see the same thing twice.
review_title: A real eye opener. The museum was amazing and the gardens wonderous.

review_text: Excellent day out. Gardens are lovely and it is well worth visiting the berber museum and Yves Saint Laurent museum on a combined ticket.

Beautiful gardens with stunning colours and a most eclectic mix of plants and trees. Resist the temptation to take photos every 5m and just enjoy the beauty of this garden. Best to arrive early, as once it gets busy, the garden does feel a little crowded. Also, if you weren't able to buy online, the earlier you arrive, the shorter the queue for tickets!! Buy a combined ticket if you can and see the YSL Museum and Berber Museum at the same time - both definitely worth visiting.
The gardens are a hidden gem in this bustling city. Get there early to avoid the masses. Well worth a visit.

The highlight is certainly the gardens. Restaurant menu lacking and I think we would have been better off eating on road in. They could also do a much better job of directing people to the offsite Yves St Laurant Museum.
review_title: Gardens wonderful. Museum good. Restaurant not so much.

review_text: What an extraordinary pleasant garden to walk around, a most unexpected treat for a Saturday afternoon,  tranquill and peaceful.
