Beautiful gardens with lots of cactus! Didn’t give 5 star because the amount of posing tourists slightly ruins the experience. Not the fault of the gardens obviously but didn’t justify the 5 star. Worth a visit but definitely go when the sun is shining. Less impressive when cloudy!

If you are into horticulture this is a must. The property and gardens saved by Yves St Laurent and Pierre Berge. The use of bold colors and shapes defines the spaces and puts a unique twist on the concept of traditional gardens.

This is such a nice cooling oasis in downtown Marrakech. The garden has one great vista after another. Many spots for photos. With the beautiful vases in blue and yellow, there are so many colorful shots to be taken and enjoyed.
review_title: Uniquely colorful garden of cactus and beautiful painted vases and brdiges

review_text: you must add this to the list of things to do when in Marrakech. The atmosphere is just phenomenal. We arrived mid afternoon and the queue to purchase a ticket was so longgggg. top tip you can buy garden ticket at the Yves Saint Lauren ticked counter. we decided to leave the garden queue and go to the museum instead becasue the line was alot shorter. when we got to the ticket counter, we saw that we could purchase the garden tickets which we did and skiped the very longggggg queue and entered the garden with ease. we had people looking at us like ermm what just happened? they were just in the queeue behind us ahahahhaa

We went there in the afternoon which was great decision. That day was quite hot, so we kind run away to the gardens. :) Jardine Majorelle is so beautiful. All those colors and plants. Extra! I would recommend to everyone. Must see in Marrakech!
Beautiful garden, the trees, plants are lovely and it was a nice break from Marrakech chaos and noise.  Nice cafe on site to rest and have a coffee.

We arrived at 09.15 to beat the queue. It was beautiful but the Villa Oasis was even better. This is only open Fri-Mon 10am and is accessed inside the Jardin Majorelle. Loads of succulents and water features. Better than the main garden. The Berber museum was interesting.
Really beautiful place to visit. Different from the rest in the city. Come earlier to avoid the line

Stunning gardens, but very busy, surrounded by other tourists (which can't really be avoided as it's such a lovely place to visit). Didn't manage to book online which would have shortened our queue time to get in but it only took us about 5-10mins of queuing anyway (around 10am ish on a Weds). Lovely cafe with some refreshing drinks.
Beautiful place to visit Great coffee in the place inside No su much space to walk buts it’s ok to see so many species of cactus

This place is lovely and so peaceful... it doesn't take hours to visit- it is smaller than you would imagine but there are some nice bars and restaurants now on the other side of the street at the entrance that are new... well worth a visit.
Really worth visiting Its very traditionally Moroccan with  desert planting and bamboo and wonderful Bougainvillea
Beautiful garden full of vibrant colours and patterns. Cactus, bamboo and the blue and yellow painted buildings. Worth the visit.
a unique experience. mixture of curious and spectacular plants with water features and colourful paint.  Shady with lots of places to rest.  Rather busy.

No words can describe how beautiful this place is! The garden is fascinating, you can walk around for hours and not get enough. I suggest to buy a combined ticket for 180MAD (18€) which you can use for the YSL museum, the garden and the Berber Museum inside. Just be aware that part of the garden closes at 4pm, and the other is until 6pm, so leave yourself enough time so you don't need to rush around.
Wonderful cacti. Fabulous blue paint . Lots of people & queues galore . Recommend getting tickets in advance then you only get 1 queue. Well laid out and a treat to wander round.
I can see why this is considered such a haven. We didn’t have to queue for long but not worth queuing for 2 hours .that can occur in the peak season.

A perfect respite from the weather, dust and beautiful business of Marrakech. Very inexpensive way to spend an afternoon admiring the varieties of cacti, palms etc. lush colors and shaded paths eventually leading to YSL’s burial site. A sense of calm prevails in this lovely place but my favorite was the cafe located inside the garden a definite must!!
When you're done with haggling and can't bear to face any more ceramics or barrels of spices, you can come here and chill.  Berber museum was also fabulous, as was YSL museum
review_title: Beautiful, tranquil gardens in the middle of the chaos

review_text: Right outside the busy Medina, a tranquil spot - although it is pretty crowded with tourists.  Interesting variety of plants.  Lovely shop.  Interesting small Berber museum.
review_title: Great collection of cacti and other plants

review_text: I am not a great fun of the botanic gardens and flowers in general but so many people suggested me to see this place that I could not resist. Finally I have to say, that in Marrakech this is a must to come here. Nicely kept, well organized, rich fauna with interesting history behind. I loved the wide variety of cactuses, the bizarre combination of colors, especially the green and majorelle blue gives some special atmosphere to the place. It is recommended to buy a combined ticked to see also the Berber museum - what is located in the Majorelle garden - and  the Yves Saint Laurent exhibition next door. Do it in nice weather and allocate half day as a minimum to enjoy some rest and view from one of the many benches there.
review_title: A garden of Eden in the middle of a lively city

review_text: Absolutely breath-taking gardens but we went on a Sunday, around lunchtime  and the ticket queue snaked around the block so we went back later in the afternoon which was a bit quieter.  However they were closing a significant and beautiful part of the garden around 4 'o clock and we just managed to get in there on time, so be aware of that. I'd love to visit when no-one else is there, to sit down and enjoy the tranquillity and wonderful plant species and water features.
review_title: Stunning but pick your time to visit

review_text: We caught the local bus 🚍 number 1 at cost of only 4 dirham from Marrakesh direct to the Gardens. We paid the entrance fee of 80 dirham about £6 or 7 euros. The whole experience was very beautiful which all the 🌴 palm trees and 🌵 Cactus, sweet smelling flowers, water features, birds etc and the 🏘 home of the famous painter Jacques Majorette including his studio. Upon his death it was taken over by the world famous fashion designer YvesSaint Laurent who along with his Partner turned it into a remarkable retreat to relax into. Upon his death his Ashes are scattered in the garden at a remorial followed by his Partner Pierre Berge. Also you can visit the museum to see his creations and designs. Highly recommended trip.
This is place near where Yves-Saint-Laurent made his home. A beautiful tranquil garden with lovely plants. Great to walk around in and take photos. It is also opposite a few shops.

Avoid the queue by buying the combined ticket from the YSL museum (it's not a big museum you're basically paying extra to avoid the queue). The gardens were bigger than I was expecting and they're well cared for with that beautiful blue building which now houses the Berber museum (again not big but with an interesting design especially the jewellery room). Interesting place with a visit.
Beautiful gardens. Bring a book to sit down in the shade and relax. Have lunch there in the gorgeous restaurant.
My favorite place to visit in Marrakech.  Museums, small shop with clothing, lots of pictures and a comprehensive display of YSL fashion from the sixties to the last designs.

The gardens alone are well worth a visit, but there are also two other museums on site. The queue to purchase tickets was long but the crowd seemed to melt away once you entered. This is a lovely site to visit when in Gueliz.

Well worth a visit, but try to go early when the crowds are less. Like Palace Bahia, the beautiful Jardin Marjorelle was so full of visitors it was hard to find a quiet spot to sit, contemplate, and enjoy. Definitely worth going though.

Loved it here. If you like plants,cactus appreciate the architecture and simply want a lovely walk around a garden with alot of energy, go visit and take beautiful picts. Really lovely and breath taking views
Beautiful gardens, peace and tranquility in a busy city. Well worth the entrance fee. The history behind the gardens and the exhibits are to be admired.
What a beautiful place. The gardens are just amazing. The colours the bamboo it is all exceptional. It is a must to do in your list. Loved this.

Do not miss this while in Marrakech! Jardin Majorelle is a fantastic garden and also connected to Villa Oasis where Yves Saint Laurent lived amajor part of his Life. And the YSL Museum next door is a must as well!
review_title: Beautiful place including the walk through the garden of Villa Oasis (Yves Saint Laurent)

review_text: Worth the visit. We went with friends around 2pm..a bit crowded but we did not have the choice as it was our last day in Marrakech. It is a must do !

I love the cactus garden, and all the vibrant gorgeous colours of the house. Because it is such a large area, even though lots of people are there the crowds aren’t overwhelming. I really enjoyed my visits here.
Nice relaxing area of Marrakesh although busy with people you can still find spots to relax and take in the colours and amazing cacti.

This is a must see site when you visit Marrakesh, and probably my favorite place in the town. The colors are gorgeous, and the garden is beautifully maintained. An island of peace and quiet in a noisy city.

Lovely 3 hours spent wandering around. Had a mint tea at the cafe and they brought some almond pastries. Very friendly and amusing lad that served us. Beautiful cactus plants, however some have been graffitied which is a shame.
We went in the early morning, it is a cute garden, great for pictures, the cats there are friendly. After half an hour we went home because we had seen everything.
Crazy place. Huge que outside even at 9.30am. Hordes of people.  It's ok but I would have been happy just visiting the secret garden and the gardens of la mamounia.
Very different to much of Marrakech but good and interesting gardens, quite shady even on a sunny day, can be combined with the YSL museum.
This place is like heaven on earth. Stunning vegetation and decoration. Must visit YSL museum too. Just beautiful

We visited the Marjorelle Gardens in early Feb and absolutely loved it. Such beauty among the plants, all telling a different story of origin; so interesting. Viewed some beautiful photos/ pictures of and by Yves Saint Laurent. Well worth a visit👏
It was beautiful, well kept and peaceful.  I would have likeed to stay longer but we had other places to visit in a short time

It is the garden of an artist rather than a gardener. We went very early in the morning and it was cool and peaceful with very few folks there. By the time we had been there half an hour it was getting quite crowded.

A lovely and interesting spot ... despite this place being choc full of visitors we still felt like it was somehow peaceful . The many varieties of cactus was astounding . The restaurant was Ferociously expensive and not worth it.

Visiting the gardens was a highlight for me. Beautiful gardens, large site to walk around and quiet and shady places to sit and watch. We spent several hours there, visiting the museum also. We had lunch at the café, which was excellent. Highly recommended!
review_title: A haven in a busy city

review_text: Must see! Although it takes a long wait to get in, especially when you get there later in the morning. Reserve online, much better!
review_title: Worthwile waiting in a long queue

review_text: To be honest my review isn’t about the garden itself as we decided after an hour in the slow moving queue to abort! The pictures we found online show it to be a peaceful place; shame we didn’t get to see it. It was too hot to stand in the queue any longer. Perhaps we chose the wrong time of day 11am. We will return to wonderful Marrakesh and will try a different time.
Well worth to visit when you are in Marrakesh Lovely garden with plenty to see To skip a crowd get early as you can
Easy to understand and get through museum with a special and a bit unusual story - we all four can recommend a few hours in the Jardin Majorelle!

Not really my cup of tea cactus every where you went big ones small ones but at least it passed an hour away we went by one of the numerous horse and carriage s that was an experience but haggle the price

Nice to see and a good use of a few hours in your trip to Marrakech. Very pretty gardens. Lots of beautiful colour and water. Go into the YSL museum next door as you can get a joint ticket and the queue is shorter.
review_title: Good use of a few hours in Marrakech

review_text: It was a really beautiful garden with wonderful blue and yellow buildings. If one thinks about going there, you should go there either very early or very late as it's otherwise very crowded and you won't be able to make any pictures without people on it :(
Really worth the visit ! we went there at 9:00 Am which was a good choice to avoid queuing. really amazing.

Small garden very popular with fashionable French due to YSL connection. Full of people posing and taking selfies, far from the oasis of quiet it promises. If it wasn't for the brightly coloured paintwork is would be a boring green

I'm not impressed. Yes, it's nice, but it's not something super impressive. What I don't like are some of the "pools" where the hygiene is not really good and the poor fishes just tried to survive. This makes me sad. ☹️

As beautiful as the gardens are, one cannot feel but moved by the beautiful story behind them and the unexpected connection to Yves Saint Laurent. This visit truly transformed my view on the history and connection between Morocco and Spain.

The queues were long to get in as it was busy. The gardens themselves are loverly A very peaceful place Amazing colours and structures No ideal for young kids but we knew this before going. Glad we went to experience it.

The hustle and bustle of the city is so bad, people head here to take refuge, oh and to take selfies/wanna be 80's model advertising shots. Headed into the gardens at opening to avoid queues we had seen previous day (hour long). Gardens opened 30 mins late and nothing inside was open. We spent £5 on a ticket and were in and out within 10 mins. The place is full of narcissistic tourists posing for that Instagram shot. The cactus are mildly interesting. I’d head back to the main city centre to buy some more tat if I were you.

The gardens are beautiful, and you should definitely go after/before visiting the YSL museum. The landscape is nice and the blue house is beautiful. You should also check out the small Berber museum in the house (included in your admission). Enjoy walking around the palms and cacti and take pictures. My only complaint is it's very busy and there's a lot of people trying to take aesthetically pleasing photos - I had to wait in line to take a picture in front of the fountain, but it was only 4 or so people in front of me, so it was fine. Pretty gardens - take about an hour to walk through and enjoy.

Beautiful and peaceful garden to walk around. We arrived around 1pm and had to queue for 30 mins to get tickets but luckily wasn't hot! There is a separate (shorter) queue for families so check the queue first. The Berber museum was closed as we went on a Wednesday so check the opening days before going if you specifically want to see the museum. There are a few restaurants outside the gardens as we found there was a wait for the cafe inside the garden.
Recommend getting here early, the queues to get in when we left at around 11 were ridiculous. Very pretty inside, make sure you wait until the other half is opened! Card payments accepted.

It’s so pleasant to walk around here - it’s large and there are plenty of plants to see, and colourful benches to soak up the sun on. Lots of nice photo opportunities and a relaxing, interesting place to visit. I recommend coming early morning (before 10) so you can avoid the worst of the crowds. I think the price is 70 dirhams for an adult ticket to just the garden. They  accept card payments.
An amazing oasis of calm and tranquility even with lots of other visitors. Try to go early to beat the heat and look out for the birds. The Berber museum is fascinating too.

Our no 1 in Marrakesh. Gardens refurbished by Yves St Laurent and his business partner. A real pleasure to stroll around. In the centre near the house a charming coffee/tea area with great service. The palms and cacti are in such good condition and the whole garden clean and well presented. Avoid the crowds and go early in the day. Buy a combined YSL museum ticket and garden ticket at the museum next door and just swan past the lines for the garden!

An absolute must if you are in Marrakech. The museum is fantatstic and we loved seeing the exhibits. The gardens are exquisite - the colours are mind blowing and the tranquilty is secodn to none. Get your tickets at the museum and do the museum first as then do not have to queue again for the gardens. Taxi is only 50 Dirrhams from the main square for 4 people - don't let them charge you more.
In a hectic city it is great to walk into a beautiful garden. The cafe is great aswell and nice shops.

This is one of the spot to see in Marrakesh so it is full of tourists... you should plan to visit early morning to avoid the crowd. We did not prebook tickets so had to queue for 45 mins before we could start the visit. Or maybe book the YSL museum at the same time to cut off the queue. This is a nice big garden, not as quiet as expected as you can hear the street nearby but still. Nice blue color.. We liked "Le Jardin Secret" better than this one (even tough it is a lot smaller)
review_title: Nice garden but you should book in advance and arrive early

review_text: Gorgeous escape in Marrakech! This place is beautiful and picturesque. A must see during your time in Marrakech. Purchase tickets in advance so you don't have to stand in line.
Over my life visiting that was so enjoyable to our life where we spent our 3rd journey after marriage. that was so beautiful.

This is a very popular oasis in the new city of Marrakesh but it really sets a standard that is not met by any other gardens that we visited here! Despite the crowds it is quiet and peaceful and the range of cacti displayed is astonishing! There's a very good restaurant, too, by the way! Wonderfully and very highly recommended!

This is a nice place for a quiet stroll. It is now possible to enter YSL's house but you can wander around the gardens.  Try and vist when there are less people as it can get crowded and you're constantly avoiding getting in people's photos or waiting them to finish :-(.   There is a small Berber museum that's worth walking around. Be advised to GET your entrance tickets the day before online to avoid queues.  Or go and get them first at the YSL Museum.
review_title: Nice place for a quiet stroll

review_text: Lovely oasis of calm and beauty. Absolutely worth the visit for the amazing colours and design of the garden. Make sure you book online first!
Really expensive for just few plants amd flower. Was really colorful and we took wonderful picture but it not worth the money for the ticket.

Probably worth getting your tickets in advance, we queued for half an hour and were advised that if we planned to see the 3 part sit would be quicker to queue for the YSL museum as we would be another hour from where we were!, so we did and 10 minutes later were in the museum, well worth a visit, by the way you do save a few dihran by getting the 3 tickets. But the gardens were simply amazing and so well kept, a great assortment of cacti amongst other things. great visit

Beautiful garden but the all too popular instagrammers ruin this otherwise idyllic place - dont dare get in the way of their photographs. Otherwise a very pretty and less bustling place to visit in Marrakech.

A beautiful oasis to feast your eyes and treat your soul!  What a splendid arrangement of flowers, cacti and many other species.  You can walk through the gardens many times and always discover something new.  A not to be missed site.
review_title: Not to be missed when in Marrakech!

review_text: I've read many review about the queue and there is. But the garden opens at 9.30 and you can buy a combined ticket there (YSL museum, Jardin Majorelle and Berber museum). I was there at 9.40 and got my ticket in 5 minutes. It's well maintained inside and lovely to see. Bigger than I thought. You can easily walk around for an hour.
I went to the Garden some years ago but on my visit last week I found to my horror it had turned into Disneyland. The garden is beautiful and well cared for but there was no atmosphere.

Perhaps visiting in February was a good idea! Not so many visitors in this lovely but rather small space! Arriving at 11 am only a short queue and not too crowded inside! A cool and beautiful oasis in this frenetic city! Not normally great fans of museums, we found the small "Majorelle Blue" museum a delightful display of Berber artefacts! An hour is enough! Then cross the road to enjoy a delicious meal or drink at the Gourmet Pause!
Dont miss this.  One of the nicest, and cleanest attractions in Marrakech.   A beautiful 3 hour visit - and the cafe is fabulous.

This was our second visit to this amazing garden. It is stunning to look at but always very busy. There is so much to see and the gardens are immaculate. The buildings are painted in Majorelle Blue and yellow which are stunning. There are two museums available at an extra cost. Well worth a visit.
review_title: A lovely garden but very busy

review_text: Sublime and beautiful garden, best cacti I've ever seen, lovely water features and ponds with fish and frogs to spot. Only a little spoiled by the hoards of instagrammers photographing themselves infront of everything!
Located outisde old Medina but it is worth visit if you like the nature. We enjoyed the types of trees and it is a oasis inside Marrakech. Recommeded if you like nature.

Garden itself is nice it has variety of cactus  and palms but it not  worth 7€ per person because nothing to do there. We stayed in the queue for the tickets for 45 minutes and walked through it in a 30 min.
I dont get how this got such a high rating. Expensive for a 10 minute walk around. I agree its a calm place compare to the rest of marrakech though.

Loved it here. The gardens are well maintained and beautiful. Lots of different plants. There’s a Berber museum inside which was really interesting and you only pay an extra 10 DHM to visit. We didn’t have to queue to get in and this was around 12.30 in the afternoon. Children under 12 are free. Definitely recommend!
Approximately 15 mins from outside Medina walls. Easy to find. Well organised. Gardens beautifully maintained and so peaceful. Well worth a visit.
Very beautiful garden, very peaceful, well maintained and clean, full of colours. Half an hour walk from the Medina.
While waiting outside for too long is no fun, once you're inside you feel at ease when not too many tourists are around photographing you!
BEAUTIFUL especially the YSL museum. Make sure to be there early because of the long waiting ques. Or come with a Guide.. they have special excess!

This is the number one tourist destination in Marrakech so you had to visit along with every other tourist. The advice about getting there early is good advice. We got there at about 10.30AM and queued for around 40 mins to get in. The gardens are nice and well tended but in truth a little underwhelming. We found the Secret Garden much nicer. The Majorelle Gardens were busy with the usual 'Instagram' posers getting in the way of everyone else. Was was more interesting was the Berber Museum and that was worth the cost of getting into the gardens in the first place.
review_title: It's OK, but there are better places

review_text: Stunning gardens. You could easily spend a couple of hours relaxing here. Take a taxi from Jemaa El Fna square to get here (20 Dirhams - although they start off asking for 50)
review_title: Beautiful gardens in a busy city

review_text: Loved these gardens. Clearly the owners have loved and cared for these gardens, using plants and landscaping to please the eye and the soul. Great cafeteria.

I'm not a gardens person, but I still appreciated the unusual specimens and the quirky nature of this site.  I arrived early, and was pleased I did as I was able to walk around in the quiet, which I wouldn't have been able to do had I arrived as I was leaving.
It’s nice to see if you are in the area, don’t go out of your way. It’s very small and full of tourists. So not so serene as it should be . The cafe food isn’t great either.
review_title: Pretty, but don’t go out of the way

review_text: beautiful gardens but had to queue for about 20 mins to get in, was very busy, but still felt calming and relaxing
Beautiful garden in centre of Marakesh. Well worth a visit. Can be busy at peak times. Good place to get away from noise and bustle of city.

This really is a must see while in Marrakesh, even given it’s full of tourists! I was able to get in fairly quickly (arrived about 9:30) and was shocked at how long the line for tickets was when I exited. I’d certainly recommend seeing the Berber Museum as well. It doesn’t take long to get through, but the quality of its exhibits/artifacts is outstanding. The restoration/preservation of the buildings and gardens were a gift from YSL and his partner to Marrakesh - and they are simply beautiful. It’s fairly peaceful for Marrakesh, and a nice break. But I’ll echo what another reviewer said, I wasn’t always impressed with the behavior of staff, and opted to go somewhere else for coffee. Not all staff, but too many seem far more interested in talking to each other than helping visitors. Still, very worth your time and money. I spent about one 1/2 to 2 hours inside.
What a lovely place- the gardens, the Berber Museum and Yves St Laurent Museum. I only wish a tour of the hose was available to the public.
This garden is absolutely stunning. Even if you aren't into gardens/plants/nature, it's still worth a visit just to walk around in what feels like paradise.
It's worth to stay on the long queue to get tickets. You will be delighted to see plants from all the world and vivid colours of buildings, tops, fishes. Just go there.

An oasis of peace full of colour away from the busy medina ~go in the afternoon as the morning is busy and you queue ~ pre book on line 24 hrs before hand to also prevent queuing~ this was my second visit as I visited years ago and it left me with such an impression that I wanted to revisit

We visited mid- afternoon without pre-booking and there were no queues. The garden is pretty and serene but prepare to queue at the various photo opportunity spots. The colours were vibrant and the cafe was very pleasant - but not cheap.
Took a taxi ride here, the gardens were lovely and it was well worth the visit.  Dont forget to take your camera.
review_title: Lovely gardens well worth a visit

review_text: Definitely a must when in Marrakesh. Don’t be put off by the que to get in. They tell you 45 minuets but it actually only took about 10. Very cheap as well. Once inside the gardens are absolutely stunning. You can take your time walking around them going at your own pace. So much inspiration for my garden. Honestly so beautiful I would definitely go again. I think my friends and I were in there about 45 minuets to an hour but you could spend less or more time if you wanted. Some of the most beautiful gardens I have seen. So rich in colours.

It is not worth the queue and the money... crowds of people, some cacti, a bit of colour and nothing beyond it. If you want to spend your time better, choose one of the magnificent riads and go to have lunch there.

For only 100durham for University students for the combined tickets we thought was exceptional value. The gardens are beautiful, lots of opportunities for pictures along the way. As a group of 3, we spent just over 2 hours. When leaving the gardens, the actual Yves Museum is found just up the road on the same side as the gardens. It isn't really sign posted or noted well even though it's part of your ticket. But don't miss it if you haven't found it.

Had a lovely afternoon here in the gardens. They are so beautiful and so tranquil. Strongly recommend visiting. We also had a delicious lunch there in their cafe. Recommend the club sandwich and matchstick fries!
review_title: Beautiful Place so tranquil and relaxing

review_text: 70 durm entry but definitely worth it!! Not what you expect after walking round the busy streets of Marrakech all day !

Finally a cool place full of greenery and charm! Perfect to take a break from the tumult of the Medina! Located in the new Marrakech this magnificent garden is a moment of perfect relaxation! but berber museum is better, and you have to pay for garden first because the museum is inside the garden The photos you take there will be magnificent! A place not to be missed

I would try to avoid crowds as people get very aggressive while they're trying to take one for the gram. Very beautiful. The restaurants nearby are a bit pricey, walk down towards the Medina a bit and you'll find awesome restaurants offering pizza for $2.
We visit this quit garden and as beautiful, located outside old medina of Marrakech but still worth visit! ell recommended!
The garden, the fascinating Berber museum and the Yves Saint Laurent fashion museum and wonderful restaurant were the highlight of our stay
Majorelle Garden makes you live your best moments of love between nature. It was nice atmosphere to get out of old medina of marrakech. We highly recommend it if you love nature!

Beautiful and immaculately maintained . Busy but never felt overcrowded . Bit of a queue but you can avoid this by buying your ticket at the Yves St Laurent museum which has direct access to the gardens .
My second visit of Jardin Mjorelle, this time with Berber Museum. Definitely worth to visit, an oasis of peace in a busy city.

Fantastic visit today with a tutor guide Mohammed, With a tour guide you go straight in and don’t have to wait in the long queues, also very informative The gardens are amazing 😉 Well worth a visit Also a lovely love story,
Beautiful gardens. I now understand the draw of an oasis. In the middle if a crazy city there is peace and quiet. Amazing.

Get there early if you have not booked online beforehand. Not later than. 09:30hrs. Gardens are quirky and very colourful. Buy the combined ticket. Head for the Berber museum first off. Cafe nice and reasonable,
review_title: Wow!!!! Must see location in Marrakech

review_text: This place was extremely beautiful! The colors were so surreal and it was definitely a nice location on our tour of Marrakech!

Worth seeing but not really worth going to see. It’s just a nice garden really, nothing overly special about it. Very busy and rammed with tourists, try and go on the less busy times as you may get a better impression than we did. Entry is 70drm (around £6.00) so not expensive and you will have to que for quite a while. The line will be long. There is no que for the pre payed tickets though, wish we had off known this.
Visited with tour and really enjoyed learning about the history of the gardens, Yves Saint Laurent and Pierre Berget. Better go early in morning to avoid crowds.

A beautiful place: the colours of the garden were magnificent against the pure blue sky, but perhaps a victim of its own success. It was potentially a calm place but tainted by the queues for 'the' instagram photo.  Recommend to book a ticket 24 hours in advance on the internet to avoid queuing (we only waited in a queue for about 10 minutes, but I heard stories of 2 hours). The Berber museum was well presented and interesting.
Was my first time, generally exploring that place was one of my good experiences. Thanx for those who made it great.

Amazing and exceptional well manicured garden. It is what u see on pictures or even better. Entry price reasonable 70dm (7usd) for the gardens only and with extras u pay almost 180dm (18usd). I learned that the best time was to arrive early morning when they are few people during the week for great pictures. Sunday late afternoon was a messy in terms of that perfect picture moment. Overall worth visiting.

Long queues.  Aggressive and whimsical staff who think yelling at the tops of their voices to each other across the gardens is a fab idea.  It is quite clear that they don't want you there. It's horribly overcrowded defeating the purpose of visiting to enjoy a peaceful garden.  The blue bits are very pretty and this must have been a lovely place to live as a private residence but it's way too small to accommodate the demand and the customer service is a complete failure. There are some nice frogs in the pond.  That was definitely the best bit. I felt very disappointed by this place on so many levels.  Thanks to the frogs for being awesome.  Come here if you like to look at frogs on lilypads with some bright yellow plant pots nearby.
This was stunning place and the Berber museum was great value. Take a relaxing walk and enjoy the garden. It was deffinitely worth the visit.

Majorelle is one of the best gardens in the world. we have seen different kinds of trees, flowers and it is a nice attraction in Marrakech which you can visit for 70 MAD. It is just 10 minutes by car from the medina of Marrakech.
It's nice, beautiful house and gardens, exactly as in the pictures. Didn't feel it was anything super spectacular, worth a visit if you check out the YSL museum anyway.

This was a very beautiful garden, with many different of plants from different parts of the world. Very colorfull and a nice mix of colors on the building and fountains, will 100% recommend to go to this place.

We went early at 9-10am and it was quick to get in. It cost 70dh to get in on the gate. The gardens themselves are very beautiful but not very big and the place was quickly becoming busy as time drew on. It does not take long to go around the gardens and by the time we left (about 10:30) it was already getting very busy. When we left there was already a long queue of people outside waiting to get in. Overall, the gardens were beautiful and it was pretty cheap to get in but I would not have gone any later because the volume of people visiting is perhaps disproportionate to the size of the gardens. We did not go to the Berber or YSL museum.
review_title: Nice gardens if a little crowded

review_text: Waste of time and money. Asking foreign tourist double the price. Complete waste of time, 3o people to get tickets the wait is 1 hour and over, absolute joke. Went inside and guess what nothing special to see. An absolute waste time and money,
review_title: Wating 1 hour and over to see 10 types of cactus trees.

review_text: Strongly recommended before we travelled and by our hostess in Marrakesh. On the hop on bus route with v good value cafe restaurant just outside. Spectacular layout and the painted blues with the natural greens were stunning. We passed on the YSL museum but add the Berber Museum to your ticket for £2.50.

Wandering in this garden after have visited the YSL Museum is a very relaxing feeling. Everything is nicely taken care of, the House of YSL is a real catch eye with the Berber blue colors and the dense vegetation around.  A must visit !

This is an interesting garden in its own right, made even more memorable because of the contrast of its cool interior to the scorched and frenetic nature of the nearby Medina. If you are buying a combination ticket to do the YSL Museum as well, the queues are much shorter if you buy the tickets at the museum, and do the garden afterwards.
This is a lovely place. Despite the crowd of visitors, you can take photos as if no one else was there. A definite must see.

Incredibly unprofessional and unpleasant staff... I inadvertently stepped off the pathway and took a picture. A staff member lost his mind and told me to return to the pathway and delete the picture, which i did. But he then demanded my phone and a 10 minute heated discussion ensued which could have taken one minute... He physically insisted on taking my phone, and I eventually realized there is a deleted photo file that he was trying to get to to again delete the picture.  If he had told me that from the beginning i would have simply done it. He also went off about how Moroccans are very smart and I can’t help but wonder if he would have scrolled through pictures if I were male instead of female. If you’re going to work at Marrakesh’s “#1 tourist attraction” maybe get some public relations training... Coffee was good, garden small but pretty, go early.
review_title: Staff will confiscate your phone and scroll through photos

review_text: This was a stunning place which when combined with the YSL museum and the Berber museum was great value (180 MAD). The blue and yellow paint was very IKEA however proved to be an impressive contrast in its use all around the garden. The Berber museum used mirrors very effectively to give the impression of a spectacular night sky. Thank you YSL for saving this garden for future generations to enjoy
A MUST for any Marrakesh visit, take a relaxing walk, enjoy the garden, and remember to take it slow, Morocco style.
It was definitely worth the visit. I would go early to avoid the clouds. Interesting history of Berber

The gardens and the museum of YSL was the most glamorous spot in the city! i was impressed with both the garden and the museum of Ysl. Ladies will be shocked with the historical collection in the museum.

Well worth a visit and entry fee. The blue, yellow, and orange colors throughout the garden were amazing. Everything was arranged very nicely. The Berber Museum was also very informative and organized. A nice place to spend a couple hours in the morning. Get there early to avoid the crowds.
review_title: Lovely Garden and Interesting Berber Museum

review_text: lovely visit we got lucky with not too many people and got to take lots of photos all over the gardens - historic visit loved it
review_title: lovely gardens plenty of photo opportunities

review_text: Look not that much to do in Marrakech so why not go here and spend half an hour looking at bamboo and cacti’s   Top tip the queue for the garden tickets is longer than the YSL museum where you can get a joint ticket. See the museum and then just walk into the garden. Enjoy!
review_title: A garden to enjoy the shade

review_text: This was high on my list of things to see in Marrakech but I was so disappointed in the experience. The garden was incredibly over crowded with visitors and an excessively large number of staff keeping an eye on you. The gardens themselves were unimpressive and there was very little interpretation as you explored them to help inform the visit. I admit we didn’t go into the museum but I expected more in the way of information outside. Sadly as a garden lover and enthusiast I won’t return when I’m next in Marrakech. The brilliant blue paint was indeed stunning against the planting, and palms against the blue sky was a striking sight but this did not outweigh my overwhelming sense of disappointment.

We visited this small garden in Marrakech after having visited several others in the area. It was expensive and we had a timed ticket which we bought on line the previous week and the site wouldn't let us buy tickets to the 2 museums as it said there were none left. On arrival we asked about museum tickets and they were available -lots of people buying them. The gardens them selves are in majorelle blue which is the garden's distinctive feature, however the gazebos were full of people queuing to have their photographs taken with views of the various water features. There is little underplanting of the various palms and little originality in any feature. The bamboo were fine. The over crowding is due to bus tours coming in from all of Morocco.
Very very crowded. Nice enough garden but over priced. Wouldn’t bother. The vistas are nice with the coloured house in background but it’s not the best thing to do in Marrakesh.
review_title: Difficult to walk around as it’s so busy.

review_text: Well organised, nice garden, full colour, interesting berber museum.  Recommend to visit also museum. Nice arranging presentation.

Very turistic place. Nice to see however the shop is majorly overpriced. Well worth a visit and 70MAD is a fair price for all the maintenance the site requires and the state of the place is impeccable

Jacques Marjorelle’s stylised garden is as far away from an English country garden as you can get.  Dominated by the sticklike trunks of the bamboo groves, the exotic banana trees and palms, the garden is interspersed with water features and pathways lined with the gorgeous‘ ‘Marjorelle blue’ painted walls and oriental shaped pots.  The scenery perfectly blends with a vibrant yellow and blue cubist style house owned by Yves St Laurent who was equally inspired by Morocco and lived in Marrakesh for many years.  A new building next door houses an exhibition of some his exquisitely designed dresses abd jewellery The garden also hosts a Berber museum containing artefacts, clothes and jewellery of this indigenous people of Morocco and it is here you can see how strong an influence their art and culture had on the artist and designer In need of refreshments, there is a delightful cafe in a walled courtyard.
Inspiring place with beautiful colours and great vibes. The cactus varitery is incredible , I recommend

You que for 1 hour to get tickets in the blistering sun, The gardens are nice and tranquil how ever you are not allowed into the actuall house, no photos are allowed in some places and it got very over crowded whilst we were there. Its not a all day activity as we were led to believe how ever it was still an ok afternoon out.
review_title: Not as amazing as made out

review_text: We took a morning guided trip to visit a number of locations and this was the first on the itenary as queues can get busy later. Very impressive gardens with well maintained exotic plants that cannot fail to impress.
review_title: Great display of exotic cacti in a lovely location

review_text: beautiful gardens to lose yourself. The que to get in moves fast so dont panic. Easy to find on foot from the main square too. maybe a 30 minute walk.
I was mesmerized by theses gardens. The use of blue and yellow throughout are stunning. I loved the well curated small Berber museum collection too
review_title: Beautiful gardens and small Berber museum

review_text: We got here on opening and enjoyed wandering around on our own. The staff were very courteous and lovely. Had a very nice breakfast with very attentive staff. Well worth it !
The exotic garden is really enjoyable, but the queue is too long and the price is too expensive. Try to not eat in their coffee shop inside, the food is quite bad...

I would highly recommend visiting the gardens, but would also recommend that you get here early. We arrived at 10am and the gardens were already starting to get crowded, but it was definitely worth the walk around. The colors are amazing and all of the different plants and cacti are gorgeous
The garden is very nice, I would go there again the next time I visit Morocco. I liked the cactus plants big like trees. I had bought the ticket online, so I skipped the line.
We truly enjoyed our tickets to the gardens. There are so many interesting plants all around and the cacti are just amazing. The blue house is stunning as is the Love paintings by YSL

There was a huge line when we arrived around noon. Place itself was nice inside. Nothing special and not worth the line there was but pro tip: if you're planning to see garden and YSL museum go to the museum first. Short line and you can buy tickets to both places at the same time. Go to museum and after museum skip the whole to the garden as you already have the ticket.
Very busy but well worth a visit, gardens lovely and very nice shop The museum was great all the Yves st Laurent was excellent

This is a nice way to spend dune time in Marrakech.  It contains the gardens themselves, the Berber museum, and the Yves St. Laurent museum. We found free on-street parking a few streets north of the museum.  Depending on which museum you want to visit, the cost can be up to 180 MAD per person.
Despite nice variety of plants and nice interior, I had a feeling it was too pricey for what you get. I would spend my money elsewhere if I knew what is behind the fence.
Do not miss this fascinating place when in Marrakech.  Great history surrounding the garden.  Peaceful and inspirational
colourful and pretty. smaller than I thought, no souvenirs to buy nearby, I find it pricey for what they have specially for tourist as locals pay a different price

Way too crowded with tourists posing. Nice restaurant,though very small. Berber museum and other museum in gardens closed on wednesday. Quite disappointing garden. Visited off season,-imagine the crowds are unbearable in summer.

Good background for pictures, loads of people. Go early for better shots, without others in them :) 180 dirham for combined ticket - YSL, Majorelle gardens & Berber museum within (not much to see there but it's just an extra €1) so migt as well. Purchase your combo ticket at YSL down the road (smaller que, if any) then go to Majorelle.

Worth a visit if you dont have to Q for too long - so come early or get a joint ticket with the YSL museum next door where you can get combination tickets and the Q's are shorter. Its like desert succulent planting. Unfortunately it is an Insta heaven so lots of tourists taking pictures and posing.
This place in Marrakech is truly worthy of a visit its interior and related to many species of plants that make the atmosphere fresh and fragrant, I recommend you visit it ...

The gardens were absolutely wonderful. The queue to get in was around a 30 minute wait but moved quickly. Once in the gardens we took a leisurely stroll around, although it was busy in the gardens you could still get nice pictures and enjoy it at your own pace. Would definitely recommend a visit to the gardens if in Marrakech.
Situated just of the street. This lovely walled garden is a ideal to get away from the busy city streets in the surrounding area.

This place is an absolute gem in Marrakech - the Yves Saint Laurent Garden. Beautiful flowers, wonderful colors. It's like an oasis in the middle of a busy and loud city. I would definetly come back again to spend some quiet time.
review_title: Beautiful garden - an oasis in Marrakech.

review_text: not much to see in this garden, very small it takes you 15 min to go around it. it does not have so much to see!

Alltough it is always crowded, this place is a bizarre and colorful oasis in the middle of marrakech. Don't miss the Café - we had the best Salade Maroccaine there. And: taxidrivers try to rip you off!! Take the public bus there and walk a little (around 10 MAD + 10min walk). Don't pay more than 80 MAD for a taxiride to the center. You're welcome.
Just beautiful.  Amazing cacti and other unusual plants set in a great environment. Great value and a must visit in Marrakech.

I came to Marrakesh last year and didn't get to come here so this time I made sure I did! I bought the whole family with me, including 3 males and they said it wasn't as bad as they had thought. I loved the place, its beautiful and peaceful and just not what you'd expect! I'm glad I went, my nan loved it as she loves gardening and the look of places, my mum who doesn't really like that sort of thing still enjoyed and said she could stay there all day relaxing. It was very calming. It's only around £5.00 entrance without museum so is good value.

This beautiful garden is well worth a visit. Mostly mature trees, cacti and succulents of which I have quite a few at home, but these are on a huge scale and are very impressive. Very well maintained with not one brown leaf in sight.  The mosaics, water features and amazing blue buildings add to making this a wonderful place to escape from the city, along with lots of different birds all singing their appreciation of this gorgeous place. I absolutely loved it and would highly recommend a visit.

This is an amazing place tucked away in a backstreet. Even though it was well attended when we visited one is never aware of crowding. It is compact with well laid out paths to follow but like us I am sure you will retrace your steps several times. Turn right after the entrance and you will reach a most attractive cafe where, and if you orde mint tea, then you your waiter will perform the local pouring from a great height then offer to let you try it. Warning, don't attempt to better him!
review_title: Fascinating, even for a non gardener!

review_text: Part of the Yves St Laurent memorial garden in Marrakech attached to his museum.  The queues are a little long and slow but once you're inside, it was a lovely breather from the hustle and heat.  These trips are only about 1 hour attractions but are popular and combined with other attractions nearby.

Wonderful garden which is the perfect break away from the busy city. Calming green cactus and palm trees all around. A lovely way to spend an hour or so. Do check out the YSL and Berber museums while you’re there. We bought a combination ticket from the YSL museum which had no queue and then we could walk straight into the gardens which had a huge queue of people waiting to buy tickets.

This a really interesting garden laid out with great care and beautifully presented.  Among the gardens are a number of bright indigo planters and a fabulously bright building designed by YSL.   Expect to queue and 5he entrance for the jardin is 70 Dirhams.  There are two other museums within the grounds that require an additional entrance fee.
review_title: Nicely landscaped and full of Bamboo and Cacti

review_text: Jardin Majorelle is a stunning place to escape the hustle and bustle of Marrakech, but get there before it opens because it gets flooded with tourists within the hour of opening!
One of our favourite tourist spots. Beautiful and peaceful after the hub-bub of the streets. Definitely a place to see while in Marrakech.

Get here around 8:30 and it is nearly deserted otherwise it gets extremely busy. Queues to get entrance tickets get very long from about 10;00 onward and seemed slow ro clear so we gave up on our first attempt to visit. If you like gardens this is a peach.

The beauty and plant diversity of the garden is only rivalled by the colours of the constructions it harbours. You'll wish you had it all to yourself even for an hour or so. Also the Berber Museum though small gathers beautiful and historical artefacts, jewellery and clothing well worth the additional.

We were advised to see both the YSL Museum & the gardens. Great advise as the queue at the gardens is usually HUGE! The Museum is very interesting with a great display of YSL clothes & jewellery. The gardens are lovely too.

What a fantastic place! We arrived at 10am and waited just 5 minutes to buy tickets. We got the combined ticket which have access to Jardin Majorelle, the Berber museum and the Yves Saint Laurent museum next door. The gardens were amazing with exotic plants and amazing colours of the buildings. It’s well worth the visit but get there early. The YSL museum next door was beautiful! Classy and elegant and showed off some of the amazing gowns created by YSL. It’s a must do when visiting Marrakech.

The garden itself is lovely and very beautiful. However be warned that the gardens are very busy and the atmosphere is ruined by a mob of tourists taking selfies and queuing for an opportunity for photos at the best spots. I would suggest arriving early and buying the combo ticket with YSL museum to save money and avoid queuing for tickets.
Modern garden and actually quite a small place. It was impossible to have any clear, undisrupted view.

For me personally it was the only thing worth visiting and paying in this crazy city. The garden is filled with beautiful tropical trees and succulents from around the world. The Berber museum according to a Berber guide I met contains fake stuff and is rather small. The YSL museum will probably be nice for fashion enthusiasts, I was bored.
We had a wonderful time visiting Majorelle Gardens, the place was so beautiful and rich with amazing things....
review_title: spending half day in Majorelle gardens

review_text: The place itself is quite beautiful, but it’s teaming with people taking millions of photos of themselves which spoilt the peaceful atmosphere for me. It’s easy to find if you jump on the city tour (hop on hop off) bus as it’s one of the designated stops.
Nice little oasis which we walked to from medina. I thought it was a bit pricey at 70 dhms for a place you could see in 15 minutes.
Nice way to see the new part city..easy to buy tickets onsite , YSLmuseum amazing. Gardens vast, feels very southwestern with lots color. Berber museum interesting

Lovely oasis of beauty and calm in the city. Very busy and lots of people taking selfies which held us up. The Berber museum and Yves St Lauren exhibition were excellent and we had a lovely lunch I the cafe.
Beatiful garden and nice retreat from the City of you need a break and want to learn about the Berber.
review_title: Beatiful garden and nice retreat from the city

review_text: Visited these gardens on Wednesday afternoon and wanted to get the combined ticket which includes entry into the YSL and berber museum however when we got to the counter we were told both the museums are closed. This should be advertised on the website better as majority of people in the queue did not know it would be closed either and if we did we would have easily rearranged our plans and visited on another day. The garden was beautiful and peaceful.
Gardens are certainly beautiful and a nice oasis from the city, but rather small (you definitely won’t need more than an hour) and we’re quite overrun with European tourists while we were there.
We visited this garden in our trip to Morocco in Marrakech. There is blue everywhere with different plans. The place is nice but try to get tickets online so that you don't wait in the queue.

This is one of the most recommended places to visit in Marrakech. Buuuut.. the tickets are very expensive, you wait around one hour before getting inside  and then it's so full of people that you cannot enjoy it. After visiting marvellous places and palaces in the Medina, Jardin de Majorelle leaves you pretty  disappointed.

Beautiful gardens! We visited after 2pm so it wasn’t so busy! Absolutely stunning plants and colours. Very peaceful and inspiring. Great to visit before going to the Yves Saint Laurent museum next door.
Sooooo average - if you’ve been to Mexico City (Coyoacán) or more precisely, to Frida Kahlo’s house.. this is just a copy paste of that. Not very Moroccan and a real waste of time
review_title: Copy paste and waste of time

review_text: It is a pleasant surprise to enter the Majorelle garden. Even though it´s crowded with people it eases your soul from stress and the outside world. The colors and all the different plants with all these small ponds o water did indeed impress me.

Interesting with so many exotic plants and colors but a bit overrated tho. Entrance fee and quite crowded place disappointed me a little. Go for a walk in nearby parks, especially in spring when flowers will bloom. Marrakech has such beautiful public parks!
review_title: Very pretty and calm but a bit overrated

review_text: Quite dull gardens that will take you 10 minutes to walk around. The museum and Berber house were a bit more interesting
A beautiful garden with museum with YSL creations - so worth seeing. Buy the whole ticket so see everything. And come early or you will meet a long line. Very popular.

If you like blue, then this is the place for you. Combine this visit with the YSL museum starting there and avoid the queue for tickets. Seriously though, despite the crowds which come and go, the gardens are a beautiful and tranquil place, restored to their original glory. Berber Museum is worthwhile too. We had lunch in the cafeteria too, a great place for a break.
review_title: Gorgeous especially if you like gardens and the colour blue

review_text: We enjoyed our visit - who knew a collection comprising mainly cacti and palm trees could be so attractive. There were plenty of cool, shaded places to rest and admire the gardens. Despite being very busy indeed, we found occasional quiet areas which heightened the enjoyment. We chose the combined museum and gardens pass mainly as that queue was much shorter but were  glad we had as the Yves Saint Laurent displays and film were excellent as was the little Berber museum.

Nice garden, not very big and very busy with tourists. Some views are really pretty. The garden has a restaurant offering decent food. Although the menu states that the prices include service and taxes, the waiter still demanded something extra for the service.
To our surprise we spent three hours here including lunch and the small Berber Museum. Largely succulents but very different to most gardens.

Had to queue even though it was early in the day and in January. Small garden, not especially spectacular.If you are in Marrakesh for a week and needed to fill in a morning, then visit but many other more worthwhile things to do.

The gardens had a variety of cacti and other plants and trees, well shaded too. Had a cafe and an art room too. It was nice enough, but I think the £5.50 entrance fee per person is pretty steep for what you get.
review_title: Lovely gardens, but not very big...

review_text: Beautiful gardens, colourful architecture in an experience I now call "Ikea Tourism." Herds of people, forced to wind through in a single direction. Sad, depressing and hot.

Really glad we made the effort to walk here from the centre of town but we made the mistake of waiting for over half an hour in the queue, would have been better to have gone to the musee YSL first, which is great, then to the garden. We stayed in the garden for ages, fascinating planting, well worth the entrance price, and the cafe is great too.
Lovely colorful gardens, a must see in Marrakech.  Even in January, the gardens were interesting an full of life.  The shop inside the garden is also a must - gorgeous hand made goods.
This is a lovely garden that you must pay to enter to see the Berber museum,  which in itself, is quite underwhelming. The cactus garden is particularly beautiful.

The gardens are nice, but they are only gardens. The different cactus was unique. I was only planning to come to Marrakech once, so obviously I had to come to the top attraction, especially one with nearly 50,000 reviews. This attraction is not a Moroccan culture-type attraction; it is only a garden-type attraction.  However we walked from the lower Médina area to the gardens and back (3-4 miles round-trip) and inadvertently got more Moroccan culture than expected.  Our adventure took 4-5 hours, but only about 40 minutes for the Jardin.

Yes the blue walls are amazing and the garden is somhow nice, however it is not worth the price. If you visit Marrakech for the first time, you need to see Jardin Majorelle but don't expect to be blown away. It's a cute garden with colourful pots and blue walls on one of the buildings. The trees are beautiful and all but again, it's not worth 70DH ! Also due to its popularity it's overcrowded and it's a literal fight to try and take a picture. Instagramers and Youtubers are fighting to take the best selfie and you might not want to join them so your experience will be poor... We went early ( around 9.30 and it was still overcrowded). We did it but won't be back and believe there are many other ways of using 70 DH ! You basically look at trees, cactus, ponds and a locked villa. The Berbere museum ( 30 DH ) was much more insteresting to us, unfortunately it was really small and overcrowded too. Maybe they should look into the amount of people allowed in at the same time because between the tourists, the numerous staff ( at every corner there is someone guardind...the trees? ), the children, the yourubers and all, it was not the relaxing walk in a garden that we expected! You will snap nice shots though ( if you can fight with other people to stand near a blue wall ) . The owners are making money for sure!
review_title: Too expensive for what it is! OVERRATED

review_text: Lovely gardens, so colourful and such carefully chosen plants. It is a must see on a visit to Marrakesh.  Maybe slightly on the pricey side for the size of site (70Dh to enter and then extra for the museums) but do go. It's not far out of the centre of town and can be walked (we did) but if it's hot, maybe take a taxi. Go early in the morning  or a couple of hours before closing to avoid the crowds.  I suggest buying a ticket in advance from the garden website as it let's you skip the main queue.
It's a nice garden but very busy, so I'd recommend going earlier in the day. Expect to queue for photos at popular spots.
The garden and adjoining Berber Museum and YSL Museum were each a visual delight. Perfect size to explore and relax. Only wish the Villa Oasis would have been open for touring.

We were very excited to visit this locale and the YSL museum, but it is far from relaxing. Picture waiting in line to take a photo in a gazebo, being met at every corner by influencers who are staging their own photo shoot, and not a moment of peaceful silence. I’m pretty sure Jacques Majorelle is rolling in his grave that a place of beauty and peace has turned into this. The Berber exhibit is very good and worth seeing, but quite small and doesn’t really make up for the rest of the experience.
People come just for pictures the garden is good no one seems to stop and see I want to seat just for peace and take a good look at the planets
After walking around in the hot medina seen no green it was a pleasant difference to spent time in the garden. It is a relative big garden with lot of exotic plants and very well maintained.
Very relaxing and quiet, 100's of plant species and lots of pretty pictures to be taken! Would reccommend for an afternoon.
review_title: Nice escape from the hubbub of the town

review_text: Lovely, but small place. It's a quick expensive (18 euros) visit, even when you make the whole pack including Berber and Yves Saint Laurent museums.
Amazing colorful garden with exotic plans in which is placed Yves Saint Laurent's and Pierre Berge's boldly colored villa and their grave as well. Highly recommended!
you need to see it! it's so gorgeous; you can take beautiful pictures. There is a beautiful house with speechless blue on it.
Good cactus garden. Busy with lost of tourists like us!  Around 30 minutes for the garden is sufficient.
Lovely gardens, very well kept. The Marjorelle blue is fantastic. We didn’t go to the museum but enjoyed the sunny gardens

The hour-long wait to buy tickets on the day was just almost worthwhile...nonetheless, it’s a good break from souks and mopeds in the Médina. But unless you have extra days for which you have no other plans, my feeling is this can be skipped.

This venue has a charge but well worth it. we walked from the Madina which is too far for most but easily done. The gardens are beautiful and a cool place to relax in the heat of the day. Well worth the effort

It is recommended that you visit the garden, as it is very well preserved and has those amazing plant species. Being a plant afficionate myself, I enjoyed it very much. The Berber museum has an outstanding collection of Berber items which totally show you through the their culture.
Nice garden , expensive entrance fee for not so big garden. Too crowded. I like the many types and sizes of cactus
Is a brilliant garden. Having a rest after lunch is just heaven. Until you end up taking photos everywhere. You and another 5000 visitors. Must see thou !!!... seriously

It was pretty busy even early am (May be different if you pre book as part of tour). Once inside it is easy to find space to relax and enjoy the mix of garden and designed pavilion or pools. The Berber Exhibition was worth the additional fee.

I'm not sure what the fuss is about really. There are beautiful phallic cacti wherever you look and a memorial to Yves Saint Laurent but that's about it. Nice place to walk around if you can avoid the Instagrammers or are EVERYWHERE. The Berber Museum is small and interesting to a point but nothing that you haven't see before. It's a nice place to walk around for a bit but spoilt somewhat by all the social media fanatics looking for the perfect picture. It's laughable and spoils a beautiful location.
We only did the garden, which was 70 dirhams pp, and you could walk around it in a few minutes without really learning much either.
review_title: Really small and therefore too expensive

review_text: In a slightly different area of Marrakech, outside the Medina walls. Stunning grounds, but everyone seems to here for just taking pictures. Easy to be in and out quickly - 1 to 2 hours maximum

It's lovely here. Really nice. However ruined by two special groups of people who should be at best banned from society and at worst pegged out at dawn for the crows. 1. Instagram w@ankers. Tutting if you get in the way of that perfect pic. Asking you to move.  Just generally being pretty inconsiderate. 2. People who think it's ok to grafiti the plants. Just about every tree, leaf, stalk etc within reaching distance has someone's initials carved into it. These things aside it's lovely. Go early to avoid the Instagramaholes.

Absolutely stunning gardens. The only down side is it is very busy but that’s because it’s so beautiful so I guess you can’t complain. Had mint tea and pancakes in the cafe. Lovely courtyard to sit in the sun however the pancakes were really disappointing more like piklets, cold and heavy.
Some places hold a space in your heart. This one colour, light and space in perfect harmony with the nature of plants

Beautiful, vivid colours, a nice place that is worth the visit. Don't stick to the garden, visit the Berber Museum also!! Very crowded though and you might need to wait a while in queue for the tickets
The gardens as such are disappointing and not worth the entrance fee. I only hope that in spring or summer there will be more to see than dead leaves and no colours at all

Jardin Majorelle is a beautiful garden with exotic plants and beautiful colors. We also visited the Berner Museum. Very interesting. We spend 2 hours in Jardin Majorelle. I really recommend it! But don't do the combined ticket, because I did not really like the YSL museum. But if you do like that, the combined ticket is better.
Beautiful gardens well worth a visit. We arrived early so were able to take photos without too many people around. It was very busy a couple of hours later.

The garden is amazing and only about 20 minutes walk from the new part of the city. It is also easy to find and well sign posted. Once you arrive it is a feast of colour and a variety of plants, that means you can walk through it enjoying the tranqulity. it has a stylish feel with the colours, layout and beautiful coulourful planters.
It was very lovely when I visited, but extremely busy...if you plan to visit the garden and Yues Saint Laurent museum nearby, go very early to beat the long queues.
This place is a must see while in Marrakesh, lots to see so give yourself at least 3 hours to see all the beauty.

The gardens are beautiful but even in the off season, I felt the crowdedness of the area made it difficult to enjoy wholly. Places like these I love to be able to stroll and appreciate the plant life and architecture but no matter where I walked or stood I was irritating someone in the middle of their "insta photo op". They also have security here but clearly its not strict enough to have stopped seemingly hundreds of people from carving their names and messages into every tree and cactus on display. It's pretty and I wouldn't discourage people from going since it is historically significant. I personally wouldn't make an effort to pay to go in again.
one of the highlights of Marrakech. calm, arty, lot of cactus ;-) we can feel the work and the attention to details that were put together to make this place such an iconic place in Marrakech !

We possibly should have researched more, however, we thought this would be more of a park, rather than a garden with roped off walkways and attendants keeping a watchful eye. All the same it was nice to see, but unfortunately even on a Monday on January it was packed full of people all queuing for that perfect picture. Didn’t stay long, was worth the visit if nothing else than to say that we’d been. Probably wouldn’t be rushing back though.
review_title: Nice but not what we expected

review_text: It is not worth the money...it is beautiful but they have raised the price form 10dh to 70dh. In the end, it is not a must to see, you can see another botanical garden a
review_title: It's beautiful but you have many botanical gardens all around the world

review_text: Very beautiful place it is a must see if you visit Marrakech..i Love every thing in it trees, plants, colours every thing is just amazing
Stunning place with such amazing colours and plants, a beautiful place to wander around.  So many little areas that were real gems.

It is a beautiful garden and if you have plenty of time and some cash to spare - pay a visit. Although it is really busy around lunch time with loads of tourists trying to take pictures so you might have to wait in a queue for a nice shot and if it is you jam - go for it. We walked around and took some lazy pictures and sat on a bench for a while to relax from a busy Medina, which was really pleasant. A tip: but your ticket at YSL museum, it is way quicker and you can get joined ticket for 3 places for 180, or if a student even cheaper.
review_title: Pretty, but not worth it of your time is limited

review_text: Great to visit again and the gardens were lovely.  Pretty good value, but get there a little earlier to beat the queues to purchase tickets.  Don't bother with the YSL museum - the building is great, but style over substance on the exhibits.
review_title: Second visit after 20 years.  Not a disappointment

review_text: The gardens were pretty with great paint colors - vibrant and lively. It was pleasant and pretty, but not a unique stunner. This was an inexpensive side trip. It's an easy walk from the old town/media - about 5-10 minutes, crossing one busy road.
review_title: Nice (but not stunningly unique) garden - plan for 20 minute tour

review_text: Next  the YSL museum you find this magical and vibrant garden . A pleasant coffee shop and a small historical museum . A very nice way to spend a morning .

This could easily become a favourite place to remember.Amazing villa and wonderful garden in a peaceful setting away from the bustle of magical Marrakech.A beautiful shop with high end products reflecting the designs of modern Morocco.A lovely restaurant with good service and lovely food.

Yes this park has nice flowers but honestly, bamboo and cactus are freely available all arround the world. We did not see why this very little park should be worth 70 MAD enttance fee. Also, all the restaurants around it cost twice as much as in the Medina.
Jardin Majorelle is nice botanic garden really worth of visit. In the garden there is also Berbers Museums that you can visit by paying extra during the purchase of your tickets.
review_title: Must see if you visit Marrakech

review_text: Lovely garden, all very clean and tidy. Lots of visitors would make this a less enjoyable trip, as more popular areas of the garden were crowded when we were there.
review_title: Ok for an hour or so

review_text: It is beautiful, really much smaller than I'd expected with the Cacti absolutely amazing. The gardens are kept beautifully too with the museum sections of the garden are of real interest. But it was too busy and the feeling of it being a quiet escape....escaped me. The cafe looks good but again it was absolutely packed so we left after only about 45 minutes. are did then go to the Yves Saint Laurent Museum (as we had tickets to cover the gardens and museums) and this was really interesting if you like the history of fashion. Watch the film in their cinema, very interestingly put together. The following day we went to The Secret Garden in the Medina, and this was so much more interesting for me. Quiet, tranquil and fascinating history on how it's just been restored.
We visited the garden on Friday - it was very crowded, and that's the only reason I'm giving it 4*. The garden is unique, the blue house fits within it perfectly. A feast for the eyes.
The colours are superb, tea and cookie was delicious in the cafe and clothing exhibition as well as video was really interesting.
Peaceful place to visit. We went to the YSL museum next door first and buying a joint ticket means you can skip the queue for the gardens.

Visited on a Saturday morning. The gardens were nice but quite busy and a shame people have graffitied some of the cacti. You'll only need a couple of hours to do everything (incl. Museums) and its not that cheap. Get a combo ticket with the museums for the best value. Overall worth a visit as its one of the main attractions.

If you are looking for a break from Marrakech, this is your place. It can be busy, so early mornings are best. Be sure to allow time to see the Berber Museum. Bring your camera for sine stunning photos!

The colours and plants were pretty in the morning sun but despite getting there for opening time as suggested, it was already full of people pouting and jostling for their best angle. This made it difficult to enjoy any tranquility that a garden might offer and caused more frustration than enjoyment. I also found it pretty depressing that visitors have to be informed upon entering to not graffiti the bamboo. There are several other gardens in the city that provide a more enjoyable experience.

Visited here over the weekend with my daughters and we all loved it. The gardens are amazing, Berber museum interesting and the cafe a great place to rest and enjoy some calm. A few negatives: the queue for tickets (though families do skip it) and the staff in the cafe are very rude. If not for these things I would have given it 5 stars.

It is an oasis in a beautiful area of Marrakech. You can see hundreds of cacti and other plants like bamboo trees. Contrast in colors between the green of plants and blue paintings of houses. The Berberin museum shows a journey in time. It is a ' must visit' place, located near the Yves-Saint-Laurent museum. Normal tickets price.
review_title: Fabulous place in a beautiful area of the city

review_text: A bit hyped park, low season but still a lot of people, many different types of cactus's were displayed. The place is not really living g up to The hype, quite average for a park that require a fee to enter.

YSL's love of Marrakech is obvious from the way he has infused his style and color into this gorgeous garden.  While there, you should go through the YSL museum to see the influence Morocco had on his design.   The Berber museum also on the grounds is very interesting and layed out nicely.

Very long queue to get into a fairly small site.  Very crowded inside and completely distracted from what should be a serene environment.    Limited selection of plants with lots of ‘bulking out’ with bamboo, philodendron and succulents.   Very overpriced for what it is. Save your money and visit the Parc Arset Moulay which is much bigger, very quite, has a good variety of plants and is free!!!

Exotic and wonderful! Lots of walking but really worth it. The museum YSL is also worth a visit. We visited first the museum bought both tickets so we avoided the long lines for the garden and visited both places.

I’ve been to a lot of botanical gardens all over the world.  This one is nice but nowhere near great.  Lots of bamboo and some cactus.  Also lots of tourists getting off busses and crowding the paths.  Get there when it opens.
Just go and visit this garden! It's not a lot you can visit in the city,so that is a good option! It's peaceful and green,and you can have some relaxing time and get some beautiful pictures there!

Arrived at the ticket office expecting to pay 70d for the entrance fee to the whole complex, haha, 70d is the fee for the garden, then it's 100d for the museum and 30 for the berber museum or 180 for the lot. I went on a 12hr trip with lunch and breakfast for less the following day. So I paid 70d for my entrance to the garden and a very nice, peaceful and pleasant garden which had obviously been well maintained, filled with plants and trees that grow naturally in this climate anyway and It takes around 10_15 mins to walk round the garden. Personally I didn't get it, cyber park was bigger and free.
review_title: Nice place but not worth the entrance fee

review_text: We had to queue for tickets but we didn't have to wait more than 20mins. Despite the queue it wasn't terribly busy inside and we could enjoy the wandering around the garden. It's not huge so we were done and dusted in an hour, we might have stayed for coffee but the cafe was busy. It is an attractive and unusual garden and is definitely a good break from the craziness of the Medina and souks.
review_title: Get away from the hustle of the medina

review_text: Sadly this beautiful garden and house is spoilt by the public queuing for pics. Too many people in at one time. It wasn't relaxing or peaceful in the slightest.
Save your £7 entry fee and spend it elsewhere. Cacti and bamboo sums this place up. 10 mins and we had seen it. Poor.
Hmmmm I really was not that impressed with this garden. I was expecting more as it was "the place to absolutely visit" overcrowded & just colorful. Not really all that .

It accommodates a very rich variety of plants in a colourful artefact. The entrance fee is 70 dirhams for non-Moroccon citizens. Walls, buildings, and pots have very bright colours which make the environment more glamorous. It is worth visiting.

The garden is very pretty! The colors and contrast was incredible. Only negative aspect was the amount of people talking pictures, not allowing you to take nice pictures and constantly asking to move out the way for the pictures. Other tan that, it is a must visit!
This is a must do in Marrakech very easy to get to by taxi and cheap to get in.We spent a pleasant hour there.
I enjoyed this garden of bamboo/  palms and many types of cacti. Interesting to know that Yves Saint Laurent lived here. The Berber Museum was not open.
Both museums closed so garden was very busy, crowded with over-enthusiastic Instagram Influencers ensuring they got their best side,

The Majorelle Gardens have become one of the main tourist attractions of Marrakesh.
