At just 2 acres the gardens are in fact quite small, and unsurprisingly filled with various displays of cactus and palms. The blue buildings and crystal clear ponds and rills are however quite enchanting. We spent about an hour in the garden, including the Berber museum and arrived early. As we were leaving the crowds had built up and the queues for tickets extended. My advice is to try to find a quiet time to visit and don;t have preconceived expectations. It is a nice Moroccan garden.
Well worth a visit to this beautiful little garden to see the beautiful cacti. Museums also interesting. Delightful shop and cafe.

We visited these gardens last week.  They are beautiful and calm, a feast for your eyes and soul.  We had to que for 30 mins to get in so I'm not sure what it would be like when its busier. Well worth a visit
A beautiful quiet haven which was a feast for the senses, loved the Berber museum, well worth a visit 💕

Majorelle gardens and the YSL museum is well worth a visit. We booked our tickets on line through the official website. In January we visited the gardens at 15:00 and it was not busy at all but with beautiful sunshine

Go early, go often, go early, or go late. The gardens change in atmosphere and in color in the mornings and evenings. By noon the crowds, esp. those with the selfie sticks have totally disrupted the tranquility. There is a nice cafe and a LOVELY boutique shop featuring native Berber goods, it is high end but high quality.
a bit expensive to pay that much to see a place you can visit in an hour or less.it is maintained and very clean. but very less plants/tress to see.

You may have to stand in line awhile but it's worth it.  Also this is one sight that is costly.  Be sure to see everything associated w/ St. Laurent's home including the fashion exhibit down the street.  I loved this garden.  Many colorful bridges, etc and a great café with delicious lemon tarts. Have lunch at the fashion exhibit nearby.
review_title: This is an absolute MUST SEE.

review_text: A wide range of trees and plants from around the world and an ecelectic mix of colour. Yes San Laurent Christmas cards across many years as he supported the gardens

Amazing oasis of beautifully designed gardens away from the intensity of the medina in Marrakech.  Lovely cafe as well.  To avoid long lines, either buy online more than 24 hours before going or show up at around 3pm

Interesting plants, plenty of large cacti and well kept, except the graffiti on the bamboo plants, not the fault of the gardeners but shameful mindless vandalism of some visitors.  If you are in the area visiting the YSL museum, you might as well visit the garden.  It took us around 30mins walk from the Medina.  We were advised to buy the combined tickets at the YSL museum to avoid the queues but as we visited in Jan and earlier in the morning, we didn't find the queues long and it was fairly quiet.  I can see how it can be packed as it is not a big garden.

If you are going to the YSL museum, don't miss the unique garden, with a wonderful Berber museum.  The spaces and planting were very special, and ensured that we would also visit the Secret Garden (different but equally enchanting).  The museum was a real treat because although we had already been exposed to some aspects of Berber culture, the exhibits gave us a much deeper picture.

The colors here- majorelle (royal) blue, periwinkle, lemon, orange- are saturated in the Moroccan sun, and are relieved by the lush greenery of the trees and plants. A memorial to Yves St. Laurent, a museum of his designs, and the Berber Museum complete the experience.
review_title: A deep breath of peace and beauty

review_text: Loved this! Beautiful gardens enjoyed by all the family. Would definitely recommend. The museum is amazing too

Such a fun morning! Get here early - 10am latest and beat all the crowds & queues. We went early as recommended by our Riad & waited perhaps 10 minutes to get in. They take card which is great & by the time we left at noon is was really really busy. The plants are spectacular & the garden has a lovely vibe. It’s chilly as it’s so shaded and the cafe is lovely. Mint tea comes with Moroccan pastries. Absolutely lovely!

The gardens are nice (though maybe a bit overrate), but the Berber Museum was extremely well put together with a lot of history, explanations and beautiful objects, jewelry and costumes. It was the best museum experience we had in Marrakesh.
If you like bamboos, cactae and vivid colors then this is a place for you. The only garden/park that worth a visit in Marrakech

A garden full of fantasy but harmonics. It does not take much time to visit it, what really takes time is the one that you are giving step by step, finding on the way an incredible cactus collection. mandatory visit point in Marakkesch
review_title: A garden full of cactus of the world

review_text: The gardens are definitely worth taking the time to visit. Try to get there quite early as it does get quite crowded.
A relaxing garden if you can find the quiet corners, gets very busy but just large enough not to feel too crowded.
review_title: Morroccan blue buildings and large plants

review_text: Despite the price (a little costly), the gardens and exhibitions were well worth the visit. Hard to believe you are in dirty Marrakech when you walk these grounds. The colours are superb, tea/cookie was delicious in the cafe and clothing exhibition as well as video was really interesting. Only issue is people taking photos and spending lengthy time getting their right pose (have never seen people looking like they were each in a modelling shoot!) which prevented others from taking photos. Should maybe be addressed. Glad I went there.
review_title: Love the colours; elegance amongst the grottiness!

review_text: A day trip to the Atlas mountains is a real just to experience the real Berber hospitality and say of life.

This is a really nice garden, but quite small and there is not that much to do there. I arrived early in the morning just after opening, so there weren't any crowds. It took me less than an hour to see everything there is to see, including the Berber Museum inside the garden. However, the entry fee is really low so it is definitely worth the price
review_title: A little change of pace from the rest of Marrakech

review_text: Ended our trip to marrakech with visit to the much talked about jardin Majorelle.  Gardens are a lovely and well kept peaceful space with some nice water features, and gorgeous cobalt blue buildings, but for me after the taxi trip there, the queue and the ticket price, I was slightly disappointed.
Only need about an hour but worth the escape from crazy Marrakech. Nice cafe but quite expensive. Lovely walk around with the beautiful colours

Beautiful peaceful gardens to relax in. Well maintained and a pleasure to dander around. From medina area you can haggle a taxi price, we paid 45 from 70, probably could have got cheaper but seemed fair. Yves st Laurent museum is in the gardens but was, unfortunately, closed during our visit
review_title: Beautiful peaceful gardens to relax in

review_text: Slightly out of the city centre. Although not far, if you try to walk you may well get lost. Take a taxi About 50Drm (£5) to get there from the Medina, but warning it's much more expensive to get back ! If you take a taxi agree a price before getting in. There are three attractions here and each requires a ticket. You can get a combined ticket for all three. (180Drm) The Gardens. Lovely. Not as big as I imagined. Huge bamboo plants and others. This is a popular place for fashion photographers, so don't be too surprised at trendy photographers and posing models. The Berber Museum. Within the gardens. Yes ok for the small additional cost. It's worth it. The YSL Museum. Just along the street. To be honest, you need to be a bit of a fashion nut, but I was very impressed by the display of garments. Warning, photos really are not permitted, and they watch like hawks. If you're going to come here at all you may as well do this. Have lunch in the cafe. Nice.

This was one of the stops on our tour and a very nice surprise. We visited the garden and then the museum up the road. The garden has lots of nice features including a room with some artwork. Definitely worth a visit if you are either in to the artist or gardens. The only thing we found disappointing was that people have scratched their names in to the plants and trees. I guess that is why there are some guards there.
This is really pretty and nice to stroll around for a little while.  It was crowded and lots of young people were taking selfies and pretending to be fashion models.

If you are a fan of YSL, this is a must stop in Marrakech. The gardens are beyond beautiful, so calming and serene. The museums at the garden have a good variety of Moroccan costumes and jewelry and the YSL museum next door is not to be missed if one loves his designs. The exhibition travels through his life and has many, many examples of his designs. My only wish was that the house he and his husband lived in was not open to the public.

We were a group of four wanting to do something a bit high cultural-stuff. The garden is quite nice with toilet and Café facilities. Compared to some places it is a bit over-touristic (beware!) and it is by most comparisons a quite small garden... but you get student discount

We escaped to this oasis on a hot afternoon in June. Really liked the fact that you could get a combination ticket for the Yves Saint-Laurent museum, gardens and Berber Museum, and we spent a couple of hours exploring it all (and you could easily spend more time in the garden). Loved the water features and the walking paths. Read a bit about the history of Majorelle (and YSL and Bergé for a full appreciation). Would definitely return on future visits to Marrakech. BONTAKS TRAVELS

Go early to avoid crowds. It was beautiful, with a great variety of trees and plants, however I felt underwhelmed, 10/15minutes in the gardens is plenty as there just really isn’t anything to do once you’ve walked around. Worth a visit as they’re rally isn’t a huge amount else to do!
Worth the small fee for entrance. Queuing at the entrance is tolerable during low seasons, but can be avoided if you invest some extra Dirham and enter via the museum.
Nice gardens but nothing spectacular. You can spend an hour at the most walking around in a nice environment.
It's an enjoyable place, but the pushy crowds just take away the magic.  I was told it's a must see, but I disagree.  It's fine, but it's hardly a must see.
review_title: It's nice, but way too busy.

review_text: Absolutely lovely gardens. Very neatly organized with guards guiding the flow of people. Beautiful greenery with a wide variety of plants and trees. The colors are stunning, and there are plenty of places for photos! Make sure to arrive early to avoid the crowds!

Don't get me wrong, Jardin Majorelle is a lovely place. The over saturated hues make for amazing pics. And who doesn't like cactus? But... The size of the place is much smaller than I had anticipated. As such, the price for a ticket is usurious. Determined to miss the vast hordes of mega tour busses, I arrived right near opening and missed the museums. Being there early meant no wait in line, but I had not managed to miss the busses entirely. And they just kept coming.... When I arrived, it was difficult to get good shots due to people taking dozens of selfies at at a time in the more famous locations. Ok, not my scene, but the plants are nice! By the time I left 30 min later, the small garden was overrun by wannabe influencers, in costume or unreasonable shoes, carrying props and reluctant spouses/photographers. Walking unimpeded was impossible. If you just want the same staged tourist pics as a thousand other bloggers, by all means go. If you want to experience Morocco, go anywhere else.
review_title: A case study in the deleterious effects of vacationing for the 'gram

review_text: Beautiful garden. There is a cute little café in. The gift shop has marvellous clothes bags and jewellery
3 hours spent casually looking at plants cacti and trees in secluded grounds. Benches to sit and ponder. With the adjacent YSL museum next door. Garden good value ONLY if you like that sort of thing.

you have to pay 100MAD, with 1-2 hours queue. while inside the garden you are obliged to follow the line with other tourists. The garden is clean, the berber museum interesting, but you can find definitely better FREE places where to go. Other gardens in Few, Marrakech, Casablanca or Essaouira are better, clean and free.
It’s a nice tourist attraction.  You can get some very nice photos if you’re willing to wait your turn.  It was crowded and not very interesting for kids.

We visited the gardens early in the morning.It was quite shady and some parts of the gardens were quite dark.The Villa was shut for restoration so we couldn't visit It took us about 30 minutes to walk around the whole garden. Some of the diagrams explaining the plants and trees were a bit confusing. We decided to do the "circuit" again as it was a bit brighter by the time we got to the beginning but the gardens were much more crowded by then and it was difficult to see anything properly. We retired to the tea room,which served expensive drinks and then left.
We enjoyed a pleasant afternoon wandering around these lovely gardens and also went to the Yves Saint Laurent. Recommended as a nice way to spend time.
review_title: Peaceful haven in the heart of the city

review_text: loved, loved, LOVED it! It's so inspiring, artistic and I wish I was there in like the 70s when Yves was still around the markets of the Medina. I will be back!

Very nice gardens just a short walk from the old town. We went later in the afternoon and the queue was short. (One thing to note is that parts of the gardens close at 16.30!! We didn’t know this and thought it was a bit of a shame that we had to rush through) I think that this should be clearly explained at the ticket desk! People were still paying full ticket price and entering ..... not knowing that part of the gardens were now closed !!! Anyway best to be entering at latest 15.30 ..... then you have an hour to see the parts that will be closing. I think it’s a must do in Marrakesh - no surprise that it’s number 1 on Trip !! Enjoy

Avoid the restaurant inside the garden with open yard. Staffs are rude and the food is not good; also long queues for cafe and restaurants. Maybe the restaurant inside the gallery is better but we didn’t try. We have been told that if you want to skip the queue, go to buy both tickets( museum and garden). We stayed in a long queue and at the ticket office we realised that there’re is another queue after buying tickets !!!! Just for going inside!!! Otherwise nice atmosphere in the garden and again queue if you want to go to Berber museum inside!!!
This is a must-see in the middle of the Madina. Beautiful gardens. A very peaceful place to relax in the middle of the hustle and bustle of Marrakesh. Amazing water system.  Great cafe.
This is quite small so it doesn't take long to walk around.  The Berber museum is closed on Wednesdays. There is a taxi rank outside for returning to your hotel.

We had high hopes about these gardens and I especially wanted to see the Yves St Laurent exhibition.  Sadly the main house was closed when we were there and the YSL exhibition shuts every Wednesday so make sure you don't go then!  The gardens are nice but not large - doesn't take long to walk round them.  It wasn't busy but can imagine in high season it would be a nightmare.  The cacti and plants are nice, and if you're interested in fashion you will enjoy the YSL exhibition which is up the road from the gardens.
review_title: A nice way to spend an hour

review_text: Lovely garden. Massive queue to get in. Was such a lovely perk to be brought to the front of the queue because we had a child under 12. Not much for kids in there (no surprises there) but at least we didn't have to wait to get in!!
review_title: Impressive. Shady so take a jumper in winter. Busy so take a child!

review_text: Great for taking some nice Pictures and relax from hectic Marrakech. We spent around 2 Hours in the garden and visited the nice cafe.

This garden is absolutely fantastic. It provides you a relax moment after go out of the Medina. Surrounded by walls, this garden have a lot of trees and water canals. It has also a Berbère museum with a lot of things of the original people from Atlas Mountains. Super recommend. The cost is cheap, 10 euros for the Garden + Berbère museum. It has another museum for Yves Saint Laurent but we did not visit it. If your flight is after midday and you are at Medina, take the morning to visit this place, you can spend 2 or 3 hours there.
Wow!!! What a stunning place!! Entry fee reasonable. Didn’t realise entry the YSL museum was a separate fee. Beautiful scenery, took some amazing photos. What more can I say !
This wasn't on the itinerary coming to Marrakesh but we stumbled upon it and were pleasantly surprised. Loved the Yves Saint Laurent Museum/Gallery on the property - do not miss it.

The gardens were lovely. Mainly cactus and palms. I am sure it would look more beautiful in the warmer months. The Berber museum was interesting but it was mostly in French with very little English so you didnt know what you were looking at. It was much smaller than I expected and for the money I'm not sure it was good value. That said, I'm glad I went and it was a good hour well spent.
review_title: Would be better in soring and summer

review_text: Once we had reached the end of the entry queue we entered a world of peace and colour. So elegant and peaceful. A well kept garden filled with colour, particularly blue. A special, deep, magical blue that worked well with the other plants. A worthwhile visit and a contrast to the rest of Marrakesh.

Just returned from an 8 day whirlwind tour of Morocco.  When asked what were some of the highligths of the trip, the Jardin Majorelle comes to mind, it's top on my list.  Absolutely gorgeous succulents and water ponds....it was so refreshing to be surrounded by nature amidst the city limits. Our group was able to skip the long entrance line, but once inside, it was very crowded.   We only had 1 hour to spend, and could have stayed 3 hours if I had had the time.

One definitely feels transported out of Marrakech into glorious green gardins when walking through the Jardin Majorelle, which hosts some unique looking trees, and plants. This is a nice way to spend a morning or afternoon though I do not know how much entrance cost because it was included in our tour. If the entrance fee is hefty... one might wish to reconsider unless they truly have an interest in this type of attraction. There are parks and gardens in every city and I would think a traveler might be more interested in the more unique aspects of this city especially if the price tag is heavy.  With that said... it was a lovely way to spend an hour or two.
The color scheme of the painted large jars, walkways and walls is beautiful, especially the use of indigo. Don’t miss the Yves Saint Laurent museum next door.
Did not knock my socks off but well worth the visit. Secret second garden entrance without the queue was a good tip.

As a garden designer, I couldn't visit Marrakech without a trip to Jardin Majorelle. Visually it's stunning, amazing plants and colours, running water and bird song. What is lacking is room to stand and any real places to sit down other than the cafe, so the final effect is one of being herded round, get the selfie by the long pool, marvel at the blue walls, then buy something or get out. It's iconic and interesting, but don't expect to spend more than an hour here Max.
review_title: Beautiful but crowded, not one for quiet contemplation

review_text: Most gardens are either collections of plants; or focus on overall design and style - these gardens do both beautifully. Can get crowded so maybe best to go quite early to get most out of it.
This place has a lovely little coffee shop within the garden where you can sit and enjoy the environment.
review_title: Beautiful garden and memorial to designer Yves Saint Laurent.

review_text: omg TOO MANY PEOPLE! I personally don’t think it lives up to the hype. The Berber museum is good but the garden itself is like 6.5/10 if it was empty. The influx for wannabe Instagram famous collecting their selfies all of the garden is kind of a grose scene. Would still recommend to go though for the Berber museum and ysl museum.
An oasis in Marrakech great value for money,overall impressions are clean tidy well laid out the only drawback is crowded so get there early.

Such a beautiful garden, full of palms, cacti, and simple, yet lovely ponds. There are lots of photo ops in this garden, whether including the lush foliage or the indigo blue and yellow backdrops. Some lovely bridges over water, and a serene setting. My only disappointment was that we went on a Wednesday, so the museum was closed. Still worth it.
review_title: Lovely Colours, A Peaceful and Artsy Display

review_text: The entry fee for the Majorelle Garden (70 Dirhams) is pretty steep, as with most things in Marrakesh. By contrast 30 Dirhams for entry into the Berber Museum, accessed via the gardens, is well worth it. The gardens and very neat and beautifully planted. They have presented YSL's Berber artefacts in spectacular and interesting fashion in the small museum. We ate a reasonable lunch in the cafe also. The whole place was packed with tourists. The queue for tickets was very long but if you buy tickets at the YSL Museum just 100 m up the street, you get in without queuing (a tip gleaned from TA!). The YSL Museum is also small but interesting: fab YSL dresses and a good temporary exhibition of paintings by Azema when we were there but again expensive: 100 Dirhams entry fee there.
review_title: Lovely planting and very good Berber Museum

review_text: We visited the garden with our 2 kids. When we arrived at approximately 11 in the morning, there were long queues. However we were directed to another counter where the queue was for people with children under 12, pregnant women and elderly or with disabilities. We had to wait for about 20-25 minutes in the queue. Children under 12 are free to enter the gardens. The garden itself is like an oasis, with huge cactus plants, palm trees, ponds etc. It’s really pretty. It takes you around 1 to 1.5 hour to explore it. We really enjoyed its vibrant colours and had a great time.
Small place but provides a nice escape from the maddness of the medina. Impressive cactus 🌵 🌵 and architecture.
This garden is beautiful and very well maintained. If you are in Marrakesh you need to visit it. It's a hidden gem.
Berber museum is a must as well as a tour around Yves villa which is nearby but separated from the Majorelle garden.
The Majorelle garden is one of the most beautiful place to visit in Marrakech This is definetly a must see full of history

When we arrived at our hotel we were recommended this tour by our rep, gardens aren’t normally my thing but I fancied checking it out. Doing it as part of a tui tour we arrived half an hour before the general public to get some nice photos. We were advised to do this as well because you can often queue for a while to get in otherwise - this was the case, as we left there were gangs of people beginning to queue to get in. The gardens are beautiful, due to the time of year we went it was a bit chilly even though you’re outside it’s quite sheltered. You can make it take as long as you like however i wouldn’t say you need much more than an hour in there (depending on how busy it is)
Hundreds of people lined up queuing for tickets to enter to take selfies of themselves in no doubt one of the few parks in Marrakech. Nothing special really.
it is very beautiful and the museum is very interesting as it is about the Berber heritage. I would advise going early and pre book if you can as it gets very bus.
review_title: Go early as it gets busy, museum is very good

review_text: this is nice garden designed by French majorelle !! really photogenic colorful view ! really we had enjoyed there !! this is one of best touristic place to approach there !! Recommended to all must visit if u there in Marrakech Morocco.

Beautiful gardens well worth a visit. We arrived a little later in the day at about 1pm when the queues to get in were already lengthy so an earlier start would have been better. Notwithstanding the number of visits the gardens still exuded a sense of calm and tranquility. The open air cafe was also a welcome bonus.
Amazing small garden .it's garden to visit in Marrakech same it's next door museum of ysl .must visit
Jardin Majorelle is a pretty and small garden. It is well cared but it is not amazing.  Have to strictly follow the walking path since the guards won't allow you to move freely
An amazing place to visit. Its a small garden but you would be awestruck at the beauty of this place. Its a visual treat for someone who likes cactuses. A must visit in Marrakech.
Beautifull adn peacefull oasis in the middle of the city chaos. Just sit an enjoy. Best to come early before the tourist crowd.
if your are in marrakech you must visit this garden, one of the tourist attraction in city and what you will find is different variety of cactus, trees and lemons and more...
review_title: one of the tourist attractions must to visit...

review_text: Really beautiful garden, although a bit out of the way / out of the city center. Worth a visit if you are in Marrakech for 2-3+ days.

We came early as a group and were let in without queing. I guess this makes a huge difference if you come on your own and waith for quite a while only to buy a ticket. Also, it was not crowded inside due to early visit. For us coming from green areas with a lot of woods this may not be something special, but to have such a garden in Marrakech is a demanding job. And unlike most of the city of marrakech these people are really trying to keep it in good shape. Aside of plants you can find a Berber museum, small but interesting enough to visit it - good thing it comes combined with a garden, on its own I guess number of visits to it would be low. You can also walk though the next garden in front of the Yves Saint-Lorent house. Very nice cafe in the jardin Majorelle and also there was a nice cafe in front of the jardin.
review_title: A piece of green heaven in Marrakech

review_text: We went down to the garden twice: first time the queue for the tickets was way to long and we spend the time in new town of Marrakech. At this time it was not possible to reserve tickets for the next day and we decided to go straight after breakfast. Second try at 10: 00 in the morning was very satisfying: the blue, yellow and green compilation are really awesome and we spend 90min there and it was relaxing and nice.
review_title: Beautiful garden - good for a trip

review_text: I think the queues to get in should have put me off- but we had walked 20 minutes to get here., so joined the line. We were queing for just short of an hour. i honestly don't know how this place can be rated as one of the best attractions in Marrakech. It was a small garden full of cacti and palm trees- nothing of note in the main garden which can't be seen in any public park in Morocco. The Villa Oasis garden was slightly more interesting, but still massively overcrowded, and has more limited opening hours. It was really disapointing to see grafitti scratched in to many of the plants- dreadful destruction of the exhibits. The place was so crowded that walking around in the main garden was difficult. This was certainly not the peaceful calm haven we had been expecting. If you can afford the $7 entry, save the money and spend in on a mint tea on the terrace of La Mamounia insteaad- end enjoy the peace and quietof their garden as part of the deal!

The place is overcrowded. Took longer in the que to buy a ticket than it took to explore the gardens. Nothing impressive just people at the blue wall trying to get perfect picture for Instagram.  Museum inside also was tiny and not worth the money you pay. It was waist of time.  Better go to see Mountains or deserts.

Took longer in the que to buy a ticket than it took to explore the gardens . Bit of a damp squib if im honest . I would estimate that the gardens wouldn't be much bigger that the size of a soccer pitch with some plants and trees and a few water features . The lunch in the outdoor cafe was nice thought . Wasn't really sure what to expect but was disappointed

Exceptional place at all levels, perfectly maintained. First, visit the garden (arrive the latest at 9:00am to avoid the crowd) and then go to the Villa Oasis and finish by the YSL Museum which both open at 10:00am. All is really amazing.
It might be a nice place to visit if no so many people there. You cannot enjoy the garden when you feel like in a subway during rush hours... I found the colors are a bit artificial as well...

This is quite a nice garden on a property once owned by Yves St Laurent. Long queues to get in, but if you go down to the YSL museum and buy a combo ticket the queue is much shorter and you then get to walk straight into the gardens and Berber Museum without the wait. The Berber Museum is well worth it. There are some wonderful artifacts there and a lot of interesting historical information.  The lighting is very poor, so if you want to read the info sheets take your best reading glasses. The YSL Museum is a waste of money unless you like modern art. There are a range of YSL dresses and accessories to look at.  I’m not into that sort of thing so didn’t spend more than 10 mins there. The gardens are peaceful and a nice chance to sit away from the crowds of the Medina.   You don’t need more than an hour to do all three. Total cost on the combo ticket is 180 dirhams. I don’t think the whole gardens/museum complex is worth queueing an hour for though.  If you are short of time you won’t really be missing anything spectacular. It’s a pity it’s not just possible to see the Berber Museum by itself, as that was the best bit.
Well worth a visit but be prepared for the crowds. We arrived early but still there were plenty of people there already.
great garden and not too far away from the Médina. Lots of tourists but still a quieter part of the city.
It’s a miracle that such botanic garden exists within a busy city like Marrakech! It has all the bright sunny colors of Morocco, and plenty of fountains!
review_title: An oasis of peace in Marrakech

review_text: It is a very interesting and nice place. The garden is really beautiful. I definitely recommend a visit. Give it about 2 hours.

Yes, paying 7 Euros per person in a family of 7 is a bit over the top for a garden and some blue walls, but it is such a beautiful place, that if you do have time for a visit you must go. There are a lot of imported cacti, trees and plants in this garden and are just lovely to look at. Although you don’t need much time in this place, every turn you take you will find something to wow about. Unfortunately when we went it was quite busy and there were many people jostling to get a photo with the blue walls. Yes, we did it too! Have a look inside the shop and you will see some beautiful fashion pieces. Maybe not worth buying them but some fabulous designs by a fabulous designer.
review_title: Over the top but oh so beautifl

review_text: A must while in Morocco. Go early though. It gets VERY crowded. Lines can be long.  We went at 9:00 am.  Walked right in.  Many photo opportunities. Gift shop had some beautiful items.  Great place to buy that one of a kind clutch & or necklace.
We went here as part of a tour so it was included. We enjoyed the walk around the area & the displays.
review_title: Included as part of a tour

review_text: These gardens are absolutely beautiful - we loved our visit and took lots of photos. Some fantastic cactii to see and a number of different areas to wander around. One tip - buy tickets in advance to avoid a very very very long queue. There are only a small number of ticket booths so it was a long wait for us. Another tip - there is a taxi rank just outside the exit to the gardens. And finally - go out of busy hours - we got a bit sick of having to wait to see certain parts because of selfie-takers!
review_title: Beautiful gardens - well worth a visit

review_text: We heard about the long lines and this place is very popular, so arrive early, around 9:45am to avoid the very long lines. We really enjoyed the gardens, they are extensive and its a nice 1 hour plus. We had coffee in their coffee shop and their 2 gift shops are worth a look.
review_title: Very worth the wait, a lovely treasure in Marrakech

review_text: Beautiful place but a lot of people even we  went there early. With student card it is possible to get 50% discount from the tickets which was nice.
Go early in the morning or late (after 4-5pm) to avoid queu! Or even better take the tickets from the YSL museum next door (they sell combo tickets for museum+garden)
Our local guide bought the combined tickets for the YSL museum. Gardens and Berber museum. We really enjoyed all three of the attractions.
review_title: So worth seeing, we really enjoyed it

review_text: This is a stunning and beautifully-maintained garden with so many species of cacti that I never knew existed! Taking a stroll around the garden was quite relaxing, despite the many tourists. Loved the blue pavilion and the surrounding pond. The memorial for Yves Saint Lauren and his partner was simple and understated yet elegant. Lovely place to visit.

This garden is definitely worth seeing, especially for the beautiful blue. Within the walls of the garden, there are some toilets, as well as two little shops and a cafe. I ate at the cafe and it was delicious and simple. You can have salads, sandwiches, little samosas and the typical green tea. It is also very reasonably priced for such a touristic place. Be careful of the tourists, this is one of the most popular sites in Marrakech so it’s very hard to find a calm spot.
Best garder in Marrakech, including the YSL museum. Price ok, experience “must to do” For a break, the bar in front of is ok

There are other gardens but these seem to be a Mecca for YSL fans who must have a selfie with no consideration for others. The tickets are confusing. We thought we had bought tickets for gardens and all contained within however there is a museum within that isn’t included so you are sent away like naughty folk. This not to be confused with the YSL museum which we were obviously fooled by. Queue was massive but although nice and pleasant the grounds are not extensive so you’re out quicker than the time in queue to get in.
Go and see this glorious Garden  for yourself.Original ,unusual and historic .Beautiful even in the winter.

We visited the gardens with our 8 year old. We were pleasantly surprised by the gardens. It was quite unique with different varieties of plants from around the world. We definitely liked the gardens. We went to the YSL museum after that.. my husband and son werent interested in that but I liked it. The cafe in the museum was really good. We loved the food there.

Beautiful little garden (you need max 20-30min to walk around and take tons of pics), the colours are amazing. We didn't visit the museums though. We did try the cafe inside, quite pricey for the quality but not too bad. The only thing is that we got there around 1:30pm and we had to queue for an hour to get a ticket to get in!!! Later in the day (when we got out) it was quite faster to get in so I would recommend to get there around 3-3:30pm. It closes at 5:30 during winter so that leaves you plenty of time to wander around. I would say this is one of the must see sites in Marrakech (probably number 2 after the palacio da bahia).
The Jardin is lovely and despite the other visitors, quite peaceful.  Of course, marjorelle blue and bright yellow is everywhere.

The garden’s are lovely but I’m slightly confused as to why this attraction is rated as no.1 in Marrakech on tripadvisor. They were nice to walk around but the queue was very long to get in (we actually came back later in the day when the queue had died down a bit) and very busy once inside which didn’t allow for the tranquil feeling of walking around gardens. It was also very expensive in comparison to other attractions in Marrakech- I don’t really understand why. A lot of the plants have been damaged by people carving their initials and names into them which is a bit of a shame. Overall I’m glad we visited here and wouldn’t say don’t bother but if you’re tight for time or choosing between here and some of the other attractions then don’t follow the no. 1 rating.
review_title: Nice gardens but definitely not the best attraction in Marrakech

review_text: This is a stunning garden to visit. Get there early as the queues were massive. Remember to take your camera as you will want to take lots of pictures
Amazing place to walk around for hours. Students get discount so make sure to use that when buying tickets.
Jardin Marjorelle was a respite from the city. We walked from the medina, and spent a leisurely day exploring the gardens and musuem

The ticket queue was fairly long for the gardens however once inside all was forgotten. The gardens are stunningly beautiful and it was so nice to be in such a tranquil setting only metres from the chaos of the crazy city streets! The colours were amazing and lots of photo ops too.  Thoroughly enjoyed!
We waited for 1 hour in the line just to purchase tickets. I would recommend u buy online 24hrs before ur visit. Its very touristy not much to see. If u dont have alot of time u can skip this
We arrived at the gardens not expecting to have to queue to get in, so be prepared for this. It is worth it though.
Just magnifique colors and lighting. Great for amateur photographers and garden lovers. Even if you’r not it is splendid

My friend recommended I check this out, but I was way more impressed than I thought I'd be. The place was magical. I definitely recommend booking online beforehand so you can avoid the line... and spend a couple of hours visiting the Berber Museum inside, walking the grounds... and just sitting and basking in the beautiful garden. It was a wonderful solo trip and created space for reflection in the midst of an otherwise very busy city.

After queuing for 45 minutes, the gardens were pretty but a little underwhelming. There are lovely palms and it is peaceful to walk around although was very busy. The Berber museum is definitely worth a visit though, the English guides to the exhibits in each room are worth picking up to read.
Too overcrowded and nothing very special in the garden itself. The Berber Museums was a very informative and fascinating place to visit.

This is a pretty garden with different types of planting throughout and a definite oriental feel.  The cafe is lovely and food excellent.  The walk from the old town to the garden is not for the faint hearted!

The gardens are absolutely gorgeous, with a variety of plants from all over the world. However, there were many tourists in this small area, so it wasn’t as relaxing and peaceful as gardens should be.
overrated, tourist trap, not worth cueing for. Dont know what else to say. Sub par. Visit a castle instead
This place is amazingly beautiful, highly recommended to purchase tickets ahead of time as there will be a huge que to get in

We queued 1 hour to get the tickets around 1 pm, so it is best to go early in the morning. The gardens are beautiful and perfectly kept, a must see if you like giant cactus! Beautiful fotos are guaranteed. We had lunch in the café inside the gardens, good choice of food and drinks.
While we were in Marrakech, we visited Majorelle Garden and was a oasis inside the city. Really beautiful and nice to see.

We came here and first walked through the Yves St Laurent museum, which was spectacularly composed, as an experience, not just a catalogue of the man's work. We had tea in the Jardin Majorelle, which was very pleasant, then enjoyed the Berber Museum, where there were traditional clothing displayed as well as jewellery, which were very interesting.
review_title: Wonderful grounds, well kept, plus two museums worth visiting

review_text: Loved the gardens, YSL Museum and the French Quarter. If you like to shop, this area had the fiber shopping

In all honesty you pay to go in, just for the name Yves Saint Laurent and nice cactus, besides that there is nothing here that justifies 70 Dh per person, that is $7. Yes at that little prize this is still very expensive for what you get
review_title: Over prize tourist trap with nioce cactus

review_text: Do worth a visit. Beautiful gardens with colour, form and tranquility. Shame it was so busy, but expected this time of year. Would go first thing in the morning on a repeat visit.

It was a nice change from the hustle and bustle of Medina to spend time in this beautiful garden where Yves Saint Laurent is memorialized. We also visited the YSL museum next door and had a wonderful lunch in their restaurant. Both places offer student discount. If you are traveling a student, be sure to bring a valid student ID.

In general Marrakech is insanely busy. Everyone trying to sell you something, mopeds everywhere... Majorelle Garden is a welcome escape from the madness. We got there around 1pm and thought he queue looked long we were in within 20 minutes. If you like a good insta snap or something for your wall the I would strongly recommend getting there as the doors open to get the perfect shot. Otherwise it’s almost impossible to get a photo without someone in it.

We arrived at the garden around 9 am to beat the rush. It was beautiful, the museum inside was an additional fee. The garden is absolutely beautiful. I would highly recommend you arrive early to avoid the crowd. It is extremely hard to walk through or take pictures once the tourists start arriving later in the morning
YSL garden and a nice stroll. But we found it quite crowded in the afternoon with plenty of people staging Instagram photoshoots.
review_title: Nice looking garden with lots of colors but crowded.

review_text: This garden is a definite must in Marrakech. Not only is the history fascinating but the variety of plants and trees is astounding. The garden is well-maintained and offers a cornucopia of flora delights.  The color scheme of the painted large jars, walkways and walls is beautiful, especially the use of indigo.  Don’t miss the Yves Saint Laurent museum next door.

I loved it. Everything was beautiful! Except the fact that we waited at the entrance for like 40 mins..and there was way too much people inside. But the garden is very beautiful and one of the things that you need to visit when you come to Marrakesh

Obviously, December isn't the best time to see these gardens but they were still very attractive.  The queue was long - about half an hour and it didn't take much longer to walk round them.  Also very very busy.  So worth a journey (we hopped off the city bus to see them) but it isn't Kew Gardens.
review_title: Lovely gardens.  Took as long to queue as to walk round.

review_text: we did some great photos here and loved the beauty of this place. had lunch in the walled garden which as also great.
review_title: amazing garden of cactus and museum

review_text: Beautiful gardens. Felt very tranquil after the hustle and bustle of Marrakech.  Fab place for photos as stunning to look at.
Its a garden in the new city of marrakech nice place with friends or family They do restaurant as well
Interesting place to visit while in Marrakesh. The YSL museum is very nice, worth visiting on one of the days

The garden was a lot smaller than expected and the queue to buy the tickets and to get in was just crazy long. It was filled with people inside and it was really difficult to get a nice photo of yourself without any interruption. It was nice exploring the garden but I would probably give this a miss if you do not have too much time in Marrakesh.

We are not into art culture at all but thought we'd have a little look. Very pretty gardens, 70MAD entry price (£5.50ish) each. I think it's a bit more if you want to see the museum as well. Nice way to spend an hour. As we went in December it wasn't too busy but I can imagine in peak times it would be a bit much.

We visited in the afternoon and purchased tickets which included a visit to the Jardin Majorelle, the Berber Museum and the YSL Museum. The garden is stunning and it is a lot larger than I thought it would be. Loved the colours, the mix of plants and the beautifully designed architecture. Jardin Majorelle is  a must-do when visiting Marrakech.
review_title: A must  do when visiting Marrakech

review_text: I was excited to visit as had seen the gorgeous pictures online and loved the colours. However. We arrived at peak time, queued for 30 minutes to get in (not bad) and were given French maps despite being English. We then spent the same amount of time inside (~30 mins) as it was a relatively small garden with not much except repetitive plants to look at. It was interesting for photo opportunities but if you want one of the iconic blue buildings you will have a hard time as far too many trees and people are in the way. It was good for a time filler but not worth the 70dh per person in my opinion. I would have been happier to pay 30-50dh. If you don't have much time in Marrakesh then don't worry too much if you miss this because there are better attractions to visit and there isn't much else in the area.
review_title: Lovely but not much to see

review_text: Be aware that there is a long queue to buy ticket if you arrive after 9am as this place is very popular for tourists. Inside the garden you feel you are in paradise or at least is a very tropical green country rather than dry Morocco. The building and colour everywhere is Mojarrlle Blue which is very eye catching and interesting, highly recommend a visit. You can also find YSL’s memorial here as when he died in 2008 his ashes brought to this garden and blown around the garden as it was his Will.
review_title: Beautiful garden and blue colour everywhere

review_text: Very lovely but the place was over-run with instagrammers seeking their next best shot. Lovely garden. Cool and inviting. Sadly many of the bamboo stalks and cactus leaves have been engraved with the names and symbols of prior visitors. The cafe was delightful and offered a great menu. Excellent attraction to visit with elderly tourists or those with physical limitations. Well paved and handicap accessible.  Guards are present to ensure no damage. I really think they should limit entrance to the garden. It defeats the whole purpose when there are too many present. In a couple of situations I gave up trying to get in close because there were to many people posing and waiting for their turn to pose....

Yes, it was YSL’s home but it just shows the demand for excellent he had that’s reflected in the garden. The only down side is the amount of tourist there for selfies. It’s a perfect place to go in with a cup of coffee and a good book, hidden on a bench in one of the beautiful trees they’ve planted. Suggest to go there early - no joke. To avoid the crowd, so you get some good pictures and some quiet time. The YSL museum is worth a visit. It opens up to where the maestro gets his inspiration from, the colouring and pattern, the museum of his collection is rather emotional but absolutely beautiful. I’m personally not a fan but walked away with much respect for the designer.

Absolutely beautiful garden.  Immaculately kept - vast array of cacti and other exotic plants.  The colours captivating - I must have taken over 100 photos. It’s quite a distance from main square but there are taxis and carriages for hire outside.

It's really good if you enjoy the history and design of the famous fashion giant. Many photogenic places with sharp colour contrasts. Like many of the Morocco places the best time to visit is near midday or before sunset to get the colours going. Trade off is the place is packed with tourists. Expect lots of cactus and lots of tourists. Dun miss the YSL museum next to it.
Nice place to spend 1-2 hours in Marrakech.  Get out of the sun and away from the honking.  The garden is very nice.
.... place. Long qeues to get in and inside mir people than trees. For sure a nice place but not half as pleasant as ANiMA garden

Loved the majorelle blue which pops up throughout the garden. A simple oasis of peace in the city. Planted with cacti and succulents from the world's desert places. The YSL museum is simple but very enjoyable featuring some the Saint Laurant's best creations.
If you only haves long weekend  and you have to choose, make sure you visit this place. It is stunning.
This is a good garden visit with french twist to it. Amazing plants to see. Well maintained. Informative.

Superb visit to the gardens and the YSL museum. Awe inspiring collection of clothes on display and truly beautiful gardens to wander around -not to be missed. Lots of excellent opportunities for photos. A lovely cafe also in the gardens which I would recommend. Tip - the combination ticket is available from the museum and the queue is shorter so walk down to the museum at the end of the road!

It is worthy of a visit. Located just outside the Medina (take a taxi to go), they have arranged a separate cashier for family with children. Wandering around the Jardin can clear your mind and spirit. Not to be missed.
Busy but with tranquil corners - a must-see in Marrakech and lovely colours and strangely a great cactus display
Although the garden is not too big, it makes up with it's stunning design and brilliant blue painted features. The Berber museum in the garden is also worth a look as it isn't too expensive.

I was disappointed. Very overrated attraction. It is a very small garden. The berber museum is also small. One super expensive cafe. Two super expensive shops. The YSL museum comprise one room with clothes and that's it... NOTE: you cannot make picture of the iconic blue building in the gardens as there are lot of threes in front of it (see the pictures below)

The Jardin Majorelle is well worth a visit, but get a 3 for 1 pass at the YSL museum. it is only 20 dirham more and you get access to the YSL museum and the Berber Museum (inside the Jadin) and don't have to que with the groups. The Jardin is cool, peaceful and calm and some very interesting succulent species.

Really enjoyed the experience and were fast tracked at the entrance. There’s not much else to do. Max time 1 hour if that. annoying thing was that toilet staff were begging for tips. There’s plenty of Pics reviewing the same so no point really. Come out of this place, and turn right and cross the road to no33 shop(boutique). They sell pure Argan oil (the real stuff!)
We visited late afternoon. It wasn’t too busy and the light was beautiful for photos! Highly recommended.
Amazing garden. Worth the taxi out of the Medina. Nice painting and drawings from YSL too.Marrakesh true colours in a quite and pieceful version.

You have to go here. Be there early, buy a combi ticket for garden, berber museum and YSL house. It is worth it.  It is truly is exciting to walk around. Not so much for the fame of YSL. Most certainly for the good taste in which the garden was made.

So many people it was difficult to get around and impossible to take photos without people in them. It seems to be a destination hotspot for certain tourists to spend a very long time in strategic viewpoints taking endless photos of themselves, which whilst amusing, is also frustrating. We went to Anima Gardens in the morning on their curtesy shuttle bus and it was much more enjoyable and, you get to see a glimpse of life outside the city en route.
I'm glad we went early in the morning because having to queue for such an ordinary Garden would be very frustrating
Brief visit, 45mins before closing time. Wish we'd had time to see the Berber museum... Plants, layout and blue painted buildings were superb. Unique!

We went to the Jardin Majorelle as a last minute morning activity prior to leaving.  It was well worth it.  The gardens were within easy walking distance of our hotel (Le Caspien).  The gardens a well maintained and beautiful, especially with the deep blue walls and trim.  The best part was the Berber Museum, a stunning small museum with some exquisite textiles and jewelry.  There is a room with a night sky illusion with a semi-circle of costumes busts.  Very tasteful.  We paid for the package but ran out of time to see the Fondation Yves-St. Laurent Building which is actually adjacent (not in) the gardens.  It was surprisingly crowded, so go early.
review_title: Don't miss the Berber Museum on the grounds.

review_text: Got there early and it was not very busy, enjoyed a peaceful visit and a good coffee and took tons of photos.
It is a wonderful garden with exotic plants from allover the world , I just loved it specially with its restaurant and delicious breakfast
It's ok but I wouldn't say queuing to visit was worth it. Theres plants inside but not much else.  Youd probably queue longer than youd spend inside
This is a peaceful beautiful place but if you have been to any botanical gardens any where else in the world this really doesn't compare.  Its the same cactus plants over and over again.

The garden looks nice, still having the ancient vibe. However, the garden is way too crowdy all walking one way and targeting their perfect picture or selfie. Therefore you have more eye for the people around you than the wonderful garden. Also, the cafe is more expensive than a regular bar in NYC.

The place is a refreshing oasis in Marrakech. Lines to get tickets are long but we were with a tour guide so he bought the tickets for us and we did not have to wait. It gets crazy inside with so many tourists, so it is difficult to get good pictures. Entrance fee is 7 euros but does not include the museum. Definitely worth a visit

We thoroughly enjoyed the gardens, which has so many varieties of plants and lovely statues. There were benches well placed to sit and see the beauty. The museum is a wonderful view of Yves Saint Laurent 's impact on the fashion world. they have a changing variety of exhibits also.
review_title: Beutiful Garden and Museum in theHeart of the City

review_text: It was about £15 to get in. There was an awful lot of Cacti and Bamboo plants, but I didn't notice much else. Could have been the time of year? To my mind not worth anything like £15.
review_title: Supposedly one of better gardens in Marrakesh

review_text: Enjoyed every bit of it. Beautiful garden with various types of trees and cactus. Small cafe inside and soothing for eyes

The gardens are well maintained, trees, cacti, impressively tall bamboo, water features and buildings.  In its day this must have been some retreat for Yves Saint Laurent. Best to see in combination with the adjacent YSL museum. There is strange featureless memorial.  For some strange reason, they don't allow you to take pictures in the Berber exhibition. What is the point please? And of course, a souvenir shop if you are that way inclined.  There is also a cafe in the park with a full menu so you can prolong the pleasant experience.
Really beautiful, unforgettably picturesque park, you see straight away that the Masters tried their best there.
While nice and photogenic, gardens are rather small (especially with the number of tourists visiting) and therefore a bit underwhelming. 2 hours is a maximum time to spend there.

Visited with children and had a wonderful time indeed. The gardens are very well kept and attended. The colours, scents, sights and overall feel make you want to re visit. The cafe serves wonderful food and drinks in a prompt fashion. I was not interested in the museum or the store so I have no comments on that. I would suggest a visit to  anyone with some free time in Marrakesh, especially if you are with children that need to let out some steam.
review_title: Beautiful and perfect for some time off the streets

review_text: Despite of the long queues and hundreds of visitors, this place is a real pearl in the noisy and polluted through traffics Marrakesh. The garden is so variable and diverse with all different vegetation from all over the world. The colour blue looks stunning in the sunshine.
Went mid december.. was not that busy and it was easy to get in. the gardens themselves are OK but im not quite sure its worth a visit.
What a beautiful place! The plants in the garden are exiting and huge. It’s a lovely garden to stroll around. And the colour blue...WOW!
Just amazing! Loterally one of the best places in the world. I wish I could go back there every year :)

we went to the gardens and the Berber museum, which was very informative. The gardens are well worth spending a couple of hours in, they are very relaxing and beautiful. The cafe (not the YSL one) is reasonably priced and in a lovely courtyard with an indoor space as well.
The garden was beautiful and unusual but nothing extraordinary, if had choice I wouldn’t go there again. There were so many people which made it absolutely impossible to take photos.

This garden is beyond beautiful! Worth a visit so you can enjoy the Majorelle blue! It’s something to behold the many species of cactus they have and absolutely a great stroll! I thought I would spend less than an hour, but two hours went quickly as you end up wanting to take pictures at every corner and for every step you take! It’s both relaxing, romantic, adventurous and the garden just simply makes you happy! And the price is nothing compared to the experience! Highly highly recommended!!
review_title: Blue could be your new favorite color!

review_text: We arrived at 8:00 and had the gardens all to ourselves. There are plenty of great opportunities to take pictures with the colorful backdrops before having a hot chocolate or tea at the cafe.
Really nice and beautiful place! I would advise to go early since it was very busy around 2pm. This is for sure a must visit.

Beautiful gardens and a MUST place to visit whilst in Marrakech. Go early as entry queues build up fast and you can wait  over an hour to gain entry after noon. Cacti garden is very impressive but he other garden is a dream. Lovely water features. Surprisingly few fragrances.

Pictures cannot do justice to this absolutely gorgeous garden. The moment you step into this garden, you are surrounded by vivid colors, pretty flora, and beautifully designed architecture. Jardin Majorelle is absolutely a must-see in Marrakesh.
The building are so gorgeous that you forget there are lovely plants all around you.  Great spot for selfies and vivid abstracts.  Would love to go back.
Beautiful colors, lovely activity for a morning, before the sun gets too hot. Also right next is the YSL museum, worth a visit.

we have visited this Garden in Nov 2019, and were impressed. The Majorelle Blue is something which can not be "copied", the Garden has been described houndred of times, so I wlll not write something unique, but once I want to stress : take time visiting this relatively small establishment . Take min 1,5 hours, to walk around, to sit down , lookin at the plants, people and just rest . The rest is not important :)
review_title: A must see Garden in Marrakesh

review_text: Do not miss, it’s a gorgeous garden!!! I’ve seen it both and summer and winter and enjoyed it on both occasions
it was so beautiful, peaceful, away from the city crowds, so many different cactuses, plants and you can hear birds tweeting.
From displaying the berber culture, to landscaping, to design, this museum has it all. Go early to avoid crowds, but go!

If you interested in Fashion, and how new styles are created and finally you perhaps buy in a department store this was Yves Saint Laurent. But not only that, he was an artist of beauty. Jardin Majorelle was his creative place.

This place has an amazing collection of plants from all over the world, beautifully displayed in the open air.  The Berber Museum which is inside the garden, but with separate admission, is also fascinating.  Highly recommended for a visit to Marrakech.
review_title: Lovely and very interesting if you are botanically inclined!

review_text: The garden is absolutely gorgeous. We went there around 3:30 pm and there was no line to get in and there was the right amount of people. If you are a student, there is a 50% discount which was not advertised online, so make sure to bring your student pass and ask for it. I think it's applicable for students from every country, as I have an American student ID and they accepted it with no problem.
review_title: Beautiful garden - bring your student pass

review_text: The garden is a pleasant oasis in the city, but is not large or spectacular compared to many other gardens around the world. It can also get very busy which diminishes the experience, so try to go early or whenever it’s least popular. The little museum (costs extra) is worth a look if you do visit.
If you run out of things to see or do then come here. It's full of cacti and bamboo. Your better off going to almost any other place.
Stylish and tranquil. Lovely gardens restored thanks to Yves Saint Laurent and Pierre Bergere. Recommended for 1-2 hours out of the Médina.
Very popular garden and consequently a rather long line to get in.  After about 30 minutes we were in and able to enjoy the beauty of these gardens.
It's definitely not worth the price as it is very small and packed with people. The most overrated sight in Marrakech so far.
review_title: crowded, overpriced place paired with mediocre gardening

review_text: Small, not well looked after, mostly Cactus garden. Could have been a lot better. Ticket price makes it not worth it for a family of 4.

The place to admire the beautiful plants and lovely collection of cacti in every shape. The place winds around and everywhere there is something beautiful to admire and photo shots. Maximum time is about 2 hours and cost is worth it if you love nature

Beautiful garden, not massive but can easily spend about 30-60 minutes there. It is about 15 minute drive on a tuk tuk from the main square, and we bargained the price down to 30 dirham. Yves Saint Laurent's garden is just next door, but you've got to pay separately for both of them (about 70 dirham per person as far as I remember).

An enchanting escape from the bustle of Marrakech, only a moderate walk away from the souls.  The garden is named after the French artist Jacques Majorelle who settled in Marrakech in the early 1920s.  For the rest of life his passion was to collect rare plants and trees from all over the world including cacti, palm trees, jasmine, willow and ferns.  The vast collection of cacti in all shape and sizes is exceptional.  There are beautiful views at every turn of the path that winds around every part of the garden.  Suggest arrive early to avoid the crowds and the queue for tickets.
review_title: Enchanting escape from the bustle of Marrakesh

review_text: For me, paying 10 euros to visit a garden smaller than my parking lot it's just not worthy. I was excited to go, but the only thing to see there is a blue house from the outside, many cactus and a store ridiculos expensive that you can't take photos. And they call themselves a notprofit organization - which I don't get it.
review_title: 5 minutes walk in a garden that costs 10 euros

review_text: These Yves St Laurent gardens in Marrakech is a must see attraction for anyone visiting Morocco. A combined ticket is the best value which incorporates the Majorelle gardens , the Berber museum and the YSL Gallery. All three were excellent and very popular with tourists. So if you plan to visit, get there early to avoid the crowds. The cafe in the gardens was also very good and reasonably priced.
Quite difficult to find, but worth the search!  Once there, these gardens are an amazing oasis in the city. Go easy, or avoid the crowds.

Such a wonderful place to visit. Beautifully laid out with some amazing specimen plants. The Citrus garden was extraordinary and the cactus are a delight. Cool and serene under the tall bamboo, we found this a real Oasis and will return.

The gardens are stunning. We spend a few hours wandering around taking in all the many plants and trees they have. The gardens are incredibly peaceful considering they are surrounded by busy roads. The gardens are full of colour. I would also recommend while you;re there buying a combined ticket and visiting the Berber museum.
review_title: A moment of peace in a busy city

review_text: I have been to Marrakesh for a week in November. I had such a great time there , I visited such beautiful places , and Jardin du Majorelle was one of them... I booked it like 2 days after arriving to Marrakesh , and then I paid around 25 euros to go there. the environment is magical... I've never been to a place like this... the colours , the cactus , the royal blue , the tiles , the flowers , I was really amazed by it all! I highly recommend this place if you go to Morrocco ! I will be back for sure.
We only visited the gardens due to limited time. It is a nice place, well preserved, a spot of nature in the noisy Marrakesh. However, I was expecting much more spectacular views.
I was blown away by the beauty of this place. It was definitely one of the highlights of my trip to Marrakech. The gardens are beautiful with enormous cacti.

I was truly enchanted, and loved every bit of my circuit, but the burly security men won't let you stray far from the beaten track. The garden has a limited number of species; lots of cactus and bamboo, lots of blue paint,  and very few flowering plants. There are ponds and watercourses everywhere. It has nothing to do with nature, of course... and everything to do with art... but it is an unforgettable experience.
Took us 25 minutes to walk to the gardens and we found them very relaxing and peaceful.  Does not take long to walk round - we did not go round the museum

When and if you visit Marrakesh make sure you set aside a few hours to spend time in this magnificent park. It is such a beautiful garden with a number of different themes. A peaceful place to sit and relax and enjoy the wonder of the beauty surround you. It is a must to see.
review_title: Beautiful Park - Great for your soul.

review_text: Superb experience! Garden is truly magnificent with all those plants, cactuses🌵 and ambiance. We arrived early morning and were pretty lucky as there were not many tourists. Unfortunately we missed YSL museum as no one really explained where is it located, even though we paid for it. We thought that it’s supposed to be inside the jardin, only the next day we realized that it’s in separate building, just before the gardens. However the Jardin de Majorelle is a must to see in marrakech!!
I did the best pic ever, so colorful and lovely,Definitely worth the price for the ticket. Highly recommended to visit.

We were so looking forward to visit this place in Marakesh, it was so beautiful, peaceful, away from the city crowds, so many different cactuses, plants and you can hear birds tweeting. Just loved it. Made some amazing pictures, I would definitely recommend this place to visit,  the best time for pictures is in the afternoon I would say .5 🌟

A great lovely garden of French influence. This garden is in new part of the town.  This garden also has Berber museum and is next to YSL fashion museum. Buy a combo ticket to visit both Garden and museum. Buildings are of cobalt blue color. It has lot of unique bird species.
we visited in november and it was drizzling but the garden is beautiful.  I'd definitely consider visiting again
Amazing, relaxing place. Really good place to relax and enjoy the heat in a shadow. Suitable for all ages.

This place is really a must do on a trip to Marrakesh, it has the colours the gardens and all the magic of the city. everything is really in good care and condition and photos will be worthy. there will be people everywhere taking instagram photos, be patient and choose goods angles to avoid photo spoilers.

What really wowed me about this beautifully sculpted garden are the larger than life cactuses and other succulents and desert plants that are so outstandingly huge, they make me feel like I'm an extra in the film set of a science fiction movie. Go as early as you can, preferably right when it opens. If you get there late, the crowds swell and you'll have to queue up just to get photos, especially at the particularly Instagrammable spots. I was there in December, the low season, and the place was thronging with people at about 11 plus.
review_title: The garden of monster exotic plants

review_text: This garden is beautiful and full of bright colors in a very orange/red city. The pops of blue and green and eye catching. I think it is worth a visit for something to do and to get out of the busy main city area. It is right next to the YSL museum so you can add that to the list and do both. Their is also cute shopping on the same street along with food and drinks.

The gardens are beautiful although very overcrowded. Highly recommend visiting early in the day as the queues can be long. One of the best in Marrakech. Only 70dh per person but a little more if you’d also like to visit the museums etc.
worth it but too many people. Its cost 70 dhs. to enter. When your are in Marrakesh, then is this place you have to see.
We did this garden lus week and was amazing, we walk from our Riad and it take about ane hour to get there but we relacxed

We booked a taxi for the day so thought we may as well visit the gardens but were pleasantly surprised as to their size and nature. Much of it is a cactus garden with plants from all continents set amongst water features and it is beautifully laid out, so relaxing to walk round. At MAD 70 (£6 per adult) you may as well pop in if it's on your route as it is stunning and for the all the fashionista's there is now a Yves St Laurant museum next door (seperate entry fee). There is a seperate entry fee for the Berber museum on site but it costs nothing to browse the YSL shop to gasp at the prices. The cafe is always busy.
review_title: Much more than expected - go by carriage or taxi

review_text: We went there for a visit for around 2 hours.  The cactus are similiar everywhere.  There are several blue + yellow walls that you can take nice pictures.
review_title: Worth a visit if you have time

review_text: I really didn’t get the point of this if your expecting natural beauty and amazing plants it didn’t live up to my expectations. It’s a man made garden with tall trees and a blue house inside. That’s all. We did however get a lot of nice pictures.

Me and my friend we were in garden marojel as  must see in Marrakech. Actually we were dispointed to go there. So bussy and I think it so expensive for its values and things to see there. We prefered the secret garden in the old city. Instead of going to majorell garden go and pleasure your eyes in secret garden
We came here around 4pm, wasn't so many people. It was a nice place to visit. The ticket is pretty expensive tough. There are many spots for instagramers, but you have to wait.
It's amazing garden Majorelle and Yves Saint Laurent the first thing i recommend if you want to visit both of them start with a museum so you will avoid to wait..
The colours, the composition, architecture and atmosphere of this place are second to none. There are many beautiful gardens in the world but this one is on my top five list of favourite gardens.

The Jardin Majorelle is situated just a few roads north of the old town of Marrakesh. It is a beautifully peaceful area, full of colour and light. The Berber museum enclosed within the gardens is small but wonderfully presented. Well worth a visit.

Although the lines are long on the weekend - this garden is worth standing in any line.  Just beautiful, magnificent, the variety of plants, water features and all carefully well groomed.  The Cafe is delightful after you've toured the grounds.
review_title: A magnificent oasis in magical Marrakech!

review_text: I been here with friends is busy garden. I find it expencive to visited becouse it's not that very sepecil to pay that.

If you like to wait in the sun for more than 1 hour, lovely place. If you like to pay too much for a combined ticket to see almost nothing, perfect. If you love to see people on instagram trying to get the perfect picture, marvellous. If you like to have a quiet day in a park/garden with not too many people, avoid this place. It is nice to see the garden if you are into botanics, even just for the bright colours of cobalt blue and sunny yellow it would be perfect. But not for the price they are charging and not for anything else you'll find there.
review_title: Tourism at its finest....Great place for instagram lovers

review_text: Step into a beautiful oasis in homage to Marojelle and Yves Saint Laurent. Fascinating succulents and beautiful water features and amazing sky high bamboo. A must visit while in Marrakesh.
The garden has been extended since my previous visit. The cafe serves really nice food and drinks, also more wc facilities have been developed

Had a lovely couple of hours here with our two children (9 & 10 years). The variety of cacti was fascinating so kept the children engaged by talking about them. Gardens were beautifully kept. Calm and peaceful to walk around (but probably not a place for children to run around). Really worth a visit. As a family with children, you don't have to join the main queue, as there is a shorter queue near the disabled entrance for families. Children are also free with a paying adult. We just visited the gardens but there are also museums on the site that you can purchase a combination ticket for if you wish to stay more than a couple of hours. A cafe and toilets are also available on site.

The Jardins seemed even more beautiful than on my last visit BUT - I'd arrived at about 10 a.m. and it was the haven of calm I remembered but by 10.30 there were three parties of local school children ( beautifully behaved but a lot of them) and a large group of Chinese tourists - less well-behaved. If I'd gone when it opened, at least I'd have had an hour of peace. I did the Berber museum this time and found it worth the money.

Jardin Majorelle visit was on the last day of our tour .. and it was good opportunity to relax in the garden spending 2 - 3 hours after 10 days on the roads You will always remember this garden with elegant view and perfect landscaping

Despite the crowds, there was something magical about these gardens. The water features and vibrant colours, succulents and cacti, flowers and palms, all create an oasis in the busy city.   Would have loved to sit peacefully with a good book, but with so many people visiting it was hard to find a moment of quiet.
Lovely garden using interesting colours to offset the planting. Some interesting reflections in the water features.
review_title: Oasis of calm in manic Marrakesh

review_text: We arrived by taxi at 12:00 and it was very crowded (in low season period). We had to wait to buy the ticket (70 MAD) around half an hour. Totally worth it though! Very calm and peaceful place full of cactus, Palm trees, lakes and colours. Credit Cards accepted. No student ticket.
review_title: Try to Go Early in The Morning

review_text: A must & very pretty. Spent about 45 mins here. Museum is extra. great plant & cacti selection. You can’t take photos in the shop.
It' over 10€/p.P without the Musee of Yves Laurant. But besides a lot of Tourists which make hundreds of selfies you'll also get to see actual plants ;)
review_title: Lots of Tourists, but also a little Oasis in Marakech

review_text: We came to visit Jardin Majorelle after reading some fabulous reviews and we weren’t disappointed!! It is a lovely place to visit, the different cacti and plants, water features and wildlife are fantastic, coupled with the brightly painted buildings and planters makes for some fantastic photos. I would advise getting there early, we arrived around 9.30am and there were a few people in the queue to get in but when we were leaving around 11am the queue to get in was quite long. There is a gift shop and bookstore within the Jardin along with a cafe and facilities. The gift shop was quite pricey but the items for sale are beautiful. I would definitely recommend a visit!!
Much bigger than I expected as there was a slightly hidden gateway into a second equally large area. Absolutely beautiful and 100% worth the queue.

The garden is beautiful but it is one of the touristic catches. So be warned: long queues for ticketing and very crowded inside. Best to buy your tickets online or take e combi ticket for the museum, so you don't have to queue for the garden.

Great selection of desert plants and trees. It's a great experience just to walk around if you are a plant person. The house was also very cute. Don't miss the museum store! They sell Laurent designed good quality products and the proceeds go to charity.

What a great garden it is really really refreshingly clean, everywhere you see is relaxing to the eye👍🏼👍🏼👍🏼 the amenities for disabled people is 5⭐️ i couldnt express how thankful i was with staff who help us with mum (in wheelchair). Will defo come back but this time with my family.
Beautiful garden in the middle of the chaos of Marrakech. there is a bit of a wait to get tickets for entry.
review_title: Tranquility in the middle of chaos.

review_text: The word: Riyad in arabic means gardens and it is often quoted in association with heaven (Jennah). The impression is they've had this in mind when they put the Jardin Majorelle together, because the place lives-up to the hype, as a slice of heaven in the middle of the city. There is a dominance of colours that you will pleasantly detect when you walk around, touring the Majorelle: There is almost as much Blue as the Green, with tasteful delights of yellow and rose/pink. The water bursting from the fountains along with the birds chirping is nature's symphony and a reminder of what a slice of heaven might look...and sound like!
review_title: From Riyad to Jennah ... and back - The amazing Jardin Majorelle in Marrakech!

review_text: Depending on where you are from the gardens will either blow you away or leave you wondering why it is such an attraction.
Marrakech has great gardens. I love Jardin Majorelle for it's colours. If you are limited on time, then I say to skip it, but if you like gardens then this is special.
Beautiful gardens and interesting succulents.  Also small museum of Moroccan art and fashion art from YSL.
Beautiful place to visit. Vibrant colors and the plants and architecture were great. Don't need to spend much time there though, take a few pics, admire the plants, and you're done.
Superb garden with extensive collection of well displayed cactus. The Berber Museum was a great bonus. Expect crowds, but the site can handle it.
review_title: Cacti from all over the world

review_text: I was soooo surprised of such a wild forest of palm trees and bamboo and cactus in such small place. Perfection! So many diversity of plants and cactus.
