A little to crowded but worth for a visit.  I thought that Marrakech is more desert but it has so much palm trees. I was really surprised
review_title: A pice of a wild forest. Crowded but nice to see it

review_text: Wooww what a beautiful place..! Couldn’t stop taking pictures.. totally enjoyed the time we spent time in Jardin Majorelle .. if you visiting Marrakech one of the place to visit..
Lovely Moroccan garden cool and tranquil. Not crowded during our visit Such a shame some hooligans insis on carving their names on the cactus plants .
I loved this place so much, Just avoid touristic season. We enjoyed visiting this magical place with all different colors
Anyone interested in the Berber culture, Yves St Laurent, Majorelle, should visit these gardens when in Marrakech!
review_title: Lovely gardens surrounded by the Majorelle blue!

review_text: we loved the colours and all the different settings. Take plenty of time to walk around and have a tea in the beautiful little cafe

The place is amazing! We visited the place late in the evening, an hour before its closing. The garden is totally amazing, a place of calmness in a city full of life! Whoever visits the place should definitely visit the Berbers' museum, which is small but shows the history of Berber People. The only negative is the price of the ticket (70 dirhams for the garden or 100 dirhams for the garden and the museum).

It's beautiful alright, but jammed with every western tourist in town!  And of course the YSL connection means there are fancy gift shops with beautiful but outrageously expensive items for sale.  And you stand in line to get in unless you have a private guide to get you in. It's one of those "you gotta do it once" like the changing of the guard at Buckingham Palace.
review_title: A standard tourist stop in Marrakesh

review_text: Beautiful garden with plants from all over the world. Well worth a visit for the price. About a 10min queue to get in. Restaurant was also very nice.

Took a tour of the facility.  Very nice, but I sense that when people to her Morocco they might be interested in sites that are a bit more unique to the region.  In any event, who would have ever guessed that YSL had a studio in Marrakesh

Many of the plants are covered with grafitti, the gardens are small, and the price is ridiculously over-crowded. Even strolling slowly you can see everything including the gift shop in 15-20 minutes and you will wait in line longer than that, depending on the time of day. Many of the succulents are unique is size and detail but compared with other gardens, this is a real disappoint.

The garden is very nice but I would think twice before paying as much again. Long queues unless you get there early and quite crowded inside. It’s amazing how many people will take their sweet time to get their ‘perfect shot/selfie’ in the ‘beauty spots’, knowing that other people are standing there waiting. This place is OK if you have plenty of time to fill in Marrakech and have nothing else you want to do. Tip - if you get there and the line is really long and you were going to get the combined ticket for the gardens, the Yvette St Laurent exhibition and the Berber museum, keep walking past the garden queue to the entrance to the YSL exhibit about 100 yds further down on the same side. The line will probably be much shorter and the ticket office is the same.
Amazing garden,lots of cactuses and luxuriant plants, a true oasis where you can relax after busy days in Medina
The experience was really great. Not sure if it’s everyone’s cup of tea but i appreciate more of the landscape and vibrant colours!

Lovely garden,  visited in a group of 8 people. Lovely collection of Flora and fauna. Loved the place. Their were some annoying tourists who were taking photos of children, had to report to security about it. Good day out, we didn't find much food variety.

We visited the park after several people and the lonely planet had recommended it. We were however disappointed, especially given the high price (70 dirham pP). It’s a nice park with interesting plants, but very small and only takes about 20-30 min to see it all. Also the Yves Saint lorent “memorial" isn’t much worth seeing (a plane stone column in the middle of the park). Not much to see here except for the beautiful blue Art Deco building which houses the Berber museum. When we visited the park, the YSL museums as well as the Berber museum were unfortunately closed. However, they would have cost an additional entry of 110 dirham which we considered to be very expensive in comparison with other museums and sights in Morocco.
review_title: Nice park, but overrated and expensive

review_text: A beautiful place with plants trees and birds!! an oasis that you must visit and admire the amazing blue of Marrakech.Very clean, with excellent bamboo and cactus.
This was good, spent a relaxing hour walking around it. Better to go early in the morning as big queue’s are later.

Set in a fairly downbeat area of Marrakesh the gardens are a beautiful oasis of towering bamboos cacti and plants imported from all around the world and all beautifully kept and presented. The Gardens plus Berber museum and YSL museum combined ticket was 180Dhr and well worth it. Allow 2-4 hours to complete the above. After the hustle and hassle of the souls this was a much needed retreat

The queue to get in was in 2 parts... 1 against the wall the other next to the kerb. We went against the wall and the other..... yes you guessed it went twice the speed. 50 minutes to get in for NO perceptibal reason. It was about 12 noon so maybe avoid then!! Gardens are bamboo and cactus orientated... they are what they are!! House art deco. Unfortunately the Berber mueseum was clased as it is a Wednesday??? WTF! Do not know if it was just today but alot of 'exotic' dressed people about.... slightly bizare BUT entertaining never the less!!
Spend a calm & quiet few hours walking around a wonderfully mature garden. Avoid the queuesto get in if possible.
review_title: Beautiful calm garden in a "mad" city

review_text: The garden is beautiful. Impressive. But my oh my the volume of people pouring thru detracts from experience. Feels worse than an amusement park. Try to go when crowds and lines are at tolerable level. Good luck.

A beautiful garden to retreat to from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. Majorelle blue is a stunning colour. It’s worth buying a combined ticket to the Berber and YSL museums. Arrive by 9.30am to avoid the queues.

The place is amazing, beautiful garden. The only thing that was disappointing was the service. We arrived there at 5:15 pm (the garden closes at 6 pm - Google says at 6:30 pm) and when we went to the cashier to get the tickets, the woman there was really rude! She told us that actually we will have 30 minutes to visit the garden and if we did want to buy the tickets that was fine, but we should do this without think because she wanted to close the cashier and go home soon. We were chocked! After that she was Benin really impatient while we separated the money to pay the ticket. Really disrespectful... Again, the place was amazing, however, the service was terrible.

Going to the museum was a real treat.  I especially enjoyed the cactus gardens. There are many rare artifacts in ther museum. So nice that Yves and Peter preserved this part of the heritage and history and shared it with the public.
I have good experince in this place Please try to travel here and you will be happy with everything Highly recommend.

The best time to see this beautiful garden is before the crowds come - we were at the garden as soon as it opened in the morning(despite the fact that it was a cold, raining day) and had a wonderful time wandering around the many paths visiting the 'rooms' and were just finishing at 10am when the hordes of tourist buses started rolling in. Across the road from the garden is a lovely coffee shop/ cafe that does great coffee. word of warning - during rain the paths get very slippery.
review_title: Stunning garden - get there before the tour buses

review_text: Lovely gardens to visit. Would recommend anyone to visit them, just don't get over charged by the taxis outside on your way back to the city.
If you are going in Marrakech don’t skip visiting the Jardin Majorelle and Ysl Museum . I highly recommend .
The gardens are amazing. So beautiful and relaxing. I loved the museum as well but the gardens are exquisite.
Nothing prepares you for the sheer beauty of this wonderful garden in the centre of Marrakech It is obvious that it meant a huge amount to YSL Go as early as you can as it does get very crowded

There " 7500 a day!! And it’s only a small city garden!! BUT a must for any lovers of Art Nouvaux  also the Cactus garden is outstanding and so Unusal ? Best time to avoid the queues is to get there at about 5.30 pm when the bulk of the tourists have left for the main square and although the museum is closed the garden is bearable with out the hoards even if you only have 30 plus minutes to enjoy a walks round ? The card shop is worth a visit as well as to gloat in the main shop but deep pockets are required for a visit here but beautifully laid out in true french sheik  style!!
review_title: Beware of the huge crowds in this wonderful garden

review_text: I don’t know if my expectations were too high but I’ve seen way better gardens. Yes it is nice to visit... but I didn’t find it anything especial. And considering is 7€ to visit, for what it is, I think is too much.
A must see in Marrakech, the garden and house are amazing! We enjoyed strolling through the gardens.
Nice quite romantic and beautiful design and plants. Access was quick and smooth. It’s a nice place to take your beloved one for a romantic walk

We had a great experience in the beautiful garden. The colors and the interior design does it good. YSL really had touch for the details. Apart from that the garden was very clean and well organized. That’s definitely a place to spend few hours when visiting Marrakech.
Lovely gardens in center of Marrakech . Bit of a queue to get in and discriminatory prices for tourists (!) ie more expensive if you are non-Moroccan, but pleasant place altogether.
Not sure if you can pre-book but long queues to get in.  It was worth it once inside though, even though it was quite crowded.  Wonderful vistas through the plants which make it a special place.
There was quite a large queue but it did go down fairly quickly.  The garden was lovely, although as others have mentioned it does get very busy.  Would recommend a visit.

Its a perfect way to start your day. The gardens are beautiful! Its better to go early like 8-9 o clock cause later is very crowded and you will wait in the queue for a long time . You can buy the ticket that includes all the museums together and it cost 18€ (you earn 2€) . We spend about 2h30min inside including a stop for coffee. Worthwhile going!

We really need to say that's amazing A beautiful garden and well done settings designed by celebrity ysl, we took a hundred of photos in order to have the best souvenir card , we enjoyed every moment we spent at this wonderful garden

The queue for tickets can be quite long but once you're in, the gardens are beautiful. There is a small Berber museum in the gardens but you need to buy the ticket for this when purchasing the garden tickets at the front entrance.
Breathtaking! Definitely recommend getting there as soon as it opens to avoid huge crowds. Beautiful experience would totally do it again

Well worth a visit. Complete contrast to most of the other attractions in Marrakesh. Tip. If you wish to also visit the YSL museum ( a bit expensive but just about worth it) avoid the queues at the Marjorelle gardens and visit the museum first (at the far end of the road past the gardens entrance). Buy a combined ticket and on leaving the museum you can by-pass the ticket queues at the garden and walk straight in.
Nice too see beautiful gardens but too many people As the title suggests... a bit like going to disney world.only good if you do not mind long queuing sessions.
Very crowded on a regular Friday morning in November. Great plants and cactus. Fun to see but in 20 minutes you are thru....
Magical, colourful and made my holiday  it was breathtaking  and relaxing. Great to walk around and take everything in.
Loved these gardens - such vibrant colours and a feeling of calm.  The YSL museum was interesting too

Definitely visit Jardin Majorelle. It's a peaceful respite from the polluted air in Marrakech, but go as early as possible to avoid the crowds. Tip: be aware that the taxi reps will gauge you if you don't know how much fare you should be paying! They'd wanted 150 Dir or 50Euros back to our Riad in the Medina. Our Riad arranged our taxi at 30 dir.
review_title: Beautiful space that's right in Marrakech

review_text: People queue to get into this attraction. Don't bother with paying extra for the YSL museum. You'll be out in 15 minutes. They don't advertise there is a section called the Oasis Garden. This shuts about 1600hrs and they will rush you out when they want to close. Their blurb states they support local producers, but I would be interested to know how much they contribute. There are staff all over the place and their overheads must be quite high. We found it difficult to get photographs as there were too many people.
This place is really beautiful, but if you want to get good pictures and avoid the crowds, arrive by 8am before the hoards come.
Best gardens I have ever visited. Fabulous cactus, colours to die for. Great cafe. Totally recommend

Gardens are really not my thing so I was reluctant to be obliged to visit this place. However, having visited I'm glad that I did. This turned out to be a very interesting place with some very worthwhile specimens to see. There are some huge cacti to see of all types and shapes. There is also a mini bamboo forest. I didn't look into the YSL stuff as I don't care for it. There is a nice cafe where you can have a good coffee, put up your feet and have a chat.
Great relaxing time. The plants were amazing as were both the Berber and Yves st Laurent museums. Well worth a visit.
Lovely and very well kept gardens. We went early/mid morning and wasn't busy. Lovely cafe with nice mint tea. Quite and relaxing atmosphere.
A pleasant break from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech we just paid 75 dirhams per person at the gate for a Garden only visit ( no museum ) taxis are very cheap from wherever you are staying.
As the title suggests... a bit like going to disney world...only good if you do not mind long queuing sessions...
review_title: Beautiful gardens but too many people

review_text: beautifull garden but too many people, too loud. Very hard to fing quiet place for rest. Tickets too expensieve.
Definitely worth a visit.  Amazing large cacti.  Does get busy so go early  before the crowds arrive...
Ignoring the queues and the most rude and unobliging people at he cash desks on the way in this place is a joy to walk around. Don't rush it but just let it seep into your bones.

Only gave one star as its the minimum, but didn't actually get in! The queues - even in November - were horrific. You must book ahead online - not an easy feat, and one we couldn't fathom from Morocco. If we go again we'll book in England.
review_title: Couldn't get in - BOOK AHEAD ONLINE

review_text: We first visited the YSL museum then headed over ti the gardens- the museum is worth it! You can buy a combo ticket there ad the line is much shorter than the one at the garden. They also have a student discount if you have your ID. It rained while we were here and we still had a fantastic time!

The gardens are well worth visiting, situated right next to the Yves Saint Laurent museum. There was a huge queue for tickets when we got there, but we learned you can get tickets for both museum and garden at the museum - avoiding the queue. I recommend this, with the visit of the museum, where the life and works of this great French artist are beautifully presented.
review_title: An oasis at the heart of Marrakesh

review_text: Good one to visit, would have helped if they had a tourist tour, was a little like a maze and not sure which way to go about. 70 dirhams was entry.

I was afraid this place will be crowded. And it was, don't get me wrong. Maybe if we came in the afternoon, it would have been a bit better, but we didn't want to stand in line for tickets, and came right at the opening. What can I say - the place is freaking majestic. I will definitely come back again when I return to Marrakech. I loved the boutique inside and wish I did some shopping there, because I haven't seen quality goods like that in entire Morocco
review_title: Glorious results of tedious gardenship and care. It's an artwork, I promise.

review_text: Jardin Marjorelle is the product of the life work of Mr. Marjorelle who lived at this property for several decades. He commissioned an architect and decorator to build his home here. The decorator used an intense blue to paint the buildings. The color now is known as Marjorelle blue. The property was sold and fell into disrepair in the 1950’s. Yves-Saint-Laurent later bought the property and had it restored. He lived here until his death. His final resting place is within the garden. The garden is beautiful. My suggestion: come early, like I did, right at opening of 9 am!  The garden is very popular with tourists. They generally start arriving around 10. By then, you want to be gone! There are a couple of museums, a restaurant and gift shop within the garden. I did not visit those.
Very beautiful garden, everyone who is visiting marrakech should make time to visit this amazing place.
Oasis in the bustling city of Marrakech. Visit early in the morning to avoid queing for the ticket. Constant birds chirping and noise of water flow
a great tranquil spot in Marrakech.  beautiful grounds and flowers.  a must see spot and a good respite from the heat.

We went on a Tuesday and were told the museum was closed. We were one of the first groups through the doors of the garden and that made for beautiful photos uninterrupted by the crowds- they come in bus loads!

This garden was absolutely lovely! I saw plants I've never seen before and the colors are breathtaking. Also, a great spot for pictures. It's great to get the combined ticket which also included the Berber Museum and the Yves St. Laurent museum. If you have a student ID you'll also get a discount.
Small oasis of electric blue with the housing the best museum (Berber Museum) I've seen in a long time, beautiful traditional clothing, jewellery and tools of the Berber Tribes - stunning
review_title: Not to be missed Jardin Majorelle

review_text: Taxi ride from Riad Baba Ali - 30-40 DH. Admission is 100DH to include Berber museum.  Well worth a visit - an oasis of plants and trees in the city.
Expensive, queues and too many people to see everything comfortably. It is lovely but I was a tad disappointed.

We pre-booked our visit to the Jardin, along with the YSL & Berber museums. The whole experience was inspiring, but I would choose a time that the coaches parties are not visiting. Both of the museum tearoom were nice, with the friendlier staff at the Berber tea room.

I'm not interested in YSL or that kind of fashion but the garden is worth visiting for three reasons... On a hot day it is very cool (literally) to walk around under the huge bamboo and trees. It's one of the 'must do' sites in Marrakesh. Just so you can say you've been there. Most interesting for me was the museum of Berber life. After spending a night in a berber camp in the Sahara I was fascinated to see and read about all of the exhibits here; clothing, weapons, cookware, jewellery etc. Unfortunately photography was not allowed in here. The best advice we were given was to go to Jardin Majorelle early and so we did. We arrived before 9am and there was just a short queue for tickets, while inside it was very quiet. However, by the time we emerged from the Berber museum at about 11am the whole place was very crowded, full of coach loads of tourists taking selfies in front of Cacti. Time to leave! And the queue for tickets to get in was huge. A good little exhibition is a small room with posters of the 'Love' greeting cards that YSL created every year and sent to his friends and collaborators. Finally, it's good to see security guards dotted around the gardens. A deterrent to the sad individuals who feel the need to carve their names into the leaves of the plants. It is worth visiting Jardin Majorelle, but go early in the day!
review_title: One of the 'To do' things in Marrakesh.

review_text: Good to see some very nice gardens and the museum but if you’re not into fashion or blogging it is an expensive walk through a park.
review_title: Nice but not for that amount of money

review_text: The garden is beautiful! Definitely worth visiting but recommend going early in the morning as it gets really busy.

Was always surprised how you could just walk into an entrance somewhere in Marrakesh and be in another world! This garden was just that! Just off of a busy street is the gardens entrance. As soon as you walk in you are greeted with a gorgeous fountain in a bright blue. The gardens and well kept and very clean. There is lots of greenery and spaces to walk and sit. Just a great place to visit. Only annoying thing... Instagrammers. UGH!
I found the entrance fee a bit pricey for what it was, but it's a nice picturesque escape from the craziness of the Medina. It's very relaxing and there's a nice cafe located inside the gardens.
What more can be said except it is a must visit on any visit to Marrakech. Recently the gardens open to visitors have been expanded
A nice half day get away from the centre of Marrakech, jump in a taxi (no your not going to get ripped off) we used a taxis every day for a week and never once felt pushed on price.
Beautiful place and a must visit. Try to get your tickets ahead of time, or buy with the museum. The lines are hugh.
But very popular so go early.  the gardens are lovely but lots of people visit.  The café inside is nice to visit and has free wifi
Only 70 dh but not really worth it. Very crowded and relatively small. Large queue early morning. Might be worth going in height of summer as very cool.
A very well presented garden with easy access around the entire site. Certainly worth a visit if you have the time.

Vibrant colors everywhere in every corner in this beautiful garden. I highly recommend it to all visitors to Marrakech. Such a beautiful place to go to. Don't miss going to the Yves Saint Laurent Museum around the corner too!
review_title: Don't leave Marrakech without visiting this garden

review_text: Beautiful garden that is well-maintained with plants from all over the world. It's peaceful to walk around and take in the unexpected calm in a bustling city.

The gardens are stunning and well worth visiting; we were also looking forward to the museums, but they were closed the day we visited, unexpectedly and without explanation - the woman on the ticket desk just abruptly told us that combined tickets were not available, without explaining why, which would have been nicer.
review_title: Stunning gardens, sadly museums closed when we visited.

review_text: Beautiful botanical garden, peaceful, beautifully maintained, plants from all over the world, with gracefully deigned ponds, a peaceful oasis, as long as you go early in the morning to avoid the crowds. Go back to the Yves Saint Laurent period, a time to dream and reflect.
review_title: A return to the 20th century Art Deco period

review_text: We were looking forward to seeing the Jardin Majorelle and we were not disappointed.  Our guide brought us there in the morning before it got too crowded and it was still somewhat crowded so I would suggest you get there as early as possible.

The garden definitely is wonderful. However, there are hundreds of tourists marching through and wherever you walk or stand you are in the way of someone who wants to do a selfie or snap a picture. It was just too much and even if the place is nice, the crowds somehow ruined the experience.
A beautiful peaceful place with a great looking café. Perfect for an easy half a day lasting relax. Very nicely designed and maintained. Cheap tickets, café a bit dear. Well worth a visit.
The garden is spectacular and the museum is very interesting. It was a lovely visit ! Arrive early to avoid long lines...
Worth a visit, cacti were spectacular. The Berber museum was amazing the artefacts and history worth the visit alone.

Have been to Marrakech many times for work but this was the first time I got to visit the gardens and they are well worth a visit...went mid afternoon, no queues or crowds...a real haven of peace, beautiful plants and wonderful water features. So glad finally made the time to visit this amazing spot.
Super garden to walk round and take in the planting and the atmosphere but it is crowded Try and book tickets before you go to avoid the long queues.
Such a treat for the senses. Calming.  Gorgeous.  Unexpected calm amidst the bustle of the city. We loved it and took tons of photos.

This place is amazing. Be sure to go around 3pm in the afternoon as most tour groups are gone by then and there’s no queue for the entrance. Buy the full ticket including the museum as that’s the main feature of the whole experience. We took two hours to walk through the gardens, museum Berbère, shop and the actual YSL museum. This has a wonderful collection of the stunning haute couture ensembles YSL created over the years.

The garden is really nice and well setup. There are many different types of cacti / succulent / bamboo plants in the garden. If you are into people watching it can also be fun to watch the many persons trying to create their instagram pictures. We were there off season and the queue was quite considerable (30 mins). I guess it can be quite a bit longer in peak season.
review_title: Worth the wait in the queue

review_text: You must take a camera on a trip to capture this beautiful place. You can count on interesting colors and cutting off the hustle and bustle of the street. Fortunately, student tickets are available.

A well presented YSL exhibition with haute couture outfits within touching distance, a bookshop full of beautiful postcards and coffee table books followed by a walk around the beautiful calm garden is thoroughly recommended. In November it was easy to take photos as it wasn’t too crowded- there are yellow pots, blue benches and green tiles for a wonderful colour combination. Huge bamboo shoots create a shady cool canopy. We asked our hotel to provide a taxi which cost £20 for both 15 minute journeys as it’s not easy to find. We spent an enjoyable 2 hours in museum and garden.

Mesmerising colours - a great place for a afternoon stroll and backdrop for photos. A well maintained and curated garden. Would definitely recommend purchasing the 3 in 1 ticket; YSL museum, Berber Museum and Gardens - cost effective and lots of cultural and fashion history and knowledge to be learnt/gained. Note: student discount available!

Amazing place, the plants and colours are extremely beautiful. Definitely worth visiting. The boutique shop I found though quite overpriced, I wish they would have some memorabilia at more accessible prices
review_title: Suggest to buy a joint ticket from YSL museum, where the queue is significantly smaller

review_text: A lovely place to visit.  Incredible range of cactii and other exotic plants.  If you can get there at a quiet time, (and that's a big if), you will find peace and tranquility here.  This was our second visit here, first time had it almost to ourselves and it was perfect, this time we shared it with that half of Tokio's population that were on holiday, so not so peaceful.
review_title: An oasis of calm in the chaos of Marrakesh

review_text: I had been looking forward to visiting Jardin Majorelle and the Yves St. Laurent Museum ever since I planned our trip to Morocco six months ago. We were just blown away by our experience there. The gardens, with its abundance of varied and unusually-shaped cacti and palm trees, had been taken over and revived by YSL years after the death of the artist Jacques Majorelle. We spent several hours in the garden, transfixed by its magical beauty. The stunning YSL Museum is also breathtaking, featuring fully accessorized and clothed black mannequins, exhibiting the strong influence Moroccan colors and textiles had on YSL's design aesthetics. There's also a wonderful and informative short movie to view as well as an art exhibit that features one artist. Be sure to buy tickets online ahead of time, as this is a very popular site to visit.
Very relaxing visit to some very well maintained gardens. A short taxi ride from the centre of Marrakesh and next door to the Yves St Lauren Museum.  Restaurant is well worth a visit.
Small haven of beauty and cool shade.  Birds singing in late November.  Cafe.  Worth a visit.  Taxi c50 dirhams   The queue for tickets took about 15mins for us.

The history behind this amazing garden is amazing, it has all different types of plants and the location is pristine, it has a small cover charge but it’s worth it. Wear fun colour that will make your pics pop.
We pay 70 DHM for this garden. It’s a very nice place to take some pictures and to spend some day. You have also the opportunity to visit a museum and the yves saint laurent museum
A lovely cafe in the beautiful gardens, busy but service is quick and efficient. Watch out for the birds in the trees though!

Wow! Truly stunning gardens with some of the most beautiful cacti I’ve ever seen. I’d advise booking your tickets so you don’t need to queue and get there very early as it gets so busy and the place just resembles a zombie film of people walking around with cameras and phones not actually looking at how beautiful it really is. The cafe courtyard is also really nice and does good coffee. The museum is a bit Meh and I wouldn’t bother with that compared to the gardens.

A lovely garden and definitly a relatively quiet place in the hustle and bustle of Marrakech, but be prepared to wait in line for a ticket and tourist masses are everywhere in the garden. it is best to not visit during lunch time as it is peak time. Better to come one or 1,5 hours before closure time.
review_title: Lovely garden but be aware of tourist masses

review_text: This garden built by french in early 1900s. Impeccable beauty, abundance of blue artifacts and all kind of exotic plants. Truly a must see place outside Medina.
Once you’ve escaped the bustle of the street outside this is an oasis of calm. Lovely shaded nooks and well thought out design of local plants. Enjoyed an hour there then did museum

What a beautiful place this is and the entry fee is reasonable. A lot larger than we first thought and although busy there are plenty of quiet spaces to sit and take in the wonderful setting. The shop was rather expensive but its YSL so to be expected.
review_title: YSL Gardens a beautiful day out

review_text: Right next to the Yves Saint Laurent Museum - this was a peaceful place full of unique cacti & succulents.  The play with color was amazing.

Spectacular cactus gardens in tow. The museum (separate fee) was a miniature gem containing a beautiful exhibit of local tools, clothing and jewelry from the Berber culture. Great small bookshop, exhibit of Yves St. Laurent Oyster display and exquisite boutique with YSL products. Relief from the bustle of Marrakech, but do go early or late as it gets busy.

A beautiful garden in the middle of busy Marrakech, very well maintained and definitely worth a visit! The dominant colour of buildings and pots is a special cobalt blue. A big selection of plants, among them many cacti and ponds with koi fish that reflect the surroundings.
A must to see in Marrakech.  Make sure you arrive early to beat the crowds. There was beauty everywhere.
Not that big but its very beautiful, well maintained. You should visit it in the morning when its not that crowded(08:00)

We visited the garden in November- it is an oasis of calm in Marrakech. Lots of bamboo which appears to filter out any noise. Purchased by Yves-Saint-Laurent in 1980 and is adjacent to the his museum. Beautiful colours, unusual plants and very enjoyable.

There’s beautiful gardens in Marrakesh , but if you are craving to be part of the Instagram crown and the other hundreds of people who are walking through this part ENJOY I felt more like a piece of a cattle
This garden was started by a Frenchman (YSL) and has lots of lovely plants and trees laid out in a nice manner. Lots of shade and beautiful water pools and channels.

It is a nice garden, nothing extra and definitely not worth queuing up for hours. If you want to see it I would recommend turning up at 9am and no later otherwise you will spend hours in  a queue for tickets and once inside you won’t be able to enjoy it due to the number of people

A spectacular garden, abundant in colour and variety of flowers and plant life.  You can purchase a ticket just for the gardens or. Combined ticket which includes entrance to the Yves San Laurent museum and Berber museum .
Well worth a visit it is in the newer part of Marrakech we really enjoyed the garden some amazing cacti
I am in love with this place! Beautiful colors, beautiful nature, very clean! Must see! I would recomend it!

Visited the gardens the 1st day of my trip to Marrakech! Full of lots of color, pattern and a great place to meditate and relax. Though there were a ton of people visiting while I was there. So many cacti and a wonderful opportunity for lots of beautiful photos! If you love gardening and plants you will appreciate this special place greatly!!!

This Garden is creative and as beautiful as it gets! Unfortunately it's pretty crowded, I would definetly recommend you to visit early! Or to skip it and visit the Anima Garden and/or the Secret Garden insted.
Beautiful! The colors, the setting! Try to get your tickets before you go there! Big cue when we got there!
it is pretty amazing how there was so many different species of plants from all over the world brought to Marrakech. The cafe is a delight and nice break and meal.
We really enjoyed our time in this beautiful oasis in Marrakesh. The wait time for tickets was very long, though.
review_title: A lovely oasis in the busy city.

review_text: Loved the gardens, and also the YSL museum! Tip: Get the tickets for the gardens first - including the museum. You will avoid the long queues that way!
Beautiful garden, it is well worth getting the combined ticket and doing the garden, Berber museum, and the Yves St. Lauren all in the same day.
Amazing gardens, a very nice relaxing break from the city's vibes. Top theme of them and beautiful colors. Recommended if have the time. Is a good spot for photos too.

Absolutely beautiful grounds. The garden and museum are outstanding. A must do while in Marrakech. The colors and history takes your breath away. All of your senses are aroused while in Morocco and this is a place to experience for all.
I love the museum at the end of the Garden tour . Great education . Blue pottery and selection of cactus was amazing .
Don't forget to visit also the museum Yves Saint Laurent.  Buy tickets in advance to avoid queing at the counters
Visited here at the same time as the YSL museum, lovely feeling to the space and interesting Berber museum also in the gardens.

We didn’t even realise this was the YSL villa but it was beautiful and the work that must go in keeping the gardens to such high standards is crazy but worthwhile. We did also the YSL museum which was interesting. Would definitely recommend.

OK think Disney crowds, long lines Space Mountain style. But I did not hate it. Everything takes longer than you think, so walk or taxi first thing in the morning or maybe the last hour of the day might not be bonkers. Buy your ticket on line, then you have to stand in the enter line. If you buy your ticket there, you can buy both tickets at the Yves Saint Lauren Museum. That line is shorter. There is also a ticket line and an enter line, if two people separate and get in both lines. The Museum café inside is amazing, we had a Middle Eastern platter, it was fresh and delicious. I would eat there every day. The garden is lovely, worth all the hassle and tourist. You've been warned.

Near the Medina. We had to wait in the queue for about 40 minutes. The ysl museum is just down the road, no queues there, so maybe you can buy tickets for both from there? A bit pricey, but a nice and quiet break away from the Medina. It's a relatively small garden, nice for pictures though.
Beautiful garden and artfully arranged cacti, other plants and trees! Berber museum a plus! RIP YSL!

We visited here on a Sunday afternoon and it was very busy.  We had to queue to buy entrance tickets which didn't really take too long but once inside the gardens, it was too crowded.  There were so many people trying to take photos of the pavilion that the tranquility was spoilt.  Try to visit mid week or early morning maybe for a more relaxing visit. Museum was interesting but shop was expensive.
Beautiful colors, lovely setting. The only complaint I'd have is that it is overrun with tourists. Try to go first thing in the AM when it is not as busy. Definitely a must-see in Morocco!

A welcome escape from the hustle and bustle of the medina and the busy streets. Long queues at both this and the YSL museum (for the combined ticket). Lots of people inside on the paths around the well established interesting planting. Lots of photo opportunities. Had lunch in the cafe, very nice salads and meatballs and atmosphere. YSL museum interesting, lots of garments on display and an interesting video.

So glad we made the effort to visit this place, it is outstanding. Every thing there is immaculate. The blue colours are just so good. All the staff make one feel welcome. We did however have to que for the entrance.
Despite the long queue to get in, it was well worth the wait. The gardens are nice and quiet, which really contrasts with the rest of Marrakech.

situated just outside the medina the Jardin Majorelle is well worth a visit, the gardens are nothing like you will find anywhere else in morocco with huge bamboo and ponds. The cafe is well worth the visit food as excellent Tip for entry - if  you are visiting the museum and gardens buy a combined ticket from the museum entrance then you can skip the queue when entering the garden which is always are nice V busy.
Far too busy and spoilt by the Instagram brigade. Great if one likes cactii, otherwise disappointing after all the hype. The YSL museum though its well worth it
the garden of the Yves St Laurent blue villa enables a relaxing stroll and the view of the ryiad and its perfection soothes the mind

Go before lunch, the queues both  inside and outside the gardens are ridiculous even out of season. We should have done more research. This is not a garden designed by YSL and has limited deference to the moorish style we had expected. If you like cacti and palm trees, you’ll love this. It’s mainly full of people wanting to be photographed in front of bright blue paint, and there is almost no chance to appreciate the peacefulness that a Moroccan garden should have. Even without the crowds, the garden is designed to be photographed in rather than to be a thing of beauty in itself. The cafe is good.
review_title: All the right components of a Garden but overhyped

review_text: love this place man. amazing care of al and the set up is great, our guide helped me with entrance quickly. good place.

The park was quite nice but I would say that entrance is too expensive for what you get. The queue was quite long for tickets so if you haven't bought tickets online and planing to go the YSL-museum (Line is a lot shorter) next door anyway then you can go there and buy a combined ticket and that way avoid some queuing time.
If I was going to skip a visit, it would've been this one... And it would have been a shame to skip. Refreshing place to be. Ideally between 11h-14h when sun is high.

Very sensibly, I went at 8am to buy or tickets to this beautiful tribute to YSL and its originator.... as the queues later would have put us off visiting. These stunning gardens of cacti, palms and bamboo are truly wonderful and the crowds didn't really reduce our enjoyment. We bought tickets to include the Berber Museum and the fabulous YSL Museum along the street. We initially baulked at 180 Dirham charge... but found it very worthwhile... highly recommended.
review_title: Crowded but beautifully peaceful... Highly recommended

review_text: This is a beautiful oasis in the heart of Marrakech.  Go early to avoid the crowds and buy tickets ahead of time.

These gardens blew us away! A must visit, the best thing to see in Marrakech! An oasis amongst the craziness. Spend some time lingering in the garden cafe with a tea. And they their amazing avocado almond date juice. YUM!!!

The gardens are beautifully maintained and interesting, but completely overrun with crowds of tourists.  Nothing tranquil about it, it's just something to see.  Not a priority if you have limited time  But if you need a break from the souk and traditional Moroccan sightseeing, it's worth an hour and you should combine it with the small YSL museum next door then walk 20 minutes west to experience the upscale modern part of Marrakech outside the medina.
Today was a beautiful day for this visit. It was busy but the gardens are amazing and are immaculate
Famous for being the garden acquired and further lovingly developed by Yves Saint Laurent, it is an exotic and unexpected charm in the very heart of the Ville Nouvelle, or French quarter.

We would recommend visiting these gardens, particularly if you're looking for a cool, tranquil getaway from the heat and hustle of the city. The garden is immaculately designed, showcasing plants that particularly suit the climate in neat gardens mixed with cool ponds and water features. There is great use of bright colours, both painted and on the plants, particularly blue and yellow, which really contrast with the surrounding 'red city'. We didn't do the museums, but found the garden itself reason enough to visit.
review_title: A cool, tranquil spot in the city.

review_text: Considering that you are in the middle of no where makes this garden unique.  It's small with a lot of wandering trails that all lead to the exit. The foliage is nice, but nothing special.  What is cool though is the array of very colorful pots and ledges amid the plants.  There is a very small museum that has a great display of jewelry and some interesting apparel. Be advised, the admission is pricey for what you are getting
review_title: The vibrant colors were my fav

review_text: This is a must visit attraction for holidaymakers in Marrakech. The gardens are beautiful and the Berber Museum (though tiny) is excellent.
Beautiful gardens ,architecture and exhibition . Get there early .It fills with people wanting to pose with the beautiful backgrounds .
review_title: Wonderful place to visit in Marrakesh

review_text: Wonderful oasis in the middle of the crowded New city. The only place though on the whole trip that we had to stand in line. But when you came inside it didn´t felt crowded...

We stood in line for over 30 min for a cashier window that had prices printed on the glass for the garden, museum, and both--but when we got to the window, they said they only sold tickets for the museum or combo tickets for the garden, not just garden tickets.  We were told to go stand in the garden ticket line (a longer, wider line nearby).  We nearly gave up in frustration, but we ended up waiting another 30 minutes in that line for tickets to the garden.  Fortunately, once we arrived inside, the crowds disappear over the expansive gardens (except for a few photo op locations).  After standing in line in the hot sun, it was a joy to walk in the shade of bamboo or sit on a bench to relax. Even if you live in a Mediterranean climate and have seen all the plants growing in your area, the gardens are laid out beautifully and interestingly and are worth a look.
review_title: Be sure to stand in the right line!

review_text: Took a cab from our hotel here on the recommendation from a local that we met in the Médina. Nice enough with great colors. We took some pictures but overall there wasn’t much to see or do in the garden. The wait for tickets was less than 10 minutes and you have the option of combining it with the Berber museum.
review_title: Beautiful garden but not worth the price

review_text: Wonderful.....the colours are just beautiful. Very special place. Buy tickets online or at theYSL Museum.

We arrived later than most people advise, just before lunchtime. We first went to the YSL museum which is just up the road and well signposted. Buying the joint ticket there was quite fast and the queue at the garden was very long. When we came to the garden the queues were still long but inside wasn't as busy as expected. It is a selfie dream here, with the plants and painted structures providing great backgrounds. It isn't as diverse a garden as anima, or as exciting to walk around. You can walk to here quickly and easily from the medina. A pleasant way to spend a couple of hours.
review_title: Buy tickets at the YSL museum if you have time to visit both

review_text: Garden was overcrowded even at start of the day. Nice collection of cacti and bamboo, but ultimately disappointing garden. I am an amateur photographer and simply couldn't get any decent shots because of how many people there were. The Berber museum was, however, fantastic!
Medina is crowdy, bit this garden is likely even crowdier. Funny think is you will see the same people you met at the garden in othet places, should you wish to follow default itinerary.
In the midst of demanding trip it's nice to take an hour or two just to wander in this very interesting garden.

Can imagine to visit this place on a hot summer day. The high trees and bamboo covering the sky from the sun. Well worth a visit. Buy multi tickets by the museum Yves Saint Laurent or online to skip the ques.
The gardens were beautiful and were a peaceful oasis in the busyness and heat of Marrakech but be prepared for long queues
We walked to the garden after lunch. The map they give you at the reception makes it look much smaller than it is. It is a beautiful garden and an oasis in the heat.

I don't mind the crowds if it's worth the visit!? Hailing from the southwest of the US, I appreciate cacti and succulents, and the Jardin Majorelle has the healthiest and most vibrant collection. Since we were only in Marrakech for two nights and one solid day, we did hire a permitted guide, whose english was limited, navigated us safely through the very complex and confusing Medina, gained front of the line entry into the Garden, Palacio da Bahia, and brought us safely back to our Riad in the heart of the Medina.
review_title: Get a guide skip the queue...

review_text: I went to the majorelle garden around 10.30 on Sunday morning and thought this was a good time to visit, but it was still very busy! Beautiful gardens and highly recommend a visit!
Amazing gardens - well worth the visit. Try to make your visit either early or late as it gets extremely busy.

This garden was amazingly beautiful and worth visiting. It's fairly large and has many really beautiful features. My only complaint was how crowded it was! Definitely an oasis in the middle of Marrakech and worth seeing.

Our Moroccan Guide recommended visiting this garden and my husband was initially not enthused. However, even he was impressed by the variety and quality of flora and fauna in this magical setting. A fabulous place for taking a break from Marrakesh madness and enjoying many incredible photo opportunities, even if you are someone not typically into gardens.
review_title: Magical, Serene Garden, Even for non Garden Enthusiasts

review_text: It's all been said... go early ie 8am when it opens if you want to avoid the crowds, have peace and quiet and avoid others photo bombing your pictures. Enjoy the birds... take binoculars if you're a birder, or buddy listen to the bulbuls if you're not.

Nice garden, but nothing special. If you like plants, then it's got a good collection of cacti and bamboo. If you're just interested in plants (which seems reasonable as you've opted to visit a garden) then it'll take about 20 minutes to see everything, which is terrible as I queued 50 minutes to get a ticket. The garden is linked with Yves Saint Laurent and this could explain its popularity. If you're interested in YSL, then it's definite worth a visit, otherwise you're not missing much.

Visited the gardens as a couple for a nice relaxing few hours. Outside there was a slight queue but this went down really quickly. When we got to the counter we asked for the combination ticket which gets you into the gardens and museums however we were told that the museums were closed and with no explanation. Instead we bought just the gardens ticket which wasn’t a bad price at 70MAD. As this was November there wasn’t many people there but it was still crowded in some spots so I can’t imagine what it would be like in the height of the summer. The gardens are clean, well kept and manned by staff. At the end of the route there is a bookstore and gift shop. It’s a nice place to visit for a few hours in the sun.
review_title: Beautiful gardens but the museum was closed.

review_text: We went to Jardin Marjorelle on our first afternoon in Marrakech. It is a great place to visit to see some beautiful plantings surrounding by brightly colored planters and buildings. You can see the gardens in under a half hour, which was a perfect activity for us after traveling by plane overnight from the United States.
review_title: Pretty Gardens with Vibrant Colored Structures

review_text: Gorgeous gardens so definitely worth time exploring while in Marrakech. You won’t need too much time, we did it in 1.5 hours.

You will find this place is crowded with mostly tourists and a few locals but this beautiful garden is simply a "Must Stop" when visiting Marrakech. It also is an interesting part of the city's history.....how it fell into ruin and was rescued by Yves St. Laurent and his fellow Frenchman....the final resting place of both men. The place is remarkably clean and well cared for.....so many beautiful plants....so many different varieties. The Berber Museum within the garden area is also worth visiting and has many fine displays....no photos are permitted though.  There is a nice little cafe there where we enjoyed a light lunch.  It is usually quite busy but they seem to move customers through at an efficient pace as we had a short wait for our food and drink.
Busy but beautiful gardens, I loved the variety and the stunning colours. The museums (there are two) are worth a visit too.

The gardens are beautiful, and well worth a visit. I would recommend going there in the morning though, as we went in the afternoon 3-5pm, and it was really busy. There were a lot of people taking photos and lining up for images, which made it a bit challenging to get around - so I'd recommend going earlier in the day as hopefully this would help others to avoid that.
The garden is not that big. Pretty enough with some exotic plants. Can be done in less than an hour.

Nice garden outside the city with beautiful grounds. Would definitely recommend the Berber Museum as well! Unfortunately a little too overcroweded with people hunting for the perfect instagram shot...

Really enjoyed our combined tour at Jardin Majorelle together with the museums of YSL and Berber. The garden is beautiful and although quite touristic it is still possible to find a quiet corner to enjoy the colours and the sun.
review_title: The garden and the museum are a must see

review_text: We were very surprised to find such a beautiful garden in the middle of Morocco! It is truly superb! OK a lot of tourists but no complains. We were tourists too!
Beautiful nice we paid as a student price 3, 50€ and worth it. A bit far away from the media but a good walk is always good.

I had expected more of this highly praised garden. It is overcrowded and full of posers and selfie maniacs so a relaxing walk toe enjoy it's beauty is impossible.  I do not recommend. Berber museum was a big disappointment as well.
Very pleasant 1 hour spent there. Many beautiful plants, everything is maintained. Generally it is expensive, but same price is for all attractions in Marrakesh.
Beautiful garden to visit - lots of palms and water and interesting memorials to Yves Saint Laurent . It gets very busy so go early if you can

Having bought ‘skip the line’ tickets my husband and I and our 18year old son spent an hour wandering in the lovely Majorelle gardens.  Fabulous collection of desert style plants providing lots of shade from the heat of the Moroccan sun.  There’s a winding path taking you through and a number of water features (some Koi fish too) reflecting the tall palm trees overhead.  Yves St Laurent’s house is within the grounds which you pay extra to visit.  It’s in that wonderful cobalt blue that started appearing in the UK gardening shows like Ground Force back in the 1980s.  It gets very busy later in the day so get there early otherwise you will be travelling at a snails pace.  Lovely peaceful place and very accessible so worth a visit.

On arrival we found that the Berber Museum and YSL was closed on Wednesday, a shame it had been our intent to do all 3 sites on our last day and we had taken a cab out from the city to do so. The garden is well maintained, beautifully established and at this time of year we saw cacti in flower and lots of unusual desert flora. We visited mid afternoon, that was a mistake it was very busy and you could not get a clear photograph without people ahead of you. I think the 3 sights in a morning early would be worth the trip. Personally I preferred the more typical structure and moroccan colours of the 'Jardin Secret' just to the north in the Medina which was simply stunning and the information provision there is rather better. You can climb a tower to enjoy a view, spend time in their open air cafe and relax in the pergola.
Lines were long but the garden is tranquil and beautiful. We spent about 30-45 minutes. An oasis in Marrakech!
Fabulous gardens! Terrific small boutique shop in middle of area. The museum was very thorough with a comprehensive review of YSL.
After an hour queuing to get a ticket for the entrance, we finally got into the gardens.expectations were too high. There are gardens elsewhere much more beautiful

Jardin Majorelle is beautiful, but I found its attractions to vary in interest.  The gardens surrounding the villa, which are not always open were incredible -- not to be missed.  The other gardens were less impressive.  And the Berber Museum, though small, was very interesting and some excellent exhibits, especially the examples of Berber dress.

I really enjoyed walking through these beautiful gardens. We spent about an hour exploring, which I feel was a reasonable amount of time for 70 dirham. I would suggest going early though to avoid large crowds and queuing for entry. It was very easy to find using Google maps. It took us about 30 minutes to walk there from Jemaa el fna square. Definitely worth a visit.

A lovely looking location with endless opportunities for a great photo. The buildings and their colours are amazing. The only "negative" is that I definitely recommend that you get here FOR the opening time as the entry queues are very long...

This was not something I knew about or expected in Marrakesh. It did prove to be well worth the visit as the gardens and museum are first class. Downside is that the money goes to the Yves St Laurent foundation and doesn't stay in Morocco.

While the queue might have been 30 mins long at 10am, it was worth it.  The garden is big enough to accommodate some mature trees and extensive stands of huge bamboo, discovered as you walk to sinuous paths. The underplanting is clever with smarter bamboos and succulents. There are a variety of water features, including some formal areas inspired by the Arabic Paradiso gardens. The Berber museum in the garden is compact, but worth the wait in get in.
review_title: Extensive leafy garden short walk from Ville Nouveau.

review_text: Long queues from two offices, but a family/pregnant women line seemed to process quickly, so good for us with children!  Even at the End Oct/Beg Nov it was very busy so pictures were hard to take that didn't have lots of other folk in, but having said that, after the noise, smoke and smells of Marrakesh it was an absolute oasis to visit and breathe freely again!  The plants are lovely, the buildings outside were colorful (we only did the garden tour not the house as well) and there are lots of little paths and outside statutes to discover, lots of photo opps.  Overall then place was smaller than I expected, and were were only there about an hour, but it was still worth doing.

Despite 40 minute queue for tickets, worth the visit as you lose people once inside the attraction.  The Berber museum particularly worthwhile - a real treasure of artefacts and jewellery, although it does cost extra to visit.
An oasis of floral beauty, perfect on a hot day.The design of the different areas were outstanding, YSL must have just loved it there.

Amazing gardens and very peaceful when there aren't a lot of tourists. Plenty of photo opportunities and beautiful secluded areas to relax in. We did not even have enough time to see the whole area and still loved what we saw. Although the garden areas are quite small, you could easily spend over two hours here.
A must visit for sure . It’s so beautiful and calm there . Please remember to purchase the ticket from YSL museum if you don’t want to wait in the queue .
Enjoyable couple of hours in this enchanting garden designed by Yves  St Lauren. Confess to not doing the museum...but the gardens were worth the visit.
review_title: Lovely Gardens an a great photo opportunity

review_text: Jardin Majorelle is a lovely garden and a must see when you are in the area. Although it’s a little bit small compared to the entrance fee.
A lot to see, nice and calm place, like beyin in the nature. Many plants,interesting story behind it, highly recommended!

This place is gorgeous. Definitely a must-see. It has beautiful gardens and so may beautiful different types of plants and flowers. Make sure your camera battery is charged because you'll be taking lots of photo of this beautiful place.

We visited Majorelle on 26th October but I have to say it is quite boring unless you are plants/nature enthusiast and certainly not for small children as they will get bored really easily. It is more for adults/couples who want some piece and quiet and can spend a bit of time just observing these beautiful plants.
The Yves Saint Laurent museum and the Berber museum were very interesting. The gardens are well kept and cared for.
review_title: An oasis away from the noise of the city.

review_text: Definitely worth paying the entrance and I guess, most importantly, doing the queue. Very beautiful, Instagram worthy sort of landscape. Note, there are 3 options to buy the tickets: reserved tickets (first ticket box), the second one you can purchase the complete ticket (garden and museums) - this has usually got the longest queues! and then the last one, 5 mins walk to the left, which is for the museum BUT where you can buy tickets for the garden. Queues tend to be shorter there. Definitely worth visiting! :)
To be in this beautiful garden is wonderful.  Yves St Laurent left a treasure for the ages.  It can be very crowded this time of year, long lines waiting to get in, have patience.
We loved visiting Jardin Majorelle. It is like an oasis in the dessert. We recommend a visit to this exotic place.

We found not a long queue for the tickets. The garden is not enormous but is very elegant and well built. Full of green, tall trees, full of fountains and paths, full of gazebos and waters. One of the must see in Marrakesh.
Perhaps we missed something but we spent an hour here and just didn’t find much to do except to visit the cafe. The staff were helpful and my soup was delicious.

This garden is simply heaven for all cactii lovers!!! I have never ever seen such a beautiful array of rare cactii. The bright colours of the surrounding buildings make  a stunning picture. The cafe in the area offers good service. have their Mint tea. The toilets are very clean, Need a good 2-3 hours to enjoy your walk. Beware as the queues are really long.

Not the type of garden I was expecting but relieved it was cool and out of the sun with the overhang of all the beautiful trees and plants. Not a large spacious garden but intimate with offshoots going here and there and great just to sit in the shade and take it all in.  Had lunch in the cute little garden cafe, really nice. There is a very expensive shop with beautiful things to buy, a little book shop and a museum, but have to pay to get into the museums.  Yves Saint Lauren statue there too. A lovely place to visit and would recommend.

I used to work for YSL in my 20 so this visit was 30 years in the making! I adored the museum, just loved seeing actual designs just stunning. Made me realise how much he influenced me from an early age. The gardens are just the best even with so many people they are so impressive colourful and the cacti are phenomenal. I loved it here worth every penny

We stopped here as a part of a tour.  Everyone in our group thought it was the highlight of the day.   The gardens are beautiful and even though they were quite crowded we all thought it was quite tranquil there.  I don’t know if there are times of the day when it is less crowded but this is worth a visit while in Marrakech.

This garden was well worth the visit. We were a group of 9 - five adults and four children ranging in age from 7 to 70 and we were all captivated by the garden. Lots of photo opportunities! We arrived at about 10 o’clock in the morning expecting very long queues but it is worth noting that if you have children you can join a much shorter queue and we were in the garden within five minutes - a real bonus! It was busy but not unpleasantly so. We only had drinks in the very nice cafe but food looked good and fairly priced. Recommended!

Bus after bus, taxi after taxi, disgorging hundreds of visitors which can overwhelm the Yves Saint Laurent designed garden and its marjorelle blues can still offer a moment of respite which I  one looks for in a garden.  Well manicured and maintained but I am mesmerized by less man made surroundings like the Dades Gorges
review_title: With Luck Quiet Bench Time At Major Tourist Stop

review_text: Haven of peace to discover absolutely With the Saint Laurent museum Trees and aquatic plants that make you dream

Best to be here at opening time at 8.00am, if you want to avoid ques. I bought a combiticket for 180 drm. Enjoyable  small garden with colourful pots and a blue house. YSL's house Oasis, the berber museum and YSL museum opens first at 10.00am, so theres time for a coffee or breakfast in Cafe Majorelle if you come at 8.00am. Only pitty with this place is, that you can't go in the houses. Otherwise time well spent.

Visitors flock to the Majorelle Gardens for the famed colors and exotic vegetation (mostly as background to countless identical selfies), but the real treasure here lies inside, not outside. Painter Jacques Majorelle's original studio has been transformed by Yves St-Laurent's partner Pierre Berge into a museum of Berber culture that ranks among the best ethnographic collections in the world. The magnificent tribal jewelry is strikingly displayed in a darkened, mirrored-ceiling room that quite literally dazzles. Costumes are no less impressive, offering a rare glimpse at full outfits of both daily and ceremonial wear. As to the gardens: early morning and late afternoon hours offer the best photographic possibilities, when the light is ideal and the hordes are reduced to a minimum. Regrettably, the flora bears the all-too-visible scars of deplorable visitors and lax security: graffiti has been carved into the palms and cactuses, spoiling the intended sense of a tranquil retreat from the madness outside the walls.
Beautiful place and so colourful and gorgeous water features. Nice café. Long queues to get in. Worth a visit.

A really wonderful place to visit. The reconstruction and refurbishment of thegardens is of a very high .standard. I f you go early enough and beat the crowds then this is a really tranquil place to spend time. A relief from the madness of the souks. Good facilities are available and the food was of a really good quality.

These gardens are nice and quiet peaceful in parts. However, we were  not blown away by these gardens as it seems to just be a photo opportunity for most people and there are lots of crowds around waiting to take pictures at the blue and yellow museum. Gardens are pretty and worth a visit but there was an hour long queue outside and I wouldn't have been impressed had we queued for that long to get inside. We went to the YSL museum first (hardly any queue) and purchased our combined tickets there, did the YSL museum and then we were able to skip the whole queue for the gardens and walks straight in. Well worth it.
review_title: Worth a look but skip the queue

review_text: This place is a must while visiting Marrakesh. The colors are so inspiring. There is also a nice caffe where you can grab a drink. It is easy reachable with a local cab.

Gardens are beautiful and gives you a serene feeling despite the crowd. YSL and Berber museums are worth the visit. We arrived late so we had to queue some time but it goes fast, i guess in the morning will be less crowded and one can enjoy in calm. The restaurant offers very nice lunch in a nice setting, food and service is really good. We had best Moroccan tapas here. Not to be missed while in Marrakech.

A beautiful garden, together with the Yves Saint Laurent museum and his former house. Be aware however, that this is a major tourist attraction of the city and you'll queue a minimum of half an hour to get combined tickets for the three places. It's owned by the YSL Foundation so it's all beautifully maintained and clean.
A great place to visit but make sure you are there at opening time if you want to avoid large queues and an overcrowded garden.
No place to come down from the souks and tourists in Marrakesch. Nice nature with nice places (without the masses of tourists).

This place is a quiet and beautiful oasis in Marrakech with a wonderful variety of plants, trees, and serene atmosphere. Its only drawback is the volume of visitors, which take some of the serenity out of the place. Still, I would definitely recommend this place.
review_title: Lovely garden, although a bit overrun by tourists

review_text: I had done no research on Marrakech before my visit as I was on a tour. Another tour member suggested visiting here after the tour and it was a real highlight. Arrive at 8 when the gates open for the best experience as by the time we left at 11 the line was at least 100m long

Nice gardens but too busy, full of tourists like us. Fine to wander for an hour. Definitely buy tickets at the YSL museum further along the road and then go straight in, it takes a few minutes but will save you at least 20-60 mins queuing. The Berber museum is accessed from inside the gardens and interesting-ish
review_title: Pleasant place to spend an hour

review_text: Gardens and museum bought by Yves Saint Laurent at 80's . Rare cactus and plants such as Baboo trees. The problem is that is often overcrowded and you need to be patient when you are waiting in the hot weather. I would like to have e-ticket system to avoid ques. Plus the student discount that is 50% , 35 Dirhams. On the whole the stroll in the gardens was a pleasant experience which had great photo ops.

Beautiful well kept and sizeable gardens. You can easily spend a couple of houts wandering round the garden or just sitting and taking in the ambience.There is also the museum of designs which is interesting plus a display of jewellery. Finally there's also an exhibition of traditional clothing, pottery and tools. All in all a very pleasant way to spend a few hours and it's not very expensive. It gets very busy in the afternoon so go before lunch.
review_title: A nice attraction well worth a visit

review_text: A wonderful contrast to the city outside. Escape the busy streets for peace & serenity. Beautifully designed gardens with the biggest bamboos we have ever seen
A must see, Best Buy a duel ticket at the museum entrance this allows you to see the museum first then the garden without lining up.

Despite warnings about not going between 12 noon and 2PM, we rocked up at 12:30PM and waited around 20 minutes to get in.  Very efficient and organised system to get in so no issues with that. Yes, it is crowded at times but as long as you find a quiet spot, there's a lot to enjoy with the most amazing cacti and other desert plants on display.  It is also very well taken care of so all the plants look really healthy but natural in their setting in the garden- it doesn't look fake!  The colours were amazing particularly the indigo blue that YSL loved so much and is such a part of Moroccan art. We had a lovely time in this Jardin.  Just relax and don't worry about the people around you.  Just enjoy the plants and the colours.  Amazing!
Very nice gardens but very busy not much room to move around advise getting there early there are better gardens to visit

Our taxi driver suggested this and boy was he right!  We didn't have to wait in line and the crowd was nothing like we were told.  The cafe was still very busy.  Gorgeous gardens - very "instagram" worthy... be patient and kind when trying to get that "perfect shot"
review_title: Try to go an hour before closing

review_text: Nicely done but more hype than plants.  Line moves quickly, people proceed through the walks at good speed, restrooms for those in need, and store has very nice items. I recommend going here if you need a break from the souk crowds or want to support the garden.

You have to give YSL a big high five for discovering what what a run down property and turning it into a wonderful paradise.  He lived there with his partner Pierre and Majorelle painted there also.  The amazing blue colour is the theme throughout.  Breakfast in the courtyard is worth getting there at 09:00 am as it all gets very busy and the queue for tickets is long.

The gardens are stunning and offer some very appreciated shade. They are quite busy and quite expensive - having got home it appears I was overcharged at the ticket box which didn't help. But the gardens themselves are definitely worth a visit!
It ws the most amazing site we have seen in the city. You can take hundreds of photos. Great plants and shade...

Do get there early to avoid a long queue for tickets and then enjoy the beauty of the gardens, even when busy. Also the cafe is a little oasis to enjoy for a light (or not so light) lunch. The gardens are so peaceful, and photogenic. Really a must in Marrakesh.
review_title: Words cannot describe the beauty of the gardens

review_text: The Jardin Majorelle is a must when visiting the area. We arrived at 10am and were in the queue for tickets for 30minutes. There is a separate queue for pre-booked tickets so I would recommend doing this as it was a shorter line. Inside it did not seem as busy as was lovely to spend the morning walking round. The cafe is beautiful and very reasonably priced.
Very good place to visit i recommend to everyone who goes to marrakesh  to visit this place I love this
Even with lots of visitors you can find a quiet, shady spot.  We only went round the garden, not the museum, as we arrived late.

A garden in the oasis! The headline proved irresistible and so we went early in the morning thinking we could beat the afternoon heat. It was a great idea, only it was shared by a thousand other people, mostly Chinese looking for great pictures, of which the place has hundreds of perfect locations to get one. The gardens are lovely, well- laid out and a cool break from the Moroccan sun. The variety of plants and flowers is striking and altogether beautiful. Unfortunately, it was hard for us to really enjoy them because of the crowd, most of whom were jockeying for position to take a five second long photo session and move on. Regardless, we particularly enjoyed the cactus section, which has amazing specimens and the long reflective pond. The bamboos were stunning, although somewhat scarred by the initials of many visitors who left their brains outside. Overall, the experience is worth the shot, especially if one waits a bit, let’s the early morning crowd have its shot (pun intended) and enjoy it in relative solitude as it should. Salaam.
review_title: It could have been a contender (or wait until the crowds disappear)!

review_text: Impressive gardens with brightly coloured blue and yellow buildings. The contrast with the green bamboo and the cacti works really well and makes a great area to wander around. The water features provide a calming factor and the Museum, whilst small, was informative. We got the combination ticket as we were going to the YSL museum as well. I’d also suggest buying tickets in advance as the queues were quite long. I believe if you have children and people who are less able then you can use the advanced ticket window but would advise still getting g tickets in advance.
A bit of a queue to get into this little island of tranquility. 70 dirhams for admission with an extra charge for the museum. A pleasant visit although a bit crowded.

I enjoyed visiting the gardens. The house was stunning, with the colors and design.  The gardens were well laid out and pretty, ranging from desert plants to lotus ponds with koi fish.  It was quite popular and there were many visitors.
Beautiful gardens, a lovely break from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech.one can walk back through the Souk

This was a pretty garden but it was quite small. There's a lot of people inside so it gets rammed very quickly, even when it first opens. We went at 9am and it was difficult to enjoy because it was so busy. You can easily walk around in less than 30 minutes when you're being shuffled around by a crowd behind you. There's lots of people queueing to take photos of certain areas for the Gram. The garden itself is really pretty and if it had been quieter, it would have been more enjoyable. We got a taxi to and from the garden. If you walk to it from the old town, try to avoid the tanneries and the tannery scam.
review_title: Quite small, crazy busy, lots of IGers

review_text: Plants from all over the world. A must see.  a memorial for Yves St Laurent and his Villa Oasis. A 30 minutes waiting line to get in!
Title says it all 7 dollars to get in and not much to see. Maybe it just wasn't for me. A couple of pools and some nice foiliage but was in and out in 20 mins. As a younger man couldn't reccomend

It is a nice garden and the history is fun. The colors are beatiful and there are lots of exotic plants. However it was much smaller than I thougt and there was so many people we could hardly fit on the paths.

When Marrakech gets a bit much, a visit to Jardin Marjorelle will help you to recover your senses. Yes it is busy but being outside it seems tranquil. A must do in Marrakech. We also had a lovely lunch at the cafe there too!

What a beautiful place! Arrive early to beat the queues and heat. It opens at 8. We spent an hour wandering round taking photos and then had a tea in the restaurant it really is a very peaceful oasis from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech.
These gardens are beautiful, but they are not a must. Would recommend if you have extra time. It cost 70 dirhams for foreigners. I did have to wait in a long line to get tickets.

There is something about these gardens that simply catches your attention; I think its innate simplicity is what draws you in, coupled with the 'Majorelle bleu' and yellow that are found throughout the gardens.  Its not even Yves St.Laurent's name that brings you in but I'm sure it helps...it's all the stunning cacti and bamboo and how well manicured the gardens are.  There is a 'je ne sais quoi' feel for these gardens and a visit there is a definite must do!

An unique garden in the middle of the urban mess in Marrakesh. Definitely worth it, with exotic plants and beautiful pictures to take. There is also a nice cafe for after you tour. I would suggest arriving early since it can get very crowed after 10-11am
Still a wonderful experience but in truth the Gardens appear to suffer from too many people and this was an early visit !

One of the major attractions at Marrakesch. The garden is very beautiful but on the smaller side. There is a small Berber Museum worth the few extra DH to visit. I didn't visit the YSL museum so I can't comment on that. I am not sure if this is a must visit stop, but is worth it if you have spare time on your hands.

Huge queues but top tip of going to YSL museum first and buying combination ticket saved a lot of time. More expensive but it did help to beat the queues. Inside it was very busy but worth a visit. Very calm spot within the hustle and bustle of Marrakesh.
perfect garden that I have ever seen in my life.. should visit list. lots of different cactus.. and lovely weather that keeps u warm and so green
This is a gorgeous oasis in the middle of the city. Beautiful plant life, stunning architecture and so relaxing!
Take the short taxi ride to visit these stunning gardens but be prepared to queue for your tickets. The Berber museum is worth seeing so buy a combined ticket.
It is one of the first things to do in Marrakech. You can spend hours in the garden and take hundreds of photos.
amazing place and restaurant. Very clean and beautiful. The coffee house and also restaurant is a good option to those who look for good food
Enjoyed these lovely gardens and the tranquail scenery. Great variety of plants. Colors of pots are cool, too.

Fabulous mostly cactus garden established some 100 years ago. Largest Golden Barrels I have ever seen - truly enormous, and fire sticks so large they are tree size. Many new world cacti, agaves, paddle cacti somewhat resembling botanical gardens in Arizona. I felt like Alice in wonderland who had shrunk to mouse size. Now for the negatives, by 10 am the place was over run by hordes with no interest at all in the plants or garden and only cared about the •perfect• selfie. So annoying. Similar experience in the Berber museum in the garden, way to many people for the venue, which is small and well laid out but can’t reasonably accommodate a bus load of 50 tourists all entering at once. My advice be there 15 min before the garden opens and be one of the first in. Experience the quiet and birdsong. Note to the gardeners trapping and rehoming  the feral cats would be a huge bonus for the  birds. Once the bus loads start to pour in its time to leave. It would be nice if they offered timed tickets to spread the load or “green background” rooms for folks who don’t care about the gardens , just the selfies.
