review_title: Fabulous garden BUT go early, very early

review_text: We went to both the gardens and the museum. It was nice but not incredible. The gardens were very crowded and it was difficult to even look at different areas as there were so many people taking pictures.
beautiful. busy. lines went quickly. worth the visit. I didn't see the museum due to lack of time but would have liked to
These gardens are beautiful and a nice way to spend an hour or so. The YSL Museum is closeby and also worth checking out!
Few gardens I’ve been to match the Majorelle for breadth of cacti species and setting. The prevalent Mogador blue is the perfect backdrop for the spiky greenery.
The only down size is the amount of people there. It becomes very busy which takes away from the calm and beauty of the place.

Such a treat to walk through these beautiful gardens. The combination of plantings and colours was just a photo opportunity at every turn. It was quite crowded as soon as it opened but it did thin out a bit later. Wear a hat if going in the hot months as the sun can be fierce.

The Jardin is lovely but gets very crowded so get there early. If you do then make sure you also visit the Berber Museum first before it gets too crowded. You can buy a joint ticket for all three so once you have come out of the garden you can avoid the queues next door  at the YSL Museum as you already have the ticket.
review_title: Visiting the Jardin, the Berber Museum in the garden and the Yves Saint Laurent Museum next door is a must.

review_text: ‘The way you do anything is the way you do everything’ is a discipline few of us live up to in entirety, but YSL is an exception. Colour, considered design, architecture ,composition, and the balance of light and shade run through every path and plant in this garden. Attention to detail is everywhere from the garden to the Berber museum , book and souvenir shop and the cafe in the courtyard. Quality surrounds you. Don’t miss the YSL museum, having visited numerous designers exhibitions this has to be one of the most impressive for the fashionista, a chronological presentation of his work, from sketches and swatches spanning the decades, collections, visual and audio presentations overlooked by 3 large images of the man himself, you wouldn’t be surprised if you bumped into him as you left the museum. A Marrakech must see.
review_title: Yves Saint Laurent style and design goes beyond haute couture

review_text: Peaceful and beautiful gardens but busy. Worth the trip tho. Buy your ticket at the museum next door to avoid the queues. Great ice cream stall across the road too. YSL Museum worth visiting tho the restaurant is pricey tho very very smart and food great.
It’s difficult to decide what to do when you are in a family group including teenagers and grandparents but this ticked all our boxes and we all enjoyed the calm beauty of the gardens
This garden was nice and good for a cool stroll I wasn't overly impressed there wasn't much to it really, not much variety in plants.
Beautiful gardens . Bought combined ticket from our hotel La Sultana for gardens, Berber museum and YSL museum. Didn’t have to queue .
many plants, cactus, palmtrees, bancs to sit on. Nice corner with paintings of Yves Saint Laurent. Ideal place to take pictures around  the waterparties.
review_title: many plants, cactus, palmtrees, bancs to sit on. Nice corner with paintings of Yves Saint Laurent.

review_text: Attend this garden at the suggestion of staff at my Riad.  Glad I did.  It was a great little space which is attached to the Yves Saint Laurent museum and house The price is reasonable to get on as well It was quite busy and took some time to get through the doors though Beautiful cacti gardens and other tropical flowers and trees. Several water features as well I would recommend if you are Loki g for something to do in Marrakech
This must be a very popular place on a very hot day as it’s so wonderfully shaded Lots of strange trees to see and the Berber Museum a must visit With a nice cafe to relax in afterwards

Honestly, we were a little underwhelmed.  It was October and it was mostly palm trees, bamboo and cactus.  However, everyone has told us it is a riot of colour and blooms in the summer so maybe we were just at the wrong time of year?  It was really packed and so it was not a peaceful wander around.
We simply love this place. Everything is done to perfection, and, aboce all, maintained by great teams of professionals. Just superb, can't be missed!
review_title: not for your eyes only, your soul will get peace there

review_text: Berber museum is excellent, although small (and mostly in French). The gardens are lovely (although it was v. hot that day so we didn't linger).

This place is full of tourists, let’s get that right. The Berber museum and the gardens themselves are very beautiful and worth a trip. This is another place that is heavily touristed, so be prepared to encounter all sorts of people in a very small space who don’t seem to have much of a regard for taking turns. Tourists are often not the best people from there respective countries. If you keep this in mind and focus on the beautiful things in the museum and the amazing landscape of the garden itself, I think you will enjoy spending an afternoon exploring this small garden.
Tried Online payment for tickets in advance it won't work from either of 3 cards tries Fix this please.

Stunning garden, but book to skip the queues, which are everywhere. It was very, very busy, so little opportunity to pause and enjoy as you follow the trail through. Exhibitions very informative about Berber culture and the great man himself, YSL, if you follow through to the museum.
review_title: The most popular garden in Marrakesh

review_text: We really enjoyed the gardens but it does get very busy. We didn’t appreciate this so didn’t buy our tickets in advance online, this meant half an hour queuing in the sun. Worth going to though, it’s a pretty oasis, and quite shady and cool in places, the cafe was a nice place to sit and have a drink
Beautiful place !! I will visit again !we were amazed with the beautiful colors , the plants , the weather , everything was perfect !! I really recommend to visit if you are in Marrakech
review_title: Best trip ever in our life.

review_text: This was a must-see for me. I’d read about the crowds, but even though it was very busy, we still enjoyed this beautiful garden. Yes, you sometimes have to wait to take a photo, but there are more tranquil parts of the garden as well. The café is lovely for lunch, and the little Berber Museum was a highlight of our visit. You pay extra for this, but we bought a combined ticket online for the garden, the Berber Museum and the Yves-Saint-Laurent Museum up the road. We spent three and a half hours in the first two, including lunch, and about forty minutes in the YSL. Please don’t miss the Berber Museum, (no photography allowed), where the mirrored room with the starry ceiling and the beautiful Berber costumes and jewellery is much better than anything in the YSL.

Undeniably, it was calm, soothing with greens but personally, I find it overrated... there are better gardens out there, well kept and all... it was really the blue colour and all that spiced up the place, otherwise a memorial section for YSL.  Museums were.closed on the day we were there... i.e. a Wednesday...  could have been better with that kind of entry price... 70 Moroccan Dirhams...
This is a tiny and pretty unimpressive garden. Lot's of cactus. A few water features.  Takes about 20 minutes to see it. Some of the exhibits were closed. Not really worth the trip, in our opinion.
We travelled by taxi to the gardens.  Extremely busy as the museum in next door as well.  Good way to spend a couple of hours seeing some exotic plants.
review_title: Great way to spend a couple of hours.

review_text: Visited here for a couple of hours and fortunately we were guided past the long queue to get in, otherwise it would have taken an hour or so just to get in.   Once inside, the gardens were nice but nothing special.   Yes there were a lot of plant varieties but the whole gardens are confined to too small an area.   It could be nice and relaxing if the crowds wren't as bad.   Nice place to visit if you are into gardens but certainly not worth the queues.  Have seen many better gardens.

Queue up for an hour to than see a few succulents, kois and ponds... Not really that spectacular in comparison to many other things that Marrakesh offers. Rather spend your dollars on a hammam or cooking class...
€7 euros to see a very small garden full of banana and baboo trees is not worthy at all . I consider my passage from there as a waste of time

This is a wonderful garden but it is very hard to take in and enjoy the beauty due to the abundance of visitors. I understand that it is a public and popular attraction but one can not fully appreciate the beauty with all the tourists stopping for pictures in every square inch of the garden.
even the paintings of YSL you have to look for. The clima in the garden is refreshing in this capital.
review_title: Nice garden with interesting plants and trees.

review_text: Purchase tickets online the day before you want to go and visit. You can do that for the Berber Museum that is in the gardens and the next door YSL museum at the same time should you like. That stops you having to queue (we witnessed people getting into verbal altercations because they wanted to jump the line). They let in way too many people at the same time in the gardens. What ends up is that the place is way too crowded. And everyone is making their narcissistic selfie pictures with the blue painted buildings and trim which stops you being able to just saunter around and enjoy.  If it wasn’t for the Berber museum then I would have skipped these gardens altogether. What Is astounding Is the cactus collection. Very impressive to see very large and healthy examples from all over the world here.
review_title: Great cactus collection - too many people let in at the same time

review_text: Wonderful place. Whilst not cheap it’s well worth a visit. The YSL museum and the beautiful gardens are wonderfully kept. The exhibition is very interesting and informative. A real oasis in the madness of Marrakech!
A must-visit, including the nearby Yves St Laurent museum (buy the combined ticket to miss the queue at Le Jardin).
review_title: A beautiful calm spot in the bustle of Marrakech

review_text: These gardens are beautiful and large. Spread out and a lot of varieties. Huge display of cacti. Enjoy a liesurly stroll. On many tours agenda and popular with locals. May be quite crowded. The Yves St Laurent is adjacent. You may not want to buy tickets for this. Some interesting displays in there, but very small floor space. Very claustrophobic.
Nice garden but quite small. decent range of plants and nice waterfountain. Not much else. Can be in and out in 30 minutes.
Went early in the morning to avoid the crowds and it was still very busy! Gardens are lovely but quite small as most areas were closed off ! If you like cactus plants you'll be in heaven!
french keyboard drana  short review  too many instqgrqmers and time wasters   go in the evening  less people

We got a taxi to send us to this place for DM300 from the Medina. The queue to buy the entrance ticket was long. However the staff there were quite alert to direct those with special needs to another faster counter. The collection of plants, the landscaping and the ambience is exhilarating.  We were unfortunate that day since the Berber museum was closed. Be prepared to queue for your turn to take photographs at some popular spots.
review_title: A breather in the warm climate of Marrakech

review_text: They opened the private garden for visitors now. It's a very well maintained garden with lots of points to sit down and enjoy the view. There can be a queue for the entry. No need for a guide there are plenty of information signs. If you have kids, watch them as the water can be a danger for them.
Great color in a serene garden but way too many tourists.   It is hard to enjoy when you need to wait for multiple photos at every turn.
The Majorelle Gardens and attached a Berber Museum are stunning .  Beautiful setting.  The museum has a great collection of amazing Berber jewelry and clothing.
Good price 70 dhm entry per person. All plants are names and it's very tranquil. Isn't very big but is a nice escape from the business of Marrakech.
The gardens are very beautiful. Loved the blue paintwork with the lush planting. Crowds are quite large unfortunately. Allow time to sit & reflect.

This garden and the adjoining Berber Museum should not be missed. The colors are spectacular and the cactus collection is magnificent. The museum has an impressive collection of Berber jewelry and costumes as well as exhibits on pottery, household goods, silver and tools. We enjoyed tea and an avocado date shake in their patio cafe. Although it can be quite crowded ( what isn’t in Marrakech) it was worthwhile and a great day to ease into Morocco.
Really beautiful. But if you have not an interest in plants or architecture than I wouldn't recommend.

We had heard good things about this garden so made an effort to go, but I have to say that I can't see what they were talking about. In my view this was a total waste of time. There were nicer public gardens around the city which you did not have to pay for and which were not so full of tourists. The best thing about having gone, was the walk from the Medina to the Gardens. We followed google maps and got to see local areas which we never would have seen otherwise, and that was great. The garden though.....not so great.
A highlight of our visit to Marrakech, with a combined ticket for the YSL Museum added bonus. Both together, present a half day trip, but easily a full day could be spent here.
review_title: A piece of paradise in a city of chaos

review_text: These gardens were falling into disrepair when purchased by Yves St Laurent and his partner. With Yves eye for design they are now a beautiful place for just sitting and contemplating their beauty. There is also a library, Berber museum, boutique and coffee shop offering orange blossom ice cream! Well worth a visit. You don’t need to be part of a tour. Just get your tickets at the gate.
It is a beautiful place, but there is something about seen nature (stunning cacti, so tall!) with so many crowds. They don't seem to control the numbers going in. So, please watch what time you go..
wanna stay here for the whole day...it's super stunning on a sunny afternoon. with vivid colors and art deco design.
The garden was much smaller than expected. Nice garden, fairly good condition. But wespent less time in the garden that the line to get in.
review_title: Wait was longer than the visit

review_text: What a marvellous place. The gardens and colours are superb and so well cared for. It can get very busy and queuing is required. When it is really hot, there is a misting system in place over the queue. Take a hat. A photo opportunity at every turn.

The Majorelle garden was a beautiful visit where it look us approximately 70 min to walked the entire place.  We went in October and it was nice to get away from the heat.  This is a great place for photography due to the amazing colors on this little oasis. The visit was well worth it.

What a fabulous oasis in the middle of a very busy city. The exotic plants and a rainbow of colours of the painted furniture were beautiful. Be prepared to queue to get tickets though but it’s well worth it. Don’t buy drinks in the cafe if you’re on a budget as the prices are extortionate!
Excellent and well-maintained gardens.  Try and buy a combined ticket for both the YSL garden and museum at the museum. This will save you time waiting in line for the gardens

Absolutely gorgeous place and don’t miss it!  Make sure you arrive at opening time or else it gets super busy very quickly since it is a beautiful spot!  Give yourself time, at least an hour to explore the gardens and the shops,  don’t rush it!

People rave about this spot, and it is nice. But I expected more... there are so many amazing botanical gardens around the world that are so special and also offer an interesting historic background...
This tranquil garden is a nice change from the chaos that can be founds in.Marrakech   Very pretty park and walking paths.
We loved it very much, the colors are amazing and YSL realy made a great effort to make this pearl in a cit of Marrakch, we really loved it very much
Beautiful oasis of gardens fabulously kept and a calm beauty in the new town. Highly recommend time to take it all in, you need a couple of hours. It can get very busy, be ready to queue to get in.

We walked form the Kasbah to the YSL exhibition and the Marjorelle gardens. Beautiful tranquil gardens, lots of cacti and ferns and brightly coloured pots and planters and buildings. You can see how Morocco inspired YSL....worth buying a joint entrance ticket to all 3 attractions for 180 dirhams and using the YSL museum entrance as less busy and no queue.

We spent our last day in Marrakech visiting the gardens and Berber museum. It is beautifully laid out and calming, with a friendly atmosphere and good café. The Berber museum, inside the gardens, is very informative on Berber culture and traditions and well worth a visit at minimal cost

The garden is very pretty, but also not very large.  Unless you get here early, as close to opening time as possible, there will be too many people to really enjoy the garden.  By 9:30am, there was already so many people that it was difficult to walk around.  The cafe in the garden is nice and offers a traditional Moroccan breakfast that we enjoyed.
review_title: Very pretty, but get here early or else

review_text: When you don't want to wait in line go early. We were there at 09.30u and had no waitingline. At 11.00u when we got out the line was crazy long. The garden is beautiful.
These gardens are well-maintained. They attract a lot of visitors so be prepared for crowded conditions. The gardens include a great variety of plants and they are worth seeing.

Gardens are a peaceful oasis in bustling Marrakesh.  The gardens, plant-wise, are nothing special, particularly if you are familiar with common desert plants.  However, the liberal use of bright yellow and marjorelle blue make the hardscape striking.  The best part is the small but excellent Berber museum on the grounds.  I would not recommend this stop at all, except for the museum.  Overall, the site was packed with tourists, even when we arrived first thing in the morning.
review_title: Peaceful Gardens, Crowded with Tourists (Go early)

review_text: It's a nice getaway. My boyfriend and I saw plantations and beauties we had never experienced before and we felt very relaxed and cool as we walked in the garden. We loved the fountain and stylish colours everywhere. It's one of the best attractions in Marrakech.

We arrived around midday on a Saturday in October to visit Jardin Majorelle. We hadn't booked tickets in advance and the queue was huge (probably would have been about a 1-2 hour wait) so we decided to try the Yves Saint Laurent museum which was a few minutes' walk further down the road. The queue was much shorter (about 20mins) and it turned out it was possible to actually buy tickets for the YSL museum as well as the Jardin Majorelle there. We ended up getting a combi ticket to visit both as well as the Berber museum inside the Jardin Majorelle. We enjoyed all three and would definitely recommend queuing at the YSL museum to skip the long lines at Jardin Majorelle.
review_title: Buy tickets in advance or at Yves Saint Laurent museum to avoid long queues

review_text: I recomnend to all the travelers that go to Marrakech. Very inspiring garden, opens you mind i makes you travel in your mind.
A lovely garden but not very big. The gift shop on the site was wonderful but you would need to be Rothschild to afford anything 😜. It was very crowded when we went at eleven in the morning.
Such a beautiful place so relaxing even though you will in the grounds witn many other people. The exhibition is exquisite and a fabulous homage to a great designer Well worth the money
Must visit this oasis in the city.  The gardens are absolutely beautiful.  The gift shop also has beautiful items to purchase.

We went on an organised tour so got in an hour earlier than the general public which was great for photographs although still quite busy. The gardens are full of palms, cactuses, bougainvillea etc all set against the very vibrant turquoise, royal blue and yellow art deco villa in the centre. well worth a visit!
Definitely worth a visit if you are in the area, a truly beautiful and relaxing place. It can be very hot and exposing though, so make sure you take sun hats!

Visited the gardens on a sunny Friday .The staff were very helpful.We had a gentleman who was disabled . They allowed us to the front of the queeue. The gardens are extremely peaceful. They are deceptive in size. It is worth spending aproximately 2 hours here.You could sit relaxing with a book if you choose,There is a cafe buy it is expensive.We choose to eat at a bar nearby.

Jardin Majorelle was more enjoyable than we expected from photos online. It was a nice break from the bustling energy of the city so I recommend saving it for day 2 or 3 of your visit. Different from many botanical gardens I've been to as the climate here is very different, with the main attractions being cacti. The Berber museum on-site was enjoyable and I recommend visiting that as well while here.
review_title: A peaceful break from the bustling city

review_text: Nice gardens to visit.  Very peaceful and enjoyable.  Buy ticket online at least 24 hours before your visit  or you will be in a 30-60 line.  If you are not a fan of YSL, do not get the combo ticket just to save time.
review_title: Beautiful Gardens in a busy surrounding.

review_text: A extremely beautiful garden with many interesting types of cacti and landscaping. On a very hot day it is a refuge from the heat, as it is cooler in the garden. A do not miss in Marrakech. Definitley good photo ops.

This is well worth an hour of two, depending on including the Berber Museum within the gardens. Hint: The ticket lines can be very long. If you want to see the YSL museum 100 yards away, and we found it extremely well presented, go to the shortest museum line and buy the combined ticket. It includes the gardens, Berber, and YSL museums. You get to enter without wait after that, which can easily save you an hour.

You need to get here early, or otherwise you have to stay in long lines and you find no space for your self because of all these people inside the garden.  Don't expect a big garden, it's more like a little oasis in the dusty Marrakech... It is a nice place, being here in the early morning you can enjoy the beautiful light creating moments and all different kind if reflection.  For sure a place you have to see. Very refreshing. Around the midday it's just stress.... And a comment at the end for all those stupid people who cut plants to leave a mark ....see I was here....no one needs that... what if that would been done o  your skin...

Created by orientalist painter, Jacques Majorelle and developed under the patronage of Yves St, Laurent and Pierre Bergé, this garden has many exotic plants brought in from all over the world. The layout is beautiful and the colors are stunning with the striking Majorelle blue effects throughout. Loved the blue gazebo. Do not miss the boutique for amazing and unique items inspired by YSL.

The queue to get the tickets for the Jardins was very long at 11 o Clock in the morning. I will definitely recommend to pre order them online. Combined tickets for jardin &YSl museum are very worth it
review_title: A day at the garden and at the ysl museum

review_text: I first came to Jardin Majorelle 5 years ago (November visit) and we practically had the place to ourselves. Fast forward 5 years and it is heaving. Beautiful gardens....but do recommend going as early as possible. We were in by 9am and it was already busy.

We enjoyed our time in the gardens , lovely and very well maintained. However everyone there appeared to think they were professional models and photographers , which made it difficult to truly enjoy the gardens without walking though peoples photos and getting past people queuing for good spots to take pics . Bit much really
If you are in Marrakesh, this is the most beautiful place to visit.  The gardens are simply amazing.  There is a beautiful gift shop and a lovely courtyard setting to enjoy a drink or lunch

I showed up at the Gardens around 11 AM when the line up was very long. I visited the Yves Saint-Laurent museum next door afterwards and came out after 2 PM, only to notice that there was virtually no line up to the Majorelle Gardens during that time. So my recommendation would be to visit the YSL museum earlier and then go to the Majorelle Gardens betwenn 1-3 pm. They are lovely to discover regardless but would have been so much more enjoyable without such a crowd around.

Here my recommendations for you that I made from personal experience: 1. The taxi from the Médina to the garden should NOT cost more than 20dhm!!! 2. Go early in the morning! (Avoid staying in line in the afternoon) 3. If you’re lucky, you’ll find a lovely Chinese, who adores taking pictures and will take awesome pictures of you (and in my case cute partner pictures) 4. Don’t take the cab directly outside the garden, which is a little taxi stand on the right side of the exit to write your name on a silly list, cause they will ask you to pay 100dhm to the Médina, go a bit further away and again, NOT more than 20dhm!
Lovely quit place. Not very big but a wonderful atmosphere. Even the teenagers enjoyed the sights. There was quite a long que, but we were with a tourguide so could skip the que.
Absolutely lovely place to escape the crowds of Marrakech. Make sure to see the Berber Museum within the grounds

Beautiful collection of exotic hot climate trees, shrubs and flowering plants all set around meandering paths and tranquil ponds and fountains, with plenty of seating to allow one to contemplate the beauty of it all. The stunning moroccan blue is uniquely alluring. Do go

If you enjoy taking pictures, go early to avoid the crowds. I went in mid September when tourist season was less, so I can only imagine how busy it can get during peak season. Visit took me about 1hr. Including the line to get in, it took me about 1.5hrs to visit.

Perfectly lovely garden, overrun by tourist.  Fight for photos at every spot.  Instagrammers posing and hogging space for their vanity project. I can't see staying here for more than 30 minutes.  I only really found the native jewelry/art/clothing museum interesting.
review_title: Social media obsessed will love it

review_text: The Majorelle Gardens, however impressive considering the Maroccan climate, are actually very small. And crowded with tourists taking selfies. The Berber museum is fan-tas-tic! The pieces exposed there are amazing and no photos allowed! The YSL museum is nice especially because it has a lovely library and, truth be told, a clean and decent lavatory. So overall it has been a pleasant visit, just expect something very... well, small!
review_title: Berber & YSL Museums are worth it

review_text: We  really enjoyed this garden. It is so beautiful, a vast array of plants so well looked after. A beautiful oasis. Only downside was the very long, slow moving queue to get in.
Can get busy, but lovely garden to visit wonderful lively colours amazing cacti species. Exotic plants, palms an artists garden.
Buy tickets online, 24 hours in advance, to avoid hour long queues. Busy in the morning, queue had shrunk dramatically by 2pm. Didn’t feel like the centre of Marrakech, leafy and calming
The most beautiful garden I have ever seen. That blue colour is unique. All the plants and blue buildings create one big peace of art. It is worth buyng tickets online as queue was about 45 min
review_title: Blue like no other. Top place

review_text: Would advise you visit as soon as it opens, as we had to queue for an hour to get in, not pleasant in the late morning. The closer you get to the ticket office there are misters and some canopy's for shade and cooling the crowd. The garden isn't large, however the bamboo is.The pool and view in front of the house is stunning. Didn't use the cafe there.Toilets were clean.

We really enjoyed the gardens but it was a little busy when we went. I think it would be better enjoyed when it's not so chaotic. But really it was well worth the time we spent there and I would go back again.
A must see when in Marrakesh. The museum was closed when I was there but the garden is stunning. The ‘memorial’ was a bit disappointing, just a large piece of concrete!
Lovely gardens with huge amount of plants which provides perfect shade in the heat. The Majorelle Blue is everywhere in the garden and is stunning!
it very busy garden, but we enjoy the peace and escape from the medina. it is possible to walk from the square around 30 minutes
I came here since i was little and was always blown away but lately it has become a go to for tourists and it became so unpleasant---
review_title: not that amazing anymore, too many tourists!

review_text: This place is a must visit in Marrakech! Such a beautiful garden it would be a shame not to go! It is simpy unlike any gardens elsewhere, and the museums inside are great and provide lots of information too.
So colourful garden filled with nice rare succulents and cacti, pity its overcrowded considering the size of it.
Very nice place , clean.  You see many plants the are interesting . the museum especial . good to visit
Well kept gardens Go early to avoid the crowds Recommend visit to Berber museum, small but beautifully presented.
Outside of Medina in the new Marrakesh you will find this beautiful garden. If you have to choose for only one  garden this is the one you have to visit.
review_title: The most beautiful garden of Marrakesh

review_text: Very nice day out ,bright lovely gardens ,get there early as there is a wait as it does get busy ,if u get dropped of take a  map with you so you can get back to the centre .

I've visited this place several times.  It helps that it's made of two of my favorite things in the world:  Cacti/succulents and the color cobalt blue!  I feel very happy here, but the crowds take away from that a bit...  Still, I'm grateful to have it here and will always visit when I'm in Marrakech.

The Marjorelle Gardens were conveniently located to our accommodation so we had a pleasant walk to the gardens.  It is located away from the busy streets in a quiet area. Entrance queues were not too bad for a top tourist destination.  We were a little underwhelmed with the varieties of plants inside although the gardens were well taken care of. Plenty of shade to keep out of the sun and a good number of benches to pause and admire the greenery. Worth a visit, but not the best botanical garden I have ever visited.
review_title: Pleasant Gardens, limited variety of plants

review_text: We arrived at 9 am on a Sunday and already there was a queue but it wasn't too bad. Inside the stunning gardens are glorious and the mix of colours were wonderful. From the giant bamboo and the water features it was a joy to visit. There are instagrammers everywhere and they seemed oblivious to the gardens just aware of themselves. please don't let them stop you walking where you want and seeing what you want. The Bereber museum is a little gem and the Yves Saint Laurent poster display and shop are good too. We didn't do the Saint Laurent museum as we had plans for the day. By the time we left at 11 it was heaving and coupled with the 40 degree heat I was glad we made the effort to get there early.
Nice place, with a good variety of plants and some lovely water features. Unfortunately, it is a victim of its own success - far too many people for the small size and thin walkways.
Lovely park with beautiful plants and paths to take. Perfect for a visit in conjuntion with the Yves Saint Laurent Museeum and the Berber Museeum. The on site restaurant is pretty good.

I am so happy that this garden was part of our itinerary - we paid for the garden visit and the museum, well worth it. If you are in Marrakech do yourself a favor and go visit this garden, it's beautiful.
The garden is small though very well kept and beautifully planted. It is a cool oasis during the heat of the day. I recommend a visit, it’s worth the while.
A small garden but nice for taking photos But we spent a long time in a row for tickets There is a shop and museum for  Uves Saint Laurent products
review_title: We spent a good time there

review_text: Jardin Majorelle (YSL gardens) are interesting example (some stunning desert plants and trees) of rich family's garden opened up to the public but really does overplay on the YSL brand. We had to queue for 30 minutes for less than an hour visit (reading all the panels and plant names)
review_title: Expensive but good to visit if in a group and beat the q's

review_text: Lovely gardens, well worth the visit, but buy your tickets in  advance if you are able, as we had to queue for almost a hour to gain entry and then as you can imagine it was quite busy inside. Of more interest I thought was the YSL museum just around the corner and tickets for this can be combined with the entry ticket for the Majorelle gardens.
review_title: Beautiful gardens, but horrendous queues to get in

review_text: Great garden. Lots to see. Cacti, reflecting ponds & native flowering plants. A must do in Marrakech.

15 minutes in the thickets of bamboo and cacti. Actually I don’t get what I pay for, because in 15 minutes walk there is absolutely free cyberpark with a lot of different trees and topiaries bushes. But it’s like must see place, so you have to visit it))
There was quite a queue to get in but the gardens are beautiful, tranquil and well worth a visit with some lovely water features.
Lovely peaceful place to visit in the heat and away from the hustle and bustle in the medina. Beautifully kept gardens and worth a visit.
The garden is so beautiful with many plants. The ticket costs seven euro. There is also a coffee inside.
Just skip it and save your money. There's already plenty of pics available of the place. Seeing it with your own eyes is a waste of time and money.
review_title: Small and overpriced for what it is

review_text: Must see.  This garden was destined for a bulldozer when Yves St. Laurent swooped in and purchased the garden and resorts it to its current grandeur.  The Berber Museum located here is definitely work a visit.

4 days ago Firstly, the gardens are beautiful. Sadly a victim of their own success. It is far too crowded. Jostled by large tour groups, and the bamboo and cacti have been horrifically vandalised. Such a shame. If like us, you feel the need to 'tick that box's and say you have done it, then go. Just make sure you visit Le Jardin Secret as well- it is a traditional, historic Moroccan garden that was excavated and returned to its former glory
review_title: Probably Great Once Upon A Time

review_text: We enjoided Majorell Gardens early at 9am. It is really beautiful, well kept and the Blue is just fabulous. At this early time it is easy to walk around, later on you have to queue and masses burst out around the place.
It was the best ever experienced walking exploring  and experiencing the flora and fauna, flowers, bamboos, cactus, palm etc. All were beautifully planted, arranged, and well taken care of.

Firstly if you can book in advance so you can skip the ticket queue which even at 10 in the morning was over an hour long in 35 degrees was pretty hard work.  Once inside the gardens were nice, cool but not surprisingly busy.  Busy with young ones all looking the Instagram shot that would prove they are an influencer, so you’ve lots of kids, girls in particular dressed up to the 9’s with camera phon constantly in hand.  People push in front and there’s lots of stopping so you don’t kill someone’s perfect pose.  The colours in the gardens, the blue and yellows are stunning and overall it was worth the £7 entrance fee.  On Wednesday’s the museums are closed as was YSL villa so maybe there’s a bit more to see than we did, but I would still recommend it even if it’s just to say you’ve been to a super popular Insta spot and are down with the kids!
review_title: OK but it’s for the Insta generation I reckon

review_text: Beautifully restored gardens. You can (slightly) beat the long line to get in by queuing at the YSL Gate next door. You can buy a Majorelle ticket there in roughly a third of the time. Take plenty of water for the ticket queue - there is very little shade. We arrived about an hour after opening and it was rammed with “influencers” trying to get the perfect selfie. Nice cafe that wasn’t overpriced.

Queues for tickets a little haphazard, unclear signage and staff advising which queue. Queues moved slowly so allow plenty of time. Get a pamphlet at the ticket office which has a little map and useful background information. Once inside you are free to roam and although busy there was room for photos. Best of course on a good sunny day. Very well maintained plantation and many but not all plants are explained along with the country of origin. The cafe was very good, attentive staff and excellent food. Make sure you tip as service charge not included.
We went to the garden and there was a 45 minute plus queue to get in. Pre buy your tickets!!,! I couldn’t wait 45 minutes in 42 degree heat
review_title: Queues were too long to wait

review_text: A popular attraction and a bit of a wait to get in, but we'll worth it for the beautiful gardens. Lots and lots of photo opportunities. A true Oasis from the craziness thar is Marrakech. Great food in their relaxing garden cafe!
A unique garden amid the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. Loved the exhibition and gardens.  A real oasis.
This was beautiful! We went on a Tuesday morning. Despite being fall, the plants were still stunning. It was a little oasis from the bustling city.

Whenever we travel to a new country, I like to reference Lonely Planet's 500 Best Places on the Planet list. Morocco has five spots on this list and Jardin Majorelle is one of them...but I'm really not sure why. :( As others have mentioned, the line to get in is very long and very hot, and the garden is quite small - you can literally see the entire thing in 10 minutes which makes the 70 DH/$7 price tag pretty steep. It was disheartening to see all of the graffiti carved into the succulents - what good is an entrance fee if the gardens aren't maintained well enough to prevent idiots from ruining it for everyone else? The cute cafe is the one bright spot, but there are plenty of other cafes to visit that won't require an entrance fee. LP steered me wrong this time - Jardin Majorelle is a big MISS.

This is a very special place outside of the Marrakesh medina. The garden itself is beautiful, and the berber museum is another gem. You can also eat inside but be prepared to pay a lot of money for the food.
One of those places where you can’t stop taking pictures as it’s so pretty. It was one of our highlights in Marrakech.
Make sure to get tickets in advance! Lines are huge ! The cafe there is delicious so plan to have lunch there too .

Used the green lime on the Tour bus. There are long queues to get in, however we knew this and were prepared for it. It’s also busy inside, but the garden is really well laid out and beautiful. Worth a visit.

The wait queuing for tickets is all worthwhile! Sun umbrellas are available for visitors queuing prior to entry.  The garden is immaculately kept and the brightly coloured   pagodas and structures are a bonus for taking pictures.  The Berber museum inside the garden is extremely interesting and highly maintained. It is highly recommended to get there early if you want to take great pictures.  It gets pretty uncomfortable with the heat waiting to the tickets.
We enjoyed very much visiting Jardin Majorelle. The gardens and the house are amazing and we took some very nice photos there. A must see from our point of view.
review_title: The most beautiful landmark in Marrakesh

review_text: Get to Jardin Majorelle early to miss the line or buy your tickets online at least 2 days prior. Jardin Majorelle is beautiful, a lot smaller than I thought it would be and I wasn't expecting the plants to be mainly international cacti and bamboo. The cafe is cute and has a lovely courtyard

The garden was beautiful, once we stepped in we almost forgot where we were. Gorgeous garden with beautiful vibrant colors. The line was a bit long but moved fairly quickly and in my opinion worth the wait. Only drawback is it gets a bit crowded so a bit hard capturing great pics without photo bombers. Still worth the trip and I’d highly recommend.
Beautiful gardens. So tranquil after spending time in the thick of the souks & markets. The museum was sadly closed on the day of our visit but it didn't spoil the experience. Not one to miss!

Gorgeous place to while away the hours. Quite crowded but not too bad. The cafe was excellent with a great range of soft drinks or hot drinks and we had no problem getting a table in the courtyard. HOT TIP if the queue is super long when you get there, just wander down the road to the museum as the queues are waaaaaaaaay shorter and you can buy tickets to the garden there.
Tranquil and beautiful gardens with vibrant colours. There was a big queue when we went so I would recommend going in the morning.
Fabulous place, worth a couple of hours exploring and loved the storks nesting! Lots of levels and not expensive to enter, beware on a hot day, shade is limited.

Discovered and bought by Yves Saint Laurent in the sixties the VM has become an Iconic shrine of culture, style and fashion in the Heart of Marrakech. The museum host a series of very interesting exhibition about Moroccan culture and Identity. Make sure you leave plenty of time for you visit so that you can enjoy a stroll in the beautiful exotic garden, the museum and a break at the restaurant. Strongly recommended!
review_title: A Fairy Tale garden and Villa.

review_text: I simply adore the tranquility and beauty of this place. The Berber museum is fascinating and you can also enjoy a drink or a bite to eat in the onsite restaurant.

The downside of visiting Jardin Majorelle are the number of tourists there at all times of day, every day.  To avoid long queues go early.  Once inside it is beautiful and remarkable.  Strange and exotic plants, vibrant colours and a wonderful feel to the place.  We have a home in Marrakech and every time we have visitors I take them there, so I visit several times a year.  You must have seriously deep pockets if you want to buy clothes in the YSL shop!
review_title: Beautiful and a must go to place in Marrakech

review_text: It's one great spot of Marakech to explore, garden Majorelle of Yves saint Laurent which which printed a nice relationship with the green nature. So it's recommended to see it.
Much has been said about the gardens, the colors and the ambience of this place, but the most important thing to remember about this place is: Get your tickets in advance to avoid the lines!
Lovely garden, and I especially loved the YSL museum. Expect to queue in the hot sun for quite a while for entrance tickets if it's peak season.
review_title: Beautiful place, but can crowded with the Instagrammers hogging the "IT spots

review_text: The Jardin Majorelle Gardens are beautiful, the art work and surroundings are very picturesque. It gets busy so if you want beat the crowds go early. There is a lot to see in the facility and surrounding attractions
review_title: The Gardens and art work are beautiful

review_text: Took a taxi from our hotel. Very different from the remainder of Marrakesh. Great gardens and YSL tribute, clearly would be very peaceful but for the throngs of people.

This is worth taking in while in Marrakech, the gardens are very well kept and the vegetation is very different from any Canadian or northern USA gardens I’ve been to.  The Yves-François Saint Laurent mansion is also well kept and worth seeing.  Taking pictures at the mansion is a challenge, there are as noted in other reviews many people taking selfies.
THE most amazing / beautiful blue you'll ever see: The famous "Bleu Majorelle". The garden is very nice as well.
review_title: Very nice place to visit in Marrakech

review_text: Worth a visit but do go early to avoid the long queue and then in turn busy gardens! The gardens are divine but the large crowds of people meant it would be much better appreciated early morning or closer to closing. Cafe and toilets inside.
Nice garden from YSL worth a visit! Very crowded with tons of instagramers... Different from rest of the city.
The Garden costs 70 dirham to get in, about £6. It was nice enough but a lot smaller than expected can get around it in 10 minutes!
Love the plants and the tranquil feeling of this place. A must on any visit to Marrakech. No good restaurants nearby so time visits appropriately.

The gardens are beautiful but jam-packed with tourists (think subway platform during rush hour).  It’s really difficult to take decent photos because of the swarms of people.   Tourism really can have a negative impact.
review_title: Pretty place ruined by crowds of tourists

review_text: Best is to get there early as we had to queue for 40 minutes to get in. A bit pricey for what it was. Beautiful cactus plants and cool colours. I think you go once and won’t come again. It’s just a tropical garden really.. we didn’t do the museum.

I loved the Majorelle Gardens (YSL resting place) It was rather busy but such a good visit. I loved the visit we took our time to go round and also sat for a whiles on the benches. Definitely a visit if you can fit it in

It was worth wandering over to the new quarter. Very tranquil, very inspiring and beautifully done. For some reason we both preferred Jardin Secret but a visit to Marrakech without seeing both would be a visit wasted.

I love the Majorelle Garden, but it has got so busy! I always go late in the afternoon, this time 4.30pm, so that I am there at the end of the day when everyone leaves. Despite the manic crowds I always find some peaceful spots to relax and listen to the birds. Its a beautiful place and I do recommend it. I tried to get a drink in the café this time, but it closes earlier than the advertised time of 5.30pm. Beautiful shop too :)
review_title: Beautiful garden, a must see despite the crowds

review_text: Well worth the queue at around £7 (70D). An hour or so walking around fantastic gardens (nearly all in the shade). It’s down a side street so we grabbed a tut tut taxi from the markets which was only £5 (50D) - dropped us off right outside.
A fantastic place to visit.Amazing gardens,great museum(BARBER),inside the gardens.Go early,long waiting outside.
Fascinating mix of plants in particular desert orgin.  Very very poular so overcrowded in midle of the day.

Beautiful gardens in central Marrakech, can be visited along with the Berber Museum, the YSL Museum, and an exhibition room (which was displaying a YSL post-card exhibition, at the time). 15 minute wait at the queue, so not a major issue, buy some water outside and stay hydrated!!
review_title: Beautiful Gardens with an Art Deco Twist

review_text: Don't get me wrong, gardens were very nice especially the cacti succulent section. Really though, who cares if Yves lived there. We waited an hour in 40 degree heat to see it. Wouldn't do if again. Ticket sales people were way under trained.

great cactus variaty, and nicely done.  if you have shor time, is better to skip this garden. it takes 1 hr or less because is not that big. is better to visit the museum of Berber art, but it closed at 4pm.

It is easy to understand why le jardin Marjorelle has become so popular: it is  stunningly beautiful and peaceful. Go there when it opens at 8.30am to fully appreciate the manicured landscape and the striking "Bleu Marjorelle". When we left at 10.00, there was a large crowd queueing for tickets.

Combine a visit to the Majorelle Gardens with a visot to the Yves Saint Laurent Museum next door you can purchase a joint ticket at the box office. The gardens are in the new town and well signposted. The gardens were set out in the early 20th century by the French Architect of the same name. They with the electric blue villa were later purchased by the fashion designer Yves Saint Laurent. The gardens are cool and shady with a variety of plants both native and imported. There are walks and pools to sit by and relax, a courtyard cafe and a gift shop with an exceptional choice of presents. Well worth a visit.

Beautiful. Pretty.  Must see.  YSL.  Well done.  The color are vibrant and showcase the native of the land. Rich use of cobalt blue and yellow  amongst the bamboo  showcase how the Morocco is rich in culture
Definitely worth to go! Astonishing! And go to both museums! Also, don't forget to bring a lot of water with you and cover your head!  Make sure you spend their plenty of time!

I have seen much more beautiful gardens elsewhere.  Most of the plants are desert based.  They keep up the grounds very well, but I would have preferred spending my time elsewhere.  Morocco is a beautiful country with so many interesting things to see.
review_title: Interesting, but I wouldn't wait in the line

review_text: It’s a good to see, it’s interesting but not outstanding Go mid day as it will be cool Tickets are around 70 Mad

This was one of the major attractions in Marrakesh to see, so a visit is recommended. However, the main plant in the garden is the cactus, and it's full of them - maybe as I'm not a big fan it didn't really get me excited.  Be aware of opening times as this venue is closed on certain days and times.
Jardín Majorelle clearly is a popular tourist destination, judging from the queues at the ticket counters and the many visitors on the walkways in the park. The gardens are lovely, but crowded

What a cool lovely place. I didn’t even know it existed and found it to be a great peaceful spot in a busy city. High end shopping inside with a Yves San Laurent  boutique. Go early and get tickets in advance. Crowds are bumping along after 11. The museum was a visual feast.

Beautiful shaded gardens with such a wide variety of plants and things to look at.  Lots of tourists will be there with you, however with a little patience it is possible to get perfect pictures and memories to treasure.  Watch out for the frogs!

Beautiful serene gardens with a stunning design. You will, however, be enjoying your experience along with many many other tourists and lots of aspiring instagram influencers. It is possible to enjoy yourself amid all the other tourists, just know that you will be dodging several ‘photoshoots.’ The Berber museum is a MUST SEE. The line at the YSL museum is typically shorter than the line at the garden. You can buy a combo ticket (YSL museum, garden, Berber museum) In the YSL Museum line. Walk through the YSL museum first, then bring your ticket right up to the entrance to the garden, skipping that line. The YSL museum line gets longer starting at 9:30/10:00. There is a taxi stand with plenty of cars available right outside the garden - negotiate the price to your destination first.

A must see venue. If you haven’t pre booked tickets go to the museum first as this will save waiting time in the queue.  The gardens, water features  and villa are stunning and a break from a very busy Marrakesh.
review_title: A beautiful garden with an interesting informative museum

review_text: We found the gardens to be nice but the experience was ruined by the hordes of Chinese tourists posing for selfies and photos in front of the primary viewing areas. Very rude and unacceptable but typical these days.

A must see while visiting Marrakech!  This was a central garden in the city that was about to be bulldozed when Yves-Saint-Laurent purchased the garden and restored it to us current grandeur. The Berber museum is definitely work the visit.  The artifacts are in pristine shape.
review_title: Beautiful afternoon in the Hardin majorelle

review_text: Very nice garden not many flowers as a bit late in the year .nicely  laid out lavender  smelt nice .wheel chair friendly

Amazing garden near to Yves Saint Laurent Museum. Please plan your visit to avoid the crowds in weekdays and early morning or late afternoon Amazing plants, Veggies, Cactus and flowers 1 hour max is all what you need
writer_informations: Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates,28 contributions

review_text: It's a nice garden with a very colorful house. It's always full of tourists and it's better to buy the tickets in advace to avoid long lines under the sun. The entrance is a bit expensive for what you'll see.

Our tour group went early in the morning to avoid most of the crowds. It is beautiful to walk through and see all the bamboo, cactus, fountains, ponds, and flowers. Too bad some have spoiled the plants by carving graffiti on them. Not sure how they did this since there are security guards all over.

There are WAY too many tourists. There are two reasons to go: enjoy and relax the beautiful garden or take pictures to show off on Instagram. Both is not possible since there are way too many people! It is not worth the wait or the money.

We knew we wanted to visit, but weren't prepared for the line up to just buy tickets. Followed then by a rather crowded venue to explore. The place is undeniably beautiful, the vivid blue colours and lush green surrounds is definitely something to marvel at. Especially in a city that is rather covered in vast spans of stone and concrete type materials. It took us approximately 20 minutes waiting in line to purchase tickets, and that's only because we managed to line up in the better of the two lines (the other line moved far far slower). Once inside there was a large number of people wandering about, as you do, so it was rather difficult to get those 'signature insta-omg' worthy photos. However, if you're patient you'll get them. I have to say though, we spent just as much time inside as we did in line, so 40 minutes all up. Worth it? I'm still not sure. But I guess some of the photos I got were nice. Pro-tip: There is a sign at the end of the line that states you can get faster access by purchasing a combined "YSL Museum and Jardin Majorelle" ticket at the YSL Museum counter, which gives you priority access to the gardens. Shorter line apparently.
review_title: Beautiful once inside, but be prepared for crowds and lines.

review_text: Very pretty garden, but overwhelmed with tourists. We tried going late morning, but the lines to get in were ridiculous. So we bought tickets at the YSL museum, saw the museum, ate lunch and returned to the gardens in the afternoon. Much better, short line, but still crowded. Loved the colors of the walls & planters. Stop in the gift shop for some very pretty items for sale.

The gardens are beautiful, we did not have advanced tickets so had to make a  half hour line. The house was not opened that day, we did not know why. The gardens are an oasis in the middle of the city. We took a tok-tok arranged by our Riad that took us there since it is a little far to walk in 90 degree weather. We could stay in the gardens as long as we wanted and there is a cafe and toilet facilities.
review_title: An oasis in the middle of the city

review_text: The garden is beautiful and chilling on a hot day. We discovered we could also lunch there which was a nice surprise.

We waited close to 45 minutes in line in 42 degrees so I highly recommend that you book in advance as the garden itself is about a 20-30 minutes at  most.  The cacti are amazing and it is an oasis away from the bustling noises of the city.

It is an interesting place for a visit, but keep in mind that it is not so big as it seem. They have some beautiful cacti all over the place, so if you like this kind of plant, it will be very interesting. I would recommend getting there early in the morning, as huge lines form to buy tickets after 10am.

Excited to visit here but it was a little disappointing. Visited as a group, first thing in the morning. The gardens were already crowded and there was little chance of getting a nice picture without ten other people unless you wanted to stand around for 20 minutes waiting for it to clear. Gardens well maintained, staffed and sign posted. I’d struggle to spend more than 20-30 minutes here though.
The garden is breathtaking and beautiful, but it’s way too crowded to enjoy the peace and tranquility of the space.
Beautiful place. Once an art studio of  Majorelle painter, Late Yves saint laurent saved and restaured. Now has a beautiful graden, store and restaurant.... please buy tickets in advance!
We really could have skipped this garden...we went to others that were free and with fewer tourists. Save your time and DH for something else.

Everyone recommended to us to go to Jardín Majorelle on our trip. Although it was pretty and not particularly expensive to get in (60dhs each), it was a lot smaller than we expected, and there was not much to see in terms of plants or other attractions. Mostly cacti and most of the ground was bare. Some nice spots where people wanted to take photos for Instagram!
Stunning relaxing gardens a must see, but our only disappointment was all the detailed plaques were in french, no English at all. Beautiful Lilly pond and cactus from different countries xx
Definitely worth a visit if you are in Marrakesh. Enjoy the bright colours and the spectacular Majorelle Blue. Best to visit in the afternoons when there are less people!
Very nice place but 70DH (about 6,5 euro) to see only plants and many tourists, the cost of the ticket is not worth it.

A beatifull garden with many panels along the route showing the name and origin of the plants. Walk through the garden and take a break on one of the small benches. Don't be surpised by all the young girls posing for the perfect Instagram post.
review_title: peace and quiet in a chaotic city

review_text: Go when it opens at 9....before all the crowds arrive...We arrived at 9...toured the gardens and the Berber museum.  We departed for the Yves St Laurent Museum a bit after 10 and the gardens were already teeming with people
An amazing garden with many beautiful plants. Would be a good getaway from the heat. It is of course one on the main tourist attraction, so expectedly many visitors.

Well worth visiting these amazing gardens. You walk off a hot, dusty street and are literally transported into a quiet, cool and refreshing area with a fountain and palm trees, before going through to a huge garden bursting with all kinds of exotic trees and ponds full of koi. Fabulous!
Went on a Saturday and it was impossibly crowded. We really couldn't get a feel for the probable beauty of the place.

The gardens were nice, but not extremely clean or cared. The house presents a good photo moment, but only if you come when they open - otherwise is so crowded that you end up with a million heads on your frame. In addition, people can approach the walls and touch them, making these dirty. I would not go back, nor have gone if i knew before. Just a tick in a box in Marrakech.

Get here early or arrive late afternoon as the queue at 11am was very long on a hot day. Beautiful gardens with palms, cacti, bamboo etc with a central long pond and a smaller pond with koi carp. plenty of shade to keep cool.  There is an Yves St Laurent shop in the grounds as he renovated the gardens with his partner. It is classy but expensive. There is also a good small bookshop. A  very pleasant spot which is not that well signposted from the main road.

Well maintained gardens with plenty of native/indigenous plant life. The history and association w/St. Laurent is interesting. Consider taking time to visit the adjacent museum. It’s impressive. But if you prefer tranquil gardens and water features, check out The Secret Garden.
We very much enjoyed visiting this garden.  We loved the large cacti and the bamboo.  There was alot of shade throughout the garden, even though it was very hot outside!
Nicely set out.  Some amazing whopper cactus!  Im not really a fan of cactus plants - but these were amazing.  Nice and shady and cool to walk around
review_title: Interesting private garden, featuring cactus plants

review_text: The garden itself is really lovely but it’s so busy! We booked in advance for an early slot so skipped the long queue but it was still so busy. Most people seem to think they are Instagram models in there so spend lots of time blocking views and posing. You end up shuffling around. The cafe was more pleasant as less tour groups were able to spend the time to relax in there.

I entered the garden right at 8 am when it opened. It was beautiful and calm. I spent two hours there and enjoyed some juice in the café. It is recommended to go really early because when I left around 10am it was extremely crowded.
Pretty but small garden quite crowded The berber museum although small was quite interesting and worth the 3 dollars I prefer the secret garden in the medina
Nice plants and greenery. Although the gardens are not that big. Its good to see as a tourist for sightseeing.  It has the YSL memorial
This garden is small and it's pretty.  However, it is far too crowded which negatively impacts the time you have here.  Maybe if you go first thing in the morning it's not as bad.

We walked to Jardin Majorelle from our hotel in the Medina, it only took us about 30 minutes, including loosing our bearings, but everyone we asked for directions could not have been more helpful. The queue for the gardens was very long and very hot, they could do with more umbrellas and mist sprays to keep people cool. Personally, we feel the entrance fee is a bit on the high side and the gift shop is very over priced for the average person. The gardens themselves are very beautiful, although it is sad that people feel the need to carve their names in the cacti. It is certainly worth a visit, and you will be amazed at how quiet it is inside the gardens, while outside there is a very busy road.
Nothing special to see. Just an ordinary garden, and to high price for it. I would not go again.....

This is a beautiful semi-tropical walled, private (admission fee) garden-park located centrally in Marrakech. The plantings are beatiful, highlighted by small pools of water. Highly recommended, one of the highlights of Marrakech.

Had a lovely time visiting the gardens, but was in and out working 30 minutes. It was overcrowded and there wasn’t a lot to see. I thought it would be more of a botanical gardens but it wasn’t and unless you had a guide it was just a case of walking around looking at a few nice bushes. I’ve given it a 3/5 because it was an average visit and the price reflected this.
A beautiful space in the middle of Marrakech. Great respite from the heat but unfortunately not from the tourists - best go very early!

Absolutely beautiful gardens.  A must see when in Marrakech.  The gardens, the Berber museum, and the YSL gallery are all fantastic. Go early in the morning to beat the crowds and the heat!  A wonderful change of pace from the frenetic pace of the Medina.
review_title: Beautiful Garden Oasis from the frenzy of Marrakech

review_text: This attraction had the biggest queue during our short stay in Marrakech. Inside was tranquil with interesting plants, beautiful lily pond reminiscent of Monet's garden but not that informative. You may feel differently if you also visited the museum's but it was a little underwhelming.

The best advice we had about coming to the gardens was get there early, so we were there at 9am and only had a couple of people in front of us.  By the time we came out less than an hour later the queue was down the street.  So get there early, as you'll also be jostling with all the other tourists taking photos and selfies!   The garden itself is beautiful and definitely worth a trip, also pop along the road to the YSL museum.

You and the other thousand people will walk around this relatively small garden dodging out of the way of people taking selfies against blue walls.  The plants you will see here are all around you in the parks and gardens in the city I don't understand why you would pay to go in here, definitely not for the plants.  Nice shade of blue though. YSL museum is round the corner for all the girls ( i know it sounds a sexist comment but its not really. I just remember the looks on the faces of all the guys in there, probably mine included).

We visited this garden in September and it was absolutely lovely - so many interesting plants and trees.  However, it would be wise to come as early as possible to avoid having to queue up for a long time - we got there at 11am and the queue was massive.  That said, we thought the garden worth the wait.
review_title: Beautiful and tranquil oasis in the city

review_text: Majorelle gardens were on our list what to do in Marrakech almost on the first spot, just after YSL museum so it was an amazing news when we found out you can buy a combine ticket for both attraction. It’s more expensive for a tourist than being local but it’s still very affordable. Don’t expect any large gardens, you can go around and see everything within an hour. If you feel like you need a little break you can grab a meal in their restaurant with an outdoor seating. It’s very busy space and to take a good picture you may have to queue. I did enjoy the visit but probably wouldn’t go back.

I’m staggered as to why this small garden, mainly containing cacti and bamboo is so highly rated. It’s essentially a walled garden with clearly defined pathways from which you can view various cacti, succulents and other uninteresting flora but with the added headache of too many people, a 700 dhm (£6:50) entry fee and a 25 minute wait to buy tickets. If you live in the UK, any decent local public park will knock this place into a cocked hat and if you don’t, and are really so utterly impressed by this attraction, you have my sympathy. Tip: Go in the afternoon (if you must go at all) and you’ll avoid big queues. Don’t queue for garden only tickets at the museum entrance - they won’t sell you them, even though it’s indicated otherwise and you’ll then have to rejoin another queue further along the street!
review_title: Amazed this is so highly rated...!

review_text: Jardín Majorelle itself is lovely. The garden is mostly well kept (some areas look like they have needed the palm leaves clearing for a good while...) so you can get some good photography. However, it is not a peaceful garden. It is very busy and everyone is looking for a photo opportunity, so you can't peacefully wander around. Get there early; we got there for when it opened and queued for about 20minutes, but when we came out, the queue was all the way down the road. If you can order tickets in advance, do this as you will miss the queue! Or, go to YSL museum first and buy the combo ticket (the queue was much shorter here). I am glad I went to tick it off but there are other more beautiful gardens. Try Jardin Secret- it is tranquil and beautiful!
Such a lovely garden to visit during the hot summer days in Marrakesh. The Berber museum is also very interesting and have lovely displays of cultural artifact.
This place is absolutely beautiful and so serene. The colors are stunning and vibrant! There was some construction or something going on on one part so I didn't see it all.

what a joy in the middle of a semi arid area.  If you have time to sit on a green bench and watch people and the birds, do that.  the museum is a small and serene.  The whole garden is not large, but do not miss it. Our thanx to St Lauren and the other person who had the vision to revive and take care of this gem.

We really enjoyed the gardens but felt there were too many people allowed in at one time. Trying to take photos was just full of tourists. difficult to get around and see everything because there’s so many people. Cost us roughly £7pp.
A true escape from the daily stressful city life. It is really a pearl in the middle of Marrakech. So peaceful and quiet and extremely well preserved. A must when visit Marrakech.

really busy , luckily we stayed nearby so could get there early , best before 10 if possible , Museum shut Wednesdays so if you want to do the whole thing go another day the YSL museum very interesting but once again can get very busy , the gardens are a delight especially if you get there when not too crowded , quite small so it soon fills up , but worth a visit  to see all including the Berber would take best part of 4 hours .

Worth a visit, if you go to the Yves Saint Laurent Museum next door. Why average?  Paved pathways, with fences between you and the gardens.  No identification of the various flora in the garden. Crowded with lots of instagram opportunities, so not the garden experience we were looking for. Tip—go to the museum first, buy a combination ticket and you can then skip the line to go to the garden. It’s near the modern or European part of Marrakech, so there is good dining and shops nearby.

This garden is an oasis of calm. It is full of impressive bamboo and many different types of cactus. Go early if you want to avoid the crowds later. If there is a long queue at the ticket booth go to the YSL ticket booth just up the street (much shorter queue) and buy a combined ticket. Well worth a visit.
A lovely, peaceful garden just outside the Medina with the YSL touch. Very popular with tourists so best go early.

What a charming place and garden on the north part of Marrakesh ! The Garden and buildings are a delight but be aware it’s also instagram hell for you are surrounded by people all trying to get that perfect shot ! There is history about this place do seek it out it’s very interesting!!
Small but perfectly formed a great place to escape from the hubbub of the medina. Buy combined ticket

My favourite garden in Marrakech without a doubt. Located in a quiet neighbourhood, once you enter the garden you will be amazed by the natural beauty combined with the bright colours of the masonry. Make sure to visit the Berber museum (This is an extra supplement to your Jardin Majorelle entry ticket, but can be bought as part of a combination ticket). The only downside is just how busy the garden is and getting caught behind visitors taking several photos whilst trying to get the perfect Instagram shot no doubt.
Beautiful gardens, perfect for an afternoon or morning stroll. Great spots for photographs and to rest your eyes
We loved it ! It was amazing ! The colors, the plants very peaceful! The museum is also worth a visit!

On 22 Sep 2019 we went to visit the YSL Museum as many told us to go, and read about the Jardin Majorelle, which was an unexpected nice bonus. The tickets for the garden alone are 40 dirhams (~ 4€/5$). Which is not bad, considering the amount of maintenance the garden needs. We bought a combo ticket @ 180 dirhams (~18€/20$) which incl. the Berber Museum and YSL Museum (which after visiting - both are very small, I think the price is overrated). The garden is not big and you could walk it all in 15min or less due to the many tourists and photo opportunities you could spend about 30-45min here easily. If I had to choose I would combine it with the Berber Museum as this tells the story of the Nomadic Tribs of Marocco. And is more fascinating, then the YSL Museum. Going here is a nice walk outside of the Medina so you see something else as the souks. Worth visiting.
Best part of Marrakech. Blew us away. The colours are incredible. Berber museum is small but worth the 30 darhim in to see it. We took so many photos

Beautiful well kept gardens and most certainly worth a visit. You may experience a rather long queue but it is worth the wait. The gardens are beautifully kept and surprisingly quite and tranquil among the mayhem outside the walls. Lovely photo opportunities!

Small & nice garden. Although spoilt by the amount of people. Too many people for the space. People holding photoshoots, with the gardens as background. WHYYYYY??? Please enjoy the  beauty of the garden instead of the urgency to place yourself in the center for the right insta pic:-(
review_title: Too busy in the mornings; walking in rows between the tourist groups

review_text: Buy your tickets at the museum further up the street (the line is a lot shorter) and go there first. If you want to see the gardens (they are ok but not mind blowing) then be prepared to watch a line of instagramers taking the same picture. It gets really annoying if you are just there to enjoy the gardens.
Very crowded, nice garden but unless you are an Yve San Lauren fan or like cacti Wouldn’t bother. Full of people posing for pictures blocking views and pathways.

We went because it's on 'the list' of attractions. The gardens themselves are pleasant and a welcome reprieve from the sun and heat. A lot of bamboo. Not worth queuing for however. Gardens are well kept.
review_title: Ok. But not worth queueing for

review_text: Defintly worth the visit if you are in Marrakesh. Beautiful. Took so many beautiful colorful pictures. We had a guide that made us skip the line which made our experience smooth.
review_title: Different than any garden I have ever been to.

review_text: I was thrilled about this place, and yes, it was beautiful. But we had to wait 30 minutes in the heat, only to get in and be squeezed together, running into selfie sticks and etc. It was not tranquil, and it was not worth the wait.
The most exotic plants and stunning beautiful colours. A pleasant place to hide from the burning sun. A nice (although expensive) souvenir shop.
Beautiful gardens.  The only complaint is that instagrammers have made this a hot spot, interfering with views and flow.   Arrive early to avoid them.
review_title: Wonderful gardens, thank you Mr. Saint Laurent.  Instagrammers stay home, you're blocking my views.

review_text: We waiting about 30 minutes to buy our tickets and spent about 45 minutes visiting. It was super crowded which made taking photos very challenging. It was nice and I would have appreciated it more if it was a public garden. This would not make my short list which visiting Marrakech.

We qued for an hour to get in and unfortunately were rather disappointed when we finally got to the font! It took us all of 30 minutes to walk around the garden ( at a very sedate pace ) and every corner is just full of tourists trying to take a selfie with a cactus in the background. The gardens are beautiful just much smaller than we expected and ruined by the overcrowding of tourists.

Do not miss this beautiful oasis in the middle of the craziness of Marrakech. The Berber museum is fantastic. The gift shop is a bit expensive but high quality. Also the shops outside are quite good. Seemed to have higher quality things than in the Medina.

If you really want to see & feel the beauty of the garden, you should visit really early or really late. Otherwise it's so crowded with "influencers" taking pictures everywhere, that you won't see anything. We waited one hour in line for our tickets and were super disappointed in the end.
review_title: Sadly just an Instagram hot spot

review_text: Lot of cactuses,well arranged,nice insta place 😁 Inside this garden is the Berber museum which unfortunately was closed when we were there... Tip: If you plan to visit the garden which is together with the Yves Saint Lauren museum,buy combo ticket for all,so you can skip the queue for the ticket in front of the Jardin Majorelle. Combo ticket will cost you 17 eur per person.
writer_informations: Skopje, Republic of North Macedonia,20 contributions

review_text: What a place! Unbelievably beautiful garden with such a great story behind it. True Moroccan beauty and must see if you are in Marrakech.

Such a beautiful garden in the new city of Marrakech! The variety of the plants and cactus is big! Bright colors everywhere mainly royal blue! All good inside but be ready to que for tickets! We waited outside for something like 40 min! The ticket for foreign visitors was 70 Moroccan Dirham (7€approx) for the entrance to the garden , the Berber museum unfortunately was closed when we visited but the fee was 30 dirham (3€ approx) and inside you will also find the Yves saint Laurent museum which costs 100 Dirham (10€ approx)! You can find a combined ticket for something like 180 dirhams!
review_title: Very beautiful garden, prepare to que for tickets!

review_text: Next to the YSL museum it's easy to combine a visit to the two.  The gardens were not overly large and were a nice break from the heat.
Nice and quiet place in a very busy city. Nice to get away from this hectic place. Garden is beautiful but small and very crowded. The line to get in was huge, so you’d better get tickets online.
Beautiful and well kept gardens. Very touristy, but well worth visiting in the early morning when its much less busy.
It’s pretty but terribly overpriced, very crowded and quite small.   Save your money and precious time while in Marrakech!
review_title: Not sure what the fuss is about!?

review_text: Beautiful gardens located outside the old medina of marrakech. Go there early because it gets busy. Its also a lot more expensive than my old guide book told me!
This is a MUST for anyone visiting marakech! Right next door to YSL Museum. Over 3000 species of plants in a very beautiful serene setting. Come early as lines get long quickly!
By all means get there when they open, we were there for 90 minutes and by the time we left it was ridiculous. Interesting Berber museum and good shopping options.

Was it beautiful? Absolutely. Was it worth the money? Here we can argue. Marrakech has a lot of free parks to relax, like the cyber park for example. We are students, and we spent 70dirham each to get in. It's not necessarily expensive, yet those are not Morocco prices. They are Europe prices. Would I go again for that price? No. Would I recommend you to see it once? Probably.

If you are able to beat the crowds you will enjoy the cool tranquillity of a lovely garden with hundreds of varieties of plants interspersed with the YSL signature blue.  As we left the queues were huge....
Good place for photos. So expect to find a lot of people taking pictures everywhere. Nevertheless, the price is to high, specially for a country like Morocco

Lovely garden. Famous blue of Yves st Lauren. Cactus. Water pools. Go early 10 am to avoid queues. Shut Wednesday. Lovely cafe Get combined ticket at museum shorter queue. Or just do garden so relaxing even though a little busy.

We are a couple in our sixties so I was expecting a rather boring garden with lots of models wearing YSL's designs. I couldn't have been more wrong : both of us were immediately struck by the garden, and its peaceful ambience. Its was simply stunning, as were two museums. The YSL museum is about 150 metres away from the majorrelle entrance, and encapsulates YSL in its design. We visited the place twice and highly recommend it. Try to get there as early as you can and allow yourselves 3 hours as it can get busy.
