A must see whilst in Marrakesh. Along with the Berber museum and Yves Saint Laurents ' Love Gallery' ( watch out for the shop there, it has some lovely posters).The gardens are a delight and an inspiration.
Beautiful, interesting and nice. Museums YSL and Berberan ware closed. One hour waiting for ticketing.
A very beautiful and typical Moroccan large courtyard garden. Very busy so go early. Mainly trees, water and desert palning.

I found the gardens to be well designed aesthetically but small and there was little else. However, my point of reference would be the royal botanical gardens in London, which are very large and have rotating art works. The time spent was pleasant enough but the time spent to make the visit did not seem worth the effort. If you are intending to visit, I suggest the advanced booking system, the queues without a ticket can be significant
Love this garden. The trees and plants are very beautiful. Also the decoration and design. The colors that us are very special.
This is quite a beautiful refuge from busy Marrakech. Colorful with quite a variety of different plants. Don't miss the Berber museum.

We visited this early in the day and got there for 9.30 as we were told that the queues were worse later on. The gardens are very small and overcrowded with everyone taking photos around so was hard to relax and enjoy the space. The cafe was okay and gardens were beautiful however very small and if you are expecting a botanical garden then be prepared to be underwhelmed. As we left the queues were very long and glad we went when we did. Wouldn’t recommend but is a standard place to visit so understand the visits.

Heard great reviews so took a taxi to get there early and to beat the queues. Whilst the place is beautiful, we did find the experience underwhelming. The cafe at the end was lovely. After an hour we were finished and upon leaving the queue was huge so definitely get there early!!

Really lovely, pretty garden, well worth a visit to escape the hustle and bustle of Marrakesh (and get some shade). The Berber museum in the grounds is also amazing, so definitely get the combined ticket (you can also combine with the YSL museum down the road, which I also enjoyed despite not being a fashionista in the slightest). I visited on a Saturday afternoon around 2.30pm and didn't have to queue at all, but I gather this is unusual. But even then, the gardens still felt fairly busy so it was hard to take pictures etc without others being in them. So I would recommend going early in the day as soon as it is open. I spent about two hours or so visiting the garden and both museums, although one could spend longer.
Not going out of my way to go there, but if I find my self there then ok it’s nice, some times it’s busy

We spend approximativ two hours here. Timeframe Thursday 10.45 to 12.45. Enjoying the cool climate and nice garden. Not that crowed, but if organized Bustours are coming, they have already tickets, the fun goes down.
Is a lovely, colorful, well maintain and enchanting place to visit. I positively recommend a visit to it particularly por cactus lovers.

so beautiful, but soooo many french tourist who think they are all models and only go to take pictures. Try an go on an off day and show up super early. museum is way calmer and one can learn much more there.
review_title: beautiful but how can one enjoy?

review_text: Must see gorgeous gardens the best one in marrakech- the queue however to get in was very long at least 1-2 hours wait so book tickets in advance
review_title: Must see whilst in the city

review_text: The wait to ticket booth is really long. We arrived around 10 and waited a good 45 mns to get tickets (70 dh/pps)  The whole visit of the garden is less than 45 mns, but you can take time and relax... All in all, there is really nothing much to see, some nice cactus, a lily pond ... And that's it. We paid 60dh for the taxi from medina , plus 70dh per person to visit it. Is it worth it with the wait time, the cost ... For me, it is no, except if you want a break from the medina.
review_title: Nothing much to see, a break from the medina

review_text: Lovely gardens with plenty of photo opportunitys. Nice place to go to see the history of YSL. Such nice restuarants to eat around there that are about 5-10 minute walk, as well as a shopping centre.
review_title: Lovely scenery and a good day out!

review_text: Has  nice resteraunt/ cafe to get some food or a drink at inside the garden as well. Discount for students and a very nice gift shop

We loved the Jardins Majorelle. A lush , immaculately tended oasis of tropical plants in the Centre of the busy , hot City of Marrakesh. An impressive selection of plants from all over the world are thriving in what was originally a palm grove with a good selection of fountains and a beautiful Lilly pond to add atmosphere. This was our favourite place to visit in Marrakesh.

The ticket line was very long. Once we got in inside, it was too packed and there was nothing much to see.  For me, i think its too pricey If u would love to take a nice picture, its the worst as they are too many people and not much spot that u can choose.
review_title: Too packed and not much things to see

review_text: Beautiful gardens with some pretty impressive plans. Tranquil environment where one can spend an afternoon reading a book and strolling through the gardens. However; there were some plants that were mutilated by probably other visitors who were stupid enough to carve writings on them.
It usually has a long line, so get there early.  There are a lot of people there as well. But worth is!  So very beautiful.
Went to the Majorelle gardens early one morning before all the crowds started.  Very beautiful and peaceful place to visit.  Many species of cactus and very lovely oasis.
Visited the garden- very peaceful. Unfortunately the Berber Museum was closed for renovation. Re opens 21 September 2019. Cafe was expensive. Walked around in 30 minutes.

These gardens have some amazingly shaped cacti, impressive bamboo plants and tall palm trees all set off by fantastic pops of colour. Large plant pots are painted orange, yellow etc and the wonderful Majorelle Blue shines through it all. The walkways (you can’t wander freely through the plants) are mostly wide and smooth. The downside is that there are so many Instagram worthy shots that you are often held up by people posing for the camera or wielding selfie sticks! The cafe is worth a visit-delicious ice-cream; you don’t have to order a full meal, and we told the waiter that we’d like to sit outside in the shade so he let us sit inside he could show us to a suitable seat. There are clean toilets in the garden for anyone to use - separate from the cafe. TOP TIP!!   The queues for the garden start early and move slowly at popular times - as we planned to visit the Yves-Saint-Laurent Museum as well, we walked further along the road, and bought a joint ticket there, the queue was short and moved quickly, then we walked back to the garden entrance and by-passed that queue to go straight in.
So peaceful in the middle of such a busy city, I would recommend going first thing on a morning before it gets too busy as I would imagine it can get quite crowded.
Beautiful Gardens. Very very busy....... Feels like Shanghai in Marrakech. we visited twice, both times it was incredibly busy. even at 10.00am when they open.
review_title: Beautiful Gardens. Very very busy....... Feels like Shanghai in Marrakech

review_text: So pleased we went was stunning!only takes about an hour and best to go first thing to avoid heat and large queues

While the garden on its own is a very nice place, the price is definitely not worth it. Every attraction in Marrakesh costs 70 dirham pp (7 euros), but paying 7 euros for a 4 acres garden filled with cacti is just ridiculous, tourist trap. (if you don't mind the money it's still nice though)
review_title: Just a bunch of cacti, but costs 7 euros pp

review_text: We loved it here. We came early morning and it was tranquil, peaceful and beautiful. I would highly recommend if you come to Marrakesh.

These gardens used to be owned by Yves Laurent.  They are magnificent.  If you are tired of the circus that is Marrakech take the time to visit these diverse and beautiful gardens.  I especially loved the cactuses and succulents that I have seen no where else.

I thought I would see roses but this garden is full of beautiful cactus and succulents plus some beautiful fountains and ponds. There is a memorial for Yves-Saint-Laurent. It took us a less than an hour to go through the entire garden

The gardens aren't overly big but they are beautiful, who knew cactus could be so pretty. You only need 1 1/2 to 2 hours to do the gardens, Berber museum and Yves Saint Lauren museum. Would I say a must see -no, would I line up for an hour or more to visit -no but if you have time visit.
I guess the only advice here is to book ahead as standing outside in 40c heat and the line not moving was nuts. Should’ve booked 24 hours ahead of time so there’s the learning - we never got in

So today we vistied the gardens which was 70 dirham each. We arrived around 9.30am, It took around 20min max to walk around, which was the amount of time it took us to get a ticket too. The gardens are very nice and we took plenty of photo's but overall it's not an out of this world activity. It was pretty busy, maybe going at a different time would be a better option.

We visited this as part of a visit to the Yves Saint Lauren museum. This, the little museum inside and the YS Museum are probably an hour or so visit each, but the garden has a lovely cafe that is worth a stop too. Expect queues to get in, but there is a window at the front for disabled people to miss the queue. There are lots of opportunities for photos to make your friends and families jealous!

We visit Marrakech every year and every time we visit these gardens as They seem to change every time.  They are beautiful and have the largest cacti you're ever likely to see.  The best time to visit is early morning before the crowds.  It can get crowded but there are always tranquil spots. The open cafe is a delightfully cool corner.
Small but beautyfull. You can make nice pictures and take a great lunch. It is crowdy but people are relaxed
Have visited many larger but seldom this well-kept. So neat and with good signage. Wonderful variety of cacti and succulents. Adequate seating and nice Koi ponds as well.
The colours and atmosphere are magical. It is very busy unfortunately, but definitely worth visiting anyway.

This was an experience in itself was so calm and satisfying In this place during the hot weather it certainly cooled me down with all the trees and beautiful plants and wall paintings and architecture. 100% must try well worth it. A nice little cafe located inside which gives everything from teas coffee Moroccan tea and ice creams to fill you down. Great place even with kids.
Please include on your visit to Morocco if at all possible. Stunning gardens. Other name yes saint Laurent.

It is a small private garden close 10 minutes walking to one of Medinas gate. Inside the garden there are Berbere museum and YSL museum. All places need ticket and you can in combo or separated. Only garden is 70MAD and all attractions 200MAD. You can see the garden in less than one hour, inside there are Cafeteria and Toiletries. This is a good place to go to get some cooling shadows in the hot days. It is possible to take nice pictures inside but expect many other tourists trying to do the same.

Popular, so get there early. The ticket queue moves pretty quickly. The gardens are beautiful, with trees, cacti and water set against the vibrant blue villa. I would love to have spent a weekend here with YSL. Imagine!
Beautiful place to visit however very, very busy so best to go first thing in the morning as the amount of people takes away from the experience.

The garden has different settings well decorated and peaceful areas. You can take wonderful pictures with the blue wall as a back ground. El jardín tiene diferentes escenarios bien decorados y áreas que evocan paz. Se pueden tomar maravillosas fotos con el azul en el area de atrás.

Beautiful and intriguing garden with different shades of my favourite colour! Luckily we got there around 9.30 am so it wasn’t over crowded (busy enough though) but it was starting to get too busy by the time we left after 10.30 am. 45 mins to one hour is ample time as the garden is not too big.
Very pretty garden tucked away behind a big wall, towards the north of the city. A little expensive for what it is, and a little over crowded, but I guess that’s the YSL effect!

The museum although small is filled with interesting Berber artifacts, textiles and jewelry. The gift shop is exquisite, pricey and in my mind worth it if you want a collectible item. Not what you’ll see in the sook.
With tall bamboo trees and unique cactus this garden is worth a visit. It has a great variety of plants beautifully arranged.

I loved the place. Was a nice little oasis amid the heat and of the city. This beauty of nature welcomed me to my trip to Morocco. This garden is a great place to go to in Morocco and I advise all tourists going to Morocco, This is a must with all its nature, fountains and beauty!
review_title: You haven't visited Marrakech if you don't visit these gardens.

review_text: Visit a new spot with excellent taste for lunch. Watch interesting video and get the feeling peace and glamour in the middle of the Medina.

The garden is beautiful it is definitelly worth a visit. You can buy combined ticket to all sights ( Jardin Majorelle, Berber museum , YSL museum) for 180mad . Note that on wednesdays the YSL museum is closed and you can not buy combined ticket on that day . Jardin Majorelle is a really popular place make sure to prepare for queing if it is rush hours. The cafe in the garden supernice with cool staff. In the garden the staff is prepared for taking pictures and really helpfull. We had a really kind guy took pictures from us

In most places people will pass by without even noticing it. I went there because a friend of mine said, when you are in marrakech you have to visit this garden. So I did, took pictures like everyone else. Will I ask anyone to go there, NO. Stand in line for one hour to get in, NO.

This is a really beautiful garden and worth a visit if you are able to go at a quiet time but for us it was totally ruined by the amount of people who were there just to take pictures of themselves at every opportunity without actually paying any attention to their surroundings. We enjoyed the Secret Gardens much more, only for the fact that we were able to take our time to stroll round an actually appreciate it all.

The place is really nice. Beautiful. But personally I would visit other places first. It is small, so the price was high in our opinion. We didn't visit the cafe or the museum, so we can't comment on that.
review_title: It is nice, but not something you can't miss.

review_text: Easy to see why YSL drew inspiration from this beautiful garden. It was vibrant, unique, stylish and informative. I'd recommend going at a time that isn't as busy (perhaps right when they open) so as to avoid the masses of instagrammers. It really is a beautiful place to sit and enjoy the colours.

I recommend seeing the gardens and the museum. A way to skip the line is of course to buy in advance but the other way is to go the museum Yves St Laurent 100 meters down on the same street and buy the combined ticket there. You will save 40-60 minutes. We went around 10am. Walk from the Medina is easy no need to take a taxi. Also check opening days for museum.
Beautiful but small gardens, with a memorial for Yves Saint Laurent and a lovely, slightly expensive cafe.

Definitely worth a visit to see such a beautiful place. We were excited to buy the combined ticket for the gardens and also the two museums however we went on a Wednesday and both museums are closed on Wednesdays. This made the garden exceptionally busy as all tourists were in the garden.
review_title: Beautiful but busy, don’t visit on a Wednesday.

review_text: Purchase combo ticket is the way to go. Beautiful garden, YSL museum was impressive, Barber  museum (they forget to include English informations).
There is no doubt that the garden is beautiful and very, very peaceful. However, I still don't think it is worth paying 70 DH for (considering this price doesn't include the museum).
Nice garden but long queue. Better to buy the tickets form the museum (museum and garden ticket). The queue is not that long. And after the museum, you can directly go to the garden, without queue

We bought our tickets from the YSL museum and got a combo ticket so that we could visit the YSl museum, Berber museum and gardens and skip the massive queue at the gardens. The gardens are lovely, albeit very busy. You can get lots of great photos - it is a shame that some cactus's have been vandalised. The Berber museum doesn't have any information in English.
review_title: Buy your Tickets from the YSL to Skip the Queue

review_text: This is a must see if in Marrakech. The gardens are literally magical and the berber museum is fascinating.

What a stunning garden. It was pretty crowded when we went, so I suggest that you try to go when it opens to avoid the crowds. You can buy a combination ticket for Jardin Majorelle, YSL museum, and Berber museum. Felt very much worthwhile getting the combined ticket.

Yes, it is worthy of mixed reviews. If you like plants then this a good place to go to, but yes, it can be done in about 30 - 45 minutes. I took my Mum there because she has an interest of plants and we both enjoyed it. Lots of different plants from different countries. Then you can have a mint tea at the cafe at the end which is good value

We arrived here and joined the queue to buy the combined ticket for Jardin Marjorell e the and the YSL museum. We entered the Jardin and enjoyed the views and the ambience in the quiet areas. There were alot of people and it was a bit of a shame but hey it's a lovely garden and people want to pose at all the key spots. The tea (black) and the coffee was great, and reasonable too! This place is great but try and go in the quieter periods ...
A quiet and serene place out of the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. I loved sitting in the garden and having a lovely mint tea.

Had a great visit to Jardin Majorelle although it is much smaller than I expected. The cafe inside was a little expensive, but very pretty. The shop had really interesting books for sale and very cute postcards.

The side of the gardens with the Majorelle House is beautiful, the rest of it is just OK. Would have been a much nicer visit if it wasn't packed full of people. We arrived at 10.30 / 11am and already a big queue outside.
review_title: Would be beautiful if it wasn't so busy

review_text: I am glad that we went to see this beautiful garden.  Lots of photo opportunities but unfortunately very crowded so difficult to get pictures of this garden without strangers in them.  Buy the combination ticket with the museum Yves Saint Laurent then it will all be worth it,

I was very impressed and stunned when I entered the garden with my family. A vibrant red colour pathways takes you around a very tidy and well organised garden full of cactuses and palm trees. There is a memorial in one corner of the garden for Yves Saint Laurent and Pierre Berge who was his partner. The little villa in the middle of the garden is painted with bright blue colour which is used widely in Morocco. The villa windows are opening to this beautiful water feature with beautiful lilies on the surface of the water. The villa is used for Berber museum and you have to pay extra on top of 100 Dirham for the garden. If you decide to visit this garden make sure you book YSL museum next door. The price for both is 170 Dirham (almost £16 each). The garden is not that big and 1 hour is enough to spend unless you want to seat on a bench and enjoy the view longer.
review_title: Beautiful oasis in middle of an African town

review_text: After being recommended this garden I had high hopes for a great and interesting experience. Sadly this attraction fell short on several accounts. Long queues of over an hour to buy tickets. Extremely crowded and too many people taking photos, selfies and generally getting in the way ruined the enjoyment for me. Sure the gardens are well maintained but not as beautiful as I expected and certainly not on par with other desert gardens I have previously visited. The only slightly redeeming aspect was the little cafe/restaurant in the centre that offered good service and tasty food, although that was a bit overpriced in comparison to other places. Sorry I can’t recommend a visit to here. Save your money and go up the road to the YSL museum which was a great find and very worth a visit.
review_title: Long queues and a big disappointment

review_text: If you find yourself in Marrakech you will likely see this garden as a must-do activity. It was only a 10 minute walk from the central Medina area and was definitely a sharp contrast. If you have an extra 2 - 3 hours you should go visit the gardens but be aware that large tour groups are also seeing this attraction. It will be full of Instagramers looking for that perfect shot.
Beautiful garden, lots of photo opportunities! My advace go on days or times where it's not so busy, otherwise you'll find ourself queuing to take photos.

This is a plce I absolutely had to get to.  Art Deco buidling, Moroccan blue colour and in Marrakech!  It really is worth the visit.  A little secluded paradise in Marrakech to explore with plenty of shade and glorious planting.  I could have stayed here all day/1
This was truly an amazing experience to walk these stunning gardens.  You find the serentity mixed with the love of design of this beloved designer

I visited the Jardin Majorelle gardens with my boyfriend. It is gorgeous, and the colours are lovely and vibrant. There are lots of opportunities for a selfie! The only down side is how busy it gets, and you could see where some people had etched their names into the cacti and other plants which was quite upsetting. Would definitely recommend visiting, although we knew what the gardens looked like from pictures the blue of the Yves St Laurent house is still breathtaking.

we visited on an excursion with tui, the gardens are very idilic and a retreat from the busy streets of marrakesh, plenty to view and lock at from exotic plants and stunning fountains, there is a berber museum in side at a extra cost showing relics ect, and also a cafe where u can sit and admire the views, a must visit

Visited with friends in April 2019; I knew nothing about the garden before going so it was a lovely surprise. The gardens are lush with cacti, bamboo and lots of other tall green foliage. It's a lovely place to spend an hour enjoying the (relative) calm and greenery. The attached museum was worth a look, even for a non-expert. it also meant we could cool down in the A/C before getting priority access to the gardens; worth the extra few dirhams.
The garden is beautiful and such a contrast to the medina - joint ticket with the YSL museum is good value
Gardens are my thing and Jardin Majorelle delivered. An amazing collection of exotic plants, tranquil ponds set against the signature indigo blue and yellow of Ives St Laurent. So worth a visit.
NIce experience. Superb colors in the gardens. When you enter the area, although it's limited in a limited piece of land it gives you a sense of tranquility and elegance at the same time!

This was the last day of our trip and we wanted to make sure we got the chance to visit. Once you walk inside the gardens you feel the peacefulness the garden offers. Then we went next door to the Yves Saint Laurent Museum and that was just fabulous! Just make sure that you don’t get a henna right before going to the YSL museum otherwise they won’t let you in. Someone offered us the suggestion to wrap our arms with tissue paper (which we did) and we got into the museum with no problem. If you love fashion, I recommend visiting the YSL Museum.

We were almost going to give up when we saw the long ticket line but I’m glad we didn’t. These gardens were absolutely worth the wait — not too crowded, lots of places to sit and enjoy the shade, and plenty of space to stop for photos. If you have flexibility in your plans make sure you pick a day when the Berber museum within the grounds is open. We heard great things but found out it was closed when we got to the ticket window. I would have picked a different day if I had known.

I have no idea why this is ranked the number one thing to do in Marrakesh. There's nothing to see, experience or do here. A massive rip off at 70dh. It should be free. When I entered I was shocked to see how small and pointless the garden is. Do not waste your time or money. The free garden in koutoubia is much better.

paradise in a desert...this can be the title of this review! A excellent garden in new Marrakesh city area, easy walking access from Medina (about 20'). Must be early (10.00 is open) because many tourists waiting on the line to enter after this...
Really pretty garden and a nice place to relax after a busy day visiting the souls very peaceful and beautiful plants
this   is a normal garden .............they are collecting aed 70/ for visit  too much .not advisable to refer any one

We found the gardens very peaceful. It is best to go early before it gets to busy. The garden isn’t overly large but it depends what you like. We stayed a couple of hours wandering about admiring the cactus and plants. It is very well designed with walkways wide enough if you have a wheelchair. The museum is a must visit and gives you the history on Berber culture. There is a cafe on site but also a lot of cafes outside the entrance. Well worth a visit.
This is a good place to do site seeing the garden it self is amazing especially the museum inside you really get to know about marrakech

This garden is very beautiful and has a nice cafe in which we ate lunch. However, don't expect to spend more than 30-45 minutes here if you're not eating as it is quite small. Lots of good photo opportunities but if you're simply walking around it will be a quicker trip.
Gardens are very beautiful, not bad value for money. Just not there for very long, but still worth taking a trip there. Especially as you can get a combined ticket to go to the YSL museum

This lovely garden owned by the late Yves SaintLaurent and used as a studio provides a lovely respite from the heat. Shaded by exotic bamboo and dotted with fountains and pools, this garden has many benches from which you can rest and escape the heat. Unfortunately, the hustle bustle of the streets will follow you in. This popular tourist attraction gets crowded so go early or late. The museum although small is filled with interesting Berber artifacts, textiles and jewelry. The gift shop is exquisite, pricey and in my mind worth it if you want a collectible item. Not what you’ll see in the sook.
review_title: Don’t let the heat get you! Chill out in the Jardin Majorelle

review_text: I have no idea why this place is even mentioned as a place to visit when you are in Marrakech. It is tiny, not well maintained and in terms of plants and flowers totally uninteresting. And we have a biologist in a our group that didn’t even feel the need to take a picture. Not worth the price of the entrance ticket let alone the taxi ride to get there. Spend your time and money on one of the many other worthwhile places to see or activities in the neighbourhood.
This is the only thing we knew we wanted to see while in Marrakesh. It was lovely. Go early to avoid the queues and the heat. We had a nice drink in the cafe. A beautiful, tranquil place.
came to explore the ysl garden with family was beautiful ! and full of nature. ,enjoyed it took loads of photos with family

The garden is small and you need a taxi to get there. I would say it's impressive if you are not used to seeing tropical plants. But at Eur7 pp we didn't think it was worth it. We did it extremely slowly and even sat down to kill time as the driver was picking us up. An hour was plenty.

Wonderful gardens and interesting YSL museum close by. Only niggle is the fellow visitors that insist on posing for multiple photos, and I do mean posing! To avoid the ticket queue buy a combined ticket for YSL museum and gardens at the museum ticket booth.

What can I say about this place. It is very touristy and makes for nice photos if that is why you are after. The area is very small so you can cover it very quick. It is a beautiful sculptured garden but that is it. If you have no time, you can probably skip it.
review_title: Easy place to visit if you have time

review_text: This is beautiful garden with bamboo trees, beautiful plants, cactus etc. There are beautiful fish in a nicely coloured pond. The whole garden is small but very beautiful worth paying a visit.
Pleasing shady walks with unbelievable cacti and other floral beauties. Water features in shady areas ad fish a plenty. Colourful buildings. All so out of the world that surrounds it
review_title: An oasis of beauty in an urban setting

review_text: What breathtaking day to walk through this magnificent garden.  The colours and plants are absolutely beautiful. Even with many tourists visiting the garden, we felt the peace and serenity.  Next to Jardin Majorell is the Musee Yves Saint Laurent  which is fantastic and if you like fashion then I suggest to put a day aside and visit both, preferably when it opens.
The garden made really good use of succulents and cactus.  The size of the garden is just over an acre so it isn't vast in size, a pleasant way to end a day of touring Marrakech.
Absolutely stunning! The colours, design and beauty of the gardens were amazing! We also went to visit the YSL museum which was a gem! I highly recommend the whole package!

This garden must be on your to do list, definitely. But don't expect too much. The garden is nice but 70Dhms is too expensive regarding the time you'll spent in the garden ! I was clearly disappointed.
review_title: Mandatory to visit but not awesome

review_text: Nice garden nothing spectacular. Admission price over priced in my opinion. If you want to escape the busy streets of Marrakech for an hour or so.
A jewel in marrakesh . Very sticking colours . A must see some very exquisite plants . The museum gives an excellent insight the YSL life

What a wonderful escape from the heat and crowd when you manage to avoid the tourist hordes! A remarkable oasis of beautiful arid gardens (don't expect too many flowers but more bamboo, cactus and palm trees with exquisite textures) with plenty of fountains and water features. Beautifully coloured bungalows, covered walkways and buildings. Every meandering path is full of amazing views. However, once the tourist swarm the place, expect selfie sticks all around, instagram posers, people stopping randomly and stopping all traffic... The Berbere museum exhibits in a few room the traditions of the original inhabitants with their traditional tools and festive dresses/accessories (for only 30 DAM it is well worth paying the entrance fee!). The Majorelle boutique is worth a visit just to look at the floors and ceilings! Absolutely gorgeous. But you will be tempted to buy some of the very expensive items in the shop (while expensive, they are handcrafted out of the best leather, wool, silk or linen so, well worth the price! And the rich blues, reds, orange and browns are stunning).
review_title: A cool oasis in a hot city!

review_text: If you need a quick escape from the heat of the city, head towards the Majorelle Garden out to the west of Marrakech. Accessible from the City Tour bus (although it is an interminably long way round to get there!) The entry fee is reasonable, it's not as big a site as some tourist guides claimed, but that doesn't matter when it's plus 40 degrees C outside and you just want to get out of the sun. There are queues - they aren't long and there are mist sprays to keep you cool while you wait - and if you have younger kids it's likely that the security ushers will pull you out of line and fasttrack you through the group bookings kiosk if they're quiet. The gardens were a lovely peaceful haven from the chaos of the city - even when busy. A wonderful collection of bamboo grasses and succulents and - as we found - an excellent venue for the selfie-obsessed... it was difficult to move without inadvertently photobombing one of the many preening beautiful people looking for the perfect background but that was all part of the entertainment - a great place for people watching! The colours are vivid, there is a monument to former owner Yves St Laurent which almost takes on the status of a sacred pilgramage site and there's also a Berber museum within - although we didn't visit it. The cafe is quite expensive compared to other local offerings. I would recommend the Pause Gourmande just outside the exit if you want good value and tasty food. It will fill an hour or two of your day but not much more. It is worth a visit though.
review_title: Shady respite from the heat of Marrakech

review_text: This place is cute and a great place to take photos. The berber museum was interesting and the Yves St Laurent museum a must.

Was  little disappointed as although the gardens were beautifully kept. The Berber museum was closed and you can't get to stand next to some of the more exquisite plants. The YSL gift shop was way too expensive

Yes, there can be a long line in front of the ticket booth. Quick advice: Send the group to 33 rue Majorelle across the street while one of you keeps waiting. You enter the Jardin - and there is silence. Enjoy the plants, the little ponds, the colors (green - Majorelle blue - yellow - red/orange). Everything is so well kept. Pay tribute to YSL. And take a break at the café and let them spoil you with a lovely lunch. Totally worth it.

The famous garden is nice, but not spectacular. But for 30 DH more (extra to the 70 DH entrance for the garden), you can access the beautiful berber-museum. Beautiful clothes, jewels and tools, very well displayed.
We visited Majorelle Garden during our stay in Marrakech and we really enjoyed it worth a visit so speacily in Summer time in Marrakech its very hot and the Graden was very nice and cool.
Worth the trip and lovely on a sunny day, it’s a must if your in marrakech and great place for pictures

Followed tip from fellow hotel guest and got the joint tickets for Yves Saint Laurent museum, Berber museum and Majorelle gardens  - saved the long queue for the gardens. Lovely spacious gardens with beautiful colours.
I just don't understand why Local people and  other nationalities pay different prices to enter the Garden . Overall nothing  speciall .

Two friends, my wife, little son and I visited the Majorelle Garden during our trip to Marrakesh. The garden is really nice and interesting. It is a little bit outside the Medina, but easy to find and also in walking distance. With its great variety of plants the Majorelle Garden offers a complete opposite pictured to the Medina of Marrakesh. It's quite and cool. We visited the garden in the evening (two hours before closing time) and there was no waiting queue at the entrance. From our point of view the Majorelle Garden is definitely worth a visit when you're in Marrakesh.
review_title: Time out from the bustling Medina

review_text: We liked it - it was cute and nice and well maintained. I think it was more interesting how the heat dropped in a desert climate, where plants and trees are luscious and well-watered. Everything looked very pretty, but we did think it was a bit tiny and missing something - likely because berber museum part was also closed. Walking distance from the Medina, or EXACTLY 23DH via small taxi.
review_title: It's a nice little oasis, but is little

review_text: We visited the garden mid-day and it was cool and fresh, and mesmerizing! Blue Majorelle is unique and the whole vibe is wonderful!
review_title: If in Marrakech, don't skip it!

review_text: I'm not really into plants etc but this was an interesting visit as it was almost like being indoors! The museum was interesting and we took lots of lovely photographs.
Definitely a must see in Marrakech, but the price was with 70Dh a little higher than expected. Would recommend.
Amazing garden with a wide variety of plants and flowers amidst small lakes. A feast of colors that fills the visitor. It is located just outside the old town and worth a visit.

Highly recommended for a visit as it’s one of the best places to visit in Marrakesh This place is gorgeous! Peaceful The ticket is a bit overprice especially the small museum A bit disappointed that there wasn't the possibility to see more real photos of Yves Henri Donat Mathieu-Saint-Laurent
review_title: Its part of the city to see

review_text: It was a really interesting place if you like to view plant life. There is access to the Berber museum (which was really good with exception of little English).
The design is cool. But in all honesty you can get it from a photo. So full of tourists it lacks serenity. I dontthink it is worth the money.
review_title: full of people so looses impact

review_text: These gardens were a nice break and change of environment from the usual hustle and bustle of Marrakech. The tickets were pretty cheap (less than 10 euros I think) and definitely worth the price. The gardens are very well maintained and their is lots to see. From the museums to all the different plants/cactuses to the lovely, bright fish. It would take you about an hour or 2 to get around and see everything that this place has to offer.
Very beautiful place, you must see it! It worth the 7 euro that you pay. It is in a hidden place, so you better get a taxi to get there
This  was no exception, a lovely walk through the bamboo to a long pond filled with turtles. Placed in the centre is a cafe with welcoming staff! A very picturesque place to visit!!

From the reviews, sounds like I was very lucky to enter without queuing. The price for the gardens and Berber museum was absolutely worth it. We spent 5 hours there. The garden juxtaposed against the Majorelle blue house and colourful vases painted by YSL was absolutely stunning. It was one of the most beautiful gardens I’ve visited! The silly Instagrm/supermodel wannabes ruin the place as you don’t have a chance to really take in the views due to silly queues at certain places in the garden. Our meal at the cafe was a very memorable experience - try the orange blossom ice-cream. If you intend to travel to the Atlas region, then the Berber Museum is really worth a visit. Overall, one of our best Marrakech experiences.

One of our favourite places in Marrakesh is the Majorelle gardens. A little bit crowded but with amazing plantation, very neat and clean and the house is mindblowing. We paid a visit to the Berber Museum as well, which succeeded our expectations by far! A must visit. Strongly suggested!! Great shops and a very cute cafe as well. You can easily spend half day in there, learn about Berber tribes and fill your camera with amazing shots.

This place is gorgeous! Peaceful, wonderful. We visited in the afternoon, there was a line to get in. The place was a little crowded, not too bad. We spent about 45 minutes here. Nice to walk around and look at all the cacti and plants. There was a couple small shops inside. Beautiful landscape.
Good place to visit while walking around old town, but the cost is high for a short visit but worth it to see nice gardens.
Beautiful garden. There were alot of people there around 2 pm but that didn’t bother us much. We got some amazing photos and enjoyed the beautiful place.

We went to Jardin Majorelle in July, such a beautiful botanical garden with lovely landscape and great for pictures. This place is busy yet so peaceful when going around, such a luxurious garden and definitely worth a visit.

Visited the Jardin in the sweltering heat, not expecting much, however I was very impressed with the garden. There are 3 tickets... (1) garden (2) berber museum (3) YSL museum. 1) The jardin was worth the entrance fee and a beautiful escape from the madness of the city 2) I did find the berber museum a waste of time and rather small with not adding much to prior knowledge at all 3)The YSL museum was not worth the price however ok to visit and see some dresses and homage to inspirations of the fashion guru. I'm glad I saw the YSL museum but Knowing what I know now..I would not have paid for it nor would I have visited the berber museum. Save your money and use it to pay for the overcharging taxi drivers :)
One of the best Place you can visit during your day trip in Marrakech with a Tour Guided . we love and the Musiem as well n

if you like to relax and explore exotic gardens, this is the place for you. it's also great for instagram shots! i loved this experience, and there is also an art gallery at the back with Yves Saint Laurent artwork going back years ago.
so beautiful. Would advise to go early around 8am when opens as gets very busy and hot. Had coffee in the little outside cafe which is beautiful

Day 3 at marrakech and we visited that magic place..its one of the most beautiful places to be in marrakech...its like a hidden oasis...it also includes a cafe under the trees to take a rest...the only annoying thing is that many people wait to get in so you have to wait about half an hour!

This is a really beautiful garden, and definitely should be at the top of your list of must-dos while in Marrakech.  We stopped by right when it opened, and were lucky to be one of the first ones there.  I would highly recommend doing this, as we went again later in our trip in the middle of the day and found it super crowded with a very long ticket line and the good photo ops inside were swamped with people everywhere.  It was much nicer to go early-it was cooler, no line, and we could wander around and take photos of whatever we wanted without anybody else in the background.  The garden itself is actually smaller than I expected, but plan to spend an hour or two here just enjoying the beauty and taking photos.  The "instagram models" and photographers were out in full force when we went later in the day and it was a bit annoying, but you can avoid this by going early.  There's a decent little cafe inside, we didn't have food but we enjoyed coffee in the stunning setting.  We also really enjoyed the shop, it has some really unique items that are far better than the typical Marrakech souvenirs you'll see in the souks.  I bought a really pretty ring there that I absolutely love.  Overall I would definitely recommend visiting this garden, just go early in the day if you can.  Stop by for a few hours, have some coffee, and then explore the surrounding streets.
this was a beautiful spot. gorgeous history and is right next door to the YSL museum, which we unfortunately didn't end up going to but the jardin majorelle made up for that

Loved the Jardin Majorelle once we got in. Lines were long so if you can book in advance, would recommend it. Once in side you'll be treated to a spectacular mix of botanic wonders that are woven into great blue/yellow backdrops of paths and structures that take you through the garden's visuals and with scene setting ponds, pools. Lot's of great photo opportunities and great for family's. Definitely should be on your list of musts for Marrakesh.
We spend half day in this garden is really nice place to see , we Been there with a local guide city tour
Amazing hidden garden of Marrakesh, where there are many opportunities for taking great family memories.

Once you step inside, these beautiful gardens, you will be transported to a quiet, cool and calm place.. provided you arrive early (big line after we left at 11:30am).. They are well maintained and provide a welcome respite to the heat and craziness otherwise known as Marrakesh.. Many great photo opportunities for the wanna-be insta models, too..
review_title: An oasis in the city.. go early!!

review_text: A must see when you visit Marrakesh! Words fail me to describe the beauty of this place but take your time. Take a seat and simply enjoy the colours, the fauna, the architecture. The cafe served a delicious lunch.  Don't rush this visit.

I would say this is a pleasant distraction from the hustle & bustle of Marrakesh, but due to tourism, Jardin Majorelle is not the quiet utopia you would wish for. That being said, it is still a nice attraction that can still be looked at with a slower & more laid back approach than elsewhere. The queue to get in can take a while, but moves quick enough (even quicker if you have a child or even quicker if you book in advance). Once in, there are multiple directions & things to look at, which will keep even the least interested person occupied for a half hour. I am a big fan of bamboo, so was pleased with the amount on show. However, the graffiti on that & the cacti was a real shame. My only other negative observation would be that there was a lot of space that was not taken up/wasted, meaning the garden didn’t feel as full & wholesome as it could have.
review_title: A pleasant place away from the city.

review_text: This was one of three tourist sites you can get on one ticket. I highly recommend getting them altogether. You buy the tickets at the Yves Saint Laurent museum, I suggest starting there. I have reviewed that museum separately . Then you walk down the block and go into the gardens. There are lots of benches and balcony-type pull-outs for great photo opportunities. The gardens are like a botanical museum. All kinds of plants and trees both indigenous and from other countries. I was recently living and teaching in Mexico, so it was fun to see some indigenous plants from Mexico. The only downside is that it was crowded so it was difficult to get a shot without other people in it. You have to be patient and bide your time. When you get to the end of the  gardens you will find the Berber Museum, I also reviewed that separately . Really a neat place, beautiful, and in spite of so many people, it felt tranquil. A must see.

Very lovely gardens with plenty of photo opportunities.  Disappointingly expensive gift shop.  Worth a visit at 70 MDH.  It took roughly an hour to enjoy and there were plenty of shady parts for shelter from the hot sun.
Its really amazing like a hidden rainforest in the middle of the City. If you have an our its a must see!

The Jardin Majorelle is well worth a visit when you are in Marrakech. Beautifully laid out,botanical garden with magnificent cacti beds.Also a homage to Yves St Laurent who lived in the adjacent villa. The "Love Gallery" is so cool!!

One of my favourite places in Marrakech. Fantastically layed out gardens with so much to look at. Very relaxing with plenty of places to sit. There is a lovely cafe with a good selection of local dishes. More expensive than many places but quality was good. Allow a couple of hours to visit.

We were amazed at how touristy this place was. We queued for over an hour to get into the garden. It appeared that it took an extensive amount of time for the Kassier to take the money. I don't understand what the wait was being caused by. They appeared very inefficient at a simple task. As we approached the Kassiers desk, a sign was hung above. It was clear that international visitors were being charged over double the cost. When entering, it became obvious that it was a glorified Instagram opportunity. Most people were more interested in getting the perfect picture instead of enjoying the scenery. Very odd. There were a number of beautiful areas but spoilt by the number of people climbing over each other to get a picture. This didn't paint a relaxing environment.
review_title: Overpriced for a glorified Instagram opportunity

review_text: YSL’s style and elegance pervades this garden. It shouldn’t be missed. Wonderful union of architectural design, colours, plant variants and water. Makes for a memorable afternoon trip, to be accompanied by tea and a well stocked design book shop
review_title: Simply exquisite garden - colours/light/variance of foliage

review_text: Its a very beautiful garden and it's not far from Jamaâ El-Fna. you really need to go there while u are in marrakech , it worth the visite
It is a beautiful garden to get out of the loud and dirty medina but a bit overrated as I was expecting it to be a bit bigger.

It is a nice garden with a museum dedicated to Yves Saint Laurent at the adjacent. Not too big featuring lots of cactus . It is hot to visit in summer but there are shades available . Do not expect big place like Singapore Botanical Garden ,Singapore Gardens By The Bay or Kyoto’s Kiyomezu Dera . If you go in the supreme heat of summer , u will appreciate it to be small but comfortable. There are a few eateries just outside which was also on trip advisor
Great place to visit. Very pleasant place. Can do it at anytime of the day even on extremely hot day

The relationship between Marrakech and Yves Saint Laurent was one to remember. This memorial and garden was a beautiful visit and a good way to keep his memory alive. Take 2 hours to visit and follow the steps of one of the greatest designers in recent history.

We visited as part of a tour and it was totally worth it. There is a lot to see and with a very rich history. Go, take your time, walk around and be in awe. Even our teenagers liked it and now I’m convinced my favorite color is Majorelle blue.

Visit early in the day to avoid the crowds, then you will be able to take lots of pics of the stunning 'Marjorelle blue' accents around the gardens. Buy a triple ticket, the best value, as it gains you entry to the gardens, Berber & YSL museums
Nice small park with some great places to take good pictures. There are two museums in the park which make it easy to spend a couple of hours

Completely different than the neighbor (Yves Saint Laurent museum) the garden is spectacular! Hundreds of types of plants - especially cactus - make this place an Oasis in very warm days! Worth a visit and a fully charged camera!

It was fun walking the garden's imagining Yves Saint Laurent walking the same pathways, gathering inspiration. Definitely worth a visit, but you could probably put it toward the middle of the list of "to do" items in Marrakech. Enjoy!
review_title: Very Nice way to kill an hour or two.

review_text: Very hot day but beautiful gardens to keep cool and spend the day outside. We spend almost our full day hanging out and chilling - time went fast  :)
Exotic plants, trees, mint tea is perfect in the restaurant! Blue and yellow colours, YSL museum. I recommend this garden.
Lovely gardens to look at and take some cute pics but not altogether amazing in any way. If i had known there was not much to do, i wouldnt have gone in
This was a nice garden to visit within Marrakech. It is cheap to get into and a nice break from the suns heat.

Jardin Majorelle is just a nice garden. I was expecting more to be honest. But I liked the variety of the cactuses they had. Worth getting the combo ticket for the YSL museum as well, cause that was the highlight of the visit!

Beautiful gardens but nobody is actually looking at them. They’re looking at themselves looking at them through a screen to get the shot. Did you even go to Marrakech if you don’t get that pic of you on the marble steps against the blue. Queues and queues of people just waiting to have their photo taken in the same spot as everyone else. Quite a sad state of affairs because it would be a beautiful place to relax and soak up the surroundings. But equally a must see so we’re a slave to it.

What a beautiful garden. A must if you are around. Slightly off the beaten track but if you happen to take the bus tour you can get off at that stop. It was a little overcrowded due to its popularity but it is still beautiful to visit. I would highly recommend
Visited as part of a city tour ,lovely gardens with an interesting history two museums within the gardens as well ,an oasis of calm in a generally busy city
Lovely planting but difficult to get near to anything or look at the bigger picture due to the number of people. A bit of a theme park
If you go to Marrakech, here you should been. Its so lovely. The best time to go is in the morning. Then is it quiet.

A beautiful educational visit to the Yves Saint Laurant Gardens and Museum. Amazing landscaping and a wonderful display of Yves Saint Laurents sublime designs. The garden is a spectacular oasis of vibrant colour and stylish landscaping and architecture. A place to get lost in your dreams.

The gardens here are lovely. They comprise of well manicured & tended to plants. The grounds were  extremely busy when we visited after our tour of the YSL Museum so if you are looking for a quiet oasis in the desert this is not it. The restaurant on site was really charming and the food was surprising delicious. We needed a rest and fortification so by default we chose to eat here. The outdoor seating was cool, the service was wonderful and the food was well prepared and very tasty. The only reason I am not giving this 5 stars is because we were charged twice for entry although we didn’t know this until later in the day when we checked our account transactions. There was a man who also was charged twice who came back to the attendant to complain but he was basically told he was incorrect even as he was showing the attendant his account details. So for one entry price it was worth it but for two not so much!
review_title: Lovely Place - Lovely Outdoor Patio Restaurant

review_text: The small gardens themselves, although nice are seriously over priced. This is the type of botanic garden that is free to visit home in Glasgow. Paying 210 drm for 3 of us to get in was rediculous. Once inside, see all the wannabe insta posers pout and waltz for their likes and appreciation of falsity. Taking more time looking at themselves than the gardens. After 10 mins of seeing t he gardens, goto the cafe and pay double to three times more than anywhere else for tea as nd ice cream. This was the biggest tourist trap we visited in our time in morrocco. Altho the garden is nice to see all the vandalised bamboo trees with names carved into them and the wonderful cactii, it really is not worth the price, the posers you have to endure that makes you despair for society and the trek from the medina. The best part was getting a horse and cart away from this glorified money trap and Instagram selfie lover hell.

I took my son 13 year old to this place. It was a really interesting place if you like to view plant life. There is access to the Berber museum (which was really good with exception of little English). There is a koi pond within the garden and it is lovely to sit and relax. It costs around £9 British to enter and children under 13 are free. There are also student discounts if you take student ID. You can definitely spend between 1-2 hours here and it is worth a visit.
We visited this garden in the morning and it was beautiful! We do recommend going between opening and 10:30 am as it got quite busy a little later on. Still Beautiful regardless
The garden is amazing. It is a great place to take pictures but there were a lot of people taking pictures also. Staff is friendly.

Beautiful gardens but really busy even in March.  Also check beforehand if the Berber house museum is open on the day you are there as you have to purchase the tickets for both a the same time otherwise have to pay full price just for Berber museum on the next day if it is open then. Fantastic restaurant in the gardens definite must to visit and great food.
review_title: fantastic gardens but check beforehand to see the Berber museum

review_text: Found this gem while searching for things to do in Marrakesh while visiting some family. Entrance fee varies depending on whether you're Moroccan or a foreigner which was slightly unusual. However, the entrance fee is a bargain for what you eventually see. Yves Saint Laurent definitely had the midas touch when it came to designing... ** I DEFINITELY RECOMMEND DRESSING IN BLUE AND YELLOW TO TAKE SOME NICE PICTURES THAT MATCH THE COLOUR SCHEME OF THE GARDEN**
review_title: Relaxing and scenic garden worthy of great photos.

review_text: Yves Saint Laurent knew what he was doing when he acquired this beautiful garden for his home in Marrakech. The vibrant colors and variety of agriculture make this place so unique and special. Before walking around the gardens, we had lunch at the cafe and it was delicious and filling. There are a lot of cats roaming around so be aware if you're allergic that you may want to take something before going. Also, they do not provide straws so if you prefer to sip your drinks out of a straw, bring your own. We also spend the extra three Euros to go to the museum of the Berber heritage and, although it wasn't the largest collection, it was fascinating to see the evolution of the culture and the influence it still has on the Moroccan people. We visited around 3:30pm and the sunlight was absolutely stunning for photos. Visit this spectacular garden if you get a chance. Should take about 1-2 hours to see everything.

This is a must see for anyone who likes gardens. It is truly stunning. They have a little pond with fish and friendly turtles that come up to the surface of the water almost as if to say hi. The colours and mix of plants in this place really make it and I could not recommend anywhere in Marrakesh more highly.

Even though it’s full of tourists as most of tourists destinations it’s still nice to visit. I would recommend you to go early morning or in the evening as during the day it’s just too many people. Do not skip the Berber’s museum, interesting to read their history and to see their jewelry and clothes. Shame photos are not allowed inside the museum.
I can recommend this visit if you are thinking to work on your own garden. lots of details that you can apply.
The gardens are really beautiful! It worths the experience.  We went really early in the morning as it gets crowded after 10.  We did not visit the museum.
The greatest place in Morocco.There are a lot of unique plants,flowers and trees,nice water reservoirs.Also it is interesting to see the house and artworks of YVES SAINT LAURENT.

Artfully developed garden with many different plants collected from several countries, many cacti, tastefully designed pools. Well maintained. Be prepared to buy the entry ticket and that the garden closes around 6 p.m.
review_title: Beautiful garden in the desert city Marrakech

review_text: Absolutely a place you should visit.  You should also enter the Berber Museum while you are there, so be sure to buy the ticket for the museum as well.
My son and I visited Jardin Majorelle. The gardens are truly stunning, fabulous photo opportunities! There’s a Berber Museum inside the gardens (extra fee) and the YSL Museum is 100m down the road.

First of all buy your tickets on line or day before to skip the waiting line. We waited in line for an hour, they do have some umbrellas and water misters going. Priced OK as the garden was beautiful, but be parepared for many many people. There is a lovely cafe inside with good toilets and great selection of food and not over priced. The museum of the Berber people is a definite go see. Garden has many parts to it and you could pack a lunch and have it in there, no grass to sit on but lots of park benches. It’s cool and pleasing to the eyes

The garden is very beautiful and despite its small size it contains a large variety of stunning plant life. Unfortunately on our visit we were not allowed to enter certain sections of the garden for reasons that weren't explained.

We went with our two kids here and loved it. The gardens are so clean and well kept and there is lots to explore for kids. Ours could have spent all day watching the fish and turtles! The vivid blue is so stunning and the gardens still feel peaceful despite having lots of people there. A must see if you go to Marrakech!
Beautiful serene gardens, nicely shaded by beautiful trees. Lovely place to walk & take in the foliage
This is definitely worth a visit. Gets very busy so go early and visit the museum inside. Very peaceful.

After visiting a number of gardens in Marrakech, this one stands out as our favourite. As others have already said, it does get very busy and it can be frustrating, but I'd have been disappointed not to have been here.
It's a special place to visit!go in the morning in summer time. 18€ entrante ticket and you can see ives sant lauren museum . It takes one hour at least to visit them.

Really enjoyed the garden. I love plants and as I am a keen gardener, I take every opportunity to visit botanical gardens round the world. The garden is really lovely and has lots of interesting specimens. The let down is the long queue getting tickets. Took us almost an hour. If the ticket office improves the service will make the whole experience a real joy. Maybe a member of staff collects the info of who wants to buy what ticket prior reaching the till and that might speed up the process.
review_title: Lovely and well manicured garden, horticultural delight

review_text: We loved this green, creative space! A wonderful tribute to a creative man. Go early to get good photos as crowds build up.
This is a must see in Marrakesh. Absolutely beautiful.  Reasonably priced, easy to get to. I suggest going early as the line gets pretty long.

I did enjoy visiting the garden but its not worth the entrance fee in my opinion.  There were some areas not very well maintained.  I have learned through visiting Morocco that photos on Instagram and the like are not a true representation of the actual real life experience, in general...

This was billed as "THE' attraction in Marrakesh...It was good but it does not deserve that monika. The location was a little away from the main part o the city and queuing was a slight problem. It was 39 degrees. take a cold drink with you when you go (the local ice-cream parlour helped)

This garden had plants and flowers from all of over the world, which were pretty interesting to look at. The Jardin Majorelle was created by the artist Jacques Majorelle and has a huge cactus collection, as well as various other flowers. The blue villa is a gorgeous building. The shade of blue contrasts with the white doorways and yellow railings. There's also a lot of streams and ponds, complete with a huge turtle population. Nice way to spend a few hours However the best thing was that you could walk around in pleasant and cool surroundings unlike the medina in marrakech where its usually too hot!
Very nice place to visit, I recomend to go early since it gets crowded, nice place to take beautiful pictures with vivid colours.
way too expensive for what is offered. well maintained yet small garden packed with tourists. I suggest avoiding and saving your money. There are other parks for free.
Went around 4pm on a weekend and there was absolutely no line. Book tickets to both YSL and Jardin and did both in a slow 2 hours.
review_title: 4pm - not too hot and no line

review_text: Lovely Garden!! Cannot miss it its part of the city to see. You can find in toilets and restaurant..
review_title: Lovely day at the Jardin Majorelle.

review_text: An place to relax and let go, to enjoy the natural flora and fauna from around the world at leisure.
review_title: An oasis within the hustle and bustle.

review_text: My teenage daughter (13) and I went there to escape the madness of the city and were not disappointed. Beautiful gardens, so well designed. A lot of variety of plant life, we especially loved to cacti, and all the different water features. You would not think you were in Marrakech as the rest of the city just melts away

Our group decided to tour this garden. Most of the plants you Will see here are cactus, bamboo and palm. They have a museum berbers which needs another payment to enter. They have a Memorial for Yves St laurent. They have a nice boutique shop. Overall a nice break from the hot Weather in the city
It's a pretty quick visit and it's a bit away from the medina, but we really enjoyed it after the busy-ness of the medina.
Gardens are absolutely stunning. A nice variety of cactus,  flowers and trees. Also make sure to see the koi pond. A bit crowded (so get here early) but well worth a visit.
Magnifique! Must see in Marrakesch. Obligatory vist + museum of YSL. Visit in the Cafe M ajorelle is a nice addition to the time spent there.

We spent just over an hour making our way through the gardens. There are many different plants and scenes which are ideal for the photographers amongst you. The colours are really nice but the garden is small but still interesting, we walked around three times and enjoyed it.

Worth the money.. just.  It is a tranquil setting and there are many pretty plants and trees to see.  It is relaxed enough to just sit and take in the surroundings.  Not massive, but a nice escape from the hustle and bustle outside.

Our riad told us this is a must see, but only right when they open.  We are glad we took that advice as we were able to go with few people there, and by the time we were leaving there was a line forming for tickets, so I imagine by 10am it would be too full of people.  I think it is closed in the afternoons too. A superb maintained garden with plants, cacti, and trees from all over the globe.  Nice walking paths, water features, buildings, and even some small art exhibits.  Do not miss going here, and as I said before, GO EARLY!
review_title: Go EARLY morning or Don't Go

review_text: So happy we choose to visit this place. Such an amazing garden full of different plants and morrocan blue decoration. Water is also a part of it. Highly recommended for a visit as it’s one of the best places to visit in Marrakesh. YSL monument is in there and also buy a combination ticket from the YSL museum which gives you access to ysl ,berber museums and Jardin Majorelle.

Very glad we decided to visit. It is truly beautiful to see. Specifically if you are into fashion/design you can see how St. Laurent was inspired to create many of his pieces as well as the beautiful design of his garden that can only come from a true artist's mind. Peaceful, quiet with beautiful colored doors, cactus' and cafes to grab a bite to eat along the same street afterwards. From what I remember too it is fairly affordable.

This garden paradise is a stunning place to spend a few hours. We only visited the garden and were satisfied with that. The greenery is wonderful. I love cacti and their cactus garden is gigantic and full of really great types.
It was one of the most beautiful things we saw in Morocco. Not sunny at all, a lot of plant species, nice architecture! It is a must!
We ony had 3 days in Marrakech and we visit the Atlas mountains and Berber Villages for a day trip from Marrakech it was the best day in morocco. then we only had 2 hours here but was great

We visited the garden on our first day of the trip excited by the very good reviews. It’s a very nice place, excellent for Instagram pictures, but super expensive. 18e(full tour) for a 15 min walk it’s quite expensive

Beautiful colors inspired I guess by Yves St Laurent. Nice layout of plants. Some great photo shots. However, the garden is simply too small to accommodate the crowds. You cannot walk any distance without bumping into someone trying to take a picture. The slightest stepping over the walkways draws a whistle and rebuke. I guess the garden is a must see in Marrakech so I’m sure you’ll go. But don’t expect a relaxing experience
review_title: Beauty but simply too crowded to enjoy

review_text: It was listed as a "must" in Marrakech, but afterwards I was not really amazed. Just a "cooler" place to escape for a little while from high temperature from Marrakech. But this is not the place which symbilizes Marrakech. Anyway, If you have time to spend in the city without any better project, you can get there...preferrably not on Wednesday, otherwise you'll miss also Berber museum which is closed on Wednesday.

Take a taxi and negotiate the price (20-30dh from Jemaa el Fnaa). Buy the combined ticket for this, the Berber museum and the YSL museum (180 dh). This is a wild garden perfectly maintained. The Berber museum is in it and it is very interesting and quick to go through.

Lovely shady garden to stroll in, have lunch in the courtyard cafe and learn about Berber culture in the small museum inside. Did a combined entry ticket with the YSL museum on the same street and avoided the queue at the Jardin entry gate. Loved the story of this fashion icon and his designs. Memorial to YSL in the Jardin too.
review_title: Combined visit with YSL & Berber museums

review_text: An arid garden connected with a berber museum and a YSL museum. In my opinion it was just a pretty garden 70 dirham to get in, and of course every one was there. All proceeds are reinvested in the people and programs of morocco. Beautiful garden with the famous blue architecture. Skippable in my opinion.
I went here to take pictures with friends and it was amazing. So glad we did- beautiful gardens, waterfalls, and unique blue walls.

I'm glad I went here, it made for a beautiful hour on a hot day. It was an oasis in busy Marrakech and was a few degrees cooler than the rest of the city due to the plant cover. If you can avoid all the Instagram photos being taken, it's really lovely. Compared to the prices of most tourist activities like this in Morocco, in my opinion it was overpriced. We bought a ticket to all 3 elements – the garden, the Berber Museum and the Yves Saint Laurent museum. While I found the Berber Museum interesting, it was quite small and I didn't really learn anything I didn't already know by visiting small towns and other historic sites etc. Unfortunately, we didn't realise the Yves Saint Laurent museum was further down the road, and thought that a small room of artworks was the museum! If you go, don't do what I did and make sure to go looking for the YSL museum.
A nice little oasis in a busy and hot Marrakech. Cost to get in was 70 MAD which we all felt was quiet expensive considering the size of the gardens and length of time you would spend there.

We only went to the garden and not the museum and it was a really great place to go to escape the madness of Marrakech. Everything is beautifully maintained and colourful. If you appreciate the serenity of nature I would definitely recommend! As expected it was very busy by about 10:30 which made it difficult to see in some places as there were a few too many posers for Instagram! Warnings that the cafe was very overpriced as well due to the captive market but still worth the experience as there are a few traditional teas. We walked 30 minutes to get here which is only advisable once as it was very chaotic beyond the grounds and cars don't stop at zebra crossings but there are plenty of taxis and horse and carts waiting around outside for a slightly safer journey back!

Stopped off on the hop-on hop-off bus route to see the gardens. They are very pleasant, and offer a cool place to be on a hot day. Spectacular? ... no. Moderate size place, On balance ok to visit once.
Highly recommended.  Beautiful and well-designed.  Cool in the heat and a nice cafe. Get the combines garden and museum ticket.
This is a beautiful garden in the madness of Marrakech. We entered through the Museum to give us easier access to the Gardens. The cafe was also lovely for a coffee.

Can’t miss this place when visiting Morocco and the museum, so beautiful. Would advise to go early around 8am when opens as gets very busy and hot. Had coffee in the little outside cafe which is also beautiful x

Never seen so many huge cacti, very peaceful. Does seem very much about selfies and people posing for photos. Definitely pay for the Berber Museum otherwise it's just selfie city and you don't learn much.
Visited with family here in July. Nothing special. If you bored then go to this place. Took 5 minutes to view entire garden.
review_title: IF YOU BORED IN MARRAKESH THEN VISIT

review_text: What a beautiful garden!  I particularly love the cactus garden - so very different to many other places.  Of course the Majorelle blue is just incredible to see in real life.  These gardens are beautifully maintained and and absolute pleasure to visit.The visit doesn't take very long so even if it is hot it is not too tiring!  Don't miss these gardens.

This place is magic. It is not big, but so nice. You must have seen it when in Marrakech. Combine it with a visit to the Yves Saint Laurent museum. Also on a hot day, the garden offers a lot of shade and water, and it a cool place to visit.
review_title: One of the most beautiful gardens I have ever seen

review_text: Enjoyed our visit to Jardin Majorelle.  We thought there would be more floral to see, but the gardens are still attractive and well kept.  Plenty of shade areas to find relief from the sun, and lots of photo opportunities.  Special interest and chance to learn more about Yves Saint Laurent which I found interesting.  It is not too large either, so doable if you don't have too much time.
review_title: Enjoy even a short visit while in Marrakesh

review_text: Garden wonderful but both museums are brilliant so make sure you also visit them. Great exhibition of Berber carpets at the YSL museum at the moment.

Worth it just for the amazing photos. Allow about 1.5 hours and longer if you are going to see the museum as well. There's a really nice restaurant in the middle and we would have eaten there if we had factored in extra time.
Great place to shelter from the heat wave in summer,beautiful place,highly recommended! We are a family with age varies from 7 to 70 and we all had a lovely time.
Such a tranquil place. The colors are so vibrant on the buildings and doors. Go with a travel guide to provide you insight into the various plants/trees.

Jardin Marjorelle is simply stunning! The online images do not do it justice. This is a "must see and experience in person" type of garden. Get there early and enjoy a quiet stroll through the gardens and arrive at The Berber Museum which in itself is pretty amazing. If you are a plant lover, you will find your joy here.  I thought that it may be just another cactus garden... well, it is but with the most magnificent specimens of so many cactus... and the bamboo forest was one of the most grand and impressive ever. All I can say... is SO BEAUTIFUL!!!

Gardens were pretty but not hugely inspiring.. lots of people taking IG type photos.. Could be a serene place to hang for a bit if there weren't so many people. We went early when it opened. We opted to purchase the (separate fee) entry to the YSL Museum and were so glad we did. The exhibits were fabulous and worth the entire trip over there. I'd say gardens were a nice secondary thing to the museum.
review_title: Pay the extra to visit the YSL Museum

review_text: A real oasis and totally unexpected, worth a visit from the chaos of Marrakech. Visit during the heat of the days to escape
Arrive early to avoid the crowds . This is an oasis of calm in busy Marrakech. An established tropical garden is well maintained and loved . Highly recommend

A lovely place to visit. The cactus are so varied and the gardens are so quiet. Great photo opportunities for so much around the gardens. A lovely house standing out amongst the greenery. Definitely a place to visit. Purchase a combined ticket which also includes entry into the Berber museum and the YSL museum. There is also a water fountain just inside the garden so you can top up your bottles.
The Jardin Majorelle is a very well-maintained and pleasant garden. There are many spots for photoshoots and there is a nice Berber museum inside.
Very pretty gardens, with colourful doors, architecture and water fountains. Nice for a midday stroll and scenery for your Instagram.
Visited the garden early in the morning. Not very busy and under the trees very cool. Walked around for 1.5 hours. Very well maintained
A wonderful garden and all the more special after our time in the Yves St Laurent Museum which gives the gardens a real providence
This is a great place to wander round.  The plants, trees and colours really catch the eye and you wont believe the size of the bamboo.
U got that one right Mr YSL !!!  Beautiful space. Just a tad over crowded. Wonderful place  to visit whilst in Marrakech.

I loved our visit here. It was quite busy but you were never surrounded by people as there were plenty of places for people to sit and wander. Some really unusual looking plants and loved the water features and shocks of bright coloured urns or plaster walls or pool surrounds. Apparently the cafe on site does very nice food but we only got told this after our visit! Worth a visit and gives you a bit of shade in the heat of the day!
review_title: Stunning oasis of vibrant colour and plants

review_text: Simply it’s a garden that you can complete it in 10 mins maximum. Not worth at all the payment specially the museum. I have paid 180 MAD for the entire garden and museum  with high expectations and surprised with what I saw. The team just look at you greedily what in your pocket .

If you are in Marrakech this place is definitely worth your time. It’s a beautiful place also giving access to the YSL museum. Perfect for taking pictures and learning about the different types of cactus from different continents. The pictures on google not do this place justice. Please don’t hesitate to visit this beautiful place.

We loved our visit to Marjorelle Gardens. It's very peaceful, which makes a nice change from the busy old city. Lots of bamboo, cactuses and other plants to see. Two fish ponds with Koi and tortoises, picturesque art deco style in the buildings and planters. Its not too big, but we probably spent an hour there, and took a lot of photos. Good value for money, would recommend.
Nice garden and a relaxing and much cooler afternoon  ...but too bad the painter’s villa has been closed for over a month and they don’t mention it when you buy your tickets
review_title: Nice garden ... but painters villa is closed

review_text: Beautiful garden with all kinds of plants. The Berber museum is also really intersiting. Beautiful place to take pictures
review_title: A must do while in Marakech

review_text: Beautiful and peaceful garden that includes tribute to Yves Saint Laurent who lived nearby.  The cactus display is absolutely spectacular
Not big, can be viewed within a hour max. Was expecting more, pretty, but too standard. Can't go wrong with that ticket price.
The gardens are beautiful and I love the blue!  I would plan more carefully next time to get there in the morning to avoid the crowds and the long line to get tickets.

We were lucky because there was not much line, around 13.00 - 14.00 it got quite busy so we are glad we went in the morning. It is beautifulk but small so do not expect something espectacular. Try to get to see the house from different points to be able to take better pictures. It gets really busy later so all your pictures will be with a lot of people, go early!
A bunch of cactus plants, some big fish in a pond and a small museum. I don't think it was worth the 70drh entry...
