We loved the Jardin Majorell, is was our favourite thing we did in Marrakech, cool, quaint and a chilled oasis, full of class and style. A must for anyone visiting the city.
review_title: A true oasis in the hustle of Marrakech

review_text: Beautiful gardens with varied plants and fascinating Berber museum showcasing jewelry and costumes of the Amazigh people. Somewhat pricey (70DH for gardens and 30DH for museum).
review_title: Beautiful gardens in Yves St Laurent's home

review_text: Beautiful...the cafe is delicious...a must do especially if you want to escape the heat..go early to beat the crowds 💕
Beautiful gardens, the colours and the cacti are incredible.  Get there for 8am as not many people there.  After that it’s a bit busy.  Worth a visit.  Loved the YSL Museum next door
Very enjoyable worth a visit and good photo opportunities. It’s an easy walk from the Médina and nice to get away from the crowds.
review_title: Great little visit to the YSL Gardens

review_text: This was something we hadn't thought about doing, however, everyone said we should. Firstly was the YSL museum. What a fantastic display and insight into the man. We were hungry and so we ate in the museum restaurant The Studio. Wow! What fabulous food! Then the gardens. Soak up this structured yet incredibly beautiful garden. Yes, it's 'designed' but it's just stunning. I wore a blue dress which totally fitted in. Unplanned but looks good in photos! Escape the crowds and the heat and explore this magical place at your leisure. We were there for well. Over 2 hours including eating.
review_title: Exquisite - make sure you do the YSL MUSEUM as well

review_text: This is the perfect place to escape the busy streets and some respite from the heat. It's cool to walk around and the plants/architecture/colours combined everything I was hoping to see in Marrakech.  Yes it's busy, and there are plenty of people taking pictures but why wouldn't you? We took as many as we could. It was not so hectic that we couldn't move around comfortably and managed to find a seat for a break. The scenery I thought was breathtaking. The boutique was amazing and oozed quality but sadly beyond my purse but looking around it was amazing. The gardens are also surrounded by lovely shops and places to eat and was a lot quieter and a nice place to stroll away from the souks for a while.
Lovely gardens, cool and tranquil, not a lot to see it look around. There is a cafe a shop or pay extra to look in the museums, roughly £7 a person unless you are local then £1 a person.
Definitely it is a worth to visit! You can spend 2 hours in blue/green garden oasis under the trees and palms.
review_title: Garden oasis in a hot city centre

review_text: Very well maintained garden, cool and peaceful especially on a very hot day when I visited. Nice little cafe and Berber museum in site as well.

Do NOT join the queue at the entrance to the gardens on Rue Yves-Saint-Laurent! Turn around the corner to the right side of the entrance and go to the ticket office for the YSL Museum (near Maroc n Roll). We went at peak time and were happily surprised to find no queue at the office (there was a massive 45 minute queue for those who didn’t know about the office). Once there get a ticket to the Berber Museum which also gives you access to the gardens and ultimately saves you buying multiple tickets and lets you skip the queue at the main door. The gardens are gorgeous, not as impressive as Kew Gardens in London (I’m biased) but it’s a beautiful setting. As many others have noted there will be swarms of people only there to take Instagram photos but that’s true of most major tourist spots. The house is stunning, the two museums and gallery were highlights of my trip and I shamelessly LOVED the gift shop. The location is beautiful, the staff were lovely and the cafe was lovely if a little bit expensive. I’ve given this 5 stars as the only fly in the ointment is dodging instagrammers so follow others’ advice and go early in the day/evening. If you do get surrounded by cameras you can always just have a chuckle to yourself, watching people take themselves way too seriously and queue to take the same photo smiling at a plant or door as everyone else.
Very pretty and peaceful gardens. The museum was very interesting. We would definitely recommend this during your trip to Marrakech.
Realy nice garden and various cactus along with other trees. Definitely the most overcrowed place in our visit there. Worth visiting. We didn’t spend too much time there though a sort walk.
We visited the Jardin Majorelle around 10 am which was perfect timing. It was still cool not that crowdy, so a nice atmosphere to walk around the Jardin.

With such hustle and bustle in Marrakech, it was a pleasant respite to visit the Gardens. Best bet is to turn up first thing in the morning as it gets very busy and is only a small area to explore The Gardens are lovely with the most amazing Cactus and tribute to Yves-Saint-Laurent, however not as big as I thought, so half an hour to an hour is all that is needed There is a Cafe on sight and also toilets Worth going to understand the dedication of the Gardens made by Yves-Saint-Laurent to the city of Marrakech after the land had fallen into dereliction

Very pleasant visit to this tranquil and cool garden despite the scorching summer temperatures in Marrakech.  Also visited the Berber Museum in the same complex but it’s a pity that none of the descriptions were in English
Had a wonderful lunch here after touring this beautiful and amazing garden which made my experience even better.

The garden is stunning and it was very refreshing to be here on an extremely hot summer day. I would definitely recommend getting the combined ticket for the Jardin Majorelle, the Yves Saint Laurent Museum and the Berber Museum for 180 dhs.
Absolutely worth a visit, go early about 8:15 tranquil and stunning not very big, 700 dirahm entry about £7.00 beautiful colours , cool tranquil
Interesting plants, great contrast with the blue colors, worth the time to visit. Recommended to go as early as possible.
Was very disappointed nothing special at all it was just ok walked around in 20 minutes quite a few tourist traps in marrakech

We were a bit dubious having read Monty D's comments on the gardens. However we were extremely  impressed. Managed to avoid getting posing selfie addicts in our pictures. The shade created by the plants was a welcome relief from the hot sun. The YSL Museum also worth a visit.

This is a beautiful setting and fun to visit if you have an interest in Yves Saint Laurent (I don't, my wife did). However it was kind of expensive and we had a long wait tho we went fairly early in the morning to line up. We both agreed it hadn't been worth it.
review_title: Fun Visit But Not Much to See

review_text: It's a big garden. Beautiful garden in the middle of the desert. Nothing to write home about but there are some good photo opportunities.

Once entered,  it is so lovely and cool. Really nice activity to walk around the gardens. The museums were unfortunately closed but that didn’t deter from the visit. Great ice cream shop opposite too😊
review_title: Nice visit on a hot day

review_text: Please see my review on Airbnb for details about my stay. I stayed here with my girlfriends for my birthday celebration.
BEST jardines actoliy nice happy with my friend that is going well for me .yes it is not available for you

Very interesting museum, it explained in detail the items that they had on display. This is probably the only museum of the few that I went to in Marrakech that had English descriptions even though it is quite small. The garden is very well maintained even though it was quite packed.
review_title: Beautiful Place from the chaos of the city

review_text: It was pretty and had some great places for photos, but that’s about it. It cost 70 Dirrhams (about £6) so not bad.

The gardens are beautiful and relaxing! The blue with which most pots are painted is beautiful and in the gift store they sell the paint! Nice restaurant for lunch (indoor and out) with Moroccan menu.
What a photogenic place - really worth the visit, together with the YSL museum right next door. The colors in the garden are superb, you keep taking pictures :)
yves st laurent berberes musea..proffesional..very nice price a little expensif but Okyves klein bleu tint exceptional gardens cactus everything in Harmonie
review_title: visit  gardens muse berberes.yves st lauren
writer_informations: Cape Town Central, South Africa,6 contributions

review_text: The gardens were beautiful, though it was Berber museum that really stood out for us. It has a number of nice restaurants, boutiques, etc. along the same road. This was a very nice change from our time in the old medina, so we were very pleased to travel here.
review_title: Lovely gardens, go to the attached Berber museum

review_text: Nice place to spend 2 hours with the kids. Gardens are a lovely refuge from the hustle and bustle of the Medina. Lots of places to sit and relax. Staff was helpful and friendly with kids. Fountains were really nice as well.
Was great to see YSL hide way and the paradise he built in such a harsh environment.. Was pleasant nit expensive interesting half day activity.

A 3.000 species of plants on its garden and a house painted in a beautiful blue , called Majorelle Blue after its creator, Jacques Majorelle. This is the last home of Yves Saint Laurent outside Paris, this was his second home. The place doesn’t open on weekends, and it opens at 8a.m. Be ready to arrive as early as that to be able to see the garden peacefully and to see the house before it gets too crowded. At 9:30 am it is already packed, with lines to take pictures of the house and around the garden. By 11:00 it has lines outside to buy tickets. No worth going that late. This is the most beautiful place in marrakech.
review_title: Unexpected blue between the red city. Most beautiful place in Marrakech

review_text: Although it is almost overrun by tourists, it is worth the wait in the ticket queue. Once inside it is possible to move to corners which are less crowded. The museums inside the garden are worth it while the restaurant is also a pleasant place to sit, relax and enjoy a cold drink on a hot day or just savoir a nice cake or crêpe.
Beautiful gardens, lots of amazing cactus, totally unexpected in the middle of Marrakech. This is a must to visit.

We loved the garden and were happy we booked the tour in advance with the tour guide. This way we could access the garden quickly and spared ourselves standing in the heat for too long, though we came in the morning which is advised. The plants are so beautiful, the place smells just great and the villa is an interesting architectural highlight: highly recommended.
I loved this garden and was grenat and beautiful thé colors were perfect people lovely sage it wasgreat
Amazing Cactus and succulents, lovely peaceful gardens.Yves San  Laurent villa was beautiful, vibrant colours of pots and buildings against the tropical green plants, lovely
One of the most beautifully presented gardens I had the pleasure of visiting.. Attention to detail in its layout and content..

Beautifully set out garden with palm trees and ornamental ponds . A nice time had walking around under the trees listening to the birds and sitting by the ponds. A few cats around longingly looking at the koi which was amusing. We had a short stop to quench our thirst at the cafe and had look in the book shop. Very expensive..but give expected as it's designer . People watching was interesting as there were so many 'models' men and women eager to take those must have selfies.
Truly stunning work of esthetic art coupled with the Ives St-Laurent museum which is amazing.  Do not miss it when in Marrakesh
Beautiful gardens. A must see when you are in Marrakech. I highly recommend it... It worth the visit
À perfect Day at thé gardens. The expeience was unique. The mixture of colors, plants as well as decors made the place a perfect getaway

The garden is beautiful, amazing for taking pictures of and walking around. Half of the visit you expect is being able to go to the Yves Saint Laurent Museum and unfortunately it was closed on the day I visited. The garden itself is a tourist hotspot so it is incredibly busy which makes it hard to enjoy and you are kind of pushed around with the crowd.
A busy and popular garden. Exotic plants and beautiful bright blue paint adorn this place.  Was quite a busy garden, situated outside of the Medina in the modern part of town.

Definitely worth a visit when you head to Marrakech. Not overly expensive to visit but you can definitely spend a few hours there. Cafe inside in reasonably priced, Berber Museum and YSL are extra but can be bought in a combo ticket alongside garden entry fee.
Great cactus garden with nice cafe inside - food is clean and tasty, reasonably priced. Definately need to check this place out while in Marrakech.

We got there seeing great reviews so maybe we had too high expectation but once we walked around, what we saw didn't seem worth the effort and the price. There were so many people, it really lost the tranquility of the place and hard to take nice pictures without people in the background. We had lunch at the nice outdoor cafe but the food was bland (except for the kids meal which was better than the mains) and expensive. We wanted to go and look at the YSL Museum but it was closed for the day (closes every Wednesday) so it was more disappointing. We only had 1.5 days at Marrakesh so if I had to do it again, I would take it off my list unless I was staying for 3 full days and pick a time when there's less crowd.
review_title: Yes, it's a pretty garden but....

review_text: Worth the visit if you are in the Gueliz. I heard it can get quite busy but it was actually peaceful enough when we were there. We went pretty early in the day. Here you can enjoy the viewing of beautiful succulents, plants and water features. There is a charming cafe inside. The walkways are paved making it quite accommodating for the immobile. Cost of entrance same as most tourists places (70 dirhams per adult). Independent from the garden are a few gift shoppes across the street - fair prices so no need to bargain.
Good to go if you’re in/ near Marrakech, but personally wouldn’t book a whole trip around this attraction. Food in YSL museum next door was delish though😋
Me and my mom were amazed by all those beautiful flowers! Also the Amazigh museum inside is great! Don't miss out of that one!
Very beautiful, although quite small and not a lot to see it is worth to go see it for the experience. Any pictures you take here will look amazing as well!

We visited the Jardin Marjorelle after reading such good reviews about it. We turned up around 11am, there was a queue to get tickets but this soon went down and we were stood for about 20 minutes. The gardens are very pretty, and shaded which is a nice break from the heat. We did think there would be a bit more to look around, as we'd pretty much walked round the garden in about 20- 30 minutes. It's very well looked after and love the colours. A perfect spot for photographs - instagram lovers paradise (you will have to avoid being a photobomber in many peoples instagram pics!).. but overall we were not blown away by these gardens after reading such good reviews, we ate at the small cafe which was nice, but after that we were pretty much ready to go. A nice attraction to visit but we were left a little underwhelmed.
review_title: Pretty colours and a break from the bustling streets

review_text: A highlight of our trip-it was really really hot so bring suncream and a hat. Amazing photographs here-our daughter is into Instagram.

A really fantastic place, not just a garden, but a museum as well. A great history ( I will not spoil it !). The colours will live with you, everything, plants, pots, water. Probably the best attraction in Marrakech.  Don't miss it ! David

The garden itself is interesting and beautifully preserved, a real treat for photographers and Instagram models alike - however, it’s best to go at the earliest possible hour, 8am, as the crowds will be less annoying and the light can be a bit smoother.
review_title: Beautiful garden... only in the morning

review_text: We have been here and was great and perfect place to visit, even though you have to wait long 40 min in order to buy ticket.
we have taken a walk to majorel garden ,it takes about 35 minutes from the jamaa el fana square ,late you discovering this magic garden.
The garden is great! Perfect place to cool off and chill out in the heat of Marrakech. The queue to buy tickets was ridiculously long as they didn't have all the ticket booths open.
The gardens were ok. But I was expecting something bigger and better after reading other reviews. Had to wait in the sun for about 40 mins to buy a ticket which was longer than I was in there

Visited here with my daughter- beautiful gardens but SO busy and full of selfie taking beautiful people who were hard to avoid owing to the crowds.!! Worth going though although maybe first thing might be a good plan.
Must place to go when you’re in Morocco, so much to see all the other comments speaks for itself!!!!
Le Jardin Marjorelle is a must see while in Marrakech!  I recommend doing the Berber Museum and the YSL Museum while there.  We could have spent all day there!

Don't miss this gem. You step out of the hustle and bustle of Marrakech into a quiet garden filled with tropical plants, and cactus.  The bright blue villa and museum of Berber culture also showcase some of its last owner, Yves Saint Laurent.

outside the Medina but not far, this place is a melting pot of colors, plants also people! GO in first morning, around NINE AM All Photo amazing , go through the green , have a Walk andkeep place! Cheaper. Must to Visit! It i s 50 m from YS L museum So: 1) Jarod in Majorelle 2) Museum 3)YSL MUSEUM CHECH ALL PH IN MY I G  PROFILE!

This was a really beautiful site. There was an amazing variety of plants including lots of succulents and cacti. The setting was stunning with that rich majorelle blue everywhere creating the perfect backdrop to the gardens
The garden is beautiful every corner or path leads you to beautiful views. Worth a vist it would be great
hello... you want a photo with extra colours for your insta, you have to visit the jardin majorelle!!!
review_title: hello... you want a photo with extra colours for your insta, you have to visit the jardin majorelle!!!

review_text: Stunning views of exotic plants and a great place to take insta-worthy photos! Will recommend visiting during mid-day when the heat is at it's peak as the plants and trees provide plenty of shade and are great to explore the different varieties from around the world. Plenty of ice-cream shops opposite afterwards to cool down and chill. Will definitely recommend.

A lovely relaxing walk through the gardens. Lots to see. Even though it was busy as it is a big gardens people were spread out and there were lots of photo opportunities. Entrance to the gardens was only 70 dirham (about £6.10)  but the cafe was very expensive. The cafe opposite the entrance was half the price and the cafe round the corner was half the price again!

This place became so popular that it is hard for anyone in it to enjoy it, purely a money machine...they should at least regulate the entrances or start selling tickets in advance because no one like to pay 70 dirhams to queue at least 30 minutes to then re-live the souks with the only difference that there is nature around! (which you can't enjoy because there are people everywhere). Yes it is beautiful, but God what a nightmare!
Very nice garden full kf history and beautiful plants The swaps are also so nice and the fishes are cute it was a nice experience and I want to do it again and again and again

Absolutely fabulous place. Magical. A must visit along with the YSL museum. Go when it opens at 8am as you get to see one garden almost on your own and avoid the queues. You can have breakfast there. But don’t miss the Oasis Garden that doesn’t open until 10am

I did enjoy the Jardin Majorelle but it's a good walk away from the main centre of Marrakech, very busy and a little overpriced with different prices depending on what country you come from. It does have a combined ticket with the Yves Saint Laurent museum just down the road which is good and you can buy that at the museum and skip the queues at the garden. I've heard it's better to go in the afternoon as the tour buses drop everyone off in the morning. I went in the morning and it was busy. Worth visiting, especially if you want some good Instagram pics but there are better gardens in the area.

This garden is just magical!  It is truly an oasis in the desert.  From the bamboo grove to all the tranquil ponds this is a truly relaxing place.  I recommend a juice at the restaurant in the garden as it was very refreshing.
Magic place. I can recomended for everybody. So nice, big, and calm place with very nice buildings. Colourful place . Nice for photos. 💋🥰😍
This is a good peaceful place to escape traffic and city noise. None of the plants are very special but they are arranged nicely among paths, pools, and terraces. Get there early to avoid crowds.
Oasis in the middle of the city but quite crowded. Anyways it's worth a visit as contains things you won't see anywhere else.
review_title: Oasis in the middle of the city but quite crowded

review_text: Well laid out gardens with plants from around the world. A real oasis in the midst of chaotic Marrakech.
A pleasant garden to explore spoiled only by the numbers of tourists (myself included).  As with the YSL museum get there early to avoid long queues for tickets.

We went to see the museums and the gardens. Sadly only the gardens were open as it was a Wednesday. Nicely manicured with some nice water features and cacti. Would have been good to visit the museums too.
review_title: Nice enough but don’t go on a Wednesday!

review_text: The garden is nice, not impressive but nice. Try to go as early as possible to avoid the crowd and get better pictures

Making our itinerary for Morocco - Le Jardin Majorelle was high on our list.  I strongly encourage you to get the full pass to see the gardens, the YSL Museum and the temporary exhibit (we saw the Berber exhibit on this trip).  The gardens themselves are very large with tall bamboo and plants to keep the place nice and cool.  The villa and structures inside the gardens pop with outstanding color and vibrancy. A great spot for vacation pics!
We have enjoyed this place so much that we will be back again next year. Its got so many tree that i have never seen before.

Beautiful, but most of the plants are things I would have found in the states. Nothing unusual. If you want a quiet stroll, go in the morning before the many other tourists arrive. Worth a visit for a short stay.
So peaceful and beautiful a real oasis.  Get there early as it opens at 10 am but queues start long before that!

Lovely color everywhere.  We are a fan of cacti so if this is your thing, then you'd love Jardin Marjorelle. We visited in April around 1:30PM and waited about 45 minutes for tickets.  Just an FYI so you can budget your time.  Once you are about 20 minutes wait from the ticket booth, they have a misting machine that blows cool mist on you and that made the waiting a lot more pleasant.
This is a place I've always wanted to visit.  The design of the house and gardens are just incredible.  A can't miss experience in Marrakech.
Beautiful garden in Gueliz. 70DRH entrance. Very quiet but quite popular so you'll probably have to queue.
Fantastic gardens- well looked after and maintained. The cafe is also fab- we had the soup and vanilla ice cream. Would recommend visiting.

This is a must if you are going to Marrakesh, beautiful gardens and colours. Don’t forget your camera if you like to take pictures. Take your time, you can easily spend 3 hrs there. You can buy your tickets from the YSL Museum if you are going to Museum and Gardens, less queue at the museum. If you are only going to the gardens, be prepare to queue for 20-30min, but it is definitely worth it.
The garden is just something else. As said, beautiful. Also great is the YSL museum on the combined ticket. What an amazing designer. Together, they are the outstanding sights in Marrakech.
The gardens were beautiful. Many species of plants were scattered about the garden, as well as ponds and beautiful indigo buildings. Well worth the visit.

I don't know if it's possible but this beautiful garden, surely created by YSL as a haven of peace, would benefit by somehow limiting the number of entrants: Line-ups to take selfies and traffic jams on the pathways are really not conducive to the kind of experience the creators had in mind.
Very beautiful garden next to the Yves Saint Laurent Museum. It is pricey for its size but its still worth the visit.

Prebook your ticket or go to the YSL museum first and buy a combination ticket (worth it) and then wander into the Gardens at your leisure. Gorgeous gardens of cactus and other plants and very instagrammable building and water features. We have even painted an interior wall that gorgeous blue colour we loved it so much. The cafe has a great range of delicious food and free Wi-Fi.
review_title: Gorgeous Gardens and Cafe but the queue for entry was hell

review_text: Was very impressed with these gardens! Gardens are gardens... well no - these gardens are exceptional! It’s an oasis!!! Would thoroughly recommend you visit on any trip to Marrakech!!!
This is the smallest botanical garden I have ever visited but it's OK and I did enjoy my tour.  I would recommend this place to someone that never been to a botanical garden before.
Incredible array of flora and fauna from around the world. Quite busy but not overcrowded. Cafe very overpriced! Overall worth a visit. Offer good discount for students.
Get away from the bedlam of Marrakesh by visiting these beautiful gardens. Stunning to look at, very peaceful and the little cafe they have is a great place to eat.

This is a beautiful garden! Lots of history but you’ll have to bring a guide with you to hear about it. There is no information provided as you walk around. We went during the week so it was not overly crowded.

The first tip: the Yves Saint Laurent Museum combined ticked gives you access to the Jardin, it has a good price and value and you don't have to be in the long lines to visit the garden. The Jardin and the Berbere Museum are very interesting, well kept, the staff is friendly. I totally recommend visiting this garden.

After seeing photos of this place, I was excited to visit.  It was a bit confusing as to whether we could visit the actual house, or which museum to see.  We were told the house was "closed" for the day (as they will say about a lot of things in the city), so we just spent time in the garden.  Even after arriving soon after opening, the place was packed and difficult to navigate around all of the people.  All in all, it was a bit disappointing.
Beautiful place to visit! Lines can get a bit long, so arrive early. Entrance fee is discounted for students and locals.
This place is beautiful. Even if you don’t care for YSL or fashion, the gardens are a must. Beautifully curated and amazing architecture. Take a guide to avoid lines at the cashier.

Spend at least 1,5hrs in this place, if you have more time will be great to visit museum that located close to this place. A lot of good photo spot in this place so be ready and wear something comfortable and noce that will match with the tone of the garden.
review_title: A must visit garden in Marrakech

review_text: just a small garden. nothing special.      overpriced and overcrowded and not so special plants. disappointed

One of the most beautiful gardens in Marrakech. The entrance fee is acceptable (7€ for adults). In this garden you will find a diverse fauna and flora to explore. We find a bit of a traffic jam for Instagram selfies but it was ok :)
Obviously, this place is a tourist magnet, but it is worth visiting. YSL just has style! Lunch in the little cafe was surprisingly good !
review_title: lots of tourists... but worth it.

review_text: Nothing amazing, but a good place to take a break from walking around the Medina.  Sort of an interesting history of the garden and not expensive.  Ride a horse drawn carriage over from the Medina and take a cab back.

Stunningly beautiful, and tranquil garden a short ride from the main square. Go to the museum first for a look at YSLs designs and dresses. As well as the gardens there is a great cafe to chill out with great food and drinks.
מקום נהננינו לטייל בגנים, תכנון יפה, שילב של הצמחיה והבריכות. לא נכנסנו לוילה We enjoyed a walk in the gardens, beautiful planning, a combination of vegetation and pools. We did not enter the villa
Need a break from the hustle of Marrakesh? This is an oasis in the centre of it all. Beautiful gardens and definitely worth buying the ticket to the YSL museum too. A must visit if in Marrakesh!
review_title: An oasis in a busy city!

review_text: This has to be on your list - but get there early to avoid the long queues for tickets. It is simply a beautiful and serene place and to be enjoyed slowly as there is so much to take in.
The place is not as big as I have expected.  It was very crowded when we were there so it was not so pleasant.  However, it is a good respite from the bustling of the city.

Waited till my last of 5 days to see this little gem.  Was somewhat disappointed with my overall Marrakech experience (still needs to develop further, lots of harassment from locals to buy stuff, etc), but this place was very well maintained and beautiful throughout.  Worth the visit for sure!

Beautifully clad botanical gardens full of exotic plants, trees & flowers, nice walk around the place, however underwhelming museum. So the iconic garden in itself is situated in the Majorelle area, around 20 minute drive from the Médina district. Located right next to the gardens is the YSL fashion museum. Tip: We found the museum experience to be below,par and really not worth the time. Skip the museum & just do the garden tour instead. Only advantage of doing the museum tour inclusive with the gardens is the fact that you get the garden tickets at the museum kiosk & this in turn helps you skip the obtusely long queues for the garden tickets and go straight to the gardens after the museum tour. But if you don’t mind queuing up & you get there early enough to avoid the ticket queues, the Majorelle garden tickets retail at 70 Dirhams per person & the YSL museum tickets are around 100 dirhams per person.
If you visit Majorelle garden you enter an amaizing wold of beautiful plants. It si also not so hot and they have also a coffee shop where you can relax
The plants and colours of this garden are worth the effort to get out there. I could have spent more than the 30 mins allocated.

It’s definitely one to tick off the list when visiting Marrakech! It’s definitely overcrowded which can spoil the visit since everyone wants to take the same photo or look at the same thing. Definitely a beautiful place.
beautiful gradens and beautiful colours. Get there early though as it gets very busy and impossible to take pictures
I am so glad we visited this garden. Beautiful although busy. Worthwhile to include in things to do in Marrakesh
Best garden in marrakech very nice but very busy must get there early in the morning. Worth the trip.
Enjoyed the trip different aspect of garden design. Not cheap but no Marrakesh trip is cheap unless you are confident enough to do in your own

As I said on the title, the garden itself was very beautiful and if you go at opening time (I believe at 8?) I’m sure it’s very very tranquil and a sight to behold. The blue, yellow and green contrasted so beautifully. Unfortunately we overslept and got there at around 10am, the queue was very small but when we got inside it was very crowded (can’t imagine how rammed it is once it reaches afternoon) Everyone is trying to take pictures for the gram (not judging - I did the same) but it really has become a tourist spot and not relaxing at all. Everywhere you go you have a billion people behind your photos. Overall I would say to go, but I would definitely not go again. A single visit is enough. The cafe is also really expensive.
review_title: Beautiful garden that’s great for Instagram but too many people, would not visit again

review_text: It's well worth a visit, especially now they have developed the area around it.  It has a lovely cafe and shops.

This garden is quite different to the usual sanctuary. Its winding paths take you through areas of shady bamboo and soaring palms, to small corners with ponds and pavilions to sit and ponder. The standout feature is the astonishing array of cacti, artfully planted to make the most of their form. These are almost sculpture like in framing the brilliant blue of the modernist house. Bright primary colours punctuate the garden in the form of pots. A world away from the city’s chaos and certainly worth seeing, especially if you have a soft spot for YSL.

Before going to Morocco, I only know this is the Yves Saint Laurent garden. I thought it might be commercial and didn't know what to expect. We arrived at around 11 in the morning. The queue took about 20min. There is a combo ticket for 180dr which includes both the garden, the YSL museum and the barber museum. A saving of 20dr. As we didn't plan to stay very long, we bought the tickets separately for the garden and museum at 170dr. Needless to say, a very pretty garden. Both the gift shop and cafe are well worth a visit. Had the best salad in Marrakech. Just simple and fresh. Also love my souvenir Majorelle blue acrylic paint.
I was expecting more from this place and it was a bit underwhelming. Makes for a few cool photo ops but it's so crowded that it's tough to even get any good pictures. Wouldn't return.

If you live cactus you will love it here. The main reason I wanted to visit is because the house once belonged to Yves St Laurent and his partner. The gardens they created are beautiful, it’s lovely to walk around.

Not to be missed. A garden of succulent delights. Don’t miss the Berber Museum within the garden. Arrive early or expect lineups although I know the website is saying buying advance tickets online is coming.
review_title: Most popular Marrakesh attraction for a reason

review_text: The desert style gardens are beautiful, big cacti and tall bamboo paths, the striking cobalt blue home and decor is so beautiful against the green of the plants. also the berber museum is interesting with a small but well done collection of berber artifacts, jewellery and costumes.

70dh to get in but buy the ticket at the Yves Saint Laurent Museum,  much shorter queue (none when we went compared to probably 40min wait). A large garden with plenty of shade (natural). There is also the villa garden which was open and has quite a different garden. We spent an hour looking around and there were lots of people sitting around relaxing.

This place was okay. The ques was huge we had to wait in line for ages in the 40 degree sunshine. Finally did got in felt like a melted ice cube. The prices were really expensive as well. They was only one ticket box office thing open as well witch made the que longer. Overall not great.
Jardin Majorelle is a very nice place, with amazing colours and a endless number of plants from all over the world.
review_title: Beautiful and peaceful place to visit

review_text: This is a lovely place to visit and lots to see, however the would definitely recommend coming early in the morning (we arrived at about 9:30) so you beat the crowds. By the time we left a few hours later, the place was mainly occupied by people posing for Instagram photos. We chose to go to the Berber museum too, which had a lot to look at, however no signs were in English, so we were sure on what we were seeing! If you want a more relaxed experience (and somewhere to sit down for a while and enjoy a mint tea in the midst of the garden) try Le Jardin Secret (but again go earlyish to beat any photo shoots). However if you’re here for a week, would recommend doing both!

We arrived early to get in the line that extended for a block.  It is an expensive attraction if you want to see everything.  While the gardens really are lovely the number of people there made it difficult to enjoy.

Gorgeous gardens. We combined the YSL museum and got a ticket for both the museum and the gardens. The gardens were very clean, the berber museum in the gardens is also interesting to see. We had a lovely day visiting YSl museum and the gardens. Highly recommend probably this is the only interesting thing in Marakkesh.

After reading reviews on how busy this place was we were hesitant on going but it came as apart of a package deal. We are glad we went as they are beautiful and such a big attraction in Marrakech, highly recommend going as soon as they open as there were no line but as we left about 45 mins after the line was very long
One of the only quiet places in Marrakech, you have to visit. Recommend going early to avoid queuing for too long

Beautiful gardens preserved by Yves Saint Laurent after they fell into disrepair. The Yves Saint Laurent museum is only 50 meters up the road and well worth a visit - and you can buy a combined ticket for the museum and the garden, saving you the (sometimes very) long queue for the Gardens.
What a lovely place, nice atmosphere unbelievable gardens. Nice cafe inside with lovely food. Very good service and a lovely place to take pictures.
Beautiful location - probably a must see in Marakesh - but very crowded and touristic - beautiful garden - but others in town are nice as well

These gardens are very popular, we walked from the medina and by the time we arrived the hordes had descended so we had to queue up to get in. I recommend an early start to avoid queues to enable getting good photos. Unfortunately the berber museum was closed on the day of our visit. The gardens are well maintained, the blue of the pavilion is exquisite but it is impossible to get a photo without other people in it unless you have good patience. Most guests seemed pre occupied taking selfies and not actually looking at the plants and trees there. We went into the gardens La Mamounia Hotel after which were free to access and equally as beautiful. Also The Jardin Secret is as beautiful as Majorelle. we arrived at 9.30 opening and had it to ourselves. Monty Don raved about it, it is well laid out as a paradise garden.
Beautiful and very well kept gardens! amazing photo opportunities, better visit in the morning cause it could be  crowded.

This place is one of those  "Instagram vs reality" It is a gorgeous location but VERY overcrowded and small. We visited a 10am and had to queue for around 40 minutes. Once you get inside you then have to queue up to get photos against the popular backgrounds. I don't know how people on Instagram get a good picture because there is always someone trying to walk past or is in the background. It is only around £7 to enter but you could easily walk around it in 10/15 minutes. We didn't bother going into the other museums or YSL section as we couldn't wait to get back to the hotel.
Go to yves saint laurent first so you can skip the 2 hour line for the garden. The best time of the day is also in the morning our guide telled us, b’coz to much people in the afternoon.
We didnt realise there was a combined visit with this and also the museum. which would of saved us money
Although I thought it was pricey for the entry, the gardens are very beautiful and semi worth it. If you want to take instagram worthy pictures this place is worth a visit.

We loved seeing the beautiful collection of indigenous and other plants.  If you love visiting gardens, DO NOT MISS this! Hint:  Bypass the (long!) line for the garden and continue down the block to the YSL Museaum window...here you can skip the long line and get tickets to see all three: Jardin Majorelle, Berber Museum(inside the garden), and YSL Museum.  This is the perfect way to spend a morning where you'll feel comfortable without a guide(save that for the Souks and Palace visits!!)
Lovely gardens! Bypass the long ticket line and head to the YSL museum a few steps away. You can buy tickets for both the YSL museum and the Majorelle gardens.

A beautiful garden full of colours and sounds in the heart of Marrackech.Plants,cactus,and trees from all over the world.Its next to the YSL Museum so you can take one ticket from the YSL museum and visit also the garden saving money and time.Also visit the small museum of berberian art which is inside the garden.The cafe inside the garden worths to pay a visit ,taking a break and enjoy a snack.
We visited around 10 am on a Sunday, the place was busy but not too crowded. Perfect photo opportunities, interesting plants, vibrant colors.

I have queued up with thousands of people for hours and hours without a roof to protect us from the sun, which has been picking up since the morning, and the smarter thing it's the security guards who are asking for money to do not make queu. the ticket is very expensive compared to museums even in Europe all that to see specimens of plants!
review_title: The biggest queu i had never make

review_text: I loved the place for the quiet atmosphere and the shadow where you can hide from the sun and chill out. I totally recommend the museum of Berber culture where you can see traditional outfits and elements of everyday life of Berber people. My friend, though, found the garden to small and too little entertaining. Still, I would go there again.
review_title: When you’re tired of the noisy Marrakech

review_text: Definitely a pretty oasis in busy Marrakech but holy people! Go early and be prepared to have people in your photos.

Created by French artist Jacques Majorelle in the 1920's and later purchased by Yves Saint Laurent, the garden is a place of peace and tranquility - and has plenty of oriental influences. The gardens offer cool relaxation in the middle of any visit to Marrakech and has been well kept over the years. Depending on when you go, it can get very busy - so avoid peak times. We visited around 9.30am and saw no queues - admittedly, not in high season.

we prebooked  with a tour company ,if we hadnt we would have been queuing around the block,and that was half an hour before it opened! It is a beautiful place and if less people were admitted at the same time. you could enjoy a lovely experience,But it is difficult to stand and enjoy whilst being elbowed and nudged so much.To take decent photos you need to be extremely patient ,then grab your chance .If you are lucky you will get a few seconds of opportunity.It wasnt as amazing as the hype led me to believe.If you want to view the museum ,it is an extra charge .
review_title: shady oasis  but a victim of its success

review_text: Majorelle created his botanical garden inspired by traditional Moroccan gardens, the end result was a lush tropical garden around his Moorish style villa. The villa houses the Islamic Art Museum of Marrakech, the Berber Museum and has recently opened the Musee Yves Saint Laurent. Really interesting
review_title: A real oasis in the city

review_text: Majorelle OK, OK, the world knows. Yves St Laurent has given his name to what was formerly known as the Jardins Majorelle. I have been going there since childhood (I am a casablancaise). I always loved the botanic gardens, its mysterious pools, and its secluded corners overrun with bamboos and greenery. Since the advent of St Laurent and his partner Pierre Berge and their coterie of jet setting friends, the gardens have turned into a must see “zoo” of epic proportions. On the day I was there in May, a line of at least 300 people was waiting to get in. Too bad: the magic of the place is greatly diminished, while the ludicrously expensive prices in the Yves St Laurent boutique keep climbing. Don’t expect to see any Majorelle paintings of any note.. they remain hidden in major collections. The Berber museum is interesting if you can elbow your way in. Dommage. If you go, try and head for Marrakech off season. The whole town has turned a sanitized Disneyland.
review_title: Avoid unless you want to stand in line with 300 others

review_text: Looked forward to visiting this house, garden and museum - a great bit of history weather you love fashion or not, Yves Saint Laurent was an icon of his time.  The garden is just beautiful with many of the same plants from the original planing.  It was a hot day but the garden has grown up to give lots of shade and comfort.  I'd recommend that you go early in the morning, it opens at 9:30, because its extremely popular and the line up grows fast.  Openly problem is you can't book ahead unless in a tour group and the ticketing is slow (very Morocco).  Lovely café with great coffee.  Well worth getting a joint ticket (three seperate venues - Garden, House & Museum, which is just down the road) as all are worth seeing and it works out much cheaper.  Give yourself at least half a day to do it all.
review_title: Lovely morning walk through a peaceful garden

review_text: A lovely oasis to visit, dedicated Yve’s Saint Laurent. Nice cafe and lots of interesting plants and fish life.
It was very well kept. Go at a time where there isn't a lot of tourist, preferably early morning or closing time, if you want lots of pictures and not to wait in line.

This is a lovely setting and peaceful in the crazy city.  Its a bit of a walk out of the Medina but worth finding however, it takes ages to get a ticket and line 2 was a lot slower than line 1.  this is because the team outside moved those in line 1 over to other ticket windows and never moved anyone out of line 2.  So don't get into line 2 as it was very frustrating queuing for an hour whilst those in line 1 joined, got tickets and entered the garden before you!
review_title: Great oasis in the hustle and bustle

review_text: Le Jardin est tres beau. Ca prends une heure. Aller au muse the YSL. Ok you need to stop by the Jardin for an hour and also the YSL museum for another hour. It is a $3 cab fare and can get a great lunch for $5 around the corner.

Had a few hours to kill before heading back to the airport, what a great place to do just that! Truly stunning gardens tucked away in Marrakech. Didn’t visit the YSL museum which lead to an half hour wait (straight to the front of the queue if you do the museum) but well shaded and fine even on a warm day. Will definitely visit the Berber museum on my next visit. The gardens are a must if you visit Marrakech

Great place for relaxing after a morning in the Souks of Marrakech. Located in Gueliz (modern part) and as students we paid a total of €7 for the two of us. Prices at the café is high, and the service is terrible. The garden itself is nice.
Beautiful garden...lines were very long...worth the wait....excellent for beautiful pics. Just expected just a little bit more from this attraction.
We went to see the gardens, not much to see really. What was worth seeing was the museums Yves St Laurent and the Berber, but disappointed that it was closed on Wednesdays.
The gardens were really beautiful and perfect for taking photos and getting out of the bustling city centre. They were very peaceful and full of lovely colours.

It is a nice garden but kind of small. For 70 dhs to enter, I felt it was a bit overpriced. They use the YSL brand to market the location so I understand why they can bring up the admission fee. The garden is well kept and the blue museum in the middle is a great location for photos.
writer_informations: Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates,602 contributions

review_text: Lovely visit, my children and I were amazed by the beauty of this garden.  It  is well worth a visit if you are a fan of nature and beautiful scenery. Jardin Majorelle is Clean, well kept and not too crowded. There is also an on site museum.

Beautiful, peaceful, not to be missed when visiting Marrakech. I went with a group of friends from a conference; once in the gardens, we all went our separate ways to view and explore all the pathways, flowers, plants, shop and museum.  I took so many pictures; each would make a lovely portrait suitable for display.
Enjoyed our time in the garden, it was like an Oasis and much more. Take your time a soak it in, it was great.
review_title: Worth the time and very relaxing.

review_text: A lovely day out, great place to see plants from all sorts of heritage, and thanks to the bamboo you can get out of the sun quite easily. Would highly recommend, well worth the entrance price. Worth noting that the student price is half so make sure to show your card if you have one.
Very nice garden with a beautiful cloth shop and a lot of influence from Western art in general. Yet, not the most representative spot in town.

This place is definitely worth a visit, and I understand why its so popular.When walking around in the garden you can see that a lot of thought has been put into how buildings, water and plants should complement each other. Colors and sounds have been put together in a very beautiful way and you can easily spend hours just walking around enjoying it. Its very popular, so expect many people and arrive early if possible.

We enjoyed visiting the gardens. They were beautiful. If you have a licensed tour  guide they are able to buy tickets in a separate area  and you don't have to wait in line. We had no wait at all- and went right in. Be sure to go visit the YSL Museum next door and their is a wonderful gift shop there too.
review_title: LOVELY PLACE TO VISIT IN MARRAKECH!  IF YOU COME WITH A GUIDE YOU DON'T HAVE TO WAIT IN LINE FOR A TICKET.

review_text: We were taken hereby our guide from Merzouga Tours, we loved the place, full of unusual plants and colour, in place for Instagram people. Little cafe inside too. We went on a cloudy day, I’m sure you would get an even better feel for the place under different sunlight.
review_title: Peaceful gardens in a chaotic city

review_text: We went in a Wednesday only to find that the museum was closed. The Gardens were beutifully kept however the place was over run with tourists taking pictures for instagram! Spoiled it slightly as it meant it slowed the walk around. The 2 shops were interesting to look around and the toilets were beautiful and clean

The garden is nice, lots of bamboo and plants from all over the world. The coolest part is the water beds and the blue house. Not expensive and close to Median so if you want to make a quick trip, it's very easy. Not super crowded either. I expected a more extravagant garden but the House is the main attraction.
review_title: Very pretty but a little underwhelming

review_text: The most wonderful place to stay and relax in Marrakech ! A Beautiful oasis in a busy city with a warm welcoming feel ,friendly staff ,relaxing pool great service & food !

Go early at morning (garden opens at 9.00AM) and there will be no lines to get in. We got there at 9.30AM but there were already very many people so it must be very crowded later. You need about half an hour to see it whole, more if you want to visit museum (we didn't go). Very picturesque place but you will not be able to take the pictures of the blue villa like in the brochures.

I love plants flowers nature so I thoroughly enjoyed walking in these beautiful gardens, it’s lovely so much colour and natural beauty.  I thought it was really reasonable price for entry . Get there early to avoid queues it opens at 10am . We got a coffee after as there is a strip of mainly coffee shops nearby, great couple of hours .

Go with time since it is a major tourist attraction, the line is reallly long. ( i would spend no more tan 30 minutes inside the Jardin) Check in advance since the day i went the museum was close and i only visited the jardin.
writer_informations: Province of Buenos Aires, Argentina,8 contributions

review_text: Nice calm gardens to enjoy huge cactus and other plants. There is a nice blue wall to grab some nice pictures! Go the the YSL museum right beside it afterwards
Nice and varied garden. Even interesting and beautiful in March. Also a nice little museum. Wonderful warm blue colours
If you have a couple of hours to kill and you like gardens. This is a good shout. We went in the morning before lunch. Its busy, 2 queues but its not expensive entry. Enjoy!

Despite the wait to buy a ticket, we loved the Jardin Majorell visit. The place holds a great history, the botanical garden is unique. Plus, what is special with Jardin Majorelle is the activities around with the beautiful berbère museum, boutique and the wonderful café.
This was so enchanting, also make sure to go into the museum and learn a little abut Moroccan Berber culture.
Worth a visit as simply stunning. Quite small and full of those seeking the perfect Instagram pose. Entry is 70 dh but so worth it.
Beautiful. Everything... each detail.... Must go... Try during the week, not the week-ends. Really, really amazing. A place to visit.
majorel gardens are even beeter than i thought, and the new museum is fantastic. i wish i had more time to go there again

Top Tip: Buy ticket in advance. There are two queues - one sells 180 dhm ticket which is museum, garden and berber museum entry. Second queue sells only park ticket 70dhm - but that queue is MASSIVE! You will wait forever in a sun to get in. Garden is small and packed with people. Hard to take a picture without anyone photo bombing you. Museum and garden is beautiful.
review_title: Buy tickets online to avoid massive queue

review_text: Wouldn't visit there is I'm on the clock and my time is limited on Marrakech. I'd definitely try to access the Berber Museum though, very interesting!!!
This was incredibly underwhelming. Also, people wrote their names on all the cactuses, crazy. It's also super tiny for the price.
Beautiful and calming gardens, well worth buying the combination ticket and visiting the berber museum and YSL museum. Well catered for disabled visitors with helpful staff.
Lovely gardens full of amazing cacti.  Feels slightly shabby but the local dress and jewellery in the Berber museum were stunning.
This is not a fair review, because we never got in. The line was 200m long and it was 40 celcius. ONE ticket office open!!!
I thought I would be wow'ed by this garden, and it is pretty enough, and I am happy to have seen it, but I have seen gardens much more spectacular than this.

Well how to start...the place is small and costs 70dh or 7 euros to enter the garden only... there is also a 2 museo options we have not done, and a long line to enter there is a catcus garden, so if you never saw catcus maybe you will like a little or if you are a Yves fan does not worth the time and money, not sure how this is the number 1 attraction listed here
This was one of the most interesting g gardens I have visited what they have achieved is amazing a MUST When visiting Marrakech
Relax and enjoy the beautiful garden with many beautiful plants from all around world. Nice and cool under the bamboo plants.

Visited this place when I was Marrakech and I was not disappointed. It's a must-see place for anyone interested in designer fashion. Great selection of YSL dresses and a very modern cinema showing a movie about designers life highlights. The place accepts card payments which is definitely a bonus, recommend buying a ticket for gardens, ysl foundation and designer house any Instagram maniac will be in heaven :)
The flowers, the colours and the architecture of this place make it a must see if you visit Marrakech. The tickets are not that expensive based on the experience.
So much colour and diversity of plant life.  Also can imagine how quiet and serene this place would have been and how it inspired Ives and the colours in his many iconic designs.
review_title: lovely place to wonder on a sunny day under the shade of many exotic trees

review_text: Exquisitely set out. The contrast of the cacti in all shapes and sizes and shades of green, the passageways of bamboo, contrasted with the brilliant blue of the house was surreal.
A must see! It was crowded with people taking photos but got better towards closing time (the last hour).
The garden is really very nice. The colors are great in the sunshine and the plants are amazing. After beeing in the desert, we just couldn't cope with such a crowd.
Amazing garden with a lot of beautiful plants, if you come in Marrakech, you're obliged to see it !!!

The gardens were absolutely stunning, we were surprised by how gorgeous they actually were because the photos online do not do it any justice! We arrived at 10.15, waited in line for ten minutes and then spent a few hours strolling around enjoying the views! 10/10 for good Instagram photos!
We love these gardens.... the feeling and beauty of them and there is a really interesting  Berber museum which is not expensive...
Very pretty gardens, interesting Berber museum (well worth the extra entrance fee), and next to Yves saint Laurent museum which you can get combined ticket for.
Great couple of hours, would liked to have stayed longer.  Beautiful garden followed by the museum.  We were dropped off at the door, it was a long queue so get there for when it opens.
Unique legacy. Yves St. Laurent's gardens, museum, new and old art and "very reasonable store" of his North African life.
Small, well kept gardens.  Given all the hype around it, I was expecting something more.  Just don't set your expectations too high and you won't be disappointed.
review_title: Nice but not worth the Hype

review_text: Absolutely beautiful! Amazing garden great place to take  some very nice pictures! This place is a must see while visiting in Morocco.
this is a must visit when in Marrakech wonderful gardens make sure to book in advance as it gets very crowded and the lines can be long !!
Although a bit small, this garden is a real pleasure to visit.  The Berber Museum was also quite small but with an interesting exhibit.
review_title: Gorgeous garden of cacti and exotic plants

review_text: The gardens are a reasonable walk out of the medina through some of the more interesting places in Marrakech. My advice if travelling in that direction would be to get a taxi. The gardens them selves are beautiful, filled with huge and dramatic plantlife. The history of the place is as interesting as the garden itself so it's well worth a visit. It is incredibly busy so pre-booking and getting there as early as possible is a must. We arrived around 9am and queued for nearly two hours. Also once inside, as the gardens are quite small, it's really busy with people stopping to take photos. All part of the experience and well worth a visit.
So... What can I say about this blue garden? It's like an Oasi. Sit there, listen... and nothing else.
This is a very popular place. Get there before the gates open (7:30 is not a bad idea and buy a ticket to the other attraction as well to cut down on the time wasted in line. Very peaceful gardens.
review_title: The early bird gets the worm

review_text: Nice place but not with the taxi ride a and entrance fee. Even at 10am it was packed, you would have people bumping into you, wanting you to respect space for the perfect instagram picture (taking 10 at a time, different poses)  but then you don't get the same respect for a quickie. Don't bother.
review_title: Waste, full of tourists in tiny space, instagram wannabes all over

review_text: The gardens are definitely beautiful and very well maintained. I was expecting to see more of the cobalt blue it is known for but was certainly not unhappy that I visited. There are several ponds and incredibly large cactus gardens and the whole place is an Instagramer's dream.
review_title: Beautiful Shady Gardens a Welcome Reprieve from the Heat

review_text: You have to wait for a long hour to book the ticket and I cannot understand why you must pay a lot of money to see a garden. I understand that you have to pay for the name of Yves Saint Laurent or Majorelle but I insist that the ticket is too expensive. Sorry about this...
Visited these place many years ago when tourists weren’t so many .. is nice to come back and see it again and it hasn’t take a wrinkle!! Take your time and enjoy it !

Worth a visit although nothing special really.  Following the advice from various websites, we arrived at 9am in the morning.  The queue was an hour long and it was a very hot day. Annoyingly, when we came out around 3 hours later there were no queues! so go later in the day if you want to avoid the line.
I visited this garden five years ago and loved it. This more recent visit was disappointing due to people mainly focused on themselves rather than the beauty of the garden
review_title: Crowded and full of people taking selfies

review_text: Worth a visit, it's an amazing botanical garden, almost a century old. It's water pods, cactus and trees are the perfect environment for a well preserved house/museum.
review_title: Outstanding Garden, 100 years old cactus and trees

review_text: It is a beautifully manicured, quite little peace of heaven in the middle of the hustle bustle of Marrakech.. So different to anything else you may get here. It is quite bright and colourful.. the only issue is you do get disturbed and distracted by the many tourists standing in corners taking photographs. Everything else was superb.
review_title: Quiet little oasis in the middle of the hustle bustle of city life!
writer_informations: Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam,1,446 contributions

review_text: Amazing garden.Amazing cafe inside.Not so hot inside so is ok. very long queue outside for entry but is normal in this places

If you are in Marrakech and can spare a couple of hours to visit this place it is worth it.  Gardens are very tropical in design, well laid out and a soothing break from the heat and noise of Marrakech.  Go early, it gets very busy.
Just Beautiful.... A Wonderful Garden that is both pleasant and truly relaxing. I Enjoyed Just Sitting There, Under The shade taking In The View!!
Lush gardens, colorful stone and tile , a fabulous little cafe with great food, great ponds with fish, This place is a hidden gem!

This garden was absolutely picturesque, but very busy! I would recommend for people to arrive just before the opening time, as there can be a queue build up.  We visited earlier on in the day, and it was very hot, so avoid around the afternoon time if you cannot take a lot of heat! All in all a great experience and it’s a must do if you’re in Marrakesh! Entry price for just the garden, 70 Moroccan Dirhams! Enjoy!
My family and I really enjoyed our morning trip to Jardin Majorelle.  It’s a great place to escape the hustle and bustle of the city.
review_title: An oasis of calm in a lively city!

review_text: Made the mistake of not booking online as the queue to pay was very long and very hot stood in the sun. Entry was reasonably priced at 70dh and another 30dh for berber museum. The layout was extremely good with good pathways and seating should you wish to rest with all types of exotic plants, shrubs and trees and wild exotic birds. There is a small restaurant which served traditional cuisine at not to bad a price. The Berber Museum was well worth the money showing the culture, artifacts, jewellery, costumes, weapons etc. You need to spend around 2hrs to appreci.ate the gardens an museum. Would recommend also just around the corner is the Yves St Lauren house and gardens a combined ticket was 180dh. I unfortunately did not visit but maybe next time
These gardens are beautiful as the museum. Too many tourists though. There is also a nice cafe' inside for a quick lunch.
We had a whole morning here and it was stunning designed beautifully lots of hidden gems plenty of room to wander and  no pressure to rush  truly fabulous

This garden is just magical and you really can't miss it whilst you are here. It's a great attraction to do the day after a walking tour or something more hectic as it feels like a world away from the busy streets of Marrakech. If I was to do it again I would get there much earlier as the queue was huge by 11am. the only thing that ruined the experience was everyone posing for selfies every two minutes, it gets exhausting battling the selfie sticks just to get a good view - but such is life these days!
We went during Ramadan and were expecting it to be a bit more quite. A lot of tourists. not as beautiful as we expected.. i think Secret Garden in Marrakech is much more beautiful. Still nice to see.

I have visited this garden twice now and it is definitely worth it as I love the colours, calmness and diversity of the plants. The entry price was 70 Dirhams (around £7). There is a one way system which was not there the first time I visited so I imagine it may get congested at busy times. I am sure more of the garden was open the first time I visited but I may be mistaken. It took us about 30 mins to walk around the garden but as we were on a time scale to get back on the open top bus tour this was enough time to enjoy the sights. The bus tour is every hour so if you are not on a time scale it is possible to stay there longer and enjoy the garden or get a meal. There are also a few local shops and cafes.
This small garden was worth the visit.  The Berber Museum was small but very well done.  I enjoyed the traditional costumes.

It’s a beautiful garden no doubt but definitely takes away by all the hard core social media posers jostling for copious amounts of pictures. It’s all about the photos and nothing about appreciating the garden and nature vibe. It’s a pity but a good place to observe the severity of current social trends. The back part of the garden is better for some quiet reflection and enjoyment.

There is a tiny garden, about 30 min walk from the medina (city center). The line up is usually very long in the morning and gets better in the afternoon ( my Airbnb was across the street) it is really surprising to see the positive reviews. The garden is very small, not impressive at all and the typical chaos that is attached to Morocco follows you there too. Honestly, for the Europeans or folks who live close to greenery, this just feels like a normal day. However, being away from the constant harassment,  theft, and aggressive and rude behaviors in Marrakech was a good change! Almost felt like this tiny ahd walled garden is a heaven!
review_title: Tiny garden! not impressive at all.

review_text: We were lucky enough to skip the long queue with a guide who purchased tickets. Knowing what’s inside I don’t think I would have waited to enter the gardens. In my opinion, the cactus were the most interesting part of the garden the rest was average if not a little underwhelming and a bit in need of upkeep. I guess it depends what you’ve seen in terms of Gardens before to know whether you’d find this worthwhile.

I highly recommend this place, one of the top attractions of Marrakech. We even managed to avoid the usual que before the entrance, we have visited Jardin Majorelle after 1pm. We have seen the next door Museum of Yves Saint Laurent and went to this beautiful garden right after. I really love the blue colour of the main villa, you can´t get enough of it :) and together with the yellow and orange and all the plants around it makes it dream-like atmosphere....the only problem is the amount of people wandering everywhere...I guess that earlier in spring it´s a bit better.

We visited here because we felt we should given it was one of most photographed buildings in Marrakech but we were actually taken aback at just how beautiful it was and how much we enjoyed it. The gardens surrounding the building are so relaxing with lots of benches dotted around and various plants to look at whilst you listen to the birds sing. Its not a huge place unless you see the other museums but is definitely worth a visit.
An absolute must. So tranquil and cool away from the manic bustle of the city. Must get here early to avoid the queues and crowds. Best enjoyed with less people about.

Visiting this garden is simply the most serene experience, soothing and peaceful with a permanent feast for the eye. This is wonderful place and their little café is excellent. I love this place and for the last 15 years I visit it at least every 2 years. It keeps getting better.
This is the spot for marrocen vibes. For local food smell and colors. Come at evening! It is much more alive... and go inside the market!
Amazing historic place to visit. Coffee place inside very welcome and tasty 😋 museum is very gorges and interesting to see and you can buy his peace’s in a shop.

You are not going to find solitude at the Majorelle Gardens, but if you can find a shady spot on a bench, you'll feel like you are alone in a beautiful sea of palms, cacti and spectacular color.  The gardens are manicured but still feel somewhat natural, even with the vibrant blue, orange and yellow pots.  The Yves Saint Laurent and Berber Museums are definitely worth a visit, and if there is a long line at the garden entrance, you can buy a combined ticket at the YSL museum. I loved the mister that kept us cool while we waited in line!
Le Jardin majorelle, together with the YSL museum, is one of the best spot in Marrakech to discover the powerful colors of this city. Pure poetry.

We visited around lunch time, place was extremely busy. Had to wait in the queue to take photo, way over crowded. Berber museum was really interesting. Nice place for lunch. Food was delicious. We spent around 3 hours in gardens as we wanted to escape Marrakech madness.

Visited these small but very stylish gardens. It was extremely busy when i went so made it difficult to get any decent photographs. These gardens however have much to offer despite its small size with ornate water features and immaginative planting. There is a very pleasant outdoor cafe which is cooled by a light water misting system. Entrance price was fair 70 dirham (about £7.00). I recommend these gardens whilst you are in Marrakech which arent far from the centre Jemaa El-Fnna.

This is one of the best maintained gardens. The variety of cacti is just breathtaking and very generously presented. One can’t wander around but the pathways allow you to see everything. The waiting line is always very very long if you don’t come w a guide. A total must.
Pre book to avoid a long queue. Great place for Instagram pics. YSL left a mark. Visit early morning

Nice place to visit when evading the burning sun during the day. Could become a little bit crowded but still worth while! Don t miss it! If you are in Marrakech this Place has to be in your bucket list. Always Busy, and outside the medina. The Place Is magical
review_title: a beautiful and quiet place in a botanical garden

review_text: This is the second time I’ve been to the gardens. I’d say it was quieter 8 years ago, and I don’t think there’s any time of the day you can go now without it being really busy. At least when you queue outside there are cooling mist sprays and a sun shade. It did look a bit tired in parts and the gardens are obviously having some work done to them - but it will always be a “must see” in the city and I would still recommend it to people. We had wanted to go to the Berber museum but it was shut - maybe next time!

We arrived with pre-ordered tickets when the gardens opened. Within half an hour it was wall- to-wall tourists jockeying for photo ops. The gardens are very pleasant, mostly cacti. The Berber museum is a wonderful intro  to Berber life. Be  sure to pick up the English language guides in each room.
This garden is paradise. Lots of shady spots to escape the midday sun. So peaceful and beautifully kept. Gets busy at peak periods, but manageable.
review_title: Stunning - a must-see when in Marrakech

review_text: We went to the Jardin this week and thought we would turn up and have a peaceful wander around the garden. We turned up and the queue to get in was huge! (Didn’t consider it being the school hols etc). Anyway we got in and spent a good few hours there - wandering around, people watching, and eating/drinking in the cafe. Despite it being so busy it was still such a pleasure to be there. Would definitely recommend it.
review_title: Even when busy it was lovely

review_text: It was OK, but I don't think that is has value to wait long time to buy the ticket.... And there are so many people and I could not see well. But I liked the berber museum inside of the Jardin.
Had a lovely morning here- but go early to avoid the droves of people posing for photos (or enjoy the people watching opportunity!). Beautiful gardens and stunning colours, well worth visiting.

We went in June. Our Riad host recommanded to go in the morning as the temperature gets verry hot in the afternoon. However, ALL tourists and tour busses go in the morning... be aware of this during your visit. The garden is not that big so it easily gets overcrowded. We took a taxi again back in the afternoon after 4pm. And indeed there was no line at the entrance. Yes temp was high in the afternoon but the garden offers enough shadow places to walk or sit in. Less crowded and more changes to take nice pictures. Afterwards you can have a nice icecream in the cafe next to the entrance. Taxi from the medina to the garden, no more than 30 dirham. Do negotiate!

I rarely take the time to write a review that doesn't have a positive thing to say, but this is an official tourist trap. Small, unimpressive garden- mostly cactus and bamboo, and supremely overpriced. Just don't go.
No clue why you would wait 1 hour + for this garden. Do the YSL museum (must see in Marrakesh) ...and the line up is much shorter :-)
The best Garden in marrakech I highly recommend to visit this place and the berber museum You pay 7 € for entry but it's a great place in marrakech

All the gardens I visited whilst in Marrakesh were incredible. This one was no exception, a lovely walk through the bamboo to a long pond filled with turtles. Placed in the centre is a cafe with welcoming staff! A very picturesque place to visit!
After waiting almost an hour in the queue to see the garden we were disappointed. Not at all as amazing as we’ve heard. If you’re a student carry id to receive discount.

The gardens are really beautiful with a wide variety of plants and trees. I was especially captivated by the cacti, of which there are quite a few different species and they grow very tall, creating a stunning display. The Berber museum is interesting and excellently presented. Just along the road is the Yves Saint Laurent Museum which is also extremely well presented and gives a great incite into the man and his journey through, and influence on, the world of fashion. The only thing that I would recommend is to go first thing in the morning as the queues to buy tickets can be long and the gardens especially can get busy, which may affect your enjoyment of the garden's tranquility.

Stunning gardens for a peaceful walk around, not what you would expect to find in the middle of Marrakesh. A must visit, I now have hundreds of photos of cactus on my phone! Looking at reviews it seems that many have trouble with ticket queues, we must have struck gold as we walked up to a booth with no one else at it.
review_title: Beautiful & peaceful escape away from the heat and buzz of the city.

review_text: Beautiful spot offering peace and tranquility. When we visited it was mid afternoon and pretty busy which was a shame as there was a large group of loud and shouty tourists in the gardens as well. As we stayed later it got much quieter so I would definitely recommend going first or last thing to enjoy the peace. Berber museum is sadly closed each Wednesday so bear that in mind. Cafe offered good drinks and ice cream
review_title: A little oasis in the centre of Marrakech!

review_text: Nice garden come early to avoid the queue, remember to buy ticket for the YSL Museum next door. Really worth a visit

The YSL Jardin is walkable from the main medina and is worth a stop, even if simply to escape the heat or the craziness of the main square. Once inside, it will likely be completely packed with tourists (probably like yourself). However, the gardens themselves are peaceful and nice to look at. It's rather small, so expect to spend 30-40 minutes maximum in here. A pro tip if the line is long is to find someone selling passes for a markup of $6 (well worth it).
review_title: Nice Refuge from the Medina and the Heat

review_text: This tiny 2.5 acre wonderland feels much bigger because the meandering paths and variety of plantings and fountains captivate the eye.  The line for tickets moved very slowly so rather than spend an hour in the sun it is wise to buy tickets online! The ice cream and sorbet across from the entrance is really good too!
review_title: Enjoyable but buy ticket in advance!

review_text: The queue into the garden was very long - we were waiting about 30 min in the tough heat. We paid 180 DH each for the combined ticket (gardens and museum roughly £15). As soon as we got in we were waiting to find out what all the fuss is about. The garden/ museum was all a let down for us but it made is appreciate the gardens in England. The garden here wasnt amazing especially as we expected it to be rather 'fashionista' as it's owned by YSL. The garden is full of green cacti and tall trees but couldn't see any colourful exiting plants or garden features. The museum was impressive but praised the owner who was just the owner of the garden so nobody 'special.' Most things were written in French  so we didn't know what things were. It is very crowded also but we definitely wouldn't recommend it to a friend.

We went during Ramadan 2019 and didnt realize it opened at 9am and not 8am as it usually does. Could not find any info online on opening hours during Ramadan either. We got there for 8 and there was no lineup. Lineup started building around 8:30. By the time we left there was still a large lineup about 100 feet long. Garden is neat! Lots of plants. Great for plant lovers. If you're not into plants or gardens, this isn't the place for you. Costs 70dh to get in. Downside is that it's crazy busy and full of tourists and large tour groups. Makes it difficult to take a picture and kinda ruins the quieter atmosphere. Taxi from the square costs 20dh..dont pay more.
review_title: Great little garden but way too many tourists

review_text: Other than having to queue for about 45 minutes, these gardens are massively overpriced. There was barely anything inside. The Secret Gardens in the centre of Marrakech are worth a visit, I wouldn't waste my time or money visiting these.

What gorgeous gardens but you cannot move for tourists they were everywhere and so rude..  it cost 70 dirhams each to get in.. there was a cafe and museums and bookstores within and many plants and cacti within.. wonderful fountains .. it took about 30minutes to get in but theres umbrellas for shade and mist so wasnt too bad. Glad I visited but wouldn't go again cos of all the people
Excellent location and amazing views and scenery. I highly recommend this to any travelers going here in the future.
