We are maybe spoilt comparing this to some of the gardens in the U.K. It wasn’t very impressive and far smaller than I was expecting. We spent more time queuing to get in than walking round the garden I’m afraid.
Lovely open air garden restaurant. Food was divine and varied, prices right. Full menu, staff very accommodating.
review_title: Spectacular garden setting in the Medina

review_text: Visited in May 2019 and found this to be a small but quaint and unique garden. You can tour the garden in about half an hour.
review_title: Small but quaint and pretty garden

review_text: You can get some nice photos and it can be cool with the shade of the trees but other than that I don’t think it’s worth the 70 dirham entrance fee. It’s super busy and full of instagram wannabes. Unless you are an expert about cacti it’s just going to be a nice garden. Also, can people stop scribing their names into the greenery? It’s not cute, it’s vandalism.
Lovely garden and cooler than the intense may heat, but quite pricey for what you see. Similar review for the YSL museum, nice but pricey
Amazing and absolutely stunning. A truly memorable experience never to be forgotten. Highly recommended.

We had a lovely visit here, it’s so peaceful amid the madness of Marrakech.  It’s a shame some visitors have found it necessary to inscribe their names into various plants around the place but it is still a wonderful garden and well worth a visit.  Price is 70 MAD for the gardens alone, 170 MAD if you want the museum aswell
Gardens were beautiful but it was so crowded (even though we went early in the morning).  Everyone seemed to be posing for selfies and instagram photos.  Almost difficult to enjoy the scenary.

I visited Jardin Majorelle with my partner in May 2019. It was a blisteringly hot day and the garden was a refreshing respite from the heat. Waiting in line for tickets did not take long and the student discount made the price reasonable. The garden is large and full of plants from all over the world. There are many beautiful photo opportunities. It was a little busy with many other tourists but manageable. While there we also visited the Berber museum which costs extra and, while small, is worthwhile.
review_title: Beautiful oasis in the red city of Marrakech

review_text: The YSL museum and the Majorelle garden are a must when in Marrakesh ! The Berber Museum was closed because of Ramadan (will have yo come back to visit it). But avoid buying things in the shop as you may get the same just outside for less than half the price
The garden is a wonderful peaceful retreat from the hustle of every-day Marrakech.  Worth the wait in line.
review_title: Gorgeous collection of plants and wonderful shade from the heat

review_text: Fabulous colour, really beautiful gardens, well worth the long queue,that was fast moving.Great photo spot too!
Lovely gardens, and beautiful blue building. Organise a guide to take you and book tickets in advance.  Long queues to get in.

Yves Saint Laurent left a beautiful and, when we visited, restful house and garden. It was getting very busy as we left at around midday. We had to queue for about 45 mins to get in, so make sure you have a bottle of water with you. We had lunch here and the restaurant/cafe was really good. Not cheap, but it's a tourist attraction so to be expected! The museum is educational and very interesting in all areas. The garden with its extraordinary varieties of bamboo and exotic plants in brightly coloured pots is delightful to walk around providing cool shade most of the way around.

The gardens are stunning & the "majorelle blue" of the buildings & walkways is breath taking. A visual masterpiece. So many species of cacti & wonderful plants. Take time to really enjoy the whole experience - get there early to avoid the crowds & enjoy a relaxing coffee in the cafe in the gardens to really soak up the atmosphere. I cannot recommend the Jardin Majorelle highly enough - it is a oasis of calm in Marrakech.

Lovely place to visit. But staff were asking visitors to evacuate main section of the garden even after charging 70 Dirhams of ticket price. Whatever may be the reason, they can do it out of operational hours. Also, it was bit too crowdy. They can control count of people at a time so that visitors can enjoy the lovely sight !
review_title: Lovely but a bit too much crowd

review_text: Worth the walk, awesome spot for pictures. The line appeared long but moved pretty fast and there was shade and water misting 👌🏻
Definitely go if you're in Marrakech - the most beautiful gardens you will ever see!!! Lots of tourists so try to go as early as possible!!!

You would think a garden is a garden and consider giving this a miss.  That would be a mistake.  There is usually quite a queue, so it would be worth booking on-line. What a beautiful venue.  The gardens are beautifully maintained, with lovely nooks and crannies, and a really lovely tribute to Yves St Laurent.  The restaurant is worth a visit as well.  For photographers, this is a dream, with bright, beautiful colours everywhere.  You won't regret adding this to your "things to do" list.

We went at about 11 am.  There was a very long line but you can bribe (literally) the guards to get you in a smaller line- which we did because it was hot and we didn't feel like waiting.  Inside was beautiful- so many vibrant colors but just very crowded.  People  everywhere.  Would probably not go again but we did get some great photos.
It's very nice, full of flowers and plants (that's all you will see) it gets very warm tho. Worth the visit!
review_title: all you will see its plants everywhere. Its lovely but it gets very warm

review_text: This is a nice garden but not worth 70 Dirhams at all....we were out in 30 minutes. I would say 30 Dirhams is problem enough, and unless you understand every type of cactus, its worth just 4-5 pictures ...

Garden and the museum  are must see in Marrakech, its well maintained and looks gorgeous its just not as big as described or expected. Museum is tiny but cute, however with combi ticket with YSL museum I am not really sure if you get the best  value out of it
Beautiful gardens. Arrive early to avoid long lines. Cafe is nice and has Wi-Fi. Be mindful of operating hours in observance of Ramadan.

The actual plants here are almost secondary to the vibrant colors and the crush of tourists. This is an extremely popular site. I recommend you get there early and buy a combo ticket so you won’t have to go through the line twice.
Must get there early to avoid queues and crowds. However the visit is 100% worth it. Tranquil, heavenly and cool, the garden is a must. There is a delight around every corner.
The garden has some beautiful plants and trees. As with most popular places, it's generally a little crowded though.

It is soemthing different in Marrakech and if you have time you have to go, but mainly cos the city itself doesnt have much to offer. The gardens cost 70 dhs and if you want to visit the bebere museum ( the only good thing inside and kind of interesting) is another 30dhs. Was good  but not amazing as some people says in these comments. If you are a big traveller this is not in your top 50 at all.
I haven’t visited a garden more idyllic more colorful and of such amazing architecture. Certainly a must in Marrakesh. Not to miss. Try to go early in the morning.
I'd been before, but this time there seemed to be more to discover...it's an incredible place and worth going and spending a whole day appreciating the beauty that they created.  A dream of a garden.
Great visit and had a great day visiting the Jardin Majorelle. I would recommend this trip to anyone wanting a relaxing walk around the impressive gardens.
Amazing what you can do with cacti and imagination. Be prepared for a long queue at busy times. We were not disappointed by our visit and would highly recommend
It was okay. nice plants, nice cafe. not very big. located in a nice area. quite touristy place. worth a visit of 1 hour or so.
Visited this one morning and delighted I did so. Beautiful gardens, immaculate maintained. YSL would be so happy his legacy is so well maintained.
Definitely a must see when visiting Marrakech. Beautiful gardens so peaceful to spend time in. However be aware that it can get very crowded there especially in the "photo" spots.

The gardens are beautiful.  This is a wonderful oasis in the city - away from everything - the chaos and the constant selling and trying to pry you away from your money that happens elsewhere in the city.  This is truly a lovely place and is worthy of being the #1 spot on TA for Marrakech
There isn’t that much to see or visit in Marrakech so lots of people go to this site. It’s pleasant enough but I suspect ardent gardeners/ horticulturists would get more from it
The gardens were absolutely stunning and beautiful and would recommend everyone that visits Marrakech to visit.
Majorelle Grden is one of the most beautiful places in marrakech to visit . really we love it than the rest of the medina of marrakash
review_title: Best Place to Visit In Marrakech

review_text: The garden was just fantastic. Very carefull and clean place. Inside is a small cafeteria for a coffee. You have to wait half an hour at least to take a ticket. Is better to buy from internet, in order not to wait in the line.
The garden its self is rather small but the Berber Museum on the grounds really helped us to understand many things we later saw in rural Morocco.

This lovely xeriscape garden was utterly spoilt by the selfie takers swarming all over it while wearing their garden inappropriate designer gear, no doubt preparatory to visiting the Yves Saint Laurent Collection just down the street. Luckily the day I visited was a cool day in Marrakech because I probably queued for nearly an hour to get in. The plantings are interesting and beautifully grown. It isn't a big garden but there is a small café restaurant on site. I didn't visit it so can't comment except as to it's existence. The gift shop has marvellous textiles and interesting stock of all kinds but it is quite pricey. AL least at a place like this you know that you are getting what you think you are getting, unlike the souks.
review_title: Hard to see because of the fashion crowd

review_text: We really enjoyed wandering round the garden, had to queue to get in. Well established planting... very photogenic - maybe a few too many instagramers!

We took a little trip to Marrakesh while my son is on his gap year from uni. We stayed in the Riad Kechmara (i’ve written a separate review if you want to know more about this superb little garden hotel) We decided to visit the Jardin Marjorelle and walked from the old town to Ru Yves Saint Laurent (the walk from the main Jamaa El’Fna ie the main souk square to the Jardin Marjorelle is pretty much a straight line apart from the left turn at the main traffic lights signposted for Casablanca and then after 50 metres you then make a right into Rue Yves Saint Laurent - will take you about 20-25 mins steady walk) The first thing you notice as you approach this high walled villa is the ever growing queue of folks wanting to get in to this ‘wonder’. The queue actually goes down quite quickly and you might well get approached by the local ‘geezer’ who can offer you direct and quick entry to beat the queues for a few dirhams extra - id say don’t waste your money since the queue moves quickly anyway. So, tickets purchased (a range of tickets available for this place, the berber museum and other locations as a combo offer - we just paid to visit the gardens works out about £6 each. As you go through the entrance way, your mind is literally blown off its hinges by the extraordinary beauty of the lushness and staggering array of stunning plants and trees - pure heavenly oasis. Plants have been brought from all over the world from the most far reaching corners eg Howard islands, mexico - the list is endless. The gardens are so well manicured and looked after, it is so pleasing to know that whilst they did fall into disrepute, that they were then restored to their former glory by Yves Saint Laurent and have been kept in fine form ever since. You will see plants there that defy belief and here they are all happily living next to each other. There is a superb cafe there albeit of course prices are higher than outside, but the service and food are excellent. There is a boutique shop with some stunning silks gowns and Ostrich skin shoes and bags/wallets etc - extremely high class and of course a price to be paid for such quality. i would say you are likely to spend about 1.5-2 hours in there simply wandering around, taking photos, staring at these marvels of nature before stepping out of the side entrance back into the real world.
A nice way to spend an afternoon.  Wander the beautiful gardens, have a relaxing refreshment in the cafe and be sure to stop in to see the collection at the Berber museum.
review_title: Lovely gardens and enjoyable Berber museum

review_text: Best place to visit if you ara a flora and fauna fan. The atmosphere and setup, the colors are amazing. Thank you, Yves St Lauren to save this garden for us!

The gardens were nice.  But would I go back? No.  Can I recommend?  No.  You have seen one nice garden, you’ve seen them all, this one included.  The shop is hideously expensive, the staff in the cafe are Uber rude (although food looked and smelled great).  It was nice but 3 hours of my life that I will never get back. Absolutely zero wow factor. Even if you adore YSL..... he never went there.  It simply has his name above the door.  Let’s be sensible please.....?
review_title: Beautiful garden that resembled - any other nice garden..!

review_text: A beautiful place, but honestly there are so many more amazing places in Marrakech.  This place although beautiful we felt was just okay. Its on every travel list to visit in Marrakech and this is why we went, but its pretty impossible to even get a nice photo because its swarming with Instagram people trying to get their shots

Most of the time when you hear an attraction has been ‘ruined by instagram’ it is just exaggerated complaining, but this is the first place I have been to that definitely fits that description. The garden is very nice, but not really uniquely so. It is also not very large, and many sections have been roped off to visitors. So since it is now swamped with people pushing and shoving around to get their perfect photos and videos, it loses all the appeal of beauty and peacefulness that must have made it famous. I would recommend instead one of the other just as nice gardens in Marrakech, especially the botanical gardens to the south. If you must go I would recommend to be there at opening time the morning on a weekday.

I was in Marrakech during Ramadan so way less visitors and I did not experience the long lines others have complained about. The gardens are lovely but they are small, we were fine in 10-15 minutes. For $7 its over priced for what you get.
A beautiful garden is met after a very long wait outside. On a hot day you are sprayed with fine mist to keep you cool.
I visited the gardens with friends and it really was beautiful. You do not feel being in a big city!

Definitely worth the crowds! Our family visited in the afternoon, after several hours of wandering the Medina it was a welcome break from the heat and chaos of the city. They even have a special line for families, so that you don't have to queue with children, which is a nice bonus!
Long lines to get in - the gardens were OK - Yves Saint Laurent Museum down the block from the gardens was good. If you have time to kill go - I liked it ok.
one of the best garden in marrakech We had a wonderful  Would recommend it! just for advice try to do the visit in the morning is not very busy

We came around 10am and it was already huge line for tickets. When we entered there were many people inside, you haf to walk in line in most places and watch out for people while walking. Also for all the "popular" places for photos there was a line. So you have to wait for people to move so you can take photos one by one. It is overall nice to see but nothing too special. Not sure if it is worth 70 dirham.

Such and amazing place. We arrived during rush hour, but the queue was handled very quickly. The garden really handles a lot of people with easy, so even though it was packed, it didn't feel cramped. We loved it, one of the best experiences in Marrakech.

The garden is very crowded and it is hard to have a good time there. Sure there are many nice spots but you have to pay 40 dirham for it. Warning: if the staff helps you to shorten the line, you have to pay the full combi ticket for 100 dirham. As I said that I just wanted to buy the garden ticket, the called the guards and I was forced to pay or go back to the end of the line. Go for the cyber park or others, they are free and beautiful too

Perhaps if you were in Marrakech for a week, and you went during a non busy time, this might be an interesting place to visit. It is a beautiful garden. On a tight schedule, during a busy time, not a chance. As part of a tour group we got straight in, and the tour guide suggested an hour—we were ready to leave in 10 minutes! The narrow paths were crowded and frequently blocked by people posing for pictures or taking pictures of the plants. I couldn’t wait to get out and could only marvel at the people lined up waiting to get in. Save your time and mo eye and skip this one.
One of the most beautiful gardens I have visited. Vibrant and colourful an oasis in the energetic buzz of Marrakech. A visual paradise.
You have to see this garden paradise to believe it. Take your time, wander, enjoy the sights and the smells and the ponds. Watch going mid-morning when most of the tour groups show up.

Even if it is overpaid ,You can’t avoid going through the visit..but get ready queuing an hour (more than time spent in there ) to get your ticket or buy it in advance . Once in their you will enjoy incredible garden and colors .

Spent a couple hours walking through here with my family.  Our toddler loved all the frogs and fish in the water <3  And the small cafe has wonderful ice cream to help beat the heat! Beautiful gardens for fantastic photo opportunities
Pretty garden with shade.  Go early the lines can get long.  There is a cafe inside to get lunch and tea.

If you like to be surrounded by crowds taking picture of every tree leaf, then maybe it's good for you. Being there I had the sensation of being teleported in one of these parks I visited back in China. Save your 7€ and go have a drink at La Mammounia, better gardens and nobody. I guess all people gather here because YSL name on it. Marketing magic
We didnt bother going-in as it was more expensive if you were a tourist....  very busy from the outside and we felt it was not worth going the 2nd time

The gardens are beautiful and perfectly kept with many different sections. There is forest a bamboo, a section with many different cacti and one with squares planted with citrus trees. There are lovely water features as well; however it is everything but peaceful it is full of people even now at the end of the season. The musée berbère is very interesting with many object artwork and item of clothing showing the berbère culture.

Came here using the green line of the hop on hop off bus, which stops round the corner from the gardens. Entry was 70 dirhams (7 euros or just under £6) without entry to the Berber museum, but it was worth every penny. The gardens are seriously impressive, with a wide variety of plants from various countries, lots of water features and some creatures within them (koi and turtles.) lots of shaded areas to sit in, especially in the heat of 2pm, a cafe and the museum of Berber life in an Art Deco pavilion if you are willing to pay the extra 30 dirham, but seeing the artefacts out of context rather than in a living village (which I did on my later Atlas Mountains excursion) did not appeal. The gardens are a must see if you are visiting Marrakesh, the perfect relief from the bustle of the medina, so set aside half a day to visit them. Even if you are not a fan of gardens, it is well worth the trek.

Made our own way using a taxi from the hotel . Went early to avoid large queues and hotter sun. The gardens are relatively easy to find and worth a visit. From gardens visit the souks before taxiing back to hotel

We visited the Gardens, the Berber Museum, the YSL Museum and the gardens of the Villa Oasis (the last only open Friday to Monday) on a combi ticket. Both gardens lived up to their expectation, a bursts of colour from flowers and water reflections from painted vases and verandahs  in an already green city. Thoughtful restoration of the gardens and great planting. An "architectural gem of a garden".

If you have a few minutes to spare you might as well pop into this garden for a look around. I found it a relaxing place to sit and wander around and to step away from the hustle and bustle. Pretty colours,  nice story behind why its there. There is a cafe inside but we didn't eat there as it was a bit pricey and full meal. However, a great ice-cream shop across the road and with a good coffee.
Cool oasis amid the metropolitan hustle and bustle. We suggest you go after noon to avoid the early morning rush.
A really enjoyable half day, combine this with the YSL museum. Get the full pack with Berber museum, really worth it. Also lovely, the cafe on the gardens.

Very very pleasant. There was a very long queue but perhaps because we looked old and knackered one of the stewards pulled us out and put us in the priority queue, generally for disabled persons and pregnant women !  You can explore the garden in an hour or so, so arriving at 4pm is not a disaster and it may get quieter by then. Like everywhere, the main disadvantage of crowds is that many visitors, especially groups, attach more importance to photos of themselves to send to friends than to the gardens and they can be a nuisance.
review_title: Pick your time of visit - very early or late

review_text: Came here with family last month. Stunning garden with so many beautiful picture opportunities. Best time would be to come when it first opens earlier as the queues can get quite long (we waited around 40/50 mins) however it is worth it. The museum is shut on Wednesday so plan accordingly.

A tranquil oasis of calm in a bustling city. During Ramadan the opening hours are shorter so we had to wait for it to open (opened at 9am not 8am) meaning a queue had already built up. If you’re a member of ICOM or ICOMOS entry is free and if you are pregnant/have small kids there is a different ticket kiosk to reduce the wait. The actual garden was stunning. The colours, the water, the plants, just heavenly. Recommended in Monty Don’s Paradise Gardens book/TV series. The small Berber museum onsite was also really worth a visit with English laminated guides in each of the rooms.
review_title: A tranquil oasis of calm in a bustling city.

review_text: It is essential to get to the Jardin Majorelle very early to have any chance of avoiding the crowds.  Despite that, the tourists and groups flood the place.  Nevertheless it is worth the effort.  The garden is beautifully maintained and offers a wide variety of trees, shrubs and plants.  There are lots of good photo opportunities.  Very colourful throughout.  There is a welcome courtyard restaurant for a much needed coffee or drink at the end of your visit.

The gardens and associated museums are very beautiful, although a little expensive for what it is. Try to go later in the day and not on the weekend to avoid the big crowds. There are always lots of taxis available along the street. There are also a number of higher-end cafes nearby catering to tourists.

This review is for the garden only. And the reason is due to the fact that we were in line sooo long in blistering heat that I had no desire to do anything but get into a pool as soon as possible! TIPS!!!! Now these are things I wish I knew before we went! 1. Try to buy or reserve tickets ahead of time. They actually have a will call window and that line was considerably shorter! 2. Even if you weren’t that interested in the museum, that line was considerably shorter and you can buy tickets for the whole visit there! You can’t go directly into the garden from there but your ticket will help you bypass the long line at the garden. 3. We showed up at the opening time hoping to avoid the worst lines and hopefully the worst heat! So did EVERYONE else!!! We waited for almost an hour.  When we left around noon there was nooooo line! I would rather of been there at noon! Especially to avoid the crowds of instagramers that monopolized every nook and cranny! I love taking and posting pics like everyone, but be considerate of others trying to enjoy the day! If your photographer didn’t get the pic of you twirling in your dress the first ten times...move it along!!!

Must come early to avoid the very long queue. Best to make reservation. Take the time to read about it beforehand and you'll appreciate it a LOT more. Lovely story of how YSL gave back to society from his celebrity influence.
A great tour of garden. Beautiful layout. Garden is huge. Different types of cactus, flowers, plants. There's also museum but in french.
Absolutely stunning and worth a visit. It was clean and tidy and very picturesque. Great place for photos and the coffee was also good too. The staff there are very friendly.

Bit of a wait to get in but your sprayed with cooling spray. Once inside lots of amazing plants and i really enjoyed the tour of the gardens lots of cactus plants all shapes and sizes which I love. A nice little tour.
Long lines to get in but it’s not something u will see anywhere else. The landscaped gardens are pretty with the Majorelle blue color! If pressed for time, skip.
Beautiful gardens; well worth a visit.  Museum is also very interesting.  Buy tickets for both and save time since the lines can be long.
Brilliant loved it. Go early to beat the crowds and queues. Wednesdays the Yves St Laurent doesn't open !
review_title: Beautiful colourful gardens worth a visit

review_text: A beautiful tranquil garden within the chaos of the city. Tropical and lush plants with the back drop the iconic blue YSL house. Well worth a visit. I could spend hours here.
A “must do” when visiting marrakech. Lovely to stroll around and enjoy the gardens. Interesting history and lots of great photo opportunities.
I love this place also with the blue and yellow it was magical there i like it if i had the chance i will visit it another time

Beautiful exotic plants and oasis of calm, definitely worth a visit but go early when they open about 8-9am, otherwise the queues are awful to get in and when trying to take photos around the gardens.  Museum worth a look also.
Fantastic gardens,a lot of beautiful spots for your photos on instagram, and try to speak with the security,cause for 100 dirham,they let you jump the queues

The gardens are beautiful but the crowds are so thick you cannot enjoy. They should consider limiting the size of visitor groups and schedule visit times each hour. I would not recommend for this reason.

We took a trip out to these gardens after doing a morning quad bike tour!  You need around 45 mins to look around the gardens.  They are very beautiful, but much smaller than I expected.  However, there are a few lovely shops and a couple of very nice cafes opposite for when you come out of the gardens.  Worth a visit but do not expect a vast garden to spend hours in.
Nice garden to casually stroll around. Then I went to the YSL what was great too. I recommend getting 3-1 tickets

Don’t miss this garden. It is cool on the hottest day and beautiful garden of mainly cacti. It is the last home of Yale’s and his partner. And the story goes that he saved it from going to ruin. Entry is not expensive and there is a good cafe in the grounds
A magical place to visit is bustling Marrakech.  Cool, quiet, dazzling colours, beautiful plantings.  I have visited this amazing garden twice and would do so again if in Marrakech

Garden as many in the world. It was nothing special for us. You need to queue for a very long time without any shade. They have just two ticket offices open for hundreds of people waiting. Ticket is 70 MAD per person.

Get there early unless you are prepared to queue an hour or two. It may be possible to buy tickets in advance. Check with your hotel. Beautiful gardens. Masses of different shapes and colours. Very relaxing and plenty of shade.Right next door is the Yves St. Laurent museum and also the Berber museum.

One of the relatively brief stops we made in Marakech while on our Gate 1 Morocco Allure tour of Morocco was the Jardin Majorelle which is also known as the Yves Saint Laurent garden. This was one of his pet projects and is where he and his life partner, Pierre Berge are interred. It is a beautiful garden filled with exotic plants, especially but not exclusively cacti. It also contains some nice water features, a covered Koi pool and many beautiful flowering plants and trees. Additionally, there also is a small gallery of his love posters which he sent out as Christmas greetings and also a boutique for YSL haute couture and accessories. This is a very quiet and tranquil place in the midst of the bustling city of Marakech. Everyone in our group really enjoyed our visit and it is certainly not a place we would have discovered on our own. If you desire a touch of green and peaceful beauty on your visit to arid Morocco, I highly recommend a visit to the Jardin Majorelle.
review_title: A real oasis of tranquility and beauty in the heart of the city

review_text: A feast for the eyes and soul. Various types of plants and flowers of varied regions being successfully grown and showcased.
review_title: Varied flora and fauna in one area.

review_text: I would highly recommend going to see this place. Just a 10-15 min walk from New Town. Queue very long at 10.30am but moved quick and we got our tickets within 30 minutes. The gardens are gorgeous I am so glad we visited this place 😊
The gardens are lovely and the Berber museum and collection of art is a terrific addition to the overall experience
A nice day out while visiting Marrakech. Gardens with flowers and palm trees and a little cafe. The service in the cafe was not great, we sat for 15 mins without being acknowledged and then left.
I don't think this place is worth what they charge.  Be there at 8 am to avoid the crowds. Berber museum onsight is excellent. Friends thought the cafe had lack luster food.

Gorgeously designed gardens away from the chaos of the Marrakech Medina. The gardens were created by French Orientalist artist, Jacques Majorelle over nearly 40 years (starting in 1923). In the 1980s the property was bought by fashion desingers Yve Saint-Laurent and Pierre Berge who restored them. I have read that during busier times of the year it might be wise to book tickets in advance as there can be long queues. We went in February which I believe is just before peak season starts and didn’t spend anytime waiting in line for any of the attractions. Tickets are 70 Dirhams (£5.50) per person so not too expensive. You can buy a combined ticket combined with the Yves Saint Laurent museum if you’re doing both (they’re right next to each other). Visiting the gardens might not be an ideal rainy day activity as I think the sun needs to be out for you to appreciate the colours. Lots of Instagrammable opportunities!
Great cacti display, different flowers and trees. This botanical garden is a great escape from the Marrakech's scorching sun.
review_title: Beautiful garden, great place to hide from the sun

review_text: Cute but a bit pricey...  If you plan to go make sure to pay the xtra 70drh and get to the YSL museum also. buying the ticket trough the museum cashier saves you from a long queue.
A must see part of any trip to Marrakesh! Beautiful gardens with wonderful water features. Just a few yards away from the YSL museum.

This is a great way to spend a few hours in Marrakech. As well as being a gorgeous garden, it has a small but very informative museum to the Berbers. There’s also an Yves st Laurent museum if that’s your thing.
review_title: Couple of hours to spend in Marrakech?

review_text: Originally created by the Majorelle family, the garden was created in the early 20th century.  After the death of the founder it went into disrepair.  That is when Yves St. Laurent purchased it to save it from real estate developers.  He expanded the gardens and made Majorelle's art studio a Berber Museum.  There is a foundation to support it and is is self sufficient with the entry fee.  A very refreshing part of Marrakech.
Much smaller than expected. Nice to see and not so much a “must visit”. Try Bahia palace instead. Expensive ticket for some square meters

A long queue awaited us when we arrived by foot but luckily it was fast moving and we soon entered into the gardens. First impressions were how lovely and shaded it was after walking there in the heat. 2nd impressions were how busy the gardens were and final impressions were how small they actually were. Worth a visit though and the admission charge was very reasonable.
review_title: A shady oasis in the middle of the city

review_text: This place is very charming and calm. Or could be if there were not all those people..but yes you can still enjoy walking the perfectly maintained garden space with cactuses of the craziest measures. The berber museum is definitely worth seeing - the room with the star skies was something really nice and our kid enjoyed. Two tips! If you have kids take them with you - they can be your priority pass - we skipped maybe 2 hours long line thank to our 9 yo and we came in the morning! the line was crazy! Tip number two - buy both here the garden and also YSL tickets - you will skip another line in front of the YSL as you already have your ticket.
It's a beautiful place to visit but you definitely want to go early as it gets very crowded later in the day. I would recommend going right when it opens.
Great place, clean, well cared for, great and helpful staff and fantastic for wheelchairs. The Berber museum is a must visit as well

The gardens are dense and compact. There are many sections including a memorial to YSL. The Villa in its deep cobalt blues houses a museum of Berber artifacts and serves as the perfect backdrop to the gardens. There is also a nice cafe on the premises. Two quick tips - go shortly after they open in the morning and buy your tickets up the street at the YSL Museum (same ticket options and no lines).

These gardens are uncomparable with any regular garden. The almost bonsai style picture perfect maintenance together with the kobalt blue buildings and fountains make this garden a feast for the eye. If you can afford it, go to the Yves Saint Laurent museum first. Only 100 steps further up the road. We had zero waiting time there. Full combiticket with gardens is 180 dirham and you can bypass the waiting line with a big smile. Museum is small but gives a nice understanding of the background of YSL’s top designs. Woth a visit
review_title: Avoid the 2 hour waiting line by going to the YSL museum first

review_text: We had to wait 45 minutes to buy tickets  to the Jardin Majorelle.  Once inside, it was so crowded that it was difficult to enjoy this quiet oasis.

Exquisite  Garden . Compact.   The  great surprise was the  Berber Museum.  likely the richest  collection  on the planet.   The Berber museum gives  great   insight in Marrakech and beyond.  Very Very crowded. hot.   if they only had private viewings and viewing at night when the sun wasn't so hot.
Absolutely stunning gardens and so moving would really recommend coming and experiencing such beautiful surroundings in the city

I visited Jardin Marjorelle on April 23, 2019 with my tour group and thoroughly enjoyed it.  It rained that day and to see the beautiful flowers and fauna made up for a dreary day.  I highly recommend visiting this site.  You will not be disappointed.

There was a massive queue, under the sun. The inside was quite nice, a generous variety of plants and threes. Majorelle, a botanical lover, brings back from his travels around the world: cactus, yuccas, water lilies, jasmines, bougainvillea, palm trees, coconut trees, banana trees, bamboo...

Defenetly recommended! Nice gardens with so many trees and cactus. Not too big. But great ! Have a coffee for rest, we wait about 10min. To get tickets and enter in. On Thursday working just Majorelle Garden . Ysl is closed.

Long queues but definitely worth the wait. One of the most beautiful botanical gardens I’ve ever seen. Once inside you forget about the hustle and bustle of the city life in Marrakech. Definitely a must see. We purchased combined tickets to see the YSL museum also.

The gardens must be the most interesting attractions of the bunch in Marrakesh. It is a nice stroll although you won't spend more than an hour there. It's not the kind of garden that you can sit into and relax or lunch. You just walk around the flora.

It's a beautiful garden, but be prepared for the long queue. We went around 11am and waited for over an hour to get in. It's not m managed very well and difficult to stand with kids so long in the sun. Once inside it's a beautiful garden...bit crowded but still a lovely walk. Felt peaceful and lots of shade.
bright ,colourfull in brief - the glamour of Morocco. has wonderfull grounds but lots lots of tourists.
Very popular garden so very busy and long queues unless you get there early. we liked the shaded Bamboo area and the turtle pond. Lovely courtyard cafe

The highlight of Marrakesh, queues for 30mins and purchased a combined ticket which included yves saint Laurent museum, you can Also reserve tickets online. The gardens are peaceful and colorful. Definitely go here If visiting Marrakesh

Beautiful but small. Full of instagrammers and selfie takers. Early morning visit advised to beat the crowds. Queues can get a bit long for tickets. Alternative ticket can also be bought in combination with tickets for the YSL museum (even smaller than the gardens), 5 minutes up the road, queues here were much shorter.

The gardens are cute but I don’t think it’s necessary to visit them. We did 1 hour of queue to entry Under the Sun. It’s quite small and it has only one small beautiful part where all the people takes photos(making line even to take photo). I think there are better ways to spending time in Marrakech. As students we paid 35 dh each, the adult normal price is 70dh ( without museum).. it isn’t worth
Loved Jardin Majorelle, we were on a tour and wished we could have lingered here for a while.  Enjoyed our stroll through this very exotic garden, would say this is a must visit in Marrakech.
It is a very beautiful garden but on the other hand it’s the most touristy place in Marrakech. So it is filled with way too many people to really enjoy the garden.

Just offside from the Medina this is a must go place when in Marrakech. Worth the money for sure! Top tip: go early when it opens if you want to capture some good spots without the crowds of tourists.
It is a testament to the generosity of people who want others to experience the beauty they have enjoyed. Thank you, Yves.
Definitely a culturally significant tourist attraction to visit, however there isn't really much to see for the price you pay.
review_title: Culturally significant but not much to see

review_text: Inside it can become quite congested, both in the garden and the museum. Still, it is a fascinating landscape to enjoy regardless.

It's a lovely garden with desert plants that not normally seen in botanical garden.  The Berber museum is nice curated.  The precious jewelry displays under a dark setting  with dotting small lights in the ceiling, just like the starry sky over the desert, pretty impressive.  Worth to pay MAD 30 to visit it.
review_title: Don't miss the Berber Museum inside

review_text: As I hinted to in my caption, this is not an ordinary garden. The Jardin Majorelle is nothing short of magnificent with all of the beautiful and vibrant colors throughout. I also enjoyed the history lessons on the Berber people that were offered here. I highly recommend taking in this beauty. It is certainly serene.
review_title: Beautiful, stunning and vibrant colors! Not your ordinary garden!

review_text: This botanical garden is quite small, crowded and not that impressive. We went in after a long wait in line (over one hour) and we were quite disappointed to find out that we could only access the gardens, as the Yves Saint Laurent museum is closed on Wednesdays. The kids found it quite boring, as there are nice free public parks in many cities we've visited. Please note that there is a special (shorter) line for families - the other queue was way more than an hour's wait!
review_title: Quite small - only worth it when combined with Yves Saint Laurent museum

review_text: An oasis within the city limits. Previously state owned, but now days operated by Yves Saint Laurent. His house was there too and his museum nearby, visited with the same ticket. Certainly worth a visit there

The most important bit of info I can give you about visiting this amazing location if you are going to do all 3 parts are going to but a combined ticket is to get it from the Musee because there will be no queue and come back to the garden after. I loved this location, it is amazing, the gardens are beautiful and so tranquil this was one of my most favorite location in Marrakesh. The garden is just so lovely and you definitely have to visit. I would highly recommend this for a morning visit. Then walk up the road 100m and go to the Yves Saint Laurent Musee.
Worth a visit. Unfortunately my tour didn’t allow time to visit their museum which only opens from 10am. Some say it closes every Wednesday
A bit far from everything. If you have other plans near there it may be a nice visit but does not worth a trip there.

Certainly the most beautiful gardens I have ever visited! The colours are truly amazing. If for nothing else, Pierre Bergé and Ives Saint Laurent deserve to be remembered for preserving this magic place!

Go and take some amazing colourful pictures! There’s some history as well and the trip is best completed with a trip to the YSL museum to follow. If you do go then make sure you get your tickets at the YSL museum first for both attractions so you can Q jump!
After standing in line 1 1/2 hours to buy tickets, we welcomed the coolness and beauty of the jardin.  It took us about 2 hours to stroll though the garden admiring the foliage colors of the flowers.

The tranquility is rather spoiled by the many tourists!  We didn’t visit the museums.  La Mamounia’s gardens were rather more impressive, closer to our hotel and of course offer the possibility of having a drink or meal on site... probably a must for YSL fans but maybe not worth going too far out of your way for otherwise.

A must for any trip to Marrakech. The gardens are brilliant - designed by the artist Majorelle. Buy tickets for the garden and YSL museum just down the road at the same time. Probably best to visit YSL first as early morning line ups. The cafe at YSKL is exceptional - an early lunch with salad and ice cream the business!!
review_title: Magical Garden and YSL next door

review_text: A great trip out of the Medina to this paradise in the city. A great look at some beautiful native and non native plants. A well landscaped garden with many places to sit in the shade. Worth the visit. You won’t spend a long time here but you will enjoy getting out of the Medina for it.
review_title: Worth the visit to beat the heat.

review_text: A short walk around Jardin Majorelle is all it takes, very pretty and worth a look while in Marrakech
review_title: A short walk around Jardin Majorelle is all it takes, very pretty and worth a look while in Marrakech

review_text: What a wonderful garden with an amazing cobalt blue (now & forever known as Marjorelle blue) house. The only disappointment was that it was a little too popular, with the 'selfie brigade' clogging up some of the more special views. To avoid some of the crowd go early just as it opens & if you want a much shorter wait in line join the line for the YSL museum next door that gives you access to the gardens afterwards.
review_title: Wonderfully coloured house in lush gardens!

review_text: Truly a lovely environment to experience and walk through. Is quite a walk to get to so a taxi ride is suggested.
writer_informations: Cape Town Central, South Africa,116 contributions

review_text: The gardens were so beautiful, but it was so busy we had to queue over an hour so go later in the afternoon or super early. we got there at half 10 and it was so busy. We got student discount half price so defo ask about student and get the combined ticket including YSL gardens.
Just a quick tip - despite many cautions of arriving early during the month of Ramadan opening hours are 9h instead of 8h - don’t make the same mistake we did and have to wait 1 hour instead

The garden is nice, but it was very crowded. We thought it was a bit strange, and didn't feel very authentic either. There are so many people getting "instagram photos" in heels and dressed up to the nines, and they're only there to grab some shots in front of a brightly coloured wall. It's a bit off-putting if you're going to actually enjoy the space and walk around it. The queue was also very long, and the ticket price felt a bit steep considering it was only a garden. I would recommend Bahia Palace and Le Jardin Secret over this garden, they were far less crowded, much more authentic and more beautiful too.

i have never seen so many different kinds of cactus in my life! from the look of the que outside and the temperature exceeding 35 degrees i suggest you come as early as possible. but its beautiful on the inside. never knew Yves saint laurent was buried there too.

I thoroughly enjoyed Jardin Majorelle, the plants are amazing.  I stayed about an hour and then also took in the Berber Museum on the same site - excellent Museum and another hour. Line up for tickets was quite long - would suggest arriving earlier in the day.

Such a beautiful garden and with a decent price of ticket. Very helpful stuff and very polite. Garden is very clean and everything inside looks magnificent. The only downside is the huge line for purchasing the tickets. It could be easily solved with an online booking system.
only 30 minutes walking from jamaa el fna you can get to majorel garden ,nice saint laurent museum close .
It is an amazing garden full of colors and beautiful cactus. Highly recommend! Usually there are some big lines to get tickets.

This is a beautiful garden and an absolute must visit. Be prepared to queue for a lengthy time, although it is not quite as long as suggested by the men who are trying to take a bribe to allow you to go to the pre-booked queue, which is quite busy too, and does not get you in much faster. Either go first thing, or perhaps later in the day, after lunchtime, although it might be hotter. We queued around 11.30am for an hour, and the queue was much shorter when we left the area around 2.30. It is a real haven of tranquility inside, despite the number of tourists, with plenty of photo opportunities.
This attraction is very popular and its is very crowded. If you go with a tour, you can go to the front of the line. The garden is like a maze and there are many different plant species.

We spent a lovely afternoon here enjoying the plants, the trees and the water. The gardens were quite busy with other people but this didn’t detract from the drama and exoticism of the garden. We loved the architectural plants and the relaxed formality of the design all set against the blue of the house and the blue of the sky. It is probably best to go very early before the crowds get there and remember to haggle if you take a caleche back to your hotel!i
The gardens are beautiful and the photos speak for themselves. Plus, I highly recommend to visit the Berber Museum inside. Very interesting!

The gardens themselves are beautiful. Serene place to walk around and contemplate. Unfortunately we waited an hour in the sun simply to buy tickets to enter. I would not recommend visiting at 11am as a result. Make sure you buy the combination ticket to see the YSL museum also.

Everywhere on this museum and garden of Yves St Laurent you will find the very best. Beautiful colors , gorgeous gardens, and some interesting history. Also some information about Berbers is very interesting .

Nice garden with different species of trees and flowers. A great place where you can just grab your camera and shoot every corner. The photos will always look great i assure you. Also the berber musem inside it is great, tells a lot about the history of bebers, so interesting!

Walking into the Majorelle Garden was like walking into a dream (though the number of tourists brings you back to reality :). The richness and variety of the plants, cacti and bamboo is overwhelming. I especially enjoyed walking around the garden in the shade of the giant bamboos.
These gardens are beautiful.  They were crowded when we went in the afternoon so I would suggest going early in the morning.
review_title: Fun to see but go early to get tickets

review_text: This is an Oasis! Go, see it... you will only regret not seeing it. The colours and the design make you feel as if you are surrounded by luxury and calm.

This is a most beautiful place to visit. Gardens are superb and shady! We had a lovely lunch in the courtyard restaurant, there was such a lovely atmosphere here, cool and calm. The Berber exhibition is  informative and really stunning in it's presentation. A lovely way to spend a few hours.
This is unique exceptional garden  with bamboo and cactus. There is lot of queue and it is really worth visiting.
Beautiful garden! Also enjoyed breakfast at Cafe Majorelle - had the typical Morrocan breakfast with the mint tea!
The gardens are beautiful, but it took longer to queue in 30 degree heat than to get around, even showing up fairly early. Not convinced it's worth it.

Found this garden utterly fascinating and so charming it was hard to leave - felt serene and peaceful tho there were many other visitors. The vistas were gorgeous and i fell in love with the variety of cacti some so huge and blossoming.  I sat for over an hour watching people from all over the world having their photos taken framed by the vivid purple Bougianvillea.
review_title: Glorious garden not to be missed!

review_text: Beautiful gardens full of colour, very cool and calm. Great cafe and shop as well I also read he letters to Yves by his partner Pierre which made them all the more special
Good excuse to visit the new town. The gardens are designed by Yves st Laurent. Exceptional plants especially the cacti interspersed with ponds.this would be a restful place if it wasn't so popular.

Spotlessly maintained, wonderful park with YSL's beautuful house. Queue might be long, in this case try the YSL museum 200 meters further the same street, where combined tickets are available. Anyway, worth the waiting time, this is a must see in Marrakech.
An incredible array of plants and cacti in a beautiful setting. Super well maintained. We loved walking around and seeing all the varieties and species of plants.
review_title: Incredible greens combined with Moroccan tile and landscape

review_text: Nice gardens hidden away from the madness of the city. Plan to visit around 9am when it's cool and no queue's to get in. Be prepared for certain tourists staging hundreds of posed photos around every corner.
review_title: Busy even early in the morning.

review_text: There are steps, benches and arches etc where nice photos can be taken for those who like this kind of thing. But during busy hours you may have to queue to get a snap. To avoid queuing to get in, I would suggest going closer to closing time. The YSL shop and love gallery is also worth having a quick look at.
A visit to this place is very interesting. Very charming! Amazing garden. Would recommend to friends.

Although obviously beautiful this was way too much for the experience.  A fascinating museum but translation into other languages would be useful. It is shame that this was an additional cost on top of an already overpriced garden viewing.

The gardens were beautiful but not worth the hassle involved. It would take several paragraphs to explain how awful it was to get in (took two tries, two days, and we never did get in the Berber Museum). On our 2nd trip, we got there before 8am and were able to see most of the garden without horrible crowds. But by 9 am, it was overrun with people including crowds of young women who were more interested in the perfect Instagram photo than gardens. They actually brought changes of shoes, accessories, etc. to stage their shots! I cannot imagine how crowded it must have been by noon. Not the garden experience I was hoping for.
review_title: Wish we'd gone to ANIMA instead

review_text: Its very beautiful with a lot of kind of plants from all around the world,very colorful building, a lot of Instagram spots. It's better to go early morning to avoid the crowd because the garden  is not so big. You can skip the garden line by buying your tickets from the museum ticket place just few meters further
review_title: Very beautiful but not that big

review_text: to avoid the crowds and enjoy the garden and the Berber Museum. The Museum shop has few nice items. unfortunately the number of visitors really takes away from the experience. Tickets are also expensive.

Just incredible - magic! Get the tickets trough the hotel in advance (a taxi will pick it up for 100 MAD 100)! Otherwise you stay in line for 2 hours... best time to go is before 10:00 a.m. Later on it‘s too croudy!
Beautiful gardens. We had a private guided tour. So wonderful. Such unusual varieties of cacti on display. History is interesting. Recommend.

A peaceful retreat in a busy city. The gardens were beautiful and well laid out. It can be busy and lines are long. If you go to the Yves Saint Laurent Museum further down the street you find a much shorter line and you can buy a combination ticket for both.
Me and my wife had been to several gardens in Morocco. All with there own flair. The Jardin garden was very nice, busy and not a chill spot. With some patience and luck we got some great Pics.

Really beautiful garden! It is worth a visit but the entrance fee is kind of expensive. As I am a student I got a discount of 80 Dh (8 Euros) by showing my student card it was only 100 Dh including both, the visit of the museum and the garden. For non students it was 180 Dirham. It was nice to walk around, but there where no possibilities to sit down and relax because most of the benches were used to take pictures. You are not free to move inside the garden; there was a lot of staff showing you the direction you are allowed to go. I was sitting on a bench with my friend until a tour guide came and said that we are not allowed to sit there because this bench "is a really famous photo place"....
Stunningly beautiful gardens, had the queues moved faster (took 40 mins to get in) it would have a five star rating

We visited on a 95 degree day, and the garden provided a respite from the heat, with its green canopy.  Absolutely beautiful with so many assorted plants, especially the cacti, and the little museum is lovely also.  We spent about an hour and a half.  Best advice -- get there when it opens, as the line to get in just gets longer as the day goes on.
It was way too crowded but the gardens are amazingly beautiful. The only part of the Berber museum I found interesting was the clothing. The gift shop is amazing!!!!!
The gardens were absolutely spectacular.  Go early in the morning to avoid the crowds so you can take in all there is to see.

Stunning gardens. Peaceful, cool, exquisitely laid out and tended. Arrived at 9am, got in for 9:40. The queues when we left after 90 minutes were horrendous. £8 to get in for gardens and Berber museum - which had a fantastic 'jewelry' display. Highlight of the holiday.
It's a nice garden with tons of different plants, but kind of simple, not worth waiting 2 or more hours to enter

Only on the second try we made it into the garden. The first day we had to queue up for 30 minutes, only after this time a staff member appeared and told us we had to leave this line as it was the family line. After 30 minutes?!? Behind us already 100 more people had queued up (no families with kids either). As we would have had to queue up again for definitely more than 1 hours we decided to leave. The next day we came earlier (at around 8a.m. when the garden opened) - there was no queue at that time. The garden itself is nice - not a must see, and if I imagine it full of tourists, well.. than I would say its ok to miss it.
review_title: Catastophic organization, garden itself is a nice place but not a must see

review_text: Absolutely gorgeous gardens. Must go. We hadn’t heard of it much before we went but it is truly a lovely place. Even kids will enjoy it.
Beautiful gardens with lots of variety of plants, trees, flowers anmd fish in ponds. Very well kept and maintained. very well explanations on displays.

A must in Marrakech; one of the most interesting and beautiful places in town. we didn't see the YSL house but the Museum and the Gardens are absolutely gorgeous. With the sun all colours are intense and every tree, corner, detail deserves a picture.

What a beautiful place! Peaceful gardens ( if you get there early), really well-presented grounds and beautiful studio. The Berber museum in the studio/house had wonderful exhibits of photographs and artifices.

The garden itself is amazing! So many different types of cactuses, trees and flowers, all have been taken good care of, really interesting to visit.   The blue house is really beautiful too, which leads to my next point - a bit too many people queuing for photos.  When you look at a plant or the building or a window, or anything, someone will push you away because they want to take a picture, or say "excuse me", in the sense of "go away, I need this spot for photo"...   I arrived there before 9, when we came out, the queue outside was at least 150 m long.  Can't really imagine how crowded it would be.
review_title: Amazing plants and garden, bit too many people queuing for photos.

review_text: The Jardin Majorelle is simply stunning and quite huge. Words casn't properly describe its beauty - just go!

The garden is an oasis in middle of the city. The gardens are beautiful for taking photos but does get very over crowded. The que outside to get ticket was about 40 minutes. The taxi from madina to garden should cost you around 40-50 drm. Do not pay more than that. Best times are mornings. You need approximately 1-2 hours to see all.

We visited these gardens in April and arrived late morning and had a huge long wait in the queue. Therefore recommend pre-booking. I visited here in 80s and they are just as beautiful just more busy. Really peacefu and beautiful and different and for me the highlight and No 1 place to visit in Marrakesh.
My husband and I agave been there, we spent some days exploring the sites including the majorelle garden in Marrakech. We highly recommend it to everyone

Found it very interesting to wander around this garden; it is filled with lots of drought tolerant plants which I found inspiring, together with exctreely advanced species of cacti.  Overall a lovely few hours, despite the crowds.

Part of me wasn't sure whether to make the trip to the gardens on our last day in Marrakech- to be honest now having gone I don't think the photos really do it justice. Itdefinitely was worth any effort, it was very interesting and tranquil. Highly recommended and near the medina. I took the advice of others and got there fairly early. That's the only way to go. We arrived at about 9.15 am and there was barely a queue. We paid by credit card. We booked for the joint ticket with the Yves St Lauren museum. The numbers in the gardens weren't too bad at that time. By the time we left just over an hour later the crowds in the gardens and in the queue outside were so big. And the queue was standing in the sun. The Berber museum (inside the gardens) was very good. I agree with comments from others - explanations in English too would be appreciated. We then went to the Yves St Lauren museum (you exit the gardens and turn left) which was very worthwhile. We didn't expect to appreciate it as much as we did, the building is great as are the exhibits. By the way, the shops in the same street as the gardens (across the road) are very good - there are some great design type stores with set prices.
Yves St Laurent created this garden in the midst of an overcrowded city.  It is worth visiting and had a great little cafe. Thanks to the staff for lending their phone when ours was not working
review_title: Adjacent to the YSL Museum - excellent

review_text: Beautiful garden! It a very nice and fresh place to visit in Marrakech. A big diversity of plants in a very well preserved space.
AMAZINGLY beautiful gardens. Definitely get there early to avoid the crazy lines. We really enjoyed walking around the gardens, as well as exploring the nearby shops afterward as well.

It was abit far from our hotel and we get ataxi for our hotel. It was very crowded and therefore really didn't give an opportunity to enjoy the place. Plus the vegetation was limited to cacti and a few tropical plants.

It was a nice place but a bit underwhelming, book an early morning tour if you want to visit, to get in quickly. Do not queue for hours in the sun as you might be disappointed. The tea in the cafe was lovely though.
Very nice and quiet place. There are many types of flowers, cactus etc. You can take really Beautiful pictures there. There is also Bistro and toilets.
Such a beautiful oasis of calm! The colours here were excellent. Expect to queue and be aware it is busy in the gardens.
Be sourrended by blu and breath a simple and joyfull moment in Marrakech and don t miss to taste Le Pain Perdu with orange butter and cinnamon at the bar inside Le Jardin. Love this place
review_title: The most peaceful place in Marrakech

review_text: The Majorelle Gardens are a must for anyone visiting the wonderful city of Marrakech. It can get a little crowded so I would recommend getting there early but if you do go when the sun is high the gardens are cool and welcoming. The cafe is a wonderful extra and not too expensive.
Beautiful gardens but every plant and tree you'll see was imported fromn other countries - so that was a bit disappointing... Very packed, but you get nicer pictures and see wonderful nature!

This is a beautiful garden, and an enjoyable place to visit. However, it gets INCREDIBLY CROWDED and it is advisable to arrive very early in order to be one of the first people through the door. It fills up very fast, and once it is crowded it is almost impossible to take nice photos without crowds in the way. Once the crowds filled up, it was actually unpleasant. You have to pay extra for the Berber museum. This is interesting enough, but again very crowded. The bookshop at the end of the Berber museum has wonderful books on Morocco. The bookshop can be accessed without a ticket to the Berber museum itself, and is worth visiting.
review_title: Enjoyable and beautiful, but arrive early

review_text: We visited the gardens with our 12 year old son and weren’t disappointed. We got there early and queued for only 10 minutes as they opened up. The gardens are sympathetically laid out and are in keeping with a traditional Moroccan garden of clean lines, water and vivid colour with statuesque trees and cacti. We had a lovely coffee and pastry three quarters of the way round before completing our tour with a visit to their shop and the excellent Berber museum. We would very much recommend this but suggest you get there early to avoid the large crowds that form later in the day.
writer_informations: Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates,63 contributions

review_text: For its price, this place is a bit too iver rated. The better plants and settings can be found in other more affordable parts of the world such as in the south east asia. Nonetheless the museums were the better attractions compare to the over rated garden.
Absolute must see if you are in Marrakesh. Go early to avoid queues and also crowds. The cafe inside is lovely too!

After negotiating public transport to find this garden I was slightly disappointed by it. Maybe I had been spoilt by the wonderful 'Secret Garden' in the Old City. It was very crowded and therefore really didn't give an opportunity to enjoy the place. Plus the vegetation was limited to cacti and a few tropical plants.

I really do not understand the hype for this place . Really we were lucky that went there early and didn’t queue....1 h later there were tons of people basically to look at a large garden .... maybe I missed something....

A quiet, beautiful place ! Go there as early as possible to avoid the crowd and the queue! It feels really good to be away from the noise of Marrakech for a little while, the plants are really nice too .

The garden is a little out of the way from the medina, but is well worth a visit!  It can best be described as a peaceful sanctuary in a bustling city.  The little cafe, although overpriced, provides a nice resting spot while enjoying the atmosphere.

A definite must see if in Marrakech. We went about 10am only the queue was already long. Once inside it is crowded with tourists. But the garden is beautiful. We also saw the Berber Museum which was good but very crowded. Coffee in the cafe was good.
By 11 am, when we arrived, the queues were extremely long and once inside the gardens, it was difficult to take pictures without people in the background. Beautiful place though albeit overpriced.
review_title: Get there before 9 am to avoid long queues

review_text: The garden is lovely though much smaller than we thought. Easy to walk round. BUT by far the best part of being there was the wonderful Berber Museum and the nearby Yves Saint Laurent Museum (even for  fashion dunderhead the YSL Museum was fantastic and it has a great cafe). Try to get there as early, 8 or 8.30 a.m, as possible by 10.30 the queues are enormous and it would be impossible to move freely in the Jardin.
The place is nice with a pretty landscape, you dont realise that you are actually in the city because inside the jardin, you will feel like in jungle
Waited in line for an hour to pay 70 DH for what was 15 minutes walking around a garden. While it was beautiful, there are much better things to spend your time and money on.
Long line, many tourists and too little space. The Berber museum was a nice surprise. We recommend to come early.

Great garden to walk through and admire the many trees, plants, ponds and their beautiful arrangement . You can also get a good impression from how many countries tourists come to visite Marrakech. Get there before 9:30 otherwise you may have to wait for 45 minutes in the line to get the tickets. (After the end of the Easter holidays it may be easier to get in.) We were so occupied looking and taking pictures that we forgot about all the other people around us. You have to strictly stay on the path. The Berber museum we recommend as we were impressed about the beauty and sophistication of the cloth, jewelry and woodcarvings on display even though we had seen photos before. Go see the Yves Saint Laurent as well. My wife loved it and I found it interesting to recognize that YSL invented styles which are now part of the women’s way to dress which did not exist before.
review_title: Great Garden but do not expect to have it to yourself

review_text: This is a gorgeous spot but far too busy. We went early and did not queue for too long but could not move for instagramming fashionistas. The Berber museum is great and the best part of the visit. If you just want a garden, go to the Jardin Secret... it’s just as beautiful if not more so, tranquil and to me a must do.
review_title: Beautiful but far too many people

review_text: Take your time in the berber museum. It is beautiful. For the gardens... find a nice spot to sit and just take it in. Very peaceful.
It’s of an unexpected beauty, fantastic... Suggestion: buy your ticket in advance to avoid a possibly long queue, anyhow are worthy
Be prepared for huge queue or go there early. Nice tip, buy the combo ticket from YSL museum that has way smaller queue and you can skip the line.
review_title: Great place!! Definitely a must visit.

review_text: First off get there early......this garden crowds very quickly. Our guide got us there as the gates opened so as we looked around were were not over run by hundreds and hundreds of people (taking selfies) with in less than an hour. The gardens are outstanding and so beautifully maintained. The Berber museum is excellent but was difficult to spend quality time in due to the crush of visitors.

The Jardin Majorelle was one of the highlights of our trip to Marrakesh. Not only are the gardens beautiful, but the small Berber Museum was fascinating, and don't forget to check out the gallery of posters Yves Saint Laurent made every New Years for his friends and clients. Do try to get there  early (before 9 AM) because it is very popular and the lines outside become very long by 9:30 am.

Get there early as the queues for this attraction are long! Inside you'll see a well maintained garden with beautiful water features and fascinating cacti grown to humongous proportions.Lots of nice photo opportunities and very well wroth the money.
lovely excursion to the ysl gardens and secret garden .. worth a visit if you get the chance go early !
Jardine Majorelle is a welcome break from the hustle and bustle of the Medina. It has very pretty gardens - tall bamboo, amazing cactus and more. A very pleasant place to pass a couple of hours.

Stunning gardens, well worth a visit. It takes about an hour to get around, without counting the time to get in. Arrive as early as possible to avoid the queues, which can take up to an hour. Although the gardens are open, the museums associated to the gardens are closed on Wednesdays.
review_title: Beautiful gardens, worth a visit (but arrive early!)

review_text: We queued for over 30 minutes to get in and then once we did enter the place was packed. It was nice enough but quite small and expensive for what it is.
Brilliant beautiful Colourful gardens.. well maintained and landscaped. Recommend this as a must see along with YSL museum.
Beautiful and stunning! Nothing more to say, you have to see for yourself. It is not worth the 2 hour queue, as the garden is actually very small. Book in advance and go early.

Didn’t have long there but loved it.  A beautiful peaceful sanctuary. The plants & shrubs are exotic & well maintained. There are occasional sitting facilities. I believe there might be a restaurant but I’m not sure. The queues are long so advise booking.

Second time visiting these beautiful gardens and glad I did as saw more then the first time!! It can be very very busy which is a little frustrating being able to walk around peacefully and not battling others to see the nice things. The colours are beautiful and the tress so tall. The flowers are beautiful and pretty and lovely to see and orange trees smell amazing. If you get the opportunity to go it is deff worth it! Children under 12 are free and 70dhs for adult just for entry. It's a cool place as sheltered by the trees so it doesnt get too hot. There is a nice cafe right at the end of the road on a corner worth a little drink and the shops across the road have lovely little things to look in.
review_title: Such a must to visit here when in Morroco!!!

review_text: We went to Jadrin Marjorelle by taxi , wae paid 120dh which was good . The Jardin is beautifull , but we had to wait for long time to get in. Worth Visting. Paulina ROMA

The garden is definitely worth a visit. A very beautiful and serene place (but with a million tourists). Has a great variety of plants, bamboo, flowers, palms etc. All arranged around ponds. Awesome for kids and great pics. They have a really cute cafe inside. We did not eat there as it was really busy.
Beautiful, stunning gardens which have been very well kept and maintained. Recommended to go there early as the queues for garden entry can be quite long and the garden can get crowded at peak times!

The best place in Marrakech.Definetely worth a visit.You can lose yourself in this amazing and colourful spot.The Berber Museum and the Yves Saint Laurent museum worthy as well. The only negative note: it could get extremely busy in few minutes.Then you can forget the quiet...

One of the most beautiful places in Marrakech, Nice place for amazing pictures and spend a good afternoon.  The design, colours and plants are really well balanced. Also, never the less, the facilities for meals and toilets are good.

The gardens were lovely but the ticking is very confusing. We lined up near the museum, we only wanted tickets for the garden. After a long wait we arrived at the ticket booth and was informed that they would not sell us a ticket to the garden. We had to buy a combination ticket to both the museum and the garden. After such a long wait we capitulated and spent the extra money. The whole experience left me very annoyed.
Everyone must visit these gardens a must to do. Long queues but worth it. So much to see and gives you great ideas for your own garden
Pretty garden but really its just a homage to YSL. Pleasant place to walk bur huge queue and not sure it is worth the price.
It is a beautiful oasis. Not your ordinary botanical gardens, picture something created but a fashion designer.

Les Jardin Majorelle is a wonderful, tranquil, yet superbly joyous and creative escape from the hubbub of the noisy city and is still uniquely very reflective of Morocco through its vibrant colours. Also a nod to the wonderful designer Yves St Laurent... I suspect this space inspired him in his works. A must if you visit Marrakech❤️

It’s s very appealing space that’s wonderfully thought of.  You need to arrive as early as possible to avoid the crowds.  It’s very much worth the visit though with very impressive greenery and flowers from across the globe

I feel the majority of the people go to this garden because of YSL and it's definitely worth the visit. The blue colors are very unique and I've never see a more bold and vibrant blue. It's perfect for taking beautiful pictures, but you will be in competition with a lot of other tourists. So my advice is go in the early morning when the sun is not too strong and wear contrasting colors like yellow to make your outfit stand out more.
review_title: The kind of blue that you never seen

review_text: Well, the garden, once we got in, was quite impressive.  The picture taking is wonderful.  I’ll spare you the blow by blow of our experience, however it can be summed up as extremely frustrating. The signage for the museum is a combination of incorrect information, contradictory and just plain missing.  Further it does not coordinate with the locations' website.   This resulted in a useless 20 minute wait in line.  Trying to buy a ticket for the Berber Museum & Garden (without the St. Laurant museum) was impossible despite the sign 18 inches from the ticket seller (see the picture).  He insisted it was impossible, and when I pointed out the sign, I was told that I could pay the extra $10 USD/per person, start over at another ticket window on a different side (street) of the museum, or go home.  Essentially we were summarily dismissed in a rather rude fashion. A note: we went mid morning  (on the day we were sent away) and the lines were tremendous. Returning the next day (Wednesday) we got there 30 minutes before the ticket booth opened and were able to enjoy the garden before the massive hordes descended.  In retrospect, we were probably lucky we didn’t get in given the massive crowds.   Unfortunately the Berber Museum is closed on Wednesday’s (information provided on just one of the signs around the property, and contradicted on the website); so we missed out on that.  Something I was particularly looking forward to.  HINT:  if you want to take pictures in the garden (and you will even if you think you won't, it's that beautiful), go early or you will be jostling for position to take a picture absent a bunch of strangers.

Jardin Majorelle was beautiful! Unfortunately we didn’t listen to the wise advice of our Riad receptionist and arrived around 10 am, to wait in an hour long line to get tickets! As such, highly recommend going when it first opens to avoid the long line and less crowds on the inside. Very beautiful inside and well worth the visit though!
always love visiting this place when in Marrakech. The colours and plants are amazing! Make sure you buy the combined ticket so you can visit the garden, berber museum and ysl musee.
Try to arrive early to avoid the crowds which flock to see this spectacular garden. Also a visit the to the Secret Garden is well worthwhile - if you can find it!

What a wonderful surprise. Very crowded so get there early. The doors open at 10 but we got there before and didn’t have to wait long to get in. An hour later there was an hour wait. First we went to the museum of ysl and it was very interesting. Don’t skip it. Well worth it. Afterwards we explored the gardens and had lunch. Give yourself time to eat it takes awhile for the food to arrive. You can also see ysl house and personal gardens.   Unfortunately you can’t go into the house. But it’s a wonderful place to explore and get away from the hustle of the Médina
we had to wait in line for over an hour, it is nice to see but not big. the Berber Museum is very nice and interesting but  also not big. descriptions in English would be nice, not just in French!
review_title: nice but not a MUST SEE!

review_text: We thought we got to the gardens early, but it turned out that we had to wait about 55 minutes to get in. I didn’t mind the wait, but I do have to say that there were quite a few people walking around the Gardens which made it a little bit difficult to enjoy the scenery. I understand that it is a very busy time of year, which made me understand that I should probably have chosen a different time to visit. We enjoyed having tea at the restaurant, but I do have to say that this is definitely a tourist trap. It doesn’t cost much to go in but everything else is quite pricey. If you’d like to take great pictures this is a wonderful place to visit.
Just a beautiful garden. But go early to enjoy it more without all the crowds and the Chinese selfies..

I found this garden to be filled with lots of different plants. You could easily spend over an hour here. The walkways are well maintained. There are some ponds with koi and lily pads. There is a nice memorial to Yves St. Laurent who rescued the gardens from disrepair.
Beautiful, amazing garden nestled in the heart of Marrakech, this beautiful & peaceful place invites you for a break in the rush! Enjoy the place, the colours & the museum! a great moment!
