If you could imagine this place without the crowds taking selfies then you'd enjoy the aesthetic pleasure of these gardens.  There are so many photogenic scenes.  Be prepared to wait - we were there at 10:15 and had to wait for 30 minutes to enter.
writer_informations: Buchholz in der Nordheide, Germany,48 contributions

review_text: This is a must visit place. Stunning gardens but one of the main gardens closed 60/90 minutes before closing and we were hurried along which was very annoying. Taxis cost 40Dhs each way
review_title: Stunning but main garden closed early

review_text: This garden was so beautiful it moved me to tears. Absolutely stunning. Loved the cacti, and plethora of desert plants amongst the flora and ponds, lilies, birds, and the colours were out of this world. Fantastic cafe where we had an amazing lunch in the shade with the fountain tricking in the background. The gardens went on too, so after lunch we could discover more and it really was the best thing we did in Marrakech
review_title: Extraordinary Gardens next to Yves St Laurent Museum

review_text: We’ve spent 3-4 hours in the gardens with my gf and it was one of the most beautiful places we’ve ever been (even though I’m not the greatest plant-lover). The entry costs 70 MAD (~7 EUR) per person and it is worth every penny. It is a bit crowded with tourists so don’t plan to just rush through it, but at least you will have the opportunity to embrace the beauty everywhere around you. I recommend buying the tickets online, otherwise you’ll have to stand in the queue for around 1 hour.
review_title: One of the best sights in Marrakech

review_text: LINES ARE CRAZY.... go early, and you should only have to wait some 20 min in line, get there after 10 or so... and the wait is infernal.  The worst part is that there doesn´t seem to be a limit to get in, and it´s really crowded.  It has really nice places for pictures - but there are people (like little ants) everywhere - that makes it hard to take nice pictures.  Also, the price is about 7 euros, but you get a discount if you HAVE the student card with you --- no card,no discount - even if it´s obvious that you are of school age.  No family tickets either.  SO, it´s nice, but not sure it´s worth the 35 euros we paid to get in (family of five).

After the heat on Marrakech streets , it was a welcome break to walk through so much greenery, amazing shape cacti, round tranquil ponds. Unfortunately the cafe was rather full to get a seat and relax but there a some benches in the grounds to have a rest.
writer_informations: Prague, Hlavni Mesto Praha, Czech Republic,253 contributions

review_text: What a place!!!  It's beautiful and well taken care of. Make sure you have time to line up for tickets, unless you send someone in front as tickets will be sold on the day of visit only. The story of the place and being there is an experience you don't want to miss

UGH I AM SO SAD TO WRITE THIS....Honestly, If you're not queuing form 7am to go in at 8am when the open the doors then I wouldn't bother going. The garden itself is BEAUTIFUL however it is ruined by people! 1. It is absolutely appealing that people have clearly climbed over barriers, and used tools such as keys to deface the plants all for the sake of leaving their initials - I mean do we really care that K.S & T.B were there?! How disrespectful can people be? 2. THE CROWDS - like I said, if you don't go early be prepared to be pushed and scowled at, and even sworn at in all the languages in the world. For some reason, when people walk through the doors they flick their selfish switches and leave their manners at the door. Taking photos is near impossible! Everyone thinks they have more of a right than you and we unfortunately saw people, on purpose, get in the way of other people's photos and obstruct their path.
review_title: Unless you're there for when the open I wouldn't bother :/

review_text: We loved the Jardin with its bright walls and beautiful plants.  The YSL store on the grounds was one of the most beautifully presented stores I have ever seen.  I would advise to get there right as it opens as it gets crowded quickly

This uniquely preserved garden in the heart of Marrakech was lovingly persevered and saved by locals and the fashion designer Yves St. Laurent (as well as his lifelong partner). These gardens and artists' studio showcase the North African tradition of garden design and beautiful living. Can get a little busy once inside the walled garden.  Avoid the temptation to rush through the grounds.  Possibly even see the gardens in reverse to capture some of the plants being lit in a different direction. A real highlight of Marrakech and do make time for this wonderful urban gem if you have time while in Morocco.
review_title: Thank God for Yves St. Laurent

review_text: Beautifull Garden with Restaurant or Cafe inside . A lot of cactus . Very nice place to visit . Great place

Touristy, but essential. Very photogenic - but so many mindless people wandering around with their iPhones etc - it gets a bit humorous. The story behind it is what makes it so special. The new YSL gallery / building next door possibly more 'impressive'.

The gardens are beautiful with a large range of plants from all over the world. There are signs telling you where each of the plants originate from which is a nice touch. Lots of fish and turtles in the ponds too. However the cues are very long even for reserved tickets. Either go very early, opens at 8am or later in the day. Midday seems to be peak time.

Most online reviews mention the queues, it’s true you will have to allow a lot of time to visit here but it is so, so worth it. Don’t let the long lines put you off. We went to the Yves St Laurent museum first , where there were much shorter lines, and bought a combination ticket. This was well worth the money as it speeded up the whole process. Yes, there were lots and lots of people there but, as the gardens are set over a number of acres, there was always a sense of serenity and calm. No pictures do these gardens justice, they  are truly beautiful. A visit here is a bit of a chore but it really is worth it. Go, you will not be disappointed. Allow plenty of time and enjoy the experience.

We queued for around 45 minutes to get in as it was extremely slow to purchase tickets which was the only downside!  The gardens are not huge but just enough for an escape for a couple of hours which included a lovely pot of tea in the cafe.  A lovely, peaceful haven where I have never seen bamboo so large!  Definitely worth a visit but if i'm lucky enough to return to Marrakesh probably wouldn't need to go again.
review_title: Beautiful, peaceful escape from the hustle and bustle!

review_text: Was beautiful  Went there with family and alone and wasn't bothered by anyone you can get a horse and cart trip from the front of the square. Get your photo taken with snakes and monkeys or get!!
It is a tranquil & cool garden with great collections of plants & cactuses. Vibrant color interior, make a charming background for photo-taking.

Very contemporary and elegant. But not unique. I am sure you have been to better gardens. The garden itself is small and was very crowded. It is good spot for pictures and I liked it because it is something different than what we saw city after city in Morocco.
A stunning garden , tranquil even though busy. Café rated highly but didn't need it a the time we visited .

Around 600,000 people visit the gardens every year, so it worth noting that, unless you are traveling with a tour guide, traveling with young children, pregnant, or eleserly, you can expect to wait on que for quite a while to buy your tickets; the aforementioned groups have a special ticket office which is much faster and is located near the entrance. Inside the walls you’ll find a large example of local and foreign plant species which provide ample shadow on those sunny days. You’ll also come across a Bedouin museum (which charges extra to visit), a memorial and a store.
review_title: One of the most visited stops in Marrakech

review_text: We got there early and were so glad we did because the crowds were awful after 9am. It was a cool garden with a variety of plants but not amazing and if we had gone any layer than we did it wouldn't have been worth it
review_title: Worth a visit but only before the crowds come

review_text: If you are there, do also include a visit to the magnificent little YSL museum next door. They are both worth a closer look.

Beautiful garden with a fascinating history. A huge variety of flowers all very nicely curated. My only advice is get there early and reserve tickets before hand because it gets SUPER busy, and the queue to get in gets massive.

The manager Mohamad Zbiri and all colleagues were rude and truly incompetent. The worst experience of my life.  The managers are incompetent, rude and useless, making tourists a source to make money without offering the service.  We bought the tickets, after almost an hour of waiting, finally we got the tickets and as soon as we enter at 15.55 pm they were saying that the gardens were private and were closed and as such we would only have a small part of the garden to see.  They must inform visitors that from a certain hour we would only have access to a very small garden or at least a reduction price for part of the gardens. They are strategizing to deceive the tourist as soon as they receive the money.  Seven pounds to see palm trees, bamboos and some fishes doesn't worth the money. The managers, the police and the other clerks were very rude and seems very corrupt as well. In a country that lives on tourism and that the King asks to treat tourists well was the worst country I ever had and obviously I will never come back and spend my money here. It's a shame. Paulo

This is really a nice garden in the newer part o Marrakech. Connected with the name Yves St. Laurant who has a museum inside there. You find plants from all over the world which were brought here. The garden is very well maintained and if you try hard to find a quiet place to relax despite the crowds that run around there.

This garden is as lovely as the pictures. We came at 08:30 and although the cashier was really slow we hardly had to wait in line. We could enjoy the tranquility of the garden and were able to sit in a bench of our own. We also had coffee, yoghurt and mint tea at the café, which we can recommend. When we were done, at about 10, there were two huge guided tours arriving. So, come early!

This magical haven needs to experienced in peace, so best to get up early to miss the crowds. The berber museum enlarges ones world view on the different tribes and cultures that people our planet.  The YSL museum next door, is also a highlight into the genius of this designer ahead of his time.

We went there on a Monday in April not expecting lots of visitors - what a mistake ! We had to wait for approx. 45 mins to get in. Once inside we were stunned by the beauty - however, enjoyment wasn’t possible due the large number of visitors. Furthermore the scratched cacti were a disgrace! Please see attached pictures....
review_title: The magnificent garden is spoiled by selfie maniacs

review_text: We queued for an hour and a half so were expecting something special... Don't get your hopes up. If you love larged catuces, then this may be your bag, but if you're a normal person, do something else. The gardens are really nowhere special and I've seen hundreds that are more beautiful.
It is not a park where you can sit and relax, but it is still very pretty, people take good care of it and has good spot for pictures. Be aware that you may face 30min-1hr queuing for a ticket

Included in our tour was this lovely garden. saved from destruction by Yves St. Laurent.  It was very crowded the day we visited; nevertheless, we enjoyed the nature beauty of land plants and water ponds.
review_title: Amazing garden in the middle of Marrakesh

review_text: It’s a small garden that doesn’t require much time. Mostly cacti so not many colorful flowers. Very popular tourist destination but don’t put it at the top of your list.
Very interesting garden with museum. I recommend to combine it with the YSL museum! It can be very crowded around noon, so it is best to go early.
I had no idea that cacti could be so stunning. This place is a peaceful respite from the craziness of the city.

When we knew we would be visiting Marrakesh this was top of my list. Didn’t disappoint, loved our visit and enjoyed having a coffee in the pretty terrace coffee shop when we felt the need for a brief sit down. Try and visit early in the day to avoid the crowds.
Wonderful peaceful place, the best to relax from the noise of the city & take remarkable pictures. The line was not really long, but you can book your tickets from the internet to save time.
review_title: A must have of experiences in Marrakesh

review_text: So I intended to break up a long walk around Marrakech with a nice relaxed break in the Majorelle gardens. Unfortunately the queue was an hour long in the sun so by the time I got in I was a little less than peaceful. Of course those queues turned into very slow walking and numerous selfie-taking blockages around the narrow paths. When quiet this would be a lovely detour. Late morning on a Saturday I would not recommend!
review_title: Nice peaceful setting, very very busy though

review_text: I think this was my favourite place in Marrakech. Stunning does not cover it. Spent a good few hours strolling around the garden taking photos.
Small but interesting. The museum and bookshop opening hours do not coincide with the garden’s opening hours!

This is a beautiful place but it was so crowded when I was there.  The Berber Museum is worth going through, particularly the textile collection.  However, because it was crowded, you were forced through in single file and had to keep moving.  The gardens would be a tranquil place without so many people.  I'm glad I saw it, but I wouldn't spend all my energy to make it happen.
review_title: If you like gardens and crowds
writer_informations: San Rafael, CA, United States,36 contributions

review_text: No doubt that it is a place to see if you are in Marrakech! We were threat 3pm and there was a lot of people. Not too much to appreciate plants and spaces, but too many to stay and enjoy one or another corner we particularly appreciated.
review_title: Beautiful but a lot of peopke

review_text: The garden is small and crowded but once you get into the environment you are captivated. The colors reflected in the pools of water are amazing. Every camera shot is a work of art. The large collection of rare cacti are the crown jewels. Endlessly fascinating.
review_title: If you like cactus you don't want to skip this

review_text: Having waited in line for a Long time, I finally got my ticket and told to join the next queue in order to enter the gardens. The staff were rude to deal with, but the gardens were pleasant- I’d rather go back to the secret garden.
This is a must visit in Marrakech, the colours and birds a sheer beauty of such compact gardens is breathtaking, one tip though GO EARLY it gets packed
review_title: A must visit if you are in Marrakech

review_text: Stunning oasis and a multiple complex of art and nature away from the chaos of Marrakech. YSL museum is stunning too.
review_title: a must see place in Marrakech

review_text: Was OK but nothing too exciting but them again I guess it comes down to preference.There are other places I would recommend visiting whilst in Marrakesh.

Look don’t get me wrong, it’s lovely and there are some stunning parts to the garden but please limit the numbers more. The peace and tranquility of the place is ruined by the number of bodies. If you’re paying around £15.00 a head, you’d like to feel there would be some point when you could relax and enjoy the view. Also, whoever defaced the bamboo and the aloe vera plants by carving their names or initials should be ashamed. Why would I want to know ‘Fred was ‘ere 2014’, made the experience even worse.

It's really popular place. Get there early, definitely by 9:00 a.m.. Even then you're gonna have a hard time getting a picture by yourself. But I do recommend going. Also the price fix shops outside will give you a good idea of a number to be looking at to get a deal in the souks.
Amazing, despite the bad weather ! Nice plants and colors. We took great pictures. Must visit, when you are in Marrakesh.

Due to it's popularity it had a rather corporate feel with structured 'roadways' and fencing controlling the flow of the crowds. Look for the quietest time if you really want to enjoy the atmosphere of this lovely garden.  Time it wrong and the line to get in will be more extraodinary than the garden!
review_title: Spoilt by it's popularity, but still not to be missed.

review_text: We had to queue to buy a ticket and the price is not super cheap but this place is really nice. We went during the lunch break which was a good idea because the crowd came after  but before even if it was busy it was fine. I like the colours of the house and the vases.

One of the most vivid blues I’ve ever seen. A wonderful, secluded hour in amongst the shady beauteous gardens hidden in deepest Marrakesh behind high stone walls. A chance to recharge your weary tourist batteries from the onslaught of over-enthusiastic medina salesmen. What a special place!
It was lovely. Would be more enjoyable without crowds- went on a Sat. Not nearly as expansive as I had thought by the rave reviews. I've been to many botanical gardens that were much better.

These gardens are nice and a worth a visit, but be prepared to queue even if you have reserved tickets. The site is small and somewhat crowded so go early if possible. That said, the plants and flowers were lovely and provided a nice break from the general craziness of Marrakech!

These gardens are stunning, plenty to walk round and explore with lots of features and new areas to discover round each corner. It was busy the day we visited but did not feel over crowded. The marjorelle blue against the yellow and greenery looked fantastic. There is a memorial to Yves Saint Laurent. There’s also a beautiful villa that can be viewed from the outside. We queued for about 20 mins to get in. Adult ticket was 100 dh. Perfect for all ages including children. Pathways are flat. We ate at the cafe, it was not easy getting a table. There is seating inside and outside. The menu serves salads, club sandwiches and crepes etc. Prices ranged from about £7 to £13. Drinks from about £1.50 upwards. We were here about 4 hours in total to see it all. One of my favourite things we did and would recommend you don’t miss it. These gardens are much much bigger than the Jardin Secret in the Médina, although the Jardin Secret is also worth a visit fir the views over the Médina from the top of the tower.
review_title: Beautiful gardens - can be seen in half a day

review_text: I really liked the garden setup, it was really nice to walk round even more than once and visit the gift shops etc. The cacti were damaged heavily by visitors graffitiing their names. I thought this was disgusting.

Truly gorgeous and inspiring.  DO BOTH the gardens (gardens first as they open at 8) and the museum.  Plan on 4 -5 hours even if you are not a garden fan OR a fan of fashion as it is all so interesting!
review_title: Outstanding.  Get in line no later then 8:00 AM before the tour buses appear.

review_text: It is a great experience to visit the gardens. Everything was unique. The color mix gave it its charm. I would recommend a full day
You cannot go to Marrakech and not visit les Jardins Majorelle and the Berber Museum and Yves Saint Laurent Museum.

This is the garden designed and created by Yves St Laurent and Philippe Berge... the other reviews said it was wonderful and I thought it truly was! Amazing colours, shapes and designs with beautifully well kept cacti and palms, water features and vivid colours in pathways, pots, garden buildings, etc .It was quiet and away from the traffic - just lovely! However it was very busy - we arrived at 11.20 on a Monday in April (just before Easter) and waited 30 minutes to get in. The cost is 70Dhms (approx £5.90) with half price concessions for students (European Universities) and children.  It was also busy inside but we did manage some quiet areas and photos. We visited the cafe and had a drink too - service good and prices reasonable. again very attractive and well designed.
review_title: Beautiful,peaceful oasis in this busy city.

review_text: Even though this place gets busy it’s worth the visit. If you hire a local guide to take you  around the city and decide to visit here you will usually skip the entry line. Worth it! So beautiful 🌴🌵💚
review_title: A little haven of lush exotic tranquility in an other wise bustling energetic city

review_text: My friend and I visited the Jardin Majorelle twice during our recent trip to Marrakech.  The gardens are simply lovely, and, with the combination ticket (definitely worthwhile!), we greatly enjoyed the Berber and Yves Saint Laurent Museums. Note: If you buy the combination ticket for all three, you can purchase it at the Yves Saint Laurent Museum at the end of the block, which is much quicker than waiting at the very long line at the Majorelle ticket window.  Otherwise, arrive at the Jardin Majorelle early, because the ticket line moves slowly.
review_title: Lovely gardens with two worthwhile museums

review_text: a beautifull oase in the middle of Marrakech. Very nice maintained and preserved garden. Most visitors are there for the perfect photo, ignore the selfi sticks and watch the cacti variery and lovely garden composition. Tip: If you have children under 12year, you can avoid the queue and go to the separate counter for reservations.We were inside after only 15minutes waiting!

I visited Le Jardin Majorelle during my recent visit to Marrakech and was surprised at how much I enjoyed it. It was beautifully designed and some of the plants were amazing to look at, featuring the tallest cacti I have ever seen. The only setback was the millions of tourists taking photos of themselves which prevented others from enjoying the garden freely.
Was so happy to finally be able to go and visit one of my bucket list dream destination. The beauty is overwhelming and visiting those luxuriant gardens is just wonderful.
writer_informations: Cape Town Central, South Africa,205 contributions

review_text: The gardens are beautiful, fresh and a great escape from the busy city and from the heat. You will find several different plants and trees, some water features and a really cool and colourful cubist villa. The museums are also quite interesting and worth a visit.

The queue at 10:30 am took nearly 45 minutes from the time we joined it. We joined caisse 2, which I am sure is faster than caisse 1 :) Watch out for those sneaky ones that try to jump the queue just at the end! The gardens are pretty and it does make for a nice day out and photo opportunities. Not cheap at 70 D each, but a nice morning spent walking in the gardens.

Nice little garden to spend your day in. It is not too big, but if you take your time that's no problem. Wide variety of cacti, lemonplants, and roses. Definetly enjoyed the little berber museum as well. Recommended!

The gardens are simply breathtaking. Unfortunately, during my visit the Berber museum was closed, but that didn't detract from the complete serenity and beauty of the gardens overall. Many unusual and exotic species of plant invite you to simply stand, take a deep breath in enjoy the experience to its fullest. The only downside for me was the amount of people that were in attendance on the day I went. Even though I was there very early in the year, before the summer rush, there were a great deal of people milling about, just as I was, taking in the amazing scenery. We seemed to get in each others' ways as there was many a faltering to take a picture that could capture the serenity of the place without a plethora of strangers in the shot. A beautiful oasis within a very special city, taking a stroll around the gardens gives you a sense of why the creators loved the area so much. A definite recommend from me (a plant lover) and with a little imagination you could almost imagine the crowds of people vanish away into the background as you take in the atmosphere of a truly magical place.

After the effort of getting to this place we had wait in a queue on the street to get our tickets. Once inside the place is beautifully presented however a lot smaller than I imagined. Being busy you are constantly dodging smartphone photographers and people milling around. The YSL memorial is a little underwhelming but the museum and other buildings are lovely with the cobalt blues throughout. There is a cafe/eatery inside but again it gets very busy.

We went early afternoon as part of a tour and caught a significant volume of visitors which made the pathways very difficult to negotiate - however the plants and water features are very interesting - many cacti and other plants make a pleaseant visit. The Berber museum is an extra cost unfortunately - we decided it would not be worth it as we had limited time.
review_title: Exotic location with major crowds - go early or late

review_text: Lovely gardens, but watch what time you go to avoid the queues. Even very late in the day 45 mins before closing, we still queued for 10-15 mins. You will likely only need 20-30 minutes in the gardens.

This garden is such a breathtakingly beautiful place to visit. The colours of the houses, flowers and nature in general seemed to be too magical to be true. Definitely must visit when visiting Marrakech. This is also a good way to get a short break from the hectic life in the Medina.
We loved the gardens,  however extremely busy, recommend going early or the end of the day to truly enjoy.
review_title: Highly recommend this, tip,  go direct to YSL museum,  no queues here and you can buy the combination ticket

review_text: This was such a peaceful place to hide from the HELL just outside the door. It is amazing to think that such a haven can even be in the middle of a hellhole like the Médina.
This is a stunning garden which the whole family enjoyed. Queues are hideously long though so expect an hour wait at least!
review_title: Beautiful but LONG queue to get in.

review_text: Relaxing and beautiful gardens with a wide variety of plants.  Perfect place to take pictures! So glad we visited.
Just beautiful, great to learn about the icon and to hear about his life. The gardens are beautiful and very instagramable! The surrounding shops are lovely and modern

Since our visit a year ago, it seems the Gardens have been upgraded. Beautiful place to visit. Lovely water features, bamboo lined walks, gorgeous historic blue and yellow pots. Just a wonderful experience. Pre-book. Queues. Combine with a visit to the new Yves St Laurent Museum.
The garden is beautiful and calm. Make sure to get there early and book tickets ind advance. We had to stand in line for an hour in the burning sun. It was worth it though.
The garden is lovely, albeit small and very busy. Amazing that such a peaceful garden is in the middle of a mad and busy city.

Must visit this place ! This garden is located in Gueliz, in the center, where you will escape from the environnment of Marrakech. The variety of plants, trees are multiple coming from different parts of the world. The architecture and design have been well studied to give a certain authenticity to this place. Colors are various and everywhere especially the blue that bring positive energy. Grab the opportunity to visit YSL exposition and Berbere museum
So you’ll probably wait in line to enter the garden, but what a treat it is once inside. Aside from the crowds, it’s so serene, and a photographers dream! Worth a visit for sure
It is a must go place. Easy access, usually no big lines and also they have a good coffee shop inside it. .
Lovely gardens, a wide variety of plants including some fascinating cactii unlike anything I’ve ever seen before. I highly recommend a visit.
Really nice place to visit be prepared to queue . I would recommend  going early morning or late afternoon  . YSL Museum next door is also interesting

We came here on our first morning in Marrakech just as we were adjusting to the (sometimes) beautiful chaos that is the city.  It allowed us some time to amble through the beauty of the garden safe from the sound of the mopeds whizzing by in the nearby streets.  We spent just an hour here which was ideal on a bright, sunny day just before the tour bus crowds arrived!
review_title: Peaceful respite in the heart of Marrakech

review_text: This delightful garden was a lovely way to while away a few hours, wandering amongst the beautifully set out garden beds. It was quite crowded when we were there, but there were still quiet corners to be found.
What an impressive garden of a great collection of Cactus well laid out some flowering , such variety interspersed with ponds containing Carp
The garden was majestic, the colors and aura is all you need to feel good ! Nothing better to do on a sunny day :)

Seeing the garden in April was perfect, some of the cacti were 8n bloom, not to hot and that is what made it perfect! The Berber museum was well worth the extra cost, so informative as well as really beautiful displays.
We were very surprised to find so much beauty and greenery ..so different than the rest of the city which is a different type of beauty For sure  worth a visit!
Truly peaceful gardens, worth a visit and the exhibition is great too. Colours are amazing under the blue skies with a tranquil feel.
Great place to spend a few hours looking around. Plenty of tall palm trees to keep you cool and in the shade. Tie it in with the YSL museum to get a discount on the entrance ticket.

Trees and exotic plants,streams and pools filled with water lilies and lotus flowers, which serve as a home for numerous birds. The Art Deco building is painted in vibrant primary colours, glowing in yellow and intense blue offering us a calming, luxurious, artistic fragranted place.

We enjoyed, and I would certainly make time to visit, but it can get quite crowded.  Perhaps that is a testament to its attraction.  Interesting varieties of cactus.  Be sure you stop in the next door Yves St Laurent museum and catch the film.
review_title: Too crowded to be an oasis in the bustling city

review_text: The creation under the direction of Yves St Laurent. The Majorelle blue hard lansdcaping is so stunning
review_title: Fabulous, but long queues for tickets and rather crowded

review_text: We queued for approx 45 minutes to get in, so if you’re planning a visit try and go early or late. Other than this, the gardens themselves were beautiful. Unfortunately the museums were closed which was a shame however it was a lovely day to enjoy nature at its finest. Would recommend overall.

It is really worth arriving early to avoid the crowds and to get the best from the garden.  An oasis of cool, beautiful planting the cacti are amazing to see and flowering so a real treat.  The colours are vibrant and work really well, there is a nice cafe in the middle which served a nice cappuccino.
I went with a group of artists and we all really loved it.  We spent a few wonderful hours here.  Don't miss it.
Book ahead... or go early. Loved it, went late afternoon when b.c. the crowds had been through. So peaceful amongst the busy.
Really pretty, loved the giant cacti. Had to come back early the next day as the queues were insane.
review_title: Go early before tour groups arrive! 8-9 a.m

review_text: What a beautiful display of plants, trees from around the globe, providing a pleasing sight to the eyes, and a respite from the hustle of Marrakech

Sadly mass tourism is everywhere nowadays, so be prepared for that. We visited Jardin Majorelle around 10:00 and it was already packed. Nevertheless it is beautiful, you just have to have a lot of patience in order to get a nice picture( without tons of people in the background).
The cacti, trees and plants must be hundreds of years old reaching up to the sky!!  This was YSL's garden, there is also a monument dedicated to him.
If you love gardens this is a don't miss. make sure you buy uour tickets ahead of time to avoid the lines.

A very sophisticated location with cobbled streets , gifts shops and places to eat.  The Gardens themselves are full of trees & plants we went in early April so only splashes of colour from trees in blossom.  The villa has a mixture of Moroccan clothes and and artifacts and some pictures from yves saint Laurent. The museum next door separate entry cost has his couture a collection of dresses etc. Worth a visit there are some nice shops in the immediate area and easy to pick up a taxi back into the centre or a 20 minute walk.

While the Medina and Souk is part of the appeal of Marrakech, it was so nice to escape to a beautiful and peaceful garden.  It is well worth the journey out of the center of the city.  We also went through the Berber Museum in the garden - well worth the time.  We gained new insights into customs and culture.  It only requires about 15 minutes.

We're not fashion lovers, but even so the gardens are beautiful to walk around. It does get very busy and they try to direct you in a certain way to walk around which can help with the flow of people.

A great garden with a contemporary feel and to the YSL link.  Plants and colours just amazing. Downside is the crowd and queue if you don’t arrive early or prebook tickets. The website ref prices is also misleading, eg. Children student prices, where we were made to pay full adult prices for all of us.  End of afternoon might be good time to visit. Teenagers not interested in gardens or art will get bored. Afterwards we walked to the Médina etc in 30 mins.
review_title: Amazing colours but get there early

review_text: Just walk around and enjoy! Visit the Berber museum too. Take pictures in the garden and enlarge them to hang on your wall.

There is nothing wrong per se with the gardens, I was just personally disappointed. I have seen a number of formal gardens over they years, both in the UK and overseas and I just didn't find that this was anything particularly special. It was just (to me) another garden of established large cacti with a memorial in it. The gardens of the hotel we stayed at were just as nice and probably bigger.

Very pretty little garden.  You should know it's very touristic and busy but that goes without saying, it is a very popular place. It is made very nicely with an abundance of plants. I liked it and would love to return.

Beautiful gardens are a must when staying in Marrakech.  Prepare to queue but well worth the wait.  Yves-Saint-Laurent museum is here also and worth buying combination ticket to see museum, gardens and Berber museum.

We went early to avoid having to wait in the long queues that build up later in the day. You can also avoid having to queue if you go into the YSL museum and buy a combined ticket for the museum and the gardens. The gardens are beautiful. Although there are lots of people visiting the gardens, there is still room to wander around and see everything. There are a couple of parts of the gardens where people queue up to take pictures but it doesnt feel cramped or too crowded. Bring your camera as you'll want to take lots of pictures
review_title: Beautiful gardens, take lots of pictures!

review_text: The garden has beautiful different plants and some fountains. It is nice for a stroll, but super busy and  bit overprised.

This is a very beautiful garden. Bold color decor, exotic plants and there are some specific settings that often seen in blogs and posts. You can see many people lining up just for a picture. Overall, it is a good place for a walk and spend the afternoon. Just mind that there may have many tourists around.

This  garden was restored by Yves St. Laurent and is a quiet jewel in Marrakesh Morocco. It is best to get there early in the morning and go in first thing before the huge crowds get there!!!! The garden contains plants from all overe the world that are clearly identified. There are some huge, absolutely stunning bouganvilla plants with magenta flowers. The buildings are painted a brilliant lapis blue and mustard yellow. Inside the gardens, Yves St. Laurent has installed a fantastic museum of Berber culture. You will see their very colorful, creative ethnic costumes that will blow your mind! There is a display of women’s hand made jewelry in a room done with a ceiling of stars. Wow!! Nearby, in the Jardin  there is a BOTIQUE of St. Lawrence designs of fun leather goods,quality jewelry,textiles and beautiful objects at all price points. In addition, there is a cafe and bookstore. Plenty of things to do in a unique place. Definately worth a morning in Marrakesh.h
review_title: Jardin Majorelle marrakesh worth spending a delightful morning . Fascinating in lots of ways.

review_text: This is a beautifully kept garden with lots of amazing plants. It isnt huge but you could easily spend several hours here wandering around. There is also a lovely cafe to sit have have a mint tea.
A lovely little treat but we did arrive around 11am and the que was very long about 35 mins but when we left it was much quieter say around 1-1:30pm.
Very nice oasis-like garden.  Garden and museum are jewels.  Small, but meticulously arranged and maintained.  Well worth the visit.  Plan 60-90 minutes.
Go early if you want to avoid the crowds. Lots of cactuses, about 30 types of lemon trees. The restaurants and boutiques around are pleasant, too.

No traveler to Morocco should bypass half a day at Jardin Marjorelle and the Berber Museum. This was one of the highlights of our entire trip. While there, spend a visit in the small cafe with its amazing menu!!!! There are a lot of online tips for getting tickets..we arrived at 9 am and were inside within 10 minutes..lovely..stunning..very special part of any Marrakech experience.
review_title: The Best Day of our Trip

review_text: This place is such a sight to see, among the hustle and bustle, this is DEFINITELY a place to visit. So beautiful and well kept, perfect place for those selfies, and just a serene and calm place. Wish I had longer to sit and admire but had a flight back, but still tried to take in as much beauty and the sunshine that swells inside these walls. Absolutely beautiful.

This is a stunning garden, the green  foliage contrasting with the beautiful blue and yellow urns and building , all reflected in the pools of water where water lilies are floating and fish are swimming. A must see .
It’s a beautiful garden, very colourful and well maintained but it’s incredibly busy, even on a Monday at 10.30am.
Whether garden fan or not this is worth the queue and entrance money, calm, spectacular and with great cafe. Stunning cacti.

Good experience whilst in marrakesh The garden is quite pretty although can be abit boring after you take all the pictures you want.. also guards ask for bribes to put you in the shorter entrance line ? I guess they are just trying to make a living and that’s fine. Worth a visit whilst your there
The jardin majorelle are a beautiful oasis in the busy city of Marrakesh! Make sure you get there early to avoid queues! Beautiful Gardens!
review_title: A must see when in Marrakesh!

review_text: We came on a beautiful sunny day. We walked around the amazing gardens and saw the memorial and most importantly we managed to buy tickets at the book shop for the Berber museum. We enjoyed it tremendously
review_title: Must visit the gardens and the Berber museum

review_text: For a nice break from the hustle and bustle of Marrakesh, take a few hours out and visit these lovely gardens.  Many varieties of flora to see.
Its a beautiful  place but  not worth the long long lines. Go in early hours >>if not >>one hour long waiting in line in the street outside, especially on hot days

The garden itself is sublime.  We arrived at 11 a.m., had to stand in a line to pay the entrance fee, and could hardly move inside. Difficult to photograph without tourists everywhere! Still, the place is amazing; find out when it opens, and get there 15 minutes early to enjoy this glorious space in peace.

The Jardin Majorelle, with its exotic greenery from 5 different continents is a wonderful experience for fans of fauna and cacti. The highlight for me was the Musée Berbère with its collection of artefacts from the mountain tribes. Can get crowded.
Amazing the view the staff very nice loved it defiantly worth visiting. Just quês very long otherwise loved it

We visited this place to enjoy a half day out of the chaotic streets of Marrakech, which started to get into our nerves after a couple of days. Really well looked after, safe, shadowy garden which is perfect for an escape from the city. Has a small (and expensive) cafetaria and the staff in the park is really friendly. Because my partner get a little bit sunsick in the ticket queue, the staff helped us getting in quicker buying tickets as priority..
review_title: Beautiful breathing place out of chaos in Marrakech.

review_text: Unfortunately, we had to queue for an hour and a quarter in hot sun before getting into the gardens.  There were only 2 ticket kiosks, which is just ridiculous for the volume of visitors.  Once inside, we enjoyed the experience. If you’re planning to visit, then pre-book your ticket for a much quicker entry.

Exotic flowering cactus' mix with rare plants. Do also visit the small onsite museum. Take a picnic and just sit and admire the views. Not too large, ideal for buggy's and wheelchair access as mainly flat. Spotlessly clean loos..and an on-site café. Simple memorial to YSL in the garden.
review_title: A little 'touristy' but still worth a visit.

review_text: The visit to Marrakech would not be compete without this site. So relaxing, so colourful, so beautiful, ...

What beautiful gardens. Absolutely stunning. Amazing plants and cacti like I’ve never seen before. A must visit in Marrakesh. The Berber museum was amazing and also YSL museum too.  Be aware it’s very busy and long queues.

Really enjoyed our time in the gardens, very nice plants. It is really easy to get about and plenty of places to sit. Priced well but go in the morning or afternoon to avoid queues. It’s amazing there is such a place in such a busy city.
review_title: Good to see in a busy city

review_text: A great stop and worth visiting.  It is like an oasis in the middle of the city.   A nice break from all of the people!
Other than it being quite crowded it was beautiful and a nice contrast from the busy streets of marrakesh.

Just visited the gardens whitout the YSL museum and berber museum. It's overpriced and very crowded. Waited about an hour to get inside, but was disappointed. Some nice blue buildings, some fountains and was 70 dirham. If you have something else to do, do it. I recommend Le Jardin Secret instead.

Our Riad owner advised us to visit as early as possible in the morning. We took a cab, the garden is located in the "new town" and arrived half an hour before the office opened and there was already a queue in front. But all is managed very efficiently and at 9:00 we were inside. At this time in the morning there is a marvellous light, one can still hear the birds and smell fresh air. We toured the garden first, it is really beautiful! Afterwards we visited the museum, at 10:00 it was already overcrowded. They have a little gift shop, with nice vintage-poster images of Marocco. The Yves Saint-Laurent museum is around the corner. You can return to the old town on foot and see some nice public gardens on the road.
review_title: Wake up early for your visit!

review_text: If you are visiting Marrakech you absolutely have to go to Jardin Majorelle. This garden was about to be destroyed and was bought by YSL and now belongs to his and his partner’s foundation. The garden isn’t just breathtaking. Be prepared to take a lot of photos. I suggest you go as early as possible to avoid crowds and also it closes at 5:30 pm so that you will have enough time. There are 2 small museums on the territory of the garden and a beautiful boutique shop but quite expensive as those souvenirs are inspired by YSL collections. The museum of YSL is just incredible. You will learn about his life and see the original pieces from his collections from different years.
Highly recommend visiting during the spring to catch the many flowers and plants in bloom!  Kathi at Roaming Camels provided insight into our visit and joined us for the afternoon.
Amazing set up, super well maintained and arranged in perfect order. Better enter from the museum side and pay the combination ticket and you will void long queues.

This is a must-see; the garden has more palm trees and cactus plants than flowers, and you wander along prescribed paths.  There are crowds of people in certain areas, but you can find a bench in a more isolated area to sit and contemplate.

This attraction is beautiful and exactly as expected, but the crowds can be overwhelming. You can buy tickets both at the garden and at the museum entrance. Usually the queue is shorter at the museum cashier. If you would like to experience (relative) calm and lush gardens, you could also check out the public park nearby, Cyber park.

The garden is much smaller than we imagined. Interesting YSL history. Some colour and a good selection of plants. Small Berber museum within the gardens. Quite expensive overall and can be very busy with long queues. W
review_title: Not as special as we thought

review_text: Very busy! We went early but there was still a crowd. Not very handy with a child/buggy. Lots of steps. No babychanging facilities. It was very nice overall but I think you pay way to much for the size.
Go early, book you tickets ahead of time.  Plan to spend an hour maximum.  Try to link this with another activity nearby.  It's beautiful, but not that big and gets crowded quickly.
Unfortunately we chose to go on a Wednesday when both the Berber and the YSL museum were closed (our mistake) but the gardens were lovely.

While in Marrakech on our Morocco trip, we toured the Majorelle Garden ... this is where Yves St.Laurent and his partner are both buried.  The gardens are well laid out for casual strolling and the tropical plants are breathtaking.  It was quite busy the day we were there, but it did not take away from the relaxing experience.

The line was very long but if you go through the YSL museum you can get in faster as they are attached. It was frustrating trying to get around in the jardin. The vast majority people who were there were teens and twenties trying to take artistic selfies or of each other. The ladies room was so full of girls putting on makeup that it was impossible to get to the sinks to wash your hands. The plants are not particularly outstanding if you can see them. I would not recommend wasting your money here.
A tranquil and beautiful garden of Yves Saint Laurent. The garden isn't too large but is well kept. There will be a lineup to buy tickets so cultivate patience.
review_title: Beautiful garden for those with patience

review_text: Really enjoyed the tranquility of walking around this magnificent garden - away from the busyness of the street! The blue of the house is exquisite as a comparison to the green of the garden and the different giant cacti are incredible!
As the title says. A really nice garden that i guess you kind of have to See, But it was filled with hundreds of tourists

It is a pleasant getaway, as other reviewers have said. My wife and I did see plantation and beauty we had not previously encountered and did feel very relaxed and cool as we strolled around the garden. We did appreciate what the garden offered and did go into the museum of islamic arts and found it interesting (we are muslim by faith and so this is obviously ones own choice whether to pay the little extra and go in
We had a morning to kill waiting for a friend who suggested we visit the garden. So glad we did. The layout, the vivid blue with the green was beautiful. Suggest you go early to beat the crowds.
This is such a beautiful garden, the cacti are so stunning but against the blue paint, they are awesome! Not too large to walk around but well worth a visit.
A nice Garden in a very arid city. Just it!! Do not expect any botanic garden.  You don’t need more than 1h to see it.
This was really beautiful. We had a long day and almost did not go. Fortunately our wonderful guide insisted. It is beautiful. Definitely worth going.
As gardens go, it was fine.  We went there and walked around and took pictures.  It was beautiful, but not exceptional.  The best part for us was to just sit on a bench and listen to the birds.
review_title: Long lines to get in...but worth a visit

review_text: Lovely gardens, but get there before 9am to avoid queues. Also a few weeks later would have had more flowers out and there better

Beautiful gardens and definitely not one to miss out! So well kept, cheap entry although we had to queue and great photo opportunities too. Possibly a good idea to avoid afternoon time sit was very busy
Beautiful gardens but get there by 9.30 to avoid the long queue. Purchase combined ticket for Yves saint Laurent museum to get direct entry.

Really quite stunning, and a peaceful exit from the bustling streets to see this amazing garden. One note though... that hypnotic color blue that you see painted is available to buy in the gift shop. However it is illegal to being onto an airplane or mail,  and was almost confiscated twice. Even in checked luggage. I got lucky but be warned.

I had been looking forward to seeing the colour and design of the garden.  Unfortunately, the reality of dealing with crowds of self absorbed instagrammed at every colourful location meant the visit was a total disappointment.  There was nowhere to sit and just look at the landscape or listen quietly.  Unless you’re focussed on promoting your latest escapade on social media rather than appreciating being in the moment, you’ll be best to avoid!  My guide advised our group of 12 that we visited at a quiet time of the day - I can’t imagine what it must be like when it’s busier!

Its a good idea to order tickets before your visit, we had to queue for nearly an hour to get them. It was probably the cleanest place we visited but perhaps we were expecting a little too much as its no Kew Gardens and it took us about an hour to get around.

Marrakech has become a really popular destination in the past few years and I had read mixed reviews about the Majorelle Gardens being crazy busy and not all they used to be, but no amount of tourists can detract from what is simply a stunning, magical place! The onsite coffee shop does yummy food at decent prices too. I had visited these gardens before and I’ll be visiting them again, always a 10 out of 10 for me!
review_title: Every time is like the first time

review_text: It was as beautiful as the pictures promise. Was definitely worth a visit with reasonable prices (40 dirhams for Moroccans/ residents - I think maybe 70 for tourists). The gardens were stunning. My favorite feature was the coy pond with the biggest coy fish I've ever seen. Downside was that the garden was very crowded. People were waiting in lines to take pictures all around. It was difficult to enjoy the full potential and beauty of the place with so many people. I went in the afternoon and think next time I'll try for early morning.
Beautiful place , many flowers and great colors! We couldn't visit the berber house because closed... Get ready for long queues for entrance tickets  ( more than 1 hour)

We were on a tour with limited time so attended early morning, bird song filled the air and around every corner, there was a delightful vista We wanted to go back later in the day, but our tour times did not permit Noted on exit that the queue at the street entrance had grown massively - clearly a very popular destination
Atlas Tours took us here. Good one hour tour. Recommend it highly. We would not have visited except for the tour guide. Very glad we saw these unusual gardens.
Worth queuing for.  Although there were lots of people, it didn't feel crowded.  We had a lovely lunch in the cafe and we spent a wonderful morning wandering through the gardens.
Nothing spectacular, nice to wander around but wouldn’t go out of way to do it. Best done with YSL and Berber museum, not as something itself
Crowded but lovely visit to a must see spot.  The gardens are breath taking and such a well done artsy spot to see!

After an hour long wait in the queue we reached the ticket booth only to find if we had visited YSL museum first we could have bought a ticket for it the garden and the Berber museum which would have fast tracked our entry to the gardens.as it was once inside the restaurant was lovely with friendly staff and lovely food.the gardens are beautiful and even though busy we didn't feel overcrowded well worth a visit
fabulous gardens & location - glad YSL saved it Ensure you do the YSL musee also (further down the road) if you love fashion - Stunning

This is one of the places you need to see in Marrakech. The gardens are beautifully kept, and the cactus plantings are amazing. This garden is right next to the Yves Laurent Museum so you can do both in one morning. It does get crowded so go early!
Make sure to buy tickets ahead of time or go with a tour guide. Otherwise, be prepared for a long line to get inside.
Fantastic garden with a lovely athmosphere .Very interesting .Lovely shade .Some queuing at the entry at noon so visit earlier if possible .But well organized .Nice shopping in Rue Majorelle
review_title: Lovely Jardin Majorelle and Rue Majorelle

review_text: It's  like you're not in Morocco, so so beautiful. So many different trees and flowers and plants. Definitely a must see when in Morocco. But keep in mind that you can wait over an hour to get in, lots of people wanna see it.
Beautiful garden with a great variety of cacti and a monument to Yves St. Lauren who had lived in Marrakech.

I was at this place very recently, in March 2019. it is a beautiful place, the plant life and little alcoves makes for great photos. but the entire walk through took no more than 15 - 20 mins. I thought it would be at least a 2 mile walk, but no, its just a large circle, then its over. but the plant life and bamboo trees were gorgeous.
A wonderful, tranquil escape from the bustling city. Beautifully set out. Go first thing in the morning as it’s at its quietest and allow an hour to wander.

My wife had read that this was a must do whilst visiting and having been I agree. We arrived just before 12 and the queue was very large, we returned around 2pm and it was better. The gardens were lovely and showcased arid planting very well. Lots of cacti and succulents along with some pleasant pools. The Berber museum was interesting enough to warrant paying the extra at the gate. It does seem very popular so can be a challenge to find space away from the crowds of people.

Lovely gardens which are bright, colourful and well maintained, although extremely busy and full of people with their phones out. Queued for a while before getting in but a nice hour spent in a more modern part of Marrakesh.

Wonderful and worth a visit, beautiful, magnificent cacti. Beautiful colours. Just one shabby aspect, portaloos in garden which you were expected to pay for, I did not as already paid alot for entrance fee! Don't let this put you off though as lovely place to visit...
review_title: Advise to book ahead online to save queue at the entrance

review_text: Loved the Garden and did enjoy the Barber Museum but didn’t think much of YSL Museum unless you really got insight knowledge of fashion industry. I think it was over priced for what you get inside. Garden is 70 dr and Barber Museum is 30dr. YSL Museum own its own is 100 dr or you can buy combine ticket for all three for 180 dr. Queues at the graden goes very long very quickly but if you go about 100 meters further to YSL Museum window the queues are smaller and you can still buy tickets for all three facilities. Inside garden is very pleasant fresh well with lots of plants and colourful buildings. You do have to wait to get a perfect picture. There was nice cafe inside the garden looked very close to nature. Toilets were clean. Barber Museum inside the garden through good light on life in the Barber village and their way of living. All in all i very much enjoyed my visit here.

We were told to get there early, but we over slept and didn't arrive until 11am. we had to que for 1 hour and 45 minutes to get a ticket, for garden entry. so either get a ticket early or late in the day or get hotel to order- if possible. Once inside the gardens are really very good, just a lot of people. I would definitely recommend visiting, just do it early.
This is simply a devine space of quiet and shade away from the noise and heat of the city. A must visit
Quiet garden, bit of a track from centre - taxi journey needed. Once there, pleasant. Cafe busy and quite expensive
Very long que, over and hours wait. But once inside, it was nice and peaceful. Lovely gardens.  Also has cafe . Food ok to good.
We went to jarden majorelle with my boy friend befor midday. this place  is one of the important place to visite in marrakech . you buy a ticket  7 euro  . But this place enjoyd for a half hour
Well worth a visit, we got a combined ticket for the gardens and YSL museum.  It is very busy so you can't sit and enjoy surroundings really.
Fabulous place with an equally fabulous cafe ... entry queue early pm was very long so early day visit advisable

When you search on what to see in Marrakech it seems you need to visit this place and spend 70 MAD is a most. Not sure why it is so overrated when there is so much else amayzing to see. Better to go and find some special riads which would even be free of charge
review_title: Not sure why to go there

review_text: A beautiful garden/park with something special around every corner.  So well designed and with an interesting history.  Lots of photo opportunities.  In addition, there is a gift shop there with some wonderful designer items that would probably sell for at least 3 times as much if you were in the states.

Beautiful, though small. This is a trip best enjoyed for a half hour to forty five minutes unless you go to the museums associated. The cage is very charming but be warned of long waits to order, pay and get a seat (which appears to involve hovering and jumping on as soon as another guests table) Definitely visit, but don't plan a day around this.

Upon arrival the queue was quite long but rest assured it was worth the wait. It was moderately priced but they also offered a student discount, so do bring a long your ID card if you have one! It’s a very peaceful and beautiful place, with lots of great photo opportunities. Although, it was somewhat polluted with people obsessing over grabbing the perfect picture and not enough people appreciating their actual surroundings.

Beautiful place, lot of trees, bamboo, cactus, flowers, palms, orangetrees... Berber museum worth of visit. The worst experience was staying in the line for tickets about 70 minutes on the sun. We were there around 11 am, the best time is afternoon around 3 pm, the line was quite short.
I love the gardens and lakes so much to see wonderful forna and plants too. so many varieties great colours too

this is something a little different to see in Marrakesh, the desert style gardens are beautiful, big cacti and tall bamboo paths, the striking cobalt blue home and decor is so beautiful against the green of the plants. also the berber museum is interesting with a small but well done collection of berber artifacts, jewellery and costumes. it was a bit busy with tourists and everyone is trying to get the best photos, but overall it was worth a visit

Two couples, two reviews. Three  parts to this: the gardens, the new YSL exhibit, and the Berber museum. The gardens, while beautiful & well cared for, were ok. Quickly walk through. If you love gardens, you’ll love this. The variety of plants & flowers is impressive. The YSL exhibit: very cool, loved by us two girls. The YSL clothing over the decades is iconic & some of it recognizable. Boys did not like this. The Berber Museum: liked by all if us!  Thoughtful, well presented info. Worth purchasing the combo ticket to visit all three.
Not to be missed garden. The plants, the peace, the sky and the Majorelle blue are just a great combination for a Nic afternoon small walk
Wonderful experience but if you don't get there first thing in the morning you will wait in long lines and be jostled by crowds.

We arrived mid afternoon to find an overwhelming melee of people queueing up to access the garden ... so we aborted and vowed to get up at 7am the next morning to be there for doors opening an 8am. It worked a treat and for thirty glorious minutes we had the place more or less to ourselves. Then it started to fill up and the magic became a little tainted. Other than this, my tips are as follows ... do buy a combined ticket (210 dirhams : circa £16) which gives you access to the great little Berber Museum within the garden ... and, more importantly, the Yves Saint Laurent Museum a hundred metres or so down the road ... absolutely not to be missed ... even if you have zero interest in fashion ... it’s worth it just to see the really lovely modern building ... and the excellent way his life and work has been curated. Do not miss the film either ... fascinating stuff. Finally, do experience the little cafe here ... beautiful setting, nice service, and quality food and drinks. The only odd thing is that the two museums do not open until 10am so one has to spin out rather ones tour of the garden.

Marrakech is very green city with several parks & gardens.  This one costs quite a lot in comparisom to other places and is very impressive. it comes in stages with add-ons for the Berber Museum & Designer Museum The queue was up to half an hour. It is beautifully laid out and worth seeing but crowded, with a quota entry system.  Make sure you want to see it rather than something else if time is short.

We went here just before midday. The queues were long and it took about an hour to get to the cashier. My recommendation would be to get there either first thing in the morning or late afternoon. The gardens are very nice and worth the visit.
It’s well worth carving out half a day to see the beautiful gardens. Go early to beat the queues (there are only two payment windows) but the gardens are worth the effort.

This garden is spectacular.  It is not like any other garden I have ever seen. You can tell it is the work of some one who really understood how different colors work together.  Do early in the morning to avoid long lines.
Really lovely gardens in the city. Ysl kept it alive after the dead of the previous owner. Really nice to see. Give it an hour to visit. You need time to make the perfect picture.

Stunning gardens with fantastic colours, arrive early to avoid the huge queues otherwise you will be standing in the sun for a while. Well laid out but can be difficult to take decent pictures when it is really busy

We had to stand in line outside for half an hour, but the visit to Jardin Majorelle was definitely worth the wait. The Majorelle blue colour of the pavillion made a nice contrast with the green plants and trees, together with the colourful flowers hanging down. It’s a peacefull place to stroll and admire the surroundings. In the cafetaria you can sit in- or outside and enjoy a lovely meal, or just a drink, at a beautiful location. Prices are great. This is a must see when you are in Marrakech. And if you are a fan of fashion king Yves Saint Laurent, you can visit the museum in his memory here too. If you take a taxi to get there, make sure to ask the driver in advance what he charges for the ride. We were almost ripped off, because right before we arrived at our destination he stopped his meter (that showed less than 5 euro) and asked for 20! After a heated discussion, we payed 6 euro. Average tourist price from the Kasbah area til Le Jardin Majorelle is between 5 and 7 euro, and even less for locals. The prices in the boutique were a little outrageous too, but it was a nice shop to see. All in all the gardens are beautiful, peaceful and inspirational. As I said, a must see!

Go early to avoid long lines.  YSL and Pierre Berge created heaven on Earth but with cacti and palm trees.  The gardens are dreamlike.  The Musee Berbere is very interesting.   We did not visit the house or the YSL Museum due to lack of time.
If you could get in without the crowds, this would be a perfect respite from the city. The layout and plants are gorgeous, and the (small) Berber Museum is a treat.
7 euros to get in very overcrowded and unkept Mueseum closed at weekends , the interesting part of gardens also closed at weekends
This place has nice colours and makes you walk into the paradise. Best place to make memories with friends, family in pictures.

Worth a visit though not as impressive for me as the very different Secret Garden. The amazing huge cacti are the best I have ever seen. Nice place for a coffee. Main problem is the vast crowds and long queue - get there early or book in advance.
An amazing tranquil paradise away from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. Beautiful, and idea inspiring for my own garden !

Eye candy in every direction. An incredible variety of flora from all over the world, laid out for easy strolling. Every turn brings a new sight.  Easily navigated by wheelchairs. Go first thing in the morning . .  can become very crowded later in the day.
It seems that all tourists in Marrakech want to go here, so expect long lines and crowds in the garden. Add that its a rather expensive attraction for Marrakech, 70 dirham. Not really worth it.

The line alone to get a ticket was about an hour and a half. Then we got in and understood why the line was so long: it was very busy. Hard to see several things because of all the people. Looks nice though but don't go if it is that full.

I love the Majorelle Garden! The first time I visited was about 12 years ago and it was practically empty! However, this time it was so crowded and the queue for tickets was very long. Once inside though it’s gorgeous and the Majorelle blue is such a mesmerising colour that I had to buy a tin of paint from the shop! I would thoroughly recommend a visit to the garden whenever in Marrakech, although I much preferred it when I almost had the place to myself!
Nice place to spend couple hours in the afternoon, just relaxing on the bench and contemplating the beauty around.
Being a keen photographer I have wanted to visit for years it was worth the wait an absolute gem beautiful explosive colours a must do when in Marrakesh
The best thing to do in Marrakesh. Only small but an amazing oasis from the city. Very busy however even though we arrived early in the day
Nice gardens,beautifull colours and the museum Yves Saint Laurent is a masterpiece..A must visit when in Marrakech.

I suppose it depends on where you live and where you have traveled, but for us it was just a nice garden to walk around for an hour. Sooooo many tourists, hard to move. People were taking photos of every single plant. I guess where they come from they have not seen such plants before. But many were typical plant varieties you'd find in the US out west, especially the cactus. There is a small monument dedicated to Yves St. Laurent as some of his ashes and his boyfriend's ashes are buried there. It takes about an hour to walk around and its a good photo op for your album.
Really Wonderful garden. You can stay there for at least 2 hours and relax. By the way the food in their restaurant/café was really awesome!
Beautiful gardens but get there early as we arrived just after opening and the queue was already really long. Busiest sight we visited while in Marrakesh.
I heard really great things about this place, but I was really unimpressed. The gardens are lovely, but they are small and unbelievably crowded absolutely all the time.

Beautiful garden, one of the best I have visited. The problem is that it is packed with tourists, much more than other tourist sites of Marrakech, so if you are after a quiet time in the garden, forget about it
We loved it here, nice to walk round and enjoy the plants. Nice outside courtyard to have drinks too

We had coach tour with a guide and visited early in the morning before the queues. Also the garden was still, peaceful, and the most beautiful garden setting imaginable. The terracotta pots were ablaze of colour - Moroccan Blue and a fabulous acid yellow. So inspirational. Gorgeous bamboo and cacti planting. Also try the cafe, a garden within a garden, for tasty coffee and a spot of people watching thrown in for free!!
review_title: The highlight of our visit to Marrakesh

review_text: A garden designed by Paul Majorelle in 1917 and opened to the public in 1947, it was in a state of decay when purchased by Yves St Laurent, who used the studio for his work and is buried in the garden with his partner.

Plagued by tourists determined to take THE best Selfie, the Jardin Majorelle is, nevertheless beautiful and exotic.  A gentle wander around the paths leads to a Summer house with photographs of Moroccan scenes and people before leading into the Berber Museum (No Photography allowed).  The Berber Museum is fascinating and well laid out with clear explanations of the exhibits.  The route leads naturally on to a gift shop and to the cafe (prices only marginally above outside cafes) which was definitely a haven of peace and quiet away from the bedlam of people trying to take there own 'special' photograph. Go early to avoid the crowds and tour groups but if you wish to jump the queue, buy the YSL Museum ticket (extra( which will bypass the ticket office for the Jardin.
review_title: A Beautiful Garden But Go Early

review_text: Nice & colorful garden but we actually believe that the entrance fee is not worth what you are gonna see.

Thanks to a tour arrangement we avoided the loooong waiting to get in - the queue was even longer when we left. The mixture of plants, trees, flowers, colours and people creates an unforgettable memory. The entrance fee is 70 Dh, extra if you want to see the small museum inside.

I think we paid around £10 to visit the gardens, which are located around 20 mins away from Jemaa el-Fnaa on foot. The colours, architecture and plant life here really were spectacular and we welcomed the lovely shadey spots the garden had to offer during the mid day sun! We didn't pay the extra to go into the museum but wish I had... So to anyone planning a visit I would deffo recommend you do it all! 🌿🌵🌴
The atmosphere is amazing. The cafe inside is nice. It is worth to visit Berber museum inside. So relaxing place. Peaceful.
review_title: One of the best place to visit

review_text: Perhaps because of too many people I didn’ find this place any special. The only thing thta I appreciated was the ethnic museum.
This garden is magical. Be sure to go buy a composite ticket so you can go to the Yves St. Laurent museum as well.
Jardin Majorelle was very beautiful. I would recommend going there early, we arrived at 10 and had to wait for a good hour to get in. It might also be a good idea to prebook tickets.

Despite rave reviews I must admit that I’ve seen better gardens. The hype could be because of yves saint Laurent ‘s influence on the place. It’s too busy as well. If you’re a student bring your id. There’s a student discount. It was ok but there are other places to do and see in Marrakech.
review_title: It’s a bit of a bust

review_text: Majorelle Gardens was a beautiful and intimate garden with a bamboo grove and many different fascinating cacti. The brilliant blue of the studio, now a Berber Museum, is a colorful contrast to the browns and greens of the plants. Come right at opening time to enjoy this intimate garden before being besieged by hoards of more tourists.
review_title: an intimate jem in busy Marrakech

review_text: Loved this small but magical garden and it's history. Well worth a visit I booked a half day private city tour with viator Adil our guide was excellent and he took us to the garden as part of the tour. I fully recommend the visit, and viator for such a professional service.

Seemed a bit too much money and queuing for what it was but a lovely, well kept garden. Not a botanical with wildlife galore that I love but peaceful and human designed. The blue house was nice. The column put up for Yves Saint Laurent seemed a little under whelming tribute to a colourful designed. (Good water features and escape from hustle and bustle)
Very beautiful garden, next to the villa of YSL. it has beautiful plants and it is very peacefull. Nice coulours and it gives you a peacefull impression. In the mornings many people though.
The place is very beautiful even if it is quite far from the old medina if you want to go there walking. And also prices are too high for what they offer (garden and a little berbere museum)

If you visit this beautiful garden and museum, try to go very early. By mid-afternoon, crowds are intense and lines waiting to enter can reach two hours. Definitely worth a visit, but I am not sure it was worth waiting two hours.
It was amazing in this beautiful garden. It was a little bit crowded, but we managed to see everything. Very beautiful oasis, we love it so much.

Great and we’ll conserved garden and „buildings“ nice and helpful personnel inside. The only problem is the long queue to get a tickets. And  personal on the caisse on them phones watching videos.... while you are asking them tickets...
Magical gardens in terms of landscape design, contrasting plantings, dramatic plants, colourful pottery, stunning architecture. Go early to avoid the crowds.
review_title: An explosion of texture and colour

review_text: Part of the YSL museum it is a must but go early , or maybe the end of the day. Buses arrive making it way to busy. It was a tribute to YSL and his gay partner. Our Moroccan guide had some serious issues with gays so we thought it was great to see both men honoured in the garden. Amazing cactus and water features . There are some nice shops over the rod and maybe a coffee when you are finished.
review_title: What a wonderful surprise even if you don’t like gardens

review_text: Absolutely beautiful gardens which manage to feel peaceful despite the dense crowds. The green colours of the planting really pop against the deep blue painted structures. The queues to buy tickets are huge so TOP TIP: buy your tickets at the YSL museum next door where the queue is much smaller.

The gardens themselves offer a superbly interesting story of the small man against the system with Yves Saint Laurent preventing the gardens from being turned into an apartment complex. They are quite obviously a huge tourist attractions now, and the gardens have been gradually developed into a full-on jungle paradise. We had to queue to enter and once inside the gardens are really quite stunning, flanked everywhere by the famed Majorelle shade of blue which looks pretty spectacular. We walked into the garden close to the house but fairly quickly lots of staff appeared and everyone was ushered out of that section for an unknown reason which was disappointing. Upon returning I walked past the fish pond and I was dismayed to see a dead fish laying on its side at the bottom which wasn't very nice to see, minus points there. The plants themselves are amazing with countless cacti of variants I have never seen before, plus there are flowers all around. It's hard to enjoy the gardens fully with the immense crowds congesting the area but I suppose this is to be expected. Possibly a timed ticket could help? Overall well worth a visit to see the top-rated attraction in the city.
review_title: Charming but too busy to fully enjoy

review_text: Beautiful garden to visit. We had a sunny day and stayed the whole afteroon in the garden enjoying our Moroccan tea and the view. It is definitly word visiting.

The gardens are so beautiful definitely worth a visit! You can buy a combined ticket for here and YSL museum which is worth it and works out cheaper! Think you can pre buy these! We didn’t pre book and had to queue! We got there early so didn’t wait too long but by the time we came out the queue was really long especially for the gardens! Was really busy inside but still one of the nicest places I think.

Walked here from central Marrakech but was good and worth it lots of gardens particularly liked the range of cacti Not overly priced well organised but clearly very tourist focused. Worth the money and time on a sunny day. Think I preferred the secret garden but that’s just a personal view point

The light the colour and the whole ambiance of this place were amazing. You must go if you are in Marrakesh. Make sure you get your ticket prior to the visit otherwise the queueing is horrendous. This was so worthwhile and the Berber museum was also interesting. 3 hours well worth it.
This garden was on my "must-see" list for Marrakesh.  It's very nice but we had to wait over an hour to get in and it was quite crowded.  Thank goodness it wasn't a hot day!
We arrived without a reserved ticket and the line of people waiting to get in was huge - I reckon the wait would be close to an hour. We just left.

The first time we tried to visit the queue for tickets was insane the second attempt was better, just 15 minute wait. Once inside felt like being on a London Underground train during rush hour. Very difficult to take photos without strangers in the shot. If you like Bamboo and catcus you will be fine. Personally we felt the gardens were overated.

Get there early! My best advice for Le Jardin Majorelle is to beat the queues by arriving 30 minutes before it opens. If you can, pre-book your ticket to avoid the inevitable. Once inside it can become quite congested, both in the garden and the museum. Still, it is a fascinating landscape to enjoy regardless.
review_title: A Beautiful Garden, Good Museum for Beginner Insight into Berber Culture

review_text: Went on the recommendation of friends. The gardens are beautiful and tranquil and shady. Interesting Berber museum and small gift shop. Best buy is the YSL museum next door- you need to exit the gardens and enter on a separate entrance but it’s less than 2 mins walk away. When we arrived we saw a huge long queue waiting to buy entrance tickets to the gardens but a very short queue for those with tickets or accompanied by a guide. Some fellow travellers told us to buy the tickets from a small excursion shop (go back to main road and it’s 50m on the left). You buy the ticket for all 3 bits of the tour, he takes you back to the garden entrance and you’re in at the front of the queue. Whole thing was £30 total- worth it not to stand in a sweltering queue for at least an hour 😊
Beautiful garden and definitely worth seeing but you could walk round it in 30 mins so don't plan 1/2 day there and avoid Wednesdays if you want to visit the Yves St Laurent museum as its closed
review_title: Go early or late to miss the queues
