review_text: It was hard to enjoy the beauty of the gardens because it was so crowded. If you go, select your time based on anticipated crowds.
Beautiful gardens with the best ever cactus display. Went in through the YSL museum which gets you in much faster. Great day
review_title: A day at the Marjorelle Gardens

review_text: Lovely, but small. Usually very busy, can be difficult to get a good picture. The queue is big during the weekends, go to the YSL museum and buy a combined ticket.
The visit was a lovely break from the intense Medina culture. What a great gift from Yves St. Laurent to the city!

Found the gardens incredibly underwhelming unless you're into wearing flowy dresses, sunhats, not facing the camera, and posting nonstop in Instagram. Too busy for such a small space. The cacti are lovely, but varieties that are found easily around the world. Yes the blue wall is stunning, and there is a museum... But in a city like Marrakech I think there is more to see...

We have been existing to visit this garden before after we heard that is is nice  but when we were going we have to wait a long time to get in even to get in no thing worth to wait for  all that time just to visit  a normal garden and not worth to pay that money

This place comes highly recommend by all the travel guides and sites. It was a nice place to visit to escape the hustle and bustle but it’s nothing special. The blue buildings are pretty and make for a nice photo opportunity. In my opinion you would struggle to spend more than an hour here.
review_title: Peaceful but don’t spend more than an hour

review_text: The gardens are simple but beautiful. I would definitely recommend the cafe inside, the staff are lovely and the food was excellent.  Definitely buy a combined ticket to see the gardens, Berber museum and YSL museum- if you like couture.
review_title: Beautiful gardens, excellent cafe, wonderful Berber museum

review_text: A lovely garden to walk through and take photographs. Mostly cactus and bamboo. It’s a bit small for a typical botanical gardens but for Morocco it’s one of their best. Berber museum was closed when we were there.

Wonderful gardens but get there early, hire a guide to get you in or expect a very long queue (2hrs). Hayfever sufferers be forewarned, even cactii and the other plants let off enough pollen to get the eyes streaming and itching. Such a cool, calm place even crowded with tourists. But awful to see the graffiti desecrating the aloes and bamboo.
You should go there if you wish to see some nice architecture, if you wish to rest and if you wish to escape from the busy streets of old medina.
Not as big as I was expecting,  but nice to get into the shade.  Get  there early as the Q extends the full length of the street

Jardin Majorelle is everything you’d expect it to be.  Beautiful and tranquil, even with the crowds of people lining up for their Instagram photos.  I believe it was about 100 dirhams (roughly $10) for tickets to the garden and the YSL museum.  Both are must see attractions in Marrakech and shouldn’t be missed.

Very nice place where you can learn a lot about Yves Saint Laurent. It is a relaxing place but you need to go at the opening time because we went around 10am and waited 1 hours queuing to buy tickets.

Would have enjoyed it more if weather was sunny, but worthwhile to see varieties of vegetation,  especially cactus of many types. Berber museum had little English, but lots of exhibits on folklore, costumes, jewelry, tools.
Was wonderful but very busy and alot of people...go early Buy tickets in advance otherwise you will stand a long time in the que

Walked here to find a very long queue outside that almost put us off. We persevered though and it was well worth it. We bought combined ticket (garden, Berber and YSL museums) for Dh180 (locals only pay 100) Beautiful gardens, well kept and numerous memorials to YSL. Best bit was the Berber Museum inside.  Some great attirants and history with well written English and French literature. Recommended. Tip: you can buy combined tickets with a shorter queue at the YSL museum.
review_title: Tranquil and Berber museum v good

review_text: Lovely, but small. Could walk through in less then an hour. Usually very busy, can be difficult to get a good picture.

The line that wraps around the block says it all. We arrived around 11am and it was as chaotic inside as the souks with people wandering in all directions. Modeling for selfies got to be a bit obnoxious especially when we tried to sit down on a bench that happened to be a prime backdrop for people wanting to take photos of themselves. The gardens and plants were interesting and several were in bloom. Real affectionados and naturalists will likely find it underwhelming especially for the price of admission.

Arrived at around 1030 to large queues down the street. Given it was our last day though we persevered and waited. The queues moved quickly and only took 20 minutes to get in. Upon entering the gardens it was like being transported to a different world. You leave behind the craziness of marrakech and enter peaceful gardens. There is plenty of lovely pictures to be taken of plant life and some fish/frogs, as well as some extremely colourful buildings painted in Marjorelle Blue. In my opinion definitely worth a visit.
review_title: Great morning exploring the tranquil gardens

review_text: A place what you have to visit. This garden is stunning! After a nice walk in the garden, you can have a lunch or a coffee in the restaurant. You will enjoy it :-)

My wife really wanted to visit the YSL gardens so naturally I took her. What a very pleasant and peaceful place it is to visit and so different to the mayhem of Marrakech. The museum is very interesting and houses a fine collection of Yves work over the years, he was a very talented man. One tip; go past the queue for the gardens and buy a ticket at the museum entrance, it's far quicker.

Friendly people and the gardens are excellent reasons to visit Marrakech. Majorelle is one of the best gardens and is close to most lodging. Buy advance tix to skip the line. Or, buy garden and museum tix at the Yves St Laurent much shorter ticket line. You will need to buy a combination ticket. We visited early on a weekday and the crowd size was manageable.
review_title: Friendly people and the gardens are excellent reasons to visit Marrakech

review_text: Lunch was delightful, despite being busy we soon enough found a table. The food was good and reasonably priced considering we were in a highly popular tourist attraction. The sandwiches and cakes looked delicious but sadly we didn't order them. Overall really nice and would recommend for a nice, clean, quality lunch.

The gardens were started in the 1920s and were once owned by Yves Saint-Laurent.  They have a variety of exotic plants, flowers and cacti.  Also in the gardens is the museum that is very well done.  We arrived when it opened and when we left the line to get in was blocks long.

I thought this was going to be just another garden.. you know... been there done that... THEN! you see the biggest cactuses you've ever seen. The layout if beautiful and breath taking.I absolutely commend them  on how they're done the layout and made it different to your average garden. Worth a look! and great for insta photos - if that's what you're into
A wonderful oasis of calm tranquility and beauty. Well worth a visit. Best to go at 10am as gets busy. A complete gem and lovely escape from the noise of the Medina.

Great experience and worth the time and queing, but far too much people to really take in. We arrived at 11'ish and found a 45min queue and almost as much people in there as you find in the souks on a sunday... One less item on my bucket list and despute the people very worth going there with a good camera.

Such a beautiful and serene garden, I can see why Yves Saint Laurent fell in love with it! Only negative - Far too busy and crowded...filled with people trying to take selfies at every chance they get! Definitely takes away from the magical experience!
review_title: Beautiful, serene and magical (just too crowded)

review_text: An unexpected oasis in this bustling city.  We visited in the morning and the gardens were not too busy.  They were immaculately tended and litter free.  Unfortunately the Berber museum was closed but the small cafe is cool and welcoming.

A bit overrated. Nice garden but such a long wait just to get in. If there was an option to purchase tickets online or get them early from hotel, that would have been so much better. Long wait in the sun was not that enjoyable. Garden itself is nice but too busy during the day. Would better visit it early to skip the crowds.
review_title: long waiting just for a garden

review_text: It was a beautiful garden, we got in with a tour guide, so we didn't have to queue. Not worth queueing for too king time. Pretty colours and flowers.

Visit early or late due to popularity it is very crowded.  The desert style garden with the Marjorelle blue house as a backdrop is visually appealing and with less people a pleasant space to sit and reflect. Musee Berber within garden worth visiting offering a visual sense of the Berber culture.
Was a lovely respite from the noise and bustle of the city!  We had a lovely light, but expensive, lunch in the cafe and very much enjoyed our walk around the garden.
It's a smallish/dull garden, which we paid 7 euros to enter. Not worth it in our opinion! Especially if you have to go out of your way to go there.

By far Majorelle Garden's was one of the best highlights of our trip to Marrakesh, you can easily get lost amongst the hustle and bustle of all the tourists, and end up in one of the gardens more quiet and serene areas. The restaurant inside is also pretty good, and worth a visit to cool down during the midday heat, or find yourself inside the museum. Top tip before you go... Make sure you buy your ticket from the YSL museum if the queue is smaller, you can queue jump.
review_title: Stunning and peaceful oasis in Marrakech

review_text: Very nice garden. Excekent cade bar with good simple, but interesting food. Maybe must wait for buy tickets, but it worth.

My partner step daughter and I visited Majorelle gardens in the early afternoon which was very busy. The gardens are beautiful, very photogenic and on a quiet visit would be an oasis of calm. Just a warning the surounding suburb to the attraction seemed to have an issue with quite aggressive beggars and hyped up tourist prices for taxis, caleche and tuc tucs.
review_title: An oasis in the middle of the city

review_text: A great garden. I love reading the history of this place. Within walking distance of the YSL museum and houses the Berber museum. Lots of great photos to take with friends and family here. Get here early it gets crowded after 12noon.
Amazing garden with a lot of different plant species. Beautiful plants, colours, pools with fishes and water plants make this garden an oasis of peace and beauty in noisy Marrakech.

This place was so boring.. all it is big plants around you. And 1-2 ponds on the ground. It’s like a green house full of plants and trees, if your into that then maybe this place is for you. I just found it soo boring. You walk around, it’s like a big forest basically. This garden has other small parks within itself which you have to PAY to enter. The ENTER FEE To come into majorelle was £10 which was quite expensive as we left within 5-10 minutes as it was the same thing over and over.
Beautiful garden with many kind of plants and small pools with colourful fish. Peaceful oasis, except for the crowds. Worth visiting, prepare to long ticket line.
review_title: Beautiful oasis in the middle of the city

review_text: The Jardin Majorelle is really nice to take some pictures, and to have something to drink or eat maybe. But it's rather small. And it's really really crowded. So if you would like to take some pictures without a ton of other tourists on it you shouldn't go at peak hours.

Lovely and peaceful gardens. I spent about 1 hour there, however do come early if you want to enjoy this. Can get full of Instagram youths so very crowded and busy. Many people there are not considerate of people wanting/taking photos. I think they should have a queuing system for taking a photo.
Beautiful garden but very busy unless you get there early! Full of instagrammers. If you are a fan of cactuses this s the place for you. the cafe is very good if a little pricey.

Huge thanks to the staff of  Maison ka Marrakech, as this the second time we stayed with them, this time we  booked the the Riad exclusive for hen party, the Riad is only 5 mins drive  from Majorelle Garden as you going to the Palemerie area, with very easy Taxi access to the front of the Riad,  Faysal the The Riad Manager advised us to go early to avoid the queues. Stunning array of plants & YSL memorabilia, very beatiful garden, we had a great time there before we headed to the Souks and Medina adventure. 4 things we would love to do again next visit: 1- stay at Maison ka to enjoy their stunning top roof pool and the amazing food 2- moring visit to Majerelle garden 3- visit the Souks 4- must book sahara trip with SaharaMoroccoTour, we used them before and we highly recommend them especially ask for Bader ( to be your driver)
review_title: Visit Majerelle garden is great way to start your day in Marrakesh

review_text: Beautiful, colorful, crowded by tourists! Impressed by all.the colors especially the majorelle blue! Entrance fee quite high for a stay less than 40 min. At extra charge you can visit yhe berber museum.
It was a long wait to get in as a lot a people waiting. Of course, we refused to pay tips to get in faster but the viewing was great and very clean . Ps: take water with you

We visited these gardens 15 years ago and they have grown into a gem in the desert. Well worth a visit and the entrance fee. A tip - by a joint ticket to the Yves Saint Laurent Museum next door first and avoid the queues to get into the gardens.
Loved visiting here!!! An absolute must see when visiting Marrakech- especially for photo opportunities!!!!
Lovely peaceful garden if arrive before the crowds. Well cared for and easy walking paths.  Best early morning or late afternoon

Not what I'd hoped for. Seems to be on most of 'the things to do' list in Marrakesh, but I came away feeling rather underwhelmed. It's was busy - should have gone earlier in the day - so walking around one was constantly having to stop for those taking photos. Like a garden, me, but not a great enthusiast of bamboo or cacti. Still, money goes to a good cause, I believe.

Stunning but it’s so busy, if you can prebook tickets & get there as it opens. Stunning array of plants & YSL memorabilia. Loved it but we were in & out in an hour having queued for our tickets for 20 minutes
review_title: Idyllic if only you could be alone

review_text: Endless lines to wait in to get in - hundreds of people everywhere making photos and posing- it was a zoo. The Mamounia resort gardens were quite spectacular which we visited afterwards, no lines and no entrance fee. It was ok...but not a must!

Its a nice garden and all, but so small! I think there are better gardens in Marrakech we went at 8.45 and around 9am got so crowded! Try to go as early as you can, but other than that its just a cute garden..
Blue and yellow flower pots and water features make this a lovely garden to visit.  Don't miss the section by YSL house. The museum also worth a visit
review_title: Wonderful gardens with vibrant accent colours.

review_text: Interesting place, nice plants but in Marrakech are according more interesting gardens. It is worth to book a ticket via the internet because the queue before the entrance is really big and you wast your time unnecessarily. Lots of tourists here!

I don’t get excited by garden visits and only went to this one as it was highly recommended as a ‘must do’. It did have some amazing cacti and a museum. It’s quite small and was too busy I felt I was constantly avoiding bumping in to people. The queue to buy a ticket was quite long too. We bought the ticket to include the YSL museum as we thought it was within th e garden and we ‘might as well’ this museum is just a little way down the road, if you are into fashion then you’d probably love this, I found it interesting but my husband couldn’t get out fast enough!

So we showed up at 11am and waited in line for about an hour to get into the garden. 10ft from the ticket counter we saw this sign (see photo). If you plan on going but want to skip the line I highly recommend reading the photo. The lines are much shorter but you’ll have to buy a combo ticket (about $2O bucks). You get full access and get to skip the garden line. Overall the garden is nice. It’s very crowded, sometimes makes it hard to take in the beauty with everyone trying to take a “glamorous selfie” at every turn. We spent about two hours there (including one hour for lunch).
I would recommend going here in the morning, it was a beautiful place. I was just disappointed the house was closed when we visited.
We had to queue to long in the hot sun.  The queue wasn´t moving at all...so we almost left...But as it turned out it was worth waiting for
A fabulous cool oasis filled with tropical plants and history. Worth a visit. Great photo opportunities and a nice cafe too.
review_title: A garden inspired and collected by YSL

review_text: Really beautiful botanical garden, definitely worth a visit. If you’re a avid plant lover then this place is definitely for you!

The gardens are compact, you don’t need much time there, but absolutely beautiful. The only downside is the number of people in a small place. I imagine planning a trip for the start or end of the day (I think last entry is 5.30pm but check first) might pay dividends.
These are worth seeing, but go EARLY. Long lines unless you are with a private guide. Spend about an hour there and dont miss the Berber Museum inside the gardens.
Lovely peaceful garden in a very busy city Sit or wander round in the wonderful surroundings Plenty of seats and toilets
very interesting garden easy walking as foot paths are level and what I though was red concrete very nice coffee shop with friendly waiters
A well-kept garden, fo relaxing walk...Colors and nature to spend some time away from the chaos of the city and above all the medina!

Great use of colour in the buildings and pots in the garden against a lush green backdrop of green cacti and other plants. Definitely go first thing in the morning - I got there by 10 and although it was a nice garden, it was not so enjoyable with the crowds and their cameras!!

If you need a break from the streets, do stop by here. However, it's crowded by tourists taking pictures. Still - the restaurant is amazing and there are some (few) places where you can chill out by yourself.
review_title: An oasis in the streets of Marrakech

review_text: Everyone had told us how wonderful these gardens are and something not to be missed. However, they are small, quite dark and overcrowded. The 45 min queue to get in was not a surprise (we had been warned), but was it worth it - I’m not sure it was. It’s not a peaceful place and many areas are overshadowed by tall dark bamboo and other heavy trees. It’s probably not worth the entrance fee either. If you want peace and quiet, in lovely gardens (quite different to Marjorelle), try The Secret Garden. Or, for free, spend some time in the lovely Cyber Parc.
review_title: Bit of a disappointment, not living up to expectations

review_text: Would not miss seeing this garden if you’re in Marrakesh. Fabulous gardens   This is Where Yves Saint Laurent is buried. Definitely a “Must”

Once you  pass into the gate you  feel  as though  you are sneaking into someones very special  secret place  where they  come  to  relax, reflect  and pause from life's hectic  pace. Make time for mint tea and a snack on the  terrace. Super cheap and nice food
Our guide too us for hald day to the Garden Majorelle we enjoyed it, but very crowded , i think because it was weekend!!!!
Stunning garden, lovely plants and all the birds! If you are lucky u will find a bench to sit and admire. Only but is the crowds.
visiting this spot gives a relaxation and a break from the red city , very calm place to be in , better to get a combined ticket from YSL museum so you won't need to queue

For my first three days in Marrakech in early March, it seemed like there were few tourists. But this place was very crowded with tourists. I'm sorry I didn't take the advice I read about going there first thing in the morning.

definitely worth a visit and probably best combined with the adjacent YSL museum Unless you are first thing in the morning,walk 100metres further up the road to the YSL museum and get your combined tickets there as it will save at least an hour of queuing.Add in the museum inside the gardens for an extra 10 dirham

We were told that there would be queues to get in so we expected the hour wait. The gardens are very pleasant & relaxing. It was lovely to wander around for a couple of hours without getting hassled. I thought it would have covered a larger area & thought there would be more benches to sit & relax. I think we stayed there for just under two hours so not that much to see after an hours wait to get in. The café/restaurant was busy & pricey compared to other  places. On the whole though we did enjoy our visit.
review_title: Nice gardens but not very big.

review_text: Beautifully laid out garden - tranquil, shady and a lovely oasis in the hustle & bustle of Marrakech.

If you visit Marrakech, you must visit the Jardin Majorelle.  An incredible place full of plant interest, beautifully laid out.  This was my second visit, and I would go again and again, its an absolute "must"!
A beautiful garden! So green and so fresh! So many colours! MAJORELE Garden touches your soul! You must visit it!

A trip to Marrakech would not be complete without visiting this truly beautiful garden. This place gets very busy, so I would recommend getting here early otherwise you can be queuing for hours to get in.  An alternative is to go to the YSL Museum first if you spot a large queue and get a combination ticket there which allows you to see the YSL Museum, the Gardens and the Berber museum in the gardens (180dh total).

If you want some beautiful vibrant photos this is the place to go.  It does get kind of crowded but we had no problem taking pictures.  It is kid friendly however it is not a place children will have much to do.
During weekends it’s crowdy but it’s gorgeous. Perfect for instagram pics due to the nice plants and colours.

After reading all the rave reviews, I was excited to visit this garden. It's nice enough, but not all that big and the crowds took away from my experience. Arrived around 10am and there was a line; it moved pretty quickly but of course the crowds don't disappear once you're inside. I think my money would have been better spent at Le Jardin Secret or another garden in the Medina. Majorelle is a nice enough garden, but for me it wasn't worth the cost and time to get there.
review_title: A Fine Way to Pass the Time

review_text: We had a great time walking around the garden and enjoying the scenery.  Pair it with the Berber Museum and YSL museum around the corner for a really nice morning or afternoon spot.

This is a beautiful, calming & tranquil place to visit, especially after the hustle & bustle of the Marrakesh souks - I'm not a gardener, but I found plenty of interest. We bought the all-inclusive tickets allowing entry into the gardens, the Berber Museum & the Yves St Lauren museum, all of which were well worth it Anyone visiting Marrakech & not going here would be missing a treat - the ride back to the centre by tuk-tuk was pretty exciting too!
We were in Morocco in the second week of March and we visited the Majorelle garden. We love it all the things inside are very nice.
Lovely calm oasis.  Immaculately kept, fascinating museum, garden and shop.  Cafe lovely - fabulous coffee.  No need to rush just soak it all up - amazing cactuses.

I arrived at 10am and queued for 15 mins to get in, and when I came out at 11.30 the queue was twice the size, therefore go as early as possible.  The gardens price is very reasonable and certainly worth it. I bought a joint ticket for the YLS museum too, but unless you're a fan of his I'd recommend the gardens only as much cheaper.  Gardens 5/5,  museum 3/5.
This is a must see in Marrakech. The park and its buildings are of extraordinary beauty. Wonderful balanced garden.

The Yves Saint Lauren gardens are wonderful. A well laid out set of spaces. The garden is shaded by large trees and ornamental bushes. The shop is lovely and the Cafe, although London prices, looks great. We'll worth a visit. There is a super Cafe /restaurant just outside which is very busy and appears to be popular.
I went there last January. Beautiful garden but very crowded. I found the museum very interesting and more peaceful

Go early.... So peaceful early, and no queue to get in..... Architectural garden rather than plant-garden. The cactus display is wonderful. The cafe is lovely too....just had a cup of tea and coffee, but the food looked good as well.
Truly beautiful garden and a must see in Marrakech! the garden was very well kept and the gift shop was beautiful.
I am a keen gardener and go to many gardens ,but this one was different with it`s cacti ,and tropical plants all laid out to perfection.

What an oasis in the middle of Marrakech Yes do go early-skip breakfast!! Yes do the Berber museum as well Centrally located between the Medina and Gueliz this will be just a walk from lots of accommodation around Marrakech Enjoyed the gardens and really enjoyed the Berber museum

Waited in line about 10 minutes to enter these astonishingly beautiful gardens.  Wide variety of cactus and plants from many continents along with pools and small fountains.  Beautiful colors of walls and pots.  Plenty of benches for just sitting and admiring this eden.  We had an enjoyable, reasonably priced lunch in the café which was not  too crowded.  Did not have to wait at all.  Thank you Yves St. Laurent  for saving this magnificent garden.  Highlight of trip to Marrakech.
The gardens were impressive,  fairly expensive to visit and you didn't need very long to walk around.  There was quite a long queue to get in.
Not a lot to see, mostly palms and some water, but fairly peaceful.Studio within garden relating to Yves St. Lauren and selling expensive gifts.
My first three days in Marrakech in early March, it seemed like there were few tourists. But this place was very crowded with tourists.
Very well maintained gardens, gets a bit crowded no matter what time of the day you go. Worth the time to see.

Don’t skip Majorelle when visiting Morocco, and be sure to buy the admission for all three parts: the garden, Yves-Saint-Laurent museum, and the Berber museum. The beauty of YSL’s designs, displayed in prototypes, reproductions, sketches, photos and video is as stunning as the garden grounds. The artistry of Berber culture is displayed through tools, crafts, clothing and jewelry. If you enjoy fashion even a little bit, it is interesting to see the impact of Marrakech on YSL’s work and the gift he and his partner gave to the city in restoring the property.

This is a very nice garden with a array of beautiful cactus and a lovely carp pond. We found 70dhm very expensive considering it was a 1/2 hour walk at most to get around. I would recommend going mid afternoon to avoid the big crowds. It's a nice little shady sanctuary from the heat too. Overall I would say it was worth a visit but I wouldn't consider it essential viewing if you have a tight budget
Well worth the visit if you have time, amazing gardens full of unusual and exotic plants, very good cafe.  Nice atmosphere here
review_title: Tranquil garden in a hectic City

review_text: lovely peaceful garden in the middle of the city , calm walking around the gardens which is beautiful

The gardens are a good way to escape the crowded Medina. They are filled with light, colors and include some nice morrocan architecture items. There can be quite a line to get tickets, but the waiting time is decent. At the ticket desk you can buy a combined ticket which includes the close by Museum Yves Saint Laurent.

This is a beautiful place of calm to visit in what can be a manic city. The gardens are set out well and easy to walk around. The cafe there is nicely sited with a spotless toilet and the prices for coffee and food very reasonable. The only downside is getting it. The queues can be long. We had to wait about 25 minutes in the sun. Definitely worth a visit if you have the time.

We went to visit the Jardin Majorelle very early on a Saturday morning and thank god because when we left around 11am the line to get in was really really long. You can spend hours just admiring the plans and flowers in this artful garden!

I cannot believe how bad the instagram girls are in Marrakech. They completely detracted from this beautiful garden for me. They are everywhere in the city but particularly bad in Majorelle Garden. Many of them even bring wardrobe changes and color coordinate to match the gold and "majorelle blue."
Beautiful plants with lots of different cactus. There is also a shop selling jewellery, leather handbags

Also known as Yves Saint Laurent garden, this small walled garden was once a private garden, the plants are beautiful with succulent and bamboo grove  and garden landscape is breathtaking with pond, pavilion bridge and sculpture.  Berber museum is in the garden which has an amazing collection of Berber Jewellery and costumes.   There's so much talks about the number of crowded visitors and sadly this is true.   We went there around 10 in the morning and it was slight crowded already.   Plan your visit to be very early in the morning to avoid group tours and booked ticket online as there's separate window for it and virtually there was no queue.
review_title: Small but beautiful, but do come early and pre book the tickets

review_text: Get there early as can be busy. Try and but a multiple ticket to the YSL museum as well.  Gardens well laid out with such a variety of plants
review_title: Beautiful gardens and is a must.

review_text: Get your ticket at the Yves saint Laurent museum 180Drh (18€) for the Jardin the YSL museum and the museum in the Jardin so you dont have to wait 45 minutes. There is a great cafe inside if you wanna rest with great deserts and espresso cofe

No idea why anyone would consider this on the must see or must do list for a short stay in Marrakech.  Relatively expensive and small without any peace and tranquility. The nearby Laurel Yves Saint Laurent museum is also disappointing. Very little information about the man’s history or his life.  Only a small number of his fashion works on display which are duplicated in the brief video. Overall I would not waste a half day visit on this combination in Marrakech and instead would recommend that you save your time and money and find a nice Riyadh or restaurant to relax in If you want to see real gardens try somewhere other than the city in the desert
review_title: Way over rated and too crowded

review_text: Beautiful do not miss if in Marrakech...Go early to avoid crowds and heat..loads of great photo opportunities

Jardin Majorelle is one of the most beautiful semi tropical gardens that you can visit. The loving detail of every plant, be it a bamboo or a cactus, can be observed first hand. Majorelle is an authentic jewel for those that love nature.

This garden is quite small and the pricing is irritating as you must pay the entrance fee to it in order to pass to the inside museums which charge their own entrance fee on top. Quite touristy and crowded, and it would have been nice to get some explanation signs for the plants it contains

A tip... do not wait in the very very long queue. Head straight to the YSL Museum (located on same street) & buy a combination ticket. This includes the Gardens, YSL museum & Berber museum. Once you have your ticket you can bypass the queue at the Gardens. If I had of waited the 1hr + to get in the Gardens I would have felt cheated as the Gardens were not what I had expected.

The garden is very nice, almost a sculpture park with ornamental plants. The berber-museum is well worth a visit. However, the garden is very crowded, even in the off-season and early morning (08:30). Not the peaceful experience you may expect from the brochure. Quite a rip-off.
Very nice garden. Many special plants, trees and so on. The buildings had very strong colors and looked great.
The place is crowded and although it's a nice desertical botanic garden, I'm not sure if it's worth the queue.

The garden alone is worth the visit -- a bit of an oasis in the midst of traffic mayhem and Marrakech's dusty streets. We were pleasantly surprised by the YSL museum -- neither of us (especially my husband) are into fashion -- the exhibition was excellent. Well worth a trek to the 'New City'.
review_title: Oasis from the hustle and bustle -

review_text: beautiful grounds, and some great photo spots. the colours are so vibrant! it was sad seeing all the graffiti on the cactuses.

Having queued for tickets for some while we were somewhat underwhelmed by the gardens. They aren't that big, the plants are predominantly cactuses and there are too many fellow visitors to savour the occasion. It's not helped either that you are forever stopping to allow Japanese ladies to take selfies or group photos often in a range of different poses! The Secret Gardens are far better and a lot more central.

Really ?   Half an hour wait in line and then pay 70 MAD to get in and battle with the crowds inside.  It’s not real big inside, we didn’t see any flowers, only bamboo, palm trees and a couple of lily ponds. The only interesting thing was the cactus garden. Expensive and disappointing for the effort.  If you really have to go, get there before it opens and be first in to get any solitude in there. Oh, don’t bother with the Berber Museum unless you speak French.  All the exhibits are explained in French and the lighting is poor.

Me and my friends really enjoyed our visit there. The only one unpleasant thing is that we waited hour to get the tickets. So be prepared for some waiting. We took the combined ticket for the gardens and the berber museum and is was worth it. The museum is small but interesting.
The garden and the coffee shop are very nice. When we were in the line to acquire the tickets was not nice for the woman at the ticket office and also for a guard taking care of the people waiting.
review_title: Small garden, but very nice and interesting.

review_text: Beautiful tranquil gardens if not too busy, but a little pricey at 70 dhm, as a visit only takes 30 minutes.
review_title: Very pretty but over priced for size

review_text: Most beautiful gardens. Get a combined ticket to take in the garden, the Berber museum and also the YSL museum. We were advised to get there by around 9 before it gets too busy, great advice as by the time we came out (early afternoon) the queues were quite long. Cafe was good and not too expensive, depending on your choice.
review_title: A great place to visit but take in YSL

review_text: Me and my wife took the day out and spend it here and wow ! What a beautiful amazing destination, for anyone who loves gardens like me, you will NOT be disappointed. We spend a good 2.5 hrs, the cactus field was a well set feature. Would do it again if we come back. 10:10
A little pricey, but very good and beautiful. Long queues but we got to skip it as large groups (Over 10 people) go in a separate queue which moves quicker.

Young painter Jacques Majorelle had TBC and other problems in breast. His father, rich man, bought for him one peace of land out of Marakech....he began to plant cactus...bamboo...in beggining of 20th century. Many years passed and this garden was bought by famous Yves Saint Laurent and his partner Pierre Berge..and they made fantastic home for them...blue, majorelle bleu, green and yellow are going through garden.. Before Yves died, unfortunately he knew...., he made special  donation and asked Pierre to open garden to public. This, you MUST visit!!
review_title: Majorelle garden is something so beautiful, that you forget breath...

review_text: This place is soo beautiful... definietly worth the small price of the ticket. The staff are helpful and friendly too. The coffee was very good. Pictures are amazing.
Nice to see where Yves Saint Laurent was living. The museum bit with the history and some of his iconic dresses is really worth seeing.
I had been before and had obviously forgotten the queues. They are BIG so go early or book as part of a tour.
A must visit and a beautiful oasis. Just try to ignore all if the photo shoots happening around you!

There were long queues to see the gardens with lots of hustle and bustle from the nearby road, but inside was tranquil despite all the visitors. Tall palm trees and bamboo mixed with huge cactus plants of all kinds, and water features, well laid out for wandering around and not as formal as I expected.
Lovely place so fresh garden and clean so busy but is very interesting and beautiful with different plante and colorfull so pretty Majorelle.

If you intend to visit both the YSL museum and the Majorelle garden, buy your entry ticket for both at the museum, that way you avoid the long line for the garden. The 1 euro entrance to the berber museum in the Majorelle gardens is worthwhile. The gardens are a well kept, original oasis just outside the medina. The berber expo in the house is small but interesting. We thoroughly enjoyed the day spent at the gardens and the YSL museum as well as the walk to it, via a non touristic souk in the north of the medina. The YSL museum serves an excellent and affordable lunch on a pleasant terrace. The visit to the garden and the berber expo lasts about an hour.
review_title: Pleasant escape from the hectic city

review_text: We loved it, take your time, meander about, take it all in. Wonderful colours and a real treat out of the hustle and bustle of Marrakech
review_title: Fabulous...an oasis of calm and beauty.

review_text: These gardens are reputed to be wonderful; we just don't know because a 20 minute rather dull walk through new city commercial streets brought us to the back of a vast queue, which didn't move for 20 minutes, so we gave up and left. Strongly advise you to book ahead and take a taxi straight there either early morning or late afternoon.

Majorelle Gardens are spectacular and colourful. They are beautifully laid out and very popular but you wouldn’t know how many people were in there. The queues move quickly. Berber museum is amazing - really recommend that - it’s in the grounds. YSL museum is just down the road and worth a visit small but has an amazing moving pictorial feature of his design sketches there is a selection of his outfits and accessories I felt the combined ticket for all 3 - gardens, Berber Museum and YSL museum well with it

We walked from the our hotel, quite a long walk with the usual life in your hands feeling when crossing roads.  Got there mid morning and there were two long queues, go earlier if you can.  We just paid for the gardens not the extra museum.  Enjoyed the visit, colourful and very different from any garden with the RHS!

If someone is fed up by Medina and wants to change environment shall visit Le Jardin Majorelle which are located in the new city. Recommendation, if someone is fan of fashion, next to the gardens there is Yves Saint Laurent's museum.
review_title: An oasis among the craziness of Marrakesh

review_text: We hopped in a taxi from Jemaa el-Fnaa after negotiating  a fare of 40 Dirhams with the driver which seems to be the going rate for tourists. As we approached the Garden, we saw a huge bunch of other tourists going back and forth to see the attraction. We encountered a big line and got our tickets after about 25 minutes. The wait was worth it. The garden is a quite and lovely place compared to the crowded and bustling city of Marrakesh. The garden is beautifully done and it was more of a relaxed environment that we were looking for. Spent around 2 hours taking pictures and seeing the various plants, trees, ponds etc. A part I did not like about this huge garden is there are only 2 toilets. SO expect a line for that too. I recommend this for an hour or 2 of relaxed time when in the city.

The Jardin was stunning, however we queued for over an hour to get in and it was so busy once we got in. Sadly we didn’t enjoy it as intended. Far too many “fashionistas” hogging every square foot for a million photographs. The Secret Jardin is equally as beautiful and is peaceful as it should have been.

Took a taxi from Jemaa el Fnaa as it's a bit too far from the medina to walk to.  Queued for about 30 minutes to get in. There was an option to visit the YSL museum and something else but we chose to do just the garden.  It really was something to behold.  The planting is amazing and the colours are stunning.  Although there were a lot of people there, with so much to see and so many different little areas we were able to take photographs without anyone being in them.  I would definitely recommend a visit.  All in all I would say allow a good hour and a half to take in the majesty of the place.

An absolute must and not to be missed. The queue was very long as we went on a Saturday morning, but if you head past the entrance to the YSL museum you can buy tickets for both attractions and skip the long queue. We were overwhelmed by the colours and plants and although the walkways are littered with people constantly taking selfies it is not to be missed. Expect it to be very busy but there are plenty of places to find peace and quiet as the gardens are extensive.
Beautifully kept and presented gardens, learnt so much about YSL , visiting Marrakesh this is a must . Had a lovely lunch in the cafe at the gardens.
review_title: Beautiful gardens and museum definitely worth visiting

review_text: We love these gardens but in the last couple of years it seems so does everyone else. It's so crowded! Best go late in the day as queues are crazy midday. Or go to the YSL musuem first which is wonderful and buy a ticket there for both places to avoid the queue for tickets at Majorelle. Lovely designer craft shops now opened around the area too, pricey but interesting to see beautiful stuff.

We were lucky to arrive early March before the big crowds flood the small garden. It is so beautiful when you can enjoy the many corners of the garden without your view being blocked or our photo being bombed. We had a great time strolling through the many pants and admiring the cactuses.

Ridiculously long line to get in so definitely go early. There's a student discount offered of 30 dirhams (70 dh original price). The garden is designed by Yves St Laurent so it's not exactly moroccan looking. You're lucky if you can get a single photo without instagram faux bloggers in the way posing. The place looks much better with all the filters people apply in their photos than it does in person. It was nice but I wouldn't want to pay the full price if I wasn't a student. I preferred Bahia Palace or just walking through the souks.
The park is beautiful well worth a visit. A nice break away from the hustle and bustle and the madness of marrakech.
Not very interesting. Just a garden with some cactusses. The Berber museum was very nice to see. However its not in English so didnt understand a lot. Would recommend.
10 euros in lovely place nice cafe at the end very strict staff your not allowed of the footpath or to touch the flowers or trees and in museum you can not take photos or you are asked to leave
review_title: Lovely gardens looks like the rain forest

review_text: The gardens are planted mostly with succulents, which are more suited to the desert climate in Marrakech. There are numerous paths to follow to view the flora and ponds, with benches to sit on and admire the beauty.  The Berber Museum featured exhibits on Berber history, customs and art, and provided much information and insight.  The only downside was that when we visited on a Friday morning the place was VERY crowded and it was hard to find a quiet place to contemplate everything I was seeing.

Nice gardens with some amazing cacti. Its a shame that some have graffiti on them. The gardens are smaller than what i thought. You can buy extra tickets for the two museums, so could spend more time there.
This garden is a must see for everyone who are visiting Marrakech. I would certainly reccomend to visit in the morning as it can be insanely busy.

Jardin is in the New town of Marrakesch and there is lot of tourist. It is better to have reservstion of ticket because we are waiting for a long time for ticket. There is a less siting places but garden is fantastic. Go!

We were a group of 12 and we all agree that the place is a extraordinary gardens to see regardless the country you are at... There are long  waiting lines  depending the season...(come early) Theres an extra ticket to  eve saint lorrain’s costumes show....not sure if it’s essential.... Warmly recommend
Although this place is beautiful - there are way too many people trying to get the perfect pictures - and they ruin it for people trying to actually enjoy the moment in real life!

This garden was an absolute joy. Full of cactus and palm trees and other interesting plants. It was a bit early in the year for us to see all the plants in bloom but we could see the architecture, both garden and building all the better. The bookshop had interesting and relevant books and the cafe was good and not overpriced. I loved all the colour.

Absolutely recommend this. It is a beautiful garden lots of plants trees blossoms etc. Fountains lakes wish fish It has a cafe and a memorial to Yve St Laurent and also an YSL shop. There is a petit museum with the larger museum next door.  It is one of the top attractions to see.

It was lovely to walk about and think this was in a big city but when promised exotic plants I expected more than just cactus and aloe I was hoping for orchids, lilies some great smelling flowers so to me it was disappointing, I liked the fish ponds
review_title: This is basically a well kept cactus and aloe garden

review_text: We visited around 4pm in the afternoon. To say it was crowded would be an understatement. It was packed! Highly unique experience but beware if the crowds.

Certainly worth a trip to the garden, it was my favourite thing I did while in the city. It is so ornately designed and well kept. Bit of a long line at mid day on a Saturday so I’d recommend to go early or late in the day.

I was wowed when I entered. Also loved the shops inside (quite expensive but beautiful items). Tip: visit YSL museum next door on the same day and buy the entrance together do you don't have to queue twice
On my list of things to see and do in Marrakech - not disappointed. Absolutely beautiful. You do need to look when you go as it can have queues to get in.
Was nice to walk around. but if you wanna get a few pics, you wont be alone on the picture, its a real tourist trap. But def worth it.

We were recommended to visit this garden and it really is something different. If you are interested in cacti then it will be extra special. It was a bit early for some of the other plants but the Majorelle blue buildings and decor were impressive. We had to queue for quite a while to get in and it was quite busy going around. A victim of their own success. The Berber museum was interesting and we also visited the Yves Saint Laurent museum which was good. Worth going to but get there early!
review_title: A very different garden to visit.

review_text: I am so glad we got to experience this beautiful place while in Marrakech. A stunning creation that reflects the beauty of paradise in this life on earth. I highly recommend you take your time to fully immerse yourself. Be sure to read the signs along the way!

We were sceptical about a visit here as it was a little difficult for us to find from where we were staying. So glad we made the trip. Stunning garden!! A bit crowded and irritating with all the instagram influencers lining up to pose... but you get that most places these days.

Beautiful garderns. Just be sure to get here early if you don't want to wait in a long line or have tons of people in your pictures. Please check out our Instagram Account for travel pictures and videos: IG Handle: @ThatCoupleWhoTravels

Went there in February 2019 (low season). Tourist QUEUE was so long that I refused to wait, and missed the opportunity to visit. People near entrance door told me they had been waiting more than one hour. Did not go back. I am sure there are many other interesting things to do in Marrakech with less wait.
I liked it very much. Would go back to visit it again. Ives Saint Laurent did a good job here. The garden is spectacular.

This is a very beautiful garden well worth visiting but get there very early. It opens at 08:00am and we arrived at 09:00am to find there were not too many people around. We covered the gardens within an hour and then sat down to enjoy the tranquillity but by this time it was starting to get very busy so instead we enjoyed ourselves people watching from a bench watching all the selfies being taken!😀

We enjoyed these gardens, which were very pleasant to wander around always with the blue colour they are famous for.  We did not visit any of the other museums that are on offer there so cannot comment, but we enjoyed the Gardens.  The only thing we did not enjoy was the one hour queue to get in.  Hence the warning to pre-book your ticket if possible.We believe the main attraction for many people to this garden is the name of Yves St. Laurent being attached to it, but it is a well laid our garden and very pleasant to wander around in the heat of the day, with a pleasant cafe to take a break in.  We got a taxi from the square.  One way we paid 50 dirhams, but the driver for the return journey accepted 40 dirham without murmer!!

My husband and I came to Marrakech for our honeymoon... jardín majorelle was amazing! Lovely place! Recommended to come any day except Thursday, as Yves Saint Laurent museum is closed on Thursday and is next to it.

We went here with our 1 year old.  We got taken to the top of the queue thanks to our mini human, which was great considering the line was long!  Inside it was busy but we enjoyed strolling around taking in the beautiful surroundings.  We gave the museum a miss but headed for the cafe for a cup of coffee. The baby needed his nappy changed and it would appear there was only one toilet and a lot of full bladders so we had to wait in line about 10 minutes. Over all a lovely morning.

Amazing cacti with lots of Mediterranean blues around be prepared to queue to get in although you can pre book a ticket 70 dirhams for the garden and 30 for the Berber museum. It was very crowded when I was there which made it difficult to take a good picture without people in it. But still worth the visit.r
Worth seeing but don’t be expecting much. Large que to gain entrance, very busy and little in to do. Suppose it is worth making a trip if you are in Marrakech but don’t put it high on your list

Very nice collection of plants and good place. I have not given 5 stars as I got the combo ticket for Berber museum and thought that was tiny - I am not museum lovers anyway. But I would definitely recommend this place.
Beautiful gardens but full of tourists looking to have Instagram photoshoots, hard to walk around the grounds as you are constantly stopping to let people get a pic
Definitely good place to relax and perfect escape from hectic medina. Can be busy sometimes, long queues, online prebookings available.
review_title: Refreshing and quite place to relax.

review_text: All what you need to know before visitinf this garden is the rush hour. Avoid the peak time from 11:00 am to 14:00 to avoid long queue to pay for the ticket. The best time either afternoon or in the early morning.

Amazing garden, ticket is about 6 euro for garden entrance, dont be late or you will stuck into a long queue. Bellissimi, avviarsi presto per evitare code, il biglietto circa 6 euro a testa per il solo ingresso giardino
Amazing collections of cactuses,  flowering plants, fruit trees and bamboos. Though this garden isn't very large, it's comfortable walking across the garden while appreciating the beautiful plants.

Lovely tranquil garden in spite of large amount of tourists. Perhaps March is not the ideal time to visit if you would like to see colourful cacti in bloom. Don’t forget the second citrus garden which is not shown on their map.
It is really worth a visit. Take some time because it can be busy, especially during the afternoon. The colours are amazing

This garden and the barbary style building inside have been designed by Jacques Majorelle and when the owner has decided to sell this place as a hotel, Yves Saint Laurent has bought and rescued it to be a hotel. Now, there is a museum inside the building and the exotic garden is really worth a visit.

Located outside Medina. Majorelle is one of the most beautiful gardens I have seen in my life. No wonder many people visit this place. If you like good photos. Check it out in its early opening hours.

The famous blue is everywhere but don't let it blind you to the exceptional collection of plants here.The sentinel cactii are worth the visit by themselves and there's a comfortable restuarant. It gets very busy.
review_title: Concentrated essence of Yves St Laurent

review_text: Visiting in early March the real flowering season really has not started but still very beautiful inside. The garden has a cafe with very rude people. Cafe closes earlier than the garden. We arrived 2 minutes to late and was rudely refused anything to eat or drink from the staff.
review_title: Skip museum and concentrate on garden

review_text: Should visit this garden and the Berbere museum. Both wery well taken care and beasutiful . The Ives St Laurent museum is next door as well .

We visited the gardens in the worst possible day, as it was raining and cold, but the gardens are very lovely and the house is the masterpiece right in the centre. The bright blue gives this edgy and warm feel. Worth visiting.
review_title: Lovely garden in a cold day

review_text: These gardens are superb. An interesting mix of plants/cacti/trees. We arrived mid morning and the queues were massive. So we decided to go to the YSL museum first, and got tickets for the garden at the same time. This meant we could walk through the gardens without having to wait in the queue. ( A good tip given to us by our host). In January, the gardens are not too crowded, (despite the queues) so we were able to take our time walking through and taking photographs. Good inspiration for our own gardens, and the blue pots and buildings are really striking against the backdrop of the wonderful array of plants.
Amazing place! Beautiful! Cafe a bit of a rip off and poor service but the gardens are wonderful! -tip tip: GO EARLY! or prebook!

A beautiful garden outside the Medina, worth seeing only for the beautiful and striking Majorelle blue building. A good collection of cacti too. It is very important to go as early as possible - we arrived at 9am and it was already getting too busy.

The gardens are tiny, you could walk around in 5 or 10 mins if you really wanted but they are really nice. There are benches around the place to sit and relax in the cool shade of the bamboo plants. Entry price is 70 dirham which was a bit expensive for what you get compared to the other attractions in marrakech for the same price.

Beautiful garden, and interesting Berber museum. Not much on the "Yves Saint Laurent" side however so don't get your hopes high. Lovely walking there when it's hot outside. Busy though and book in advance if you can to prevent queuing for too long.

You need a sunny day to appreciate the colours...but also means the long queues outside can be unpleasant. Somewhat oddly, the security guards would pull people out of the queue with no explanation. But as we found out, nothing sinister but to let us bypass the queue and go in through a different gate. I suppose then the queuing tip would be to look hot! Inside is relatively small - it is after all a house in town  - but well maintained. There are some wonderful photo opps if you can snatch a shot between everyone else doing it as well.

We visited the gardens and admired the beautiful house. One cannot go in, but wandering through the shady gardens is wonderful. Exotic plants and winding paths, lead you to ponds and waterways. It can be crowded but worth it.

I attended at the gardens about 11am. There was a large queue which seemed to take an age to go down. My wife wanted to see the gardens so I went along. As the sun was roasting my patience was slowly disappearing. Eventually we gained entry, 100 MAD for the gardens and Berber museum. They are nice gardens. They are peaceful. They are gardens. The place was mobbed though. The museum was interesting, though mainly in French.  English info cards are available if you seek them out. It was a pleasant morning and lead up to lunch. I guess I am just not that into gardens.

Kind of ruined by too many visitors - a few years ago there was NO ONE there.  But it has grown - there is much more to see and the plants are interesting, the Berber museum is a little gem, and the Saint Laurent Museum up the street is nice - though the lighting is weird.
Beautiful cactus gardens that are a bit unusual, but certainly worth a visit. The museum located on the same property is very interesting with many aspects of Berber life.
review_title: Pretty but VERY crowded in nice weather

review_text: A nice garden with a calm and enjoyable atmosphere. A little bit crowded and expensive entrance fee (70 MAD).

The garden is beyond praise, but a little warning and a tip might be in place. We visited the place twice and the second time we went at 8 in the morning. That action payed of. We were the first to walk the paths and see the house in breaking daylight. No selfie making, forever taking photo sessions and dozens of people through which the beauty of the house was still visible but not enjoyable... So folks, go early, take breakfast later and do the unforgettable YSL-museum afterwards.

The gardens were lovely and cool. I can see why people talk a lot about this destination. The only issue was the long line at the unreserved ticket line and an inability to find ticket information on the garden website. The trick is to buy tickets at the YSL museum around the corner. There were some nice cafes in the area for those who also need thinking time. We spent about 90mins here and enjoyed the experience immensely as well as taking some nice ideas home for our garden!

Gorgeous gardens in the ‘new town’ area of Marrakech. Wonderful palm trees, cacti and succulents, artfully arranged around patios and pools, with the typical majorelle blue pots contrasting with the greens of the plants and trees and the blue sky. Well worth a visit, even with a long queue at the entrance.

The gardens are magnificent. The beautiful bamboo canopy upon entrance and the various varieties of cacti making this a gorgeous setting.The Berber Museum with ancient jewelry and clothing  are not to be missed.The colors of the buildings are just what you would expect in Marrakech vibrant and alive.
A lovely garden with true Moroccan colours. Yes it is busy, but you can still see everything and appreciate the garden designs and plants.
review_title: Lovely garden in true Moroccan colours

review_text: Is it beautiful? Of course. Is it 7€ beautiful? Not really. Strolling thru this garden takes about 20 minutes, absolutely not worth the entrance fee.

Even though it is a short visit that can be done in half an hour or less, I still recommend to visit this attraction as it is without hesitation a very beautiful garden in the heart of Marrakesh and the perfect pair to see right after visiting the Yves Saint Lauren museum (just oposite to it). You will certainly be amazed by the variety of plants brought from all over the world and the size of these ones as they’ve been building this garden for at least 40 years.
Beautiful Gardens, Berber Museum, Cafe and YSL shop. Totally worth walking to and enjoying all of the rare plants and colors of the gardens.
A must to see for your trip to Marrakech. The gardens are beautiful and the Yve-Saint Laurent house is there

This is certainly a lovely place to visit. The line was rather long and the place was bustling. I admired how many people had coordinated their outfits in advance to take pictures against the bold colors of the house/gardens. We enjoyed our visit but it was relatively underwhelming and felt like a place to grab some neat pictures and then move on from quickly. I noticed that most of the plants are transplants from around the world.
Go early to avoid crowds and get great photos. Ask at your hotel if they can provide tickets. Visit the Berber Museum and YSL Museum, both excellent.

There are the most interesting cacti I have ever seen. The use of a vibrant blue paint against the green of the foliage is dramatic. Yves St Laurent is buried in the Garden. A really restful and lovely place to visit
review_title: Beautiful garden and well worth a visit.

review_text: We visited the Jardin and the museums (Berber and YSL, combined ticket). It is a beautifully planted garden with some impressive trees, succulents and an unexpected bamboo trove. However, we found it hard to appreciate it as there were so many people there - a few of whom happily etching their names on the bamboo and cacti, which was shocking. It’s a paradox of modern tourism, the best spots are too busy to enjoy...If you’re looking for a leisurely stroll in a garden, I would recommend the (incongruously named) Cyber park.

The Garden is beautiful, quiet, and relaxing way to spend a couple of hours away from the hustle bustle of the city. There were a lot os people because it is compact but we enjoyed the visit. The museum in the garden was small but cute.

These gardens are definitely a must when visiting the city. They are just magical. Take no notice of the many guide books that tell you one tour group will fill the place - they are much larger than you think. We visited at 10.00 and had many opportunities to take photos 'people free'.
A must see in Marrakech, try to go there early before 10 am as it gets very busy and it's hard to click photos.

The garden is very nice, but it is crowded with people and therefore it lacks the tranquility it should have. I am not the typical tourist who enjoys this crowded places. I only visited because I went to the YSL Museum.

We went here in February the gardens were lovely to stroll around. Be warned there are very long queues, best to prebook online to reduce queuing times. Another option is to buy a combined ticket with the Yves Saint Laurent museum next door as their queue was considerably shorter!

Not only that exclusive tone of blue, but also the red of the floor, the beige of some walls, and the green and yellow of the plants make this place unique! Besides the stunning gardens, there is also a Berber museum inside the place. I didn't really feel like visiting the latest, since I had spent some quality time with real Berber people, but it might be interesting. It also has a different price, not included in the price of the main ticket. Crowded place, make sure to arrive early, as queues are way too long, and it could take you over 1 hour to get in.
Everything especially the Barber museum was great! I loved it! The YSL museum was also very nice. Also there is a  oil store where you can buy YSL posters and cards.

The gardens make for a nice visit if you are looking to escape the desert environment and see some more greenery but it is overall rather underwhelming. The art gallery is a tiny room in the back corner near a cafe. The walk itself is very short and it seemed to be over in under 10 minutes. However, it was a reasonably pleasant walk and it was nice to escape the crowded town.
Beautiful picturesque gardens, but could open some more payment possibilities and information points
Americans will probably find the garden nice, but not exceptional.  It's worth about 30 minutes of exploration.  The Berber Museum within the garden was very interesting and worth seeing.
This is a delightful piece of heaven. The plants were beautiful and very diverse. Quite interesting.

The garden was packed with tourists while I was there and it was still an excellent place to get photos. The vegetation and the color of the foundations and surrounding infrastructure provide great backgrounds for photographs. I’m sure social media is loaded with pictures from this garden. I would suggest going early to beat the crowds. I went midday and had to wait in a rather lengthy line. Enjoy!

We visited the gardens via the Yves St Laurent museum. This meant we had a much shorter queue to enter with a combined ticket bought at the adjacent museum. At midday the queue to enter the gardens directly seemed very long indeed. The gardens are pleasant and cool, although they are so popular it’s quite difficult to find a quiet area to take a seat to enjoy the space. We visited in the middle of the day so I would recommend visitors to time their entry for either earlier in the morning or towards the end of the day for more peaceful experience.
review_title: Pleasant couple of hours, but busy

review_text: Beautiful garden with trees and cacti from all over the world in a peaceful small setting. I wanted out pretty quickly because of the 200 people taking staged pictures of themselves. Influencers...ugh...

I have been entranced by these gardens for 15 years. This most recent visit was a bit of a shock. My views might annoy the locals, but I think the enthusiasm for maximum greenery has overwhelmed the structural/ sculptural elements of the garden. It is too lush now, so you don't see the extraordinary outlines of the desert plants as you did some ten years ago. I've no complaints about the huge bamboos as you enter. They're a welcome shift from the intense sun outside. But I deplore the pitch for general greenery of no particular merit as you go round. There are too many people in this space - inevitable at such an iconic destination - but it still moves me. Just, I'd like the gardeners to be directed by someone who values the lines of the plants, as against their burgeoning greenness.

First of all we waited one hour in the line for the tickets to find out the 2 museums were closed as it was a Wednesday. That beeing said the garden is nice but dies not worth it the waiting time without the museums.
An oasis of quiet in a bustling city, spent several hours there, just chilling out after a month of radiotherapy
Fantastic gardens for the opening party of the 1.54 Africa art fair enjoyed the cocktails and meeting artists people whom had travelled to be at the event.
Well worth a visit after going to the YSL museum. Lotsa great photo ops. Beautiful garden any time of the day.

I loved the colours of this place the most! There are lots of different types of plants I havent even seen before in my life! It was very crowded but it was fine because we got to see the whole place. It wasn't the highlight of my trip but it was alright, I wouldn't visit it again. Its a must see if you enjoy nature, if you dont then its not one for you.

It’s a cool garden and very unique. It’s overpriced but bring your student ID and you will get a much cheaper rate. The tour is very short and something easy to do. I would go back to show a loved one or friend. It was very crowded and the tourist were like ants on a pancake.

The garden and accompaning Berber museum is a nice stop if in the area.  The visit will not take more than an hour and the change in climate and vegetation is astounding.  The YSL monument is not very exciting, but seeing bamboo this tall in the desert is.
review_title: A very nice garden to escape the heat and dust of the city

review_text: The colours are amazing and the architecture is really unique. The elements of green and water inside the gardens give a truly unique atmosphere. Inside the fountains, you can find turtles and fish.
review_title: one of the most outstanding places to visit in Marrakech

review_text: Very nice stop on our trip visiting Morocco, in the French side of town, with all sorts of types of plants.  Enjoyed getting away from the bustling town.

We visit the Garden short after noon time. It’s crowdy and you have to wait min 30-45 minutes. Inside it is beautiful . The Problem is there are so many people so it’s not possible to take a single picture. But the mix of blue colors and green from all these different plants and houses are impressing. Definitely you have to visit this place but may at different day time. Greatz. SFI

just a nice tropical garden with a nice villa of the 30s.....where the only touch of local culture were the pottery painted vases and a long water fountain.....a very ‘colonialist’ place...the ‘arabic’ gardens are not ‘botanical’ gardens...very disappointing, expecially for the long line of tourists for the tickets ( but if you go 20 meters on,at the museum entrance,you find a much shorten line and you can do the same combo ticket)...what is very interesting is the small berber museum located into the villa...beautiful jewelry)...the Saint Lauren museum is disappointing too...quite every piece looks very cheap for fabrics and craftship.....much better in the photographs...

The garden is tiny, crowded with tourists, who want to take photos and selfies.Not quiete at all. The plants are more or less bambus, nothing else, wirh the concrete pathways, it looks totally artificial. The entrance fee  ( 70 Drh) is not at all worth going there. All the other gardens in Marrakesh are better. Beautiful free garden are Cyber Park Garden and Jardin du Hartsi. If you want to pay an entrance fee, the anima garden of Andre Heller with free shuttle bus is a good choice.

I really enjoyed my visit there! One of my favourite places in Marrakech. The plants, the ponds, the colours! Tranquillity, beauty. A gem! Unfortunately I didn't have time to visit the berber museum,but I went to YSL museum 🙂

Spent 3 hours walking and just sitting enjoying the vistas and plants in this garden, this after only queuing for 15 mins after arriving just after lunch. Very relaxing time and surprised at the beauty and colour in this garden. Never thought cacti could be so interesting to look at!!!

These beautiful gardens were a great place for an afternoon stroll. The colours and landscaping were amazing. The Berber museum was quite small and there was no signage in English, but it is nice to see some artefacts that haven’t been stolen by old colonial powers. If you enjoy a photobomb you’re in luck as there are a lot of people having their own private photo shoots.

When you walk in, there’s a gorgeous pond and a backdrop of extremely tall bamboo which is a picture in itself!  There is a windy paved pathway throughout the two acres of gardens.  Virtually all of the vegetation is cacti, so, if you enjoy cacti, you’ll be in heaven.  There is a blue house which is someting special to see as well as several other elements of beauty.  There is a cafe which is so very beautiful and the menu looked great!  We got there just after 9:00 and we completed our visit by 10:00 at which time, it was getting busy.  They open at 8:00 and I suggest that you get there by 9:00, especially if you want to visit the two museums and/or have lunch in the cafe. There are some really nice shops across the street,
Very underwhelmed with this place, just a few cactus and palm trees... better things to do in Marrakesh

We arrived shortly after opening and there was already a large queue. We were stood in it for around 30 minutes. If you want to avoid queuing I would suggest pre buying your tickets. The queue for pre booked is a lot shorter. The gardens are very pretty and there are both shaded places and sunny places to sit and enjoy the gardens. People say they are expensive to enter but it is only 70 MAD per person. This seems reasonable to me. It’s a nice change of pace from the hustle and bustle.
Nice garden, very well kept, but extremely crowded which takes a bit of the serenity out of it all... but your ticket for both garden and museum (ysl) early in the morning when there are no lines.

Lovely walk through the gardens opening up to the gorgeous Majorelle blue house. We opted for the combined ticket to visit the Berber museum which was worth it. Had a lovely tea in the cafe afterwards.
review_title: After Frida Kahlo's Casa Azul, this is my other favourite blue house!

review_text: This a lovely oasis in Marrakesh. It would be best to go at opening time. It gets so crowded and long lines to get in.  Entrance is the standard fee of seventy Dirham.  It is worth the visit but passes about an hour not more.

The cue is very long. Perhaps 1 hour waiting time. Sometimes the cue for the Yves Saint Laurent Museum is shorter. At the Jardin Maiorelle you can get the entrance ticket for 70 Dirahm approximately 7 Euro. At the museum you can‘t get the entrance ticket only for the Jardin but a combi ticket where the Jardin is included for 180 Dirham = approximately 18 Euro  (including Berber Museum). Alternativ also only Museum (100 Dirham) and Jardin (70 Dirham) together. Be aware that is every day quite full and the relaxing factor is limited. Also the prices for the Drinks and Foods are somehow very high for Morocco. We were enjoying the opportunity but would had done the visit knowing what we we know now
review_title: Nice but expensive and long cue

review_text: One of the most beautiful gardens! Would visit again! We had absolutely lovely time. We arrived around 10 and waited max 10 min in the line to buy tickets. Price was 70 MAD. Worth it!
Lovely Garden in the midst os a bustling town, do visit. The water features are so beautiful, just a calming place!
We visited on a glorious day. The kids loved the fish, terrapins and inventing personalities for the cacti. We loved the calmness, although busy, and beautiful colours.

Buy a combo ticket and spend half a day and see Jardin Majorelle, the Berber Museum, Yves Saint Laurent museum and eat lunch here at the same time. The park is a cool and relaxing place with good facilities and a nice café. Can be crowded though so arrive before eleven to avoid lenghty queus and too much people. Don't miss the museums!
review_title: Pleasant cool park with an educational museum

review_text: The garden of YSL is beautifully made but with regard to the price smaller than expected. You definitely pay for the “insta photo” but the crowd makes it hard to take nice pictures. The museum was also quite nice but a little pricey as well compared to the size of it. Yet not minding the price and waiting queue the visit is nice and worth it.
review_title: Beautiful but small garden for a high price

review_text: Not particularly extensive, not well laid out, but fascinating range of cacti. Berber Museum in the grounds is well worth visiting.
review_title: Great Berber Museum and fab cacti

review_text: Get a “Combination” ticket for 180 DH which gives you access to YSL Museum + Berber Museum + Gardens. You’ll skip the line to gardens (which TRUST me) is long!

A small but very beautiful garden but if you want to have a good time then go as early as possible (they open at 8:30 am). We went there one day at noon and there was a long queue outside for tickets so we went back and went the next day at 9:30 am. There were still quite some people inside but still acceptable. Otherwise a must visit, colorful place.
I love all the colors and the authenticity.  Go early in the morning before it gets too crowded.  Loved shopping at their gift shop.  Pricy but unique and high quality.

I took the trip advisor community at their word and we arrived before 11am, it was quieter and cooler than when we left at about 12.30! We just bought the single ticket 100 Dirham each. The gardens are very tranquil, lots of staff there keeping an eye on visitors. We got a taxi so we didn’t get lost, it is tucked down a side road in the new town. We had a coffee in the small cafe which was very pleasant. A visit is a must!

A very enjoyable visit. Go early to miss the crowds, or go any day other than Wednesdays to buy an all inclusive pass from the Yves San Laurent museum next door and then skip the queue to the gardens.
A must visit when in Marrakech. Peaceful and truly beautiful and unique design of garden and plants. I wish I had the time for a second visit on the same trip.
As above. It's nice in there, but it's quite small and busy. A little expensive for what it is really, but at least profits go to local causes (apparently).
We went because it was on the list, but would choose to do something else if I returned to Marrakech. Unless you have a green thumb its just cactus and palm trees. Not much color or flower varieties.
crowded, but even so wonderfull place. Very friendly staff, get families with children out of the long queue.
We walked here from the main square - a fascinating journey - but were disappointed. The gardens aren't very large, they were crowded on a mid February afternoon and were underwhelming.
The ticket is a bit expensive, but since it hardly rains I can imagine why. It is a beautiful garden worth a visit.
Oh my the gardens are so very pretty. The blue building, the blue sky... just stunning. It is of course very touristy but still a must-see when in Marrakesh.
Very nice garden with a variety of plants .. Also, the people working there are very friendly. Go early morning to avoid the crowds of tourists.
Many people on my tour had a specific desire to see these gardens. The gardens were lovely but after touring sites in Fez, Meknes I was somewhat disappointed!

Small but very nice museum of Moroccan ethnic clothing, decorative personal and home items. Well designed layout. For English speakers/readers, make sure to pick up the translation cards for item identification available at the entrances to the rooms. The gardens are lovely. Specimens well identified. Make sure to check out all paths - garden is much larger than it appears but possible to visit both museum and garden in 2-3 hours. Yves Saint Laurent memorial is simple, calm, quiet and appropriate.
Nice place to see if you are in the city. The entrance fee is 70 DH/ person. Flowrs and much more to See.
Very nicely kept gardens. But : quite small, very busy, and expensive. I enjoyed the walk back to El fna more than the gardens 😉
review_title: Number one on TripAdvisor rose my expectations too much

review_text: I went here in februari during a very sunny week and was amazed at the large size of the gardens. It is a wonderfull place to stroll around for 2-3 hours and can be combined with the berber museum. Ben aware of the long queues in the weekends.
Beautiful place. We were standing in the queue for a ticket for 1 hour... But still it was worth it.
